site_title: UK cosmetics group Lush relocates staff to Germany post-Brexit
summary: UK cosmetics group Lush is relocating European staff from Britain to Germany due to uncertainty caused by the Brexit vote. The company has accelerated plans to increase production at its German factory in Duesseldorf, aiming to protect its production, sales, and multinational workforce. Nine staff members have already moved from Britain, with more expected to relocate in the coming days. Lush's factory in Poole, where the company was founded, voted 58% in favour of leaving the European Union.

images.alt_text: UK cosmetics maker and retailer Lush is relocating European staff from Britain to Germany and has expanded production at its German factory in the wake of Britain's vote to leave the European Union, it said on Wednesday.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei edges up to 3-month closing high
summary: Japanese stocks reached a three-month closing high, with the Nikkei gaining 0.2% to 16,926.84, while the Topix and JPX-Nikkei Index 400 also advanced 0.6%. The gains were driven by banks, offsetting losses in mining shares. Investors await US jobs data, which may signal an interest rate hike.

site_title: WeChat chats fuel China money exodus into Hong Kong policies
summary: WeChat chats are fueling a money exodus from China into Hong Kong insurance policies, with sales to mainland Chinese visitors more than doubling in the second quarter to HK$16.9 billion. Mainland regulators have imposed restrictions, including investigating sales of overseas policies and requiring buyers to sign acknowledgments of risks, but agents have found ways to circumvent these rules through social media and one-on-one meetings. As a result, insurance sales have surged to record levels, with Prudential and AIA Group reporting significant boosts in sales, and demand for policies combining life insurance and investment components remains high.

site_title: Chinese banks' shadow loans grow despite regulatory pressure
summary: Chinese banks' shadow loans have surged in the first half, despite regulatory pressure, with receivables increasing by 14% to 1.27 trillion yuan. Mid-tier banks, such as Shanghai Pudong Development Bank and Industrial Bank Co, have significantly expanded their shadow loan portfolios, raising concerns about financial stability. The China Banking Regulatory Commission's efforts to curb shadow lending have yet to yield results, with some analysts predicting further growth in the second half.

site_title: China's top planning agency vows to streamline investment approvals
summary: China's top planning agency, the National Development and Reform Commission (NDRC), vows to streamline investment approvals to bolster the economy. The agency plans to cut the list of sectors requiring approvals by 50% and retain approvals for cross-border and electric vehicle projects. This move aims to reduce red tape and simplify procedures for new projects and companies, following Premier Li Keqiang's efforts to curb corruption and promote growth.

site_title: Ex-Air China worker charged by US for smuggling for Chinese military
summary: A former Air China employee, Ying Lin, has been indicted by US prosecutors for smuggling packages on flights from New York to China on behalf of Chinese military personnel. Lin, 46, allegedly received benefits, including discounted liquor and tax-exempt purchases, for her role in smuggling packages. She is also accused of obstructing justice by instructing a Chinese national to flee the country. The indictment follows a previous arrest and charge in 2015 for structuring bank deposits to evade reporting requirements.

site_title: Inaugural commercial flight from US lands in Cuba
summary: The first regular commercial flight from the US to Cuba in over 50 years landed in Santa Clara, Cuba, on August 31, 2016. The flight, operated by JetBlue, marked a significant step in the US and Cuba's efforts to boost ties. The flight was greeted with a water cannon salute and symbolically exchanged US and Cuban flags. The move is part of a thaw in relations between the two countries, with regular air service expected to increase to 110 daily trips connecting US cities to Cuban airports.

site_title: Singapore to launch corporate digital identity CorpPass on Sept 15
summary: Singapore will launch its corporate digital identity, CorpPass, on September 15, 2016. CorpPass will replace multiple digital identities used by businesses to transact with government agencies online. It will be a one-stop portal for businesses to grant and manage employee access to government services. Initially, services from agencies such as the Intellectual Property Office and Ministry of Trade and Industry will be available. The service is expected to be available to foreign entities in 2017, with ACRA-registered entities encouraged to register by the end of 2017.

site_title: Seoul: Won ends down, stocks pare losses on domestic stock buying
summary: The South Korean won dropped 0.7% to 1,122.1 to the US dollar as investors purchased US dollars, offsetting earlier losses. Local institutional buying helped pare earlier losses, with the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) closing down 0.1% at 2,032.72 points.

site_title: Tesla plans to raise funds this year to tackle cash crunch
summary: Tesla plans to raise funds this year to address a severe cash crunch, with a potential equity or debt offering to support the development and production of its Model 3 sedan and battery factory. The move comes after CEO Elon Musk warned of a possible equity capital raise in 2017. The funds may also be used to support Tesla's acquisition of SolarCity Corp.

site_title: Singapore manufacturing PMI at 50 in August, slightly short of Asean's 50.3
summary: Singapore's manufacturing PMI remained unchanged at 50 in August, slightly short of the 50.3 reading across Asean countries. Despite this, conditions in the sector marked a seven-month high. Indonesia, Malaysia, and Vietnam reported expansion in output, while Singapore's performance was countered by falling new orders. The sector remains well-positioned for future growth, according to IHS Markit economist Alex Gill.

site_title: China says 21 of its nationals in Singapore infected with Zika
summary: China's Foreign Ministry reported that 21 Chinese nationals in Singapore have been confirmed to have contracted Zika. The health situation is deemed not serious, with some having recovered. The incident occurred in the past but no further details are provided in the article.

site_title: Brazil opts not to raise taxes to meet 2017 fiscal goal
summary: Brazil's newly confirmed President Michel Temer submitted a 2017 national budget that limits spending but avoids tax hikes, aiming to close a financing gap. The government raised tax revenue estimates and privatization revenues to meet its primary deficit goal of 163.9 billion reais, relying on an economic rebound. Modest budget cuts were made, with a focus on balancing public accounts to exit Brazil's worst recession in decades.

images.alt_text: Brazil's newly confirmed President Michel Temer submitted to Congress a 2017 national budget that limits spending as promised but steers clear of tax hikes that analysts say are needed to quickly rebalance the country's depleted fiscal accounts.

site_title: Japan Q2 capex lacks momentum, suggests little change to revised GDP
summary: Japan's Q2 business expenditure fell 0.2% annually, suggesting minor revisions to revised GDP figures, indicating stagnant economic growth. Sluggish capital spending is a major concern, with exports also declining. This data undermines recent GDP figures, which previously showed a 0.2% annualized expansion.

images.alt_text: Japanese business expenditure fell in April-June from the previous quarter, suggesting only minor revisions will be made to recent gross domestic product figures and a sign that sluggish capital spending is hampering economic growth.

site_title: Kickstarter platform debuts in Singapore, Hong Kong
summary: Kickstarter, the popular crowdfunding platform, has launched in Singapore and Hong Kong, making it easier for local creators to launch projects. The move aims to promote more creative and innovative projects globally, with local backers able to participate in experiential rewards. Notable projects on the Singapore platform include the self-watering pot and automated indoor plant care system. The move follows a similar launch in Hong Kong, where Kickstarter has been overwhelmed by passionate backer communities.

site_title: UK to seek 'unique' deal to leave EU: PM's spokesman
summary: Britain will seek a "unique" deal on leaving the European Union, with the goal of controlling immigration while retaining strong trading ties. The government wants to balance these objectives despite warnings from other nations that single market access is incompatible with limits on free movement. Prime Minister Theresa May has appointed anti-EU ministers and will not trigger Article 50 before the start of next year, amid pressure from European nations to move faster. The UK voted to leave the EU in June, prompting the resignation of David Cameron.

site_title: South Korea's August house price growth slows for 8th straight month: Kookmin
summary: South Korea's house price growth slowed for the 8th consecutive month in August, with Kookmin Bank's composite housing purchase price index rising 0.13% from the previous month and 2.08% from last year. This marks the slowest pace since October 2014. The steady growth is a departure from previous months, which also showed a decline. The data suggests a stabilization in the country's housing market, but the trend is still uncertain.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 4.110 points to 1682.350, opening higher on Thursday with a trading volume of 61.3 million lots worth RM43.9 million. Losers outnumbered gainers 86 to 81.

site_title: UOB's US$600m 2.88% notes 7.3 times subscribed
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) has announced plans to issue US$600 million of 2.88% subordinated notes due 2027, priced 7.3 times subscribed. The notes, intended to qualify as Tier 2 regulatory capital, will be issued under UOB's S$15 billion Euro Medium Term Note programme and are expected to be rated 'A2' by Moody's and 'A+' by Fitch Ratings. The proceeds will be used for general business purposes, and UOB will last trade at S$18.01.

site_title: After Apple, EU may focus on companies closer to home
summary: The European Commission, led by Commissioner Margrethe Vestager, is likely to focus on European companies for future antitrust investigations, following the high-profile case against Apple for 13 billion euros in back taxes. The Commission has already ordered Starbucks to repay up to 30 million euros to the Netherlands and Fiat to Luxembourg. Vestager may choose to target European companies due to the limited resources and evidence available from the 1,000 companies being investigated.

site_title: Australia sues Volkswagen over alleged emissions fraud
summary: Australia's consumer watchdog sued Volkswagen's Australian arm for allegedly selling 57,000 vehicles with software that lied about toxic emissions. The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission claims the company engaged in "extraordinary conduct" and faces costly legal fallout globally. This is part of a growing trend of class action lawsuits and penalties from antitrust authorities worldwide.

site_title: Six Bangladeshi nationals in Singapore infected with Zika
summary: Six Bangladeshi nationals in Singapore have tested positive for the Zika virus, according to the High Commission of Bangladesh. The patients, who are experiencing mild symptoms, are recovering and have been in touch with the Ministry of Health. The Zika virus was detected in Singapore, marking the country's first reported cases.

site_title: Oil dives on bearish US inventory report
summary: Oil prices fell for the third consecutive day, with West Texas Intermediate down $1.65 to $44.70 per barrel and North Sea Brent down $1.33 to $47.04 per barrel, following an unexpected rise in US crude inventories. The US inventory report was seen as bearish, contributing to the decline.

site_title: Oil prices rebound on weaker US dollar
summary: Oil prices rose in early Asian trade on Thursday, rebounding on a weaker US dollar. The US dollar index fell against a basket of currencies, making greenback-denominated commodities like oil cheaper for holders of other currencies. This support for oil prices was attributed to a weaker dollar, which is governed by supply and the strength of the dollar.

site_title: Crackdown on soaring executive pay urged by UK Tory lawmaker
summary: A UK Conservative lawmaker urges action to curb rising executive pay, citing public resentment and poor investment returns. The average FTSE 100 CEO earns £6 million, 150 times the income of the average worker. Proposed measures include publishing pay ratios and holding annual shareholder votes, as well as mandatory shareholder committees with employee representatives. These recommendations echo Prime Minister Theresa May's drive to deliver more inclusive growth and follow Switzerland, the Netherlands, and Denmark's approaches.

site_title: UK banks attacked for elitism as May targets social inequality
summary: UK banks are criticized for elitism due to a high proportion of top investment bankers educated at fee-paying schools, despite less than 7% of UK pupils attending private schools. The Social Mobility Commission found that 50% of top investment bankers attended such schools. This lack of diversity is attributed to a "arcane culture" barrier that excludes "bright working-class kids." The report calls for greater inclusivity in the banking industry to address social inequality.

site_title: Shanghai-listed firms' H1 profits drop, Shenzhen's SMEs rise
summary: China's Shanghai-listed firms saw profits drop 5.7% to 1.14 trillion yuan in the first half of 2016, while smaller start-ups on the Shenzhen Exchange saw profits rise 5.8% to 244 billion yuan. Revenues edged up 1.3% in Shanghai and 8.6% in Shenzhen. The divergence in fortunes reflects the struggle of state-owned firms amid a slowdown, while smaller private companies are driving growth through industrial upgrading and technological innovation.

site_title: Australia home prices accelerate in August: CoreLogic
summary: Australian home prices accelerated 1.1% in August, driven by record-low mortgage rates in Sydney and Melbourne. This marked a 7% annual growth rate, up from 6.1% in July. The increase remains below last year's peak of 11%. Patchy performance was seen in other markets, contrasting the hotspots of Sydney and Melbourne.

site_title: May spells out immigration limits as the first Brexit red line
summary: Theresa May has outlined the UK's first Brexit red line, seeking to end the free movement of people from the European Union and potentially leaving the single market to achieve controls on immigration. The cabinet has agreed to pursue a bespoke deal with the EU, rather than copying existing models, and has decided not to hold a parliamentary vote before triggering two years of formal exit talks. This move has been criticized by the opposition Labour Party as "sheer high-handed arrogance."

site_title: Grab is now TransCab's booking app
summary: Grab has partnered with TransCab to become the taxi operator's go-to app for bookings, moving 7,000 drivers onto the platform. The app will handle on-demand passenger bookings, and TransCab will continue to accept telephone bookings. Drivers will undergo training and receive subsidised smartphones. This partnership aims to increase drivers' earnings and attract more drivers to join the fleet, with TransCab managing director Teo Kiang Ang describing it as a "win-win situation".

site_title: Energy shares fall on oil decline; US yields post monthly surge
summary: US and European shares fell on Wednesday due to a drop in oil prices, with the S&P energy index and European STOXX 600 Oil and Gas sector declining 1.4%. Oil prices tumbled to two-week lows after government data showed a large weekly build in US crude and distillate stockpiles. Two-year US Treasury yields surged 1.1% in August, the largest monthly increase since November, as investors expect a potential Federal Reserve interest rate hike.

images.alt_text: US and European shares fell on Wednesday as a drop in oil prices weighed on energy stocks, while two-year US Treasury yields ended August with the biggest monthly increase since November on growing expectations the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates.

site_title: Macau gaming snaps two-year slump to rise 1.1% on new resorts
summary: Macau's gaming revenue rose 1.1% in August, snapping a 26-month slump, driven by new resorts including one owned by Wynn Resorts. Gross gaming revenue reached 18.8 billion patacas (S$3.3 billion). This followed a 4.5% decrease in July, beating the median estimate of a 1.5% drop by analysts surveyed. The rebound is attributed to increased visits by recreational gamblers and tourists to the new resorts.

site_title: Greece's Eurobank profitable for second straight quarter, rival NBG swings to loss
summary: Greece's Eurobank reported its second consecutive profitable quarter with net earnings of 46 million euros, while rival National Bank (NBG) swung to a loss due to higher bad credit charges. Eurobank's non-performing loans eased slightly to 34.7% of its loan book, and the bank strengthened its deposit base. NBG reduced its borrowing from the European Central Bank and Greece's central bank, but increased bad loan provisions. The results reflect the ongoing efforts by Greek banks to manage their large problem loan portfolios and reduce dependence on central bank funding.

site_title: Turkish interior minister resigns in surprise move
summary: Turkish Interior Minister Efkan Ala resigned unexpectedly, according to Prime Minister Binali Yildirim, following a failed July 15 coup blamed on Fethullah Gulen supporters. Ala, a loyalist of President Recep Tayyip Erdogan, served nearly three years as interior minister and was replaced by Suleyman Soylu. The move comes amid ongoing insurgency with the Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK) and questions about intelligence failings following the failed coup. No official explanation was given for Ala's resignation, which was described as a surprise by Turkish media.

images.alt_text: Turkish Interior Minister Efkan Ala, a loyalist of President Recep Tayyip Erdogan, on Wednesday resigned in a surprise move, the prime minister announced.

site_title: LG Electronics cancelling orders with Hanjin Shipping
summary: LG Electronics is cancelling orders with Hanjin Shipping Co Ltd due to the company's filing for court receivership. Hanjin's financial support was ended by creditor banks, and some ports have denied entry to the company's ships. LG is setting up countermeasures for cargo already on board Hanjin ships in case they are seized. The move affects LG's shipments of televisions and home appliances, but the exact volumes were not disclosed.

site_title: Brazil impeachment opens diplomatic rift in South America
summary: Brazil's Senate voted 61-20 to convict President Dilma Rousseff, ending 13 years of Workers Party rule, and installed her conservative vice-president Michel Temer as interim president. Leftist governments in Venezuela, Ecuador, and Bolivia recalled their ambassadors in protest, calling it a "coup." Brazilian Foreign Minister Jose Serra defended the impeachment, criticizing Venezuela's lack of democracy. The move has heightened tensions between Brazil and its South American neighbors, particularly Venezuela, which has accused the US of backing the impeachment.

images.alt_text: Brazilian Foreign Minister Jose Serra defended the constitutionality of Rousseff's impeachment and questioned the legitimacy of Mr Maduro's government.

site_title: Three Hanjin ships stranded off Los Angeles, Long Beach ports
summary: Three Hanjin ships, bound for the Los Angeles-Long Beach port complex, are stranded off the US West Coast due to unpaid fees, according to the Marine Exchange of Southern California. Hanjin Shipping filed for court protection after lenders rejected its restructuring proposal, marking the company's fourth attempt to reschedule debt since May. The ships' cargo, including time-sensitive goods, may be delayed, but they represent less than 1% of the ship traffic in the area. Hanjin's woes reflect the struggling global shipping industry, which is expected to lose $5 billion this year.

site_title: Australia's inflation goes down as high-rise apartments go up
summary: Australia's inflation rate slowed to a 17-year low of 1% in the year to June, mainly due to record-low rental yields. The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) cut interest rates to a record low of 1.5% in response, but economists warn the trend may continue, as a surge in new home construction and vacancies compresses rental yields. The RBA expects inflation to remain below target until late 2018, citing the impact of the housing market on the economy.

images.alt_text: Australia has successfully used historically low borrowing costs to spark a boom in home building that has helped shepherd the economy through the dog days of a global mining downturn.

site_title: Italy and Germany signal tougher EU stance on migrants
summary: Italian Prime Minister Matteo Renzi and German Chancellor Angela Merkel agreed to step up efforts to repatriate migrants without asylum rights in Europe. The leaders stated that not everyone can stay in Europe, echoing a hardening of attitudes on the migrant crisis. This stance signals a tougher EU stance on migrants, with both countries emphasizing the need for a common agenda to address the issue.

site_title: Duterte's stock rally withers as foreign investors pull cash out
summary: Philippine stocks, which reached a 15-month high after Rodrigo Duterte's presidency, have declined sharply, erasing their gains since his inauguration in June. The Philippine Stock Exchange Index sank last month, marking the region's steepest drop, and valuations remain near their most expensive level since 2013. Foreign investors have pulled out cash, contributing to the decline.

site_title: Japanese airline ANA to replace 100 Rolls engines on 787s
summary: ANA Holdings Inc, Japan's largest airline, plans to replace all 100 Rolls-Royce engines on its 787 Dreamliner fleet due to corrosion and cracking of turbine blades. The process will take up to three years and will involve installing new blades on all 50 aircraft. ANA has already repaired three engines and five more need repairs, but will replace all engines for enhanced safety measures. Rolls-Royce is producing new blades, which will be incorporated into engines on new 787s next year.

images.alt_text: ANA Holdings Inc, Japan's largest airline, said on Wednesday it will replace all 100 Rolls-Royce engines on its fleet of Boeing 787 Dreamliners following three engine failures this year caused by corrosion and cracking of turbine blades.

site_title: Taiwan to appoint new chairman for Mega Financial
summary: Taiwan's government is set to appoint Michael C S Chang as chairman of state-owned Mega Financial Holding Co Ltd, replacing Shiu Kuang-si who quit after the New York branch of the firm's banking unit was fined for anti-money laundering violations. Chang, a banking veteran, previously served as chairman of First Financial Holding Co Ltd from 2006 to 2008. His appointment comes as the government aims to stabilize the financial sector following the recent fine. The formal announcement is expected later on Thursday.

site_title: DBS appoints former Stanchart banker as group head of strategy and planning
summary: DBS Group Holdings appointed Shee Tse Koon, 46, as group head of strategy and planning, effective immediately. He previously served as CEO of Standard Chartered Bank's Indonesia franchise. Shee will advise DBS' senior leadership team on strategic issues and implement organic and inorganic initiatives. This move comes as DBS last traded at S$15.06, up seven cents from the previous day's close.

site_title: EU business lobby warns of protectionist backlash if China doesn't open market
summary: A top European business lobby warned China that it risks a protectionist backlash unless it opens its markets faster to foreign investment. The European Union Chamber of Commerce in China said China's slow progress in opening markets is "not politically sustainable" and could lead to restrictions on European companies. China has been angered by recent blocking of foreign investments, but business groups argue that restrictions on foreign companies are often greater than those faced by Chinese firms abroad. China must reciprocate by opening up its markets to avoid a middle-income trap.

site_title: Lufthansa, Air China said to finalise venture this month
summary: Lufthansa and Air China are set to finalize a joint venture this month, allowing them to share revenue and coordinate routes under legal restrictions. The deal comes after over two years of negotiations and will give Lufthansa an edge over European rivals. The joint venture will cover nearly half of Lufthansa's long-haul capacity, more than any other European network carrier. This agreement follows a similar deal with Singapore Airlines last year and deepens ties between Lufthansa and Air China, which have been operating under code-share agreements since 2000.

site_title: US tax code may allow dramatic retaliation in EU Apple case
summary: The US tax code may allow the Obama administration to double tax rates for European companies in response to the European Commission's order for Apple to pay $14.5 billion in back taxes to Ireland. Section 891 of the tax code, passed in 1934, gives the president power to double tax rates for countries considered discriminatory against US companies. Experts say this measure is unlikely and may be struck down by courts due to treaties. The US Treasury has declined to comment on the possibility of such drastic measures.

site_title: Europe: Shares rise at open, buoyed by Elekta
summary: European shares rose 0.6% at the open, driven by commodity stocks and a strong performance from Sweden's Elekta, which rose 5.2% after beating Q1 profit forecasts. The energy and mining sectors also gained, with oil and metal prices stabilizing and recovering respectively. Banks continued their recent rally, with HSBC up 2.4%. In contrast, recruiting firm Hays fell 3.9% after weak hiring in Britain.

site_title: Trump talks immigration with Pena Nieto as Mexicans fume
summary: US presidential hopeful Donald Trump met with Mexican President Enrique Pena Nieto in Mexico City, sparking criticism from Mexicans over Trump's caustic remarks about their country. The meeting, which took place just hours before Trump's highly-anticipated speech on immigration, was seen as a potential "political stunt" by Pena Nieto to boost his own poll numbers. Trump's visit has been met with widespread disdain from Mexicans, who have compared him to Hitler and Mussolini. The meeting's outcome remains uncertain, with Trump seeking to capitalize on dramatic optics and potentially soften his hardline immigration policies ahead of the US presidential election.

images.alt_text: Donald Trump met with President Enrique Pena Nieto in Mexico on Wednesday amid a firestorm of criticism from Mexicans irate over the Republican White House hopeful's caustic tirades belittling their country.

site_title: Samsung unveils bigger Gear S3 smartwatches
summary: Samsung unveiled two new smartwatches, the Gear S3 Frontier and Gear S3 Classic, with a rugged and refined design, respectively. The watches feature large faces, cellular radio chips, and up to four days of battery life. They also offer features like always-on color displays, dust and water resistance, built-in speakers, and GPS location-finding technology. The new watches are expected to go on sale before the end of the year, with prices yet to be disclosed, competing with Apple's upcoming Apple Watch 2 line-up.

images.alt_text: Samsung Electronics unveiled two new smartwatches on Wednesday which boast a range of digital features while also promising up to four days of battery life, seeking to outshine the Apple Watch.

site_title: Gross calls for two Fed hikes at double the pace seen by market
summary: Bill Gross, billionaire manager of the Janus Global Unconstrained Bond Fund, recommends the Federal Reserve raise interest rates twice by as early as March, a pace the market doesn't expect until the end of 2017. Gross suggests the first hike at the Sept 20-21 Federal Open Market Committee meeting, with a 33% probability of action. The probability of two quarter-percentage-point increases by December 2017 stands at 47%.

site_title: US dollar wavers ahead of US jobs data, oil slide hits commodity currencies
summary: The US dollar wavered ahead of Friday's non-farm jobs report, with a 0.2% decline against the yen. The dollar had gained 1.5% against the yen last week following Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen's comments on near-term rate hike prospects. The euro remained flat, while commodity currencies, such as the Canadian and Australian dollars, were hit by the drop in crude oil prices. The US dollar index was steady at 96.007, with traders expecting the jobs report to shape interest rate expectations and impact the dollar's momentum.

site_title: Asia: Shares fall following oil slump; yen climbs, ringgit sinks
summary: Asian markets declined following a slump in oil prices below $45 a barrel, with commodity stocks leading the losses. The yen rebounded, while the ringgit slid to a two-month low. The yen strengthened to 103.22 against the US dollar, while the ringgit weakened to 4.0925. The decline in Asian markets was attributed to oscillating sentiment over supply and demand in oil trading and the outlook for US monetary policy.

site_title: McDonald's names new head of US unit
summary: McDonald's names Christopher Kempczinski, 47, as new head of US unit, succeeding Michael Andres, who will retire at the end of the year. Andres took the helm in 2014 and was appointed by Don Thompson, but was unexpectedly replaced. Kempczinski, currently executive vice president of strategy, comes from Kraft Foods Group. The move comes as McDonald's fights to maintain momentum amid intense competition and low grocery prices. Analysts say the continuity of the turnaround is the biggest question, but McDonald's has a deep bench of management talent.

site_title: UOB latches onto 500m yuan in Asean-Chongqing investment flows
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) facilitated over 500 million yuan (S$102 million) in cross-border investments between Chongqing and South-east Asia since January, with 90% going to Singapore. The number of companies UOB worked with rose 35% in seven months, primarily from automotive, trading, and services sectors. This comes as part of the Sino-Singapore Chongqing Connectivity Initiative, which saw a 28.7% increase in overseas direct investment from Chongqing to US$769 million in the first half of 2016. UOB expects demand for cross-border financial solutions to continue growing.

site_title: Australia business spending shows signs of life outside mining
summary: Australian business investment declined 5.4% to A$28.71 billion in the second quarter, but spending plans for 2015/16 rose 15.2% to A$105.17 billion. Non-mining sector investment increased 2.8%, with manufacturing up 13%, while mining investment fell 16%. The Reserve Bank of Australia may see a stronger economy due to the upgraded spending plans, which could support the non-mining economy. This data provides early signs of a recovery outside of the mining sector, which has been driving the economy for years.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks dip to over one-week low; financial shares drop
summary: Taiwan's stocks fell on Thursday, reaching a one-week low, as overseas markets declined and heavyweights in the financial sector were hit hard. Mega Financial Holding Co Ltd's shares dropped 1.9% after its chairman resigned following a fine for anti-money laundering regulations. The main Taiex index fell 0.9% to 8,980.21, its lowest since August 22. The Taiwan dollar strengthened against the US dollar.

site_title: China steel mills chase top quality iron ore to boost output
summary: China's steel mills are chasing high-quality iron ore to boost output and meet environmental standards, driving a premium for top-grade ore to its highest in two years. The preference for premium ore is expected to benefit top miners such as Vale and Rio Tinto, while contributing to growing stockpiles at domestic ports. Chinese steel prices have risen following mill closures and output curbs, leading to surging premiums for high-grade iron ore.

site_title: UOB Venture Management to invest US$25m in Vietnam hydropower firm
summary: UOB Venture Management is investing US$25 million in Bitexco Power Corporation, a Vietnamese hydropower company, alongside Orix Corporation. The investment will be used for business expansion and to solidify Bitexco Power's market leadership in the renewable energy sector. This deal is part of UOBVM's Asean China Investment Fund III, which focuses on growth-oriented companies in East and South-east Asia. The investment is expected to support Bitexco Power's growth and further establish its position in the sector.

site_title: Indian growth slows sharply in April-June quarter
summary: India's economic growth slowed sharply to 7.1% in the April-June quarter, missing economists' predictions and Prime Minister Narendra Modi's target. This marks a 15-month low and puts pressure on Modi to deliver on his promise of creating 250 million jobs over the next decade. Despite being the world's fastest-growing large economy, the slowdown highlights the challenges Modi faces in meeting his job creation goal.

images.alt_text: India's economic growth hit a 15-month low between April and June, putting Prime Minister Narendra Modi's target further out of reach and making it tougher for him to create millions of new jobs for a burgeoning workforce.

site_title: Fears of Zika's effects may impact fertility, birth rates: specialists
summary: Singapore reports 33 new Zika cases, including a pregnant woman, amid concerns over the virus's impact on fertility and birth rates. Specialists warn that short-term precautions are necessary, but if the situation doesn't improve, couples may delay or forgo having more children, potentially affecting fertility and birth rates in the long term. The risk of microcephaly in unborn babies is estimated to be between 1-13%, according to a recent study.

site_title: Clinton at peak unpopularity but still leads Trump: polls
summary: Hillary Clinton has reached a record low in popularity, with 41% of Americans having a favorable view and 56% unfavorable, according to a Washington Post-ABC News poll. This is her worst ratings in a quarter century in public positions. Despite being ahead of Donald Trump in surveys, Clinton's image has taken a severe beating due to renewed questions over her email server and the Clinton Foundation. She trails Trump by five points overall with 42% support compared to 37%. This is the most unpopular presidential candidate in modern US politics.

site_title: Federal Reserve officials push financial stability to centre of rate debate
summary: Federal Reserve officials are shifting the focus of the interest rate debate from solely targeting inflation to preserving financial stability. Chicago Fed President Charles Evans argues that delaying rate increases until inflation reaches the 2% target would not pose significant risks, citing subdued business expectations and lower long-term interest rate expectations. However, some officials, including Boston Fed President Eric Rosengren, express concerns about the potential for asset price misallocation and a repeat of the 2013 yield surge. The Federal Open Market Committee will consider these views when meeting next month.

site_title: Canada opts to join China-led AIIB
summary: Canada is applying for membership in the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB), a China-led development bank, becoming the first North American nation to join. The decision further isolates the US and Japan, which are the only declared holdouts among advanced economies. Canada's move brings the total number of AIIB members to 58, as the bank opened its doors in 2016.

site_title: Singapore Reits hitting their limit over compliance rules
summary: Singapore's Reits face increased compliance costs due to stricter rules, which may lead to a "diminishing returns" situation, causing delistings. Reit managers, including those from Starhill Global Reit, Keppel Reit, and Ascott Residence Trust, expressed concerns about the rising costs and regulatory burden. They advocate for a balanced approach to ensure Reits can continue to attract global capital while maintaining compliance. Key issues include revising MAS guidelines to align with SGX rules, reinstating stamp duties remission, and increasing transparency on taxation for international investors.

site_title: New fossils show life on Earth at least 3.7b years old
summary: Australian scientists have discovered fossils in Greenland dating back 3.7 billion years, pushing the estimated age of life on Earth to at least 3.7 billion years. The fossils, called stromatolites, are 220 million years older than previous records and provide evidence of life emerging just a few hundred million years after the Earth's formation. The discovery could aid in the search for life on Mars, suggesting that the Red Planet may have had oceans and conditions suitable for life 3.7 billion years ago.

images.alt_text: Life on Earth is even older than we thought, said Australian scientists on Thursday as they unveiled fossils dating back a staggering 3.7 billion years.

site_title: China's hard line toward Hong Kong democracy faces election test
summary: China's hardline stance on Hong Kong democracy is being tested in the upcoming Legislative Council election, where almost 4 million voters will choose 70 members. The election may impact the future of unpopular Chief Executive Leung Chun-ying, with a strong showing by "localist" contenders risking tensions over Beijing's increasing grip on the territory. The results may also indicate the future direction of Hong Kong and whether people still support the pro-democracy cause, with some polls showing a significant percentage supporting independence from China.

site_title: Indonesia inflation slows to weakest in 7 years, misses target
summary: Indonesia's inflation slowed to 2.79% in August, the weakest in nearly seven years, missing the central bank's target of 3-5%. The country's economy has a manageable inflation rate and current-account deficit, allowing for further interest-rate cuts. Bank Indonesia still sees room to ease policy, with some economists predicting a 25 basis point rate cut in its September meeting. The central bank's decision is influenced by the size of tax amnesty inflows. This move bolsters the case for interest-rate cuts, providing a boost to the economy.

images.alt_text: Indonesia's inflation slowed to the weakest in almost seven years and fell below the central bank's target, bolstering the case for further interest-rate cuts.

site_title: Singapore mom-and-pop investors face losses as bond risks spread
summary: Singapore's retail investors face potential losses as four new issues of Singapore dollar-denominated notes have dropped below par sales value, sparking concerns of a default and bond restructuring. The market's stress is fueled by recent failures of small- to medium-sized enterprises, including Swiber Holdings and Pacific Andes Resources Development. Regulators are tightening safeguards to protect investors, and analysts warn that a slowing economy could exacerbate the risks.

site_title: Singapore shares open 0.1% up on Thursday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index opened 0.1% higher on Thursday, advancing 2.11 points to 2,822.7. The market is in a wait-and-see mode ahead of US jobs data, with 50.7 million shares changing hands. The field was evenly matched, with 53 gainers and losers.

site_title: EU Apple tax demand precipitates trans-Atlantic row
summary: The European Union has issued a 13 billion euro tax demand to Apple, claiming the US tech giant received an effective subsidy from Ireland's low tax rate. The EU's anti-competition order requires Apple to pay back taxes. The US has strongly protested, saying the decision undermines international tax norms and unfairly penalizes Apple. The move has sparked a trans-Atlantic trade row.

site_title: Uniqlo making biggest South-east Asia bet as Yanai looks abroad
summary: Uniqlo is opening its largest store in South-east Asia, a 2,700 sqm store on Singapore's Orchard Road, marking the brand's biggest bet in the region. The store aims to drive growth for Uniqlo, which is expanding globally to revive flagging profits at its parent company, Fast Retailing Co. Chairman Tadashi Yanai seeks to generate $66.5 billion in sales by 2020, but analysts warn that achieving this goal in three years will be difficult. This is Uniqlo's 25th store in Singapore, part of the brand's 130 outlets in the region.

site_title: SIIC to buy stake in China wastewater treatment firm for S$55.8m
summary: SIIC Environment will acquire a 60% stake in Ranhill Water (Hong Kong) for S$55.8 million in cash, targeting a wastewater treatment firm in China. The acquisition aims to expand SIIC's business and enhance shareholder value. Ranhill Water provides wastewater treatment services to industrial parks in China with a total design capacity of 260,000 tonnes per day. The deal will be funded by bank borrowings and internal cash resources.

site_title: Twitter offers video creators a share of ad revenue
summary: Twitter has introduced a new Amplify Publisher Program, allowing individual video creators in the US to share a cut of ad revenue from the ads shown on their tweets. The program, launched with select media partners, enables creators to upload, manage, and publish media more efficiently and effectively. Video creators will be able to get a share of revenue generated from audiences they attract, with reports suggesting a 70% cut similar to media partners. This move aims to help Twitter compete with YouTube and Facebook for content.

site_title: Being a best employer is good for business
summary: Aon Hewitt's Best Employers list reveals companies in the top category outperform the market in revenue and profits, with revenues 18% higher and profits 11% higher. The top honor, Best of the Best, goes to Ritz Carlton Millenia Singapore. The list highlights companies with high employee engagement, effective leadership, and performance culture. 86% of best employers deliver on promises, and 86% integrate promotion-linked goals into performance management, surpassing market averages. The list, which includes 11 companies, is an annual publication, up from a biennial format until 2015.

site_title: Singapore Land Authority launches online service MyProperty
summary: The Singapore Land Authority (SLA) has launched an online service, MyProperty, allowing property owners to view their title deeds and boundary plans without charge. Currently, about 130,000 HDB property titles have been digitized, with the rest expected to be completed by 2019. The online service, accessible via SingPass, will eventually include all private property titles and additional features in phases. This move aims to simplify access to property information, reducing the need to purchase it through the Integrated Land Information Service or in-person.

site_title: Quotation of taxable book-entry Singapore Government Bonds
summary: Singapore Government Bonds quotation increased, with taxable book-entry bonds reaching a new record high. NTT DC Reit's public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. US stocks opened lower due to fresh tariffs on Canada. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss. London's Heathrow is considering higher fees for a £10b upgrade. Indonesia detained an employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. OCBC announced Tan Teck Long as its new CEO, replacing DBS veteran. MAS and PBOC plan to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance.

site_title: Institutional money can fill gap in Asean infrastructure financing: HSBC
summary: HSBC reports that the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean) faces a significant infrastructure financing gap, with estimated $2.1 trillion needed across Asean-6 countries. Current public and private spending plans fall short, prompting governments to boost public-private programs and deepen capital markets. Some Asean countries, including the Philippines and Indonesia, are increasing infrastructure spending, but more aggressive action is needed to meet the 5% GDP benchmark. Institutional monies, such as those from China and Japan, may fill the gap once procurement bottlenecks are eased.

site_title: Hanjin now a symbol of shipping industry slump
summary: Hanjin Shipping Co, South Korea's largest container-shipping company, has filed for court receivership after lenders rejected a restructuring proposal, citing insufficient funds to roll over debt. The company needs an additional 1.3 trillion won to cover losses over the past four years. The move highlights the struggling container-shipping industry, which has been plagued by losses since the 2008 global financial crisis. Hanjin's woes are a symptom of the industry's ongoing slump, with many companies trying to restructure through mergers, acquisitions, and cost cuts.

site_title: Singapore companies to benefit greatly from TPP
summary: Singapore companies are expected to benefit greatly from the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP), with international law firm Freshfields Bruckhaus Deringer predicting an increase in cross-border mergers and acquisitions (M&A) activity following full ratification of the treaty. The study found that member states generally experience a 29.2% increase in cross-border deals with other member states in the first two years after ratification, with Singapore companies being well-positioned to take advantage of this growth. The TPP is set to provide a reliable dispute-resolution mechanism, attracting multinational companies to invest in TPP member states, particularly Singapore.

site_title: Spanish towns seek to repeat success of Tomatina festival
summary: Spanish towns are emulating the success of Tomatina festival, dubbed "the world's biggest food fight", which drew 22,000 revellers in 2016. The festival, which started in 1945, generates significant revenue for the town of Bunol, including 300,000 euros from film productions. Other towns, such as Mataelpino and Haro, are adopting similar festivals, including a "Boloencierro" and a "wine fight", to attract visitors and boost local economies.

site_title: Obama leaves Washington for final G20 summit
summary: US President Barack Obama departed Washington on August 31 for his final G20 summit, marking his 10th trip to Asia since his "pivot" to the region. He will attend the summit in Hangzhou, China, and meet with world leaders, including Chinese President Xi Jinping, to discuss climate change, the global economy, and regional issues. Obama's agenda includes pressing China to limit steel capacity and reform the industry, as well as meeting with Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan and Philippine leader Rodrigo Duterte.

site_title: Samsung warns of more Galaxy Note delays amid battery explosion claims
summary: Samsung Electronics Co Ltd is delaying shipments of the Galaxy Note 7 smartphone due to quality control issues, specifically related to battery explosions. Shipments to South Korea's top three carriers have been halted, and the company is conducting additional tests. If confirmed, quality control problems could harm Samsung's sales momentum. The firm is working to resolve the issues by replacing parts and modules and changing design circuits, with production expected to ease within a few weeks.

site_title: Keeping the door open for employees
summary: The Ritz-Carlton Millenia Singapore has been recognized as the "best of the best" in Aon Hewitt's "Best Employer" award, a title the hotel has held since 2001. The hotel's success is attributed to its focus on treating employees as its most precious resource, with a culture that prioritizes staff engagement and well-being. Key practices include a daily 15-minute briefing with staff, an open-door policy, and a commitment to recognizing and addressing employee concerns. By putting staff first, the hotel believes it can create a positive impact on customer satisfaction.

site_title: US$ hits one-month high against yen
summary: The US dollar rose to a one-month high against the yen on August 31, 2016, due to speculation of a potential interest rate hike by the US Federal Reserve in the coming months. The dollar gained 3% against the yen since the Jackson Hole meeting, where Fed chair Janet Yellen and vice-chair Stanley Fischer kept open the possibility of a rate hike. The dollar index rose 1.5% and the yen was pressured by weak Japanese data, with some experts predicting a reversal in the yen's recent strength.

site_title: Hard to escape governance risks of dual-class shares
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) is considering allowing dual-class shares, but regulatory safeguards may not completely mitigate governance risks. The Listings Advisory Committee's recommendations aim to address concerns by requiring a more detailed and explicit regime, but limitations in monitoring and holding independent directors accountable remain. The proposal also fails to address the entrenchment issue and the oxymoronic relationship between size and risk. While investor education is recommended, its effectiveness is uncertain. Ultimately, SGX may need to accept higher levels of governance risk if it decides to allow dual-class listings.

site_title: US August car sales may fall as producers ease discounts
summary: US car sales in August may fall as manufacturers reduce discounts, potentially marking a decline in industrywide annual sales for the first time in seven years. Industrywide sales are projected to be around 17.2 million cars and light trucks, down from a 17.9 million rate in July. Despite a seasonally adjusted annual sales pace, carmakers are prioritizing profit over sales, with transaction prices at a record high. The decline in sales may be partly due to the weakening of underlying trends, including low unemployment and available credit.

site_title: Tencent skyscraper doubles as IoT test lab
summary: Tencent Holdings Ltd has unveiled its new US$599 million headquarters in southern China, featuring two 50-storey glass and steel towers connected by skybridges. The campus-like complex aims to create a unique urban setting, with a focus on innovation and technology. The project is part of Tencent's efforts to establish itself as a leader in the tech industry, with a focus on artificial intelligence, the Internet of Things, and other emerging technologies. The new headquarters is set to become a hub for IoT testing and development.

images.alt_text: The building will feature hologram tour guides, conference rooms that adjust temperatures based on attendance and alerts for the best parking spots before commuters arrive.

site_title: Foreign investors turn sellers in Vietnam after 10-year spree
summary: Foreign investors are shifting from buying to selling assets on Vietnam's Ho Chi Minh City Stock Exchange for the first time in a decade, after pumping in $3.4 billion since 2006. Despite a near-eight-year high benchmark VN Index, the market remains small and lacks liquidity, with average daily trading values less than a quarter of those in Malaysia or Indonesia. The nation's equity market is expected to meet MSCI's emerging-market criteria by the end of 2016, but foreign investors are hesitant due to stalled bank reforms and limited liquidity.

site_title: BOJ more likely to go for easing with limp July data
summary: The Bank of Japan is likely to adopt new monetary-easing tactics in July due to stagnant economic data. Industrial output in Japan halted in July, following a June gain. This move aims to prevent deflation and recession. The decision is based on the BOJ's concerns about the economy's slowdown. Analysts expect the BOJ to ease monetary policies to stimulate growth.

site_title: Tented restaurant on wasteland dazzles with a taste of London
summary: A unique, London-based restaurant, Xiringuito, has opened in Margate, a seaside town in Kent, despite its uninviting location. The tented eatery, designed by architect Asif Khan, serves creative, locally-sourced dishes by chefs Conor Sheehan and Jackson Berg, who previously worked at prominent London restaurants. The menu features simple, yet flavorful options, including sweet local oysters and soft-shell crab in a fruity curry sauce. Xiringuito, which runs until late September, is a step towards revitalizing Margate's traditional resort and may attract fashionable Londoners looking for a taste of the seaside.

site_title: CapitaLand unveils mall management strategy
summary: CapitaLand has signed its first third-party management contract to manage a retail component of a China integrated development, Fortune Finance Centre in Changsha, marking the property giant's expansion into third-party retail mall management. The contract covers 95,000 sqm of retail space and is expected to commence operations in 2018. Analysts say this move can boost profitability but may lead to brand dilution if not executed well. The deal increases CapitaLand's presence in Changsha and allows for future acquisitions through its right of first refusal.

site_title: Abercrombie shares fall the most in 3 years as slow sales weigh on results
summary: Abercrombie & Fitch Co. reported a 25 US cent per share loss in its second quarter, exceeding analyst projections of a 20 US cent loss. The company cited slow sales at flagship locations as a major factor, leading to plans to close more stores and shrink its US store base by a third over the past six years. This marks the largest decline in Abercrombie's stock price in three years, sparking concerns about its turnaround efforts.

site_title: China's yuan weakens in cautious mood ahead of G20, US jobs data
summary: China's yuan weakened ahead of the G20 summit, with investors cautious about potential interest rate hikes by the US Federal Reserve. The spot yuan opened at 6.6795 per US dollar, 14 pips weaker than the previous close. The People's Bank of China set the daily midpoint at 6.6784, firmer than the previous fix. The offshore yuan was trading 0.14 per cent weaker than the onshore spot, as investors await US labor figures on Friday that may influence interest rate decisions.

site_title: Brazil's Rousseff stripped of presidency, Temer sworn in
summary: Brazil's President Dilma Rousseff was stripped of the presidency on August 31, 2016, after being convicted by 61 of 81 senators of illegally manipulating the national budget. Her bitter rival Michel Temer, a center-right former vice president, was sworn in as the new president, shifting Brazil's economy sharply to the right. Rousseff, who vowed to return to politics, condemned the impeachment process, while Temer vowed to steer Brazil away from 13 years of Workers' Party rule and implement market-friendly reforms.

images.alt_text: Brazil's Dilma Rousseff was stripped of the country's presidency in an impeachment vote Wednesday and replaced by her bitter rival Michel Temer, shifting Latin America's biggest economy sharply to the right.

site_title: Swift discloses more cyber thefts, pressures banks on security
summary: Swift, the global financial messaging system, has disclosed new hacking attacks on its member banks, with some successful attempts, since June. The attacks, similar to the 2016 $81 million heist at Bangladesh Bank, targeted banks with lax security procedures for Swift-enabled transfers. Swift is pressuring banks to comply with security measures, including stronger systems for authenticating users and updates to its software, by November 19. If banks fail to comply, Swift may report them to regulators. This move aims to coerce members into prioritizing cyber-security and sharing confidential information about security lapses.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: SATS, a Singaporean airport services provider, has seen its stock ranking drop to No 8 in July due to a 3.2% dividend yield below the market average. The company's H1 2016 tourist arrivals of 8.2 million fell short of expectations, leading to a downgrade from "add" to "hold" by CIMB Research, citing a valuation of 22 times forward price-earnings, more than two standard deviations above its long-term mean.

site_title: Gold holds monthly drop as payrolls in focus for data-driven Fed
summary: Gold prices dropped 3.1% in August, marking a monthly decline, as investors await the US jobs data on Friday to gauge the timing of a potential interest rate increase by the Federal Reserve. The metal has been dented by Fed officials' indications of further monetary tightening before the end of the year. Companies added workers to US payrolls in August, contributing to signs of a steady labor market. The Fed's decision at its Sept 21 meeting will be based on economic data, with traders closely watching the nonfarm payrolls report.

site_title: Tepid activity in strata commercial, shophouses seen for H2 2016
summary: Singapore's strata commercial market saw a decline in transactions in the first half of 2016, with strata office and shophouse deals falling 20% and 30% respectively, compared to the same period last year. However, strata retail transactions rose 20% due to the launch of Centrium Square, which attracted a single buyer to purchase all 49 retail units for S$135 million. Experts predict muted transaction volumes for the rest of the year, but note that companies may consider purchasing office units for their own use as they seek cost sustainability.

site_title: China official services PMI expands at slightly slower pace in August
summary: China's manufacturing sector activity expanded at a slightly slower pace in August, with the official Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) rising to 50.4, above the 50-point mark separating growth from contraction. The modest gains suggest the economy is steadying but still sluggish, with higher government spending on infrastructure projects boosting demand for materials. Factory output and new orders rose, but new export orders continued to fall. Despite this, profits earned by industrial firms grew, possibly due to rebounding commodity prices rather than sustained demand, and factories continued to cut staff at a slower pace.

site_title: Challenge of cutting global coal dependence
summary: The world's effort to drastically reduce fossil fuels, particularly coal, is facing significant challenges. Despite Germany's ambitious plans to phase out coal, the country's government backed down due to opposition from labor unions and coal country governments. The US and China, the world's largest coal consumers, also struggle with the transition. Experts note that while official data suggests coal production has peaked, new generators are still being built, and local governments in China often ignore Beijing's orders to shut down coal mines. A successful transition to a low-carbon future requires the support of workers and communities that depend on coal, which remains an afterthought in the public debate over climate change.

site_title: Former HUDC estate in Potong Pasir up for collective sale
summary: RAINTREE Gardens, a 175-unit residential development in Potong Pasir, Singapore, has been launched for collective sale with a minimum price of S$315 million. The tender, set to close on Oct 5, offers a potential gross floor area of 201,405 square feet, with a breakeven cost of S$1,250 psf for the developer. Industry players believe the site's waterfront location and proximity to upcoming developments make it an attractive offering for developers.

site_title: S'pore shares slip further on oil, gas woes
summary: Singapore shares slipped for the fourth consecutive session, with the Straits Times Index declining 0.3% to 2,820.59. The oil and gas sector remained under pressure, with AusGroup's fourth-quarter loss and breaching of financial covenants affecting the sector. Noble Group, a commodity trader, closed at a 13-year low after dropping 3.3%. Despite this, MM2 Asia's shares rose 1.3% to 77.5 Singapore cents. Investors are cautious ahead of US payrolls data and rate hike concerns.

site_title: China's top steelmakers bounce back to profit after price rally
summary: China's top steelmakers, including Hesteel Co Ltd and Baoshan Iron & Steel Co Ltd, reported gains in first-half profits as a price rally lifted earnings. Hesteel's net income rose to 409 million yuan, while Baoshan's net income increased 9% to 3.47 billion yuan. The steel market gained momentum in the first half due to low inventory levels, but remains on a downward trend, with conditions potentially peaking. Analysts warn of sluggish growth for China's economy in the second half, and significant declines in demand and output.

site_title: Dual class shares: safeguards or minefields?
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) is considering allowing companies to list with dual-class shares (DCS), which has raised concerns about entrenchment and expropriation risks. The Listings Advisory Committee (LAC) has proposed certain safeguards, including a maximum voting differential of 10:1 and auto-conversion of multi-vote shares into one-vote shares. However, critics argue that these safeguards may not be effective and could lead to poor-quality companies being listed. The SGX has promised a public consultation, but some stakeholders are skeptical about the ability of the LAC to effectively mitigate these risks.

site_title: China readies for G-20 meeting in Hangzhou
summary: China will host the Group of 20 (G-20) meeting in Hangzhou from September 4-5, marking the first time the world's second-largest economy will host the event. The meeting will bring together heads of state from the world's 20 leading economies to discuss global growth, corruption, and fiscal policies. China has set the agenda, focusing on green finance, global fiscal policies, and infrastructure investments. The event aims to promote cooperation and showcase China's influence on the world stage, with independent bilateral meetings and a joint communique setting growth priorities for the next few years.

site_title: Update: Malaysia confirms first case of Zika in woman who visited Singapore
summary: Malaysia has confirmed its first case of Zika, a 58-year-old woman who visited Singapore, where 115 people have been infected. The victim showed signs of a rash and fever after returning from Singapore on August 21. Malaysia is carrying out control measures against Aedes mosquitoes near the woman's home to prevent the spread of the virus. The US has warned pregnant women not to travel to Singapore due to the outbreak, which is linked to microcephaly and has spread through the Americas and the Caribbean.

site_title: Mystery of oil held on Chinese islands puzzles crude markets
summary: China's oil reserves, equivalent to 100 days of net imports, remain shrouded in secrecy, puzzling the global crude market. The country has been stockpiling crude in underground caverns and above-ground sites, with record purchases this year helping oil prices recover. Analysts disagree on the timing and extent of future purchases, with some estimating the country will continue buying and filling up commercial tanks, while others predict a slowdown. China's lack of transparency has given it an advantage, with the country potentially being able to increase purchases even if it runs out of space, according to industry consultant Energy Aspects.

site_title: Global governance versus national government policies
summary: Global governance is crucial in addressing the world's economic problems, as international cooperation is necessary to tackle challenges like climate change, taxation, and monetary policies. However, Dani Rodrik argues that global governance often promises more than it can deliver, diverting attention from practical reforms that national governments should implement. To address these issues, strengthening institutions like the IMF, EU, and G-20 is necessary, but national or local policies should also be pursued when sufficient to address a problem, emphasizing the principle of subsidiarity.

site_title: India's Tata Motors overhauling domestic business in 3-year plan
summary: Tata Motors, India's largest carmaker, is overhauling its domestic business in a three-year plan to become one of the top three car brands by 2019. The company is rationalizing its supply chain, product portfolio, and organizational structure, eliminating suppliers that don't meet quality, cost, and delivery standards. It's also increasing accountability among employees and focusing on timely decision execution. Tata Motors' domestic operations have suffered due to a slowing economy, but truck sales are recovering, and the company has turned a profit in the last fiscal year.

site_title: UK home prices rise the most in five months in August
summary: UK home prices rose 0.6% in August, the largest increase in five months, driven by a shortage of supply supporting values despite weaker demand. Prices are up 5.6% from last year, averaging £206,145. The Nationwide Building Society attributes the rise to a decline in supply matching a decrease in demand, suggesting long-term housing supply issues continue to support prices.

site_title: Australia, NZ dollars inch higher on positive economic news
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars rose on Thursday, driven by positive economic data, despite a looming US jobs report. The Australian dollar climbed to US$0.7538, while the New Zealand dollar increased to US$0.7252. Australia's business investment showed signs of improvement, and China's manufacturing sector rose to 50.4 in August, supporting the currencies. However, the Reserve Bank of Australia's decision on interest rates remains uncertain, with a 50-50 chance of a move by December.

images.alt_text: The Australian and New Zealand dollars edged higher on Thursday as investors focussed on the positives in domestic economic data, though their longer-term direction remained at the mercy of a looming US jobs report.

site_title: S-Reits a safe haven in hunt for yield
summary: OCBC Investment Research analysts predict S-Reits will remain a safe haven for investors seeking yield, having outperformed the Straits Times Index (STI) this year. With interest rates likely to stay low, Reits are expected to continue attracting investors. Analysts also recommend four S-Reits for "buy" ratings: Frasers Centrepoint Trust, Keppel DC Reit, Ascendas Reit, and SPH Reit. Additionally, OCBC has "buy" ratings on property developers CapitaLand, City Developments, and Global Logistic Properties, and a "buy" rating on ComfortDelGro for its potential gains from the Land Transport Authority's new bus contracting model.

site_title: Direction of DC rates reversed for three use groups - for six months
summary: The Singapore government has reversed the direction of development charge (DC) rates for three key use groups for the Sept 1, 2016, to Feb 28, 2017, period. DC rates were increased by 2.7% for non-landed residential use, 0.6% for commercial use, and 1.4% for hotel/hospital use. This reversal follows improved sentiment in the property investment sales market, driven by major office sales transactions and the triggering of the Central Boulevard site from the reserve list of the Government Land Sales (GLS) programme.

images.alt_text: The government has reversed the direction of development charge (DC) rates for three key use groups for the Sept 1, 2016, to Feb 28, 2017, period - on the back of improved sentiment in the property investment sales market.

site_title: Asian bonds still attractive, says UBS fixed income manager
summary: Asian bonds continue to be an attractive investment option, offering phenomenal returns despite pending interest rate hikes, according to Ashley Perrott, head of Pan Asia Fixed Income at UBS. Asian bonds have returned 6.1% per annum over the past 5 years, outperforming Asian equities, and the UBS Asian USD credit strategy has delivered an 8.8% return. However, Perrott warns that the bond market may be becoming overheated, with investors taking on more risk due to low yields. He advises investors to diversify and carefully select individual bonds, rather than relying on individual expertise.

site_title: Russia tycoon invests US$50m in wireless carrier FreedomPop
summary: Russian billionaire Mikhail Fridman has invested US$50 million in FreedomPop, a wireless carrier backed by Skype co-founder Niklas Zennstrom. The investment will help FreedomPop expand into Asia, Europe, and Latin America, with plans to add eight new markets by the end of next year. LetterOne, Fridman's investment vehicle, will provide strategic advice and has a goal of investing up to US$3 billion in global technology pioneers. This investment aims to help FreedomPop grow beyond its US market and benefit from emerging markets expertise.

site_title: July pending home contracts surge after falling 2 months in a row
summary: US pending home contracts surged 1.3% in July to 111.3, the second-highest reading in over a decade, after two months of declines. Economists had forecast a 0.6% rise. Demand is driven by the labor market's steady wage increases and tight inventory conditions. Home-price appreciation is moderating, making it attractive to buyers and sellers. Regional gains include a 7.3% rise in the West and 0.8% in the North-east, while the Midwest saw a 2.9% decline.

site_title: Nexus Capital buys more China Vanke shares
summary: A Hong Kong-based fund, Nexus Capital Management, has increased its stake in China Vanke Co Ltd, the country's biggest property developer, to 11.5% of Vanke's Hong Kong-listed shares. The move, which has lifted its interest in total shares to 1.4%, comes as China Evergrande, the country's second-largest property developer, has built up a near 7% interest in Vanke. The emergence of Evergrande has fueled market speculation about Vanke's shares, with Vanke's Hong Kong-listed stock rising 2% and its Shenzhen shares jumping 10% in Wednesday's trade.

site_title: Partnering competitors - Reits find ways around disruption
summary: Singaporean Reits are adapting to disruptions in the market by collaborating with competitors and changing their product offerings. Ascott Residence Trust listed its properties on Airbnb, but found no bookings, while Starhill Global Reit focused on improving food and beverage options in its malls to avoid competition from e-commerce. Meanwhile, AIMS AMP Capital Industrial Reit has seen an increase in demand for logistics space from local companies, and the trust is adding more warehouses to meet the demand. These strategies aim to minimize disruption and maintain business profiles globally.

site_title: S'pore August market cap flat after July's nine-month high
summary: Singapore's stock market ended August with a flat total value of S$860 billion, down from July's nine-month high of S$860.4 billion. The market capitalization is still higher than end-2015's S$856.4 billion, with a 0.7% year-over-year gain. Losers outnumbered gainers 352 to 267, with agriculture companies posting the strongest gain of 4% and finance companies increasing by just 0.1%. The largest companies by market value outperformed smaller ones, with the largest 10% of companies rising 0.2% and the smallest 10% dropping 53.9%.

site_title: Filmmakers focus on infamous crime in Black Lives Matter era
summary: At least three film productions are underway to tell the story of Emmett Till's 1955 lynching, a racially motivated crime that sparked outrage and galvanized the Civil Rights Movement. Till, a 14-year-old black teenager, was tortured and murdered in Mississippi for allegedly whistling at a white woman. The recent resurgence of the Black Lives Matter movement has reinvigorated efforts to bring Till's story to the screen, with new adaptations in the works to shed light on this infamous and pivotal moment in American history.

site_title: Apple's fight to lure Japanese from cash starts at the turnstile
summary: Apple plans to introduce FeliCa technology, a mobile tap-to-pay standard, in its upcoming iPhone in Japan to foster growth in digital payments. This move aims to boost iPhone sales by encouraging users to adopt Apple Pay and expand e-money usage in the country. Japan still predominantly uses cash, with only 17% of retail consumption made through non-cash payments, leaving room for growth in the digital payments market.

site_title: China's big banks set for hard slog as margins fall
summary: China's four "Big Five" state-owned banks, including Industrial and Commercial Bank of China (ICBC) and Bank of China (BOC), have warned of declining profits in the second half of the year due to slowing economic growth and increasing sour debt. The banks face lower interest margins and rising volumes of non-performing loans, prompting concerns of a government bailout. The central bank's rate cuts have chipped away at interest income, and the banks' core capital has slipped, raising the likelihood of a government intervention.

images.alt_text: ICBC, China's biggest bank by assets, on Tuesday reported near flat half-year profits, and has written off 44.8 billion yuan of bad debt in the first half.

site_title: Surprise surge in financial sector lending in July
summary: Singapore bank lending rose 1.1% in July, driven by a 11.9% surge in lending to financial institutions and a 5.7% increase in general commerce lending. This lifted business lending by 1.9% to S$352 billion, cushioning the 1.7% dip in construction lending. Consumer loans grew 2.2% year-over-year, while car loans contracted 0.2% and credit-card loans fell 1%. The growth in financial sector lending was attributed to yield-seeking by companies in response to Brexit concerns.

site_title: India dangles 10-year residence in return for investment
summary: India is offering 10-year residence to foreign investors who invest 100 million rupees (S$2 million) over 18 months or 250 million rupees over three years. The program aims to attract entrepreneurs to create jobs for the poor, particularly in manufacturing. Investors must create at least 20 jobs for resident Indians each financial year and can buy one residential property, allowing spouses and children to work or study. This move is seen as a step towards making India more attractive to foreign investors, but may not surpass destinations like Singapore and Hong Kong.

site_title: Time for Brexit doomsayers to revise their view
summary: The UK's decision to leave the European Union (EU) has defied initial predictions of economic disaster. Nine weeks after the referendum, house prices have not tumbled, interest rates have remained low, and unemployment has not risen. Shares have risen, and government bonds have soared. The only accurate forecast was the pound sterling's initial decline. The UK's economy appears to be more resilient than expected, contradicting the Treasury's dire predictions.

site_title: US human-resources startups betting on 'gig economy'
summary: US human-resources startups are capitalizing on the gig economy, attracting $1.2 billion in venture capital this year. Apps like Snagajob, Job Today, and CornerJob are connecting temporary workers with employers, with Snagajob doubling revenue in the past three years. The trend is driven by the blurring of lines between full-time and contract work, with companies opting for temps to avoid providing healthcare. Experts say the gig economy is here to stay, with alternative work arrangements accounting for net employment growth in the US from 2005 to 2015.

site_title: India's growth down sharply to 7.1% in Q1 from 7.9% in Q4 FY2015-16
summary: India's economic growth slowed to 7.1% in Q1 FY2016-17, down from 7.9% in Q4 FY2015-16, missing expectations. The country retained its position as the world's fastest-growing major economy, but sluggishness in the construction and mining sectors is cited as the cause. Economists expect an interest-rate cut, but the data has raised questions about the accuracy of India's GDP figures.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: DBS Group Holdings priced its US$750 million perpetual securities at 3.6% with an 8.7 times subscription rate. Roxy-Pacific Holdings bought a freehold residential site at Pasir Panjang Road for S$33.25 million. Swee Hong Ltd recorded three consecutive years of pre-tax losses and may be placed on a Singapore Exchange watch-list. Vallianz Holdings received letters from Swiber Holdings' interim judicial managers requesting approximately US$63.5 million in payments, which the company declined to make.

site_title: Entrepreneur who's no stranger to disruption
summary: Entrepreneur William Chew, founder of myHealth Sentinel, has shifted his focus from telehealth to connecting disparate healthcare ecosystem components through technology. After launching his startup in 2011, Chew initially aimed to create a "McDonald's of telehealth" but faced challenges in convincing patients and doctors to adopt the service. He later won a tender from the Health Ministry and IDA to develop a patient monitoring system, which has led to growth in revenue, expected to increase by 70% year-on-year. Chew emphasizes the importance of learning from past mistakes to drive future success.

site_title: Swee Hong gives notice that it meets criteria for SGX watch-list
summary: Swee Hong Ltd, an engineering group, has met the criteria for being placed on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) watch-list due to three consecutive years of pre-tax losses and a market capitalization below S$40 million. The company will make an immediate announcement if notified by SGX of its placement on the watch-list.

site_title: China pushes for green finance development
summary: China is pushing for the development of green finance to tackle environmental issues. The People's Bank of China and other government departments issued a joint statement on green finance, outlining measures to provide green funds, encourage environment-related investments, and develop green insurance. Chinese officials have made "green finance" a top priority, aiming to improve the country's patchy track record on environmental issues.

site_title: Vallianz declines requests for payments from Swiber totalling US$63.5m
summary: Vallianz Holdings has declined requests for payments of approximately US$63.5 million from Swiber Holdings and Swiber Offshore Construction, citing extended credit and netting off practices. The interim judicial managers of Swiber claim the funds are owed to the companies. Vallianz is awaiting a response and will make further announcements as necessary.

site_title: E-commerce to drive Asian plastics demand growth through 2017
