summary: Asia's plastics demand is expected to grow due to the region's e-commerce market expansion, with a projected 5.1% increase in demand for polyethylene in 2017. The demand is driven by online shopping and steady economic growth in countries such as Indonesia, Vietnam, and the Philippines. Asia's polyethylene demand is expected to reach 41 million tonnes in 2017, accounting for half the world's consumption, with China and India being the top consumers. This growth will defy a broader downturn in the petrochemicals sector and mitigate "go-green" efforts.

site_title: Giving the low-down on how to be a best employer
summary: Three companies - Mundipharma, OCBC Bank, and DBS - were featured in a roundtable discussion on becoming a best employer. The panelists agreed that becoming a best employer requires creating a high-performance culture, nurturing environment, and investing in talent development programs. They emphasized the importance of employee engagement, open communication, and inclusive work environments. Mundipharma focuses on diversity and fresh perspectives, OCBC Bank engages employees through various channels and programs, and DBS invests in digital skills and future-proofing employees. The companies have seen positive results, including low employee turnover, high employee engagement, and recognition as a best employer. They conclude that becoming a best employer is an ongoing journey, requiring continuous effort and investment in people and programs.

site_title: Debenture Note is interest-free loan to JTC that must be fully repaid
summary: A Singaporean entity, likely referring to a noteholder of Jurong Country Club Ltd (JCC), has expressed dissatisfaction with JTC's (Jurong Town Corporation) handling of a 1993 deal. The entity claims JTC's 280 new JCC memberships were not sold at a discounted price as initially stated. Instead, only 196 memberships were sold, resulting in a shortfall of 84 memberships, indicating the deal was not as "cheap" as claimed. The entity urges JTC to review the issue in a fair manner.

site_title: World's top-performing fund running out of good stocks to buy
summary: India's best-performing stock fund, DSP BlackRock Micro Cap Fund, is limiting client inflows due to a severe shortage of bargains in its market niche of Indian small-caps. The fund, which has produced a three-year return of 275%, has restricted daily inflows to 100,000 rupees per investor, citing concerns over high valuations. The fund's managers believe share prices have climbed too far, too fast, and are limiting their ability to build decent-sized positions. The move reflects growing apprehension towards India's economic revival under Prime Minister Narendra Modi.

site_title: Magical musical kicks off star-studded Venice fest
summary: Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone star in Damien Chazelle's La La Land, a musical tribute to the Golden Age of American musicals, which premiered at the Venice Film Festival on August 31, 2016. The film, described as a brand new start to the musical genre, is one of 20 films competing for the Golden Lion award. This year's festival features a US-heavy lineup, including Denzel Washington and Michael Fassbender, and includes a virtual-reality viewing salon, with La La Land among the films vying for the coveted award.

images.alt_text: Damien and Emma at the photocall for the movie "La La Land" at the 73rd Venice Film Festival on Wednesday. All eyes at the event will be on the jury for hints as to the next Oscar favourite.

site_title: Tourism industry keeps careful watch on Zika outbreak
summary: Singapore's tourism industry is closely monitoring the Zika outbreak, with some hotels reporting minor cancellations due to the virus. Despite the Health Ministry's 115 locally-transmitted Zika cases, tourism players expect the industry to remain unaffected, with hotels taking precautionary measures such as providing mosquito repellent and conducting daily checks for mosquito breeding sites. Travel advisories have been issued by several countries, including the US, China, and Taiwan, warning pregnant women against traveling to Singapore.

site_title: China will set up seven more free trade zones: Xinhua
summary: China will establish seven new free trade zones, bringing the total to 11, with locations in Liaoning, Zhejiang, Henan, Hubei, Sichuan, Shaanxi, and Chongqing. The decision to expand the zones demonstrates the government's commitment to advancing reforms and opening up. No opening date was provided, and a government think-tank expressed caution about the potential impact on China's financial system and real economy.

site_title: US to urge G20 to boost economies, pay attention to angry citizens
summary: US President Barack Obama will urge G20 leaders to boost economic growth and reduce excess capacity at steel factories, while addressing concerns about globalization and technology. The US will also press for universal banking services and phase out inefficient fuel subsidy programs. Obama's message aims to boost the living standards of poor and middle-class families, as well as address the concerns of anxious citizens who feel left behind by the global economic recovery.

site_title: Empathy for and outrage about Syria must be matched by action
summary: The Syrian refugee crisis, sparked by the 2011 civil war, has become a devastating humanitarian tragedy with the largest refugee crisis since World War II. The international community's response has been insufficient, with many citizens and right-wing anti-immigration parties in Europe taking advantage of the crisis to gain power. The crisis has had a significant impact on the geopolitical and geoeconomic balance of power, with global powers such as the US, Russia, and EU vying for influence in Syria. Unicef executive director Anthony Lake emphasizes that empathy and outrage must be matched by action to address the crisis.

site_title: Amazon Dash one-button ordering device arrives in UK
summary: Amazon is launching its one-button ordering device, Amazon Dash, in the UK, allowing British Prime customers to order household essentials with a single touch. The device, priced at £4.99, is dedicated to a single product and connects to wi-fi. Over 150 US brands have joined the service, with a three-fold increase in customer orders in the past two months. Amazon aims to automate the service, partnering with companies like Bosch and Siemens to integrate Dash Replenishment into their products.

site_title: Opec oil output hits record as Gulf gains counter African losses
summary: Opec's oil output is expected to reach a record in August, driven by increased production from Saudi Arabia and other Gulf members to offset losses in Nigeria and Libya. Saudi Arabia's production has likely reached a fresh record, meeting seasonally higher domestic demand and maintaining market share. Other major Middle Eastern producers also boosted output, contributing to the expected record output.

site_title: PwC fined over botched audit of UK lender Cattles
summary: British accountant PwC has been fined over 3 million pounds for its botched 2007 audit of UK lender Cattles, which failed to detect a deep hole in the company's books. PwC partner Simon Bradburn was also fined 75,600 pounds. The Financial Reporting Council issued a severe reprimand, stating that both PwC and Bradburn failed to uphold high standards and were "deliberately misled by third parties." The audit led to a seven-year inquiry and a confidential settlement with Cattles' creditors in 2015.

site_title: US private sector adds 177,000 jobs in August: ADP
summary: US private sector added 177,000 jobs in August, exceeding economists' expectations of 175,000. July's private payroll gains were revised up to 194,000. The ADP National Employment Report, jointly developed with Moody's Analytics, comes ahead of the US Labor Department's more comprehensive non-farm payrolls report on Friday. Economists expect US private payroll employment to have grown 178,000 jobs in August, with the unemployment rate forecast to tick down to 4.8% from 4.9% the previous month.

site_title: JTC: Purchase offer is consistent with market practice
summary: JTC has made an offer to purchase notes issued by Jurong Country Club Limited, with an offer price of S$84,200 per note, 17 years before their maturity date of Sept 1, 2033. The offer, made using the discounted cash-flow method, takes into account the risk-free rate of Singapore government bonds. This decision allows noteholders to monetize their notes early, and JTC has assured them that the offer does not affect their rights as members of the club. The offer is voluntary and noteholders can choose to hold the notes to maturity or accept the offer.

site_title: First case of pregnant woman with Zika in Singapore; Bedok North Ave 3 potential new cluster
summary: A pregnant woman in Singapore's Bedok area has been confirmed with Zika, marking the first case of a pregnant woman in the country. This follows another 24 confirmed cases of Zika infections as of August 31. The patient lives in the Aljunied area, where a household member had earlier tested positive for the virus. This new case raises concerns about a potential new cluster, with public health officials closely monitoring the situation.

site_title: Payment company Nets to announce listing plan on Thursday: sources
summary: Denmark-based payment company Nets plans to announce its initial public offering (IPO) on Thursday, following its acquisition by private equity firms in 2014. The actual listing is expected in September, with a potential market capitalization of 30-35 billion crowns (S$6.07-6.35 billion). This marks the company's first attempt at going public, following a similar path taken by British payments processor Worldpay Group last year.

images.alt_text: Denmark-based card payment services company Nets will announce its plan for an initial public offering (IPO) on Thursday, two people involved in the process said on Wednesday.

site_title: G-20 summit: China to focus on positives
summary: China is set to focus on long-term goals at the G-20 summit in Hangzhou, prioritizing sustainable growth, innovation, and connectivity over immediate concerns. The summit offers China's leader Xi Jinping an opportunity to promote its vision for global order, with China's influence expected to surpass that of the US. China's goals include completing IMF reform, strengthening international anti-corruption efforts, and industrializing Africa. The country also seeks to establish the G-20 as an international institution with a secretariat and links to other organizations, including the UN.

site_title: China financial minister says local govt debt swaps at 2.96t yuan Jan-Jul: Xinhua
summary: China's minister of finance reported that municipal bond issuance under the local government debt swap programme reached 2.96 trillion yuan (S$598.41 billion) in the first seven months of 2016. This is nearly as large as the total swap volume for 2015. The ministry plans to strengthen risk controls, improve debt calculation methods, and intensify oversight of issuance to address concerns over irregular debt issuance.

site_title: US housing market turnover to improve over coming year
summary: US housing market turnover is expected to improve over the coming year, with a majority of analysts forecasting steady house price gains of 5.2% this year and 4.6% next year. The strong job market and low mortgage rates are driving optimism, with the Federal Reserve likely to raise interest rates gradually. Existing home sales are forecast to rise, and the housing market is expected to remain relatively affordable, with a median affordability rating of 6 out of 10. However, many young buyers are still priced out of the market due to high student debt.

site_title: Mao Zedong: great leader or destroyer?
summary: Mao Zedong's legacy is being reevaluated on the 40th anniversary of his death. Despite being worshipped as a great leader, his rule was marked by widespread starvation and deaths of tens of millions of Chinese. The Communist Party of China's resolution on Mao's rule omitted the scale of the disaster, instead focusing on inner-party struggles. Scholars estimate that at least 45 million deaths occurred during his rule, including the Great Leap Forward and Cultural Revolution. Mao's posthumous legacy remains a topic of debate, with some questioning how history would have viewed him if he had not lived to be 82.

site_title: Ascott Reit gets new chairman
summary: Ascott Residence Trust has appointed Tan Beng Hai as its new chairman, replacing Lim Jit Poh, effective September 1, 2016. Tan, an independent director and Fellow of the Institute of Chartered Accountants in England and Wales, will also lead the Corporate Disclosure Committee and step down from the Audit Committee.

site_title: India unveils a US$1.5 million investor visa to spur expansion
summary: India has introduced a US$1.5 million investor visa, offering 10-year permanent residency to foreigners investing 100 million rupees (S$2 million) or 250 million rupees over three years. The move aims to attract foreign entrepreneurs, particularly in manufacturing, and create jobs for the poor. The proposal, unveiled by Finance Minister Arun Jaitley, comes as India's economy grows at a 7.6% rate, but still lags behind countries like Singapore and Hong Kong in terms of ease of doing business.

site_title: Payment firm Nets to announce IPO plan: sources
summary: Denmark-based payment firm Nets plans to announce an initial public offering (IPO) on Thursday, according to sources. The intention to float has been targeted since 2014, following the acquisition by private equity firms and a Danish pension fund. Nets handled over 7 billion card transactions last year and is expected to have a market capitalization of 30-35 billion kroner (S$6.1-8.6 billion). The actual listing is planned for September, with a prospectus to follow within weeks.

site_title: Roxy-Pacific to buy Harbour View Gardens for S$33.25m
summary: Roxy-Pacific Holdings has agreed to buy the freehold residential site at Harbour View Gardens in Pasir Panjang Road for S$33.25 million. The site has an estimated 30,745 square feet land area and a plot ratio of 1.4 for residential development. The purchase is conditional upon obtaining an "order for sale" from the Strata Titles Board or the High Court. Roxy-Pacific will finance the acquisition using internal funds and bank loans.

site_title: Chinese purchases of Hong Kong insurance surges to all-time high
summary: Chinese residents purchased Hong Kong insurance at a record HK$16.9 billion in the second quarter, more than doubling from HK$7.1 billion a year earlier. This surge comes despite China's regulators limiting insurance sales to sidestep capital controls. For the first half of the year, sales to Chinese residents reached HK$30.1 billion, accounting for 37% of new individual premiums in Hong Kong.

site_title: Worst is over for oil as investment at risk, IHS's Yergin says
summary: Oil prices are expected to rise to the "mid-$50 range" next year, according to IHS Markit's Vice Chairman Daniel Yergin, as the global oversupply diminishes. US crude production is set to fall another "couple of hundred thousand" barrels a day by the end of this year, and the market is rebalancing. Yergin stated that the worst for oil prices is over, but a persisting supply glut may pin prices at half the levels of two years ago, potentially leading to investment issues in the future.

images.alt_text: The worst has passed for oil prices, which are now too low to ensure investment in the new supplies needed during the rest of the decade, IHS Markit Ltd's Vice Chairman Daniel Yergin said.

site_title: Bill Gross steps up criticism of Fed, central banks for zero rates
summary: Bill Gross criticizes the Federal Reserve and central banks for their zero interest rate policies, calling it "market manipulation." He accuses Chair Janet Yellen and her predecessors of prioritizing asset price elevation over the real economy. Gross warns that ultra-loose policies keep "zombie" corporations alive and inhibit "creative destruction." He also notes that $11 trillion of negative-yielding bonds are liabilities, not assets, and that investors are walking on thin ice due to high global debt and outdated monetary policies.

site_title: Eurozone inflation, jobless figures steady
summary: Eurozone inflation and jobless rates remained steady in August, with consumer prices rising 0.2% and unemployment at 10.1%. This data fell short of analyst forecasts, suggesting the European Central Bank may need to adopt more stimulus measures to boost the economy. The steady rates indicate the Eurozone is "bumping along," according to the article, highlighting the ongoing economic challenges in the region.

images.alt_text: Eurozone inflation and jobless data on Wednesday fell short of analyst forecasts as the economy bumps along amid speculation the European Central Bank will have to adopt more stimulus measures.

site_title: Singapore shares close lower amid pressure on oil & gas
summary: Singapore shares slipped 0.3% on Wednesday, closing at 2,820.59, due to pressure in the oil and gas sector. Ezion Holdings and Ezra Holdings fell 6.4% and 2.5%, respectively. Losers outnumbered gainers 195 to 168, with Singapore Telecommunications dropping 2%. The Straits Times Index (STI) has been experiencing a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, with stocks showing resilience despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: India growth slows sharply to 7.1% in April-June quarter
summary: India's economic growth slowed to 7.1% in the April-June quarter, missing expectations but retaining its position as the world's fastest-growing major economy. The slowdown was attributed to sluggishness in the construction and mining sectors. Economists predicted a slight slowdown to 7.6% but welcomed the data as a possible indication of an interest rate cut. Despite the slowdown, India's inflation remains under control at around 6%. The government has signaled a message of continuity with the appointment of new RBI governor Urjit Patel, who may consider cutting interest rates to boost growth.

site_title: MMP Resources to raise S$1.3m for Japan expansion through share placement
summary: MMP Resources plans to raise S$1.3 million through a share placement to fund its expansion into Japan. The company has entered into a share agreement with Vessel Gate Investment Pte Ltd to issue 185.7 million new shares at 0.7 Singapore cent apiece. The proceeds will be used for further strategy implementation in Japan and exploring joint ventures with Alliance Brands Limited. The subscription shares represent about 9.77% of MMP's enlarged share capital.

site_title: SIA appoints new independent director
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) appointed Lee Kim Shin as an independent non-executive director, effective Sept 1, 2016. Lee, a member of the Duke-NUS Medical School governing board and Singapore Institute of Directors' governing council, will join the Board Nominating Committee and Board Safety & Risk Committee. Directors Christina Ong and Lucien Wong Yuen Kuai will retire on the same date, having joined the board in 2007.

site_title: Indonesia central bank eases property loan rules to spur spending
summary: Indonesia's central bank, Bank Indonesia, has eased property loan rules to boost spending amid sluggish economic growth. The bank lowered the minimum down payment for first, second, and third homes to 15%, 20%, and 25%, respectively. The move aims to increase credit growth and combat declining housing loans. To implement the changes, banks must maintain net non-performing loan rates below 5% and gross non-performing loan rates below 5% of property loans. This is the second time the central bank has eased property loan rules in two years.

site_title: Norway fund pays US$453m for stakes in San Francisco office buildings
summary: Norway's $888 billion sovereign wealth fund has purchased $453 million stakes in two San Francisco office buildings, owned by Kilroy Realty Corporation. The fund acquired 44% of the properties, while Kilroy retains 56%. The deal marks a significant investment in the US real estate market.

images.alt_text: Norway's US$888 billion sovereign wealth fund, the world's biggest, has bought stakes worth US$453 million in two office properties in San Francisco, the fund's manager said on Wednesday

site_title: Canada to join China-led infrastructure bank in Win for Xi
summary: Canada is set to join China's $100 billion Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB), marking a diplomatic victory for President Xi Jinping ahead of the G20 summit. This move makes Canada the first North American country to join the bank. The decision comes after China agreed to ease restrictions on Canadian canola exports earlier in the day.

images.alt_text: Canada will join China's new US$100 billion Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB), a diplomatic victory for President Xi Jinping just before he hosts the Group of 20 summit.

site_title: BOC Aviation orders five new Airbus A321 aircraft, for leasing to Asian airline
summary: BOC Aviation has ordered five new Airbus A321-200 aircraft, all leased to an Asian airline, with deliveries scheduled for 2017. The list price is approximately $574.5 million, paid in cash in five instalments prior to delivery. This incremental order reflects the popularity of the A320 family among customers, with BOC Aviation's cumulative Airbus orders reaching 311 aircraft.

site_title: UOB latches onto 500m yuan in Asean-Chongqing investment flows in 2016
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) has facilitated over 500 million yuan (S$102 million) in cross-border investments between Chongqing and Southeast Asia since 2016, with 90% of the investments going to Singapore. The number of companies supported by UOB's Chongqing branch has increased by 35% in the last seven months, primarily from the automotive, trading, and services sectors. This growth follows the Sino-Singapore Chongqing Connectivity Initiative, which aims to promote regional economic ties. UOB's branch manager expects the demand for cross-border financial solutions to continue growing.

site_title: Samsung Card to buy back 253.6b won worth of its own shares
summary: Samsung Card Co Ltd plans to buy back 253.6 billion won (S$308.9 million) worth of its own shares between Sept 1 and Nov 30 to boost shareholder value. The company will purchase 5.79 million shares during this period. This move aims to increase shareholder value and is part of the company's strategy to enhance its financial position.

site_title: Sterling boosted by consumer confidence and housing data
summary: Sterling rose on Wednesday, boosted by improved consumer confidence and rising British house prices in August, defying expectations. The GfK consumer confidence gauge rose to -7, the second-lowest since early 2014, and British house prices rose 5.6% in August, faster than July's 5.2%. These positive economic indicators contrast with the UK's post-Brexit economic uncertainty, suggesting the economy may be holding up better than anticipated.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks rally, led by exporters
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 0.97% on Wednesday, driven by a weaker yen that boosted exporters like Toyota and Nissan. Despite below-par factory output data, the Nikkei 225 index closed at 16,887.40, while the Topix index gained 1.27%. The rally offset concerns about Japan's stalled economy.

site_title: DC rates raised for non-landed residential, commercial and hotel/hospital uses
summary: The Singapore government has increased development charge (DC) rates for non-landed residential, commercial, and hotel/hospital uses, effective Sept 1, 2016. The rates have been raised by 2.7% for non-landed residential, 0.6% for commercial, and 1.4% for hotels and hospitals. DC rates remain unchanged for landed residential, industrial, and other use groups. The changes are part of the Ministry of National Development's twice-yearly review of DC rates, which affects 118 geographical sectors in Singapore.

site_title: SingPost inks e-commerce logistics deal with POST Luxembourg
summary: SingPost has signed a strategic collaboration agreement with POST Luxembourg to provide e-commerce logistics solutions between Asia and Europe, starting September. The deal allows for end-to-end tracking and more predictable delivery times, increasing customer satisfaction. SingPost CEO Mervyn Lim stated that the collaboration enhances the company's global e-commerce logistics ecosystem. The partnership will benefit customers of both companies, with SingPost gaining a European gateway and POST Luxembourg a new gateway to Asia.

site_title: Hong Kong shares end lower, Shanghai up
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell 0.17% to 22,976.88, following losses on Wall Street, while Shanghai stocks rose 0.35% to 3,085.49. The gains in Shanghai were attributed to a mix of mining and healthcare stocks. The Shenzhen Composite Index also rose 0.22%.

site_title: Europe: Stocks fall slightly at open
summary: European stock markets fell slightly at the start of trading on Wednesday, with the FTSE 100 index down just a couple of points to 6,818.72. The eurozone's DAX 30 and Paris CAC 40 indices also declined, while Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index rose almost one percent due to a weaker yen.

site_title: Market capitalisation
summary: NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. US stocks opened lower due to Trump's fresh tariff salvo on Canada. Creative Technology warned of possible H2 revenue below target and an operating loss similar to H1. London's Heathrow plans to increase fees for a £10 billion upgrade. An Indonesian court detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case. Tan Teck Long, a former DBS veteran, is set to become OCBC's incoming CEO. MAS and PBOC will deepen cooperation in green and transition finance. Singapore stocks experienced a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Myanmar's Suu Kyi kicks off peace conference with appeal for unity
summary: Myanmar's Aung San Suu Kyi launched a peace conference, appealing for unity among ethnic minorities and the military to end decades of fighting. The conference, attended by representatives from various rebel groups, aims to discuss security, representation, and resource control. Suu Kyi emphasized the importance of unity in achieving peace, while military chief Senior General Min Aung Hlaing expressed optimism about the talks. Despite the challenges, the conference marks a significant step forward, with powerful armed groups participating, partly due to China's support.

site_title: Deutsche Bank considered Commerzbank merger, Magazin reports
summary: Deutsche Bank explored a merger with Commerzbank in a theoretical and early-stage consideration, according to a German magazine report. The move comes as the German lender is restructuring to bolster profitability, with thousands of job cuts and scrapped dividend payments. Deutsche Bank shares have dropped 43% this year, and the bank's CEO, John Cryan, is scheduled to speak at a conference in Frankfurt. The consideration of a merger was not confirmed by a Deutsche Bank spokesman.

site_title: Singapore urges tests for pregnant women with Zika signs
summary: Singapore has urged all pregnant women showing symptoms of fever or rashes to be tested for the Zika virus, with 82 cases reported in the city-state. The US and Britain have also advised pregnant women to avoid non-essential travel to Singapore, where authorities are expanding a fumigation campaign to eradicate mosquitoes that spread the disease. The health ministry has advised pregnant women to take precautions against mosquito bites and seek medical attention immediately if symptoms appear.

site_title: Revised insurance premium payment framework to start from Sept 1
summary: The General Insurance Association of Singapore (GIA) has announced changes to the premium payment framework, effective September 1, to minimize claim disputes. The revised framework requires premiums to be paid on or before the inception date or renewal of coverage. Failure to pay premiums by then will result in no cover and benefits will not be payable. This change aims to reduce disputes between insurers and customers regarding delayed or non-payment of premiums.

site_title: Japan's METI seeks to expand support for energy-saving efforts
summary: Japan's Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry (METI) is seeking to allocate 206 billion yen (S$2.72 billion) for energy-saving efforts, a 33% increase from the previous year. The allocation includes 42.5 billion yen for Fukushima's clean energy expansion, 10.4 billion yen for fuel cell subsidies, and 250 million yen for examining carbon pricing. The plan aims to promote the use of clean energy in local communities and support the development of hydrogen production technologies using renewables.

site_title: There were signs pointing to Swiber's troubles before collapse: S&P Global
summary: Swiber Holdings, a marine engineering firm, collapsed due to a prolonged slump in global crude oil prices, high leverage, and financial struggles. S&P Global Ratings found that Swiber's financial ratios and liquidity profile were typical of companies with high default risk, making it 20x more likely to default within a year. The rating agency warned that the possibility of further credit stress and defaults in the sector remains, citing the vulnerability of oil and gas companies to market fluctuations and high debt levels.

images.alt_text: Swiber Holdings' failure was a result of a protracted slump in global crude oil prices hitting its earnings and the marine engineering firm's high leverage, S&P Global Ratings said on Wednesday.

site_title: ECB should stick to current policy stance: Villeroy
summary: French central bank chief Francois Villeroy de Galhau stated that the European Central Bank (ECB) should maintain its current monetary policy stance, exercising caution. Villeroy emphasized that European governments must also contribute to reviving growth, as the ECB alone cannot achieve sustainable growth. He rejected helicopter money as a tool for cautious policy, instead advising a more balanced approach.

site_title: South Korean prosecutors summon Lotte Group family member
summary: South Korean prosecutors summoned Shin Dong-joo, the elder son of Lotte Group founder Shin Kyuk-ho, for questioning as part of a resumed investigation into the conglomerate. The probe was restarted after the suicide of Lotte vice chairman Lee In-won last week. Prosecutors were initially looking into a possible slush fund and breach of trust involving transactions among Lotte's companies, which had raided the company's offices in June.

images.alt_text: South Korean prosecutors summoned the elder son of the founder of Lotte Group for questioning on Thursday, signalling the resumption of a criminal probe against the conglomerate following the suicide of a senior executive last week.

site_title: Seoul: Won ends higher on exporter US dollar sales; stocks edge down
summary: The South Korean won ended higher on Wednesday, up 0.5% to 1,114.8 to the US dollar, as exporters' US dollar sales supported the currency. This marked a third straight month of gains, with the currency up 0.4%. Meanwhile, South Korean shares edged down 0.3% to 2,034.65 points, with Kospi shares rising 0.8% for the month.

site_title: Brexit can't free Britain from sharing EU costs, Denmark warns
summary: Denmark's Finance Minister Claus Hjort Frederiksen warned that Britain shouldn't be allowed to stop paying EU project costs, as negotiations to leave the bloc are underway. The UK will inherit ongoing projects and can't turn their backs on costs, Frederiksen stated. This warning comes ahead of talks on how to extract the UK from the 28-nation EU bloc.

site_title: China's steel mills hunt for high-grade iron ore to boost output
summary: China's steel mills are seeking high-grade iron ore to boost output and meet environmental standards, driving a premium for high-quality ore to its highest in two years. The preference for high-grade ore is expected to benefit top miners such as Vale and Rio Tinto, while contributing to growing stockpiles at domestic ports. China's steel prices have risen following mill closures and output curbs, buoying mills' profitability and increasing demand for premium iron ore.

site_title: China Eastern sign code-share deal with British Airways to boost sales overseas
summary: China Eastern Airlines signed a code-sharing deal with British Airways to boost overseas sales. The deal allows passengers to connect on seven Chinese and seven British routes, including flights to London Heathrow and cities in China. The agreement aims to strengthen the network between Europe and China, and comes as China Eastern seeks to expand its overseas business. This move is also seen as a response to the declining profits of China Eastern's main domestic rivals, Air China and China Southern Airlines.

images.alt_text: China Eastern Airlines Corp Ltd said on Wednesday it has signed a code-sharing deal with British Airways (BA) for flights on seven Chinese and seven British routes, a move China Eastern said could boost sales outside its home base.

site_title: VW could agree US large-car diesel fix by October
summary: Volkswagen's global Audi sales chief, Dietmar Voggenreiter, said discussions with US authorities over large-engined diesel cars that cheat emissions tests are progressing well. A technical and financial settlement could be agreed by October, with the latest possible agreement being in the beginning of November. This comes after the US Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) announced plans to fine Volkswagen up to $40 billion for the emissions cheating scandal.

images.alt_text: Volkswagen AG's global Audi sales chief said on Wednesday that talks with US authorities over large-engined diesel cars found to have cheated emissions tests are progressing well and a technical and financial settlement could be agreed as soon as October.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Bank lending in Singapore rose 1.1% in July, driven by loans to financial institutions and trade sectors. Meanwhile, interest rates for non-landed residential, commercial, and hotel/hospital uses were raised. Overseas news included Vietnam's surprise reaction to US tariffs, a Malaysian agency's plan to seize Daim Zainuddin's assets, and China's GDP growth expected to slow. Citigroup predicted a mid-2026 target of 1,150 for the global equity index. In other news, Thailand's Thaksin Shinawatra expressed confidence in his daughter's suspension as PM being cleared, and the UK economy contracted for the second month in a row.

site_title: India growth threatened by business 'roadblocks': Kerry
summary: US Secretary of State John Kerry warns that India's economy growth is threatened by excessive bureaucracy and red tape, hindering entrepreneurs and foreign investors. Despite being the world's fastest-growing major economy, India must improve its business climate to create jobs for its rapidly increasing labor force. Kerry urges the government to streamline regulations, ensure transparency, and create a level playing field to attract investment capital. India aims to improve its ranking in the World Bank's ease of doing business league table, currently ranked 130th.

site_title: Three arrested in Malaysia over planned attacks on eve of independence day
summary: Malaysian police arrested three local supporters of the Islamic State militant group who planned to attack an entertainment center, a Hindu temple, and a police station on the eve of independence day. The suspects, who received instructions from a Malaysian Islamic State fighter, had allegedly planned to join the group in Syria after carrying out the attacks. A grenade and handgun were seized, and the suspects, a lorry driver, butcher, and drinks seller, are believed to have been planning to leave for Syria. This brings the total number of arrests linked to Islamic State in Malaysia to 230 since 2013.

site_title: Saudi Arabia will maintain responsible oil production policy: Falih
summary: Saudi Arabia's energy minister, Khalid al-Falih, stated that the country will maintain a responsible oil production policy, meeting customer needs without targeting a specific production figure. Despite low crude prices, al-Falih expressed confidence in the demand for oil, citing China's "very healthy" demand. Saudi Arabia pumped a record 10.67 million barrels per day in July, with a production capacity of 12.5 million barrels per day, allowing it to boost output in case of global outages. The country's policy prioritizes meeting customer needs over production targets.

site_title: British house price rises pick up speed in August: mortage lender
summary: British house prices rose 5.6% in August compared to the same month last year, exceeding expectations, according to Nationwide. This marks a faster increase than July's 5.2%. The rise is attributed to a shortage in the market, outweighing the impact of the Brexit vote and a recent tax increase. Economists had forecast a 4.8% rise.

images.alt_text: British house price rises picked up speed and increased more quickly than expected in August as a shortage in the market outweighed the impact of Britain's Brexit vote and a recent tax increase, mortgage lender Nationwide said on Wednesday.

site_title: Kerry calls on China, Philippines to abide by tribunal ruling on South China Sea
summary: US Secretary of State John Kerry urged China and the Philippines to abide by an international tribunal's decision on the disputed South China Sea region, calling for respect for international law and regional stability. The remarks come ahead of a G20 summit in China, where Beijing plans to outline a global growth strategy, potentially overshadowed by territorial disputes and protectionism. Kerry's comments aim to uphold the existing rules-based international order and promote regional prosperity.

site_title: US auto sales seen sliding for August on dialled-down discounts
summary: US auto sales are expected to decline in August due to automakers scaling back discounts, potentially marking the first annual sales drop in seven years. Industrywide sales may fall 3.5% in August, with Ford, GM, and Volkswagen brands expected to see significant declines. Despite this, buyers remain loyal to pickups and SUVs, driving sales in these categories. Honda bucked the trend with car sales rising 6.8% in July, attributing the growth to improved models rather than incentives.

site_title: China's hottest property market imposes curbs to cool prices
summary: China's southern city of Xiamen has imposed curbs to cool its property market, banning local buyers who already own two residences from purchasing homes and non-residents from buying a second house. The curbs, effective from September 5 to the end of 2017, apply to homes smaller than 144 sq m. This move is part of a broader effort by Chinese cities to curb soaring property prices, which have led to concerns about market bubbles. The curbs aim to stabilize the market and prevent further price increases.

site_title: China's yuan edges up in cautious mood on fear of intervention
summary: China's yuan edged up against the US dollar on Wednesday, trading at 6.6904 per dollar, due to investor caution about potential central bank intervention. The currency had previously fallen below 6.7 in mid-July, prompting state-owned banks to aggressively sell US dollars. The People's Bank of China set the midpoint rate at 6.6908 per dollar, and the offshore yuan was trading 0.19% weaker than the onshore spot. This move was seen as a sign that Chinese authorities are reluctant to see the yuan breach the 6.7 mark again.

site_title: Taiwan: Shares fall, Mega Financial down after chairman quits
summary: Taiwan's main Taiex index fell 0.2% to 9,091.60 on Wednesday, following a decline in overseas markets. Shares in Mega Financial Holding dropped 1.1% after chairman Shiu Kuang-si resigned amid investigations into anti-money laundering violations and a US fine of $180 million. The Taiwanese firm is being investigated for potential breaches of local laws. The Taiwan dollar softened to NT$31.722 per US dollar.

site_title: New members appointed to Iras board
summary: The Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (Iras) has appointed four new members to its board, effective September 1, 2016, including Adam Abdur Rahman, Ng Wai Choong, Sum Yee Loong, and Tan Boon Gin. Four existing board members were also reappointed. Dr. Lee Kwok Cheong, Pek Hak Bin, and Pok Soy Yoong will retire after serving six years each. The new appointments aim to bring diverse expertise to the board, which also includes chairman Tan Ching Yee and Iras CEO Tan Tee How.

site_title: G20 to go long on rhetoric, short on economic policy: experts
summary: G20 leaders will meet in China, focusing on making the world economy "innovative, invigorated, interconnected, and inclusive". However, given the economic uncertainty and sluggish global growth, breakthroughs are unlikely. Experts say there's a lack of common interests among major economies, and compliance with past pledges has fallen to 63%. The G20's failure to deliver on promises has raised questions about its credibility, and its mission of strong, sustainable, balanced growth remains unachieved. Beijing is expected to push for long-term agreements on lower-key matters, including eco-friendly projects and infrastructure spending.

site_title: Mystery of oil held on Chinese islands puzzles crude markets
summary: China's oil stockpiles have puzzled global markets, with the government refusing to disclose details on its strategic petroleum reserves. The country has been buying record amounts of crude, helping to recover oil prices from a historic crash, but its intentions remain unclear. Analysts estimate China's stockpiles could be filled by August, potentially leading to a drop in imports. However, the government's ability to shift oil between commercial and strategic storage sites may allow it to continue buying, even if its own storage capacity is full.

site_title: Australian banks dodge bullet as parliament rejects sweeping probe
summary: Australia's parliament rejected a motion for a sweeping Royal Commission into bank misconduct, instead approving a limited inquiry into mistreatment of small business customers. The government's decision, made with its one-seat majority, was seen as a relief for the country's four major banks, which control 80% of lending. Despite this, opposition leader Bill Shorten accused the government of "running a protection racket" for the big banks, and another scandal could revive calls for a Royal Commission. The government has instead implemented various reforms and strengthened oversight to address public concerns.

site_title: Gold heads for monthly decline as Fed rate fears damp its appeal
summary: Gold prices are expected to decline for the first time in 7 months, with investors anticipating higher US borrowing costs and slowing purchases of bullion-backed exchange-traded funds. The metal is down 2.8% this month, with Fed Vice Chairman Stanley Fischer expressing optimism about productivity growth and the timing of interest-rate increases. Investors are closely watching the nonfarm payrolls report on Friday for further insight into the US economy and rate hike timing, with odds of a December rate hike at 59%.

site_title: Bank lending in Singapore up 1.1% in July on loans to financial, trade sectors
summary: Bank lending in Singapore rose 1.1% in July, driven by a surge in loans to financial institutions and trade sectors. This is the strongest month-on-month jump since June 2015. Business loans increased 1.9% to S$352 billion, while lending to financial institutions jumped 11.9% to S$75.8 billion. Consumer loans remained flat at S$245 billion. From a year ago, bank lending was down 2.2%.

site_title: Google said to tie up with MUFG on Android Pay mobile payments
summary: Google is partnering with Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group (MUFG) to integrate MUFG's debit cards with Android Pay, a mobile payments platform. The tie-up aims to tap Japan's rapidly growing digital payments market. Users of certain Android-based mobile phones will be able to make transactions using MUFG's debit cards starting in Japan's autumn. This collaboration follows Apple's reported plans to include FeliCa technology in its next iPhones in Japan, which is a mobile tap-to-pay standard developed by Sony Corp.

site_title: China stock traders bet US$305m on military tensions
summary: China's stock investors are betting $305 million on military tensions, with exchange-traded funds (ETFs) tracking the CSI National Defense Industry Index rising 18% since its May low. The funds are capitalizing on escalating geopolitical tensions, including China's territorial disputes and the US deployment of an anti-ballistic missile system in South Korea. Analysts predict the ETFs will outperform the broader market if tensions continue, citing a positive outlook for China's military industry and potential budget increases.

site_title: Malaysia: Markets closed for National Day
summary: Malaysia's financial markets closed on August 31 for National Day and will resume trading on September 1. This article is not relevant to the topic and appears to be a collection of unrelated news articles about various financial markets and companies.

site_title: Elections, running clock frustrate Obama's trade deals
summary: President Barack Obama's two major trade deals, the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) and the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP), are facing significant hurdles due to electoral politics in the US and Europe. Despite being negotiated, both deals are unlikely to be completed by the end of Obama's term in January 2017, with analysts estimating they will likely be stalled until at least 2018. The US presidential and congressional elections have soured the political atmosphere, with both presidential candidates opposing the deals.

site_title: India said to mull 100-million-rupee investor visa to spur growth
summary: India is considering a 100-million-rupee (S$2 million) investor visa to attract foreign entrepreneurs, offering 10-year permanent residency in exchange for investment. The proposal, unveiled by Finance Minister Arun Jaitley, aims to woo investment in manufacturing and create jobs for the poor. However, critics argue that the nation's complex rules and infrastructure issues may deter investors, and alternative destinations such as Canada may be preferred.

site_title: Australia tells new lawmakers to take cautious view of Chinese investment
summary: Australia's non-partisan parliamentary library has issued a briefing book warning lawmakers to be cautious when considering Chinese investments, citing concerns over China's long-term aim to create a Eurasia-wide bloc to counter the US. The move comes after Treasurer Scott Morrison blocked two Chinese investment deals citing national security concerns. China is Australia's largest trading partner, but the US has raised concerns over a Chinese lease of a northern Australian port. The briefing book advises lawmakers to adopt a more economically and strategically prudent attitude when evaluating the Australia-China economic relationship.

site_title: Singapore Land Authority launches online service MyProperty
summary: The Singapore Land Authority (SLA) has launched an online service, MyProperty, allowing property owners to view their title deeds and boundary plans without charge. Previously, members had to pay a fee to access this information. The service is available at www.sla.gov.sg/MyProperty and includes private property titles and about 130,000 HDB property titles. Additional features, such as updating personal data and receiving online alerts, are expected to be rolled out in phases.

site_title: New Clinton e-mails to be reviewed for link to Benghazi attack
summary: A federal judge ordered the US State Department to disclose how many of 30 newly discovered Hillary Clinton e-mails relate to the 2012 Benghazi attack within a week. The e-mails were recovered by the FBI and are part of a Freedom of Information Act lawsuit by Judicial Watch Inc. The State Department must file a report by September 6, disclosing the number of responsive documents and a schedule for their release. The discovery comes as Clinton's presidential campaign nears its end.

site_title: Korea's Hanjin Shipping becomes symbol of industry in pain
summary: Hanjin Shipping Co, South Korea's largest container-shipping company, has filed for court receivership after lenders rejected its restructuring proposal, citing an insufficient plan to address its cash shortage. The company, which is struggling due to heavy losses and oversupply of vessels, may need up to 1.3 trillion won (S$1.64 billion) in cash to roll over debt. This move highlights the industry's struggles since the 2008 global financial crisis, with companies trying various measures such as mergers, acquisitions, and cost cuts to stay afloat.

site_title: Australia: Shares dragged down by basic materials - oil, NZ flat
summary: Australian shares fell 0.97% to their lowest in six weeks, closing at 5424.9, as the US dollar strengthened ahead of US jobs data. Basic materials and energy stocks led the losses, with mining majors BHP and Rio Tinto down 3.2% each. Oil stocks also declined on weaker crude oil futures. New Zealand's benchmark index remained flat. The decline was attributed to traders seeking to hedge against potential US interest rate hikes.

site_title: Australian dollar near 1-month lows, kiwi boosted by business confidence
summary: The Australian dollar traded near one-month lows at US$0.7521, following upbeat US data and the risk of a near-term Federal Reserve rate hike. The Aussie has been on a downtrend since hitting a near 3.5-month high in August. In contrast, the New Zealand dollar rose to US$0.7244, boosted by business confidence data, while the kiwi gained against the Aussie, slipping to a seven-week trough of NZ$1.0376. The Fed's case for a rate increase is strengthening, according to Chair Janet Yellen.

site_title: South Korea's July factory output rebounds, focus turns to trade
summary: South Korea's industrial output unexpectedly rose 1.4% in July, mainly due to temporary factors, despite analysts' forecasts of a decline. Electronic components and car production boosted activity, while improving exports and shipments aided production. The median forecast for the quarter is 3.0% growth, with the economy expanding 3.2% in the second quarter. Service sector output declined 0.7% in July, but is expected to improve.

site_title: Australia's opposition moves motion for Royal Commission into banks
summary: Australia's opposition leader Bill Shorten moved a motion for a Royal Commission into the banking system due to allegations of misconduct, including financial planning scams and insurance fraud. The government has opposed the inquiry, but Shorten argued that a Royal Commission has the necessary coercive powers and jurisdiction to address bank misconduct. This comes after similar inquiries were convened for institutional child sexual abuse and corruption in the building trades. The opposition's motion aims to hold banks accountable for their actions.

site_title: Seoul: Won, stocks tread water; major economies' data awaited
summary: South Korea's won and shares made minimal movements on Wednesday, with investors waiting for major economies' data releases, particularly the US August jobs report. The won rose 0.3% to 1,116.7, while the Kospi index fell 0.3% to 2,034.60 points. Offshore investors were moderate sellers, with a net 18.5 billion Korean won sold. Shipping company Hyundai Merchant Marine Co Ltd gained 8.9%, while Korean Air Lines Co Ltd rose 5.8% after Hanjin Shipping Co Ltd filed for court receivership.

site_title: Berlin's IFA fair dons virtual reality headsets
summary: Berlin's IFA fair is set to feature virtual reality headsets and cameras, with analysts predicting smartphone makers will unveil new models compatible with VR technologies. The annual show, which began as a radio exhibition, has become a massive showcase for technological innovations, with VR headsets and cameras expected to draw attention. This comes after the success of Pokémon Go, which highlighted the appetite for reality-altering technologies.

site_title: Japan's military seeks record spending to counter North Korea, China moves
summary: Japan's defense ministry has requested a record $70.2 billion budget, a 2.3% increase, to counter growing ballistic missile threats from North Korea and China's assertive moves in the East China Sea. The defense budget will fund upgrades to Japan's Patriot batteries, improvements to Aegis destroyers, and the purchase of new aircraft and ships. The nation is shifting its focus from defending the north to reinforcing its island chain in the East China Sea, where it is locked in a territorial dispute with China.

site_title: First US-Cuba scheduled flight in decades set to depart
summary: The first regularly scheduled commercial flight between the US and Cuba in over 50 years is set to depart on Wednesday, operated by JetBlue Airways Corp. The 150-seat Airbus A320 flight will depart from Fort Lauderdale, Florida, to Santa Clara, Cuba. US Transportation Secretary Anthony Foxx and other officials will be among the passengers. The flight marks a new chapter in the Obama administration's efforts to open trade and travel with Cuba, which had been hostile since the 1959 revolution. Several US carriers are expected to begin serving Cuba in the coming months.

site_title: Japanese police corner suspect in deadly shooting
summary: Japanese police have cornered a suspect in a deadly shooting, Yasuhide Mizobata, who killed a construction worker and wounded three others before going on the run. Mizobata, reportedly the son of the company owner, was holed up in an apartment building in Wakayama, 450km southwest of Tokyo, during a tense standoff with police. The suspect had threatened to shoot police and turn the gun on himself. Gun violence is unusual in Japan, with only eight reported gun crimes in 2015.

site_title: Foreign investors turn sellers in Vietnam after 10-year spree
summary: Foreign investors are selling assets in Vietnam for the first time in a decade, with overseas traders offloading US$106 million in Vietnamese investments this year. The nation's US$71.3 billion equity market remains one of the region's smallest, and despite being near an eight-year high, MSCI has yet to elevate the market to emerging status. The root cause of this trend is market access, with low liquidity and limited trading tools hindering foreign investment.

site_title: Indonesia's Widodo masters the politics, but reform agenda fades
summary: Indonesia's President Joko Widodo appears to be consolidating his power and building alliances, rather than pursuing radical reforms. After a tumultuous first year, Widodo has regained control and is now focusing on economic recovery. However, analysts say his efforts to build a stable government may mean he will avoid pursuing significant economic reforms, instead opting for a more pragmatic approach that prioritizes stability and infrastructure development. Widodo's ability to master the politics of the country has raised concerns about his willingness to tackle corruption and promote merit-based appointments.

site_title: Apple to fight record EU tax bill
summary: Apple will appeal a record 13 billion euros in back taxes demanded by the EU, which claims the company avoided paying taxes through an illegal arrangement with Ireland. The EU's competition commissioner said Apple paid an effective corporate tax rate of just 0.005% on its European profits, compared to competitors who paid higher rates. Apple's shares dropped 0.77% after the ruling, and the US warned that the decision could damage transatlantic economic ties, threatening to undermine foreign investment and the business climate in Europe.

site_title: Singapore shares open 0.2% down on Wednesday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index opened 0.2% lower on Wednesday, closing at 2,823.29 points. This followed a decline in US stocks and a stronger dollar amid rate hike worries. Trading volume was high, with 50.8 million shares worth S$106.3 million changing hands. Despite the decline, the market still favored gainers over losers, with Noble Group being the most actively traded counter.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Shares open flat
summary: Hong Kong shares opened flat on August 31, 2016, with the Hang Seng Index edging down 3.92 points to 23,012.19. Shanghai's composite index was flat, and the Shenzhen Composite Index dipped 0.21 points.

site_title: Asia: Shares ease, taking cue from Wall Street, oil slips
summary: Asian shares eased on Wednesday, following modest losses on Wall Street, but are still on track for a monthly rise as investors await the US job report. Japan's Nikkei stock index rose 0.9% and is poised for a 1.8% monthly gain, driven by a weaker yen. The dollar remained steady against the yen, and crude oil futures slipped due to oversupply concerns. The US job report is expected to show 180,000 jobs added in August, potentially leading to a US interest rate hike in September.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher as weaker yen offsets Wall Street loss
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 0.79% and 0.84% in opening deals on Wednesday, driven by a weaker yen and bargain-hunting, offsetting a lackluster lead from Wall Street. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index gained 132.47 points to 16,857.83, while the Topix index rose 11.08 points to 1,323.89.

site_title: US slams EU, but Apple tax demand first issued in Washington
summary: The European Commission has ordered Apple to pay 13 billion euros in back taxes to Ireland, prompting a US backlash. The US Treasury claims the EU's demand endangers US-EU economic relations, while EU officials say the US initially revealed the tax scheme in a 2013 Senate report. The US has criticized the EU for "a cheap money grab," but EU officials argue that they are filling a vacuum left by US authorities failing to claim taxes on Apple's overseas profits.

site_title: Evergrande shopping spree to continue even as debt soars
summary: China Evergrande Group continues its debt-fuelled expansion, despite soaring interest payments and marketing costs, which ate into its first-half profit. The company aims to acquire brokerage and trust companies, as well as smaller rivals, and may invest in other listed companies. Evergrande's debt soared 28% to 381.3 billion yuan, with interest payments tripling, and its credit rating remains low. The company pledged to lower its net debt ratio and stabilise its net profit margin by collecting more cash from sales to roll over borrowings.

site_title: DBS perpetual securities offering 8.7 times subscribed
summary: DBS Group Holdings priced its US$750 million perpetual securities at 3.6% per annum, with an 8.7 times subscription. The securities are issued under its US$30 billion global medium-term note program, featuring a reset distribution rate tied to the prevailing US dollar swap rate plus 2.39%. This is DBS's first Basel III compliant additional Tier 1 capital issuance in US dollars.

site_title: Theranos retracts submission of Zika blood test to FDA
summary: Theranos Inc withdrew its submission for emergency clearance of a Zika virus diagnostic blood test to the US FDA after regulators found issues with patient data collection. The firm had submitted the test on August 1, but was inspected by the FDA earlier this month and found problems with data collection protocols. Theranos plans to resubmit the test, but the withdrawal may not impact sanctions against CEO Elizabeth Holmes, who faces proposed penalties for lab failures. The clearance would have helped Theranos regain credibility but is not a priority given the regulatory issues.

site_title: United jumps after adding American Airlines' no. 2 to executive team
summary: United Continental Holdings surged 8.6% after adding American Airlines' president, Scott Kirby, to its executive team. Industry analysts praise the move as a key step to closing the airline's profitability gap with American and Delta Air Lines. Analysts expect Kirby to help United adopt a more aggressive approach to matching low fares, potentially impacting industry pricing dynamics. United's stock jumped to $50.99, while American rose 2.4%. The move is seen as a strategic boost to United, with analysts noting Kirby's experience in labour issues and fuel hedging.

site_title: E-commerce, bags to drive Asian plastics demand growth through 2017
summary: Asian e-commerce growth and steady economic expansion are expected to boost plastics demand in the region through 2017, with polyethylene demand projected to reach 41 million tonnes, a 5.1% increase from 2016. The demand growth will offset a broader downturn in the petrochemicals sector and mitigate "go-green" efforts to ban plastic packaging. Countries such as China, Indonesia, and Vietnam will drive the demand, with Asia accounting for 50% of the world's polyethylene consumption in 2017.

site_title: Swift discloses more cyber thefts, pressures banks on security
summary: Swift, a global financial messaging system, disclosed new hacking attacks on its member banks, with some successful attempts, since June. The attacks, similar to the 2016 US$81 million heist at Bangladesh Bank, targeted banks with lax security procedures for Swift-enabled transfers. Swift pressured banks to comply with security procedures, threatening to report non-compliant banks to regulators and share confidential information about security lapses. The attacks, deemed persistent and sophisticated, prompt regulators globally to urge banks to bolster cyber-security defenses.

site_title: Hong Kong to vote in first election since occupy protest
summary: Voters in Hong Kong head to the polls on Sunday for the Legislative Council election, the city's most high-profile democratic outlet since the 2014 "Occupy" protests. The election will determine the balance of power in the 70-seat council, with a pro-democracy umbrella potentially blocking legislation if they secure 35 or more seats. The outcome will also affect Chief Executive Leung Chun-ying's administration ahead of a vote to select the next chief executive next year, with critics seeking to pressure the Chinese government to consider replacing him.

site_title: Uber hires Target marketing chief as startup's president
summary: Uber Technologies Inc hired Jeff Jones, former Target marketing chief, as its first president, overseeing global operations, marketing, and customer support. Jones replaces Ryan Graves, who will become head of human resources. The move aims to integrate marketing efforts with city operations, addressing concerns about the company's brand and policies. Jones' appointment is seen as a strategic shift to improve customer engagement and retention.

images.alt_text: Uber Technologies Inc hired Target Corp chief marketing officer Jeff Jones to run the ride-hailing company's global operations, marketing and customer support.

site_title: Islamic State leader in charge of foreign attacks killed in Syria
summary: Islamic State leader Abu Muhammad al-Adnani, responsible for directing attacks overseas, has been killed in an air strike in Syria. The US confirmed the operation, although details are still being reviewed. Adnani's death will likely hurt the group, which has been losing territory and facing military setbacks. He was a key figure in launching attacks outside the group's core area, including in Europe and Southeast Asia. His death is a significant blow to the militant organization, which has seen several leaders killed in recent air strikes.

images.alt_text: The Islamic State group announced on Tuesday that one of its longest-serving and most prominent leaders, Abu Muhammad al-Adnani, was killed in Syria, depriving the organisation of the man in charge of directing attacks overseas.

site_title: Trump may meet with Mexican president ahead of immigration speech
summary: Donald Trump is considering a last-minute visit to Mexico City to meet with President Enrique Peña Nieto ahead of a speech on immigration policy in Arizona. Trump's campaign has accepted an invitation to visit Mexico and is working out logistics and security concerns. In his speech, Trump will reaffirm his stance on building a border wall and deporting undocumented immigrants who have committed crimes, but will also discuss a path for the majority of the 11 million undocumented immigrants who have integrated into US communities.

images.alt_text: Donald Trump is considering traveling to Mexico City on Wednesday to meet with Mexican President Enrique Peña Nieto, just hours before the Republican presidential nominee delivers a speech in Arizona on immigration policy, according to a source familiar with the situation.

site_title: US democrats seek FBI probe of allegations Russia seeking to influence presidential election
summary: US Democrats, including Senate leader Harry Reid, asked the FBI to investigate potential Russian interference in the presidential election, citing concerns of cyber attacks and tampering with voting results. The letters, dated August 27, also inquire about possible collusion between campaign officials working for Donald Trump and Russian interests. FBI Director James Comey declined to provide details, but indicated the agency is monitoring foreign efforts to influence the election. The request comes amid a spate of hacking attacks targeting US political databases, with Kremlin officials denying involvement.

site_title: Oil heads for biggest monthly gain since April before Opec talks
summary: Oil is poised for its biggest monthly gain since April, with futures up 11% amid speculation of Opec talks in Algeria that may lead to production cuts. Iraq's Prime Minister Haidar Al-Abadi expressed support for a freeze on output, while US crude stockpiles rose by 942,000 barrels last week. Oil entered a bull market last month, and a deal to freeze supply was proposed in February but failed to materialize. Analysts say a freeze may not have a significant impact on the market, and prices could drift lower as refineries enter maintenance season.

images.alt_text: Oil is poised for the biggest monthly advance since April amid speculation informal talks among Opec members in Algeria next month may result in action to stabilise the market.

site_title: Singapore mom-and-pop investors face losses as bond risks spread
summary: Singaporean mom-and-pop investors are facing potential losses as four new bond issues this year have dropped below par sales value, amid concerns of default risks. The broader market has seen failures, including Swiber Holdings Ltd's missed payment and Pacific Andes Resources Development Ltd's reneged securities. The Monetary Authority of Singapore is tightening safeguards in the bond market, requiring issuers to make timely and relevant disclosures to retail investors. Experts warn that investors need to look beyond headline yields and consider the financial performance and credit risk of the issuer.

site_title: SpaceX signs first customer for used Falcon rocket
summary: SpaceX has signed its first customer, Luxembourg-based satellite operator SES SA, to launch a previously flown Falcon 9 rocket. The launch is planned for later this year and will mark the first commercial reuse of a Falcon 9 rocket, with a target price of $43 million per flight. This move aims to reduce the cost of space launches and pave the way for reusable rockets to make spaceflight more efficient and affordable. The deal is crucial to SpaceX's efforts to slash launch costs and make travel to Mars more affordable.

site_title: South Korea's September manufacturing sentiment steps up to 1½-year high
summary: South Korea's manufacturing sentiment for September reached a 1½-year high, according to the Bank of Korea's survey, with the manufacturing business survey index standing at 77. This is the highest reading since March 2015. The outlook for future business sentiment improved, especially for exporters and conglomerates, with a majority of indexes showing sentiment improvement. Exports are expected to rebound into positive territory for the first time in 19 months, mainly due to smartphone exports and additional working days.

site_title: Twitter to share ad revenue on videos by US users
summary: Twitter is introducing a new program allowing US users who upload videos to share in any advertising revenue generated by the platform. This move aims to attract video talent and compete with other social media giants like Facebook and YouTube. Video creators will receive a 70% share of revenue, with individual users also allowed to share their videos on other platforms. The change is part of Twitter's push into video content, following deals with media companies and sports organizations to stream major events.

site_title: CapitaLand Mall Asia signs first third-party management contract in China
summary: CapitaLand Mall Asia signed its first third-party management contract in China to manage the retail component of Fortune Finance Center in Changsha, Hunan province. The contract covers 95,000 square meters of retail space and is expected to commence operations in 2018. This marks the beginning of CapitaLand's enhanced asset-light strategy to expand its mall network. The contract is seen as a way to rapidly scale up its mall network, benefiting from scale and network effects to boost leasing efforts and enhance shopper loyalty programs.

site_title: Lamborghini pivots to target women and families
summary: Lamborghini is shifting its brand image to appeal to women and families, moving away from its aggressive past. CEO Stefano Domenicali aims to create a softer tone with upcoming models. The change is part of the company's efforts to expand its customer base and increase sales. Domenicali has called for a change in tone at the company, which previously focused on sharp-edged designs and V12 and V10 engines. The new direction is expected to appeal to a broader audience, including women and families.

site_title: UK consumers choose spending over saving as confidence rises
summary: UK consumers have regained confidence after a post-Brexit wobble, with a household confidence index jumping 5 points to minus 7 in August. Retail sales rose 1.4% in July, and consumers are willing to make major purchases. Expectations for personal finances also improved. Savings dropped to the lowest since 2013, indicating consumers are choosing to spend over saving. This marks the second report in less than a week showing consumers are recovering from the initial shock of the Brexit vote.

site_title: Google cloud unit close to winning PayPal business: CNBC
summary: Google is close to winning PayPal as a client for its cloud business, potentially beating out Amazon and Microsoft. Despite being the front-runner, PayPal is evaluating other providers and hasn't made a decision yet. If successful, the deal would bolster Google's cloud presence, which has gained momentum under Diane Greene. PayPal may not move its technology infrastructure in the fourth quarter, and it already has existing business with Amazon Web Services.

site_title: Washington warns of strain on EU economic relationship after Apple ruling
summary: The US government has strongly rebuked a European Commission order requiring Apple to pay 13 billion euros in taxes, warning it could strain US-EU economic relations. Critics in Congress call it a predatory money grab, while analysts see it as a new dimension in the tax reform debate. The US Treasury Department noted that making US companies pay back taxes in Europe could hit US coffers, and lawmakers have vowed to examine the EU decision. Apple and Ireland have announced plans to appeal the ruling.

site_title: Trump loses latest bid to derail university fraud lawsuit
summary: US District Judge Gonzalo Curiel rejected Donald Trump's attempt to block a California class-action lawsuit against Trump University, accusing the school of fraud. The former students claim they paid tens of thousands of dollars for real-estate seminars that turned out to be infomercials. The judge found that Trump's lawyers selectively interpreted a former student's deposition, which showed the student believed Trump University was legitimate due to its association with Trump, regardless of accreditation. A trial is scheduled for November 28.

site_title: Apple on firm financial footing as EU tax bill hits
summary: Apple's financials remain solid despite a record 13 billion euro EU tax bill, which could bruise the company's image. Analysts see Apple as being able to fend off the blow, but the ease of paying the bill may raise concerns about the company's moral stance on taxes. Apple's share price slipped less than 1% in response to the news. The company is expected to unveil a new iPhone model on September 7, which may not be revolutionary, but could provide a much-needed boost to its sales and profits, which have been sliding due to iPhone sales.

site_title: US dollar rises after consumer confidence uptick
summary: The US dollar rose against major currencies following a gain in US consumer confidence, reaching 103.02 yen and US$1.1143 against the euro. The Conference Board reported a 4.4-point increase in its consumer confidence index to 101.1, the highest since 2015. This boost is seen as a positive sign for the dollar ahead of Friday's release of official US job creation figures, which may influence interest rate decisions.

site_title: UK banking startups turning to deposit funding
summary: UK banking startups are turning to deposit funding as regulators discuss licenses with around 20 firms seeking to take deposits, surpassing total approvals in the past three years. Startups aim to meet funding requirements with retail deposits, as wholesale markets may become more volatile post-Brexit. Analysts at Moody's Investors Service predict a decrease in reliance on wholesale funding due to slower loan growth and cheaper funding options from the Bank of England's Term Funding Scheme. This shift towards deposit funding reflects a return to traditional methods of funding, common before deregulation.

site_title: Oil falls on Iranian production vow, rising dollar
summary: Oil prices fell on Tuesday, with West Texas Intermediate dropping 63 cents to $46.35 a barrel, and North Sea Brent falling 89 cents to $48.37 a barrel. The decline was attributed to the US dollar's strength and an Iranian official's vow to increase production, potentially limiting the impact of an Opec-Russia meeting. Iran's oil minister, Bijan Zangeneh, stated that his country would boost output to regain lost market share. The market sentiment suggests that the meeting may not result in stronger prices.

site_title: Hanergy Thin Film returns to profit with sales to Macrolink
summary: Hanergy Thin Film Power Group Ltd, a Hong Kong solar company, returned to profit in the first six months of 2016 with net income of HK$821 million, up from a loss of HK$59 million the previous year. Sales rose to HK$3.3 billion, driven by 78% sales to Macrolink and affiliates of its parent company. This comes after a tumultuous year, including a stock suspension and a partnership with Ikea falling apart. Founder Li Hejun stepped down as chairman in May to improve corporate governance.

site_title: Judgment vote looms for Brazil's Rousseff
summary: Brazil's suspended President Dilma Rousseff is set to face a Senate vote on Tuesday to remove her from office, despite her claims of being a victim of a coup. Rousseff defended herself in a 14-hour session on Monday, warning that Brazilian democracy is in danger. Lawyers made final arguments in the impeachment trial, which could end 13 years of leftist rule. The outcome of the vote is uncertain, but Rousseff's removal from office would mark a significant shift in Brazilian politics.

site_title: Fertiliser giants Potash Corp, Agrium in merger talks
summary: Potash Corporation and Agrium, two Canadian fertiliser giants, are in preliminary merger talks. The companies, based in Saskatchewan, Canada, have not made a decision on proceeding with the combination and have not reached an agreement. Potash Corporation is the top producer of a potassium compound used in agriculture as a fertiliser. The potential merger aims to strengthen the companies' market position and enhance their competitiveness in the crop nutrient supply market.

site_title: Burning rain forest a hard habit to break for palm oil industry
summary: The palm oil industry faces significant challenges in meeting sustainability standards, 12 years after the Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) set its certification standards. Despite efforts to promote sustainable production, only 17% of global palm oil supplies are certified, with companies such as IOI Corp and Golden Agri-Resources making progress in compliance. The industry's growth has led to widespread deforestation and environmental degradation, prompting consumer backlash and calls for greater accountability. The RSPO aims to increase certified supply to 50% in Indonesia and Malaysia by 2020, but critics argue that the pace of change is too slow.

site_title: Rajoy seeks support for second term as Spanish PM
summary: Spanish Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy is seeking support for a second term as PM in a confidence vote on Wednesday. He argues that Spain needs a government to recover from economic challenges. Rajoy's Popular Party has ruled since 2011 but failed to secure an absolute majority in two recent elections. He needs the support of 176 lawmakers to secure a new term, but the Socialists, his traditional rivals, have refused to help, citing corruption scandals and public spending cuts. A second vote is set for Friday if no breakthrough is made.

site_title: Banks dropping support for Hanjin Shipping, say sources
summary: Creditor banks of South Korea's largest shipping carrier, Hanjin Shipping Co Ltd, have decided to stop supporting the company, increasing the likelihood of court receivership. Hanjin's shares fell 26% after the decision, while its competitor Hyundai Merchant Marine Co Ltd rose 7% amid the company's own debt restructuring efforts. The move comes after the Korean government created a 11 trillion won fund to support struggling shipping and shipbuilding firms, including Daewoo Shipbuilding & Marine Engineering Co Ltd, which was bailed out after the Asian financial crisis.

site_title: EDBI invests in US cybersecurity firm LogRhythm
summary: EDBI, the investment arm of Singapore's Economic Development Board, has invested in US cybersecurity firm LogRhythm, participating in a $50 million funding round. LogRhythm plans to use the funds to innovate and expand globally, with potential R&D efforts in Singapore. The investment aims to strengthen Singapore's cybersecurity resilience and ecosystem. This move comes as Singapore steps up its cybersecurity efforts, including a new cybersecurity bill and a bilateral partnership with the US.

site_title: Europe: Financials help shares to hit 2-week high
summary: European equities reached a two-week high on Tuesday, driven by financial stocks' gains amid expectations of a possible US rate hike this year.
