The European Banks index rose 1.8% with shares of Deutsche Bank, ABN Amro, Natixis, and Credit Suisse increasing 2.7-3.8%. Investors are watching Friday's US non-farm payrolls data for a potential rate hike, which could benefit European lenders with US business. The STOXX 600 index closed 0.5% higher, while miners lost ground due to a stronger US dollar.

site_title: EU tells Apple to pay up to 13b euros in tax to Ireland
summary: The European Commission ordered Apple to pay up to 13 billion euros in taxes to Ireland, ruling that a special scheme to route profits through Ireland was illegal state aid. Apple has already said it will appeal the decision. The EU executive said the ruling could be reduced if other countries sought more tax from the US tech giant. The decision could anger Washington, which has accused Brussels of campaigning against US corporate success stories.

site_title: Tiger, tiger burning bright
summary: Tiger Balm, a 90-year-old Singaporean brand, is embracing innovation to stay relevant. The company has introduced over 10 new products in the past two decades, including mosquito repellent patches and muscle relief gels. Under the leadership of AK Han, executive director of Haw Par Corporation, the brand has expanded globally, exporting products to about 100 countries and establishing a strong presence in the Western market. Tiger Balm plans to release a new product in the next couple of months, focusing on prevention rather than just curing ailments, to drive growth and maintain its heritage brand's relevance.

site_title: Argentina central bank cuts key interest rate, expects lower inflation
summary: Argentina's central bank cut its 35-day reference rate by 50 basis points to 28.25% in a bid to combat inflation. This is the fifth rate cut in as many weeks, aiming to boost the economy and push cash into the real sector. The move follows July's inflation rate of 2.0%, down from 4.2% in May. The bank expects inflation to be less than 1% in August and 40.2% in 2016, one of the world's highest rates.

site_title: Obama to assure Asian leaders on TPP amid US opposition
summary: US President Barack Obama will reassure Asian leaders on the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) during his upcoming trip, despite domestic opposition and concerns from presidential candidates Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton. The 12-nation trade deal is seen as crucial to Obama's Asia rebalance strategy and his legacy. Failure to approve the pact would cede the region to countries like China, which do not set high standards for trade agreements. Estimates of the TPP's economic impact vary, but most show little meaningful growth for the US economy, with polls showing most Americans support the deal.

site_title: Top HSBC executive pleads not guilty to rigging forex markets
summary: HSBC executive Mark Johnson, global head of forex cash trading in London, pleaded not guilty to rigging foreign-exchange markets. He and former HSBC executive Stuart Scott allegedly manipulated the British pound to take advantage of inside information about a client's US$3.5 billion currency transaction, reaping US$8 million for the bank. Johnson was arrested in July and released on US$1 million bail, awaiting trial on 11 counts of wire fraud and conspiracy. This is the first US case of its kind, with the US seeking to extradite Scott, who remains in the UK.

site_title: US: Wall Street ends lower as EU's Apple tax decision draws ire
summary: US stocks closed marginally lower on Tuesday as Apple's shares fell 0.8% due to European authorities' demand for $14.5 billion in back taxes. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.3% to 18,454.30, while the S&P 500 lost 0.2% to 2,176.12. Tech companies, including Microsoft and Alphabet Inc, also declined. In contrast, financial sector giants like Goldman Sachs and Bank of America rose, while US oil companies were mixed. The decline was attributed to the EU's decision, which drew ire from US officials.

site_title: Tough job representing bunker industry
summary: A new association, the Association of Bunker Industry (Singapore), has been formed to represent the Singapore bunker industry, following a dialogue session with the Maritime Port Authority of Singapore in June. The association aims to improve standards, provide training programs, and engage with national and international bodies. The group has already mapped out plans, including a focus group to review bunker surveying processes and has received support from the MPA. The association has registered 29 members, mostly from the bunker surveying sector, which is experiencing a decline in business due to the mandatory introduction of mass flow meters in Singapore.

site_title: JTC says noteholders had enjoyed cheaper club membership fees
summary: JTC, the statutory board behind Jurong Country Club, has defended its offer to buy back debentures with a discount, citing that noteholders benefited from cheaper club membership fees when they purchased their memberships in 1993. The board used a discounted cash flow method to determine the present value of the notes, which resulted in an offer price of S$84,200. Noteholders, however, claim that the offer is "grossly unfair" and that they should be redeemed at par, as their memberships are terminating and the land is being taken back by the state.

site_title: Dim sum market spurned by companies after yuan devaluation shock
summary: The dim sum bond market in China has shrunk significantly since the yuan devaluation shock in 2015, with only three corporate issuances this year, down from 73 two years ago. Sales have fallen 49% to 118.1 billion yuan, and the average yield has dropped to 3.86%. The lack of a well-rounded offshore yuan bond market hinders China's efforts to increase the yuan's use in international trade. Foreign investors remain cautious, and Panda bonds are expected to eclipse dim sum securities as a means of yuan fundraising.

images.alt_text: The dim sum bond market is inching closer to insignificance for corporate treasurers looking to raise Chinese yuan.

site_title: Industry watchers split over move on dual-class shares
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has opened up the issue of dual-class share listings, sparking debate among industry watchers. Proponents argue that it will make SGX more attractive for initial public offerings (IPOs), particularly for high-profile tech companies, and that safeguards such as a 10-to-1 differential in voting power will address governance risks. Critics, however, express concerns about the efficacy of the safeguards and the risk of setting a precedent, citing doubts about the robustness of independent directors as safeguards.

site_title: US SEC awards US$22m to ex-Monsanto executive through whistleblower programme
summary: A former Monsanto executive who tipped off the US Securities and Exchange Commission to accounting improprieties involving Roundup has been awarded $22.437 million through the agency's whistleblower programme. The award is tied to a $80 million settlement between the SEC and Monsanto in February. The whistleblower's identity remains undisclosed, but the award is the second-largest under the programme, surpassing $107 million in total payouts since 2011. The SEC's case against Monsanto centered on a corporate rebate program designed to boost Roundup sales, which led to the company "materially" misstating its earnings for three years.

images.alt_text: A former Monsanto Co executive who tipped the US Securities and Exchange Commission to accounting improprieties involving the company's top-selling Roundup product has been awarded more than US$22 million from the agency's whistleblower programme, the executive's lawyer said on Tuesday.

site_title: Ghost headquarters and double Irish companies: Apple's tax deals
summary: The European Union ruled Apple's tax deal with Ireland illegal, ordering the tech giant to pay 13 billion euros in back taxes. The deal involved a phantom headquarters and two companies, making it possible for Apple to avoid tax. Two "tax rulings" granted by Ireland in 1991 and 2007 allowed Apple to reduce its tax liability. The EU's decision aims to crack down on tax avoidance schemes used by multinational corporations.

site_title: Market ends flat after rebound bid
summary: The Singapore stock market ended flat on Tuesday, closing at 2,828.39, after a brief rebound bid. Concerns over a Zika infection outbreak and the oil and gas sector weighed on the market, with air transportation counters and oil and gas companies experiencing declines. Despite a stronger showing from real estate investment trusts, the market underperformed regional peers. Analysts attribute the market's performance to anxiety about upcoming US non-farm payrolls data and the ongoing oil and gas downturn.

site_title: US dollar off highs as investors seek more guidance
summary: The US dollar held firm on Tuesday, just below its previous day's high, as investors awaited the next set of US data to gauge the likelihood of a Federal Reserve interest rate hike. Despite hawkish comments from Fed officials, markets still price in less than 50% chance of a rate rise in September. The dollar index rose to 95.804, driven by consumer spending data showing a fourth straight month of growth, and a strong jobs report expected on Friday.

site_title: Why governance lapses are recurring
summary: Despite extensive corporate governance reforms, governance lapses continue to occur due to three key factors: corporate culture, cross-border differences, and complexity of organizations. Weak corporate cultures, often prioritizing performance over ethics, contribute to scandals like BP's Deepwater Horizon disaster and Takata's airbag failure. Cross-border differences in laws, regulations, and business practices lead to cases like HSBC's money-laundering scandal and GSK's bribery scandals. Complexity of organizations, with proliferation of group entities and limited governance roles, is also a contributing factor to scandals like BP's environmental disaster and OW Bunker's collapse.

site_title: EMs see slow but sure recovery in 2017
summary: Emerging markets (EM) outside of China are expected to transition from a period of adjustment to a gradual recovery by 2017, driven by improving investor sentiment and capital inflows. Following a period of misallocation, where macro policies led to rising imbalances, EMs will enter a phase of productive growth, characterized by strong productivity and macro stability. As policy-makers restore macro stability through tightening monetary and fiscal policies, productivity will improve, and the economy will gradually return to a sustainable growth path.

site_title: Working from home: Is this the future?
summary: Working from home has become increasingly common, with 37% of Americans working from home at least one month in 2015, up from 9% in 1995. However, this shift is not evenly distributed, with 55% of college-educated respondents working from home compared to 26% of non-college graduates. While some employers have encouraged telecommuting, others have backtracked, and big cities have continued to grow economically. The rise of online shopping and e-commerce has also led to a decline in in-person retail sales and public transit ridership, suggesting that the shift towards working and consuming at home is likely to continue.

site_title: G-Shock staying relevant amid smartwatches
summary: G-Shock, the iconic watch brand, is staying relevant in the smartwatch market by focusing on connecting its existing watches to smartphones rather than competing with them. Under the guidance of its creator Kikuo Ibe, G-Shock will continue to prioritize durability and shock resistance, releasing new designs and models with advanced features such as triple sensors. The brand aims to cater to its loyal cult following, particularly in professions that demand toughness, and explore new markets like space tourism, where G-Shock plans to develop watches that can withstand extreme environments.

site_title: IRAS tax collection for FY15/16 hits all-time high of S$44.8b
summary: Singapore's Inland Revenue Authority (IRAS) collected a record S$44.8 billion in tax revenue for FY15/16, a 3.2% increase year-over-year, accounting for 11.1% of the country's GDP. The number of millionaires in the country also swelled to 5,141, up from 4,557 the previous year. Tax compliance remained high, with 96% of individuals filing on time and 82% of companies doing so. The government's operating revenue was largely funded by tax collection, with income tax making up 55% of IRAS's total collection.

site_title: Oil market rebalancing could take until end 2017: Shell
summary: Shell's chief energy adviser, Wim Thomas, predicts the global oil oversupply may not clear until the second half of 2017, delaying rebalancing. The return of 1.5 million barrels per day of Libyan and Nigerian supply, combined with uncertainty over Iranian and Iraqi production, may postpone rebalancing. Thomas cites factors such as increased demand from China and India, as well as the resilience of US shale producers, as potential disruptors to the current situation.

site_title: Singapore's tech IPO push unlikely to be a game-changer
summary: Singapore's tech IPO push is unlikely to be a game-changer due to the increasing competition from international markets. The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has introduced easier rules on minimum price and dual-class shares to attract technology startups, but the move may not reverse the slump in listings. With 90% of startups failing, local investors face higher risks, and the global role of Singapore's stock market is likely to continue shrinking as investors gain access to stocks worldwide.

site_title: Strong demand for DBS US$ bond deal and two other issues
summary: DBS Bank successfully priced a record-low USD 3.6% Additional Tier 1 bond deal, receiving over US$8 billion in orders. Two Chinese issuers, Chongqing Western Modern Logistics Industrial Zone and Road King Infrastructure, also tapped the market with strong demand exceeding US$16.55 billion. The market's strong demand is attributed to investors seeking yield and a subdued interest rate outlook. This follows recent US Federal Reserve interest rate hike speculation, which often causes bond markets to wobble. The Asian USD bond market has seen significant activity, with year-to-date sales reaching US$119 billion.

site_title: S'pore Post tops the sell stocks with S$139.8m
summary: Global mutual funds bought more Singapore stocks than they sold in the three months leading up to Aug 24, with net buys of S$942.2 million and net sells of S$604.6 million. The top selling stock was Singapore Post with S$41.1 million, while the top buying stock was Hutchison Port Holdings Trust with S$20.7 million, resulting in a net sell of S$139.8 million in the utilities and transportation segment.

site_title: Sifting for signs of the next Swiber
summary: Singapore-listed marine engineering company Swiber Holdings Ltd defaulted on a coupon payment in 2016, amid the fallout from the 2014 oil price slump. The company's high leverage, weak financial ratios, and fragile liquidity were key warning signs of its impending failure. Swiber's creditworthiness was rated higher than other companies in Singapore, but the company's collapse highlights the importance of rigorous credit assessment and monitoring in the bond market. The oil and gas sector, particularly in Singapore, remains vulnerable to further credit stress and defaults.

site_title: Failed deal reinforces Hershey's image as a company not for sale
summary: Hershey Co's failed deal with Mondelez International Inc has reinforced its reputation as a company not for sale. Mondelez abandoned merger discussions after failing to reach an agreement on a US$115 a share offer, which was 18% higher than the pre-disclosure stock price. The deal's rejection comes amid turmoil at the Hershey Trust and the company's struggles with shifting consumer tastes and an ill-fated expansion into China. The failed bid is expected to deter future bidders, with analysts saying it will have a dampening effect on potential offers for Hershey.

site_title: VMware in enhanced cloud tie-up with IBM
summary: VMware has announced a tie-up with IBM to enhance its cloud-computing offerings. The company unveiled new tools and products, including the Cloud Foundation, a unified software-defined data centre platform that integrates compute, storage, and network virtualisation solutions. The partnership will enable customers to run applications across clouds and devices in a common and secure operating environment, with IBM being the first major global cloud service provider to integrate the Cloud Foundation into its services. The Cloud Foundation is expected to be available by the third quarter of this year, with plans to expand to other major cloud-computing service providers.

site_title: Tokyo probe finds Mitsubishi falsified mileage for 8 more models
summary: Tokyo's transport ministry ordered Mitsubishi Motors to stop selling eight vehicle models due to overstated fuel economy. An investigation found the fuel economy on models such as the Pajero and Outlander were 8.8% and 4.2% lower than advertised. This is the second order for Mitsubishi, following four minivehicle models whose mileages were falsified earlier. The ministry expects the process of submitting correct readings to take a few weeks, potentially affecting the carmaker's domestic sales and bottom line.

site_title: Shenzhen-Hong Kong link likely to start in November
summary: China's markets regulator expects the Shenzhen-Hong Kong stock market link to start in mid to late November, with technical preparations set to take place from August to November. The link, the second after Shanghai-Hong Kong, aims to open mainland equities to the global financial community and increase foreign trading access. Daily limits for the Shenzhen link will be 13 billion yuan northbound and 10.5 billion yuan southbound, with small-cap companies valued over HK$5 billion included.

site_title: JTC's treatment of Jurong Country Club notes grossly unfair, devoid of reason
summary: The Jurong Country Club (JCC) Debenture Note Working Committee (DNWC) has criticized JTC's offer to repurchase the Noteholders Debenture Note (DN) for S$84,200, citing it as grossly unfair and devoid of reason. The DNWC argues that the note is an interest-free loan and should be repaid at par value of S$120,000. JTC's offer would result in a loss of S$35,800 for noteholders, while the company gains S$35,800. The DNWC requests JTC to redeem the DN at par value when the club's memberships cease this year-end, as both the DN and memberships are bundled together.

site_title: Hafary sets eyes on overseas markets
summary: Hafary Holdings, a Singapore-based building materials supplier, is expanding its geographic base through overseas markets such as Malaysia and the UK. The company is seeking to mitigate the risk of downcycles in the domestic market, which has seen a surge in recent years followed by a decline. Hafary has recently set up a separate business unit focusing on public projects and is tendering for subcontracting work in London for the Royal Wharf project. The company also has a licensing agreement with a local partner in Myanmar and a 49% stake in Viet Ceramics International Joint Stock Company in Vietnam.

site_title: Yun Nam boss picks up GCB at Brizay Park
summary: Yun Nam Hair Care boss Andy Chua has purchased a Good Class Bungalow (GCB) in Singapore for S$33 million, bringing the total number of GCB transactions in 2016 to at least 23. The property, located on nearly 29,800 sq ft of freehold land, was bought at S$1,108 per square foot. This deal follows Chua's previous purchases of a duplex penthouse and a private lunch with Warren Buffett in 2014, highlighting his significant investments in Singapore's luxury properties.

site_title: Pimco to hire 20 people to target US$17.4 trillion Asian wealth
summary: Pimco plans to hire 20 people in marketing, operations, and compliance teams to target the US$17.4 trillion Asian wealth market. The move aims to capitalize on the region's growing high net-worth individuals, with 5.1 million people having more than US$1 million in investible assets. Pimco expects to increase its penetration in retail and alternatives spaces in China, despite not having an office on the mainland. The firm's Asia-Pacific head, Eric Mogelof, believes the region's wealth dynamics and diminishing barriers to entry will drive growth.

site_title: Trudeau touts agricultural safety amid China canola dispute
summary: Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau emphasized the safety and quality of Canadian agricultural products during a visit to Beijing, amid a dispute over canola imports. The dispute, worth C$2 billion, threatens to limit trade ties between the two countries. Trudeau and Trade Minister Chrystia Freeland are working to resolve the issue, while Trudeau also plans to discuss human rights and the case of a detained Canadian citizen. China's new standard for canola imports, which would significantly raise costs for exporters, has been a point of contention.

site_title: Aussie office deals down the most since H108
summary: Australian office deals plummeted 57% to $7.5 billion in the first half of 2016, the largest decline since the global financial crisis. High-yielding assets are making owners reluctant to sell, with yields nearly twice as high as in Asian markets like Singapore and Hong Kong. Foreigners accounted for 43% of acquisitions, but domestic players are holding onto prime assets with little incentive to sell, making them scarce in the low-return environment.

site_title: Europe still a global force despite its many big challenges
summary: Europe remains a significant global economic force despite facing numerous challenges, including the refugee crisis, terrorism, and Brexit. The EU is the world's second-largest economy and will continue to grow, with a forecasted increase of $2.3 trillion by 2020. Europe leads in technology, innovation, and design, and is a key player in addressing global issues such as climate change, migration, and social inequality. While Europe faces challenges, it is investing in solutions that will be relevant for countries and companies worldwide, maintaining its position as a global leader.

site_title: Machiya dwellings in Kyoto get a new lease of life
summary: Kyoto's traditional machiya dwellings are being restored through specialized loans offered by local banks. The loans, tailored to preserve the architecture, allow borrowers to renovate while maintaining classic features. Since 2011, Kyoto Shinkin Bank has lent 2.9 billion yen for 112 restoration projects. The initiative aims to preserve Japan's cultural heritage sites, with many machiya having been destroyed or lost their traditional appearance due to modernization and development.

site_title: Shenzhen express set to go but it's not for everyone
summary: China's ChiNext board, a Nasdaq-style stock exchange, is set to open with over 200 start-ups listed, despite concerns it may not be suitable for ordinary people due to high valuations and prices. China's asset bubble remains inflated, with residential housing in Beijing costing over $2 million and A-share valuations 15 times higher than Hong Kong's main board. The move aims to attract foreign capital and address the issue of a massive asset bubble, which has persisted despite recent market turmoil and capital outflows.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Ezion Holdings' share price falls by S$0.01 to S$0.235 due to differences in associate's full-year results, which impacted its share of results from associates and jointly controlled entities. UOB KayHian maintains a "hold" rating and lowers its valuation benchmark. Meanwhile, SATS wins a tender to build and operate a cargo terminal in Dammam, Saudi Arabia, with a 22.5-year concession period. The broker upgrades its fair value to S$4.70 and maintains a "hold" rating. Croesus Retail Trust's shares fall to S$0.855, with Phillip Securities Research recommending an "accumulate" position due to stable historical sales at two newly acquired malls.

site_title: French Economy Minister Macron resigns: official
summary: French Economy Minister Emmanuel Macron has resigned from government, effective immediately. He will be succeeded by Finance Minister Michel Sapin, who will take over the portfolio alongside his current finance role. The move comes after Macron's decision to leave the government amid a presidential election.

site_title: Apple to unveil new features for iPad, Macs: sources
summary: Apple is set to unveil new features for its iPad and Mac laptops, aimed at professional users. The iPad will receive wider operating-system support for its stylus accessory, hardware performance improvements, and enhanced Apple Pencil functionality. New Macs will include thinner laptops, refreshed iMac desktops, and a 5K standalone monitor in collaboration with LG Electronics. The new features are expected to support Apple's growing sales of higher-paying iPad Pro models, which have seen an increase in quarterly revenue. The updates are set to be announced at an upcoming Apple event.

site_title: JTC should redeem JCC notes at par
summary: The Jurong Town Corporation (JTC) has made an offer to repurchase S$120,000 notes at S$84,200, which is deemed unsatisfactory by a noteholder. The note is interest-free and bundled with a Jurong Country Club membership, making it essentially a loan. The noteholder argues that the current situation of an impending land acquisition is not a normal market situation and that JTC should redeem the notes at par value of S$120,000 each, rather than using market practice to discount the value.

site_title: Too early to tell if Zika will hit S'pore economy hard, say observers
summary: Singapore may experience minimal economic impact from the Zika virus, with indicators such as the Formula One Singapore Grand Prix turnout in September and tourism and retail sales data in November expected to provide early signs. Despite new cases being detected, the government and businesses are taking precautions, and residents and travelers appear to be unaffected. Observers compare the situation to the Sars outbreak in 2003, noting that while the Zika virus is a significant concern, its transmission and mortality rates are lower. Economists caution that it's too early to determine the virus's full impact, but emphasize the importance of effective communication to mitigate concerns.

site_title: CDLHT needs to bolster overseas presence
summary: CDL Hospitality Trusts (CDLHT) is facing challenges in the hotel industry due to a supply surge in Singapore and global economic headwinds. Visitor arrivals have grown 12% year-over-year, but hotel industry growth has been less exciting. The company's Singapore hotels reported a 3% drop in occupancy, 6% decline in average room rates, and 9.2% drop in revenue per available room. To mitigate this, CDLHT is exploring overseas markets, particularly in Japan, Europe, and New Zealand, with a gearing of 36.3% and debt headroom of S$155 million.

site_title: No cut to annual growth limit on Aussie mortgage loans
summary: Australia's banking regulator, Apra, has no plans to lower its annual lending growth limit of 10% on speculative property investors, despite concerns over high home prices in Sydney and Melbourne. Chairman Wayne Byres said actual growth in investor lending is around 5%, and that reducing the cap to 7% may not make a significant difference. Total domestic housing loans rose 8.1% in the June quarter to A$1.44 trillion, with Apra increasing scrutiny on commercial property lending.

site_title: 3 steps to innovating without denting profit
summary: SMEs in Singapore struggle to balance short-term profit needs with long-term innovation aspirations. A recent survey found that only about half of the 233 SMEs surveyed are trying to innovate, with less than 35% investing in innovation in the past two years. To overcome this challenge, experts suggest that SMEs can juggle short-term and long-term needs by implementing a three-step approach: (1) identifying key areas for innovation, (2) developing a clear innovation strategy, and (3) allocating resources to support innovation initiatives. By adopting this approach, SMEs can drive growth and competitiveness while maintaining profitability.

site_title: More London financial firms seen mulling over move to Dublin
summary: Ireland is experiencing a surge in inquiries from London financial firms considering relocating to the country due to Brexit. Over 35 concrete enquiries have been received, with companies seeking a contracting entity to maintain access to the European market. Ireland's tax regime and similar structure to the UK make it an attractive alternative. Other financial centers like Frankfurt and Paris are also vying for business, but Ireland remains a popular choice among fund managers and insurers, with several firms considering moving or expanding operations there.

site_title: Singapore Zika cases surge to 82
summary: Singapore has reported a surge in Zika cases, reaching 82, with 26 new local infections confirmed, mostly in the eastern Aljunied suburb. The government is intensifying its mosquito-fighting efforts, inspecting 5,000 homes and destroying breeding sites. Pregnant women are particularly vulnerable to Zika's microcephaly, a birth defect. Neighbouring countries have issued travel advisories, while Singapore remains a densely populated tropical island prone to mosquito-borne diseases.

site_title: Model fights 'weighty' issue
summary: South Korean plus-size model Vivian Geeyang Kim is fighting against online trolls and societal pressure by promoting self-acceptance among curvy women. Despite being mocked as "flat-out fat" and "disgusting" in her homeland, Kim has built a successful online clothing shop and magazine catering to plus-size women, challenging the country's unrealistic beauty ideal of a 50kg weight limit. Her campaign has sparked an online backlash, but Kim remains defiant, saying she wants to send a message to girls like her that they are beautiful no matter what.

images.alt_text: Kim during a photo shoot (above) to update her online clothing shop and at her clothing shop office in Seoul. The South Korean model is defying online trolls in her daring campaign to persuade curvy women they have nothing to be ashamed of.

Kim during a photo shoot (above) to update her online clothing shop and at her clothing shop office in Seoul. The South Korean model is defying online trolls in her daring campaign to persuade curvy women they have nothing to be ashamed of.

Kim during a photo shoot to update her online clothing shop and (above) at her clothing shop office in Seoul. The South Korean model is defying online trolls in her daring campaign to persuade curvy women they have nothing to be ashamed of.

site_title: Disruption is here to stay, and it's time to face the challenges head-on
summary: Disruption is increasingly affecting businesses worldwide, including in Singapore. Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong identified disruption as the "defining challenge" for the country's economy. Disruption is impacting sectors like transport, retail, and food and beverage, with Uber and Airbnb changing traditional industries. To address the challenge, the government and companies will work together to develop programs to help companies use new technologies and invest in skills. Employers must also upgrade their staff's skills and embrace technological advances to remain competitive.

site_title: France urges halt to thorny EU-US trade negotiations
summary: France is urging a halt to EU-US trade negotiations, citing a lack of political support and an imbalance in favor of the US side. President Francois Hollande stated that no deal can be reached until after US President Barack Obama leaves office in January. France's junior trade minister Matthias Fekl described US negotiators' offers as "nothing or just crumbs," and the EU Commission has rejected claims that talks are on track. The talks, aimed at creating the world's largest free-trade area, have been stalled due to concerns over EU standards in areas like health and welfare.

site_title: Oil discoveries at 70-year low signal a supply shortfall ahead
summary: Oil discoveries have reached a 70-year low, sparking concerns about a potential supply shortfall. Drillers have cut exploration budgets by more than half since 2014, resulting in a record low of 2.7 billion barrels discovered in 2015. This year, only 736 million barrels of conventional crude have been found, putting pressure on the industry to meet growing global demand. Experts predict that global spending on exploration will remain at $40 billion through 2018, and that the lack of new discoveries will lead to a shortage of oil supply by 2025, potentially driving prices up.

images.alt_text: Oil prices remain at about US$50 a barrel as a glut caused by the US shale boom (above) sent prices crashing. When Opec decided to continue pumping in a Saudi-led strategy designed to increase its share of the market, US production retreated to a two-year low.

site_title: Autism becoming Silicon Valley asset with social quirks
summary: A California company, MindSpark, is employing individuals with high-functioning autism to test software for top clients, including Fox Networks Group and Liberty Mutual. The firm seeks out people with attention to detail, pattern recognition, and focus, which are common traits among those on the autism spectrum. With 27 analysts, MindSpark offers a supportive community and flexible work arrangements, including part-time options. The company's model aims to drive social change by providing a workplace community that accommodates the needs of autistic employees, who often face challenges in traditional work environments.

images.alt_text: MindSpark has been refining its model for the past three years, with its roster of clients growing to include Fox Networks Group and Liberty Mutual.

site_title: Drop in Japan's July household spending less than expected; jobless rate at 21-year low
summary: Japan's household spending fell 0.5% in July, less than expected, and the jobless rate hit a 21-year low at 3%. The economy is still stagnant, with inflation sliding further away from the Bank of Japan's 2% target. Despite the low unemployment rate, economists expect the bank to ease further stimulus next month due to weak wage growth and consumer spending. Retail sales also fell 0.2% in July, and core consumer prices dropped by the most in over three years, putting pressure on the BOJ to expand its stimulus programme.

site_title: White House still hopes to finish US-EU trade deal this year
summary: The White House reaffirmed its goal to complete the US-EU trade deal by year's end, despite French and German officials questioning the pact. White House spokesman Josh Earnest stated that President Barack Obama's top trade official, Mike Froman, will travel to Europe in the coming weeks to continue negotiations. The agreement, which would create the world's largest free-trade area, faces significant political headwinds due to upcoming government elections in the three countries. Despite this, the US remains committed to completing the deal by the end of the year.

site_title: Traders are turning bullish on growth
summary: Global equity traders are shifting their focus from defensive stocks to cyclical ones, with miners, technological, and industrial firms seeing significant gains. The FTSE All World Cyclical Index is on track for its best two-month showing since 2012, with companies like Toyota, Samsung, and ABB soaring over 12%. Improved economic data, earnings reports, and central-bank assurances have led investors to become more optimistic, with bulls predicting a sustained cyclical recovery. Analysts forecast global growth of 3.2% next year, up from 2.9% in 2016.

site_title: Lowe's seeks to wind up venture with Woolworths
summary: Lowe's Cos has asked an Australian court to appoint a liquidator to wind up its home-improvements business with Woolworths Ltd due to "oppressive" and "prejudicial" behavior. The venture, Masters hardware division, was formed in 2009 but has been unprofitable. Woolworths has proposed a three-step plan to exit the venture, including selling 82 properties and development sites. Lowe's claims Woolworths has conducted the affairs of the joint venture in a "manner oppressive and unfairly prejudicial" to the US company.

site_title: Novo's auditor highlights qualified opinion, emphasis of matters on financial statements
summary: Novo Group's independent auditor, Baker Tilly TFW LLP, has issued a qualified opinion and emphasis of matters in its report on the company's financial statements for the year ended April 30, 2016. The auditor highlighted concerns over the group's property, plant, and equipment, as well as investments in subsidiaries and amounts due from subsidiaries. The auditor was unable to determine whether adjustments are necessary to the net carrying values of the group's property, plant, and equipment due to insufficient audit evidence.

site_title: Consumer confidence in US rose to 101.1 in August from 96.7
summary: Consumer confidence in the US rose to 101.1 in August, an almost one-year high, according to the Conference Board. This represents a 4.4% increase from the revised 96.7 reading in July. The median projection from economists was 97. This improvement is a positive sign for the US economy, indicating increased optimism among consumers.

site_title: Olive Green turns plastic eco-friendly (Amended)
summary: Singapore-based company Olive Green has developed a biodegradable compound called CornWare, made from plastic and corn starch, to replace non-biodegradable petroleum plastic materials. CornWare is the first brand of corn-based disposables in Asia and is registered in 12 countries. The company uses natural chemicals to create eco-friendly materials, including thermoplastic starch and polylactic acid. While CornWare is biodegradable, it is not compostable due to the plastic component. Olive Green aims to expand into the electronics and pharmaceutical industries, targeting 5% market share in eco-friendly biodegradable plastics by 2020.

images.alt_text: Mr Cheong and Ms Leo of Olive Green Pte Ltd, which launched its flagship CornWare brand of biodegradable disposable crockery and cutlery in 2008. The brand has been registered in 12 countries.

site_title: Cash-on-tap means Super Sept for EM bond sales
summary: Emerging-market borrowers are poised to issue tens of billions of dollars in new bonds between September and November, taking advantage of historically low costs and abundant cash. Investors are flocking to emerging markets, with record inflows of $18.7 billion in July and $4.2 billion in August, seeking higher yields. Issuers, including Saudi Arabia, Russia, and Brazil, plan to tap the market to raise money before interest rate hikes and US elections potentially undermine investor confidence. The surge in demand is driven by investors fleeing negative-yielding US debt, with average yields on emerging-market bonds at record lows.

images.alt_text: As the world's central banks took their cue from Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen's dovish policies, EM sovereign dollar bonds handed investors 15% this year, and local-currency notes gave 7%.

site_title: Pregnant women with Zika symptoms advised by MOH to be tested for the virus
summary: The Health Ministry of Singapore is advising all pregnant women with Zika symptoms, regardless of travel history, to be tested for the virus. This includes those experiencing fever, rash, red eyes, or joint pain. Additionally, pregnant women with Zika-positive male partners should also undergo testing. The advisory aims to monitor the spread of the virus and prevent potential birth defects.

site_title: Modern wine cellars go beyond basics
summary: Modern wine cellars have evolved beyond basic storage, becoming luxurious spaces that integrate into the living environment. They feature advanced technology, sleek designs, and premium materials, such as steel and glass. To maintain optimal conditions for storing fine wine, cellars often incorporate features like refrigeration, backup systems, and smart glass filters. The trend is shifting towards integrated designs that allow for wine tasting and sampling, with some owners opting for two cellars: one for long-term storage and another for current consumption. Designer cellars can be extremely expensive, with prices ranging from $46,000 to $220,000 or more, depending on the number of bottles and materials used.

site_title: Top Glove buys Selangor freehold property for RM51.5m
summary: Top Glove Corporation Bhd has proposed to acquire a freehold property in Selangor for RM51.5 million. The 34,499 sq m property, currently occupied by a factory and production office, will be used for future glove production line expansion. The proposed acquisition is expected to be completed by the first quarter of next year.

site_title: ST Engineering's US unit enters into Saudi JV
summary: ST Engineering's US subsidiary, VT Halter Marine Inc, has formed a joint venture, ZHR Marine LCC, with Raytheon Company and Zamil Group in Saudi Arabia. The JV aims to bid on projects under the Royal Saudi Naval Force Eastern Fleet Modernisation Programme, focusing on local content. The partnership combines VT Halter Marine's naval vessel construction expertise, Al Zamil Group's shipbuilding capabilities, and Raytheon's naval systems and integration expertise. The joint venture has an issued and paid-up capital of 3 million Saudi riyal, with each partner holding one-third of the shareholding.

site_title: MPA to reduce incident risk off S'pore: Khaw
summary: The Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore (MPA) is increasing efforts to reduce incident risk for passenger ferries and smaller vessels in Singapore waters, following the 2015 Sea Prince ferry incident. MPA has increased inspections and improved safety equipment on board ferries, producing a safety video for passengers and mandating Automatic Identification System-B (AIS-B) transponders and electronic chart systems (ECS) on harbour and pleasure crafts. The MPA will also fund the installation of 2,600 units of AIS-B transponders and ECS by 2017, aiming to enhance safety within Singapore's port waters.

site_title: China Sky Chemical Fibre says winding-up proceedings of subsidiary not verified
summary: China Sky Chemical Fibre Co Ltd says its subsidiary Quanzhou Tianyu Chemical Fiber & Weaving Industry Co Ltd has started winding-up proceedings in China, but the information has not been verified due to uncooperative legal representation. The company is seeking Chinese counsel to gather more details and will keep shareholders informed of any developments. This follows other challenges, including lawsuits from former employees and an outstanding sum of unpaid salaries and social security contributions. The company's nylon and textile production has been impacted by weak demand and softening selling prices.

site_title: Eurozone monthly economic sentiment falls more than expected
summary: Eurozone economic sentiment fell to its lowest level since March, dropping to 103.5 in August, below the forecast of 104.1. Confidence declined in four of the eurozone's five largest economies, with Italy's confidence reaching an 18-month low due to banking problems. The decline in sentiment adds to economic uncertainty following the UK's Brexit vote and the European Central Bank's struggles to stimulate growth. The ECB is set to meet next week amid concerns about inflation and growth.

site_title: US banks see higher net income, expand lending in Q2: FDIC
summary: US banks reported a 1.4% increase in net income to $584 million in Q2, driven by a 1.5% increase in total credits to $241 billion. New home loans and real estate credits led the growth. Loan growth remained strong, with the number of unprofitable banks at an 18-year low. However, low energy prices may put pressure on the energy sector and banks that service it. The FDIC announced that the largest US banks will contribute more to the insurance fund to comply with the Dodd Frank Wall Street reform legislation.

site_title: US: Wall St flat as investors look for clues on rates
summary: US stocks remained flat on Tuesday as investors awaited a report on monthly payrolls data and digest the Fed's hawkish tone. Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen stated the case for a rate hike is strengthening, but provided little indication on timing. The Dow and S&P 500 ended the day with slight changes, while the Nasdaq rose. The dollar index continued to trade at a two-week high due to prospects of a rate increase. Key sectors, including energy and technology, saw fluctuations, with Apple shares falling 0.5% due to an EU antitrust ruling.

site_title: Malaysia: Stocks close lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's stock market closed lower on Tuesday with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 3.540 points to 1,678.060. The market saw 1.997 billion lots worth RM2.263 billion, with losers outnumbering gainers 419 to 409.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Ezion Holdings, a liftboat provider, has revised its second-quarter and first-half results due to additional impairment charges, reducing profit after tax to US$8.1 million (vs US$19.8 million earlier). Chip Eng Seng Corp announced a contract worth S$75.9 million for a precast concrete supply project. Top Glove Corp has proposed acquiring a property in Selangor for RM51.5 million to expand its glove production lines. Viva Industrial Trust secured an anchor tenant for an area at Viva Business Park, while Serrano Ltd faces lawsuits from Maybank and VGS Imports & Exports over unpaid debts.

site_title: UN aid going to Assad-linked companies: report
summary: The United Nations has awarded tens of millions of dollars in aid contracts to companies and individuals closely associated with Syrian President Bashar al-Assad, despite US and EU sanctions. Analysis by The Guardian found that UN agencies partnered with the Syria Trust charity, a state-owned fuel supplier, and Syria's national blood bank, all linked to the Assad regime. The UN Food and Agriculture Organisation also gave $13.3 million to the Syrian agriculture ministry, which is on the EU sanctions list. The UN defended the contracts as a necessary choice to provide life-saving assistance to civilians in need.

site_title: Singapore's tax revenue up 3.2% to S$44.8b in FY15/16
summary: Singapore's tax revenue increased by 3.2% to S$44.8 billion in FY15/16, exceeding the previous year's figure. Tax compliance remained high, with 96% of individuals and 82% of companies filing on-time. Goods and services tax collection also rose marginally to 23% of overall revenue. The Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (Iras) recovered over S$411 million in taxes and penalties through audits and investigations, keeping the cost of collection low at 0.83 cents per dollar collected.

images.alt_text: THE Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (Iras) collected S$44.8 billion in tax revenue in FY15/16 - 3.2 per cent more than in the previous financial year.

site_title: Chip Eng Seng unit wins S$75.9m contract
summary: CHIP Eng Seng Corporation Ltd announced that its subsidiary, CES-Precast Pte Ltd, won a S$75.9 million contract to supply precast concrete items for the "Thomson-East Coast Line" project. The contract was awarded by GS Engineering & Construction Corp and is not expected to impact the company's earnings or net tangible assets for the current financial year. The board of directors stated that none of the directors or substantial shareholders have any direct or indirect interest in the transaction.

site_title: No EU-US trade deal before Obama leaves office: Hollande
summary: French President Francois Hollande announced that a long-awaited EU-US trade deal will not be agreed upon before US President Barack Obama leaves office in January. Hollande stated that France prefers to maintain the current situation rather than pursuing an agreement under the current US president. French junior trade minister Matthias Fekl also expressed dissatisfaction with the negotiations, saying they lack "political support" and that the US negotiators offer minimal concessions. The talks are likely to be suspended to restart on a more solid foundation.

images.alt_text: French President Francois Hollande said Tuesday a long-awaited EU-US trade deal would not be agreed before US President Barack Obama leaves office in January.

site_title: China stocks close higher as banking shares rebound
summary: China stocks closed higher on Tuesday as banking shares rebounded, despite weak earnings reports and concerns about bad loans. The rebound was driven by relief that interim results didn't show rapid deterioration in asset quality. Transport stocks were sold, leaving major indexes little changed.

site_title: S'pore banks able to withstand a sharp property fall: Fitch
summary: Singapore's banks are well-equipped to withstand a sharp decline in the property market, according to Fitch Ratings. A 45% home-price collapse and a 5% non-performing loan ratio would shave 17-24% off their 2015 earnings, but the regulator's proactive measures and banks' disciplined underwriting standards should mitigate this impact. Household balance sheets are also strong, with low leverage and diversified assets. Fitch expects a further decline in home prices due to a supply of new homes and moderating population growth, but believes the potential earnings impact on banks will be manageable.

images.alt_text: Fitch expects Singapore's private residential-home prices to weaken further as a large supply of new homes floods the market.

site_title: Singapore shares close flat with STI at 2,828.39
summary: Singapore shares closed almost flat at 2,828.39, with the Straits Times Index (STI) easing 0.04% or 1.04 points. A total of 1 billion shares changed hands, with Reits gaining 0.41% and DBS Group rising 0.13%. United Overseas Bank retreated 0.11%. The STI has notched a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Russian hackers attack two US voter databases: reports
summary: Russian hackers may have breached US voter registration databases in Illinois and Arizona, potentially undermining November's presidential election. The FBI attributed the attacks to Russian spy agencies, citing concerns Moscow may be trying to create uncertainty. Hackers stole data from up to 200,000 voter records, but no records were deleted or altered. The incidents prompted Homeland Security Secretary Jeh Johnson to urge state election officials to secure their systems. This is the first reported hack tied to the Russian government.

site_title: Millions at risk from rising water pollution: UN
summary: A UN report warns that millions are at risk from rising water pollution, affecting over 300 million people in Africa, Asia, and Latin America. The pollution, driven by factory waste, fertilizers, and untreated sewage, poses a disease risk, threatens fisheries and farming, and endangers access to quality water. The report estimates that 164 million people in Africa, 134 million in Asia, and 25 million in Latin America are at risk of water-borne diseases. To combat this, the report recommends treating polluted water, recycling wastewater, and restoring wetlands to remove pollution.

images.alt_text: Increasingly polluted rivers in Africa, Asia and Latin America pose a disease risk to more than 300 million people and threaten fisheries and farming in many countries, a UN report warned Tuesday.

site_title: India may auction diamond mine abandoned by Rio Tinto
summary: India plans to auction a diamond mine abandoned by Rio Tinto, with the estimated 27.4 million carats of diamonds potentially worth billions of dollars. The mine, located 500 km southeast of New Delhi, was discovered in 2004 but Rio Tinto will pull out by the end of the year due to financial constraints. The government will move quickly to tap the resource, considering auctioning or allocating it to a state firm.

site_title: Germany's EU commissioner doubts Brexit will happen
summary: Germany's EU Commissioner Guenther Oettinger expressed doubts about the UK's exit from the EU, saying he wouldn't "bet on Brexit". He assumed the June referendum outcome was "binding" but predicted economic and political insecurity if the UK waits longer to trigger Article 50. Oettinger's comments come as Prime Minister Theresa May delays the trigger, citing the need to shape Britain's exit objectives. German Chancellor Angela Merkel has refused to enter preliminary negotiations until Article 50 is activated.

site_title: EU, US still have work to do on standards in free trade deal: German foreign minister
summary: German Foreign Minister Frank-Walter Steinmeier stated that the EU and US still have work to do to negotiate standards and procedures in the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP) deal. The talks remain unclear, partly due to calls for caution from US presidential candidates. Germany's Economy Minister Sigmar Gabriel described the talks as having "de facto failed." The pace of negotiations has been slow, and the EU had previously negotiated high-quality standards in a separate free trade deal with Canada.

site_title: UK company pension insurance deals drop 39% in H1: Aon Hewitt
summary: UK bulk annuity company pension deals totalled 2.7 billion pounds in the first half of 2016, a 39% drop from last year, according to Aon Hewitt. Pricing remains competitive, and deal volume is expected to accelerate in the second half. Falling UK interest rates have widened pension deficits, prompting companies to offload risk. Insurers such as Legal & General and Pension Insurance Corp have completed deals in July and August.

site_title: US home prices ease in June
summary: US home prices eased in June, with the top 20 cities experiencing a 0.1% decline, according to the S&P CoreLogic Case-Shiller Indices. The year-on-year rise slowed to 5.1%, down from 5.3% in May. Despite the slowdown, analysts expect solid demand and tight supplies to maintain a floor on the market, particularly in northwest cities like Portland, Seattle, and Denver.

site_title: China's big banks set for hard slog as margins shrink
summary: China's four major state-owned banks, including ICBC and BoC, expect profits to be pressured in the second half due to slowing economic growth, which is affecting borrowers and reducing lender margins. Rising volumes of sour debt are also forcing quicker write-offs, despite rate cuts that have reduced interest income. The banks have warned of tough times ahead, indicating a challenging period for the industry.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's tax revenue increased 3.2% to S$44.8 billion in FY15/16, according to the Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore. Changi Airport saw increased activity in July, while the Asian US dollar bond market saw strong demand for US$ bond deals. Australia, Taiwan, and South Korea issued travel warnings for pregnant women due to the Zika virus outbreak in Singapore. The Straits Times Index (STI) closed flat at 2,828.39.

images.alt_text: THE Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (Iras) collected S$44.8 billion in tax revenue in FY15/16 - 3.2 per cent more than in the previous financial year.

site_title: US, India sign military logistics agreement
summary: The US and India signed a military logistics agreement, allowing both countries to use each other's bases for repair and resupply. The agreement aims to build defence ties and counter China's growing maritime assertiveness. US Defence Secretary Ash Carter and Indian Defence Minister Manohar Parrikar emphasized that the agreement does not allow for US troop basing in India, alleviating concerns about India's autonomy. The deal is seen as a milestone in the US-India defence relationship, with both countries prioritizing a closer defence partnership to counter regional security challenges.

site_title: China foreign ministry condemns attack on embassy in Kyrgyzstan
summary: China's foreign ministry has condemned a car bomb attack on its embassy in Kyrgyzstan, where three embassy staff were wounded in the incident. A suspected suicide bomber rammed the gates, killing himself, and no organisation has claimed responsibility. The staff suffered minor injuries and have been taken to hospital. China is urging Kyrgyz authorities to investigate the incident thoroughly.

site_title: Engie, Green Climate Fund invest in off-grid solar developer
summary: Engie SA and the Green Climate Fund invested US$20 million in BBOXX Ltd, a UK-based off-grid solar developer. This investment aims to boost the rapidly expanding global market for off-grid solar power, particularly in Cameroon and the Ivory Coast. BBOXX plans to use the funds to expand its operations in these countries. The investment reflects the growing interest in off-grid solar power and the potential for Africa's energy market.

site_title: Morgan Stanley says forget September as JPMorgan tips weak jobs
summary: Morgan Stanley predicts the Federal Reserve will not raise interest rates in September, citing no significant change in policy makers' views from the Jackson Hole meeting. The market-implied odds of a rate hike have dropped to 42% from 24% at the start of the week. Despite this, the yield on five-year notes rose 3 basis points to 1.19%, and Morgan Stanley continues to recommend investors buy US sovereign debt.

site_title: Sterling slips back towards US$1.30 as Transatlantic rate paths diverge
summary: Sterling slipped back towards US$1.30 as investors diverged in expectations for monetary policy, with a 55% chance of a US interest rate hike by year-end and a possible cut in British rates. Sterling has fallen over 1% against the US dollar since the comments from US Federal Reserve chair Janet Yellen and vice chair Stanley Fischer, trading 0.2% lower on the day at US$1.3076. Analysts expect further declines due to the BOE's easing bias and sterling's role as a funding currency.

site_title: Volvo Cars to hire 400 engineers to spearhead high-tech push
summary: Volvo Car Group, owned by Chinese company Zhejiang Geely Holding Group Co, plans to hire 400 engineers over the next year to focus on safety technology, autonomous driving, and electrification. The recruitment drive is part of the company's efforts to solidify its position in the premium car market. Most engineers will be based at Volvo's research and development center in Gothenburg, Sweden, and the company has also opened a new center in Lund, southern Sweden. This move aims to establish Volvo as a hub for automotive software engineering.

site_title: VW reviews its procurement strategy in wake of supplier dispute
summary: Volkswagen is reviewing its supplier and procurement strategy after a dispute with suppliers Car Trim and ES Automobilguss led to production slowdowns and stoppages at six plants in August. The dispute was caused by halting deliveries of seat covers and gearboxes. CEO Matthias Mueller said the company will examine multi-sourcing and single-sourcing options and optimize procurement contracts with suppliers. A similar escalation with other suppliers, who are members of the VDA, is less likely due to an agreed code of conduct. Prevent Group, the non-VDA member, was the sole cause of the dispute.

site_title: Australia, Taiwan, South Korea issue travel warnings for Singapore
summary: Australia, Taiwan, and South Korea have issued travel warnings to pregnant women and those attempting to get pregnant, advising them to avoid travel to Singapore due to a Zika virus outbreak that has infected over 50 people, including at least 56 confirmed cases. The outbreak poses a risk to pregnant women, potentially causing severe birth defects. Authorities in Singapore are inspecting homes and spraying insecticide, while tourism remains a "safe destination," according to the city-state's Tourism Board.

images.alt_text: Australia, Taiwan and South Korea advised pregnant women and those attempting to get pregnant to avoid travel to Singapore after an outbreak of the Zika virus infected more than 50 people in the city-state.

site_title: Philippines says China must recognise South China Sea ruling
summary: Philippine Foreign Minister Perfecto Yasay stated that China will be the "loser" if it doesn't recognize an international court ruling against Beijing's territorial claims in the South China Sea. The ruling, made by an arbitration court in The Hague in July, found China had no historical title over the sea and had breached the Philippines' sovereign rights. China's refusal to acknowledge the ruling has sparked tensions between the two countries.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares end up as US rate hike views ease
summary: Hong Kong shares rose 0.9% on Tuesday as investors became less optimistic about a US interest rate hike in September, following Fed Chair Janet Yellen's comments. The Hang Seng Index increased to 23,016.11, while the China Enterprises Index rose 1.1%. Material stocks led the gain, but China Southern Airlines' stock slumped 6% after reporting a 11% drop in first-half profit. The US Federal Reserve's rate hike timing remains uncertain, keeping investors on edge.

site_title: Update: ST Engineering's US subsidiary in Saudi JV
summary: ST Engineering's US subsidiary, VT Halter Marine Inc, has formed a joint venture, ZHR Marine LCC, with Raytheon Company and Zamil Group in Saudi Arabia to bid on the Royal Saudi Naval Force Eastern Fleet Modernisation Programme. The joint venture aims to leverage expertise in naval vessel construction, shipbuilding, and naval systems integration to secure local content projects. The partnership is not expected to impact ST Engineering's financials. In separate news, former ST Marine executive Han Yew Kwang was sentenced to six months' imprisonment and fined S$80,000 for corruption and bribery charges.

site_title: Europe: Stocks stable at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets steadied at the start of trade on Tuesday, with London's FTSE 100 index down 0.1% and Frankfurt's DAX 30 up 0.4%. The Paris CAC 40 also rose 0.4%. The moves followed investors' reaction to the US Federal Reserve's interest rate hike expectations, with Asian equities rising as the yen fell against the US dollar.

site_title: Tokio Marine in exclusive talks to buy RHB's general insurance unit: sources
summary: Tokio Marine Holdings Inc is in exclusive talks to buy RHB Bank's general insurance unit in a deal valued between 3-3.5 times book value, potentially worth up to US$500 million. This acquisition would make it one of the most expensive non-life insurance deals in Southeast Asia. The planned deal builds upon an existing distribution agreement between the two companies to sell life insurance products in Malaysia, and other global insurers are also interested in the unit if Tokio Marine fails to meet RHB's price expectations.

site_title: UK consumer credit growth cools, mortgage approvals lowest since Jan 2015
summary: The UK's consumer credit growth slowed in August, marking the first annual decline since December 2014. Consumer credit rose 1.181 billion pounds, the weakest increase since August 2015, and annual growth fell to 10.1% from 10.3%. Mortgage approvals for house purchases also fell to 60,912, the lowest since January 2015. This marks a contrasting trend to other consumer demand indicators, which have shown little immediate impact from the Brexit vote.

site_title: Hong Kong housing prices to fall a further 10%, Nomura says
summary: Hong Kong home prices are expected to fall 10% in the medium term, according to a report by Nomura Holdings Inc. Analysts cite a weakening economy, stagnant real household income growth, and looming interest rate hikes as factors contributing to the decline. The report also predicts a 5% drop in rental returns for Hong Kong's retail property market and office rents may fall as much as 5%. Despite the negative outlook, Nomura remains positive on Hong Kong property names with healthy debt levels and solid balance sheets.

site_title: Strong demand for US$ bond deals
summary: Strong demand for US$ bonds is seen in the Asian market, with three benchmark-sized deals receiving combined orders over US$16.55 billion. DBS's USD Additional Tier 1 bond deal received over US$8 billion in orders, priced at 3.65% with a 5-basis point band. Chinese issuers Chongqing Western Modern Logistics Industrial Zone and Road King Infrastructure also secured significant orders, with final prices guidance set at 1.198% and 4.70-4.75% respectively. The strong demand is attributed to investors seeking to capitalize on subdued interest rates and under-investment in cash.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks, won end up as Fed's hike concerns ease
summary: South Korean shares and the won rose on Tuesday as concerns over a US Federal Reserve interest rate hike eased. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) closed 0.4% higher at 2,039.74 points. Foreign investors bought 58 billion won worth of Kospi shares, and the won strengthened 0.5% against the US dollar to 1,119.9 to the dollar.

site_title: Italy prepares to sell bonds as political hurdles loom
summary: Italy is set to sell up to 7.75 billion euros in bonds on Tuesday, amid concerns over Prime Minister Matteo Renzi's future. The yield on Italy's 10-year BTP bond rose 1.5 basis points to 1.13%, following a two-week decline. Analysts attribute the rise to uncertainties in Italy's referendum and market sentiment. This sale marks a major test of investor confidence in the euro zone, following a steady rise in yields over the past fortnight.

site_title: Obama to meet Philippines' controversial President
summary: US President Barack Obama will meet Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte on the sidelines of a summit in Laos, despite concerns over Duterte's war on crime that has claimed over 2,000 lives. Obama will likely voice disquiet over the bloodshed and Duterte's abusive remarks, including calling the US ambassador a "son of a whore." The US State Department has expressed deep concern over reports of extrajudicial killings, and the UN has criticized Duterte's promise of immunity and bounties for security forces. The meeting is seen as a test of the US's commitment to its treaty ally despite significant differences.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares edge lower as soft data offsets weak yen
summary: Tokyo shares closed 0.07% lower on Tuesday, offsetting the previous day's sharp jump, as tepid data and profit-taking weighed on the market. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index fell to 16,725.36. A weaker yen also contributed to the decline. The Nikkei 225 index had surged 1.21% the previous day, but profit-taking and weak data data limited gains.

site_title: Vietnam says all will lose in any South China Sea war
summary: Vietnamese President Tran Dai Quang warned that any armed conflict in the South China Sea would result in no winners, but rather all parties would lose. He cited recent developments as threatening regional security, without mentioning specific countries. China claims most of the South China Sea, leading to territorial disputes with neighboring countries like Vietnam and the Philippines. The region's maritime security and freedom of navigation are at risk, with the US also seeking to ensure freedom of navigation through the sea, which handles $5 trillion in annual global trade.

images.alt_text: Vietnamese President Tran Dai Quang warned on Tuesday there would be no winners in any armed conflict sparked by territorial disputes in the South China Sea.

site_title: South Korea 2017 budget focuses on job creation, spending up modestly
summary: South Korea's 2017 budget focuses on job creation, with a 3.7% increase in spending to 400.7 trillion won. The government aims to create 17.5 trillion won in new jobs, with a focus on industries preferred by young Koreans, such as gaming and technology. Exports are expected to remain weak, and the economy is projected to grow 3.0% next year. The government plans to reduce its fiscal deficit to 1.0% of GDP by 2020, while keeping sovereign debt at 40% of GDP.

site_title: Asia: Markets track Wall St up, US jobs in focus
summary: Asian markets rose on Tuesday, following a Wall Street rally, as investors awaited US job data and potential interest rate hikes. The yen fell against the US dollar amid expectations of Japanese monetary easing. Bets on a US rate hike have increased after Janet Yellen's statement at the Jackson Hole symposium.

site_title: Samsung SDI to build 400b won car battery factory in Hungary by 2018
summary: Samsung SDI plans to invest 400 billion won (approximately $487 million) to build a car battery factory in Hungary by 2018. The plant, which will start production in the second half of 2018, will produce batteries for 50,000 electric vehicles, helping the company save logistics costs and meet European demand. This move joins the company in the race to build capacity and tap into European demand, as Chinese demand is disappointing. The factory will be located near Budapest and will support Samsung SDI's customers, including BMW.

site_title: Transatlantic trade talks should be halted: French trade minister
summary: French Trade Minister Matthias Fekl says the current round of Transatlantic trade talks should be halted and a new set started. German Economy Minister Sigmar Gabriel stated negotiations over the TTIP had effectively failed due to Europe's refusal to accept US demands. Fekl plans to suggest halting negotiations at the end of September trade ministers meeting in Bratislava.

site_title: Truck with Takata airbag parts explodes, kills US woman
summary: A truck carrying Takata airbag parts exploded on a US highway, killing a woman and injuring four others. The accident occurred on August 22 in Maverick County, Texas, and was caused by a road accident, not the defective airbag part. The victim's body was severely damaged, but dental records were used to identify her. Takata denied the accident was related to the airbag defect, which has caused at least 15 deaths and scores of injuries globally, with 100 million airbags recalled.

site_title: Australia shares end marginally higher; New Zealand bounces back
summary: Australian shares rose 0.17% to close at 5478.3, driven by gains in healthcare and energy stocks. Ramsay Health Care Ltd reported record-high earnings, contributing to the recovery. New Zealand's benchmark index rose 0.28% to 7387.95, with Auckland International Airport Ltd and Fisher & Paykel Ltd among the biggest gainers. The gains followed overnight strength on Wall Street and upbeat US consumer spending data.

site_title: Australia, NZ dollars pare losses on Fed hike scepticism
summary: The Australian dollar rebounded from near 1-month lows, holding at US$0.7569, as traders became skeptical about a US rate hike in September. Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen provided little detail on when the Fed might next move, and market expectations shifted to a high probability of a 2016 Fed lift-off. The New Zealand dollar also recovered after hitting a two-week low, with yields 6 basis points lower at the long end of the curve.

site_title: AirAsia may sell leasing unit as early as December to pare debt
summary: AirAsia may sell its aircraft-leasing unit, Asia Aviation Capital, as early as December to net up to $1 billion and pare debt. The company's CEO, Tony Fernandes, stated that proceeds from the sale could be used to reduce debt or pay a dividend. AirAsia's board has approved the sale process, with RHB Investment Bank, Credit Suisse Group, and BNP Paribas serving as joint advisers. The sale could involve divesting all or a minority interest in the unit, depending on the buyer.

site_title: Oil edges back in Asia after sharp losses
summary: Oil prices edged up in Asia on Tuesday, rising 0.21% to US$47.08 for West Texas Intermediate and 0.08% to US$49.30 for Brent. The gains came after a sharp decline on Monday, following the Federal Reserve's possible rate hike indication. Investors are waiting for US jobs data and a key producers' meeting next month to determine the direction of oil prices, with lingering worries about a global supply glut. A deal to limit production is seen as necessary to stabilize the market and push prices higher.

site_title: Viva Industrial Trust secures anchor tenant for business park's 'white' space
summary: Viva Industrial Trust secured an anchor tenant for the 'white' space at Viva Business Park, a 38,000 sq ft area with a leading household name as a tenant. The tenant will occupy the space, increasing the proportion of committed leases for the 214,951 sq ft area to above 90%. The renovated section will offer sports and fitness, food and beverage, and family-oriented amenities, catering to the wider Bedok region. Total occupancy for the 1.5 million sq ft park is currently 70.2%.

site_title: Debt-led phone war may blow US$74b hole in India wallet
summary: India's planned spectrum auction may fall short of expectations due to carriers' financial constraints. The 12 wireless companies in the country carry over $61 billion in debt, with average revenue per user declining as customers shift to data plans. The government aims to raise $113 billion, but carriers may only bid a fraction of that due to debt and the need to fund billionaire Mukesh Ambani's venture, Reliance Jio Infocomm. The auction, which could raise $74 billion, may be hindered by high reserve prices and a fierce price war, potentially blowing a hole in the government's budget.

site_title: Thailand's first halal hotel hopes to help boost Muslim arrivals
summary: Thailand has opened its first halal hotel, the Al Meroz, in Bangkok, aiming to attract more Muslim visitors and boost its economy. The four-star hotel, which opened in November, offers mosque-like architecture, prayer rooms, and halal dining halls, catering to the 1.6 billion-strong Muslim market. Despite a 10% increase in arrivals from the Middle East in 2015, Thailand still lags behind, with only 658,000 Muslim visitors. The hotel's general manager hopes to capitalize on the growing Muslim tourist market and change the country's economic fortunes.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks rise as Fed worries ease; won recovers
summary: South Korean shares rose 0.8% on Tuesday, driven by easing concerns of an interest rate increase in the US as early as September. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) reached 2,049.21 points. Foreign investors, including domestic institutions, bought local equities, contributing to the market's recovery. The won also recovered from Monday's loss, supporting the market's upward trend.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks up with overseas markets; tech shares drag
summary: Taiwan's main TAIEX index rose 0.1% to 9,119.56 on Tuesday, boosted by a bounce in overseas markets. However, gains were limited by profit-taking in key tech stocks, including TSMC and Hon Hai, which fell 0.3% and 0.2% respectively. The Taiwan dollar strengthened to NT$31.719 per US dollar.

site_title: Shenzhen-Hong Kong link expected to start in November, CSRC says
summary: China's markets regulator expects the link between Hong Kong and Shenzhen stock markets to start in mid- to late-November. Technical preparations will take place from August to November, following a four-month timeline announced earlier. The link aims to open China's markets to the global financial community, addressing barriers to foreigners trading mainland equities. The daily limits for the Shenzhen link will be 13 billion yuan northbound and 10.5 billion yuan southbound, with small-cap companies valued over HK$5 billion eligible for inclusion.

site_title: Thai factory output unexpectedly slips 5.1% year on year in July
summary: Thailand's industrial output declined 5.1% year-over-year in July, contrary to expectations, due to sluggish exports and domestic demand. This is the first decline in five months. Industrial goods accounted for 80% of total exports, which contracted 4.4% from a year earlier. The sector's capacity utilization was 62.34% in July. Exports have declined in each of the past three years, with the central bank forecasting a 2.5% contraction this year.

images.alt_text: Thailand's industrial output declined for the first time in five months in July, contrary to expectations and showing the sector continues to struggle in the face of sluggish exports and domestic demand.

site_title: Captain America directors to form venture with Huayi Brothers
summary: Huayi Brothers Media Corp has formed a venture with the directors of the Captain America movies, Joe Russo and Anthony Russo, to produce and invest in English-language films. Huayi will own 60% of the venture and invest $250 million, while the Russos will hold the remaining 40%. The move aims to expand Chinese companies' presence in Hollywood, following Huayi's previous partnership with STX Entertainment and billionaire Wang Jianlin's acquisition of Legendary Entertainment. The venture will have exclusive distribution rights for Greater China and South-east Asia.

site_title: BOJ needs massive shock & awe, US$2t investor says
summary: The Bank of Japan may announce a "massive stimulus program" to reach its 2% inflation target, according to UBS Wealth Management's global chief investment officer Mark Haefele. Consumer prices fell 0.5% in July, and the central bank's benchmark inflation gauge has been declining. The BOJ will review its monetary policy ahead of its Sept 20-21 meeting, with Haefele suggesting the central bank may adopt more stimulus to boost inflation.

site_title: China Southern profit declines as Spring Air, Hainan advance
summary: China Southern Airlines reported a 10% decline in profits to 3.12 billion yuan for the first half of the year, due to a 10-fold surge in currency losses from the yuan's depreciation. The airline will consider hedging for fuel to revive earnings, as low-fare carriers like Hainan Airlines and Spring Airlines Co reported a 4.4% and 740 million yuan increase in profits, respectively. The airline's yield fell 7.5% due to expansion of international services.

images.alt_text: China Southern Airlines Co, Asia's biggest by passengers, said its profits were dented by the yuan's depreciation while two of the country's largest private carriers reported an increase in earnings amid a surge in travel.

site_title: Oil prices rise as US dollar retreats from two-week high
summary: Oil prices rose on Tuesday as the US dollar retreated from a two-week high, but concerns over a successful OPEC production freeze continued to weigh on markets. International Brent crude oil futures rose 8 US cents to $49.34 per barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures increased 15 US cents to $47.13 per barrel. The US dollar's decline makes oil purchases cheaper, potentially boosting demand, but OPEC talks remain uncertain, with some producers tempering expectations for a production freeze.

site_title: DBS debuts US$ denominated securities
summary: DBS Group Holdings has launched its first US dollar-denominated Additional Tier 1 securities, offering a yield of around 4%. The perpetual non-call five notes will be rated A3/BBB and reset in September 2021 to the prevailing five-year US dollar swap rate plus an initial spread.
