The securities will permanently write off in the event of a loss-absorption event or as determined by the Monetary Authority of Singapore. DBS is sole global coordinator and joint bookrunner with Citigroup, Deutsche Bank, HSBC, and Societe Generale.

site_title: Philippines' budget deficit widens to US$1.1b in July
summary: The Philippines' budget deficit widened to 50.7 billion Philippine pesos (US$1.1 billion) in July, exceeding the previous month's 45.2 billion peso gap and last year's 32.2 billion peso deficit. This brings the January-July shortfall to 171.0 billion peso. The government's budget deficit goal for the year was set at 388.9 billion pesos or 2.7% of GDP. The wider deficit is a concern for policymakers.

images.alt_text: The Philippine government had a budget deficit of 50.7 billion Philippine pesos (S$1.5 billion) in July, which brought the shortfall in January-July to 171.0 billion peso, the Department of Finance said on Tuesday.

site_title: Design flaws led to deadly Brazil mine disaster: report
summary: A technical report commissioned by BHP Billiton and Vale found design flaws and a series of problems over six years led to the 2015 Brazil mine dam collapse, resulting in 19 deaths and a tsunami of toxic waste. The report identified a chain of events from 2009 to 2015 as the cause of the disaster. Samarco, the mine's operator, is facing billions of dollars in legal claims for clean-up costs and damages.

images.alt_text: Design flaws and a series of problems over six years led to the collapse of a mine dam and the loss of 19 lives in Brazil's worst environmental disaster, mining giant BHP Billiton said Tuesday.

site_title: Changi Airport's activity rises in July
summary: Changi Airport reported increased activity in July 2016, handling 5.18 million passenger movements, a 5.9% year-on-year rise. Aircraft movements rose 4.7% to 30,790 landings and takeoffs, while cargo shipments increased 9.4% to 161,450 tonnes. Passenger traffic to and from China grew 13.4%, with Denpasar and Melbourne recording the strongest growth among top 10 cities, both up 13.1% and 20.6%, respectively.

site_title: Australia shares bounce on Wall Street, financials lead; NZ stocks up
summary: Australian shares rose 0.5% to 5497.6, driven by overnight gains on Wall Street and upbeat US consumer spending data. The S&P/ASX 200 index rebounded after hitting its lowest in over a month due to concerns of a US interest rate hike. Strong US consumer spending lifted the mood, supporting gains in the financial sector.

site_title: Tennis: Djokovic beats scare, Nadal eases at revamped US Open
summary: Defending champion Novak Djokovic overcame an arm injury scare to defeat Jerzy Janowicz 6-3, 5-7, 6-2, 6-1. Rafael Nadal shone with a 6-1, 6-4, 6-2 win over Denis Istomin. In the women's event, Angelique Kerber and Garbine Muguruza progressed, with Muguruza needing treatment after a first-set loss. The revamped US Open complex showcased its US$650 million upgrade, hosting its first match under the new roof.

images.alt_text: Defending champion Novak Djokovic overcame an arm injury scare and long-time rival Rafael Nadal shone in 33-degree heat as the US Open showcased its US$650 million upgrade on Monday.

site_title: These are the must-have amenities for luxe wine cellars today
summary: Luxury wine cellars have evolved from basic storage spaces to sophisticated, high-tech amenities. Today's wine cellars often feature tasting tables, comfortable seating, and advanced lighting systems, making them a stylish addition to the home. Many ultra-high net worth individuals are investing in wine collections, with global real estate company Knight Frank reporting a 241% increase in wine investment over the past decade. Designer cellars can cost upwards of $220,000, with features such as refrigeration, smart glass, and security systems. The trend is towards integrating the cellar into the main living area, with a focus on strategic lighting and design.

site_title: NEA, MOH step up fight as Zika cases rise to 56
summary: The National Environment Agency (NEA) and the Ministry of Health (MOH) in Singapore have stepped up efforts to contain the Zika virus after 15 new cases were reported, bringing the total to 56 locally infected individuals. Authorities warn that more cases may be uncovered. The Zika outbreak has prompted increased vigilance and surveillance measures to prevent further transmission.

site_title: Cathay Pacific is the world's least-favourite airline stock
summary: Cathay Pacific Airways Ltd has been ranked as the world's least-favourite airline stock, with analysts giving it a score of 2.26 out of 5. The carrier's shares have tumbled 11% this month, falling to a record low, due to an 82% drop in first-half net income and declining passenger yields. Rising competition from Chinese airlines and capacity constraints at Hong Kong's airport are denting the outlook for Cathay Pacific. Analysts predict a "multi-year" decline in passenger yields and a further 3% decline in the company's shares over the next 12 months.

site_title: Volkswagen decides not to sue South Korea over sales ban
summary: Volkswagen has decided not to sue South Korea over the suspension of sales of most of its models due to fabricated emissions and noise-level certificates. The German carmaker will instead attempt to achieve certification for the affected models and resume sales quickly. This decision comes after the South Korean government imposed a 17.8 billion won fine and halted sales of 80 model variants. Volkswagen's sales in South Korea plummeted 40% to 12,888 vehicles from January to July, following its emissions-test cheating scandal.

site_title: Denied work, Rohingya trapped in limbo in Malaysia
summary: Malaysia is grappling with a large Rohingya refugee population, estimated at 150,000, who lack formal status and are barred from working officially. These refugees, mainly from Myanmar, are forced to find odd jobs due to the country's restrictive policies, leaving them vulnerable to exploitation. A new government-led task force has been established to address refugee registration issues and explore the possibility of opening up job opportunities for refugees, including education for their children. However, many refugees face challenges such as harassment from law enforcement officials and limited access to medical treatment and housing.

site_title: Stocks to watch: GL, Ezion, Healthway
summary: GL Ltd reported a 41% increase in net profit to US$67.6 million. Ezion Holdings' second-quarter results were adjusted down by US$11.7 million due to additional impairments. No other material announcements were made.

site_title: Pimco to hire 20 people to target US$17.4t Asian wealth
summary: Pimco, a US$1.5 trillion money manager, plans to hire 20 people in the next two years to expand its presence in Asia's affluent markets. The company aims to target high net-worth individuals in Hong Kong, Singapore, Thailand, Malaysia, and the Philippines, where wealth has grown 10% to US$17.4 trillion. This move follows a significant increase in Chinese investors fleeing a weakening yuan, with Pimco experiencing "significant" growth in net inflow this year. The company plans to establish an onshore presence in China in the future.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares pick up at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose in the first minutes of trade on Tuesday, following a regional rally and a strong lead from Wall Street. The Hang Seng Index increased 0.73%, adding 166.28 points to 22,987.62. The Shanghai Composite Index also edged up 1.41 points to 3,071.44, while the Shenzhen Composite Index remained virtually flat. This uptrend is in line with a regional market rally, with other Asian markets also showing gains.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open lower despite Wall Street gains
summary: Tokyo shares opened lower on Tuesday, despite gains on Wall Street, with the Nikkei 225 index falling 0.28% and the Topix index losing 0.24%. The moves followed a positive lead from US stocks, which edged to fresh records. The opening losses were attributed to ongoing market volatility and uncertainty, particularly regarding US trade policies.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 5.020 points to 1686.620. The index saw 23.87 million lots traded worth RM15.62 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 107 to 56, indicating a positive market trend.

site_title: Australian state of Victoria to permanently ban onshore gas fracking
summary: Victoria, Australia plans to ban onshore gas fracking permanently, citing concerns for farmers and potential health and environmental risks. The ban applies to shale and coal seam gas fracking, but conventional gas drilling is allowed until 2020. The decision aims to protect the state's farmers and groundwater reserves, which are at risk of depletion or contamination. The move comes as eastern Australia's gas supply is set to increase due to liquefied natural gas export plants in Queensland.

site_title: European experts float post-Brexit "partnership" with Britain
summary: European experts propose a "continental partnership" with Britain post-Brexit, allowing Britain to contribute to EU security and budgets in exchange for easy immigration for European workers. The proposed partnership aims to avoid a split and maintain Britain's stake in European economic and political stability. Key figures, including a German lawmaker and a former Bank of England deputy governor, argue that Britain's geographical interdependencies with the EU require collaboration. This proposal reflects a potential compromise for Britain's post-Brexit relationship with the EU.

site_title: Chinese private investment funds to conduct 'self-inspection'
summary: Chinese private investment funds will conduct a "self-inspection" of their business practices to ensure compliance with regulations, following a directive from the State Council. The inspection will cover advertising practices, fundraising from prohibited investor classes, and other prohibited activities. This initiative comes after a finding by China's securities regulator that some funds had regularly violated regulations. The funds are also required to strengthen internal risk management and boost training on regulations and societal responsibility. The move aims to improve oversight in the finance sector, which has faced increased regulatory scrutiny since the 2015 stock crash.

site_title: AT&T escapes regulator's US$300m data throttling case
summary: AT&T has escaped a US$300m data throttling case filed by the Federal Trade Commission (FTC). A federal appeals panel ruled that the FTC lacked jurisdiction to crack down on AT&T for deceiving 3.5 million customers who paid for unlimited data plans but had their speeds cut. The panel agreed with AT&T's argument that the FTC's net neutrality rules stripped the agency of jurisdiction. The FTC plans to consider its options for moving forward, while AT&T expressed satisfaction with the court's decision.

site_title: Yen holds losses before next clue on Fed rates from jobs data
summary: The yen remains weaker against the US dollar, dropping 1.7% in the past four sessions, amid speculation that strong US jobs data will boost the likelihood of a Federal Reserve interest rate hike. The Fed's next policy meeting is on September 20-21, with US jobs data on Friday expected to fuel expectations for a rate hike. The yen's decline has widened policy divergence with the Bank of Japan, which has signaled a readiness to ease monetary policy further.

site_title: Alphabet executive steps down from Uber board amid growing competition
summary: Alphabet executive David Drummond stepped down from Uber's board amid growing competition between the two companies, particularly in the autonomous vehicle business. Drummond joined Uber's board in 2013 after Alphabet's venture capital arm GV invested $250 million in Uber. His departure is seen as a signal of increased overlap between the companies. Uber is focusing on developing self-driving cars, while Google is also working on making its self-driving car experiments into a viable business.

site_title: Dotcom says extradition appeal to be live-streamed
summary: New Zealand judge grants Kim Dotcom's request to live-stream his extradition appeal, allowing the public to watch the proceedings. The live stream will start with a 20-minute delay to prevent restricted material from being published. Dotcom faces up to 20 years in prison if convicted in the US of video piracy charges, which US authorities claim cost copyright owners hundreds of millions of dollars. The live stream will be broadcast after Dotcom's lawyer, Ron Mansfield, argues that the case raises "unprecedented issues of public and international interest."

site_title: Ezion revises Q2 results down US$11.7m after associate impairment
summary: Ezion Holdings has revised its Q2 results down by US$11.7 million after an impairment of property, plant and equipment and intangible assets of an associate. This results in a profit decline from US$19.8 million to US$8.1 million for the three months ended June 30, and from US$35.3 million to US$23.6 million for the half-year. Total assets and equity will also decrease accordingly. The carrying amount of the associate's investment is now US$6.7 million.

site_title: Singapore shares open 0.6% up on Tuesday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 15.58 points to 2,845.01, up 0.6%, following market sentiment recovery from Fed rate hike fears. About 41 million shares changed hands at S$0.77 per share, with gainers outnumbering losers 92 to 48. The rally comes ahead of GDP data, with top stocks including HTL International, Singtel, and ComfortDelGro.

site_title: Traders said to discuss data superhighway from Chicago to Japan
summary: Rival high-frequency trading firms are in talks to jointly build a Chicago-to-Japan communications link, dubbed "Go West", to accelerate trans-Pacific trading. The project would install microwave towers along the US west coast and connect to an undersea cable. The firms involved include Citadel LLC, Virtu Financial Inc, and Jump Trading LLC, aiming to reduce infrastructure costs and cut trading times. This collaboration may signal a truce in the high-speed trading arms race, allowing traders to compete on strategy rather than speed.

site_title: FBI detects breaches against two state voter systems
summary: The FBI has detected breaches in Illinois and Arizona's voter registration databases, with the agency urging states to increase computer security ahead of the November 8 presidential election. The breaches, which occurred in late July and involved malicious software, are not believed to have manipulated votes but may be a precursor to a larger attack. The FBI is investigating whether other states may have been targeted, amid concerns about Russian hacking attempts.

site_title: In Asia, Obama faces trade pact test amid US opposition
summary: US President Barack Obama is set to visit Asia to reassure leaders of the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) despite opposition from his successors and congressional leaders. The trade pact, which aims to boost labor and environmental standards, faces uncertainty after Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell said it would not be voted on this year. Obama's efforts to secure approval for the deal come as estimates suggest little meaningful growth for the US economy, with some critics labeling the projections as overly optimistic.

site_title: Central bankers get tired of gold as falling exports reduce cash
summary: Central banks, which hold about 32,900 metric tons of gold, reduced their purchases by 40% in the first half of 2016, the lowest since 2011. This decline is attributed to falling exports reducing cash inflows for emerging-market nations, which previously fueled gold buying. Despite this, central banks are expected to continue accumulating gold due to low yields on alternative assets and the need to diversify currency reserves.

site_title: Six US senators urge Obama to prioritise cyber crime at G20 summit
summary: Six US senators have urged President Barack Obama to prioritize cyber crime at the upcoming G20 summit in China, following the $81 million heist from Bangladesh's central bank. The senators, led by Gary Peters, call for a coordinated strategy to combat cyber-crime at critical financial institutions and express concern over the lack of robust defenses and collaborative systems to prevent and mitigate cyber attacks. The White House has confirmed that cyber security will be on the agenda at the summit, with a focus on enhancing confidence and trust in the digital economy.

site_title: Boeing keeps jetliner prices steady amid slowing sales
summary: Boeing has held jetliner prices steady for the coming year, marking the first time since 2009. The company will continue to quote July 2015 base prices, as airlines typically negotiate discounts. Boeing has booked 335 new orders for planes through August 23, down from 418 in the first seven months of 2015. This decision comes as the company faces a slowdown in sales.

site_title: Mitsubishi Motors overstated fuel economy on 8 more models: Nikkei
summary: Mitsubishi Motors Corp admitted to overstating fuel economy on eight additional vehicle models, in addition to four earlier admitted models. The company is likely to withdraw the affected vehicles from the market and revise its catalogues, a process expected to take 2-3 weeks. Compensation to customers may be considered, and shares in the automaker slipped 0.8% in early trade. The scandal, part of a broader investigation, has led to a slump in Mitsubishi's market value and a significant loss of operating profit. An internal investigation found poor communication, governance issues, and pressure on engineers.

site_title: UK foreign investment sets record, boosted by emerging markets
summary: The UK set a record for foreign investment in the 2015-16 financial year, with 2,213 projects funded, creating or protecting 116,000 jobs. Emerging markets, particularly Latin America and East Europe, drove the surge. The US was the largest source of outside financing, followed by China and India. Despite uncertainty over Brexit, foreign investors continued to flock to the UK, cementing its position as Europe's most popular destination for foreign investment.

images.alt_text: A record number of overseas investments were made in the UK in the 2015-16 financial year, buoyed by a surge from emerging markets, making the country Europe's most popular for external financiers.

site_title: Japan jobless rate falls to 3% in July
summary: Japan's seasonally adjusted unemployment rate fell to 3.0% in July, according to the Ministry of Internal Affairs and Communications. This marks the lowest rate in over a decade. The median estimate from economists was for a rate of 3.1%, but it remained unchanged from June. The jobs-applicants ratio also remained steady at 1.37, unchanged from June.

site_title: Parisian luggage maker for the truly rich seduces luxury giants
summary: A 200-year-old Parisian luxury luggage maker, Goyard, is being courted by luxury giants Kering and LVMH, according to industry insiders. The company, known for its classic trunks and high-end leather goods, has maintained its exclusivity despite expanding its sales to the wealthy. Founded in 1792, Goyard has counted aristocrats and celebrities among its clients, and its brand is prized for its timeless elegance and craftsmanship. The company's current owner, Jean-Michel Signoles, is considering selling the business, which has seen significant revenue growth under his leadership.

site_title: Mylan fails to stop firestorm over EpiPen price increases
summary: Mylan, the manufacturer of the EpiPen allergy shot, has failed to alleviate criticism over the significant price increase of its US$600 brand-name version. The company's response to the controversy, including introducing a generic version for US$300, has been met with skepticism from politicians and analysts. The House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform has demanded documents explaining the price hike, and several senators are calling for a Federal Trade Commission probe. Despite Mylan's efforts, the debate over EpiPen's skyrocketing price is likely to continue, with critics arguing that the company's control of the market will not alleviate the issue.

site_title: Syrian rebels make gains in northern Hama province, capture strategic town
summary: Syrian rebels have captured the strategic town of Halfaya in northern Hama province, threatening government-loyalist towns populated by minority Christians and Alawites. The hardline jihadist Jund al-Aqsa, alongside Free Syrian Army brigades, launched a battle that overran several army and pro-government checkpoints. The rebels' rapid collapse in government defenses has brought them closer to the army stronghold of Soran, the army's northern gateway to the city of Hama. The offensive follows weeks of heavy Russian and Syrian army bombing of rebel-controlled areas, with the rebels threatening to hit a power plant if civilians are bombed.

site_title: Apple said to prepare iPad upgrades and refreshed Mac lineup
summary: Apple is developing new features for the iPad and refreshed Mac lineup, including wider operating-system support for the Apple Pencil stylus, faster display technology, and a thinner MacBook Pro laptop with a digital function key display. The company hopes to ship the updated iPad software next year and the Macs as soon as late 2016. The new Macs will include new versions of the iMac desktop, MacBook Air laptop, and 5K standalone monitor, with the goal of keeping sales numbers stable despite falling sales of rival personal computers.

site_title: Oil falls on bullish Fed talk and rising US dollar
summary: Oil prices fell on Monday after US Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen's relatively bullish talk on a near-term interest rate hike, which boosted the US dollar. Hopes of an agreement to curb production in Algeria meeting next month also faded.

site_title: Apple to show off new offerings on Sept 7
summary: Apple is set to unveil new iPhone models on September 7 in San Francisco. The event is expected to feature improved software, cameras, and processing speed, as well as the removal of headphone jacks. Apple may also showcase updates to its smartwatch and laptop computers. The company has maintained a yearly rhythm of introducing updated iPhone models to coincide with the holiday shopping season.

site_title: Oil discoveries at a 70-year low signal a supply shortfall ahead
summary: Oil discoveries have reached a 70-year low, sparking concerns about a potential supply shortfall ahead. In 2015, only 2.7 billion barrels of new supply were discovered, the smallest amount since 1947. This year, drillers have found just 736 million barrels of conventional crude, with global demand projected to grow from 94.8 million barrels per day to 105.3 million barrels in 2026. Industry spending on exploration has decreased to $40 billion, and new discoveries are at rock bottom, with the industry expected to replace only one in 20 barrels consumed this year.

site_title: Apple sued over iPhone 6 touch-screen freezes
summary: A lawsuit was filed in Silicon Valley federal court against Apple, alleging the company knowingly sold iPhone 6 models with touchscreens that froze. The plaintiffs claim Apple concealed a design defect, refused to repair iPhones for free, and demanded unspecified cash damages and attorneys fees. The lawsuit seeks to grant class-action status to represent anyone in the US who purchased an iPhone 6 or 6 Plus with the defective touchscreen. Apple did not respond to the allegations.

site_title: Brazil's Rousseff urges vote against 'coup' in Senate trial
summary: Brazil's suspended President Dilma Rousseff testified at her impeachment trial, calling voting against her a "coup d'etat" and warning Latin America's largest country was losing its democracy. Rousseff, accused of mismanaging state loans, recalled her torture under Brazil's military dictatorship and battling cancer. With a two-thirds majority expected, pro-impeachment senators are likely to remove her from office, paving the way for her former vice-president Michel Temer to become president until elections in 2018.

site_title: Mosquitoes can spread Zika to their eggs: study
summary: Researchers at the University of Texas Medical Branch found that female mosquitoes can transmit the Zika virus to their eggs and offspring, suggesting that killing adult mosquitoes alone may not be enough to eliminate the virus. One in 290 infected mosquitoes transmitted the virus to their eggs, which can persist even when conditions are poor. This "vertical transmission" may help the virus survive in tropical urban communities. The study's findings raise concerns about the effectiveness of mosquito spraying in controlling Zika transmission.

images.alt_text: Female mosquitoes can transmit the Zika virus to their eggs and offspring, suggesting that efforts to kill adult mosquitoes will fall short, researchers said Monday.

site_title: Kim has two officials killed by anti-aircraft gun, JoongAng says
summary: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un ordered the execution of two senior officials, Ri Yong Jin, a possible education minister, and Hwang Min, former Agriculture Minister, using an anti-aircraft gun in early August. Ri Yong Jin was executed for dozing off during a meeting with Kim, while Hwang Min was purged over a project seen as a challenge to Kim's leadership. The executions were carried out on Kim's orders, according to South Korea's JoongAng Ilbo newspaper.

site_title: Support for Australian PM hits all-time low
summary: Australia's Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull has seen his lowest level of public support, with 34% satisfaction rate according to a poll. This marks a significant drop from his record-high approval ratings after securing the leadership in 2014. The government's struggles to pass legislation, including corporate tax cuts and workplace reforms, have contributed to the decline in support. The recent early election, which resulted in a one-vote majority for the ruling Liberal-National coalition, has further complicated the government's legislative agenda.

images.alt_text: Support for Australia's Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull has fallen to an all-time low, according to a poll by The Australian newspaper on Tuesday.

site_title: Swiss fighter jet missing, believed crashed: ministry
summary: A Swiss army fighter jet, an F/A-18 C, went missing over the Alps on Monday during a training exercise and is believed to have crashed. A large-scale search and rescue operation has been launched, with two ground crews continuing the search in difficult-to-access terrain. The suspected crash site is near the Susten Pass. This is the latest in a string of crashes to befall the Swiss airforce, including a fatal accident in 2013 and previous incidents in 1998 and 2016.

site_title: Chinese-owned Zhongwang USA enters US aluminium market with Aleris buy
summary: Chinese-owned Zhongwang USA has agreed to buy US aluminium company Aleris Corp in a $2.33 billion deal, marking the largest entry by a Chinese company into the US aluminium industry since trade tensions began. The acquisition is aimed at capitalizing on the growing demand for automotive aluminium, with Aleris set to produce 200,000 tonnes per year for US auto manufacturers. The deal comes amid trade tensions between the US and China, with Zhongwang facing allegations of evading US import duties on aluminium extrusions.

images.alt_text: Zhongwang USA, backed by Chinese aluminum magnate Liu Zhongtian, said on Monday it would buy US aluminum company Aleris Corp in a bet by the billionaire that the nascent US automotive aluminum sector will be the industry's next big growth market.

site_title: Apple's Irish tax bill might jump by billions on EU decision
summary: The European Union is set to announce a decision on Apple's Irish tax bill, potentially leading to a billions of euros in tax payments. The EU alleges Ireland provided Apple with a sweetheart deal in exchange for creating jobs, violating EU competition laws. If the US loses the case, Apple may face a $19 billion bill, although estimates range from 100 million euros to billions. The ruling could heighten tensions between Europe and the US over taxation policies, with the US pushing for tax fairness and EU regulators denying targeting US companies.

site_title: Japan household spending falls less than expected, jobless rate hits 21-year low
summary: Japan's household spending fell 0.5% in July, less than expected, and the jobless rate hit a 21-year low. The data offers some hope for policymakers as the economy struggles to grow. Despite this, economists expect the Bank of Japan to ease its stimulus next month due to inflation sliding further away from its 2% target. The economy's sluggish growth and low inflation rates have led to concerns about the bank's ability to stimulate the economy.

images.alt_text: Japanese household spending fell less than expected in July and the jobless rate hit a two-decade low, offering some hope for policy makers battling to pull the world's third-largest economy out of stagnation.

site_title: Gazprom net profit down due to higher costs
summary: Russian gas giant Gazprom reported a 17% decline in net profits in the second quarter due to higher operating costs, despite exceeding forecast revenue. The company's net profit fell to 245 billion rubles (S$5.2 billion) from the previous quarter, primarily due to increased running costs and currency exchange rate fluctuations. Exports to Europe rose 19% despite EU efforts to diversify gas supplies, while domestic sales and sales to Ukraine declined.

images.alt_text: Russian gas giant Gazprom on Monday said net profits in the second quarter plunged 17 per cent due to higher operating costs which offset a hike in revenues.

site_title: Mondelez drops merger plans with Hershey
summary: Mondelez International dropped plans to merge with The Hershey Company, a US$23 billion takeover offer rejected by Hershey in June. The merged company would have become the world's largest candy purveyor, overtaking Mars. Mondelez cited "no actionable path forward" and was "disappointed" by the decision. Hershey shares plummeted 11.4% in after-hours trade, while Mondelez shares rose 3.9% in late trading.

site_title: Australia's richest woman considers bid for country's largest ranch
summary: Australia's richest woman Gina Rinehart is partnering with Chinese developer Shanghai CRED to bid for S. Kidman & Co, the country's largest private land holding. This may prompt the Australian government to approve a sale, following their previous rejection of a Chinese-led consortium's bid. Rinehart's involvement could secure government approval due to her close ties with key politicians, including National Party leader Barnaby Joyce. The new bid is expected to offer around A$300 million, a substantial discount to the earlier rejected bid.

site_title: John Lennon's killer denied parole for 9th time
summary: Mark David Chapman, the 61-year-old man who killed John Lennon in 1980, has been denied parole for the 9th time, maintaining his 20-year-to-life sentence. Chapman, an obsessed fan, was convicted of 2nd-degree murder and has petitioned for parole every two years since 2000. The New York Board of Parole rejected his request, citing the premeditated nature of the crime and the seriousness of the offense, deeming his release incompatible with public welfare. Chapman's next parole hearing is scheduled for August 2018.

site_title: VW diesel owners quick to pick buyback option over emissions fix
summary: Volkswagen AG owners are overwhelmingly choosing the cash buyback option over an emissions fix for their diesel-cheating cars. Almost half of the 475,000 US drivers have registered for the settlement program, with 210,000 opting for the buyback and 235 for the free fix. The program offers a cash buyback of $5,100 or a free repair, with Volkswagen aiming to fulfill its obligation to remove 85% of polluting vehicles from the road. The settlement has seen a low opt-out rate, with less than 0.05% of class members rejecting the deal.

site_title: Lum Chang's full-year earnings flat at S$29.52m
summary: Lum Chang Holdings reported flat full-year earnings of S$29.52 million, despite a 36% surge in revenue to S$426.1 million. The decline was due to fair value losses on investment properties and lack of divestment gains. Revenue from two new construction projects and lower revenue from completed projects contributed to the increase. The company secured a S$60.8 million contract and has proposed a final dividend of 1.25 cents per share, unchanged from the previous year.

site_title: Currency traders can't lose as trusted strategies reap big gains
summary: Three major foreign-exchange trading strategies are producing positive returns for the first time in a decade, with the carry trade on pace for its biggest annual gain since 2012, according to Deutsche Bank AG index data. The yen, undervalued by over 14% at the start of the year, has surged 18% in 2016, while the Australian and New Zealand dollars have also rallied. These gains are attributed to central-bank monetary stimulus and currencies linked to historically low interest rates, making the correct foreign-exchange strategy crucial for investors.

site_title: Deals freeze up in one of Asia's most lucrative office markets
summary: Dealmaking in Australia's office market has plummeted by 57% to US$7.5 billion in the six months ended June 30, the largest drop since the 2008 global financial crisis. This decline is the steepest among Asia's top five investment markets. The freeze in transactions is attributed to owners holding onto high-yielding assets, which suggests a cautious approach to selling properties in the market.

site_title: Li Ka-shing set to win approval for 3 Italia's buyout of a competitor
summary: Hong Kong billionaire Li Ka-shing is set to win approval for 3 Italia's buyout of a competitor, creating the country's biggest telecom operator. The deal is significant for Li, who faces setbacks from failed deals in the UK and Australia. The acquisition is expected to boost CK Hutchison's earnings by up to 8% and lift its Ebitda margin from 18% to 41%, a significant improvement over its UK business. Despite recent setbacks, Li's company has seen a surge in optimism, with 13 out of 15 analysts rating the stock a "buy".

site_title: The best in the business
summary: The Business Excellence Awards honored accounting firms and individuals for their dedication to quality assurance, innovation, and client service. Precursor Assurance PAC received a "Highly Commended"accolade for Best Practice Award, while CA Trust PAC won the Outstanding Growth Award. The Individual Excellence Awards recognized outstanding practitioners and young accountants in practice and business. The awards aim to promote excellence in the accounting profession and encourage young accountants to play a greater role in shaping the industry's future.

site_title: SGX's advisory body gives nod for dual-class shares
summary: The Listings Advisory Committee of the Singapore Exchange (SGX) has approved the use of dual-class shares among listed issuers, subject to certain safeguards. The committee stated that dual-class shares will only be permitted if listing applicants have a compelling reason to adopt such a structure. This decision allows SGX to permit dual-class shares, a feature often associated with technology companies, but with conditions to ensure fairness and transparency in the market.

site_title: 'Willy Wonka' star Gene Wilder dead at 83
summary: Gene Wilder, the actor known for his iconic roles in "Willy Wonka & the Chocolate Factory" and "Blazing Saddles," died on August 29, 2016, at the age of 83 due to complications from Alzheimer's disease. Wilder's nephew, Jordan Walker-Pearlman, announced his passing, saying he continued to enjoy art and time with loved ones despite his illness. Wilder was acclaimed for his comedic talents and collaborations with director Mel Brooks, and his legacy is remembered as a universal artist and beloved figure in the entertainment industry.

site_title: 55% jump in China visitors to Singapore in first half of 2016
summary: Singapore saw a 12.5% year-on-year growth in visitor arrivals in the first half of 2016, with 8.17 million visitors, driven by a 55% jump in Chinese visitors to 1.47 million. However, growth slowed in June, and analysts attribute this to factors such as the absence of the Southeast Asian Games and the weakening RMB against the Singapore dollar. The hospitality sector saw total room revenue grow 3% to S$1.58 billion, but room rates slid 3% and revenue per available room (RevPar) dipped 2.5%.

site_title: Tech sector bets on eyes as virtual-reality interface
summary: US startup Eyefluence has developed technology that enables users to control virtual reality headsets using their eyes, revolutionizing the way people interact with virtual worlds. The system, which can track users' gaze and allow them to select, zoom, and pan, has sparked interest from major headset manufacturers and industry leaders. Eyefluence's technology has the potential to alleviate nausea experienced by VR users and enhance security with iris scans. Several companies, including Motorola Solutions and Fove, are testing the technology, with some predicting it could popularize VR like the mouse did with personal computers.

site_title: Food for thought: behind that stamp of quality
summary: AsureQuality's accreditation for food and contaminant testing laboratories has helped its customers access new markets, gain competitive advantages, and protect their brands and reputations. In the food industry, where quality and standards are crucial, external accreditation is necessary to ensure compliance. AsureQuality, a New Zealand government-owned business, provides food safety and biosecurity services worldwide, recognizing the importance of accreditation in the industry. This accreditation has enabled companies to penetrate chosen markets, gain a competitive edge, and protect their reputations.

site_title: Safe-haven demand for gold to outweigh effects of US dollar rise, say analysts
summary: The price of gold continues to decline, reaching a low of US$1,315.51 an ounce on Monday. Despite this, analysts believe the yellow metal will be supported by safe-haven demand until the end of the year due to uncertainty surrounding major economies. The US dollar's rise is also seen as having a limited impact on gold prices, with analysts expecting gold to remain stable.

site_title: Affordability and flexibility is Eleven's mantra
summary: Eleven Sports Network, a Singapore-based online streaming sports content provider, has launched its service offering affordable and flexible options for fans to watch English Premier League (EPL) matches, Swimming World Cup, and other sports events. Eleven's business model, priced at S$24.90 a month for a 3-month subscription, allows subscribers to watch three "live" EPL matches and three delayed games per round. The company aims to cater to young fans seeking value-for-money and flexibility, setting itself apart from Singtel's S$64.90 a month subscription for all EPL matches.

images.alt_text: Speaking to The Business Times in a recent interview, Singapore-based Mr Biswas said that Eleven's business model stands out because it offers flexibility, choice and value-for-money.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer has been oversubscribed 9.8 times. Meanwhile, Singapore stocks have seen a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data. Creative Technology has warned of possible below-target H2 revenue and similar operating losses. Indonesia has detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case. London's Heathrow is considering higher fees for a £10 billion upgrade. MAS and PBOC are set to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance.

site_title: Small completed condos worst price performer in July from year ago
summary: Singapore's small completed private apartments and condos saw a 4.4% year-on-year price contraction in July, according to NUS flash estimates. This decline is the worst among the four SRPI categories tracked by the National University of Singapore. Analysts attribute the drop to "specuvestors" who bought small units before the introduction of the total debt servicing ratio (TDSR) framework, leading to overstretching. New project sales in the small units sub-market accounted for 78% of total sales, drawing buyers away from the resale market.

images.alt_text: "Anecdotally, many property agents were among those who picked up small apartments during the heyday of the market," says Mr Cheong of Savills

site_title: Claims against Swiber rise to US$197m
summary: Swiber Holdings has received US$197 million in claims as of August 25, up from US$135.9 million a week prior, ahead of its October 6 hearing for judicial management. The claims are primarily from trade creditors, including O&M contractors in Singapore and India, and have led to a significant increase in Swiber's total trade debts to US$264 million. Several companies, including ASL Marine and Pacific Radiance, have also acknowledged exposure to the Swiber fallout, with some providing for doubtful receivables. The prospects for unsecured trade creditors recovering their debts appear slim, but they may be able to claim tax relief for uncollectible receivables.

site_title: When four may not be enough
summary: S i2i Ltd, a Singapore-listed firm, has downsized its board to four members, raising questions about its effectiveness in raising shareholder value. The new board consists of two independent directors and two non-independent non-executive directors, including chairman Bhupendra Kumar Modi, the firm's largest owner. The move comes as the company embarks on a new business to distribute and sell electrical vehicles in Singapore, following a tie-up with a China-based EV maker. However, the company's incomplete disclosure of the deal drew queries from the Singapore Exchange and raised concerns about its governance.

site_title: South Korea home-building boom may lead to housing glut
summary: South Korea's housing market is experiencing a boom, with 5,301 unsold new residential units in the city of Yongin, a record high in the country. The rapid construction pace, fueled by low interest rates, has led to a housing glut, threatening consumer spending and prompting policymakers to intervene. Household debt, already the highest among emerging markets, is a major concern, and resale prices in areas like Yongin may suffer as a result. The government has announced measures to rein in household credit and curb new housing supply to prevent a damaging crash.

site_title: US dollar rises following uptick in consumer spending
summary: The US dollar rose against major currencies, including the euro, yen, and pound, following a bullish outlook from US Fed Chief Janet Yellen and positive consumer spending data. US consumer spending rose 0.3% in July, while core inflation rose 0.1%. Yellen's remarks on monetary policy increased the likelihood of an interest rate hike this year, boosting demand for the US dollar. The euro fell to $1.1187, while the yen rose to 101.88, and the pound dropped to $1.3105.

images.alt_text: The US dollar rose against the euro, the yen and the pound on Monday as US Commerce Department data showed consumer spending had risen in July.

site_title: Opec's output freeze: What has changed since Doha?
summary: OPEC is considering a production freeze at its upcoming meeting in Algiers, with Saudi Arabia reportedly willing to participate. The move aims to stabilize oil prices, but past attempts have been unsuccessful. The Saudi energy minister's indication of willingness to freeze production has sparked hopes, but the region's history of false promises and oil price volatility remains a concern. A successful freeze would prevent further price erosion, but the region's producers must navigate the delicate balance of maintaining leverage over oil prices.

site_title: BMW planning coupe variant for its flagship 7-Series: source
summary: BMW is planning to introduce a coupe variant of its flagship 7-Series, a luxury sedan, in 2019. The sporty two-door version is part of the company's efforts to boost sales of its highest-end car, which has been underperforming since its introduction last year. Despite initial concerns, the 7-Series remains a vital part of BMW's bottom line, and the coupe is expected to help revitalize sales.

site_title: US: Wall St gains as data points to budding economy
summary: The US stock market rose on Monday, driven by a fourth consecutive month of consumer spending growth, which points to a potential pick-up in US economic growth. Financial and commodity-sector stocks led the S&P 500 higher, with utilities also gaining, despite a sell-off on Friday. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 0.58% to 18,502.99, while the S&P 500 gained 0.52% to 2,180.38. US Federal Reserve officials' comments suggested a possible rate hike in September, but with less hawkish tone than initially thought.

site_title: GIC aiming for 7.73% stake in Vietcombank
summary: GIC, Singapore's sovereign wealth fund, is investing 7.73% in Vietcombank, Vietnam's largest bank, with a stake of 305.8 million shares. The deal, valued at less than $400 million, aims to boost portfolio returns and provide technical assistance. The investment will increase Vietcombank's charter capital and help the bank prepare for the implementation of Basel II. The transaction is expected to be completed by the fourth quarter of 2016, subject to regulatory approvals.

site_title: Peter Lim lodges police report over get-rich-quick schemes
summary: Singapore tycoon Peter Lim lodged a police report against online get-rich-quick schemes using his name to lure people into investment programs. Lim denies any involvement and warns the public to be cautious, advising them to protect themselves from potential scams. The schemes, which promise easy wealth creation, are false and misleading, with Lim's name being used to mislead unsuspecting individuals, according to his firm.

site_title: Opening the door to success
summary: SIAC Pte Ltd, a Singapore-based acoustic solution provider, continues to innovate and adapt to market conditions. The company, which has diversified into the construction industry, offers a one-stop solution for residential, commercial, and industrial applications. With a focus on excellent customer service, quality products, and employee growth, SIAC has established itself as a reputable company in the acoustics industry. The company's managing director, Mike Chin, emphasizes the importance of innovation, adaptability, and hard work in propelling the business forward, with plans to expand into new markets, including the UK.

site_title: Zika under-reported in South-east Asia, say regional specialists
summary: Regional specialists warn that the Zika virus spread in South-east Asia, particularly in Indonesia, Thailand, and Vietnam, is likely under-reported due to inadequate screening and under-diagnosis. Despite the World Health Organization's classification of these countries as having possible endemic transmission, many cases go unreported, with some countries testing fewer than 1,000 people in a year. The lack of a vaccine or treatment, combined with 80% of infected individuals having no symptoms, complicates efforts to contain the outbreak.

site_title: Hawk sighting sends investors scampering
summary: Singapore stocks fell 1% on Monday, with the Straits Times Index ending at 2,829.43, amid light trading dominated by blue chips. The decline was sparked by hawkish remarks from US Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen on Friday, which raised expectations of a US rate hike before the end of the year. Almost all key index stocks closed lower, with Singapore Telecommunications falling 2.37%, and the FTSE ST Oil & Gas benchmark dropping 1.8%. The decline was seen as an adjustment of expectations rather than an outright dump, with investors awaiting Friday's US non-farm payrolls numbers.

site_title: End of the road for tax discs from February
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) in Singapore announced that road tax discs will be phased out from February 15, 2017, marking the transition to a paperless system.

site_title: Spain a eurozone dynamo despite political deadlock
summary: Spanish Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy is facing a confidence vote amid a prolonged political deadlock, with the country's economy showing signs of resilience. Despite nearly eight months of gridlock, Spain's GDP grew 3.2% in the last year, with unemployment falling to 20%, its lowest level in six years. The government's ability to maintain economic stability is partly due to the European Central Bank's stimulus policies. A confidence vote could lead to a third general election in December, but the economy appears to be weathering the uncertainty, with the government forecasting a further decline in unemployment to 16.6% in 2017.

site_title: Refining empire helps Sinopec outshine Chinese energy rivals
summary: Sinopec, China's largest refiner, reported a 19.9 billion yuan (S$4 billion) profit for the first half of 2016, outshining its domestic state-run rivals. The company's fuel-making business helped it weather the worst crude crash in a generation, with its refining exposure positioning it for benefits from low crude prices. In contrast, PetroChina and CNOOC Ltd reported significant losses, with PetroChina's net income dropping 98% and CNOOC's loss reaching 7.74 billion yuan. Sinopec's management is credited with maximizing refining incomes while containing crude losses, with the company planning to raise refining throughput in the second half of the year.

site_title: Invoicing and payments solution launched for SMEs
summary: A new invoicing and payments solution, ABSS Click to Pay, has been launched in Singapore to help small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) transition to digital payment methods. The solution, a collaboration between ABSS, Mint Payments, and NETS, enables SMEs to manage invoices and payments online, reducing the need for cash and cheques. The move aims to improve cashflow management and reduce costs, with the potential to save SMEs up to S$2 billion per year.

site_title: BOC Aviation's H1 profit up 23.8% at US$212m
summary: BOC Aviation's first-half profit soared 23.8% to a record US$212 million, driven by 8.2% revenue growth and gains from aircraft sales. Lease rental income rose 5.7% and interest income increased 62.5%. The company sold 22 aircraft, with all planes over 10 years old disposed of by June 30. BOC Aviation plans to use its US$550 million IPO proceeds to purchase and leaseback aircraft and buy planes from manufacturers.

site_title: US$ hits three-week high against yen
summary: The US dollar rose to a three-week high against the yen, reaching 102.39 yen, due to comments from senior Federal Reserve officials that strengthened expectations of a US interest rate hike. Treasury yields rose, and rate futures indicated a 30% chance of a hike in September. Fed Chair Janet Yellen and Deputy Stanley Fischer's comments created a positive market reaction, with the dollar also rising against a basket of major currencies.

site_title: Yellen's comments on next US rate hike weigh on Asia bourses
summary: US Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen hinted at a possible interest rate hike in September, sparking a mixed reaction in Asian markets. The MSCI Asia Pacific Excluding Japan Index dropped 0.9% as Indonesian equities led losses, while Japan's Topix index rose 2% due to a weakening yen and the Bank of Japan's pledge to add stimulus if needed. Odds of a rate hike in September increased to 42% from 22% a week ago, with the Fed citing stronger economic growth and the impact of a rising US dollar.

site_title: Honouring a profession's brightest
summary: The Singapore Accountancy Awards 2016 honoured the best and brightest in the local accountancy sector. Organised by the Institute of Singapore Chartered Accountants, the awards recognised businesses and individuals for their innovation, growth, and excellence. Winners included PwC Singapore, Crowe Horwath First Trust, and Ardent, among others. The awards also recognised individuals such as Kon Yin Tong, Yeoh Oon Jin, and Chua Sock Koong for their contributions to the sector and profession. The awards aim to promote good practices and strengthen the branding of the profession and industry.

site_title: US computing firm Nutanix buys two startups amid IPO delay
summary: Nutanix, a US computing firm, acquired two startups, PernixData and Calm.io, to enhance its data and storage services despite a delayed initial public offering (IPO). The acquisitions will improve the speed of Nutanix's cloud computing platform and create new software products. The deal is part of Nutanix's effort to grow its business while remaining in the private market, amid a challenging IPO market. The acquisitions are expected to have no impact on Nutanix's plans for an IPO.

site_title: Consumer spending continues growth in July as incomes rise
summary: US consumer spending advanced 0.3% in July, supported by stronger income gains and low fuel costs, marking the fourth consecutive month of growth. Incomes rose 0.4%, the most in three months, and disposable income adjusted for inflation grew 0.4%. This robust spending is likely to boost expectations for the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates in September, as economists project a rebound in expansion this quarter. The growth supports ongoing job growth, wage growth, and higher asset values, with economists predicting continued consumer strength.

site_title: EU insists 'ball still rolling' on US free trade deal
summary: The European Commission insists that talks on a US free trade deal are on track, despite German claims that the negotiations have failed. Commission spokesman Margaritis Schinas stated that the EU is making steady progress and stands ready to close the deal by the end of the year. The EU has proposals for almost all chapters and a good sense of the outline of the future agreement. Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker has secured backing from all bloc leaders for the negotiations, and the EU will not compromise on social health, data protection, or cultural diversity standards.

site_title: Cockroach startup that's profitable from Day One
summary: Flare Dynamics, a Singapore-based aerospace precision engineering company, has achieved profitability from its inception in 2014. The company, founded by Lu Weiyao and Vincent Loh, specializes in building custom-built drones for law enforcement, defense, and logistics sectors. With a revenue-driven business model, Flare Dynamics charges customers based on the degree of customization and ownership of rights to customizations. The company reports a 98% increase in net profit to S$99,000 for FY2016, with revenue doubling to S$660,000. Flare Dynamics plans to mature its technology development and expand its business arm, with ambitions to take its drones to overseas markets.

images.alt_text: Mr Loh and Mr Lu with Flare Dynamics's Discrete-i Micro UAS, which was created for surveillance in a military and law enforcement context. The company's other flagship product is the Rapide-i UAV.

site_title: New govt policy may help China firms save 150b yuan a year
summary: China's government may allow companies to save up to 150 billion yuan (S$30.5 billion) a year by reducing their contributions to employees' social security and housing plans. This move aims to cut financing, labour, energy, and logistics costs, and lower the annual tax burden for firms. According to a researcher, businesses could save 100 billion yuan annually on social security policies and an additional 40 billion yuan on housing funds, as the government seeks to offset the impact of a prolonged economic slowdown.

site_title: China's three biggest airlines face 8.5b yuan currency losses
summary: China's three biggest airlines, Air China, China Southern, and China Eastern, are expected to report a combined 8.5 billion yuan (S$1.73 billion) in currency losses due to a weaker yuan, down from 16.2 billion yuan in 2015. The losses are narrowing, with the yuan stabilizing after a tough second quarter. The carriers have also benefited from cheaper fuel, with jet fuel prices dropping 30% in the first half. The losses are expected to ease in the second half of the year, with analysts predicting a more positive outcome.

site_title: GL Ltd's full-year profit surges 41%
summary: GL Ltd reported a 41% surge in full-year net profit to US$67.6 million, driven by lower administrative and income tax expenses and reduced finance and net financing costs. However, revenue fell 7% to US$393.9 million due to lower hotel revenue and oil and gas royalty income. The company flagged Brexit-related uncertainties, expecting volatility in the hotel industry in the UK and continued pressure on oil and gas royalty revenues. Despite this, shares closed unchanged at 79.5 Singapore cents.

site_title: Remote region in Nepal races to preserve culture
summary: Nepal's Upper Mustang, a remote high-altitude desert, is undergoing cultural transformation with the completion of a new road to China. The region, previously closed to foreign visitors until 1992, is now experiencing economic growth. The unpaved highway has brought unprecedented change to the area, which is known for its vast canyons and red mountains. Locals are adapting to the influx of new visitors and economic opportunities, while efforts are being made to preserve the region's unique culture and traditions. The region's unique history and legends are also being shared with the world.

site_title: Xi reshuffles key party posts ahead of congress
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping has reshuffled key party posts ahead of the once-every-five-years congress, appointing close allies to the Politburo and Politburo Standing Committee. Three new provincial-level party chiefs were named, including Chen Hao in Yunnan and Du Jiahao in Hunan, both of whom previously worked with Xi in Shanghai. A new party chief for Tibet, Wu Yingjie, was also appointed, following a similar pattern of promoting individuals with ties to Xi. The moves are seen as a bid to cement Xi's hold on power and place loyalists in key positions ahead of the congress next year.

site_title: Campaign in the UK against piped music gets heard
summary: A campaign in the UK is raising awareness about the annoyance of piped music in public places, with some individuals describing it as comparable to passive smoking. The movement, led by a long-time anti-piped music campaigner, aims to bring attention to the issue and potentially lead to changes in policy. Supporters argue that the constant music can be overwhelming and distressing for those with sensitivities, while opponents see it as a harmless and entertaining aspect of public spaces.

site_title: Modern art threatens relevancy of old masters
summary: A decline in sales and interest in old master artworks has led specialists to question their relevance at auction houses and museums. Over the last year, old master paintings and drawings have seen a 33% decrease in values, according to the Tefaf Art Market Report. As a result, auction houses are focusing on contemporary art, with some specialists leaving the old master field. Despite this, some museums are continuing to attract large audiences to exhibitions featuring old masters, and there is still a public appetite for viewing these artworks.

images.alt_text: Peter Paul Rubens' Lot and His Daughters fetched US$58 million at Christie's London's old masters sale, the second-most expensive work ever sold at auction by the artist.

site_title: Draghi's silence puts numbers in spotlight ahead of ECB meeting
summary: European Central Bank President Mario Draghi is avoiding making key policy decisions ahead of the ECB meeting on September 8, instead relying on economic data to guide his actions. Despite a slowdown in inflation, Draghi is keeping his options open, as economists predict a slight increase to 0.3% in August, still short of the ECB's goal of 2%. The UK's Brexit vote has sparked concerns about the region's economic growth, with Germany's business sentiment plummeting and France and Italy experiencing growth halts. The ECB is expected to reassess its growth forecast and inflation outlook in the coming weeks.

site_title: S$ falls 2% to S$1.36 from month high after Yellen's speech, but rates still weak
summary: The Singapore dollar (S$) fell 2% to S$1.361 on Monday, following US Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen's speech that raised expectations of an interest rate hike next month. Despite the S$ decline, local interest rates remain weak due to abundant liquidity. Experts expect the S$ to continue weakening in the coming months, with forecasts of a US$/S$ rate of 1.40 by the end of the year. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) may be less likely to ease interest rates if the Fed hikes rates next month, which could further support a weaker S$.

images.alt_text: The Singdollar (S$) fell to S$1.361 on Monday at 2.29 pm, almost 2 per cent lower from the month high of S$1.338 on Aug 16.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Singapore Exchange appoints new chairman Kwa Chong Seng, succeeding Chew Choon Seng, effective September 22, 2016. Olam International accepts Kwa's resignation and begins searching for a new chairman. AusGroup posts a net loss of A$99.5 million for Q4 due to higher costs and impairment charges. PEC reports a net profit of S$8.2 million for Q4, reversing a net loss in the previous year. Healthway Medical Corp agrees to issue new shares to raise S$3.75 million for working capital and expansion.

site_title: BOJ may switch from QE to project funding
summary: The Bank of Japan may shift its monetary policy from quantitative easing (QE) to project funding after its Sept meeting, according to analysts. This could involve buying bonds of local governments and public corporations that fund infrastructure projects, rather than directly financing fiscal spending. This move would target financing projects closer to the ground, such as trains, hospitals, and power plants, and could be seen as a stopgap measure until more comprehensive fiscal policies are implemented. The exact details and timing of such a move are yet to be confirmed.

site_title: New rules threaten to wipe out 90% of China's 200-plus e-car startups
summary: China's government is imposing stricter technology standards on electric vehicle (EV) startups, potentially limiting their number to 10 and pushing 90% of the country's 200+ EV startups towards extinction. The government aims to weed out weak manufacturers and ensure they meet quality-control measures, including 17 technologies that companies must possess to sell electric cars. Only two startups have obtained approval to build cars, and three others plan to apply for permits, amid concerns of overcapacity and high inventories in the industry.

site_title: Piyush Gupta, tech entrepreneurs top LinkedIn's Power Profiles list
summary: DBS chief Piyush Gupta, along with entrepreneurs Roger Egan III and Darius Cheung, have topped LinkedIn's 2016 Singapore Power Profiles list. This list showcases the most-viewed local professionals on the business social networking site, with categories including CEOs, tech, finance, marketing, and human resources. The list, now in its third edition, highlights the importance of social media in business influence, particularly in smaller economies like Singapore.

site_title: C&G to sell its principal businesses
summary: C&G Environmental Protection Holdings, a Singapore-based waste-to-energy firm, is proposing to sell its principal businesses to two Chinese companies. C&G agreed to dispose of its Thailand operating subsidiary to New Sky Energy for HK$600 million (S$105 million), and all its group companies except C&G Thailand to Ahead Auto for HK$600 million (S$105 million). The sale proceeds will be distributed as a special dividend, with the company aiming to become a cash company to explore potential new business acquisitions.

site_title: China's P2P lenders target students
summary: China's peer-to-peer lenders, which target students with no credit history, are expanding rapidly, with market leader Fenqile having 50,000 part-time marketers at over 3,000 universities. The lenders offer interest rates many times higher than traditional banks, and borrowers can use the funds for various expenses. Regulatory scrutiny is growing, but the market remains largely unregulated, creating a grey area between peer-to-peer lending and e-commerce.

site_title: Central bankers 'in a hole' over economic slowdown
summary: Central bankers gathered in Jackson Hole, Wyoming, acknowledging that unconventional monetary policy has reached its limits in helping the global economy recover from the 2008 financial crisis. The slowdown in global growth has been attributed to various factors, including deflation, demographic changes, and the reluctance of consumers and investors to spend. Japan's experience with Abenomics, a three-pronged approach of monetary easing, fiscal stimulus, and structural reforms, has shown limited success, with only 18% of increased liquidity benefiting the real economy. The debate at Jackson Hole highlighted the need for a more holistic approach, including infrastructure investment and addressing corporate cash hoarding, but no significant discussion on these issues took place.

site_title: There's more on Singapore investors' minds than what the Fed does next about rates
summary: Singapore investors are less concerned about the US Federal Reserve's potential interest rate hike, with domestic and regional issues taking precedence. Despite US Fed Chair Janet Yellen's remarks on Monday, analysts believe the market's reaction was muted, with the Straits Times Index (STI) shedding 1% and the Singapore dollar falling 0.7%. Analysts point to factors such as corporate growth, asset quality, and regional trade partners as more significant influences on investment decisions, with interest rates playing a relatively minor role.

site_title: German trade group slashes export forecast as Brexit impact looms
summary: Germany's BGA trade association has slashed its 2016 forecast for export growth to 1.8-2.0% due to the delayed impact of Brexit, which is expected to hit the economy massively in the near future. Global demand for German goods has slowed significantly, and exports to Britain, the US, and France have also fallen. The association had previously forecast a 4.5% growth in exports, but now believes stagnation is possible as early as 2017 if viewed pessimistically. Uncertainties over the US presidential election and other crises are also affecting Germany's trade prospects.

site_title: UK's new social housing rule won't meet aims: report
summary: The UK's new social housing rule, requiring tenants to pay higher rents, may not meet its aims, according to a report by estate agent Savills for the Local Government Association. The rule, set to take effect in April 2017, will force 70,000 households to pay higher rents, generating around £75 million in government revenues, but causing stress for families and administrative costs for councils. Critics say it will price many tenants out of London, exacerbating income inequality and altering the city's social fabric.

site_title: Private banks must disclose all 'conflicted remuneration'
summary: Private banks in Singapore are under scrutiny for not disclosing rebates of up to 1% they receive from bond issuers to sell unrated bonds to clients. At least half of $875 million worth of defaulted bonds since November were sold to private clients, including Swiber Holdings and PT Trikomsel Oki. The lack of transparency raises conflicts of interest issues, as banks earn a spread from bond sales and receive rebates on top. The practice is currently not explicitly required to be disclosed, despite a code of conduct that mandates disclosure on fees and conflicts of interest.

site_title: Zika outbreak: 4 more suspected cases at another Sims Drive clinic
summary: Four more suspected Zika cases were reported at a Sims Drive clinic in Singapore, with three women aged 32, 26, and 24, and a 44-year-old man. All are non-pregnant. The cases have been sent to the Communicable Disease Centre at Tan Tock Seng Hospital for further investigation. This brings the total number of suspected Zika cases in Singapore to an unknown number, although the article does not provide an update on the current outbreak.

site_title: US: Wall St rises as hawkish Fed boosts financial stocks
summary: US stocks rose on Monday as financial stocks gained after Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen stated the central bank was close to meeting its goals of maximum employment and stable prices. The S&P 500 financial index rose 0.6%, with Wells Fargo and JPMorgan increasing about 0.8%. The chances of a rate hike in September jumped to 30% from 21%, while the core personal consumption expenditure increased 1.6% in the 12 months through July.

site_title: Kwa Chong Seng appointed new SGX chairman, steps down from Olam's board
summary: Kwa Chong Seng has been appointed as the new chairman of the Singapore Exchange (SGX), succeeding Chew Choon Seng. Kwa Chong Seng will step down from Olam International's board to focus on his new role. He was previously chairman and managing director of ExxonMobil Asia Pacific Ltd and will oversee a seamless transition at Olam. His appointment is seen as a positive move for SGX, with outgoing chairman Chew praising Kwa's capabilities and experience.

site_title: Chinese, British energy officials discuss Hinkley Point nuclear project
summary: Senior Chinese and British energy officials met on August 25 in Beijing to discuss the Hinkley Point nuclear project, a £24 billion plan that was delayed by the British government. Chinese energy official Nur Bekri met with British Minister Lucy Neville-Rolfe to discuss the project and a clean energy partnership. The meeting aimed to address China's concerns about the delay, which had upset one of the project's backers. No details about the partnership or future discussions were disclosed.

images.alt_text: Senior Chinese and British energy officials have met to discuss the Hinkley Point nuclear project after the British government's surprise decision to delay the US$24 billion plan upset China, one of the backers of the scheme.

site_title: Asean's regional integration: Look beyond the South China Sea
summary: Singapore's small and medium enterprises (SMEs) should remain optimistic about the Asean Economic Community (AEC), despite regional tensions and challenges. Asean's unique approach, prioritizing consultation and consensus, has fostered close economic cooperation in a diverse region. The AEC aims to be fully implemented by 2025, with SMEs playing a crucial role in the regional integration agenda. With the virtual zero-tariff environment and growing investment in emerging Asean economies, Singapore SMEs can capitalize on the opportunities presented by the AEC, particularly in Vietnam and Indonesia.

images.alt_text: Despite criticisms, the Asean Way of doing things with consultation and consensus has been credited with fostering close economic and socio-political cooperation in a region that is far more diverse in culture, religion and ethnicity than any other part of the world.

site_title: Understanding the Snooze Economy
summary: The US economy has entered a "Snooze Economy" phase, characterized by a lackluster expansion that is neither exciting nor concerning. Despite conflicting economic indicators, including a 1% annual GDP growth rate and 255,000 payroll jobs added in July, the economy's performance is neither impressive nor alarming. This mixed picture may be helping Hillary Clinton by minimizing bad economic news, and a continued expansion could potentially erase most of the losses from the Great Recession. The Federal Reserve is struggling to determine the right course of action, weighing the need to stimulate the economy against the risk of a potential market correction.

site_title: S'pore, Vietnam governments and business leaders open doors
summary: Vietnamese President Tran Dai Quang's state visit to Singapore has strengthened bilateral economic ties between the two countries. The visit aims to boost trade, investment, and tourism, with plans to allow more commercial flights from Changi Airport to multiple cities in Vietnam. Singapore's Minister for Industry S Iswaran encouraged cooperation in various sectors, including manufacturing, consumer services, and urban solutions. The visit also marked a significant increase in bilateral trade, with Singapore being the sixth largest trading partner for Vietnam and Vietnam being Singapore's 11th largest trading partner, with a total of $38.1 billion in Singaporean investments in Vietnam.

site_title: Beyonce dominates MTV awards, taking home eight gongs
summary: Beyoncé dominated the 2016 MTV Video Music Awards, taking home eight awards, including Video of the Year for "Formation." Her performance, which included a 16-minute medley of songs from her album "Lemonade," featured a dance routine with a red fog and gunshots. The video was seen as a nod to the Black Lives Matter movement. Other notable performances included Alicia Keys' poem and Kanye West's speech about empowerment, which sparked controversy.

images.alt_text: Beyonce accepting the award for Best Female Video at New York's Madison Square Garden. The pop superstar also won the Video of the Year award, which she dedicated to the people of New Orleans.

site_title: Singapore steps up Zika prevention effort as confirmed cases rise to 56
summary: Singapore has confirmed 15 new cases of locally-transmitted Zika infections, bringing the total to 56, as authorities step up efforts to contain the outbreak. All cases were in or near the Aljunied area, where testing for the virus is now complete. The National Environment Agency has inspected thousands of premises in the area and six other parts of the island, urging pregnant women and those living and working in the risk areas to monitor their health and seek medical attention if they are unwell.

site_title: Rebound in Greek economy elusive despite Q2 growth
summary: Greece's economy grew 0.2% in Q2, its first quarter-on-quarter expansion since late 2015, but weak demand and investment mean a strong rebound remains elusive. The economy shrank 0.9% annually, more than expected. Economists predict a mild recession for the year, with some rating agencies expecting a decline of 0.7-1.0%. The EU projects a 2.7% rebound in 2017, but Greeks remain unimpressed by the modest growth, citing stagnant consumer spending and liquidity issues.

site_title: Oil falls towards US$49 on high output, strong dollar
summary: Oil prices fell towards US$49 a barrel on Monday due to high output from Middle East Opec members and a stronger US dollar. Iraq plans to continue increasing its oil exports, while Saudi Arabia maintains record output levels. The US dollar's rise makes dollar-priced commodities more expensive for holders of other currencies, putting downward pressure on oil prices. The market is increasingly unlikely to support a production freeze, with oversupply expected to persist into 2017.

site_title: Healthway Medical to issue up to 133.3m new shares at 3 Singapore cents apiece
summary: Healthway Medical Corporation plans to issue up to 133.3 million new shares at 3 Singapore cents apiece, raising approximately S$3.75 million. The funds will be used 45% for working capital and 55% for a Singapore expansion plan. The placement shares are priced at a 10.7% premium to the weighted average price of S$0.0271.

images.alt_text: CLINIC operator Healthway Medical Corporation on Monday said it will issue up to 133.3 million new ordinary shares at three Singapore cents each, to raise net proceeds of about S$3.75 million.

site_title: Trump's move to the centre unlikely to work
summary: US President Donald Trump's attempt to shift his image to the center is unlikely to succeed, according to analysts. Trump's efforts to appeal to white professionals, blacks, and Hispanics may not resonate with the target audience, as his past rhetoric and policies have alienated many in these groups. The 1950s Operation Wetback program, which forcibly deported Mexican immigrants, is often cited as an example of Trump's divisive approach to immigration. Trump's new strategy may be seen as too little, too late, and his ability to win over key demographics remains uncertain.

site_title: Less haze this year, Indonesia promises
summary: Indonesia is confident it will have fewer forest fires and haze this year due to favourable weather conditions and a quicker emergency response. The country has seen a 61% reduction in hotspots compared to last year, with six provinces declaring a state of emergency. However, green activists and neighboring nations have criticized Indonesia for failing to stop the region's annual haze, largely caused by forest-clearing for palm and pulp plantations. Despite this, Indonesia's Disaster Agency believes prevention measures need to be improved to address the issue.

site_title: Hedge funds bail on copper as Goldman sees 'supply storm'
summary: Copper prices are expected to fall below $2 per pound by the end of the year, according to Goldman Sachs, due to a "supply storm" predicted by the bank. Demand in China, the world's largest copper user, is slowing, with inventories reaching a 10-month high. Hedge funds and speculators have taken a net-short position, betting on price declines. Analysts predict increased production from major copper-producing companies, which could lead to a surplus of supply, further depressing prices.

site_title: Accreditation a de facto 'passport' in business
summary: Singapore-based testing firm, Singapore Electrical Testing Services (Sets), has found accreditation to be a key requirement for its business, enabling it to gain access to new markets. By attaining accreditation under the Singapore Accreditation Council's Singapore Laboratory Accreditation Scheme (SAC-SINGLAS), Sets has been able to test its products to international standards, reducing testing turnaround time and increasing competitiveness. The accreditation has also allowed Sets to bear the International Laboratory Accreditation Cooperation - SAC (ILAC-SAC) mark, recognized internationally, and has facilitated trade by reducing the need for repeated testing.

images.alt_text: Singapore Electrical Testing Services provides testing services for a wide range of wiring accessories and switchgear products for various countries in the world; (above L-R) executive engineer Victor Ang, associate technical officer Vivian Lee, laboratory manager Wong Chee Kian, Mr Soon, test officer Leong Chun Pong and test engineer Alvin Low.

Singapore Electrical Testing Services provides testing services for a wide range of wiring accessories and switchgear products for various countries in the world; (above) performing endurance testing.
