site_title: European Commission says "ball still rolling" on trade deal with US after German comments
summary: The European Commission stated that negotiations on a free trade deal with the US remain ongoing, despite Germany's economy minister saying the talks had "de facto failed." The Commission has a unanimous mandate from the EU's 28 members to finalize the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP) deal by the end of the year, but critics argue it would harm consumers and workers. The Commission is making progress in the negotiations, with proposals for almost all chapters on the table, but the UK's Brexit vote has cast doubt on the deal's completion.

site_title: BOC Aviation's six-month net profit rises nearly 24%
summary: BOC Aviation's six-month net profit rose 23.8% year-over-year to a record $212 million, driven by 8.2% revenue growth to $579 million. The aircraft leasing firm reported earnings per share of $0.31 and declared an interim dividend of $0.061 per share. BOC Aviation currently manages a portfolio of 265 aircraft, with an average age of 3.3 years and an average lease term of 7.2 years.

site_title: OKH swings to S$16.5m net loss after development, construction services revenues fall
summary: OKH Global Ltd reported a net loss of S$16.5 million in its full financial year, compared to a net profit of S$46.2 million in the preceding year. Revenue plummeted 70% to S$75.8 million, with property development revenue dropping 70.7% and construction services revenue falling 96.3%. This resulted in a loss per share of 2.62 Singapore cents and a net asset value per share of 17.3 Singapore cents.

site_title: Driverless taxi firm eyes operations in 10 cities by 2020
summary: US software firm nuTonomy plans to operate driverless taxis in 10 Asian and US cities by 2020, with the first test sites expected to be announced within the next month. The company recently launched the world's first public trial of driverless taxis in Singapore, with over a dozen people experiencing rides in a modified Mitsubishi i-MiEV electric vehicle. Trials are also planned in the Middle East, the US, and Britain, with data from the Singapore experiment feeding into the rollout of driverless taxis in 2018.

site_title: Lower-paying industries seeing fastest wage-growth in US
summary: US wage growth is outpacing higher-paying sectors, with lower-paying industries seeing the fastest growth. Bank of America Merrill Lynch economists attribute this to minimum wage increases and a tight labor market among less-educated workers, who are seeing an acute rise in pay levels. Unemployment rates among Americans with less than a high school diploma hit a record low, with wages rising at a much faster clip than higher-paying sectors. This trend is expected to continue, with labor supply dynamics differing greatly by educational attainment.

site_title: Ong joins MAS board
summary: Acting Minister for Education Ong Ye Kung has been appointed to the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) board, replacing Minister Lawrence Wong, who will step down on Monday. Ong's term will last from August 29, 2016, to May 31, 2019. The MAS board, chaired by Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam, includes other notable ministers such as Lim Hng Kiang and Heng Swee Keat. This appointment reflects the Singaporean government's efforts to diversify the MAS board and bring in fresh perspectives.

site_title: Sunseap wins tender to build first large-scale solar farm in Cambodia
summary: Sunseap Group, a Singapore-based solar company, has won a government tender to build the first large-scale solar farm in Cambodia. The 10-megawatt project, located 10 kilometers from Bavet, aims to meet the energy requirements of the area, which currently rely on 40 megawatts of imported power from Vietnam. The project is expected to be completed by mid-2017 and will be powered by a 20-year power purchase agreement with the state utility Electricite du Cambodge. This marks Sunseap's expansion into the international market and highlights the growing importance of renewable energy in the region.

site_title: PEC back in the black in Q4, with S$8.2m in net profit
summary: PEC Ltd reported a net profit of S$8.2 million in its fourth quarter, reversing a net loss of S$7.8 million in the previous year. Revenue declined 10% to S$142.7 million, but earnings per share and net asset value per share increased. The company also announced an ordinary dividend of two Singapore cents and a special dividend of one Singapore cent for FY2016. PEC shares closed 0.01 Singapore cent higher at 43.5 Singapore cents.

site_title: Latest Earnings
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Singapore's NTT DC Reit's public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss in the second half. London's Heathrow plans to increase airport fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case worth 285 trillion rupiah. OCBC appointed Tan Teck Long as its incoming CEO, replacing a DBS veteran. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and People's Bank of China (PBOC) will deepen cooperation on green and transition finance. Singapore stocks experienced a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: New suspected MH370 debris found in Mozambique
summary: A piece of aircraft wreckage, believed to be from the missing MH370 flight, has been found in Mozambique. The debris, described as triangular in shape and measuring 1.2m x 1.2m, was discovered by a South African hotelier and handed to local police. This is the latest in a series of debris finds, including five pieces discovered in Mozambique, South Africa, and Mauritius, which are almost certainly from the plane. The search for MH370, which vanished in 2014 with 239 people on board, continues.

site_title: Chinese cities shut down factories ahead of G20 summit
summary: Chinese authorities have ordered a shutdown of factories and a mandatory holiday for workers in Hangzhou ahead of the G20 summit on September 4-5. The city has also encouraged citizens to take a holiday out of town to reduce congestion. Certain factories within a 300-kilometre radius have been forced to shut down for 12 days to ensure clear skies for visiting dignitaries. This move aims to improve air quality in the city, a common practice in China to clean up polluted skies before high-profile events.

images.alt_text: Chinese authorities have shut down scores of factories and ordered a mandatory holiday for workers ahead of a summit of leaders of the Group of 20 economic powers, authorities said.

site_title: Micro Mechanics full-year profit slips 1.1% on forex translation
summary: Micro Mechanics Holdings, a semiconductor industry tool manufacturer, reported a 1.1% drop in full-year net profit to S$11.9 million due to a 1.8% decline in revenue. The decrease in revenue was attributed to the depreciation of the yuan and ringgit. The group's revenue slipped to S$51.3 million for the 12 months ended June 30, 2016.

site_title: GL's full-year net profit up 41% to US$67.6 million
summary: GL Ltd's full-year net profit rose 41% to US$67.6 million, driven by lower administrative and income tax expenses, finance and net financing costs. Revenue declined 6.9% to US$393.9 million. The company's results were announced in a Singapore Exchange filing on August 29, 2016.

site_title: Thai Q3 GDP growth seen close to Q2: finance minister
summary: Thailand's finance minister, Apisak Tantivorawong, expects the country's Q3 GDP growth to be close to the 3.5% annual growth rate reported for the previous quarter, marking the highest growth in 13 quarters. This follows years of subdued growth, with exports and domestic demand remaining weak. Government spending and tourism have boosted the economy this year.

site_title: S$ falls nearly 2% against US$ from August high after Yellen's speech
summary: The Singapore dollar (SGD) fell nearly 2% against the US dollar to S$1.361, its lowest level since July 25, after US Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen hinted at a potential interest rate hike next month. This move was accompanied by a decline in other Asian currencies. Despite this, local interest rates remain weak due to abundant liquidity. Analysts from DBS Bank and ABN AMRO predict the SGD will continue to weaken in the coming months, with forecasts of a USD/SGD rate of S$1.40 by the end of the year.

images.alt_text: THE Singapore dollar fell to S$1.361 against the US dollar on Monday at 2.29pm, almost 2 per cent lower from the August high of S$1.338 following last Friday's highly anticipated speech from US Federal Reserve chairwoman Janet Yellen.

site_title: Prada shares surge as chairman forecasts improvement
summary: Prada's shares surged 15% after Chairman Carlo Mazzi forecasted the company's return to growth in sales and earnings in 2017, driven by cost-cutting and online expansion in Asia. The company reported a 25% drop in first-half EBITDA to 330 million euros. Revenue fell 15% to 1.55 billion euros due to weak demand in China and a drop in European tourism. Despite this, Prada aims to double e-commerce sales in the next three years, with analysts attributing the company's struggles to its slow e-commerce investment and high-priced handbags.

site_title: Singapore stocks close lower after Yellen speech; STI drops 1%
summary: Singapore stocks fell on Monday after US Federal Reserve chairwoman Janet Yellen's remarks raised expectations of interest rate hikes, leading to a 1% drop in the Straits Times Index to 2,829.43. Key index stocks, including Singapore Telecommunications, United Overseas Bank, and DBS Group, also declined. The market saw low trading volume, with 719.2 million shares changing hands for S$733.8 million. Losers outnumbered gainers 248 to 141, resulting in a 28.22-point drop.

site_title: Visitor arrivals to Singapore up 14%, tourism receipts rise 2% in Q1
summary: Visitor arrivals to Singapore increased by 14% to 4.1 million in Q1, while tourism receipts rose 2% to S$5.4 billion. China was the top visitor-generating market, followed by Indonesia and Malaysia. Despite a 2% decline in revenue per available room, hotel room revenue grew 4.6% and average occupancy rate increased. Receipts from shopping and food & beverage grew, while those from sightseeing and entertainment declined.

site_title: AusGroup sinks into the red for Q4 with A$99.5m loss
summary: AusGroup, an Australian oil and gas engineering services provider, reported a net loss of A$99.5 million for the fourth quarter ended June 30, compared to a net profit of A$266,000 in the same period last year. Revenue rose 14.1% to A$103.4 million, but higher cost of sales and impairment charges pushed the company into the red. The firm's operations in Singapore, including a fabrication business, were closed, resulting in a significant impairment charge. AusGroup is in breach of a financial covenant due to its high current liabilities, with ongoing debt restructuring efforts.

images.alt_text: HIGHER cost of sales and a host of impairment charges has pushed Australian oil and gas engineering services provider AusGroup into the red for the fourth quarter.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's Swiber Holdings sees claims rise to US$197m, while the Singapore dollar fell 2% against the US dollar after Janet Yellen's speech. Visitor arrivals to Singapore rose 14% in Q1, with tourism receipts growing 2%. GIC plans to acquire a 7.73% stake in Vietnamese bank Vietcombank. Singapore shares fell 1% after Yellen's remarks, and Peter Lim lodged a police report against claims linking him to get-rich-quick schemes.

site_title: GIC plans to acquire 7.73% stake in Vietcombank
summary: Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC plans to acquire a 7.73% stake in Vietnam's largest bank, Vietcombank, through a private placement of new shares. The investment aims to increase the bank's charter capital and prepare it for the implementation of Basel II. The transaction is expected to be completed by the fourth quarter of 2016, pending regulatory approvals. The deal reflects GIC's confidence in Vietnam's long-term growth potential and positions Vietcombank for a leading role in the country's banking sector.

site_title: Malaysia: Stocks end lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index ended lower on Monday, closing 1.490 points down to 1681.600, with a trading volume of 1.486 billion lots worth RM 1.4324 billion.

site_title: Europe: Shares edge lower; Alstom rises on contract win
summary: European shares declined 0.1% in early trading on Monday, despite Alstom's 2% rise after signing a 1.8 billion euro contract with US rail operator Amtrak to design and build 28 high-speed trains. Stada fell 1.2% due to an ex-dividend and failed attempts to remove the supervisory board chairman. Thin trading was expected due to a UK holiday, with the pan-European Stoxx 600 index pulling back from previous gains.

site_title: SMRT makes two key appointments
summary: SMRT Corporation announced two key appointments: Ng Bor Kiat as chief technology officer and Koh Keng Swee Gerard as chief corporate officer. Ng Bor Kiat, current senior vice-president of Systems & Technology and Technology Management Office, will oversee technology investment and innovation. Koh Keng Swee Gerard, current vice-president of Human Resources, will lead the Corp Services cluster, focusing on IT and organizational excellence. Both appointments will take effect on September 1, 2016, and report to SMRT's president and group CEO, Desmond Kuek.

site_title: Peter Lim makes police report against claims linking him to get-rich-quick schemes
summary: Veteran investor Peter Lim has filed a police report against individuals making online claims linking him to get-rich-quick investment schemes. Lim denies the claims, stating he's concerned and alarmed by the misuse of his name to mislead the public. The billionaire, ranked 11th among Singapore's top 50 richest, advises netizens to refrain from circulating false claims and protect themselves against get-rich-quick scams.

site_title: End of the road for tax discs from Feb 2017
summary: The Singapore Land Transport Authority (LTA) announced that road tax discs will be phased out from February 15, 2017, marking the end of a paper-based system. This change aims to make the country's transportation system more efficient and paperless.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close down on Yellen comments
summary: Hong Kong stocks declined Monday after Federal Reserve boss Janet Yellen hinted at possible US interest rate hikes by the end of the year. The Hang Seng Index fell 0.38% to close at 22,821.34, while the Shanghai Composite Index remained flat. Yellen's comments sparked concerns about increased borrowing costs, affecting Asian markets.

site_title: SGX advisory body okays dual-class shares, subject to safeguards
summary: The Singapore Exchange's Listings Advisory Committee (LAC) has approved the permitting of dual-class shares among listed issuers, subject to certain safeguards, including a maximum voting differential of 10 to one. Companies can adopt dual-class shares only if they have a compelling reason and existing shareholders were not aware of the risks. The LAC also recommends clear disclosure of shareholder rights, distinctive identification of securities, and investor education initiatives. The SGX will refer listing applications with dual-class structures to the LAC initially, and chairman Chew Choon Seng will retire after the annual general meeting on September 22.

site_title: Los Angeles police say reports of gunfire at airport were false alarm
summary: Reports of gunfire at Los Angeles International Airport (LAX) were deemed a false alarm, with no injuries reported. The incident prompted the evacuation of at least two terminals, with security personnel checking for suspicious activity. Video feeds showed dozens of people gathered on a tarmac and outside terminals. An investigation is underway, following similar incidents at US airports in recent months, including a terminal evacuation at JFK Airport two months prior.

site_title: As Beijing aims for blue skies over G20, China's steel mills get unexpected boost
summary: China's steel mills have received an unexpected boost after the government ordered hundreds of industrial plants to close ahead of the G20 summit in Hangzhou. The closures, aimed at improving air quality, have led to a surge in steel prices, with some mills earning up to 1,000 yuan (S$204) a tonne. This has helped restore profitability for the industry, which had been struggling due to weak prices and a global glut. China's steel production has cut by nearly 1 million tonnes, and the country is on track to slash 45 million tonnes of capacity this year, amid escalating tensions over Chinese exports.

site_title: South-east Asian online groceries firm HappyFresh raises at least US$12m
summary: HappyFresh, a South-east Asian online groceries delivery company, has raised at least $12 million in its latest fundraising round, beating its previous round. The company, which operates in Indonesia, Malaysia, and Thailand, will use the funds to expand its product offerings, fleet of motorcycles, and number of partner supermarkets. Investors include Samena Capital, Temasek Holdings, and Sinar Mas Group. This is a bigger round than the company's previous $12 million fundraising in 2015.

site_title: Veam raises $96m in Vietnam's biggest IPO this year
summary: Vietnam Engine and Agricultural Machinery Corp (Veam) raised 2.14 trillion dong (S$130.57 million) in its initial public offering, the largest in Vietnam this year. The company sold 149.5 million shares at an average price of 14,291 dong, exceeding its 12.57% stake target. The IPO result follows a 75% increase in IPOs from state-owned enterprises in the first seven months of 2016, with a total of 5.29 trillion dong raised. Veam forecasts a dividend ratio of 18% this year and plans to sell a 36% stake to strategic investors in September.

site_title: Seoul: Won, stocks slip as Fed comments support rate hike
summary: The South Korean won dropped to a one-week low at 1,125.0 to the US dollar following comments by top Federal Reserve officials that hinted at a possible US rate hike as early as next month. This strengthened the greenback, causing South Korean shares to slip 0.3% to 2,032.35 points. Foreign investors snapped a three-day selling streak, buying 84.5 billion won worth of Kospi shares.

site_title: Lum Chang's FY net profit dips on fair value losses, absence of divestment gain
summary: Lum Chang Holdings reported a 1% dip in net profit to S$29.5 million for FY ended June 30, mainly due to fair value losses on investment properties and an absence of divestment gain. Revenue rose 36% to S$426.1 million due to recognition of revenue from two construction projects. The company also recorded a S$11.5 million gain on disposal of a London property, contrasting with a S$4 million loss in the previous year.

site_title: Malaysia's CIMB posts 36% rise in quarterly profit
summary: Malaysia's CIMB Group Holdings Bhd reported a 36% increase in second-quarter profit to RM872.8 million, driven by higher net interest income. However, the bank stated it will miss its loan growth and return on equity targets for the full year. This surpasses analysts' average forecast of RM695 million for the quarter, according to Thomson Reuters data.

site_title: Malaysia's Felda Global Ventures posts 35% rise in profit
summary: Malaysia's Felda Global Ventures, the world's third-largest palm plantation operator, reported a 35% increase in second-quarter earnings to RM62.2 million, driven by stronger crude palm oil production. Revenue eased slightly to RM4.14 billion, compared to RM4.19 billion in the previous year. The firm attributed the growth to efforts to boost fruit yields.

site_title: South Korea economy to see mild improvement led by services, consumption
summary: South Korea's economy is expected to see a mild improvement in coming months, driven by services and domestic consumption. Exports will remain sluggish but are forecast to recover gradually. Manufacturing is predicted to be steady, with semiconductor and smartphone production rising in certain areas. The central bank attributes the economic growth to increased tourism and nationwide discount sales, part of a government scheme to spur economic activity.

site_title: China oil giant Sinopec net profit dives over 20%
summary: China's largest oil refiner, Sinopec, reported a 21.6% drop in first-half net profits to 19.92 billion yuan (S$4.05 billion) due to low oil prices. Despite a 4.4% rise in domestic oil consumption, the decline in international crude prices overshadowed the increase. This is the second major Chinese oil producer, PetroChina, to report a significant decline in profits, with PetroChina's net profit plummeting 97.9% year-on-year.

images.alt_text: Chinese oil giant Sinopec, Asia's biggest refiner, saw its first half net profits drop 21.6 per cent, it said, hit by low oil prices.

site_title: Kerry arrives in Bangladesh with offer of stronger security ties
summary: US Secretary of State John Kerry arrived in Bangladesh to offer stronger security ties amid growing extremism, following deadly attacks that raised concerns about the Islamic State. Kerry met with Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina and opposition leaders, potentially presenting new military and law-enforcement support. The visit comes as Bangladesh seeks to project an image of order after a bakery attack killed 22 people, mostly foreigners. Kerry's decision to visit reflects the US focus on Bangladesh as a potential Islamic State breeding ground.

site_title: Prices of completed private apartments, condos up 0.2% in July: NUS index
summary: Singapore's National University of Singapore (NUS) released a 0.2% month-over-month increase in the Overall Singapore Residential Price Index (SRPI) for July 2016, following a 0.7% gain in June. This marks the first time the index has increased since March. The July increase is attributed to the rising prices of completed private apartments and condominium units. The SRPI measures the prices of completed private apartments and condominium units in Singapore, providing insights into the country's property market.

images.alt_text: Prices of completed private apartments and condominium units in Singapore crept up 0.2 per cent in July over the preceding month.

site_title: China's Xi reshuffles key party posts ahead of congress
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping has reshuffled key party posts ahead of a party congress next year, cementing his hold on power. He appointed close allies, including Chen Hao and Du Jiahao, as provincial party chiefs in Yunnan and Hunan, respectively. The moves are part of Xi's strategy to consolidate power and appoint loyalists to key positions. The reshuffles also include Wu Yingjie as party chief of Tibet, and Lou Yangsheng as acting provincial governor in Shanxi.

site_title: Japan promises Kenya aid to fund development, power generation
summary: Japan has pledged $13.36 million in aid to Kenya to support economic and social development, with an additional unspecified amount for a geothermal power project. This move aims to tap Africa's natural resources and reduce dependence on oil and natural gas imports. Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe and Kenyan President Uhuru Kenyatta announced the aid in a joint statement, building on Japan's commitment of $30 billion in public and private support for infrastructure development in Africa over three years.

site_title: Ex-owner of Kay Lee Roast Meat and wife convicted of tax evasion
summary: Former owner of Kay Lee Roast Meat Joint Ha Wai Kay and his wife Kong Kuee Chin have been convicted of tax evasion. Ha underpaid S$54,917.15 in taxes for 2010 and 2011, while Kong knowingly under-declared over S$325,000 in sales income. They were sentenced to four weeks' jail and ordered to pay penalties of $164,751.45 and $164,751.45, respectively.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks surge after Yellen speech weakens yen
summary: Tokyo stocks surged on Monday, ending a two-day losing streak, after Federal Reserve chief Janet Yellen hinted at possible US interest rate hikes before the end of the year. This led to a weakened yen and boosted exporters, with the Nikkei 225 index rising 2.30% and the Topix index 1.97%. The yen's decline contributed to a rally in Tokyo's stocks, with the benchmark index closing at 16,737.49.

site_title: Australia shares close at lowest in over 3 weeks; NZ down
summary: Australian shares closed at their lowest in over 3 weeks, falling 0.84% to 5,469.20 points, due to US Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen's speech on a near-term rate hike. Energy and consumer cyclicals were dragged down, with Woodside Petroleum and Wesfarmers Ltd losing 2.83% and 3.32% respectively. New Zealand's benchmark index also fell, losing 0.33% to 7,367.26, with Westpac Banking Corp and Australia and New Zealand Banking Group Ltd losing 1.27% and 1.15% respectively.

site_title: Vietnam's growth offers Singapore firms new opportunities: Iswaran
summary: Singapore's Minister for Industry S Iswaran said Vietnam's growth trajectory offers new opportunities for Singapore companies, particularly in manufacturing, consumer services, and urban solutions. Vietnam's "sound economic fundamentals" and "political stability" make it an attractive emerging economy in Asia. Companies can tap into Vietnam's competitive manufacturing base, offer supporting services, and provide customized experiences in the consumer sector. Urbanization also presents opportunities for urban solutions. Bilateral trade between Singapore and Vietnam reached S$21.6 billion in 2015, with Singapore being the third largest foreign investor in Vietnam with US$38.1 billion in investments.

site_title: BMW plans a coupe to put boring 7-Series back in luxury race
summary: BMW plans to release a coupe version of its 7-Series sedan in 2019, aiming to boost sales of its luxury car and compete with Mercedes-Benz's S-Class. The move comes after the 7-Series saw a 40% decline in sales compared to the S-Class. BMW's efforts are also influenced by Audi's upcoming self-driving A8 model, set to be released next year. The coupe variant is expected to be a crucial factor in BMW's strategy to regain its lead in the luxury car market, with the company seeking to increase its profit margin in the segment.

site_title: Police investigating unconfirmed reports of shots fired at Los Angeles airport
summary: Los Angeles airport police are investigating unconfirmed reports of shots fired at Los Angeles International airport, with the central terminal's arrival and departures areas closed. Officials are taking precautions to ensure public safety, advising passengers to contact airlines for flight status updates. No confirmation of a shooting has been verified yet, and police are searching the airport. The airport has closed the Central Terminal Area and recommended passengers to contact airlines for flight status information.

images.alt_text: Los Angeles airport police said on Twitter late on Sunday they were investigating unconfirmed reports of shots being fired at Los Angeles International airport, with officials closing the arrival and departures areas of the central terminal.

site_title: Claims on Swiber balloon to US$197m
summary: Swiber Holdings' claims have risen to US$197 million, up from US$135.9 million previously. The company is seeking legal advice on the claims and has obtained an extension to announce its second quarter results until November 14, 2016.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 3.850 points to 1679.240. The market saw a trading volume of 30.1 million lots worth RM11.23 million, with 95 gainers and 71 losers.

site_title: ANA found damaged turbines in three 787 Rolls-Royce engines
summary: ANA Holdings Inc, the world's largest 787 operator, has found damaged turbines in three Rolls-Royce engines on its Boeing planes, prompting the cancellation of over 300 flights. The issue, caused by corrosion on turbine blades, was first discovered in February and has resulted in the shutdown of one engine. ANA will replace the current blades with modified ones starting January and has reported the damage to Rolls-Royce. The problem is the airline's biggest issue with the 787 model since a 2013 global grounding.

site_title: Asia: Most markets slump, Tokyo soars on US rate talk
summary: Japanese stocks rose 2.2% on a weaker yen, while other Asian markets declined following Federal Reserve chief Janet Yellen's hint at a US interest rate hike by the end of the year. Yellen's speech strengthened the case for a rate hike, with some experts speculating September could be the target. The dollar surged, buying 102.11 yen, while the euro fell and higher-yielding currencies declined. The weaker yen boosted Japan's exporters, but other regional markets fell, including Hong Kong, Sydney, and Shanghai.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Stocks open down after Yellen rate hike hint
summary: Hong Kong and Shanghai stocks fell after US Federal Reserve boss Janet Yellen hinted at a possible interest rate hike before the end of the year. The Hang Seng Index dropped 0.16%, while the Shanghai Composite Index edged down 0.06%. The move followed Yellen's comments, which sparked concerns about the impact on global markets.

site_title: Australia: Shares at 1-month low on US rate rise concerns
summary: Australian stocks fell 0.4% to a one-month low on Monday, weighed down by concerns over a potential US interest rate hike this year. Fed officials, including Janet Yellen and Stanley Fischer, suggested a possible rate hike in September or December, increasing the likelihood of a December hike to 60%. This led to losses in energy and consumer cyclical stocks, with oil prices also falling due to output from Iraq.

site_title: Want a hedge fund job? Knowing about wavelets improves your odds
summary: Hedge funds are increasingly seeking quants with expertise in wavelets, a mathematical tool used in data mining, to improve their investment strategies and keep up with top firms like Renaissance Technologies and Two Sigma Investments. Top hedge funds, such as King Street Capital Management and Tudor Investment Corp, are hiring quants, with some offering base salaries of up to $150,000 per year. PhDs in mathematics or related fields can earn even higher salaries, with some quants earning up to $200,000 per year after five years of experience.

site_title: Gold in longest stretch of declines since May as Fed bets climb
summary: Gold prices dropped for a seventh consecutive day, reaching the longest decline since May, amid speculation of a US interest rate hike as early as next month. The metal lost 0.4% to $1,316.09 an ounce, with comments from Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen suggesting a tightening of monetary policy. This move boosts the dollar and weighs on gold prices.

site_title: Ong Ye Kung joins MAS board
summary: Acting Minister for Education Ong Ye Kung has been appointed to the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) board, with his term set to run from August 29, 2016, to May 31, 2019. Lawrence Wong, who was appointed to the MAS board in 2011, is stepping down. The MAS board includes Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam, Minister Lim Hng Kiang, and Minister Heng Swee Keat.

site_title: Seoul: Won, stocks fall on growing chance of Fed rate hike soon
summary: The South Korean won plummeted over 1% against the dollar after US Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen hinted at a possible rate hike by year-end, and possibly twice, citing a strengthened US economy. The won fell to a one-week low of 1,128.5, while the Korean Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) also edged down 0.4%. Foreign investors purchased Kospi shares, while automobile manufacturers like Kia Motors and SK Chemicals declined.

site_title: Central bankers spurn call for radical approach at Jackson Hole
summary: Central bankers at the Jackson Hole meeting reaffirmed their commitment to fighting low inflation, citing the power of monetary policy. Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen stated that additional tools remain under research and are not being actively considered. The group rejected proposals to abolish cash, raise inflation targets, or keep permanently large balance sheets. Yellen emphasized that monetary policy remains a key tool in preventing deflation, but acknowledged the need for continued research and evaluation of new approaches. The meeting concluded with a cautious stance on radical policy changes.

site_title: Kim Kardashian game maker among Tencent's losing investments
summary: Tencent, China's largest Internet company, has seen six of its 11 listed investments, including Glu Mobile's Kim Kardashian: Hollywood, decline since its US$126 million investment in 2014. Despite this, Tencent's gaming investments have been successful, with its mobile gaming revenue doubling to 9.6 billion yuan in the second quarter. The company's strategy of building an ecosystem for its digital services appears to be paying off, with its shares reaching a new record.

site_title: More flights from US spell likely end for Cuba's 'mules'
summary: US commercial flights to Cuba resumed on August 24, 2016, marking the likely end for the "mules" who supplied scarce consumer goods to the island. For decades, charter flights and travel packages allowed Cubans in the US to ship goods to relatives in Cuba at a low cost. However, with the restoration of direct commercial flights, this practice is expected to cease, as companies like FedEx are set to begin shipping goods directly to the island. This change is expected to reduce the need for mules and alter the way consumer goods are transported to Cuba.

site_title: Japan's first home-made jet back in hangar after aborted tests
summary: Japan's first locally built passenger jet, the Mitsubishi Regional Jet, has returned to its hangar after two aborted test flights due to a faulty air-conditioning system. The test flights, which were intended to take the plane to the US for certification, were delayed but not expected to cause another postponement. Mitsubishi Aircraft Corp plans to resume test flights once the issue is fixed, with delivery to ANA Holdings Inc scheduled for mid-2018. The delay is seen as a minor setback in the company's bid to challenge Embraer and Bombardier's dominance in the regional-jet market.

images.alt_text: Mitsubishi Aircraft Corp, the builder of the Mitsubishi Regional Jet, will make a decision on resuming its test flight to the US after the problem has been fixed, spokesman Kenichi Takemori said by telephone from Nagoya Monday.

site_title: Petronas's C$11b Canada gas plan buoyed by Aboriginal vote
summary: Petronas's proposed C$11 billion liquefied natural gas export plant in Canada is receiving a boost after the Lax Kw'alaams Band, which initially opposed the project, signals openness to the project and suggests the location may be changed. The band's mayor, John Helin, has expressed optimism that talks on compensation for impacts on their traditional lands will take place. The project's developer has not confirmed any changes to the proposal, but the move may alleviate concerns and pave the way for the project's approval.

site_title: Beyonce dominates MTV awards with fiery show
summary: Beyoncé dominated the 2016 MTV Video Music Awards with a visually intricate medley of her album-film Lemonade, featuring the mothers of four young black men whose deaths have galvanized the US public. The performance included a medley of songs, including "Formation," which was the most politically charged song of her career. Other notable performances included Alicia Keys' powerful poem and Kanye West's nearly stream-of-consciousness speech about empowerment. Rihanna opened the ceremony and won the Video Vanguard Award.

images.alt_text: Beyonce on Sunday stole the spotlight at the MTV Video Music Awards with a visually intricate medley of her next album with a subtle political touch.

site_title: Foreign brewers fight for Vietnam's thriving beer market
summary: Foreign brewers, including Heineken, Thai Beverage PCL, and Asahi Group Holdings Ltd, are expanding in Vietnam's thriving beer market, which is driven by a growing young population and rising middle class. The market is expected to reach 4.04 billion liters of beer consumption this year, the most in the region. Global interest in Vietnam's beer market is also being fueled by the government's plans to offload lucrative assets, with Carlsberg set to double its stake in state-run Habeco. Economists predict Vietnam will be among the world's fastest-growing economies in 2016, with a manufacturing industry that's grown in importance over the years.

site_title: 'Missile practice' caused deadly Taiwan misfire: prosecutors
summary: A Taiwanese naval officer, Kao Chia-chun, was charged with negligence leading to death and injuries after accidentally firing a supersonic missile towards China, killing one and injuring three. The incident occurred when Kao, unsupervised, practiced with the missile launcher, ignoring the system's "combat mode" and live-fire mode. His supervisor, Chen Ming-hsiu, and lieutenant Hsu Po-wei were also charged for neglecting official duties. The incident embarrassed President Tsai Ing-wen and strained relations with China, with 1,500 Chinese missiles reportedly aimed at Taiwan.

site_title: Majority want Japan PM Abe to stay on until Tokyo 2020 Olympics: poll
summary: Support for Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe has reached over 60% for the first time in almost two years, according to a media survey. Nearly 60% of voters want him to stay in office until the 2020 Tokyo Olympics. However, opinions on his economic policies, including the Bank of Japan's negative interest rate stance, are divided, with 47% opposing it. The survey's findings may be linked to Abe's appearance at the Rio Olympics closing ceremony, where he dressed as Mario.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks fall on weaker overseas markets, technical selling in TSMC
summary: Taiwan's stocks fell on Monday, tracking weakness in overseas markets and technical selling in TSMC. The main TAIEX index dropped 0.7% to 9,070.84, following a possible US rate hike hinted by Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen. TSMC fell 1.1% and display makers AU Optronics Corp and Innolux Corp declined around 2%. The Taiwan dollar softened to NT$31.824 per US dollar.

site_title: Singapore steps up zika fight after confirming 41 local cases
summary: Singapore has confirmed 41 locally transmitted Zika cases, with 34 fully recovered, and is intensifying efforts to control the Aedes mosquito population. The Ministry of Health will screen people who had close contact with those infected and has identified seven areas of concern where some infected individuals live. The Zika outbreak highlights the threat of infection across Asia, particularly for pregnant women who are at risk of giving birth to babies with microcephaly. The National Environment Agency is also stepping up its efforts to control the mosquito population.

site_title: China's yuan hits weakest level versus US dollar in more than a month
summary: China's yuan hit its weakest level against the US dollar in over a month, falling to 6.6850 per dollar, following Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen's comments on the US economy and traders' expectations of an interest rate hike. The dollar index remained steady at 95.551, its loftiest level since August 16. China's central bank set the midpoint rate at 6.6856 per dollar, its weakest level since July 25, due to broad dollar strength.

site_title: Singapore shares open 0.4% down on Monday
summary: Singapore stocks opened 0.4% lower on Monday, with the Straits Times Index shedding 10.95 points to 2,846.7, due to indications from Fed officials that a rate hike is on the way this year. Losers outnumbered gainers 73 to 49.

site_title: China needs to urgently transform its economy: cabinet think-tank
summary: China's cabinet think-tank urges the government to implement supply-side and structural reforms to transform its economy. Vice head Wang Yiming warns that if old ways continue, investment rates will fall, debt will rise, and financial risks will increase. The country needs to shift from producing low-end products to more efficient, middle, and high-end products. This transformation is necessary to address slowing GDP growth and rising pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Oil prices sink in Asia on strong US dollar, output fears
summary: Oil prices in Asia plummeted on Monday, falling 1.11% to $47.11 for US benchmark West Texas Intermediate and 1.04% to $49.40 for Brent. A strong US dollar and concerns over Opec producers limiting output next month contributed to the decline. Iranian oil minister Bijan Zanganeh expressed his country's desire to regain pre-sanctions oil market share, potentially limiting participation in an Opec production freeze. The comments from Zanganeh and Saudi Arabia's energy minister Khalid Al-Falih downplayed hopes for a production cut, further pressuring oil prices.

site_title: China to publish debt-to-equity plan soon: media
summary: China is set to publish a debt-to-equity plan, allowing industrial firms with development potential to convert debts into equity stakes as early as next month. The plan aims to address the country's high corporate debt ratio of 145% of GDP, which the International Monetary Fund warned could erode economic growth. The government plans to eliminate failing firms and help restructure struggling ones, while insisting it won't prop up "zombie enterprises". The move is part of China's efforts to rejuvenate its economy and address its debt challenges.

site_title: Australian casino billionaire sells down Crown Resorts stake below half
summary: Australian billionaire James Packer has sold 4.8% of his stake in Crown Resorts Ltd for A$450 million, trimming his ownership to 48% from 53%. The sale was part of Consolidated Press Holdings' financing strategy and does not affect its commitment to the company. The reason for the sale and identity of the buyers were not disclosed.

site_title: Global Yellow Pages remains in the red for FY2016
summary: Global Yellow Pages (GYP) reported a net loss of S$9.3 million for FY2016, compared to a net loss of S$62.4 million in the previous year. Revenue from continuing operations rose to S$32.3 million, driven by full-year rental revenue from a shopping mall and six months' revenue contribution from a master franchisor rights acquisition. Total expenses fell to S$36.8 million, and cash and cash equivalents increased to S$9.7 million. GYP remains committed to its digital strategy and diversification plans.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher as exporters surge on weaker yen
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Monday, with the benchmark Nikkei 225 index surging 1.65% due to the weaker yen, boosted by US Federal Reserve chief Janet Yellen's suggestion of near-term interest rate hikes. The Nikkei 225 index rose 270.35 points to 16,631.06, while the Topix index of all first-section shares also increased 1.65% to 1,309.17.

site_title: After building boom, South Korea girds for housing glut
summary: South Korea is grappling with a housing glut, with 5,301 unsold new residential units in the city of Yongin, a record high. The country's housing boom, fueled by low interest rates, has led to a surge in borrowing and household debt, exceeding 88.4% of GDP. Policymakers are concerned about the potential destabilization of financial markets when the bubble bursts. To address the issue, the government has announced measures to encourage households to take out fixed-rate loans and stricter bank lending standards.

site_title: Oil falls near US$47 a barrel as US crude rig count unchanged
summary: Oil prices fell near US$47 a barrel as US crude rig count remained unchanged, despite storm preparations in the Gulf of Mexico. Futures dropped 1.2% after advancing 1.9% over the previous two sessions, driven by speculation of potential Opec output freeze. West Texas Intermediate (WTI) for October delivery fell 59 US cents to US$47.05 a barrel, while Brent for October settlement declined 47 US cents to US$49.45 a barrel.

site_title: China plans to raise scale, quality of dairy sector: minister
summary: China plans to boost the dairy sector's scale and quality to increase local consumption and rural employment. Agriculture Minister Han Changfu stated that China's dairy sector is underdeveloped, with per capita consumption rates only a third of the global average. The country aims to develop the dairy sector to ensure a stable supply of agricultural products and create jobs. China currently has over 1 million dairy farmers and 10 million dairy cows, but the industry is "big but not strong."

site_title: Currency traders can't lose as trusted strategies reap big gains
summary: US currency traders are experiencing a rare year of success, with three major foreign-exchange strategies producing positive returns for the first time in over a decade. The carry trade, valuation strategy, and momentum trade are all on pace for significant gains, driven by central-bank monetary stimulus and historically low interest rates. Investors are diversifying their trades to capitalize on emerging-market currencies, with the Australian and New Zealand dollars rising despite central banks cutting rates. This year's strong performance is a stark reversal from last year's 7.7% decline, with many foreign-exchange investors adapting to the changing market conditions.

site_title: US SEC paid US$3.75m to BHP Billiton whistleblower: report
summary: The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) paid BHP Billiton insider $3.75 million for information in an investigation into alleged bribery of Asian and African officials. This is the first time an employee of an Australian company has received a US whistleblower bounty. BHP settled a SEC case last year, paying $25 million to resolve charges of violating a US anti-bribery law related to the 2008 Beijing Olympics. The Australian Federal Police continue to investigate BHP.

site_title: Stocks to watch: C&G, Cordlife, Oxley
summary: Stocks to watch: C&G, Cordlife, Oxley. C&G Environmental Protection Holdings proposes selling its business to Chinese partners for S$0.197 a share. Cordlife Group posted a 59.8% drop in net profit to S$13 million, while revenue rose 3.5%. Oxley Holdings reported a 114% jump in net profit to S$73.8 million, despite a 15% decline in revenue.

site_title: Fiat Chrysler chief calls Samsung a potential strategic partner
summary: Fiat Chrysler Automobiles NV CEO Sergio Marchionne has expressed interest in Samsung Electronics as a potential strategic partner, citing a "very good relationship" between the two companies. Samsung is in advanced talks to buy Fiat Chrysler's Magneti Marelli components unit, with a focus on Marelli's lighting and in-car entertainment business. Marchionne stated that while Fiat Chrysler has had suitors for the unit, the company is not interested in selling and will focus on eliminating debt before his CEO post in 2019.

site_title: Qatar to levy airport tax on passengers
summary: Qatar will levy a new airport tax of 35 riyals (S$13.05) on every passenger leaving Doha's Hamad International Airport, starting Tuesday. The tax, applied to tickets issued after August 30, will be used to increase airport capacity and invest in new infrastructure. This move comes as the country seeks new revenue streams amid falling oil prices and a projected deficit of 46.5 billion riyals in 2016. The tax follows similar measures announced by airports in the United Arab Emirates.

site_title: Vienna Airport grounds flights due to technical problems
summary: Vienna Airport grounded 113 flights due to technical issues with automated flight data transmission, leaving hundreds of passengers stranded. The problem occurred when the European air traffic control agency and Austrian air traffic control lost communication, causing flights to be delayed or cancelled. Airlines affected included Lufthansa, British Airways, and Turkish Airlines. Extra staff were brought in to manually enter data into the system, and the airport provided free food and drinks for stranded passengers. Operations were expected to return to normal on Monday morning.

site_title: Biggest China banks grind out meagre profit gains as loans sour
summary: China's largest banks reported meager profit gains in the second quarter, with Agricultural Bank of China Ltd increasing net income by 0.5% and China Construction Bank Corp by 0.9%. Despite this, bad-loan pressures persist, with Agricultural Bank's nonperforming-debt ratio rising to 2.4% and the other banks maintaining high provisions for bad loans. The situation remains severe, with some lenders announcing plans for new fundraisings to mitigate risks. China's central bank and regulators are exploring tools to tackle leverage and bad credit, including debt swaps and NPL-backed securities.

images.alt_text: China's biggest banks are grinding out meagre profit gains as they grapple with pressure from loans going bad.

site_title: China stock traders feel the heat with 774 probes in two months
summary: China's stock regulators have intensified scrutiny of unusual price movements, opening 774 investigations and halting 38 investor accounts since July. Exchanges in Shanghai and Shenzhen have also published case studies of "abnormal trading" and challenged companies for extreme price movements. This campaign aims to damp speculation in China's financial markets.

site_title: Forget helicopter money: BOJ may prefer to fund railways, sewers
summary: The Bank of Japan may consider funding local infrastructure projects such as railways, hospitals, and power plants by buying bonds of local governments and public corporations, rather than helicopter money. This move would help finance infrastructure investments and increase money flow in the economy. Analysts suggest that the BOJ may target local government bonds, known as zaito institution paper, after its September meeting. The decision would be a reasonable move for the BOJ, but could have negative effects on investors, such as higher prices and a rise in struggling investors.

site_title: China's three biggest airlines face 8.5b yuan currency losses
summary: China's three largest airlines, Air China, China Southern Airlines, and China Eastern Airlines, are expected to report combined losses of 8.5 billion yuan (S$1.77 billion) due to currency fluctuations this year, despite rising traffic and cheaper fuel. The losses are narrowing compared to 2015's 16.2 billion yuan. The airlines' strategy to trim dollar-denominated debt is seen as a positive step, and analysts predict a better second-half performance. The yuan's depreciation has been the main factor in the losses, with further weakening expected by the end of 2017.

site_title: US dollar holds climb as odds of Fed hike increase, Yen nurses drop
summary: The US dollar rose to a two-week high after Federal Reserve officials hinted at a potential interest rate hike as early as next month, boosting bets of a rate increase. The dollar strengthened 0.1% against the euro and 0.1% against the yen, which lost 0.1% to 101.96 per dollar. The Bloomberg Dollar Spot Index reached its largest gain since May. Fed Chair Janet Yellen and Vice Chairman Stanley Fischer fueled speculation of a rate hike, with futures indicating a 42% chance of a rate increase next month.

site_title: Most of China's electric-car startups face wipeout by new rules
summary: China's electric-vehicle industry is facing a massive shakeup as the government imposes stricter technology standards and considers limiting the number of startups to 10. Most of the 200+ companies backed by billionaires, including Jack Ma and Li Ka-shing, risk extinction due to lack of technical know-how. The industry is plagued by overcapacity, with 90% of current startups unlikely to meet standards in two years. The government aims to raise the threshold and phase out subsidies after 2020 to ensure healthy industry development.

site_title: Dotcom demands live-stream of extradition appeal
summary: Internet mogul Kim Dotcom launched an appeal against extradition to the US, demanding his case be live-streamed to ensure a fair hearing. The Megaupload founder faces up to 20 years in jail if convicted of video piracy, which US authorities claim cost copyright owners hundreds of millions of dollars. Dotcom argues that Megaupload was a genuine file-sharing site and that live-streaming of the hearing would address "unprecedented issues of public and international interest." A previous nine-week hearing found there was "overwhelming" evidence to support extradition, but Dotcom plans to relaunch his Megaupload empire in 2017.

images.alt_text: Internet mogul Kim Dotcom launched his appeal against extradition from New Zealand to the United States on Monday arguing for his case to be live-streamed to ensure a fair hearing.

site_title: C&G to sell its principal businesses to Chinese business partners
summary: C&G Environmental Protection Holdings is selling its principal businesses to Chinese partners. The company agreed to dispose of its Thailand operating subsidiary, C&G Environmental Protection (Thailand) Company Limited, to New Sky Energy (Thailand) Company Limited for $38 million. It also entered into a conditional sale and purchase agreement with Ahead Auto Limited to sell its remaining group companies for $105 million. The sale proceeds will be distributed as a special dividend, representing a premium of 74% to the volume weighted average trading price.

site_title: Herbalife may have misled investors, SEC on impact of FTC deal, one short-seller says
summary: A private investor alleges Herbalife misled investors and the SEC about the impact of its Federal Trade Commission (FTC) settlement, claiming the company's verbal optimism about its business model did not match its more cautious SEC filings. Herbalife agreed to restructure its US business and pay a $200 million fine to settle the FTC probe, but its SEC filings suggest the company may face significant disruption and long-term impact. The investor's accusations could potentially lead to short sellers and investors reevaluating their positions on the company.

site_title: Two United Airlines pilots held on alcohol charge in Scotland
summary: Two United Airlines pilots were arrested in Scotland on suspicion of being under the influence of alcohol, just hours before a flight to the US. The 35- and 45-year-old pilots, aged 35 and 45, were detained under a railway safety act and will appear in court on Monday. The flight, carrying 141 passengers, took off nearly 10 hours late with a new crew. United Airlines said the two pilots had been removed from service and will conduct its own investigation, prioritizing customer safety.

site_title: JPMorgan wants millennials to buy cars - so, naturally, it built an app
summary: JPMorgan Chase has launched Chase Auto Direct, a car-buying smartphone app in partnership with TrueCar, to target millennials. The app allows approved borrowers to apply for car financing online and be routed to Chase-affiliated dealerships with the desired vehicle. The service is available to Chase customers in 30 states and aims to simplify the car-buying process. The move is part of JPMorgan's efforts to attract and retain millennials, who are increasingly shopping for cars online.

site_title: Mexico discovers hidden tunnel to US
summary: Mexican authorities have discovered a hidden tunnel extending nearly 1.5m in Mexico and over 30m in the US, from Sonora to Arizona. The tunnel, partially constructed with wood beams and dirt, was likely used by drug traffickers or undocumented migrants. This discovery follows previous tunnel discoveries, including the 800m-long tunnel found in April that connected Tijuana to San Diego. Authorities on both sides of the border regularly find such hidden tunnels, highlighting ongoing smuggling and migration issues.

site_title: Anti-burkini law would be 'unconstitutional': French minister
summary: French Interior Minister Bernard Cazeneuve stated that a nationwide ban on the burkini would be "unconstitutional" and cause irreparable harm. The government opposes legislating on the issue, which has sparked debate about women's rights and France's secularism. Despite 30 coastal resorts banning the full-body swimwear, France's highest administrative court overturned the measures, setting a legal precedent. Cazeneuve warned that pushing for a ban would create antagonism and tension, and urged Muslims to engage with the government on gender equality and tolerance.

site_title: Goldcorp could rise more than 40% without gold gains: Barron's
summary: Goldcorp's stock could rise over 40% without gold price gains, according to a Barron's report, due to the company's cost-cutting efforts. The miner's US-listed shares have risen 38% this year, below peers Newmont and Barrick. Despite low interest rates and global growth fears, Goldcorp's recent earnings reports missed expectations and the company cut its dividend by two-thirds. Mexican regulators are examining the company's handling of a contaminated water leak, but cost-cutting efforts may lead to a 20-cent-per-share earnings boost. The stock could reach $23 without gold price support.

site_title: Germany, Paris, Warsaw call for closer ties post-Brexit
summary: Germany, France, and Poland's foreign ministers pledged to strengthen ties post-Brexit, aiming for a safer and more effective union. The ministers, gathered in Weimar, Germany, to celebrate the 25th anniversary of the "Weimar Triangle" forum, vowed to intensify cooperation. They emphasized the need for a united Europe to address challenges, such as security threats and economic uncertainty. The declaration aims to promote a closer relationship among the three nations, potentially influencing the EU's future direction.

site_title: Scant rallies for Brazil's Rousseff before big day
summary: Brazil's suspended president Dilma Rousseff is set to defend herself in person on Monday against impeachment charges for alleged illegal state accounting maneuvers. Supporters held small street rallies in the capital ahead of the trial, which is expected to end 13 years of leftist rule in the country. The impeachment trial is seen as a dramatic last stand for Rousseff, who faces the possibility of being fired within days.

site_title: Colombia ceasefire to end half-century war in hours
summary: A historic ceasefire is set to end a 52-year-old war between Colombia and FARC rebels, with hundreds of thousands of Colombians having died in the conflict. The Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) has ordered its fighters to observe the ceasefire from midnight, following peace negotiations in Havana since 2012. The measure is followed by a six-month demobilization process, where guerrilla fighters will gather and give up their weapons under UN supervision. A referendum on the peace agreement is set for October 2, with approval requiring a majority "yes" vote by at least 4.4 million people.

site_title: Quest to save a few dollars per air bag led to a deadly crisis
summary: General Motors' decision to adopt a cheaper air bag design from supplier Takata in the late 1990s led to a deadly crisis, resulting in at least 14 deaths and over 100 injuries. The design, which used a volatile compound, was deemed too expensive to replicate by GM's air bag supplier, Autoliv, which had raised concerns about its safety. Despite warnings from Autoliv and research from experts, GM prioritized cost savings, and the faulty air bags were installed in over 100 million vehicles across the US and globally.

site_title: Applying the edutainment tool of virtual reality to industry
summary: Aviation Virtual, a Singapore-based virtual reality solutions company, has developed a simulation programme to enable industry professionals to visualize and interact with complex systems in a life-size format. The company, founded in 2014, initially focused on aircraft maintenance training but has since expanded to other industrial verticals, such as buildings and architectural industries. With a S$1 million government grant and private investments, Aviation Virtual aims to reach a topline of S$4 million by the end of 2016, with plans to grow to S$10 million in five years. The company's innovative approach is transforming the way industries approach design, decision-making, and training, opening up new dimensions for collaboration and innovation.

site_title: Only a very strong or truly awful jobs report will drive stocks higher
summary: US stocks are poised for volatility ahead of a high-stakes jobs report, with rate-sensitive sectors expected to be the biggest movers. Fed officials, including Chairwoman Janet Yellen and Vice Chairman Stanley Fischer, have indicated that the US economy is already hot enough to warrant a rate hike, potentially prompting a rate-sensitive sell-off. The jobs report, expected to show around 175,000 new employees added to payrolls, will be closely watched, with economists anticipating a modest but steady growth rate.

images.alt_text: Biotechnology companies are losing ground as Mrs Clinton, who retains a commanding lead in national polls, plans to probe their pricing practices after Mylan raised prices on its EpiPen medication.

site_title: Cash up or ship out: it's the big O&M squeeze post-Swiber
summary: Singapore's offshore and marine (O&M) sector is facing a squeeze as analysts warn of high debt-to-equity gearing, low or negative cash flows, and short-term debt deadlines. The demise of Swiber Holdings has triggered a wake-up call, with 12 out of 14 listed companies having short-term debt over S$100 million and nearly all being highly geared. Only a few large-cap yard operators are expected to benefit from the industry's recovery, while small and mid-cap players may struggle to survive, with some potentially filing for bankruptcy protection.

images.alt_text: The offshore support vessel (OSV) segment is still haunted by a supply glut from excessive newbuilding and demand destruction from a slump in offshore drilling and EPC activities.

site_title: US election so nuts I just might win, libertarian Johnson says
summary: Libertarian candidate Gary Johnson says he might win the US presidential election, citing polls showing widespread dislike for the two major nominees. To secure a spot in the debates, Johnson needs 15% support in five national polls, currently at 8.1%. He proposes a national sales tax, removing marijuana from the DEA's list, and easing immigration policies. Johnson's running mate, Bill Weld, has taken a more pragmatic approach, blending libertarian principles with fiscal conservatism and social views. Johnson believes his third-party candidacy could lead to a bipartisan administration, offering a "third alternative" to the polarized options.

images.alt_text: Libertarian Gary Johnson's plan for capturing the White House hinges on voters following through on polls suggesting they dislike the Republican and Democratic presidential nominees more than in any election year in history.

site_title: Landmark San Francisco building sold for US$375m
summary: A New York-based developer, Thor Equities, has sold the historic Phelan Building in San Francisco to a member of the prominent Hotung family in Hong Kong for US$375 million. The 11-story landmark, built after a 1906 earthquake, was purchased by Thor Equities in 2008 for US$130 million and renovated at a cost of US$40 million. The sale marks a significant investment in US commercial property by Chinese investors, who have pumped US$17 billion into the market this year. The Phelan Building now serves as home to online credit site Credit Karma and Medium.

site_title: Rosberg cruises to win in eventful Belgian Grand Prix
summary: Nico Rosberg won the Belgian Grand Prix, rekindling his bid for the drivers' world championship. His Mercedes team-mate Lewis Hamilton finished third after a thrilling drive from the back of the grid. The event was marked by chaos and crashes, but Rosberg's dominant performance secured his victory.

images.alt_text: Rosberg, who started from his third successive pole position, led from start to finish to secure his first victory in Belgium and his sixth of the season.

site_title: Pedal for charity and bond with colleagues
summary: Twelve Singaporean firms have signed up for The Business Times Cycle of Hope Corporate Bike Ride, raising over S$20,000 for four charities during the event. The ride is part of OCBC Cycle's charity partnership program, promoting a healthy lifestyle and corporate social responsibility. The event takes place on the Oct 1-2 weekend, supporting charities in need.

site_title: The big data revolution in energy
summary: The big data revolution in energy is transforming the sector with seismic shifts in cost, production, and customization. Advances in analytics and automation are driving efficiency, reducing costs, and enabling more personalized energy services. This shift could lead to a 50% decrease in capital expenditure costs, fewer new power plants, and the emergence of "transactive energy" where consumers trade energy with others. The industry is also adopting asset-light business models, with technology companies providing energy network optimizing software and auto companies offering energy services through their battery technology.

site_title: Petronas C$11b Canada gas plan buoyed by aboriginal vote
summary: A proposed C$11 billion liquefied natural gas export plant in Canada by Petronas has received a boost after the Lax Kw'alaams Band, an aboriginal community opposing the project, signaled openness to it amid speculation of a potential location change. The community, which initially rejected C$1.15 billion in compensation, is set to meet with officials to discuss alternative venues. Two-thirds of the band's 812 members voted in favor of continuing discussions on the project, provided environmental protection is prioritized. A decision on the project is expected from the Canadian government within the next month.

images.alt_text: The Petronas-led proposal is among almost two dozen being considered for Canada's Pacific Coast.

site_title: Is gold really losing its lustre?
summary: Gold investment demand reached a record high of 1,064 tonnes in the first half of 2016, with the gold price rallying over 25% since the start of the year. However, its momentum appears to be losing steam, with the gold price hovering above 1,300 for over a month without breaking the 1,400 resistance. Analysts suggest that gold's bull market may be a flash in the pan, as the UK's low interest rate environment and global economic uncertainty continue to impact its value.

site_title: ENI expects to restart Goliat oil platform within days
summary: ENI expects to restart oil production at its Goliat platform in the Barents Sea off Norway within days after a power supply loss prompted a partial staff evacuation. The platform lost power from shore on Friday, but supply was restored after several hours. ENI's spokesman stated that production will resume when "all the facts are gathered" as a safety precaution. The restart is expected to happen within a matter of days, following a brief shutdown due to the power outage.

images.alt_text: Oil firm ENi expects to restart oil production at its Goliat platform in the Barents Sea off Norway within days after it was shut on Friday, a spokesman said on Sunday.

site_title: Batteries win biggest energy-storage contest of the year in UK
summary: National Grid plc announced it will award contracts to eight providers in the UK to enhance the frequency of the grid and respond to fluctuations, a step to help expand the use of renewable energy. Batteries won the biggest energy-storage contest of the year, providing a quick power source to keep the grid stable. This move aims to support the UK's transition to more renewable energy sources.

images.alt_text: National Grid will award contracts to eight electricity providers that bid to enhance the frequency of the grid if needed and help respond to fluctuations on the network.

site_title: Megabrew deal a boon for bankers and lawyers
summary: Anheuser-Busch InBev's $103.8 billion takeover of SABMiller Plc has generated $2 billion in fees for bankers, lawyers, and other companies. AB InBev will pay $1.74 billion, with an additional $202 million for fees. This deal follows a recommendation by SABMiller's board last month, marking the biggest acquisition in the beer industry.

site_title: 2009: Dealing with a crisis
summary: In 2009, Singapore's property market experienced rapid price increases amidst the global financial crisis, rebounding to pre-crisis levels by year-end. The government responded by introducing cooling measures, including dipping into national reserves for the first time, and imposing S-chip listing rules to address governance issues. The measures were aimed at preventing a bubble, but it took about four years for prices to recede. The government's actions helped maintain confidence in the economy during the crisis, earning commendation for its fiscal initiative.

site_title: Money, in the eye of the beholder
summary: A Singaporean shopper was perplexed by prices at a high-end Bangkok supermarket catering to the top 1% of Thais and expats. The prices were significantly higher than those in Singapore, despite the shopper's higher salary. This highlights the subjective nature of value and wealth, where people's preferences and perceptions of "affordability" vary greatly. The article suggests that the concept of "cosmic justice" in the game of wealth is often based on percentages, rather than absolute values.

site_title: New musical talents strut their stuff in Sentosa
summary: A new generation of local music stars showcased their talents at Singapore Rhapsodies - The Concert 2016 in Sentosa, attracting a 3,000-strong crowd. The event, organized by The RICE Company and supported by the Sing50 fund, featured diverse music genres and collaborations between established and up-and-coming artists. The concert aimed to provide a platform for industry collaboration and raised funds for local schools. Minister for Social and Family Development Tan Chuan-Jin was the event's guest of honour. The concert was a success, highlighting the growth of local music talent in Singapore.

site_title: Mercedes, Infiniti owners most likely to accept driverless cars
summary: A survey by MaritzCX found that Mercedes-Benz and Infiniti owners are more likely to accept driverless cars, with 27% expressing interest in purchasing a fully self-driving vehicle. This is compared to owners of Jeep and Ram vehicles, who were the least interested. The survey results suggest that luxury vehicle owners may be more open to adopting autonomous technology.

site_title: Fed will need to tread carefully to avoid market crises: Mobius
summary: US Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen's recent statement that the case for a rise in US short-term interest rates has "strengthened" may lead to market crises in emerging markets, warns veteran investor Mark Mobius. He cautions that equity and bond markets are at risk of sharp corrections unless the Fed walks a fine line between caution and inflation risk. Mobius also warns about overpriced Internet stocks and advises emerging-market authorities to develop their capital markets to mitigate future shocks.

site_title: Russia's Lada maker boss eyes profits despite struggling car industry
summary: Nicolas Maure, CEO of Avtovaz, a Russian carmaker majority-owned by the Renault-Nissan Alliance, aims to return the company to profit by 2018 despite the struggling Russian car industry. Maure took over Avtovaz in April, amid major losses and bankruptcy fears, but notes that the situation is more favorable than when he arrived, with steady demand and a growing market share. The company has seen an uptick in sales and is exploring foreign markets, including the Middle East and Africa, to increase exports and profitability.

site_title: Digging into the risks in China's mounting debt
summary: China's mounting debt has raised concerns among investors, with some likening the situation to the US before the 2008 financial crisis. The country's total debt has grown 465% over the past decade, with corporate debt increasing to 165% of GDP, while household debt remains relatively low. However, if a crisis were to occur, it's more likely to be triggered by corporations and their creditors, the banks, rather than households. China's unique state-owned corporate and banking landscape also presents opportunities for the government to address debt problems in unconventional ways.

site_title: Only in Palm Beach: The US$95 million teardown
summary: Russian billionaire Dmitry Rybolovlev is tearing down his $95 million Palm Beach estate, once owned by Donald Trump, into three properties for sale. The 6-acre estate, known as Maison de l'Amitié, will be demolished, and its value is expected to be split among the three parcels, each valued at $35-40 million. The sale is seen as a new level of disposable wealth in the high-end resort town of Palm Beach.

site_title: Dollar rebounds as hawkish Yellen prevails
summary: The US dollar surged to a two-week high against the yen and Swiss franc, driven by Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen's comments on an improving US economy, which bolstered the case for an interest rate increase. Yellen stated that improvements in the US labor market and expectations for moderate growth have strengthened the case for a rate rise. Futures markets indicated a 36% chance of a rate hike in September and over 60% in December. The dollar index rose 0.8% to a 10-day high, with the dollar up 1.3% against the yen and 1.2% against the Swiss franc.

site_title: Oxley turns tables on critics with overseas success in property
summary: Oxley Holdings, a Singapore-based property developer, has reported a 114% jump in net profit to S$73.8 million for its fourth quarter, despite a 15% decline in revenue. The company's international expansion, particularly in London, has helped it buck the trend of falling profits among local developers. Oxley's full-year net profit rose 162% to S$206 million, while revenue surged 40% to S$981.4 million. The company's CEO, Ching Chiat Kwong, attributes its success to its bold expansion abroad and its ability to adapt to the local market.

site_title: Vietnamese President in Singapore for state visit
summary: Vietnamese President Tran Dai Quang arrived in Singapore for a three-day state visit, strengthening bilateral relations and exploring deeper business ties. The visit includes a state banquet, business forum, and the 38th Singapore Lecture. Singapore and Vietnam have a strong relationship, with bilateral trade reaching S$21.6 billion in 2015 and Singapore being the sixth largest trading partner for Vietnam. The visit aims to deepen cooperation in sectors such as banking and air connectivity, with potential for increased investments and regional connectivity.

site_title: Director buying stays active in absence of sellers
summary:
Here is a summary of the article in 100 words or less:

Buyback activity fell in Singapore last week, with 17 companies posting 48 repurchases worth S$7.3 million. Despite this, buying by directors remained active, with 28 companies recording 57 purchases worth S$1.81 million. Companies such as Soup Restaurant Group, EnGro Corporation, and Global Palm Resources made significant buyback moves, citing lower prices. Insider buys were also reported, with Pavillon Holdings and Plato Capital Limited seeing transactions. The absence of sellers was attributed to the low trading volume, allowing buyers to dominate the market. The buyback activity is consistent with the previous week's trends.

site_title: India eyes huge investment to double its mining output
summary: India aims to attract $22.2 billion in investment over five years to double mining output and cut mineral imports. Mines Minister Piyush Goyal plans to fast-track exploration, including upfront payments for discovered deposits, and invite foreign companies to participate. Despite challenges such as land acquisition and environmental hurdles, Goyal believes there is potential for $50 billion in deposits. The government will also focus on attracting top technology used by overseas companies and respect the environment.

site_title: Gender inequality costs Africa US$95b a year
summary: The UN Development Fund (UNDP) has urged African nations to address the gender gap, which costs an estimated US$95 billion annually in lost economic potential. This gap hinders women's ability to access land, borrow money, and invest in their productivity. The UNDP cited agriculture as an example, where women's lack of access to land and resources leads to reduced productivity. In some nations, such as Rwanda, progress has been made, with 65% of elected MPs being female. The UNDP emphasizes that addressing gender inequality is crucial for economic growth and development.

site_title: Vietnamese President Tran Dai Quang in Singapore for three-day state visit
summary: Vietnamese President Tran Dai Quang arrived in Singapore for a three-day state visit, aimed at strengthening bilateral and business ties. Accompanied by his spouse and a high-level delegation, Quang will meet with Singapore leaders, including Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong and Deputy Prime Minister Teo Chee Hean. The visit highlights the strong relations between the two countries, with Singapore being the third-largest foreign investor in Vietnam and Vietnam's sixth-largest trading partner for Singapore.

site_title: Central bankers seek bold govt measures
summary: Central bankers from the Federal Reserve, Bank of Japan, and European Central Bank called for bold government measures to boost economic growth, citing low growth, low inflation, and low interest rates. They urged policymakers to implement structural changes, such as immigration reform in Japan, and fiscal policies to encourage household and business investment. The bankers warned that a slump in expectations about inflation could hinder their efforts to reach inflation targets and dim prospects worldwide, particularly in Japan and Europe.

site_title: On a roll with a handle on taste receptors
summary: Chef Tim Ross-Watson's new restaurant, Pyxie Moss, offers inventive and sustainable food with a sense of fun and whimsy. The chef's "waste-not-want-not" approach incorporates every last scrap of ingredients, such as fish scales used for shoelaces. Pyxie Moss is now open online for reservations, with a unique approach to reducing food waste.

site_title: Germany's economy minister: US-EU free trade talks have failed
summary: Germany's Economy Minister Sigmar Gabriel stated that US-EU free trade talks, specifically the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP), have failed due to European resistance to American demands. The negotiations, which began three years ago, have stalled over issues such as agriculture, and Gabriel believes that "things are not moving on that front."
