images.alt_text: The US and the EU have been negotiating the TTIP for three years and both sides had sought to conclude talks in 2016 but they have differences over various issues, including agriculture.SOURCE: REUTERS

site_title: Talks on EU-US trade deal have failed: Germany
summary: Germany's Vice-Chancellor Sigmar Gabriel says EU-US trade deal talks have effectively failed due to disagreements over terms and opposition from France and Germany. The Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP) negotiations, which aim to create the world's largest free trade area, are stalled. France's Prime Minister Manuel Valls also expressed doubts about concluding negotiations by the end of 2016. Diplomats suggest talks may be suspended until after US presidential elections and elections in France and Germany.

images.alt_text: Mr Gabriel said "the talks with the US have de facto failed because we Europeans of course must not succumb to American demands"

site_title: Gold pares gains as Fed stirs doubt over rate hike timing
summary: US gold prices trimmed gains after Federal Reserve chair Janet Yellen's comments on interest rate hikes, citing a strengthening case for increases but cautioning on timing. Gold rose 1.5% initially before giving back gains, while the dollar and US stocks fell. Yellen said rate hikes should be gradual, but didn't specify what data the Fed needs to see to raise rates. Gold is sensitive to rising interest rates and a strong dollar.

site_title: Keeping up with disruption
summary: The 2016 National Day Rally in Singapore highlighted the need for the country to stay ahead of disruption in a rapidly changing world. Key takeaways include embracing a culture of innovation, adopting a digital future, and seizing the opportunities of disruption to cement Singapore's position as a stable, trusted, and innovative economic hub. The government and private sector must work together to upskill the workforce, foster a culture of continuous learning, and encourage businesses to take chances and build capabilities to capture new opportunities. Ultimately, Singapore needs to remain resilient, united, and grateful for its blessings to thrive in this uncertain world.

images.alt_text: Loh Boon Chye
Lionel Lim

site_title: Motor racing-Rosberg eases to Belgian GP win
summary: Nico Rosberg won the Belgian Formula One Grand Prix, crossing the finish line 14.1 seconds ahead of Daniel Ricciardo. Lewis Hamilton, who started from the back of the grid due to an engine penalty, finished third. The victory marks Rosberg's first win of the season, while Hamilton remains the world championship leader.

site_title: Crossing the governance chasm: from assessment to performance
summary: Corporate governance rankings are seen as validation of governance policies, but the value of measurement and measurement system is a sticking point. The Singapore Public Utilities Board (PUB) has introduced a corporate governance ranking system, with NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer being 9.8 times oversubscribed. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and the People's Bank of China (PBOC) are set to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance. Meanwhile, OCBC Bank has announced Tan Teck Long as its incoming CEO, replacing its outgoing CEO.

site_title: Returnships: Tech firms offer path back to office
summary: Tech companies are offering returnships, 18-week internships for mid-career professionals who took time off to care for family, to help firms plug their talent pipeline and improve their reputation as inclusive workplaces. Six San Francisco-based tech companies, including GoDaddy and Zendesk, are partnering with non-profit Path Forward to bring in about 20 mid-career professionals. The program aims to combat the stigma around time off and provide a path back to the office. The initiative is expected to help tech companies hire more women and address the industry's leaky pipeline, with high success rates in established programs.

site_title: Top dairy exporter Fonterra struggling amid global dairy glut
summary: Fonterra, New Zealand's top dairy exporter, is struggling due to a global dairy glut and reduced Chinese demand, which has led to a 50% drop in whole milk powder prices over the past three years. The company is facing reduced earnings and a decline in farmer returns, with some farmers switching to competitors. Fonterra is responding by selling assets, cutting jobs, and closing factories to improve efficiency and strengthen its balance sheet. Despite efforts to increase value through consumer and food service businesses, the company remains sensitive to commodity-price variability and faces challenges in extracting more value from its milk.

site_title: PSI in unhealthy range as haze continues to cover Singapore
summary: Air quality in Singapore remained unhealthy on Saturday, with a haze covering the city, prompting the National Environment Agency (NEA) to advise reducing prolonged outdoor physical exertion. The unhealthy range is expected to continue throughout the day.

site_title: UK's May orders Brexit plans from Cabinet ahead of China G-20
summary: UK Prime Minister Theresa May has asked her Cabinet to develop a plan for how their departments can benefit from Britain's exit from the European Union ahead of the G-20 summit in China. The plan is expected to be discussed at a Cabinet meeting at Chequers, with May prioritizing a successful Brexit. The Cabinet is divided on whether to continue operating in the EU single market, with some ministers resisting the idea. Treasury officials and chief Brexit negotiator David Davis will submit papers on the matter, with both advocating for a swift exit from the EU.

images.alt_text: UK Prime Minister Theresa May asked her Cabinet ministers to come up with a blueprint for how their departments may be able to benefit from Britain's exit from the European Union ahead of the Group of 20 leaders' summit in China, according to newspaper reports.

site_title: FBI raids home of ex-College Board official in probe of SAT leak
summary: The FBI raided the home of former College Board executive Manuel Alfaro, who accused the organization of leaking hundreds of SAT questions and falsifying test development processes. The investigation is looking into computer intrusion and theft of confidential information, including test questions and internal emails. Alfaro, who left his job in 2015, had previously contacted state governments and publicly criticized the College Board's testing practices, claiming shortcuts were taken in the test development process. The College Board has denied the allegations, calling them "patently false."

site_title: Join legal profession if you believe in its ideals, says CJ Menon
summary: Singapore's Chief Justice Sundaresh Menon has warned aspiring lawyers to join the profession if they genuinely believe in its ideals of justice and service, rather than for financial rewards. With a record 535 new lawyers admitted last year, the number of new entrants has doubled in five years, leading to an oversupply of young lawyers. To address this issue, Menon has set up a committee to review the training contract system, explore regulating supervised training, and consider alternative structures for those not retained. He also highlighted the need for law firms to prioritize the genuine nurturing of young talent and adapt to the impact of new technologies on the profession.

site_title: Hong Kong's first suspected Zika case tests negative
summary: Hong Kong's first suspected Zika patient, a 38-year-old woman who traveled to the Caribbean, has tested negative for the virus after being discharged from hospital. The woman, who experienced joint pain and red eyes, had been admitted after spending two weeks in the Caribbean. The Zika virus has been linked to severe birth defects and has spread across the Americas, with over 1,800 cases of microcephaly reported in Brazil.

site_title: Fight over Viacom control ends after granddaughter backs down
summary: A months-old battle over Viacom control has ended after the granddaughter of billionaire Sumner Redstone agreed not to oppose her grandfather's decision to resolve lawsuits. The decision allows a settlement to proceed, removing a key obstacle. Judge George Phelan described the agreement as "reasonable and optimal." The resolution also paves the way for a meeting between Mr. Redstone and his granddaughter, Keryn Redstone, who has challenged his competency in a Massachusetts court fight.

site_title: US dollar rises following Yellen remarks on rate hikes
summary: US Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen hinted at a near-term interest rate increase, strengthening the case for a rate hike. The US dollar rose against the euro, yen, and British pound, reaching 101.77 yen and US$1.1195 euro. The US Dollar Index posted its widest daily trading range of the week. US central bankers will meet three times before the end of the year.

site_title: Tapping high-performing markets
summary: Singtel has enhanced its deemed stakes in top Indian and Thai telcos, Advanced Info Services (AIS) and Bharti Airtel, through share purchases from Temasek Holdings, gaining access to high-performing markets. The move aims to tap into rapidly growing smartphone penetration and mobile data adoption in Asia and Africa. CEO Chua Sock Koong believes the deal will allow Singtel to capitalize on emerging trends, including data growth and digitalization, and expand its presence in the Singapore domestic market, where it faces competition from established players.

site_title: 41 cases of locally-transmitted Zika confirmed in Aljunied Crescent cluster, 34 fully recovered
summary: The Ministry of Health (MOH) in Singapore has confirmed 41 cases of locally-transmitted Zika, all residents or workers in the Aljunied Crescent and Sims Drive area. Out of 124 tested, 78 have tested negative, and the remaining five cases are still pending. 34 of the confirmed cases have recovered. The confirmed cases include 36 foreign construction workers. The National Environment Agency is investigating the source of the outbreak.

site_title: The mental side
summary: There is no article provided to summarize. The given text appears to be a collection of news headlines from various sources.

site_title: Virgin boss injured in bike accident in Caribbean
summary: British billionaire Richard Branson injured his cheek and tore some ligaments in a biking accident on Virgin Gorda in the British Virgin Islands. The 66-year-old Virgin boss, who was cycling with his children, hit a bump on a road and was hurled over the handlebars. Branson said he thought he was going to die and that the helmet saved his life. He will still participate in the upcoming Virgin Strive Challenge despite the injury. Branson has a history of daredevil stunts and previous close calls, including a 1998 balloon accident and a 2014 space tourism setback.

site_title: Sporting connections
summary: SunMoon Food Company Limited, a consumer-focused distributor and marketer, collaborates to develop innovative and nutritious food products for health-conscious global consumers. However, the article does not provide further information about the company or its products.

site_title: Carro simplifies car buying, selling
summary: Carro, a homegrown car portal, aims to simplify car buying and selling by utilizing a proprietary machine-learning algorithm and a 120-point inspection process. The platform, which has raised over $6 million in less than a year, seeks to accelerate consumer-to-consumer sales in the pre-owned car market. By addressing concerns around vehicle authenticity and pricing, Carro hopes to disrupt the traditional dealership-dominated industry.

site_title: Jeepers creepers
summary: There is no article about "Jeepers creepers" in the provided content. The article appears to be a collection of news summaries from various dates, but none of them match the title "Jeepers creepers".

site_title: UN council condemns North Korea missile launches, vows new measures
summary: The UN Security Council has condemned North Korea's test-firing of ballistic missiles, agreeing to take "significant measures" in response. The 15-member council issued a unanimous statement, backed by China, calling for continued monitoring and further action. The statement did not elaborate on the specifics of the measures. The condemnation comes after a series of missile launches, with the council urging restraint from the North Korean regime.

images.alt_text: The UN Security Council on Friday strongly condemned North Korea for test-firing ballistic missiles and agreed to take "significant measures" in response the latest series of launches.

site_title: Oil prices edge up but Opec giants downplay output limits
summary: Oil prices edged up on Friday, with US benchmark West Texas Intermediate rising 31 cents to $47.64 a barrel and Brent North Sea crude increasing 25 cents to $49.92 a barrel. However, Opec giants, including Saudi Arabia and Iran, downplayed the possibility of cutting output, citing concerns over restoring lost market share and the need for a production freeze. This has rekindled concerns over the ongoing oversupply, which has hammered the crude market for over two years.

site_title: Bangladesh police kill suspected cafe attack mastermind
summary: Bangladesh police killed three suspected Islamist extremists, including Tamim Chowdhury, the mastermind of the July 1 cafe attack that killed 22 hostages, mostly foreigners. Chowdhury, 30, a Bangladeshi-Canadian citizen, was leading a faction of the JMB militant group. The operation, which lasted an hour, involved a gun battle and the use of grenades and AK 22 rifles. Chowdhury's body was identified by police, who had offered a 2 million taka reward for his capture. The killings bring the death toll of suspected militants in Bangladesh to 11 since the cafe attack.

site_title: Facebook makes trending news feature more automated
summary: Facebook is further automating its "trending" stories feature, relying more on an algorithm to prevent personal bias from influencing the highlighted stories. The feature, which previously required human input, will now list topics and the number of people talking about them, with automatically selected original news stories available upon hover. The move comes after an internal investigation found no evidence of systematic bias in the selection of stories, and Facebook has made changes to ensure real-world news and not internet trends are featured.

site_title: Japan housing market a rare bright spot amid stalling growth
summary: Japan's housing market experienced its fastest residential investment growth in five years, with a 5% increase in April-June. This growth, driven by low interest rates, is expected to continue and support consumer spending and employment. Rising property prices are also boosting demand for durable goods, potentially helping to break Japan's deflationary mentality. Related industries, such as construction, retail, and home electronics, are expected to benefit from the housing market's growth.

site_title: Spotify said to retaliate against Apple's exclusive artists
summary: Spotify has reportedly retaliated against artists who signed exclusive deals with Apple Music by making their songs harder to find on the platform. Artists who gave Apple Music new music exclusives have been told their tracks won't be featured on Spotify playlists, and their songs are buried in search rankings. Spotify denies altering search rankings, but this strategy has been ongoing for about a year. The move comes as Spotify is in the midst of renegotiating licensing contracts with record labels and prepares for an initial public offering.

site_title: Italy mourns quake dead as hope for survivors wanes
summary: Italy mourns the deaths of at least 281 people from a devastating earthquake that struck central Italy, with hopes of finding more survivors waning. The quake, which had a magnitude of 6.0-6.2, has left 388 injured and destroyed hundreds of old buildings across dozens of tiny communities. The country has declared a state of emergency, and Prime Minister Matteo Renzi has released €50 million in emergency aid. As the death toll rises, Italy prepares for an emotionally charged day of mourning, with funerals and funeral services scheduled for Saturday.

site_title: US: Wall Street slips in wake of comments by top Fed officials
summary: US stocks slipped on Friday after a volatile session, with the S&P 500 rising 0.7% before falling 0.6% as investors weighed the timing of a potential interest rate hike. Fed Chair Janet Yellen said the case for a rate hike had strengthened, but did not indicate when the Fed would act. Fed Vice Chair Stanley Fischer's comments raised the possibility of a rate hike as soon as next month, increasing the perceived chances of a September hike to 36%.

site_title: Fiat chief rejects complaints over US sales data
summary: Fiat Chrysler Automobiles (FCA) CEO Sergio Marchionne rejected allegations of falsifying US sales data, calling them "meritless" and saying the company's financial reports are "totally accurate." The allegations followed a restatement of unit sales for the past five years after a dealer group sued over sales reporting practices. Marchionne cooperated with the Securities and Exchange Commission and Justice Department, and denied any intent to deceive. FCA is also exploring selling its component unit Magneti Marelli to South Korea's Samsung.

site_title: Declining inventories curb Q2 growth; consumption surges
summary: US economic growth in Q2 was slower than initially thought, expanding at a 1.1% annual rate, down from 1.2% in the previous estimate. This was due to declining inventories and weak spending by state and local governments, offset by a surge in consumer spending. The economy's growth has struggled since 2015, and while a buoyant labour market may support consumer spending, weak corporate profits and low inflation may limit growth. The Federal Reserve is expected to raise interest rates again in December.

site_title: Amazon dabbling with 30-hour work weeks: report
summary: Amazon is reportedly testing a 30-hour work week for select teams, including managers, with the same benefits as full-time employees but reduced pay. The initiative, aimed at its diverse workforce, aims to create a work environment that balances success and career growth. The program will involve a handful of small teams involved in designing technical systems, and not the entire company. Amazon has faced criticism for its working conditions, particularly at fulfillment centers, and this experiment is seen as a potential solution.

site_title: Australian PM urges divided Senate to tackle budget deficit
summary: Australian Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull urged the divided Senate to support his economic reform agenda to cut the country's high debt levels, which are projected to reach A$37.1 billion. With a razor-thin majority, Turnbull depends on opposition support to address the budget deficit. Australia, with a triple-A credit rating, risks downgrade if the deficit is not addressed, which could harm confidence and lead to downgrades for banks and companies. The government aims to return the books to balance by 2020/21, with a projected budget surplus by 2019/20.

site_title: Japan takes aid show to Africa, in China's shadow
summary: Japan hosts the Tokyo International Conference on African Development (Ticad) in Kenya for the first time, aiming to promote high-quality aid and investment over quantity, rivaling China's influence. Prime Minister Shinzo Abe will meet with African leaders, unveiling projects in healthcare and industrialization. Japan's participation seeks to bolster its clout in Africa, with the country's trade with the continent valued at around $24 billion, compared to China's $179 billion. The conference aims to boost two-way trade and address security concerns, following a 2013 attack on a Japanese gas plant in Algeria.

images.alt_text: Japan takes its aid and trade show to Africa on Saturday, opening a huge two-day development conference in Kenya, hoping that quality will trump quantity in the battle for influence against cash-rich China.

site_title: Kuok scion picks music over palm oil
summary: Kuok Meng Ru, the third child of a billionaire agri-business tycoon, has chosen a career in music over the family business, according to a recent report. Kuok was sent to a British boarding school at 10 and later graduated from Cambridge University with a degree in mathematics. Despite his privileged upbringing, Kuok has pursued a path that differs from his family's business interests.

site_title: Brazil police urge graft charges against ex-leader Lula
summary: Brazilian police recommended corruption charges against former president Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva in a probe into the embezzlement scheme at Petrobras. The decision is the latest blow to Lula and his suspended successor Dilma Rousseff as their Workers' Party crumbles. Lula's lawyer branded the move as politically motivated.

site_title: Canada PM Trudeau to mount charm offensive in China: officials
summary: Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau will embark on a charm offensive in China, visiting Beijing, Shanghai, and Hong Kong from August 30 to September 6 to bolster trade and diplomatic ties. Trudeau will meet with Chinese President Xi Jinping, women entrepreneurs, and basketball star Yao Ming, and will also attend a Group of 20 economic summit in Hangzhou. The trip aims to address trade irritants, including restrictions on Canadian oil-sand leases and canola imports, and to reset the relationship. Trudeau seeks cooperation on climate change, tourism, and investments in Canada.

site_title: Watch this
summary: A fashion designer showcases their style, stating it is inspired by Japanese influences with clean lines and simple accessories. Asean agrees that the Myanmar election is not a priority, while a low-profile property trust invests in a data center. US weekly jobless claims drop unexpectedly, and China urges Southeast Asia to support openness amidst US tariffs. Chinese property shares rise on unverified reports of a sector revival meeting. Reliance Jio delays its India IPO beyond this year, and China introduces new steps to aid employment amid trade tensions.

site_title: Massages for pups as Tel Aviv celebrates Dog Day
summary: Tel Aviv celebrated its first Dog Day festival, where hundreds of dogs and their owners participated in activities such as massages, joint portraits, and lectures on "dog emotions". The city, known for being one of the most dog-friendly in the world, boasts over 60 dog parks and 24/7 services for strays. Residents and event organizers emphasized the importance of community and bonding between dogs and their owners, with the city's high dog-to-resident ratio of one for every 17 residents. The festival highlighted Tel Aviv's unique approach to canine care and socialization.

site_title: Europe: Shares rise as Yellen keeps options open
summary: European shares rose 0.5% on Friday, driven by Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen's cautious comments on a possible interest rate hike. The pan-European Stoxx 600 index gained 0.1% before Yellen's comments, with metal prices and digital security firm Gemalto seeing significant gains. However, shares in Vivendi fell 1.7% due to weaker-than-expected core profits. Yellen reiterated that future rate hikes should be "gradual," suggesting a more cautious approach than expected.

site_title: Maybank expanding its digital presence across the region
summary: Maybank has partnered with Samsung Pay in Singapore, allowing its 550,000 cardholders to make transactions at merchant locations using mobile wallets. The service will be available on five Samsung Galaxy smartphones starting August 31. The bank aims to register 10,000 cards within the next 12 months and 20,000 by the second year. Maybank also plans to integrate iris scanning as a payment authentication method on the Galaxy Note 7 later this quarter. This move is part of the bank's digital roadmap to strengthen its presence in the region and become the top community bank in Asean.

site_title: Philippine central bank says does not have to move in sync with Fed
summary: The Philippine central bank's governor, Amando Tetangco, stated that the bank's policy decisions do not have to move in sync with the US Federal Reserve's actions. Tetangco reiterated that the country's inflation outlook remains manageable, with forecasted August inflation between 1.6-2.4%. The central bank has not changed its monetary policy stance since a 25 basis point rate hike in 2014, citing strong growth and low inflation. Tetangco emphasized the bank's ability to monitor and adjust its stance as needed to address potential price and demand dynamics.

site_title: Croesus Retail Trust Q4 DPU rises to 1.7 cents
summary: Croesus Retail Trust reported a 21.8% decline in net profit to 4.43 billion yen in Q4, but a 1.7 cent increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.7 Singapore cents. The trust's gross revenue rose 34.5% year-over-year to 2.68 billion yen, driven by contributions from recent acquisitions. The trust's portfolio comprises 11 retail properties in Japan, with a total asset value of 112.64 billion yen and an average occupancy rate of 98.1%.

images.alt_text: NEW ACQUISITION: Feeeal Asahikawa mall is one of four yield-accretive retail assets which the trust acquired in Japan in FY16

site_title: Play it
summary: The Audi quattro Cup is celebrating its 25th anniversary in a modified foursomes format, combining skill and strategy. The tournament features two-person teams, where both players tee off, choose the best drive, and play alternate shot until the ball is holed. This format emphasizes the importance of teamwork and strategy in golf.

site_title: Time to fly flag high
summary: Singaporean businessman Melvin Choo, 46, is set to represent the Republic in golf after retiring from racing in 2012. Choo, a low-profile property trust executive, is seen as a potential candidate to fly the flag high in the sport.

site_title: Solid supporters, one and all
summary: Teams Edge Golf and Team Boustead are tied for the top spot in the BT Corporate Golf League after the fourth round, with 423 points each. A four-way tie for second place has emerged among Team SunMoon, Bank of Singapore, Emerio, and The Crane Boomers, all with 414 points. The fifth round will take place on August 30 at Singapore Island Country Club's New Course.

TEAM KPMG From left: Richard Tock, Karen Lee, Philip Lee and Steven Lim

site_title: Design home-base
summary: Ikea's Young Designer Award showcased innovative designs for time-strapped homemakers. Anthony Yu, 24, created Fläckfri, a hanging rack for kitchen rags that promotes hygiene and air circulation. Melody Koh, 19, designed Origami-san, a space-saving pot organizer. Kevin Chiam, 24, developed Runda, an improved Lazy Susan with a communal spirit. The designs, along with others, were chosen for their practical solutions to real-life needs and innovative approaches to everyday problems. The award aims to provide a platform for budding young local design students to showcase their talents and share Ikea's global design expertise.

site_title: HDR for video is the all-new TV format
summary: High Dynamic Range (HDR) video is a new TV format that highlights details in brightness and darkness, offering more realistic colors and contrast. Two formats, HDR10 and Dolby Vision, are available, with HDR10 being open-source and widely adopted, while Dolby Vision is proprietary and requires a special processor. Netflix is offering both formats, with some content available in HDR, and subscribers need to be signed up for the highest tier to access HDR content. Playback of HDR content is done by default on compatible TVs, with HDR icons indicating the format.

site_title: MAS must take the lead and end private banking rebates
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority (MAS) is reviewing the practice of offering private banking rebates to wealth managers for selling high-risk bonds to clients. The rebates can range from 0.1% to 1% of the client's investment, often benefiting high net worth individuals. MAS should clarify this practice and consider ending the system to reduce conflict of interests, similar to how US authorities curbed mortgage brokers' incentives before the sub-prime crisis.

site_title: Silverlake's Q4 profit up 3% on revenue growth
summary: Silverlake Axis Limited reported a 3% increase in net profit to RM77.2 million in its fourth quarter, driven by 32% revenue growth. Higher contributions from all segments except software project services contributed to the revenue rise. Administrative costs increased by 51%, and other income dropped by 69%. The company declared a final dividend of 1 Singapore cent per share, down from 1.2 cents in the previous year. Silverlake plans to focus on expanding market shares and evaluating acquisition opportunities.

site_title: Testing for heart disease
summary: Computed Tomography Angiogram (CTA) is considered the single best non-invasive test for diagnosing heart disease, according to a study published in the Circulation journal in 2016. CTA provides direct visualization of heart arteries, allowing doctors to make better diagnostic decisions and reduce the need for expensive invasive tests. Studies such as PROMISE, SCOT-HEART, and PLATFORM demonstrated that CTA is more accurate than stress testing and functional testing, and can help patients with chest pain and risk factors for heart disease avoid unnecessary invasive tests and take proactive preventive measures.

site_title: Yellen says rate-hike case 'has strengthened in recent months'
summary: Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen stated that the case for raising interest rates has strengthened as the US economy approaches the central bank's goals of full employment and stable prices. The economy is "nearing" these goals, according to Yellen, who also noted that gradual increases in the federal funds rate will be appropriate over time to achieve and sustain employment and inflation near the Fed's statutory objectives. This comes amid a reassessment of monetary policies globally, with central banks considering lower peaks in policy interest rates due to ageing populations and declining productivity.

site_title: AGV gains 9% on debut, continues Catalist's string of splashy entrances
summary: AGV Group, a corrosion protection specialist, made its Catalist debut with a 9.1% gain, ending at 24 Singapore cents. The company's IPO offered 26.92 million shares at 22 Singapore cents, with 7.9 million shares changing hands on the first day. This marks the latest in a string of positive debuts for new Singapore Exchange-listed companies, with 11 out of 16 IPOs this year rising above their IPO prices.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Wing Tai Holdings' fully-owned subsidiary Wing Tai (China) Investment sold its 40% stake in Optima Investment & Development to Singbridge Guangzhou for S$89.3 million, ceasing Optima as a joint venture company.

site_title: YZJ to cut 2,000 more jobs
summary: Chinese shipbuilder Yangzijiang Shipbuilding (YZJ) plans to cut 2,000 more jobs, or 10% of its workforce, to reduce overheads amid slowing shipbuilding orders. The company has already cut 4,000 jobs and reduced second-quarter shipbuilding costs to 1.38 billion yuan (S$281 million). YZJ secured US$600 million worth of newbuilding orders, below its annual target, and has diversified revenue streams. The shipbuilding industry remains weak, with global outstanding shipbuilding orders at their lowest level since June 2013.

site_title: ACING ASIA
summary: Deloitte Southeast Asia CEO Philip Yuen assumes leadership of the 25-office, 270-partner, and 7,300-professional firm, tasked with harnessing the region's massive growth potential. Yuen, 52, brings 31 years of experience, including six years as CEO of Deloitte Singapore, and a vision for the firm's success. He sees the Asean Economic Community's integration by 2025 as a key opportunity, citing the region's 600 million population, growing middle class, and young population as drivers of growth. Yuen aims to unlock synergies from the firm's advisory and consulting base, invest in technology, and upskill professionals to address challenges posed by the digital age.

images.alt_text: 'The perennial problem that we've faced so far will still be there - the challenge of maintaining gross margins. What's key is to work on productivity, be it through technology, offshoring (of certain services), etc. We need to create more value in our services, so that clients and customers will perceive the greater value and will pay.'

site_title: S'pore workplace stress on the rise: survey
summary: A survey by Roffey Park found that Singapore office workers face high levels of stress, with 52% of respondents citing increased stress levels over the past six months. Top stressors include office politics (40%), workload (35%), and lack of support (35%). Long working hours and unproductive meetings also contribute to stress. The survey suggests that a culture of open challenge and generous support can help alleviate stress, and that leaders must focus on developing interpersonal skills to improve productivity.

site_title: China's Wanda makes entertainment tracks
summary: Wanda, a Chinese property tycoon, is expanding into the entertainment industry, set to become the largest cinema operator with over 13,000 screens on four continents. The company's push into movies was accidental, driven by its need to operate movie theaters at shopping malls. Wanda's Dalian Wanda Group controls Hollywood studio Legendary Pictures and US cinema chain AMC Entertainment Holdings.

site_title: Worst may be over for Norway's oil industry: agency chief
summary: Norway's oil industry may be nearing the end of a two-year crisis, with companies increasing investment and completing development plans. The Norwegian Petroleum Directorate's head, Bente Nyland, cited improved talks with oil companies and an increased willingness to complete projects. Despite challenges, the industry's output is expected to remain stable, with production forecasted to reach 3.65 million barrels of oil equivalent per day by 2020. The agency is pushing for oil firms to add extra capacity to fields to secure future production, particularly for the Johan Sverdrup field, set to account for 25% of Norway's petroleum output.

site_title: Let's do brunch
summary: Brunch culture has grown in popularity in Singapore, with more restaurants introducing their own menus to attract weekend crowds. Japanese restaurant Kinki has launched a Saturday Bottomless Brunch, featuring an a la carte buffet and free-flow sake, in an effort to boost traffic on weekends. The move comes after the restaurant found it challenging to attract customers on weekends due to its location near the Central Business District. This trend is expected to continue, with more eateries joining the brunch scene.

site_title: Surprise 3.6% fall in Singapore's July factory output
summary: Singapore's manufacturing output unexpectedly declined 3.6% year-over-year in July, reversing four consecutive months of expansion. The decline was attributed to broad-based contractions in all clusters except electronics, which saw a 16.2% increase. The weak showing prompted economists to warn of downside risks to Q3 GDP growth and prompted at least one bank to lower its full-year industrial production growth forecast to 1%.

site_title: SPH acquires golf media company
summary: SPH, a Singapore-based media company, has completed the acquisition of Pacom Media Pte Ltd, a golf media company. The assets, including Golf Vacations magazine and media representation rights, are now part of SPH's wholly owned subsidiary, SPH Pacom Pte Ltd. The acquisition aims to expand SPH Golf's revenue streams and grow its presence in the local golf market, both in Singapore and the region. This move complements SPH's English/Malay/Tamil Media Group and will provide a foothold for the company to enter golf business adjacencies.

site_title: Unmistakably Mustang
summary: The Ford Mustang is now available in right-hand-drive from the factory, marking a significant milestone for the iconic American car. First introduced in 1964, the Mustang was previously only available in left-hand-drive, sparking a new segment in the automotive industry.

site_title: Is this the top-secret KFC recipe?
summary: KFC's closely guarded original fried chicken recipe, considered one of the world's biggest trade secrets, may have been accidentally revealed. A reporter, Jay Jones, claimed to have obtained a recipe from Joe Ledington, a nephew of the recipe's creator, Harland Sanders. The recipe, which includes 11 spices, was allegedly written by Sanders' second wife, Claudia, and stored in a family scrapbook. However, KFC denies the authenticity of the recipe, stating that it was incorrect and that many previous claims have been inaccurate.

site_title: STI down on wispy volume as market awaits Yellen
summary: Singapore shares closed lower on Friday, down 19.28 points at 2,857.65, due to weak volume ahead of US Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen's key speech. Investors took profits on Singapore banks, Singtel, and S-Reits, with only Ascendas Reit rising. Analysts expect Yellen to take a cautious stance on monetary policy, with no strong signal of an imminent rate hike, and some predicting a potential rate hike at the September FOMC meeting.

site_title: Friends, colleagues celebrate the life of an 'extraordinary' man
summary: Former Singapore President SR Nathan, known for his thoughtful handwritten notes, passed away. Friends and colleagues praised his sincerity and warmth in his letters, recalling his love of good food and appreciation for the company of others. The two-hour state funeral service was attended by prominent figures, including Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong, who shared anecdotes about Nathan's love of writing letters and his kind nature.

site_title: A grand send-off for one of Singapore's greatest sons
summary: Singapore bid farewell to its sixth and longest-serving president, SR Nathan, with a grand state funeral service. The 92-year-old statesman, known as a "super ambassador" and "loyal servant" to the country, passed away peacefully four days prior. Seven eulogies were delivered by prominent figures, including Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong, who praised Mr Nathan's contributions to the nation and his 73-year marriage to his wife, Urmila. The service was attended by thousands of people, including foreign leaders, who paid their respects to Mr Nathan, who was laid to rest at Mandai Crematorium and Columbarium.

site_title: Business receipts for services industries up marginally in Q2 (Amended)
summary: Business receipts for services industries in Singapore increased 0.4% year-on-year in Q2, with a 1.1% quarterly gain. Categories such as health and social services, education, and information & communications services showed growth, while transport & storage and recreation & personal services declined. The Business Receipts Index measures short-term changes in business receipts and excludes wholesale & retail trade and accommodation & food services. The quarterly gain is a reversal of the 3.9% decline in Q1.

images.alt_text: Business receipts for the services industry in Singapore edged up 0.4 per cent year-on- year in the second quarter but were up 1.1 per cent quarter-on- quarter.

site_title: China's most risky short goes from first to worst
summary: China's Yirendai Ltd, the nation's only publicly-traded peer-to-peer lender, has seen a 35% drop in US trading over the past four days, reversing its 953% rally since mid-February. Annualized borrowing rates for Yirendai shares jumped to 40%, the highest among big Chinese companies. The stock's sudden reversal has raised questions about the company's business model and the impact of new regulations. While some attribute the surge to a jump in earnings, others blame an undisclosed employee stock-buying program by Yirendai's parent company.

site_title: India's forgotten 8% yielding bonds seen luring foreigners back
summary: Foreign investor holdings of Indian corporate bonds have hit a 19-month low, with 65% of their US$51 billion cap allocated, down from 73% at the start of the year. Despite India's world-beating economic growth and yields close to 8%, foreign investors are drawn to the country due to negative interest rates globally. India's US$2 trillion economy has seen improved growth, and reforms such as the goods-and-services tax and appointment of deputy governor Urijit Patel are seen as positive structural reforms, attracting foreign investment.

site_title: Putting country before self, 'he gave his best years and more' to S'pore: PM Lee
summary: Former Singapore President SR Nathan, who died at 92, was remembered by Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong for his tireless dedication to the country. Nathan served in various fields, including diplomacy, journalism, and academia, and was known for his "never-give-up" attitude. Lee praised Nathan's commitment to Singapore, saying he "put country before self" and inspired Singaporeans to do the same. Nathan's legacy includes securing the freedom of hostages and defending Singapore's stance on various issues, and he remains an influential figure in Singapore's nation-building efforts.

site_title: Valley of the East - Singapore or HK? (Amended)
summary: Singapore and Hong Kong are emerging as key hubs for fintech innovation, with both cities boasting vibrant ecosystems and a range of initiatives to foster growth. Singapore's Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has set up a "Smart Financial Centre" vision, while Hong Kong's institutions are catching up with not-for-profits and partnerships with stakeholders. Both cities have strong regulatory frameworks, with Singapore's "regulatory sandbox" and Hong Kong's laissez-faire approach offering different advantages. The availability of talent and funding is comparable, but Singapore's predisposition to fintech growth gives it an edge. It's premature to declare a winner, with healthy competition driving innovation and empowering communities.

site_title: Samsung slays with its curves
summary: Samsung's new 4K Curved Smart TV, KS9000 Series 9, boasts a 1,000 nits edge LED display, the first to achieve this brightness level, making it compatible with HDR10 content. The TV features quantum dot LED technology, offering improved color and black levels. It supports 4K and HDR content, including Netflix's HDR10, but requires an expensive subscription tier. The TV's curved display and sleek design set it apart, but its price, starting at S$7,199, is competitive with other high-end TVs.

images.alt_text: BIG-SCREEN OUTING: With Samsung's support for ultra-high definition 4K and HDR, shows such as Netflix's Marco Polo offer a rich vibrancy one usually finds only on cinema screens.
BIG-SCREEN OUTING: With Samsung's support for ultra-high definition 4K and HDR, shows such as Netflix's Marco Polo offer a rich vibrancy one usually finds only on cinema screens.

site_title: LG leads the charge in high-tech TVs
summary: LG's Signature G6 OLED TV is a standout product with a 2.57mm thick display, almost as thin as three credit cards. The 65-inch screen seamlessly blends into its surroundings when perpendicular to the viewer, but becomes a prominent feature when viewed from an angle. This technology showcases the latest advancements in high-tech TVs, offering a unique viewing experience for enthusiasts.

images.alt_text: LG SIGNATURE STYLE: Even when switched off, the 2.57mm thick display on the 65-inch review set, which is roughly the thickness of three credit cards, is a wonder to behold.

site_title: VW reaches accord with US dealers to cover losses from diesel-cheating scheme
summary: Volkswagen has agreed to pay $652 to 652 US car dealerships for losses from the diesel-cheating scheme, affecting over half a million cars. The deal covers used vehicles with unfixable engines and provides additional benefits. The company faces a $14.7 billion agreement with car owners and regulators to buy back or fix 480,000 Volkswagens with two-litre engines, and is on the hook for $603 million to 44 states. A settlement for three-litre engine models, including the Touareg and Porsche Cayenne, is pending, with a plan due by October 24.

site_title: MTV awards to feature cutting-edge videos
summary: The MTV Video Music Awards (VMAs) may return to its roots as a celebration of music videos, rather than a platform for provocation and controversy. This year's nominees, including Beyoncé's "Formation," Drake's "Hotline Bling," and Justin Bieber's "Sorry," showcase state-of-the-art content, concept, and delivery. The awards have the opportunity to reframe music video as a stand-alone art form, particularly with the rise of YouTube and the increasing importance of video in the music industry. The VMAs could once again serve as a showcase for innovative music video artistry, reminiscent of the 1980s and 90s golden era of MTV.

site_title: Apollo agrees to buy Cloud Seller Rackspace for $4.3b
summary: Apollo Global Management agreed to buy cloud-services company Rackspace for $4.3 billion in an all-cash transaction. The deal, expected to be completed in the fourth quarter, will give Rackspace the time and space to transition its IT operations to larger competitors' servers. As a private company, Rackspace will have more flexibility to manage its business for long-term growth and enhance product offerings. The deal represents a 38% premium to Rackspace's closing price before the announcement.

site_title: Moving forward
summary: Singapore's fitness industry is experiencing a shift, with boutique studios emerging to stand out from the competition. Equilibre Pilates Studio, founded by Susan Su-Lengowski, offers personalized instruction and small class sizes, focusing on long-term benefits and injury prevention. GuavaLabs, a pop-up studio by fitness subscription company GuavaPass, offers a wide range of classes and a holistic approach, aiming to curate classes based on member demand. Capital Tower Sports Performance, a rebranded Fitness First location, focuses on improving performance in extracurricular activities, incorporating intrinsic motivation components such as competence, autonomy, and social relatedness.

site_title: Training with D.J.
summary: Training with D.J. Johnson aimed to build strength and commit to winning major championships. Diovisalvi recalled a conversation with Johnson about his goals. No specific events or conclusions are mentioned in the provided article.

site_title: Opening Singapore's doors to the world
summary: Singapore is embracing the sharing economy through home sharing, allowing locals to rent out their homes to short-term visitors. This trend is expected to boost tourism and local businesses, with 97% of accommodation costs staying in the local economy. A recent poll found 72% of Singaporeans support new rules allowing home sharing, and the government is working with Airbnb to establish clear and simple regulations. This approach aims to promote trust and safety, while allowing Singapore to capitalize on its unique housing market and cultural heritage.

site_title: Mylan offers discounts on EpiPen amid criticism
summary: Mylan, a pharmaceutical company, has announced it will reduce out-of-pocket costs for its EpiPen allergy injection by increasing the maximum copay assistance program to $300, up from $100, for patients who pay in cash or with commercial health insurance. The list price of the drug remains unchanged. This move comes amid criticism over the product's rapidly escalating price, which has sparked outrage from lawmakers and the public.

site_title: Gold believers losing faith in mining companies
summary: Investors are losing faith in gold mining companies as their shares have risen significantly, despite remaining bullish on the outlook for gold. Many funds, including those managed by George Soros, have sold shares in companies like Barrick Gold and Newmont Mining, while retaining or expanding holdings in physical gold. Despite this, analysts predict that bullion could rally to $1,500 an ounce next year, driven by low interest rates and sluggish global growth.

site_title: UK economy escapes Brexit blow, for now
summary: The UK economy has shown resilience in the aftermath of the Brexit vote, with retail sales reversing a post-vote slump and unemployment benefit claims falling unexpectedly in July. Despite this, economists caution that the long-term outlook remains uncertain, citing concerns over investment, inventory levels, and construction. The Bank of England's interest rate cut has benefited some mortgage borrowers, but prices and turnover in the housing market are expected to be negatively impacted. Prime Minister Theresa May has delayed triggering Article 50, and investors are cautiously optimistic about the economy's future, but most economists remain concerned about the potential for a recession.

site_title: Prada predicts return to growth in 2017 after H1 profits slump
summary: Italian luxury goods maker Prada predicts a return to sales and profit growth in 2017 after a 25% drop in first-half earnings and net profit. The company attributes growth to improved sales trends in China, with Chairman Carlo Mazzi stating that 2016 is a "turning point" for the group's recovery. This marks the first time Prada's sales have grown on a like-for-like basis since 2014.

site_title: Mortgage bonds continue to punish investors
summary: A New York City property that was touted as a future home for an iconic Apple store is stuck in a mortgage bond facing hundreds of millions of dollars in unpaid debt. The $100 million mortgage, issued by Wachovia Securities, remains unpaid, and investors are at risk of significant losses. The property, 21-25 West 34th Street, was originally valued at $125 million but is now estimated to be worth $75-85 million. The deal, which included 149 commercial mortgages, is a reminder of how pre-crash securitisations continue to punish investors a decade later.

site_title: AirAsia values its leasing arm at RM4.1b
summary: AirAsia values its leasing arm Asia Aviation Capital (AAC) at RM4.1 billion, aiming to attract an equity investor by end-2016. The airline plans to expand AAC's portfolio to 200 aircraft in five years, up from 55 currently. A successful deal will help AirAsia bolster its finances and cut debt, following a rough patch since the 2014 Indonesia crash and accounting issues. Analysts expect the airline's 2016 net income to rise by 59% this year, driven by its cost advantage and growing market value.

site_title: Lloyd CEO says planned UASC merger benefits to show in 2017
summary: Hapag-Lloyd CEO Rolf Habben Jansen expects the planned merger with UASC to yield $400 million in annual synergies by 2019, with the company aiming to realize the full benefits from 2019. The merger, signed in July, aims to increase the company's scale and reduce costs as the global shipping market faces a downturn. The deal will create the world's fifth-largest shipping company. Habben Jansen stated that the company plans to permanently lower costs by 2019.

site_title: US: Wall St rises as Yellen says case for rate hike stronger
summary: US stocks rose on Friday as Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen stated the case for interest rate hikes has strengthened, despite no specific timeline for rate hikes. The Dow Jones Industrial Average increased 0.57%, and the S&P 500 rose 0.64%. Financials sector led the gains, with major banks such as Bank of America and JPMorgan rising 0.9-2%. Yellen's comments set the stage for potential rate hikes in September or November, but no specific timeline was provided.

site_title: Wing Tai unit sells interest in joint venture company for S$89.3m
summary: Wing Tai Holdings' subsidiary, Wing Tai (China) Investment, sold its 40% interest in joint venture company Optima Investment & Development to Singbridge Guangzhou for S$89.3 million. Following the disposal, Optima has ceased to be a joint venture company of Wing Tai.

images.alt_text: WING Tai Holdings said on Friday that its fully owned subsidiary Wing Tai (China) Investment has disposed of its 40 per cent interest in the issued share capital of Optima Investment & Development to Singbridge Guangzhou for a cash consideration of S$89.3 million.

site_title: UK's Restaurant Group to sell or close 33 outlets
summary: Restaurant Group, the UK operator of Frankie and Benny's, announced plans to sell or close 33 underperforming outlets as part of a strategic review following two profit warnings and CEO/CFO departures. The company aims to reprice and add popular dishes to menus, and will take an exceptional charge of £59.1 million for the closures. Despite a 4.4% operating profit decline, the company maintains its full-year profit forecast, with shares rising 3.7% following the announcement.

site_title: Malaysia: Stocks end higher
summary: Malaysian shares ended higher on Friday, with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index gaining 2.79 points to 1,683.090. The index saw 1.49 billion lots traded, with 441 gainers outnumbering 360 losers.

site_title: Golf and the Olympics not yet a sweet symphony
summary: Golf made its Olympic debut at the 2016 Rio Games, with Justin Rose and Park Inbee claiming gold medals. This marks a milestone for the sport, which has been a part of the Olympic program since 1900.

site_title: Fed's Yellen says case for interest rate hike has strengthened
summary: Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen stated that the case for raising US interest rates has strengthened due to improved labor market and moderate economic growth expectations. The US economy is nearing its statutory goals of maximum employment and price stability. Yellen reinforced the possibility of a rate hike later this year, with Fed policy meetings scheduled in September, November, and December. The Fed is expected to raise rates at its September meeting, according to CME Group's FedWatch tool, with 18% probability.

site_title: Playing up the curves
summary: A Singaporean couple, Loke Wen Wei and Ooi Beng Koon, hired interior designer Lim Ai Tiong to create an apartment that mirrored the curved design of their condo, d'Leedon, which was designed by the late starchitect Zaha Hadid. Lim Ai Tiong played up the curves in the interior, creating dramatic 3D silhouettes with organic-shaped panels and timber veneer. The treatment was reversed in the bedroom, where timber walls and ceiling complemented white organic-shaped panels. The result is a unique and cohesive design that has become a talking point among friends and family.

images.alt_text: CURVY-LICIOUS:Storage cabinets and shoe racks are built within the timber panels which seamlessly connect with the TV console in the living room. Backlighting highlights the curvy outline of the panels. The L-shaped sofa from Cierre and dining chairs from Marquis are in tan to match the wood tones.
CURVY-LICIOUS: d'Leedon, designed by world renowned architect, the late Zaha Hadid.
CURVY-LICIOUS: The white gypsum boards in the bedroom are clad with white wallpaper for a textural look. The slim ceiling fan is from Haiku.
CURVY-LICIOUS: The panel boards are water-resistant, so they can be safely used in the bathroom too.

CURVY-LICIOUS: The original walls of the study were torn down and replaced with curved glass walls. This lets in more light into the study and living areas, and also creates more visual connectivity in the home.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end week on a high
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.4% on Friday, closing at 22,909.54, but ended the week flat. The Hang Seng index was led by gains in the energy and tech sectors. Investor caution ahead of Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen's speech contributed to the flat week.

site_title: Tour de force
summary: The second-generation Volkswagen Touran is a versatile family wagon with a sharper profile. It's 113mm longer and wider, with a 54mm increase in third-row legroom, making it more spacious. The interior features 47 storage compartments, a soft-touch dashtop, and a high-quality in-dash CD player. The 1.4-litre turbocharged petrol engine provides 250Nm of torque, and the 7-speed DSG transmission offers adequate handling. The Touran is priced at S$138,900 and is available in Singapore.

site_title: US hacking firm teams up with short seller
summary: A US-based cybersecurity firm, MedSec, has partnered with short seller Muddy Waters Capital to expose vulnerabilities in St Jude Medical's pacemakers and defibrillators, which could put patients' lives at risk. MedSec found security failures, including encryption issues and unauthorized device communication, and shared this information with Muddy Waters in exchange for a potential payday. St Jude Medical's shares declined 4.4% after the news, and the company has acknowledged the risks but claims to be taking steps to address them. This unprecedented partnership raises questions about the ethics of cybersecurity disclosure and its impact on public markets.

site_title: German economy set fair on growth path despite Brexit risk
summary: Germany's domestic economy is poised for further growth, driven by robust household and government spending, despite Brexit risks affecting German companies trading abroad. A strong labour market, rising wages, and low borrowing costs are expected to boost consumer spending, with private consumption forecast to grow 2% in 2016. However, companies are hesitant to invest due to external risks and uncertainties, including Brexit negotiations. Despite this, the economy is expected to expand 1.7% in 2016, with some analysts predicting a higher growth rate in the third quarter.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Singapore telecoms sector brokers predict a high probability of a fourth mobile operator in the market, despite a recent 15% rise in StarHub and M1's stock prices, which are near their historical mean valuation. If a fourth operator emerges, investors are advised to be cautious. Meanwhile, Raffles Medical Group's stock is recommended to hold, with a target price of S$1.54, due to its diversified patient mix and long-term growth prospects. Soilbuild Business Space Reit is recommended to accumulate, with a target price of S$0.79, following its acquisition of Bukit Batok Connection.

site_title: Vard wins contracts to build two luxury cruise vessels
summary: Vard Holdings has secured contracts to design and build two luxury expedition cruise vessels for Hapag-Lloyd Cruises. The contracts' effectiveness depends on customary financing conditions and the value of the contract was not disclosed. This marks the second major contract for Vard in 2016, following a May announcement.

site_title: Land Rover slower sales growth drags down Tata Motors profit
summary: Tata Motors reported a 57.3% decline in Jaguar Land Rover's profit to £304 million in the first quarter, due to slower sales growth. Land Rover's deliveries increased 4% from last year, while Jaguar's deliveries surged 76% driven by demand for the XE sedan and F-Pace SUV. The company attributed Land Rover's slow growth to waning demand for the Range Rover models. Shares of Tata Motors rose 4.3% following the announcement.

site_title: ABR terminates contract to buy Australia land plot
summary: ABR Holdings has terminated its contract to purchase a 1.5-hectare land plot in Yarraville, Victoria, Australia, following a review of due diligence results. The group had agreed to buy the property for A$20 million and had paid a deposit of A$1.9 million. The deposit has been refunded, and ABR Holdings will no longer redevelop the site into residential houses for sale.

site_title: Cordlife's full-year profit down 60% despite higher revenue
summary: Cordlife Group reported a 59.8% drop in net profit to S$13 million for its fiscal year ended June 30, 2016, despite a 3.5% increase in revenue to S$59.6 million. Lower fair value gains on investments and derivatives contributed to the decline. The company's CEO Jeremy Yee resigned in March, citing dissatisfaction with the growth pace of the firm's core business. Despite this, Cordlife expects its core business to remain profitable in FY2017, with plans to expand its geographical footprint and introduce new products.

site_title: People may be losing faith in ECB's ability to fix inflation -ECB research
summary: Euro zone businesses and homeowners may be losing confidence in the European Central Bank's ability to lift inflation back to its 2% target, according to ECB research. Long-term inflation expectations are showing signs of drifting below the target, or "de-anchoring". The ECB's credibility remains intact, but the risk of de-anchoring may rise if the bank needs to extend its timeframe to reach the target. This could perpetuate a low inflation environment and make it harder for the ECB to boost price growth. The ECB is considering using forward guidance to manage inflation expectations.

site_title: SPH acquires Pacom Media to grow golf business
summary: SPH Holdings Limited acquired Pacom Media Pte Ltd, a Singapore-based golf media company, for its business assets. The acquisition includes the Golf Vacations magazine and franchises in China, Hong Kong, Malaysia, and Thailand. The deal complements SPH Golf, a unit under SPH's English/Malay/Tamil Media Group, and aims to expand revenue streams in the local golf market. The acquisition will also enable synergies between the two businesses, positioning SPH Golf for growth in Singapore and the region.

site_title: EU clears aid for renewable energy projects in Luxembourg, Malta
summary: The European Commission has cleared aid for renewable energy projects in Luxembourg and Malta, stating that the schemes do not distort competition. Luxembourg will receive 150 million euros (S$213.7 million) for wind, solar, and other renewable energy installations, while Malta will receive 140 million euros (S$213.7 million) for solar and onshore wind energy. The measures aim to encourage the deployment of renewable electricity installations and help the countries achieve their 2020 renewable energy targets.

site_title: AB InBev said to plan 5,500 job cuts after SABMiller deal
summary: AB InBev plans to cut approximately 5,500 jobs, about 3% of its enlarged workforce, over the next three years following its takeover of SABMiller. The job cuts aim to maximize annual savings of $1.4 billion, equivalent to almost a tenth of SABMiller's annual revenue. The reductions will be implemented gradually and in phases, with the company seeking to achieve similar efficiency gains as seen in its previous deals, such as the acquisition of Anheuser-Busch Cos. in 2008.

site_title: Eight police killed in southeast Turkey PKK bomb attack
summary: Eight Turkish police officers were killed and 45 injured in a car bomb attack blamed on Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK) militants outside a police building in Cizre, southeast Turkey. The attack caused extensive damage, with the police building reduced to rubble and nearby buildings on fire. The PKK claimed responsibility for the blast, which is part of a near-daily assault on Turkish security forces since a ceasefire collapsed in 2015.

site_title: Singapore's air quality remains unhealthy as haze worsens
summary: Singapore's air quality remains unhealthy due to haze from Indonesian forest fires, peaking at 215 on Friday. The National Environment Agency advises people to reduce outdoor activities as readings above 200 are considered "very unhealthy." Indonesia deployed firefighters, used cloud seeding, and water bombing to combat the fires, which have decreased from 6,595 in 2015. The haze has become an annual occurrence in Southeast Asia, causing periodic tensions with the Indonesian government.

site_title: Oil trades near US$47 as Saudis see freeze as positive for market
summary: Oil prices traded near US$47 a barrel as Saudi Arabia's energy minister said an output freeze would be positive for the market. The announcement followed a report that Iran will attend informal talks next month, which may lead to a deal to stabilize the market. Oil futures rose 1.2% on Thursday but lost 0.3% on Friday. Experts believe the freeze would be a symbolic gesture, but could keep prices firm. Inventories and US shale producers' agility limit the potential price rise to around US$55-60 a barrel.

site_title: Loan growth in eurozone private sector improves: ECB
summary: The European Central Bank reported a 1.3% increase in private sector loans in eurozone countries in July, slightly faster than the 1.2% growth in June. This uptick in credit growth is seen as a positive indicator of the eurozone's economic health. The ECB's monetary policy measures, including bond purchases and ultra-cheap loans to banks, appear to be having a positive impact. The data may ease pressure on the ECB to take further action to boost the economy at its upcoming meeting.

site_title: SR Nathan encouraged many to better their lives: eulogy speakers
summary: Former Singapore President SR Nathan, who passed away at 92, was remembered for his ability to relate to the common man and encourage them to make a difference in their lives. He was a founder of the Singapore Indian Development Association and spearheaded initiatives that improved many lives. His words, such as "the small man is important," inspired the labour movement to fight for workers' rights. Nathan's selfless acts and love for those who benefited from his actions left a lasting impact on those who knew him, with his state funeral service concluding with a private cremation.

images.alt_text: SINGAPORE'S former president SR Nathan could relate to the common man and encourage them to make a difference in their lives, said eulogy speakers at the state funeral service of Mr Nathan.
