The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and the People's Bank of China (PBOC) are expanding cooperation on green and transition finance.

site_title: FJ Benjamin widens full-year loss to S$23m
summary: FJ Benjamin Holdings reported a widened full-year net loss of S$23 million for FY16, down from S$17 million in the previous year. Group turnover declined 14% to S$253.6 million, with fashion and timepieces segments experiencing declines of 9% and 13% respectively. The company attributed the decline to store closures, discontinued businesses, and currency translation losses. Despite this, management plans to continue identifying opportunities to restore competitiveness in a challenging economic environment.

images.alt_text: FJ Benjamin Holdings widened its full-year net loss to S$23 million for FY16 compared to S$17 million a year ago.

site_title: Chuan Hup full-year profit plunges 71.9% at US$10.3m
summary: CHUAN Hup Holdings reported a 71.9% drop in net profit to US$10.3 million for the year ended June 30, 2016, from US$36.7 million in FY2015. Revenue increased 1.5% to US$238.5 million, driven by apartment unit sales, but lower electronics manufacturing services revenue. The company attributed the decline to a lower revenue from the sector.

site_title: China to prosecute former statistics bureau chief for corruption
summary: China will prosecute former statistics bureau chief Wang Baoan for serious corruption, including extravagance, abuse of power, and selling power for sex. Wang, 52, lacked political faith and abused his position to get benefits for relatives, accepting gifts, property, and bribes. The move is part of President Xi Jinping's sweeping campaign to root out corruption, targeting high-ranking officials and state-owned companies. Wang's case will be handed over to legal authorities, with convictions generally a foregone conclusion in China's party-controlled courts.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore is mourning the loss of SR Nathan, who passed away. PM Lee remembered Nathan as 'giving his best years and more' to Singapore despite his retirement. The country is also focusing on sustainable aviation, with a new centre to be set up. Graduates are advised to stay calm, with better employment rates shown in early data. DPM Gan will visit the US for trade talks, and businesses hit by tariffs can receive up to S$100,000 in grants. Singapore is also seen as a potential hub for advanced chip packaging and has opportunities for workers to future-proof their careers.

site_title: Declining inventories curb US Q2 growth
summary: US economic growth in the second quarter was slower than initially thought, expanding at a 1.1% annual rate, down from 1.2% in the first estimate. The slowdown was attributed to businesses aggressively liquidating inventories, which reduced GDP growth by 1.26 percentage points. Consumer spending, however, remained strong, increasing at a 4.4% rate, and imports also grew at a 0.3% rate. The revision reflected weak spending by state and local governments and lower profits for corporations.

images.alt_text: US economic growth was a bit more sluggish than initially thought in the second quarter as businesses aggressively ran down stocks of unsold goods, offsetting a spurt in consumer spending.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks, won end steady ahead of Yellen event
summary: South Korean shares and the won ended nearly steady on Friday ahead of Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen's speech. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) closed 0.3% lower at 2,037.50 points. The won rose 0.2% to 1,113.7 to the US dollar, following a nearly unchanged onshore trade. Investors took a wait-and-see approach as Yellen's speech is expected to provide insight into the Fed's monetary policy.

site_title: SR Nathan was 'extraordinary' by being 'simple and ordinary': Zainul Abidin Rasheed
summary: Singapore's former president SR Nathan was remembered as an extraordinary man for his humility and sincerity, which endeared him to people worldwide. Zainul Abidin Rasheed, a former senior minister, praised Nathan's ability to retain his "simple and ordinary" nature despite interacting with world leaders. Nathan's passing was marked by a state funeral service at the National University of Singapore, where seven eulogy speakers, including Rasheed, paid tribute to his life and legacy.

site_title: China: Stocks end flat, but fall more than 1% on week
summary: China's stocks ended flat on Friday, with the CSI300 index falling 0.1% to 3,307.09, and the Shanghai Composite Index rising 0.1%. For the week, the CSI300 fell 1.7% and the SSEC fell 1.2%. This marks the second consecutive week of losses for Chinese stocks, which had previously gained 1.4% in the previous week. The decline is attributed to renewed slides in property shares.

site_title: Singapore shares close lower ahead of Yellen speech
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index closed down 19.28 points at 2,857.65 ahead of US Federal Reserve chair Janet Yellen's speech, which could indicate the timing of the next interest rate hike. The market was also affected by the upcoming GDP data release. Volume was low, with DBS and SIA being the top losers. This marks the end of a 5-day rally for Singapore stocks.

site_title: World's biggest pension fund loses US$52b in stock rout
summary: Japan's Government Pension Investment Fund (GPIF) reported a $52 billion loss in the last quarter, erasing previous gains since 2014. The fund's assets declined 3.9% due to a 7.4% drop in Japanese shares and a 9.1% surge in the yen against the dollar. Despite losses, GPIF's president said the fund is committed to its long-term investment strategy, citing the importance of risk management and expert hiring. The fund's performance is closely watched due to its significant size and impact on Japan's pension system.

site_title: Europe: Shares steady in early deals, focus on Yellen
summary: European equities steadied in early trading on Friday, with investors focusing on a speech by Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen for hints about a US interest rate hike. The pan-European STOXX 600 index was down 0.1% and Britain's FTSE 100 index fell 0.1%, while Germany's DAX dropped 0.2%. Yellen's speech, delivered at a global central bank gathering, follows hawkish comments from other Fed officials, raising expectations of a rate hike this year.

site_title: US dollar dips as dealers hope for US rate policy clues
summary: The US dollar decreased against other currencies, reaching 100.47 yen, as traders await guidance from Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen on monetary policy plans. Yellen's speech at the Jackson Hole symposium may provide clues about the central bank's outlook for the US economy and potential rate hikes. Despite divergent views from Fed officials, markets are positioned for a possible rate hike in December, rather than a September increase.

site_title: Australia shares end week flat, NZ stays near record high
summary: Australian shares ended the week flat, falling 0.5% on Friday, after a heavy sell-off in financials. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 5,515.5 points, down 0.2% for the week. New Zealand's benchmark index also fell 0.5%, near a record high. The decline was attributed to earnings from big companies and the impact of Bunnings vacating seven warehouse properties owned by real estate investment trust BWP.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks end lower, dealers await Yellen speech
summary: Tokyo stocks ended the week lower, with the Nikkei 225 index falling 1.18% and the Topix index shedding 1.26%. The decline came as investors awaited Federal Reserve chief Janet Yellen's remarks and amid ongoing struggles to kickstart inflation in Japan.

site_title: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding to slash 10% more jobs this year
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding Group plans to cut 2,000 more jobs, or 10% of its workforce, due to slowing shipbuilding order intake. The company had previously cut 4,000 jobs in the first half of the year, reducing its workforce to 22,000. Shipbuilding orders are expected to fall to 100 million compensated gross tonnes over the first half of 2016, the lowest level since June 2013. This move aims to reduce costs, with the company's Q2 shipbuilding cost decreasing to 1.38 billion yuan (S$280 million) from 3.2 billion yuan last year.

site_title: Business receipts for Singapore's services industry up 0.4% in Q2
summary: Business receipts for Singapore's services industry rose 0.4% year on year in Q2, according to the Department of Statistics. This growth was driven by categories such as health and social services and education, while others like transport and recreation declined. On a quarter-over-quarter basis, business receipts increased 1.1% non-seasonally adjusted. All services industries except education and financial services reported higher revenue.

site_title: Air New Zealand flies to record profit
summary: Air New Zealand announced a record NZ$463 million (S$457.11 million) after-tax profit, up 42%, in its 76-year history. The airline's passenger revenue rose 8.9% to NZ$4.5 billion, coinciding with a 11% increase in short-term visitor arrivals to 3.31 million. CEO Christopher Luxon expressed confidence in meeting increased competition, forecasting pre-tax earnings for 2017 to be in the range of NZ$400 million - NZ$600 million. The airline will pay an ordinary dividend of 10 cents per share and offer bonuses to staff.

site_title: Italy quake toll rises to 267
summary: A powerful earthquake in central Italy has resulted in a death toll of 267, with 367 people hospitalized for injuries. The government has declared a state of emergency and released 50 million euros for emergency aid. A new earthquake prevention plan was announced by Prime Minister Matteo Renzi, amid questions over the high number of deaths, just seven years after a devastating quake in the nearby city of L'Aquila.

site_title: Update: Top Lotte lieutenant found dead amid probe into Korean group
summary: Lotte Group Vice Chairman Lee In Won was found dead in Yangpyeong, South Korea, hours before being questioned by prosecutors about corruption allegations. He was the top executive outside the founding family and was scheduled to meet with investigators into slush funds, embezzlement, and tax evasion. Authorities found a suspected suicide note in his car. The investigation into Lotte Group's corruption is ongoing.

site_title: Defying Najib, Malaysian students plan rally calling for 1MDB arrest
summary: Malaysian student activists plan a mass rally on Saturday to demand the arrest of an unnamed 1MDB official who allegedly received $700 million. The protest comes despite Prime Minister Najib Razak's crackdown on dissent and his denial of wrongdoing in the scandal. Najib has tightened his grip on the ruling party and wielded draconian security laws to stifle free speech. The rally is a defiance of Najib's efforts to silence critics, as the official's arrest is seen as a key demand in the ongoing 1MDB scandal.

site_title: Singapore's July industrial output surprises with 3.6% decline year on year
summary: Singapore's industrial output declined 3.6% year on year in July, reversing four consecutive months of expansion. Manufacturing output fell 4% month-over-month, with broad-based contractions in all clusters except electronics. The decline was attributed to weak demand in the marine and offshore engineering segment, as well as low oil prices. Electronics was the only cluster to post an expansion, with a 16.2% increase in semiconductors.

site_title: SR Nathan 'gave his best years and more' to Singapore: PM Lee
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong eulogized SR Nathan, the country's sixth and longest-serving president, as a dedicated public servant who "gave his best years and more" to Singapore. Nathan, who died on Aug 22, 2016, at 92, continued to engage with Singaporeans in his final years, sharing his experiences and lessons. Lee noted that Nathan remained sharp and focused until the end, urging Singaporeans to "not give up" and drawing a key lesson from his memoirs.

site_title: Maybank cardholders can use Samsung Pay from Aug 31
summary: Maybank cardholders will be able to use Samsung Pay for transactions at merchant locations across Singapore starting August 31. This move is part of the bank's strategy to strengthen its digital presence in the region. Maybank cardholders can add their credit and debit cards to a compatible Samsung smartphone and pay by holding the phone near a contactless reader at stores.

site_title: China's Golden Concord said to compete for SunEdison yieldco
summary: Golden Concord Holdings Ltd, a Chinese clean-energy group, is planning to bid for SunEdison Inc's controlling stake in TerraForm Power Inc, a US renewable-energy company. This move pits Golden Concord against a planned joint offer from Brookfield Asset Management and billionaire David Tepper's Appaloosa Management LP. TerraForm Power has a market valuation of about $1.6 billion and is one of SunEdison's most valuable standalone assets. The bidding process could lead to a court-supervised auction, with Golden Concord seeking to acquire assets at a discount to increase its overseas business.

site_title: Obama to create world's largest marine reserve
summary: President Barack Obama is set to announce the world's largest marine reserve in Hawaii, expanding the Papahanaumokuakea Marine National Monument to 1.5 million square kilometers, nearly quadrupling its size. The protected area, home to over 7,000 marine species, will prohibit commercial fishing. Obama will make the case that climate change makes protecting public lands and waters more important than ever, underscoring his environmental legacy. The move is seen as a significant step in his presidency's focus on conservation and climate change.

site_title: Gold near one-month low with investors in waiting-for-Janet mode
summary: Gold prices near a one-month low at US$1,322.80 an ounce due to investors awaiting Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen's address on Friday, which may provide clues about US monetary policy. A five-day skid has pushed gold prices down, with the metal heading for a weekly loss. Rising concerns about a potential interest rate hike by the Fed, indicated by 57% chance of a move in December, have contributed to the decline.

site_title: Hazy skies and burning smell across Singapore; 24-hour PSI reaches moderate level
summary: Haze returns to Singapore, with the 24-hour PSI reaching a moderate level of 51-62 as of 10am on August 26. The burning smell and hazy skies are reported across the island.

images.alt_text: The haze appears to be back in Singapore, as netizens posted on social media photos of the hazy Singapore skyline and commented on the burning smell across the island on Friday (Aug 26).

site_title: Iron ore holds above US$61, restocking seen ahead of G20
summary: Iron ore prices have reached a 3-1/2-month high above US$61 a tonne, driven by Chinese steel producers restocking ahead of the G20 summit. The price increase of 42% year-to-date surpasses oil and is largely attributed to Beijing's efforts to tackle a chronic steel glut. Analysts expect iron ore to hold up due to tightening steel markets in China and boosting steel prices and margins. Chinese lenders are also increasing scrutiny of lending to sectors with excess capacity, including coal and steel, amid efforts to curb overcapacity.

site_title: China puts reform back on table as monetary easing shows limits
summary: China has returned to reform mode, unveiling plans to address excess capacity, level the playing field for investors, and take a step forward in a long-awaited fiscal shake-up. The move comes as China's leaders seek to show progress to world leaders ahead of the G20 summit, where the country is hosting leaders from the world's 20 biggest economies. The reform push aims to boost long-term growth prospects, following a stabilization of the economy with fiscal support and monetary easing.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Stocks open higher ahead of Yellen speech
summary: Hong Kong shares rose ahead of Federal Reserve boss Janet Yellen's speech, with the Hang Seng Index adding 0.52% to 22,933.91 and the Shanghai Composite Index marginally higher at 3,069.85. The Shenzhen Composite Index also rose 0.20% to 2,022.96. Traders are focusing on Yellen's speech, which could impact global markets.

site_title: Australia, NZ: Shares subdued amid mixed earnings reports
summary: Australian shares dipped 0.2% on Friday, ending the week unchanged, amid mixed earnings reports. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 5,531.5. Star Entertainment Group reported a 15% rise in net profit, but fell 0.5% after missing expectations. Flight Centre Travel Group gained 4%, while Air New Zealand recovered from a dip after warning of increased competition. Meanwhile, New Zealand's S&P/NZX 50 index edged down 0.3%.

site_title: Europeans look to fasten seatbelts, surf for free at 30,000 feet
summary: Lufthansa flights in Europe will soon offer free Wi-Fi with speeds comparable to those of existing US-based services, thanks to a partnership between Inmarsat and Deutsche Telekom. The hybrid network combines satellite and ground-based infrastructure, aiming to bridge the gap with US airlines that offer Wi-Fi on about 75% of flights. The move is part of a push by European airlines to catch up, with other companies like ViaSat and Panasonic also vying for market share, and is expected to increase customer loyalty and generate revenue.

site_title: Olympics: Swimmer Lochte charged over false robbery claim
summary: US swimmer Ryan Lochte has been charged with making a false statement about being robbed at gunpoint during the Olympics. Lochte, a gold medal-winner, admitted to exaggerating the story and taking responsibility for it. He risks a jail sentence of one to six months if summoned to court. The incident, which involved Lochte and three teammates vandalizing a gas station bathroom, has embarrassed the Olympic authorities and raised security concerns. Lochte could also face disciplinary action from USA Swimming and the International Olympic Committee.

site_title: Australia, NZ dollars gain modestly as Yellen's speech looms
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars gained modestly on Friday, ahead of Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen's speech, with the Aussie rising 0.18% to US$0.7630 and the New Zealand dollar up 0.15% to US$0.7310. The Aussie is poised to end the week mostly flat, while the NZ dollar is expected to be influenced by Yellen's comments, which may impact the USD's response and carry trade dynamics.

images.alt_text: The Australian and New Zealand dollars inched higher on Friday, poised to end the week barely changed, as investors awaited Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen's speech at a gathering of global central bankers.

site_title: China, US still in talks on trade pact despite challenges: Chinese commerce official
summary: China and the US are still in talks about a bilateral trade pact despite challenges in the global trade environment. China's economy is growing at its slowest pace in 25 years, and it faces rising trade tensions due to a record trade surplus. US Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump has threatened to slap tariffs on Chinese products, while China has imposed anti-dumping and countervailing duties on US goods. China's Ministry of Commerce spokesman Shen Danyang attributed China's rising exports to greater competitiveness of Chinese firms, citing falling costs. The two sides can resolve disputes through the World Trade Organisation.

site_title: Silverlake Axis Q4 profit up 3%
summary: Silverlake Axis Limited reported a 3% increase in net profit to RM77.2 million for its fourth quarter, driven by revenue growth in all segments except software project services. Revenue rose 32% to RM166.9 million, primarily due to higher contributions from all segments and an appreciation of the Singapore dollar and US dollar against the Malaysian ringgit. The company's fourth quarter earnings per share edged up to 2.9 sen from 2.78 sen in the previous year.

images.alt_text: REVENUE growth in all segments except one gave a lift to Silverlake Axis Limited's earnings for its fourth quarter, though this was partially negated by the absence of one-off gains and higher administrative costs.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks flat on caution in overseas markets, financial shares slip
summary: Taiwan's stocks remained nearly unchanged on Friday, with the main Taiex index at 9,113.28, due to cautious trade. Financial shares slipped, with CTBC Financial up 0.3% and Mega Financial down 0.2%. The electronics subindex fell 0.2%, while the financials subindex gained 0.1%. The Taiwan dollar softened to NT$31.680 per US dollar. CTBC Financial scrapped a deal with CITIC Bank International, and Mega Financial is under investigation for anti-money laundering violations.

site_title: France's top court to rule on burkini ban
summary: France's top administrative court is set to rule on the ban of the burkini swimsuit, a move that has sparked controversy and debate over women's rights and secularism. The ban, implemented in several French towns, has been challenged by human rights groups and has sparked outrage from some politicians and international leaders, who argue it is a form of stigmatization of Muslims. The court's decision is expected to set a precedent for around 30 French towns that have banned the garment.

site_title: Taiwan's CTBC Financial, China's Citic Bank cancel deals
summary: Taiwan's CTBC Financial Holdings and China's Citic Bank Corp have cancelled investments in each other amid rising tensions between the two countries. The deal, signed over a year ago, was the first failure of its kind since Taiwan's Democratic Progressive Party leader Tsai Ing-wen took office. China regards Taiwan as a wayward province and has stopped communication with the island, citing concerns over Tsai's push for formal independence. The cancellation was reportedly due to China Citic Bank not meeting a regulatory requirement, with CTBC stating they did not submit an application.

site_title: Stocks to watch: IHH, Croesus Retail Trust, Sim Lian
summary: IHH Healthcare's second-quarter net profit rose 8% to RM246.1 million, driven by gains from divestment and foreign exchange. Croesus Retail Trust's net profit fell 21.8% to 4.4 billion yen due to fair-value adjustments, while Sim Lian Group's full-year net profit dropped 71% to S$68.8 million due to revenue decline.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open down ahead of Yellen speech
summary: Tokyo shares opened down on Friday, August 26, 2016, ahead of a key speech from Federal Reserve boss Janet Yellen. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.40% and the Topix index declined 0.43%. Investors awaited Yellen's speech, which may impact global markets.

site_title: British economy escapes Brexit 'bomb', for now
summary: Britain's economy appears to have narrowly avoided a recession after the June Brexit vote, with retail sales rebounding in August and unemployment benefit claims falling. However, economists caution that the uncertainty surrounding Brexit's impact on the economy is too great to make long-term predictions. Despite some positive signs, such as a weaker pound attracting overseas buyers, many experts believe that the economy's future remains uncertain and that a technical recession is possible. The British government has delayed triggering Article 50, and the outlook for the housing market and investment remains unclear.

site_title: Seoul: Won, stocks take breather ahead of Yellen's speech
summary: South Korea's won advanced 0.2% to 1,114.2 against the US dollar on Friday, driven by local exporters' demand. However, trading was subdued ahead of Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen's speech at the Jackson Hole gathering, with investors seeking clarity on US interest rates. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) fell 0.3% to 2,037.05 points, with foreign investors selling Kospi shares and retail investors buying. The Lotte Group's shares were mixed amid a criminal probe into the business.

site_title: Malaysia's PM Najib signs condolence book for former Singapore president S R Nathan
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak signed a condolence book for former Singapore President S R Nathan at the Singapore High Commission in Kuala Lumpur, praising Nathan's contributions to bilateral ties. Najib expressed gratitude to Nathan's work in civil service, including his tenure as High Commissioner to Malaysia from 1988.

site_title: Obama's TPP deal won't get Senate vote this year: Senator McConnell
summary: US Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell announced that the Senate will not vote on President Barack Obama's Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) deal this year, citing its "serious flaws." The decision effectively paves the way for the next President to review and modify the agreement. Despite White House efforts to promote the deal, several senators, including Tim Kaine and Patrick Toomey, have expressed opposition to the current version. McConnell hopes the US will continue its trading tradition, but acknowledged the need for bipartisan support.

site_title: Top Fed officials meet protesters on sidelines of Jackson Hole
summary: Federal Reserve officials, including Vice Chairman Stanley Fischer, met with protesters from the "Fed Up" coalition to discuss concerns about the central bank's representation and policies. The coalition, which advocates for greater diversity among Fed leaders and policies that benefit low- and middle-income families, met with 11 Fed officials on the sidelines of the Jackson Hole economic conference. The meeting was seen as a response to criticism that the Fed is out of touch with the needs of poorer Americans, particularly in the context of the US presidential election.

images.alt_text: Federal Reserve vice chairman Stanley Fischer and 10 of his colleagues met Thursday with a coalition of activists to hear complaints about the US central bank, in a first-of-its-kind event on the sidelines of an annual policy retreat in Jackson Hole, Wyoming.

site_title: Oil holds gains as Saudis see freeze as 'positive' for market
summary: Oil futures held gains after Saudi Arabia's energy minister described a proposed output freeze as "positive" for the market. Iran will participate in informal talks next month, and a deal to freeze production could stabilize prices. Oil entered a bull market last month, and prices rose 1.2% on Thursday. West Texas Intermediate futures rose to $47.36 a barrel, and Brent futures increased to $49.68 a barrel. Analysts expect prices to remain firm due to overhanging inventories and the agility of US shale producers, with prices predicted to stay around $55-$60 a barrel.

site_title: China urges Japan to be "constructive" at G20 summit
summary: China urged Japan to play a "constructive" role at the upcoming G20 summit in Hangzhou, emphasizing cooperation is in the interests of all parties. Tensions between the two Asian economies stem from their wartime history and territorial disputes, including the South China Sea. Chinese diplomats, including Premier Li Keqiang, expressed hopes for improved relations and a "correct understanding" of China. Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe will attend the summit, where cooperation with China is expected. The G20 summit starts next weekend with world leaders, including US President Barack Obama, in attendance.

images.alt_text: Japan should play a "constructive" role at the upcoming G20 summit in the Chinese city of Hangzhou because cooperation is in the interests of all parties, China's top diplomat told a visiting Japanese envoy.

site_title: Singapore shares open flat on Friday ahead of Fed chief's speech
summary: Singapore shares opened flat on Friday ahead of US Federal Reserve chair Janet Yellen's speech, with the Straits Times Index gaining 0.08 points to 2,877.01. Gainers and losers were largely evenly matched, with 57 gainers and 53 losers after 37.2 million shares worth S$48.6 million changed hands. Land transport company ComfortDelGro and industrial conglomerate Keppel Corporation were among the top actives, trading flat.

site_title: Line hunts for acquisitions armed with US$1.3b war chest
summary: Line Corp plans to use $1.3 billion from its IPO to acquire content and technology companies, transforming its messaging service into a one-stop shop for Asian social media users. The Tokyo-based company aims to build a "smart portal" with features such as food delivery, job searches, and travel reservations. Line is open to acquiring companies globally, with a focus on those in Japan, Thailand, Taiwan, and Indonesia, where its monthly active users have risen in recent months.

site_title: Rudy Van Gelder, legendary recorder of jazz, dead at 91
summary: Rudy Van Gelder, a renowned jazz recording engineer, died at 91. He supervised iconic albums such as John Coltrane's 'A Love Supreme' and worked with Miles Davis, Herbie Hancock, and other jazz legends. Van Gelder spent decades as the key recording engineer at Blue Note Records, where he recorded masterpieces that are still celebrated today.

site_title: Three die in crossbow attack in Toronto, man in custody: police
summary: Three people were killed in a crossbow attack in Toronto's east end, and a 35-year-old man was taken into custody. Police responded to a stabbing call, finding the victims with crossbow bolts and two others seriously injured. The motive behind the attack remains unknown. In a separate incident, police evacuated a building in downtown Toronto due to a suspicious package. An unrelated incident from 2010 involving a crossbow in a Toronto public library was cited for comparison.

site_title: Asia: Stocks drop as investors avoid risk before Yellen speech
summary: Asian stocks fell, led by Japan, due to investor risk aversion ahead of Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen's speech. The MSCI Asia Pacific Index dropped 0.3% and Japan's Topix index lost 0.6%. Odds of a September interest rate hike rose to 32%, while a December hike is now seen with a 57% chance. Markets await Yellen's speech for clarity on the Fed's rate decision.

site_title: Senior exec of South Korea's Lotte Group has died: Lotte official
summary: A senior executive of South Korea's Lotte Group, Lee In-won, a Vice Chairman, has died, according to a police investigation. A body believed to be Lee's was found on a walking path outside Seoul, with a suicide note discovered in his car. A criminal probe into the business is underway. The cause of death is currently under investigation.

images.alt_text: A senior executive of South Korea's Lotte Group has died, an official at the country's fifth-largest family-run conglomerate told Reuters on Friday, amid a sweeping criminal probe into the business.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 4.89 points to 1,675.41. The market saw a slight increase in volume, with 25.7 million lots worth RM10 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 83 to 78.

site_title: Apple fixes security flaw after UAE dissident's iPhone targeted
summary: Apple has released a patch to fix a previously unknown security flaw in iPhones and iPads after researchers discovered a hack on a UAE dissident's phone, Ahmed Mansoor, which used a text message to remotely take over his device. The hack, attributed to NSO Group, an Israeli company that sells monitoring software to governments, was thwarted when Mansoor forwarded the message to researchers at the University of Toronto's Citizen Lab. The patch was released as an automatic update to iPhone 6 owners, and experts say it highlights the risk of "lawful intercept" malware being used for malicious purposes.

site_title: Pension fund taps won rally to shop abroad as yields slump
summary: South Korea's Government Employees Pension Service (Geps) is increasing its overseas investments, driven by the won's 3.4% gain versus the dollar this quarter. The fund aims to boost returns by investing in real estate abroad, with properties in the US, Australia, and Belgium. Geps' chief investment officer, Choi Young Gwon, believes the won's strength makes overseas investments more attractive, as domestic bonds yield less than 1.5%. The fund plans to increase overseas investments to 30% of total assets by 2021 and 20% this year.

site_title: US dollar wavers, poised for weekly gains ahead of Yellen speech
summary: The US dollar is poised for a modest weekly gain ahead of Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen's highly anticipated speech on Friday, where she may provide clarity on whether US interest rates are headed higher this year. Despite some analysts believing she will stick to her data-dependent stance, Yellen's speech could send a clear signal that the Fed is gearing up for a rate hike. Meanwhile, regional Fed presidents have pushed a hawkish message, and data released overnight reinforced upbeat assessments of the US economy, with futures markets indicating a 24% chance of a rate hike in September and 57% in December.

site_title: GM wins ignition-switch trial, but legal troubles aren't over
summary: General Motors (GM) has won a trial related to an ignition-switch defect, its third victory in such cases. However, the company still faces numerous lawsuits, including over 12 trials scheduled for the next year. The latest trial in Texas concluded with a jury finding GM not liable for a 2011 accident that left a 19-year-old with a brain injury. Despite this win, GM's legal troubles may persist for years, with lawsuits over economic losses due to vehicle value reductions also pending.

site_title: Leap of faith leads to Benjamin Barker menswear label
summary: Benjamin Barker, a Singaporean menswear label, was founded by Nelson Yap after he left his family's struggling business to pursue his passion for film. Yap took a leap of faith, establishing the brand in 2009, with a loan from his mother and a 60 square meter space at Marina Square for a significantly lower rent due to the economic crisis. Today, the label has over 60 employees, 12 outlets, and rings in S$10 million in revenue annually, with plans to expand overseas, including franchising in South-east Asia.

site_title: Hong Kong regulator wants a tighter grip on IPOs in blow to HKEx
summary: Hong Kong's Securities and Futures Commission is moving to tighten its grip on initial public offerings, shifting power from the Hong Kong Exchanges & Clearing Ltd. The plan, which would see some of the Listing Committee's responsibilities transferred to a new six-person Listing Regulatory Committee, has been driven by the SFC and is seen as a response to concerns about the quality of companies applying for IPOs. The proposal has sparked tensions between the bourse and regulator, with the exchange opposing the shift in power.

site_title: After backlash, EpiPen maker to help reduce patient costs
summary: Mylan NV, the manufacturer of EpiPens, announced it will expand existing programs to help extreme allergy sufferers meet the costs of the life-saving devices, following a five-fold price hike that sparked outrage. The company did not lower prices, but instead will defray out-of-pocket costs. A pack of two EpiPens now costs over $600, compared to less than $100 in 2007. This move comes after backlash from patients and critics who argued the price increase was unaffordable.

site_title: Questions mount as Italy quake toll hits 250
summary: A powerful earthquake in central Italy has claimed 250 lives, with the majority in the town of Amatrice, where 193 have been confirmed dead. The disaster has exposed the region's vulnerability to seismic events, with limited preparations in place despite a devastating 2009 earthquake in the nearby city of L'Aquila. Prime Minister Matteo Renzi has announced a plan to improve earthquake preparedness, while an investigation into potential responsibility for the disaster is underway. The Italian government is also focusing on securing "a place to sleep" for those who lost their homes.

site_title: US: Stocks edge lower ahead of Yellen speech
summary: US stocks fell 0.2% on Thursday ahead of Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen's speech, which analysts expect to clarify the Fed's policy stance. Healthcare shares declined amid outrage over Mylan's EpiPen price hike. The Dow Jones Industrial Average closed at 18,448.41.

site_title: Asia's biggest container shipper posts loss after China merger
summary: China Cosco Holdings, Asia's largest container shipping company, posted a net loss of 7.21 billion yuan (S$1.47 billion) in the first half of 2016, due to excess capacity and declining cargo rates. The company's sales dropped 8.5% to 30.9 billion yuan. The loss is attributed to the government-led merger of China Ocean Shipping Group and China Shipping Group, which created China Cosco Shipping Corp. amid efforts to consolidate the industry and address overcapacity.

site_title: Seiko is no more just quartz
summary: Seiko, a Japanese watchmaker, is expanding its presence in the high-end mechanical watch market with the launch of its Presage line and a limited-edition tourbillon. The Presage line features 60 models with mechanical movements, including the exclusive 8R, and prices range from $500 to $2,600. Seiko also unveiled four limited-edition Grand Seiko sports models and its first-ever tourbillon, the Credor Fugaku Tourbillon, priced at $462,000.

images.alt_text: Front and back view of Credo Fugaku Tourbillon.
Presage Chronograph.
Grand Seiko GMT.
Presage Chronograph.

site_title: Europe: Shares end lower on weaker miners and drugmakers
summary: European stocks fell 0.8% on Thursday, driven by weaker miners and drugmakers amid expectations of a potential US interest rate hike by the Federal Reserve. The decline was also influenced by a disappointing German business morale survey and a weaker metals market. Pharmaceutical stocks, including Glencore and Qiagen, were among the top decliners, while some telecoms stocks, such as Sunrise Communications, rose after posting narrower-than-expected losses.

site_title: US Navy ship fired warning shots at Iranian vessel: official
summary: The US Navy fired warning shots at an Iranian vessel in the Persian Gulf after it approached US patrol ships too closely. The incidents occurred in international waters, with three separate events on Wednesday, including an Iranian Revolutionary Guard Corps boat maneuvering around US ships and coming within 183 meters of one vessel. The USS Squall fired three warning shots after the Iranian vessel approached head-on, causing it to turn away. Similar incidents occurred on Tuesday, with four Iranian warships speeding close to US Navy guided missile destroyers with their weapons uncovered.

site_title: Dwayne Johnson tops Forbes list of best paid actors
summary: Dwayne "The Rock" Johnson has been named the world's highest paid actor by Forbes, earning US$64.5 million in 2016. This surpasses Robert Downey Jr.'s three-year title hold, with Johnson more than doubling his earnings from last year's US$31 million. Johnson's roles in Central Intelligence, Fast & Furious, and Baywatch contributed to his new title. Jackie Chan came in second with US$61 million, followed by Matt Damon, Tom Cruise, and Johnny Depp. The disparity in earnings highlights the ongoing debate about the gender pay gap in Hollywood.

site_title: Deutsche Boerse, LSE submit merger deal to EU for approval
summary: Deutsche Boerse and the London Stock Exchange (LSE) have submitted a US$29 billion merger deal to the European Union for approval, aiming to create the world's biggest stock exchange by revenue. The deal faces tough scrutiny due to the combined presence of the two companies in derivatives clearing. The European Commission has set a provisional deadline of Sept 28 for its preliminary review, which could lead to major concessions such as selling overlapping businesses. US and Russian authorities have already approved the deal, and it also needs approval from the German state of Hesse.

site_title: Thoughts in motion
summary: Three choreographer-directors, Dimitris Papaioannou, Bill T Jones, and Trajal Harrell, share their creative processes at the Singapore International Festival of Arts (SIFA), exploring socio-political issues. Dimitris Papaioannou's "Still Life" uses visual physical theatre to tap into the Greek myth of Sisyphus, while Bill T Jones's "A Letter/Singapore" is an impressionistic take on the city, guided by Frida Kahlo-like images of his nephew's struggle. Trajal Harrell's works, "In the Mood for Frankie" and "The Return of La Argentina," combine Japanese butoh and Harlem voguing, rethinking the relationship between unsettling and stylized dance forms.

images.alt_text: From left: Still Life by Dimitris Papaioannou, In the Mood For Frankie by Trajal Harrell and A Letter/Singapore by Bill T Jones.
Bill T Jones's lecture performance will be at 8pm on Sept 14 at 72-13, Theatreworks, Mohamed Sultan Road.
The Return of La Argentina is Harrell's research and production of dance pieces related to Hijikata.

site_title: Whirlpool to recall 15,200 microwaves due to fire hazard issue: CPSC
summary: Whirlpool is recalling 15,200 Whirlpool brand microwaves due to a fire hazard issue, where internal sparks could ignite a plastic component. The US Consumer Product Safety Commission reported five incidents, including one home fire and two surrounding cabinet fires. Whirlpool has received reports of smoke and burning odors. The recall is a precautionary measure to prevent potential fires.

site_title: Croesus's Q4 profit falls 21.8% on fair-value adjustments; DPU up at 1.7 cents
summary: Croesus Retail Trust reported a 21.8% decline in Q4 net profit to 4.4 billion yen (S$59 million) due to fair-value adjustments. However, the distribution per unit (DPU) increased 1.7 cents. Net property income rose 19.4% to 1.44 billion yen, while fair-value gains slipped 6.2% and derivative financial instruments incurred a loss. For the full year, net profit fell 21.5% to 5.9 billion yen. Unitholders will receive a distribution of 1.61 Singapore cents per unit on Sept 28, 2016.

site_title: Billionaire's 28-year-old son picks digital music empire over palm-oil riches
summary: Kuok Meng Ru, 28, has chosen to pursue his father's digital music empire over palm oil business. Kuok Khoon Hong built Wilmar International Ltd into the world's largest palm oil business, starting from scratch in 1991. Meng Ru attended a British boarding school and graduated from Cambridge University with a mathematics degree. He will likely take over his father's digital music business, following in his footsteps after spending little time with him during his upbringing.

site_title: Trump victory could cause global recession: Citigroup
summary: Citigroup warns that a Donald Trump victory in November's US presidential election could lead to a global recession, with a potential 0.7-0.8 percentage point decrease in global GDP growth. The bank's chief economist Willem Buiter cites increased global uncertainty and tightening US financial conditions as key factors. A Trump victory would push global GDP growth below the threshold for a recession, defined as a 2.0% expansion rate.

images.alt_text: If New York developer Donald Trump wins the White House in November, the global economy could slip into recession, according to a forecast from Citigroup Thursday.

site_title: Plot thickens in SEC case of a US$35b company no one knows
summary: Neuromama Ltd, a US$35 billion search engine firm, has seen its market value surge before being halted by US regulators due to "potentially manipulative transactions." Chairman Vladislav Zubkis, also known as Steven Schwartzbard, has stepped away from the company on an open-ended leave of absence, citing a "crusade to bring his daughter's murderer to justice" as the reason. The SEC previously sued Zubkis over a penny stock scam and he received a prison sentence. The company defended Zubkis, stating he was a third-party contractor and his leave was a temporary contract suspension.

site_title: Russian lawmaker's son convicted in US for hacking scheme
summary: Roman Seleznev, son of a Russian lawmaker, was convicted on US charges of hacking into businesses to steal and sell credit card numbers, costing over $169 million. He was found guilty on 38 counts, including wire fraud and intentional damage to a protected computer. The 10-year-long investigation by the US Secret Service led to his arrest in 2014. Seleznev faces a mandatory minimum sentence of four years in prison and plans to appeal his arrest and the introduction of evidence from a corrupted laptop.

site_title: Central bankers eye public spending to plug investment gap of US$1 trillion
summary: US central bankers, led by Janet Yellen, are urging public spending to address the $1 trillion investment gap in the economy, citing weak growth, lagging productivity, and low business investment. The Fed has traditionally refrained from discussing fiscal policy, but its top officials have spoken in one voice, signaling the need for more infrastructure spending and education to boost the economy. Business investment has fallen below pre-2008 levels, and companies are holding onto record amounts of cash despite cheap financing, sparking concerns about the effectiveness of monetary policy.

site_title: Singapore's self-driving taxi trial starts at one-north
summary: Singapore launched a self-driving taxi trial in the one-north area, with a fleet of six cars and invited passengers. nuTonomy, the firm behind the service, aims to expand to thousands of passengers by the end of the year. The trial collects data on software performance, vehicle efficiency, and passenger experience, with the goal of launching a commercial service by 2018. The move puts nuTonomy ahead of competitors in the rapidly growing autonomous vehicle industry, which is estimated to be worth US$2 trillion by 2025.

site_title: Trump, Clinton exchange angry charges of racism
summary: US presidential candidates Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump exchanged angry charges of racism, with Clinton accusing Trump of flirting with racist ideas and Trump labeling her a racist whose family foundation was a "criminal enterprise". Clinton cited Trump's history of discriminatory actions, including being sued for failing to rent to black and Latino tenants and black employees of his casinos. Trump responded with a personal attack on Clinton's family foundation. The exchange marked a darker tone in the presidential campaign.

site_title: Chinese takeovers trigger global backlash ahead of G-20 summit
summary: China's growing investments abroad have sparked a global backlash ahead of the G-20 summit in Hangzhou, China. Countries such as Australia, the UK, and Germany have blocked or reviewed Chinese-funded projects, citing national security concerns and unfair competition. China has responded by announcing plans to further open its economy to foreign investors. The opposition is seen as a significant escalation in the economic tug-of-war between China and the rest of the world, with potential implications for the global economy and China's relations with key trading partners.

images.alt_text: Forget about Yankee go home. Now it's Chinese go home.

site_title: Why we splurge on timepieces
summary: Luxury watches are often purchased for their brand stories rather than technical precision. The desire to own a timepiece is driven by the emotional connection to a brand's history, values, and craftsmanship. According to Simon Sinek's Golden Circle framework, luxury brands start with a "Why" that represents their purpose, followed by "How" guiding values, and finally "What" technical details. Brands like Rolex and Benrus have managed to thrive by tapping into this emotional connection, creating a sense of permanence and identity for their owners. Ultimately, luxury watches are a form of self-expression and storytelling, rather than a necessity.

site_title: Best Buy poised to be virtual reality's first mainstream test
summary: Best Buy is launching a major test of virtual reality (VR) products, starting with 500 in-store demos of Oculus Rift headsets and 200 demos of PlayStation VR headsets. The move aims to bring VR to mainstream consumers, particularly during the holiday shopping season. CEO Hubert Joly believes VR has the potential to contribute to Best Buy's growth, but acknowledges it's in the early stages and faces obstacles such as high costs and consumer readiness. The success of the test will be a key indicator of VR's future success in the electronics industry.

site_title: Women's power pieces
summary: Women's watch brands are gaining popularity, with luxury watchmakers creating more women's lines and models. IWC, Roger Dubuis, and Audemars Piguet unveiled new women's watches, including the IWC Pilot's Watch Automatic 36 Ref 3240 and the Audemars Piguet Diamond Fury. Jaeger-LeCoultre's Reverso line also celebrates its 85th anniversary with new women's models, while Cartier introduced the Tourbillon Mysterieux Azure and Van Cleef & Arpels' Rubis Secret Bracelet Watch. Other brands, such as Piaget, Bulgari, and Chopard, also released new women's watches, showcasing their craftsmanship and attention to detail.

site_title: Afro Asia Building owner said to be partnering Shimizu for redevelopment (Amended)
summary: Afro Asia Building, a 1960s office block in Singapore, may be redeveloped after Afro-Asia Shipping Company (AAS) partners with Shimizu Corporation. The two parties have signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) and plan to propose an office scheme with ground-floor retail amenities. The proposed joint venture values the existing property at S$170 million and will effectively double the building's existing GFA. Shimizu will handle construction and pay the bulk of a lease-upgrading premium. The redevelopment plans come after a family feud between the Tan family, who own AAS, was settled last year.

site_title: France, the burkini and a 'battle of cultures'
summary: France's Prime Minister Manuel Valls defended the ban on burkinis in over a dozen coastal towns, labeling them a "symbol of the enslavement of women." The ban, which has sparked global controversy, is part of France's broader response to homegrown jihadists and security concerns. Education Minister Najat Vallaud-Belkacem warned that the ban fuels stereotypes and discriminates against the Muslim community, while former President Nicolas Sarkozy called it a "provocation" that tests the French Republic.

site_title: Rolls-Royce engine corrosion spurs ANA to check Dreamliners
summary: ANA Holdings Inc, the world's largest 787 Dreamliner operator, is cancelling flights and inspecting Rolls-Royce engines on its fleet due to corrosion. The airline, with 50 Dreamliners, has cancelled nine flights and may scrap over 300 planes through September. The issue requires replacing medium pressure turbine blades on the planes, similar to a 2013 issue with the lithium-ion battery that grounded the global fleet. This is the largest 787-related flight cancellation for ANA since 2013.

site_title: Avant-garde design with technical flair
summary: Hautlence has sold out its first two editions of the HL2 line, with the HL2.6 featuring a groundbreaking movement with three patents. The HL2.6 showcases a dynamic time-keeping display, with retrograde minutes and hours on a 12-link chain that advances every 60 minutes. The Invictus 04 chronograph, also produced by Hautlence, features the same skeletonised movement and a titanium case with a red and black colour scheme. The brand's unique design and technical flair continue to set it apart in the watch industry.

site_title: FJ Benjamin secures Marc Jacobs distribution rights
summary: FJ Benjamin, a Singapore-based fashion group, secured exclusive distribution rights for Marc Jacobs, allowing it to open four stores in Singapore, Malaysia, and Thailand within the next two years. This move comes as FJ Benjamin reported a net loss of S$5.1 million for the third quarter, its fifth consecutive quarter of losses, primarily due to revenue drops from store closures and currency fluctuations.

site_title: Sharing the stories behind the songs
summary: Elvis Costello is set to perform his Detour World Tour in Singapore in September, where he will play stripped-back versions of his extensive back catalogue and share the inspirations behind the songs. The tour features a changing set list, mixing hits with B-sides and rarities, and includes stories about his musical heroes, such as his late father and fellow icons like Burt Bacharach and Paul McCartney. Costello's unique approach to storytelling through song will be showcased in a one-man gig, offering fans a treat.

site_title: Why Uber is testing self-driving cars in Pittsburgh
summary: Uber is testing a fleet of 100 self-driving cars for hire in Pittsburgh by the end of the month, marking the first time everyday commuters will be able to hail a ride in a driverless car. The company will have two trained safety drivers on each ride to comply with state law. While the move is seen as a significant step towards perfecting autonomous vehicle technology, experts warn that the project is still a long way from being considered safe, with hundreds of millions of miles of testing required to meet regulatory standards.

site_title: A movie that is dated, irrelevant and mostly unfunny
summary: The movie "Absolutely Fabulous: The Movie" fails to capture the essence of the original BBC sitcom series, now 30 years old. The film follows Edina Monsoon and Patsy Stone, senior citizens trying to stay young and hip, but their characters feel dated and unfunny. The movie's plot, centered around Edina's attempt to snag Kate Moss as a client, is thin and relies on throwaway lines. The cast, including Jennifer Saunders and Joanna Lumley, is suitable for a Brit version of "The Golden Girls" but not for this film. The movie feels like an extended episode with a bigger budget.

images.alt_text: Saunders (58, above left) and Lumley (70) are still believable as the best of chums but their characters are a bit long in the tooth.
Moss in Absolutely Fabulous: The Movie. There is an undeniably 1990s feel to the film, though not in a good way.

site_title: Line between celebratory events and ambush marketing far from clear
summary: The International Olympic Committee (IOC) has taken issue with Singapore's celebrations of Joseph Schooling's Olympic gold medal, citing potential ambush marketing. The IOC reminds advertisers that using Olympic logos, words, and symbols without permission is prohibited. Rule 40 prohibits competitors from using their person, name, picture, or performances for advertising during the Olympics, with penalties including withdrawal of accreditation and disqualification. The IOC has sent a letter to the Singapore National Olympic Council (SNOC) to enforce this rule, highlighting the blurred line between celebratory events and ambush marketing.

site_title: Threat of war, quakes and Brexit can't stop EU gas plunge
summary: European natural gas prices remain near six-year lows despite geopolitical tensions, including the threat of war between Ukraine and Russia, and Brexit. The slump in gas prices is attributed to an expanding supply glut, with large producers outside the EU increasing exports and meeting demand through liquefied natural gas trading. Citigroup and other analysts predict further declines in gas prices, with UK gas prices potentially falling to US$4 per million British thermal units in 2017.

site_title: Non-defence capital goods orders surge 1.6% in July
summary: US non-defence capital goods orders rose 1.6% in July, the largest gain since January, as demand for machinery and other products picked up, offering a tentative sign that a business spending downturn is easing. The number of Americans filing for jobless benefits also fell last week, with initial claims slipping to 261,000, the third straight weekly decline. Despite business investment expected to remain tepid in the third quarter, labour market strength should support consumer spending and cushion the blow on the economy.

site_title: E-payment rule changes: MAS wants feedback
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has proposed updates to e-payment rules, aiming to strengthen consumer protection, anti-money laundering, and cyber security. The new framework will bring stored-value facility holders, remittance companies, and virtual currency intermediaries under a single regulatory umbrella. A National Payments Council will be established to coordinate key initiatives, including promoting interoperability and adopting common standards. The public consultation on the proposal will run from August 25 to October 31, seeking feedback from stakeholders on the proposed changes.

site_title: Octo all grown up
summary: Bulgari's Octo collection has made a significant impact in the luxury watch world, just five years after its launch. The brand has introduced several high-complication timepieces, including the world's thinnest minute repeater and the slimmest hand-wound flying tourbillon. The Octo Finissimo Tourbillon and Octo Finissimo Minute Repeater have received attention, showcasing Bulgari's capabilities as a watchmaker. The collection has helped reposition the brand as a major player in the watch industry, with a notable marketing push and record-breaking feats.

images.alt_text: Octo Automatic
Octo Finissimo Skeleton.
Octo Chronograph
Octo Finissimo Minute Repeater
The Octo Finissimo Tourbillon made its appearance in 2014.
The Octo Finissimo Tourbillon made its appearance in 2014.

site_title: Most companies not ready for new standard on lease accounting: survey
summary: A new lease accounting standard, FRS 116, is set to take effect in 2019, requiring companies to record lease assets and liabilities on the balance sheet. Despite 72% of surveyed companies being aware of the standard, 53% have not started preparing for it, citing challenges in upgrading accounting systems and analyzing tax considerations. Industry sectors most affected include airlines, retail, and energy.

site_title: Patek Philippe offers smashing combination
summary: Patek Philippe has released the World Time Chronograph, Ref 5930, a rare combination of a world-timer and chronograph in a wristwatch. This is likely the first time such a combination has been created in the industry. The new timepiece features a 30-minute chronograph, a significant improvement from the original 1940 model. The automatic movement has been reworked extensively, making it a new and complex mechanism. The Patek World Time Chronograph is a unique addition to Patek Philippe's regular lines, showcasing the company's expertise in combining popular complications.

site_title: Staying innovative in a soft market
summary: Panerai unveiled its first minute repeater, the Radiomir 1940 Minute Repeater Carillon Tourbillon GMT, and an ultra-light tourbillon watch, the Lo Scienziato Luminor 1950 Tourbillon GMT Titanio. The minute repeater features a three-hammer and three-gong mechanism, allowing for a more melodic sound, and can be set for a home or second time zone. The tourbillon watch boasts an ultra-light 47mm titanium case, weighing 100g, and a power reserve of up to six days. Both watches are highly complicated and made to order, with prices starting at $414,000 for the repeater and $144,000 for the tourbillon.

site_title: Recovering banks drive market rally
summary: Singapore stocks rose for a third consecutive day, driven by recovering banks, as the Straits Times Index increased 7.36 points to 2,876.93. Despite muted trading activity ahead of US Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen's speech, banks United Overseas Bank, OCBC Bank, and DBS Group led the gains. Total turnover was S$718 million, with blue chips dominating trading. Market sentiment remains cautious ahead of Yellen's speech, with analysts expecting volatility to pick up if she mentions a September interest rate hike.

site_title: Watches for 2016 Olympics
summary: Omega, the official timekeeper of the Olympic Games for 27 years, has launched limited-edition watch models to celebrate the 2016 Rio Olympics. The special models feature wave patterns inspired by Copacabana's sidewalks and bronze, gold, and silver rings on the dials, reminiscent of Olympic medals. The watches also include engravings indicating their higher-end movement and limited edition numbers. These popular models were quickly snapped up by buyers, solidifying Omega's reputation as a premier Olympic timekeeper.

images.alt_text: Seamaster Bullhead "Rio 2016".
Seamaster Bullhead "Rio 2016".
Speedmaster Mark II "Rio 2016", marked by its barrel-shaped stainless steel case, made its debut in 1969.
Seamaster Diver 300m "Rio 2016".

site_title: Corporate disclosures must improve for financial reporting to stay relevant
summary: Singapore investors have high confidence in financial information, but it lacks clarity and transparency. A study found that investors rate financial statements as the most important source for investment decision-making, but also cited issues with aggregated information, insufficient disclosures, and difficult-to-understand reports. The study calls for companies, accountants, and regulators to improve disclosures and for investors to engage more actively with companies and auditors. Regulatory initiatives, such as the Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority's (ACRA) 10th Practice Monitoring Programme, have been well-received by investors, but awareness of specific initiatives is low, highlighting the need for more outreach efforts.

site_title: Adequate disclosures required for 'death spiral' convertibles: SGX
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) chief regulatory officer Tan Boon Gin has stated that companies issuing "death spiral" convertible bonds must inform shareholders of the risks and directors must provide a fiduciary opinion on the proposed deal. These convertibles have the potential to create "runaway dilutive scenarios" and can significantly harm companies and existing shareholders, according to Tan. This move aims to increase transparency and protect investors.

site_title: Watchmakers fight quiet times with multi-pronged strategies
summary: Swiss watch producers and Singapore retailers are preparing for an upturn in luxury watch sales, despite a slowdown in the industry due to a downturn in the luxury watch trade. Swiss watch exports, accounting for virtually all luxury timepieces globally, have declined. However, experts believe an increase in business is on the horizon, driven by the resilience of the watch industry. Watchmakers are employing multi-pronged strategies to adapt to the market shift, including diversifying their product lines and expanding into new markets. This suggests a more optimistic outlook for the industry's future.

site_title: Economic riddle of the Wall Street brain drain
summary: The article discusses the shift in the preferred career destination for smart college graduates over the past decade. In the 2000s, many Ivy League graduates, including those from Princeton, pursued careers in finance, particularly on Wall Street. The high salaries in finance were likely a major draw, and the sector's reputation for offering lucrative opportunities may have created a self-reinforcing cycle, where talented individuals were attracted to finance due to its high pay and, in turn, the sector's salaries increased to reflect its talent level.

site_title: Bling with zing
summary: Chopard is celebrating two anniversaries: the 40th birthday of its Happy Diamonds collection and the 20th anniversary of its LUC line. The brand reissued its first Happy Diamonds watch, a men's timepiece, with a softer look and smaller case, now designed for women. Chopard's LUC collection, which includes a limited-edition perpetual calendar watch and a simplified version, showcases the brand's in-house mechanical movements, solidifying its position as a serious watchmaker.

site_title: Upping the ante
summary: A Lange & Sohne unveiled its Datograph Perpetual Tourbillon, a horological work of art featuring a flyback chronograph, perpetual calendar, and tourbillon with a patented stop-second mechanism. The timepiece, part of the brand's seven new models, unites three key complications in perfect harmony. The Datograph Perpetual Tourbillon is the latest milestone in Lange's chronograph design, building on its legacy of innovation since the 1999 Datograph. The watch is considered a masterpiece of horological engineering, combining tradition and innovation with the highest technical and artistic value.

site_title: The high-tech future of energy in Singapore
summary: Singapore is shifting towards a more efficient, sustainable, and "smart" energy future, driven by the need to increase energy sources, reduce costs, and enhance quality of life. The nation is leveraging alternative energy sources like solar, which has shown significant growth potential, with costs expected to drop by up to 40% by 2025. The government's "Smart Nation" vision aims to maximize energy efficiency through technology and digitalization, with initiatives such as the Energy Innovation Programme Office and the use of data-generating devices to optimize energy production and distribution.

site_title: IWC Big Pilot shows its range and depth
summary: IWC unveils its Big Pilot line with a wide range of new timepieces, including the giant 55mm case and world-timer watch. The new models, such as the Heritage Watch 55 and Timezoner Chronograph, pay homage to classic designs while introducing innovative features like a world-timer and perpetual calendar. The collection also includes the smallest Pilot watch, the Automatic 36, and entry-level Mark XVIII models. The new releases showcase IWC's focus on balance, elegance, and functionality.

site_title: City buzz
summary:
Key events and highlights include:

- Singapore Rhapsodies, a music festival celebrating 50 years of Singapore's music heritage, debuts this weekend with emerging and established artists.
- Whisky Sukiyaki, a unique dish introduced by chef Patrick Tan at Tamashii Robataya, combines A5 Saga Wagyu beef, vegetables, and whisky for a savory and slightly sweet taste.
- National Geographic Live: Chasing Ancient Mysteries with Albert Lin explores his research and expeditions, including the search for Genghis Khan's long-lost tomb and the disappearance of MH370.
- The Singapore Night Festival returns for its second and last week, featuring street-theatre performances, projections, and other events.
- The String Social, a classical music concert, showcases new-age musicians Min Lee, Chloe Trevor, and Drew Alexander Forde, streamed live on social media platforms.

images.alt_text: Singapore Rhapsodies is more than just a treat for the ears as the festival site at Sentosa's Palawan Green will also be transformed into a carnival-esque picnic ground.
Whisky Sukiyaki.
National Geographic Emerging Explorer Albert Lin.
Invasion.
Min Lee.

site_title: Tighter China rules may see Canada losing biggest canola buyer
summary: Canada's canola exports, valued at C$2 billion, are at risk of being halted due to China's new certification standards, set to take effect September 1. China, the world's largest canola buyer, boosted purchases tenfold in the past decade and now accounts for 40% of shipments. Canada's reliance on China has increased significantly, making the country vulnerable to changes in Chinese trade policies. The new standards may cut off Canada's biggest export market, potentially harming the country's farmers who are preparing for one of their biggest harvests ever.

site_title: Richard Mille in colourful tie-ups
summary: Richard Mille has collaborated with artists, sports stars, and private jet builders to produce colourful timepieces. The company has recently launched three new watches with bright dials, including a tourbillon complication with French painter Cyril Kongo. The RM 68-01 Tourbillon Cyril Kongo is a limited-edition watch priced at S$1.03 million, marking the first time an artist has transferred their universe into a watch. Richard Mille has also partnered with Airbus Corporate Jets and Spanish tennis champion Rafael Nadal to create unique coloured models.

images.alt_text: RM50-02 ACJ Tourbillon Split Seconds Chronograph.
Front view of RM 68-01 Tourbillon Cyril Kongo.
Back view of RM 68-01 Tourbillon Cyril Kongo.

site_title: Showing its mettle in extreme conditions
summary: The Edox Iceman Chronoffshore-1 chronograph has been tested in extreme conditions, including a 200-meter free dive under the North Pole's polar ice cap. Christian "The Iceman" Redl, who wore a 2mm wetsuit, set a world record in the process. The watch's ability to withstand freezing temperatures and 500 meters of water depth was demonstrated, with Redl crediting the Edox Iceman Chronoffshore-1 for its role in the successful dive.

site_title: Omega's frontman hits the high notes
summary: Omega introduces its Master Chronometer certification, a new benchmark for mechanical watches, at Baselworld 2016. The certification, carried out by the Swiss Federal Institute of Metrology, requires watches to meet eight criteria, including surviving a 15,000-gauss magnetic field. Six new movements and 46 models were released, including the Seamaster Planet Ocean, Constellation Small Seconds, and Speedmaster Moonphase watches. The Globemaster, a precursor to the Globemaster Master Chronometer, was also re-released with a new annual calendar complication, showcasing Omega's commitment to innovation and excellence in watchmaking.

site_title: Godzilla reboot made with fanboy love
summary: A Japanese film, Shin Godzilla, redefines the creature feature genre by blending action and satire, taking cues from the 1954 original. Directed by Hideaki Anno and Shinji Higuchi, the film follows Godzilla as a metaphor for the 2011 Fukushima disaster. The film features a mix of CGI and motion capture, and pays homage to old-school Godzilla films. With a complex plot and plenty of dialogue, Shin Godzilla may require multiple viewings to appreciate its unique approach, but its entertainment value and potential as a classic make it a standout.

site_title: Carmakers take different routes on controls for self-driving cars
summary: The automotive industry is at a crossroads on how to implement self-driving cars, with some manufacturers like Google opting for a "no-wheel, no-pedals" approach, while others like Audi and Ford plan to introduce automated features gradually. Google's experiment with its employees resulted in a brief period of relaxation and over-trust, leading to a decision to avoid creating a system that relies on drivers taking control at critical moments. Audi and other companies are instead introducing features like lane-departure warnings and cameras, and will only allow drivers to take control when necessary.

site_title: Unrated bonds: Conflict of interest flagged
summary: Singapore's private banks are under scrutiny for earning bonuses by selling unrated debt bonds, sparking concerns of a conflict of interest. The practice, where banks receive rebates of up to 1% for selling risky securities, has led to at least half of the S$875 million bonds that have defaulted since last November being sold by private banks earning rebates. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is reviewing the practice and has called for greater disclosure to clients. Industry experts say the practice poses a conflict between the banks' interests and those of their clients, and should be abolished.

site_title: CPFIS funds up 0.68% on average in 2nd quarter
summary: Singapore's CPFIS funds posted a 0.68% average gain in the 2nd quarter, driven by broad-based gains in equities and bonds. However, over the past year, funds are down 5.94% on average, with bond offerings outperforming equities and other asset classes. Global markets have rebounded following the UK's Brexit decision, but uncertainty prevails. Investors are advised to remain cautious and diversify their portfolios to counter market volatility, according to Thomson Reuters Lipper.

site_title: Steeling the show
summary: Patek Philippe's Ref 5016A "Only Watch" set a world record in 2015 for the most expensive wristwatch sold at auction, selling for 7.3 million Swiss francs. The timepiece, featuring a tourbillon, perpetual calendar, and minute repeater, was cased in stainless steel, a rare choice for such a complex watch. This sale challenges traditional notions of luxury watch materials, as stainless steel is typically used for affordable or sports watches.

site_title: Manly Must-Haves
summary: Longines unveiled the RailRoad watch, inspired by a 1960s model worn by railwaymen, with a 24-hour dial and "RR" marking. Ulysse Nardin launched the Grand Deck Marine Tourbillon, a limited 18-piece watch priced at 280,000 Swiss francs. These new timepieces were showcased at Baselworld and Salon International de la Haute Horlogerie Geneve.

site_title: Iconic pieces get a facelift
summary: Iconic watch brands such as A Lange & Sohne, Rolex, Audemars Piguet, Breitling, Omega, and TAG Heuer have released updated versions of their classic sports models, paying homage to their heritage while incorporating modern features. The updates, which include new materials, complications, and designs, aim to strike a balance between tradition and innovation. The reworked watches are designed to appeal to both long-time fans and new enthusiasts, with many featuring subtle tweaks that enhance their functionality without compromising their iconic status.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Sim Lian Group recorded a 71% drop in net profit to S$68.8 million for FY2016, with revenue down 52% to S$570.9 million. The company's property development division contributed 91% less, while its construction division saw an 88% jump. A first and final dividend of 1.5 Singapore cents was proposed, down from 7.28 cents last year.

site_title: Japanese seek bargains as Abenomics loses shine
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's "Abenomics" stimulus programme, which began three years ago, has failed to lift a deflationary mindset among businesses and consumers. The world's third-largest economy continues to falter, with a stronger yen affecting overseas profits and domestic consumption eroding companies' confidence to invest or raise wages. As a result, firms that initially raised prices in hopes of a sustained recovery are rethinking their strategy, underscoring the programme's limited success.

site_title: JTC makes early-buyback offer for Jurong Country Club notes
summary: JTC Corporation has made an early-buyback offer for Jurong Country Club (JCC) debentures, purchasing S$23.5 million worth of notes 17 years ahead of maturity at a discounted price of S$84,200. Noteholders, who are also JCC members, have expressed dissatisfaction with the offer, claiming it is unfair and does not address their concerns. The offer, which expires on September 23, allows noteholders to monetize their notes now or hold them until maturity in 2033.

site_title: A teary goodbye to a statesman who gave his all for Singapore
summary: Former Singapore President SR Nathan, who served for 31 years, died on August 22, 2016, at the age of 92, after suffering a stroke. Thousands of people gathered at Parliament House for a state funeral service, where seven people, including Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong, delivered eulogies. Foreign leaders and dignitaries from various countries also paid their respects to the late statesman, who was accorded Singapore's highest honour. His body will be cremated privately after the funeral service.

site_title: Pavilion Energy inks MOU with Indonesia's Pertamina
summary: Pavilion Energy, a Temasek-backed firm, signed a memorandum of understanding with Indonesia's state-owned energy firm Pertamina to develop small-scale liquefied natural gas solutions in the region. The partnership aims to explore opportunities in regional small-scale LNG projects, joint marketing, trading, procurement, and investments. This move supports the development of energy solutions in the region and fosters closer collaboration between the two parties. The partnership is seen as a significant step towards making small-scale LNG solutions available in South-east Asia, particularly in Indonesia, which has the potential to become a major small-scale LNG player in Asia.

site_title: Bell & Ross skull watch gets a tattoo
summary: Bell & Ross has released the BR 01 Burning Skull watch, the latest model in its "Skull" collection. The watch features a tattoo-inspired design, with a skull face and flames on both the front and back of the case. The design is achieved through a labor-intensive process involving manual engraving and firing in an oven to fix the lacquer. The watch is limited to 500 pieces and is powered by an automatic movement, paying tribute to the legendary parachutists of World War II.

site_title: Reworked evergreens a sign of the times
summary: Luxury watchmakers continue to produce new models despite a dip in global sales, with a focus on stainless steel watches, reissues, and women's timepieces. The use of stainless steel is seen as a cost-effective alternative to precious metals, offering affordable options for buyers. Reissued models, such as Rolex's Cosmograph Daytona, are also popular, with some selling out quickly. Meanwhile, watchmakers are targeting new growth markets, including women, with some brands launching pilot watches designed for women's wrists.

site_title: Transparency pays . . . in good and bad times
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) Chief Regulatory Officer Tan Boon Gin emphasized the importance of transparency in disclosures of material information, particularly during an industry downturn. This comes amid concerns over disclosure lapses by companies such as Swiber Holdings, a troubled oil & marine player. Tan urged listed companies to consider economic conditions when weighing the materiality of information, highlighting the need for companies to provide detailed information in their disclosures. Examples of companies that have fallen short of this standard include Cosco Corporation and Emas Offshore Ltd, which have made announcements with missing client information and contract values.

site_title: Daytona gets its ceramic bezel
summary: Rolex has finally introduced its stainless steel Daytona chronograph with a ceramic bezel, nearly a decade after its introduction in other models. The new watch features improved reliability and accuracy, with a Superlative Chronometer certification that surpasses official chronometer standards. The ceramic bezel, which replaces the 1965 Plexiglas and steel rim, is hard and scratch-proof, justifying the premium price tag of S$40,000, nearly two times the retail price. The watch was initially expected to arrive in July but quickly sold out at premium prices, with buyers willing to pay up to S$50,000.

site_title: Fine on Sports Hub licensee raises questions about fourth telco
summary: Consistel (Singapore), licensee of Sports Hub, has been fined S$300,000 and reported to the police for breaching licensing obligations, raising questions about its eligibility to bid for a fourth mobile telco operator in Singapore.
