summary: Philippe Dauman, the ousted CEO of Viacom Inc., will receive a total of approximately $95 million in exit payments, including $75 million in cash severance, $12.9 million in restricted stock, and an estimated $3.45 million in early vesting options. His severance package was largely negotiated before the boardroom battle with the controlling Redstone family. Dauman will remain non-executive chairman until September 13 and has until September 7 to propose a deal to sell a minority stake in Paramount Pictures.

images.alt_text: Philippe Dauman, the ousted chief executive officer of Viacom Inc., will receive US$75 million in exit payments. Add his bonus for this year and other benefits, and he walks away with even more.

site_title: Cathay Pacific applies to sell US$2b in medium notes
summary: Cathay Pacific Airways Ltd, Asia's largest international carrier, has applied to raise US$2 billion in medium-term debt over the next 12 months. The move is part of its efforts to fund new aircraft orders, including the Airbus A350 and Boeing 777X, amid increasing competition from Chinese and Middle Eastern airlines. The debt program, arranged by HSBC Holdings Plc, will give the airline flexibility to access foreign markets as needed. The move comes as Cathay Pacific seeks to maintain its market position in a rapidly changing aviation landscape.

images.alt_text: Cathay Pacific Airways Ltd, Asia's biggest international carrier, applied to raise US$2 billion in debt over the next 12 months.

site_title: Japan to train peacekeepers to conduct military escort missions
summary: Japan is set to train its Self Defence Force soldiers to conduct rescue and military escort missions during UN peacekeeping operations. The training will begin this month for units to be deployed to South Sudan in November, marking Japan's potential involvement in overseas military actions for the first time since World War Two. Any rescue missions would be decided by the cabinet, and the training is aimed at enhancing Japan's ability to participate in international peacekeeping efforts.

site_title: Secret data leak hits French submarine maker: report
summary: A massive leak of 22,400 secret pages of data on French submarine maker DCNS' Scorpene-class submarines has been reported, likely alarming India, Malaysia, and Chile, which use the boats. The leaked documents detail the combat capability of the submarines and were marked "Restricted Scorpene India." An inquiry has been launched by French national security authorities, and DCNS has stated that the leak may have come from India. The leak does not appear to affect Australia's A$50 billion submarine contract with DCNS, which is building 12 Shortfin Barracudas for the Australian navy.

site_title: Blatter in last fight against Fifa ban
summary: Sepp Blatter, former FIFA boss, is appealing his six-year ban to the Court of Arbitration for Sport (CAS) on Thursday. Blatter's ban was imposed after a year of scandal that led to his expulsion from football. The 80-year-old claims to be "very confident" of an outcome, but his chances of an outright victory appear remote. This marks his final challenge against the ban, following a tumultuous period for the embattled FIFA leader.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks extend global rally in opening trade
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Wednesday, extending a global market rally. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.32%, and the Topix index climbed 0.60%. The rally follows a global trend, with US stocks reaching fresh records despite tariff uncertainty. Investors appear to be brushing off new Trump threats, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq also reaching new highs. The global market momentum continues, with Tokyo's stocks leading the way.

site_title: Tritech to raise S$5.8m by placing shares at 6.61 cents apiece
summary: TRITECH Group is issuing 87.3 million new shares at 6.61 Singapore cents apiece, or S$5.8 million, to settle a loan and an outstanding payment for a January acquisition. The proceeds will be used to capitalise a S$4.97 million loan and pay S$800,000 for the acquisition. The placement will not result in a change of control. The shares will be issued to six parties, including Tritech Group's managing director and executive director, and businesspeople.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SGX, penny stocks, AusGroup, Santak, Mary Chia
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) is suspending minimum trading price requirements for mainboard-listed companies, giving breathing space to 125 listed companies. AusGroup warned of a fourth-quarter net loss due to a prolonged adverse business environment. Santak Holdings expects a significantly deeper loss for the year due to losses in Chinese operations and lower turnover. Mary Chia Holdings received a notice of arbitration for S$4.81 million from a former partner in a soured joint venture.

site_title: Illiquid assets at Europe investment banks fuel capital doubts
summary: Europe's largest investment banks, including Deutsche Bank AG, Credit Suisse Group AG, and Barclays plc, hold illiquid assets valued at over $102.5 billion, contributing to concerns about capital and financial health. These "Level 3" assets, such as bespoke credit derivatives and mortgage-backed bonds, are difficult to value and unwind, with some having maturities of up to 30 years. The banks' failure to cut these assets quickly enough has led to lingering doubts about their health, with shares plummeting and the firms facing fines and lawsuits related to pre-crisis excesses.

site_title: Alphabet hires new leader for internet balloon project Loon
summary: Alphabet's Project Loon, a high-profile effort to provide broadband internet via balloons in remote areas, has appointed Tom Moore, co-founder of WildBlue Communications, as its new vice-president and general manager. Moore brings commercial experience to the project, which has been testing balloons since 2013 and has traveled over 17 million km. The move aims to transition the project into the commercial stage, with X partnering with wireless operators to provide internet access in rural and mountainous areas.

site_title: Oil pipeline leak in Red Sea, Jordan tells Israel
summary: Jordan has informed Israel of a pipeline leak in the Red Sea, which has reportedly dumped 200 tonnes of crude oil near the port of Eilat. The leak occurred off the Jordanian port of Aqaba and is currently being handled by the Jordanians, with Israel standing ready to provide assistance.

site_title: Qantas annual profit soars as Joyce nears end of turnaround plan
summary: Qantas Airways reported a 56% surge in annual profit to A$1.53 billion, exceeding analyst expectations. The airline's turnaround program, led by CEO Alan Joyce, is nearing its end. Qantas will pay its first dividend since 2009 and announce a stock buyback of up to A$366 million. The company's earnings before tax and one-time items have more than tripled in the past year. Joyce's leadership is expected to be evaluated at the end of the turnaround plan, which has been in place since 2013.

site_title: Amtrak names new CEO
summary: Amtrak has named Charles Moorman as its new CEO, succeeding Joseph Boardman who is retiring next month. Moorman, a freight rail veteran, was previously the chairman of Norfolk Southern. The announcement comes as Amtrak presses to build a new tunnel under the Hudson River between New York City and New Jersey.

site_title: Mary Chia Holdings faces arbitration over former partner's S$4.81m claim
summary: Mary Chia Holdings has received a notice of arbitration and a claim for S$4.81 million from its former partner, Slim Beauty House Co, over a soured joint venture. The dispute arises from an agreement to set up a beauty services center in Singapore. Mary Chia disputes the termination of the joint venture and claims that Slim Beauty House's claims have no merit. The company has appointed a legal adviser for the arbitration proceedings, stating that the termination was unjustified and that Slim Beauty House's claims have no basis.

site_title: Glencore raises US$670m in Australian copper mine stake sale
summary: Glencore has agreed to sell a 30% stake in its Ernest Henry copper mine in Australia to Evolution Mining for A$880 million, including 30% of production and capital costs tied to copper concentrates.

site_title: North Korea test fires submarine-launched missile: Seoul
summary: North Korea test-fired a submarine-launched ballistic missile from a submarine in the East Sea, days after threatening a nuclear strike in response to large-scale South Korea-US military exercises. The Joint Chiefs of Staff stated the missile was launched at around 5:50am Seoul time, but provided no further details or verdict on its success.

site_title: US: Best Buy shines as stocks edge higher
summary: US stocks edged higher on Tuesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 0.1%, S&P 500 adding 0.2%, and Nasdaq Composite gaining 0.3%. Best Buy surged 19.4% after beating forecasts and boosting its year-end outlook. Mylan Pharmaceuticals fell 4.8% after lawmakers called for probes into the EpiPen price. The market remained cautious ahead of Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen's speech on the economy.

site_title: 'He was a people's leader who cared for us . . . '
summary: Singaporean labor leader Mr. Nathan, a people's leader, was remembered for his courageous fight for workers' rights in the 1960s. As President of the National Trades Union Congress, he prioritized cooperation over confrontation and tripartism over self-interest. His leadership earned the Labour Movement's strongest support, and he was humbly praised by union leaders for his dedication to the cause. Nathan's legacy as a champion of workers' rights continues to inspire, with his quotes emphasizing the importance of the trade union movement and the small man's role in shaping the labor movement.

site_title: Ley Choon wins contract, updates debt revamp
summary: Ley Choon Group secured a S$35.3 million contract from the Public Utilities Board (PUB) to supply and install a pipeline. The company is in the midst of a debt-restructuring exercise, which includes divesting non-core assets, and aims to return to profitability. As part of the exercise, Ley Choon has sold several properties and has a strong order book with S$172 million in secured contracts. The company's shares closed unchanged at S$0.03, and it plans to re-apply for a transfer from the mainboard to the Catalist board.

site_title: Top French court to examine burkini ban
summary: France's highest administrative court will examine a ban on the Islamic burkini swimsuit, which was implemented by several French towns, including Villeneuve-Loubet, in response to jihadist attacks. The ban was upheld by a lower court, but human rights groups have appealed, claiming it is a "serious and illegal attack on numerous fundamental rights" including freedom of religion. The ruling could set a legal precedent for towns to follow across the country, raising questions about what constitutes unacceptable beachwear.

site_title: South African finance minister summoned over police probe: spokeswoman
summary: South African Finance Minister Pravin Gordhan has been summoned to appear before a special police investigative unit, the Hawks, over allegations of a "rogue spy unit" during his tenure as commissioner of the South African Revenue Service. Gordhan denies any knowledge of wrongdoing, but investigators have sent him a list of 27 questions to answer. The rand has dropped 3.0% in response to the news, and Gordhan is currently taking legal advice. The summons comes amid strained relations between Gordhan and President Jacob Zuma, who has been accused of trying to limit Gordhan's efforts to clean up corruption and wasteful expenditure.

images.alt_text: South Africa's finance minister has been summoned to appear before a special police investigative unit, a treasury spokeswoman told AFP Tuesday.

site_title: Chinese investors on the hunt for yield are running out of options
summary: Chinese investors seeking stable returns are shifting to the stock market, driven by falling sovereign bond yields. The Shanghai Stock Exchange Dividend Index has rallied 5.6% in the past month, outperforming the benchmark Shanghai Composite Index. Investors, including risk-averse institutional funds, are drawn to high-dividend stocks, such as banks and utilities, which offer relatively safe returns. The nation's largest state-controlled lenders have cut their dividends, highlighting a "new normal" of low profit growth.

images.alt_text: Residential and commercial buildings stand deserted at a construction site at the Caofeidian industrial zone near Tangshan, Hebei province, China. As a further slowdown is expected for the Chinese economy, investors are hedging their bets and trading out of the doom and gloom.

site_title: Saudis ramping up oil output to gain leverage in Opec talks in Sept
summary: Saudi Arabia is reportedly increasing its oil output in August to a record high of 10.8-10.9 million barrels per day, giving it more leverage to influence September's Opec talks on a possible production freeze. This move could allow Saudi Arabia to outproduce Russia, the world's top oil producer, and gain more bargaining power at the talks. The country's oil minister, Khalid al-Falih, has hinted at taking action to help the market rebalance, which has led to a surge in oil prices.

site_title: India tech startups take cost cutting route as funding falters
summary: India's tech startups are taking a cost-cutting route as funding falters, with Flipkart and Ola among those to have made significant layoffs. Chairman Sachin Bansal attributed the job cuts to poor performance, despite recent financial struggles. The move is seen as a response to intensifying competition from Amazon and Uber, which are expanding their operations. Funding for startups in India has slowed, with venture capital flowing in at a record low of $3.3 billion in the first two quarters of 2016.

images.alt_text: Following in Flipkart's footsteps, ANI Technologies PVT's Ola has shuttered smaller brand TaxiForSure, acquired over a year ago for US$200 million, and let go of staff.

site_title: Oil prices jump on report Iran could support Opec limits
summary: Oil prices surged after a Reuters report indicated Iran may support Opec and Russia's efforts to freeze production and stabilize prices. This reversal reverses earlier price drops driven by Nigeria and Iraq's potential output increases. US benchmark WTI rose 69 cents to $48.10 a barrel, while Brent North Sea crude added 80 cents to $49.96 a barrel. Analysts remain cautious, with some questioning the likelihood of actual production cuts. The market is now pricing in a chance for change, despite ongoing oversupply concerns.

site_title: Indonesia expects slower growth in direct investment this year
summary: Indonesia expects a slower growth in direct investment this year, with a 12-14% annual increase, excluding investment in banking, oil, and gas sectors. This compares to a 17.8% growth in 2015. The country's investment board chief, Thomas Lembong, attributes the decline to regional competition from Vietnam, which has become an investment magnet. Despite this, Indonesia aims to improve its investment climate by reviewing and dropping regulations, and enhancing permit handling efficiency in provinces that received the most investment. The country's growth forecast for this year has been trimmed to 4.9-5.3%.

site_title: Europe: Markets rise on better data
summary: European stock markets rose on Tuesday, driven by improved eurozone data and signs that the initial impact of Britain's EU exit vote may not be as bad as feared. The eurozone economy maintained its resilience, with a strong showing from France and Germany, according to data monitoring company Markit. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and the S&P 500 both added 0.2-0.4% as investors awaited Federal Reserve boss Janet Yellen's speech on the US economy. The euro rose against the dollar, while shares in Germany's Volkswagen closed up 2.4% after the company reached a deal with suppliers.

site_title: Microfinance leaves India banks in the dust
summary: India's microfinance industry is thriving, outperforming traditional big banks. After nearly collapsing six years ago due to borrower suicides, the industry has rebounded, with Bharat Financial Inclusion (BFI) growing rapidly. Lending rates are now below 20%, and the company's net interest income has grown 70% year-over-year. In contrast, India's largest lender, State Bank of India, has stagnant growth and higher non-performing loans. BFI's shares have risen 50% this year, while smaller rivals have also seen significant growth, indicating investors are shifting to microfinance as a more attractive option.

site_title: British pound gains but African rand plunges on finance minister probe
summary: The British pound strengthened against the dollar to $1.3194, its best level since August 4, due to positive eurozone purchasing manager data. However, the South African rand plummeted 3.0% to $14.00, amid concerns over Finance Minister Pravin Gordhan's possible removal from his position. The rand's decline is attributed to Gordhan's recent police summons, related to his previous role as Revenue Service commissioner. The dollar remained relatively unchanged against the euro, with markets awaiting the US Federal Reserve's central banking symposium and Chair Janet Yellen's speech on Friday.

site_title: The Singapore route to Hong Kong independence?
summary: A recent discussion on Hong Kong's possible independence from China has sparked debate, with some arguing it's a viable option due to China's pledge to allow Hong Kong "a high degree of autonomy" for 50 years. However, the Chinese government has declared "one country, two systems" as a national policy and stated that Hong Kong is an inalienable part of China by law. Unlike Scotland, which held a referendum on independence in 2014, Hong Kong's independence is unlikely due to its reliance on China for essential resources. Pro-independence advocates face an uphill battle, with few examples of successful independence movements in Asia, and a peaceful resolution may be the most feasible option.

site_title: S'pore inflation negative for 21st straight month, but core inflation holds steady
summary: Singapore recorded its 21st straight month of negative inflation in July, with a headline reading of -0.7% due to low oil prices and administrative measures on accommodation and private road transport costs. However, core inflation remains steady at 1% and economists stress that the country is not in a deflationary spiral. The Monetary Authority of Singapore and Ministry of Trade and Industry expect headline inflation to rise in the coming months, while core inflation is projected to pick up gradually to average around 1% for the full year.

site_title: Jennifer Lawrence tops list of best paid actresses
summary: Jennifer Lawrence tops the list of best-paid actresses for the second year, earning an estimated $46 million from her profit share in the final Hunger Games movie and an upfront fee for the space thriller Passengers. She ranks ahead of Melissa McCarthy, who earned $33 million, and is down from last year's $52 million. The top 10 highest-paid actresses made a combined $205 million, with men still earning more than their female counterparts, according to Forbes.

images.alt_text: Oscar-winning Jennifer Lawrence was named the world's highest-paid actress for the second year running on Tuesday, with estimated pre-tax earnings of US$46 million.

site_title: Can theatres keep up as Ang Lee embraces faster film format?
summary: Film director Ang Lee is set to return to theaters with his new war film, Billy Lynn's Long Halftime Walk, in the fall. The movie, which was shot at a revolutionary 120 frames per second, will be shown in a specially outfitted New York Film Festival cinema with advanced projection systems. The film's unique blend of visual formats may pose a challenge for commercial theaters, which may not have the necessary technology to display it. The film's world premiere will take place at the festival on October 14, with a national release scheduled for November 11.

site_title: Farewell to a father figure
summary: Singapore's former President S.R. Nathan, who passed away recently, was remembered for his kind demeanor and dedication to serving the nation. The journalist Lee U-Wen recalls meeting Nathan in 2005, when he was the only reporter covering the President's visit to a special school, and later interviewed him again at a book launch in 2011. Nathan was known for his patience and understanding of special needs children, and his efforts to promote education and awareness among authorities. He devoted over 50 years of his life to public service and will be remembered as an inspirational leader and father figure.

site_title: Thai industrial estate developer Amata to expand into Myanmar
summary: Thailand's industrial estate developer Amata Corp Pcl plans to expand into Myanmar by 2020, capitalizing on rising foreign investment in the country. The company aims to generate 5% of its revenue from Myanmar, with a focus on Vietnam, where it expects 20-25% of its sales. Amata's revenue growth target was cut to 5% for 2016, but it aims for 12.5-13.5% annual growth by 2020. The expansion is subject to board approval and will be clearer by the end of 2016.

site_title: Tech firms dominating US stock market
summary: Technology companies have surpassed banks as the largest influence on the US stock market, with computer and software stocks now accounting for nearly 21% of the S&P 500 Index's value. This represents a 15-year high and a divergence from the pre-2008 financial crisis era. Despite warnings of a potential bubble, experts say the industry's growth is driven by earnings and driven by demand for products like iPhones and Google's Web ads. The sector's valuation is relatively low, with a 20-year average price-to-earnings ratio of 18, and its growth is expected to expand profit by 2.8% in the coming quarter.

site_title: Africa: promise, opportunities, and challenges
summary: Africa's economy, despite facing challenges, remains promising, with a growing workforce and increasing consumer spending. The continent's GDP growth has slowed, but individual countries have accelerated growth, with the rest of the continent achieving 4.4% growth over the past five years. Africa has opportunities for investors, with a projected $5.6 trillion in consumer spending by 2025, and a potential to nearly double its manufacturing output to $1 trillion. However, corporate Africa needs to step up its efforts, and African governments must improve their leadership and governance to attract foreign investment and promote regional integration.

site_title: BOJ 'given up on shock tactics', says former bank official
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) has limited room for "shock tactics" to meet its monetary targets, according to former BOJ economist Hiromichi Shirakawa. He warned that a sharp rise in the yen exchange rate, potentially exceeding 90 or 85 to the dollar by the end of 2017, is likely. Shirakawa's comments come as the BOJ faces challenges in achieving its targets, and the yen's strength may hinder its efforts. The yen's current value is unlikely to fall below 100 to the dollar this year, according to Shirakawa.

site_title: US$ dips as focus shifts to Yellen's Friday speech
summary: The US dollar weakened 0.1% to 94.411 against a basket of currencies, nearing a two-month low, as investors shifted focus away from hawkish remarks on interest rates by Federal Reserve officials and towards Fed Chair Janet Yellen's speech on Friday. Yellen's cautious tone is expected to alleviate concerns about a potential rate hike. The New Zealand dollar rose 1% to its highest level since 2016, while the euro edged up 0.1% to its highest level in two months.

site_title: SGX suspends minimum-price rules, wants to add market-cap test
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has suspended its minimum-price rules, known as the minimum trading price (MTP) requirement, to consider a proposal to add a minimum market capitalization criterion. Under the new proposal, companies with low share prices will only be added to the MTP watch list if their market capitalization is below $40 million. The public consultation is open until September 23, and if implemented, the changes could benefit 56 companies currently on the watch list or with too-low share prices. The SGX aims to fine-tune the MTP requirement to address market risks associated with lower-priced securities.

site_title: Evolving with the times
summary: IG Asia, a London-listed trading platform, has grown steadily over the past decade, expanding from a single office in Singapore to two offices and over 30 employees. The company focuses on retaining quality clients by offering innovative products, such as guaranteed stop losses and extended trading hours, and educating them on risk management tools. IG also offers a popular mobile platform, binaries, and algorithmic trading tools, catering to the needs of retail traders. The company's premium client segment offers bespoke services and benefits, including cost savings and exclusive events, to attract high-volume clients.

site_title: Opportunities despite high valuations
summary: US stock market indices are nearing all-time highs, driven by strong employment numbers, high profitability, and low interest rates. However, valuations are historically high, making it challenging for investors to buy low-cost ETFs tracking the S&P 500. Instead, investors are turning to cheaper pastures in Asia, where valuations are relatively lower. Some Asian countries, such as Singapore, Hong Kong, China, and Russia, offer opportunities for value investors. The US presidential election in November may create uncertainty, with a potential win by Donald Trump leading to higher interest rates and tariffs, which could negatively impact emerging markets.

site_title: Big China cities could see renewed spike in home prices as housing glut eases
summary: China's biggest cities may see a renewed spike in home prices as housing inventories eased in July, falling 4% in first-tier cities and 0.5% in second-tier cities. Unsold new homes decreased 18% and 4.5% year-on-year in first and second-tier cities, respectively. Analysts predict it could take 2-3 years to reduce the huge inventory, but a report suggests it could take 10 months to move remaining homes. This could lead to more price increases and force local governments to impose cooling measures, reversing a cooling trend seen in recent months.

images.alt_text: Prices in major Chinese cities are still sharply higher from the same period a year earlier, with those in Shanghai (above) up nearly 28%.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: OPEC members are meeting non-OPEC countries to discuss oil market stabilization, potentially leading to a decrease in oil prices. Meanwhile, Singapore stocks are expected to remain volatile, with companies in the oil and gas sector facing tough operating conditions. Retail trusts like CapitaLand Retail China Trust and Wing Tai have made positive announcements, with CapitaLand Retail China Trust acquiring a new mall and Wing Tai announcing a special dividend.

site_title: From delinquent to president: ESM Goh, PM Lee letters recount Nathan's life
summary: Singaporean former president SR Nathan, known for his delinquent past, became the country's longest-serving president after overcoming his circumstances to become a well-loved leader. Letters from then-PM Goh Chok Tong and PM Lee Hsien Loong to his family revealed Nathan's dedication and responsibility. He overcame his past to endear himself to Singaporeans, drawing from his life experiences to make the institution more relevant to the nation. Nathan's legacy includes the President's Challenge, a charity drive that showed concern for ordinary people.

site_title: Gold, gems pile up in Singapore vault as wealthy investors seek refuge
summary: Wealthy investors are seeking refuge in Singapore's vaults and safe deposit boxes as a result of negative interest rates, stagnating economies, and political uncertainty. The logistics and storage provider Malca-Amit has seen a 90% increase in its gold, silver, and gem stash over the past year, with 70% of its storage space filled. Revenue has grown at least 45% in 2016. Gold prices have rallied 26% and silver 37% this year, with investors like billionaire Bill Gross favoring gold as a hedge against low bond yields.

site_title: Paris tourism lost 750m euros after attacks
summary: Paris tourism suffered a significant loss of 750 million euros (S$1.1 billion) in the first half of 2016 due to Islamist attacks, strikes, and floods, deterring foreign tourists. Hotel stays declined 8.5% in the Paris-Ile de-France region, with a 46.2% drop in Japanese visitors and 35% decline in Russian visitors. The tourism industry is facing an "industrial disaster" and needs massive investments to protect jobs, according to the Paris region tourist board.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: CNMC Goldmine Holdings' application for large-scale operations at its Sokor gold field project has been approved, allowing for unlimited ore mining and a lease extension to Dec 31, 2034. AusGroup has issued a profit warning, ceasing its Singapore fabrication and manufacturing businesses due to a prolonged adverse business environment. Sembcorp Marine is acquiring a 15% stake in PPL Shipyard for US$115 million. Magnus Energy has added a new substantial shareholder and converted redeemable convertible notes into new shares. Tiong Woon Corporation reported a net loss of S$9.7 million in FY2016 due to foreign exchange losses and higher impairment charges.

site_title: 2 initiatives in S'pore for smoother container trucking & depot ops
summary: Singapore's Minister for Trade and Industry S Iswaran announced two initiatives to boost the container logistics industry. The Electronic Container Trucking System (eCTS) will transform container logistics operations, improve supply chain visibility, and provide a common IT platform. The TR53:2016 standard will standardize container depot operations, increasing efficiency in managing empty containers. The initiatives, supported by Spring Singapore and the Singapore Workforce Development Agency, aim to deepen partnerships between the government and industry to achieve industry transformation and improve productivity.

site_title: Qantas shareholders expecting carrier to reinstate dividends
summary: Qantas Airways Ltd is expected to announce record annual profit on Wednesday due to lower fuel expenses and faster-than-expected gains from CEO Alan Joyce's restructuring. Shareholders are hoping for a roadmap to reinstate dividends, which have been withheld for seven years. Qantas has made two one-off capital returns totaling over A$1 billion in the past year, but not reinstated dividend payments. Analysts predict a 0.6% rise in Qantas stock and a potential dividend payment at the end of 2017, which could attract a wider group of investors seeking income-generating assets.

site_title: Sengkang EC site draws land-hungry developers
summary: A Singapore executive condominium (EC) site in Anchorvale Lane drew 16 bids, with Hoi Hup-Sunway leading the pack with an offer of S$355.07 per square foot per plot ratio (psf ppr), 27% higher than the price paid for the Treasure Crest site. The top bidder expects to launch the project in late 2017, with an average selling price of S$755-760 psf. The strong take-up for Treasure Crest boosted developer confidence, indicating improved market sentiments in the EC development segment.

site_title: S'pore's move to build talent with overseas exposure picks up steam
summary: Singapore ties up with the Economic Development Board to launch the U Future Leaders Global Programme, providing international exposure to promising young executives. The programme aims to build key leadership attributes and develop relevant competencies for corporate leaders. 13 scholarships have been awarded by International Enterprise Singapore to groom the next generation of talent. This move follows a study by LinkedIn and NTUC, which found that more than half of corporate executives in Singapore have worked or studied abroad.

site_title: UBS hires junk-debt traders Chang, Raman from Morgan Stanley
summary: UBS Group AG hired traders Jeff Chang and Vivek Raman from Morgan Stanley to bolster its junk-debt trading business in the US. Chang, an executive director, will oversee US high-yield corporate bond trading in New York, while Raman joins as a director. Both will start at UBS in October and September, respectively.

site_title: BlackRock bullish on EM as profits improve
summary: BlackRock has upgraded emerging-market equities to "overweight" due to improved fundamentals and a stable US dollar outlook. The move comes after a three-month rally that pushed the benchmark index to a one-year high. The upgrade, made by the world's largest asset manager, cites a stable US interest rate environment as the Federal Reserve moves slowly to raise interest rates. This decision follows a similar upgrade in developing-nation bonds last month.

site_title: Counting on fiscal policy to beat the UK downturn
summary: The UK government is taking action to counter the economic downturn following the Brexit referendum, with the Bank of England's monetary easing announced on August 4. The government plans to temporarily expand the budget deficit to boost economic activity, with a focus on public sector housing and infrastructure projects. However, monetary policy is seen as running out of steam, and fiscal policy is expected to play a more significant role in stabilizing the economy. The government is likely to rely on fiscal measures rather than monetary policy to counter the referendum repercussions, with a warning that the worldwide decline in long-term interest rates and bond prices may be a bubble waiting to burst.

site_title: US retailers' heavy discounting hurting luxury brands
summary: US retailers' heavy discounting has hurt luxury brands, including Michael Kors and Ralph Lauren, by tarnishing their images and training consumers to expect special deals. Promotional sprees at department stores have reached an all-time high, with prices slashed by up to 80% in May, June, and July. Luxury brands are pushing back against the discounts, with Michael Kors ending coupons and friends-and-family sales at department stores, and Ralph Lauren reducing excess inventory. The trend is damaging relationships between brands and retailers, with some predicting it will be difficult to wean shoppers off discounting.

site_title: July new-home sales surge to almost nine-year high
summary: US new-home sales surged in July to a nearly nine-year high, increasing 12.4% to a 654,000 annualized pace, exceeding forecasts. This is the fastest pace since October 2007. Strong demand in the South, the strongest since the start of the last recession, drove the increase. The data adds to signs of persistent housing-market strength, despite economic uncertainty.

site_title: Russia wheat in best run since April as buyers seek quality grain
summary: Russia's wheat prices rose 1.2% to $170 a tonne, the best run since April, due to high-protein grain being sought by buyers after rains damaged crops in Russia and France. Farmers are charging more for high-quality grain, helping Russian export prices rebound after a record-low six-year slump. Demand remains active amid concerns about western European crop quality.

site_title: Microsoft buys AI startup, Apple boosts health focus
summary: Microsoft acquired startup Genee to boost its artificial intelligence capabilities, allowing users to schedule meetings with virtual assistants. Apple confirmed an acquisition of Gliimpse, a startup that uses machine learning to manage and share personal medical information. The deals aim to enhance Microsoft's and Apple's respective focus on AI and health. Genee's technology will be integrated into Microsoft's Office 365 software, while Gliimpse's platform will be used to improve fitness and health management on Apple devices.

site_title: Singtel's Intouch, Bharti Telecom deals promise long-term benefits
summary: Singtel has announced a deal to buy a 21% stake in Intouch Holdings in Thailand and an entire 7.39% stake in Bharti Telecom Ltd in India, increasing its deemed stakes in AIS and Bharti Airtel to 31.8% and 36.2%, respectively. The deal, valued at S$2.47 billion, aims to raise Singtel's interests in these Asian markets, where 4G networks are rapidly expanding. The move is expected to offset potential losses from Singtel's divestment of its holding in NetLink Trust and provide opportunities for Singtel to expand its enterprise business in India and Thailand.

site_title: If the Fed had to choose its poison, it'd be stagnation over inflation
summary: The US Federal Reserve is considering holding interest rates unchanged, citing the risk of premature monetary tightening and the potential for stagflation. Unemployment and inflation are near the Fed's targets, but the economic slowdown is a global phenomenon, with major economies in Europe and Asia also stagnant or slowing. The Fed must balance the risk of inflation with the risk of stagnation, and the decision may ultimately depend on the Fed's ability to support the economy through fiscal policy.

site_title: SPH unveils integrated marketing division
summary: SPH, a Singapore media and property group, has launched an integrated marketing division to serve advertisers across its various platforms. The new division, led by Elsie Chua as group chief marketing officer, brings together sales and marketing staff from print, digital, radio, and out-of-home platforms. The move aims to offer more effective media solutions to advertisers and partners, capitalizing on the strengths and experience of staff across the group's platforms. The changes take effect on September 5, as part of a major review of sales operations.

site_title: Tiger tourism still thriving in Thailand amid captive breeding
summary: Thailand's tiger tourism business continues to thrive, despite a recent wildlife authority raid on the infamous Tiger Temple. The captive tiger population has grown 33% since 2010, with 830 tigers in 2015-16. New venues have opened, and some practice "speed breeding" to produce tiger cubs for tourist photo-ops. Wildlife activists call for a complete breeding ban, citing inadequate regulations and zero conservation purpose. Authorities have implemented a population management regulation, but critics say it is insufficient.

site_title: Lochte loses all his major sponsors after Rio incident, apology
summary: US Olympic swimmer Ryan Lochte lost all four major sponsors, including Speedo USA and Ralph Lauren Corp, after apologizing for an "over-exaggerated" story about being robbed at gunpoint at the Rio Games. His false account embarrassed the host city and local officials, casting doubt on his story and dominating news coverage. The incident occurred during the Rio Games, and Lochte's apology led to the loss of his major sponsors.

site_title: Bringing sexy to cashback
summary: Henry Chan and Joel Leong, co-founders of ShopBack, a Singapore-based e-commerce platform, successfully launched their cashback model after two failed startups. With no existing players in Southeast Asia, they secured seed funding from Accel-X and East Ventures. ShopBack now operates in five countries, linking over 1,000 merchants and directing more than $15 million in sales monthly. The company plans to expand beyond cashback, offering value-added services and improving its risk management systems. Despite facing competition and not being profitable, ShopBack aims to become profitable within 12 months and has refused acquisition offers to maintain control.

site_title: Keeping abreast of changes in age of robotics, digitalisation
summary: Accountants face disruption due to technological advancements, such as robotics, analytics, and digitalization, which threaten to render traditional roles obsolete. To remain relevant, accountants must adapt and acquire new skills, including soft skills like communication, leadership, and problem-solving. Employers and educators must partner to provide training in these areas, and accountants must commit to lifelong learning to stay up-to-date with changing technologies. Failure to adapt may result in limited career options and remuneration opportunities.

site_title: Asia poised to play dominant role in Africa's future growth
summary: Sub-Saharan Africa is expected to post strong growth of 4.1% in 2017 and 5.2% in 2018, driven by attractive demographics, urbanization, and rising consumerism. The region's structural growth drivers remain intact despite a weaker global outlook and subdued commodity prices. The growth of fintech firms and online lenders is also supporting the middle-class segment by improving access to credit. In contrast, Africa lacks access to electricity, with 50% of the population not having power, compared to 80% in India.

site_title: Li Ka-shing's second Pakistan terminal to start operations after 5-year delay
summary: Li Ka-shing's Hutchison Port Holdings Ltd will start operations at its second Pakistan terminal in Karachi, a 5-year delayed project, before the end of this year. The terminal will handle 1.7 million TEUs annually, increasing Pakistan's container handling capacity by more than half. The project, valued at $46 billion, is part of China's investments in Pakistan, targeting a 7% annual growth rate. The terminal's operations will begin in October, with initial capacity of 250,000 TEUs, increasing to over 2 million in five years.

site_title: Hedge-fund startup bets big on T-bills with China funds
summary: A hedge fund startup has teamed up with a Wall Street bond trader to make significant bets on US Treasury bills, specifically T-bills, with Chinese funds. The partnership, located in a small office building in Connecticut, is a rare collaboration between a Chinese financial heavyweight and a US-based trader. The move is seen as a strategic investment in the US Treasury market, driven by China's growing dollar asset diversification efforts. The partnership aims to capitalize on the growing demand for US debt from Chinese investors.

site_title: London boom to end next year on Brexit
summary: London's housing market is expected to experience a downturn next year due to economic uncertainty from the UK's vote to leave the European Union. Countrywide Plc forecasts a 3.5% price growth in 2016, slowing to 1.25% in 2017, and a 6% drop in prime central London properties this year. The luxury market is also being affected by increased sales taxes and oversupply. However, the company expects Greater London home values to rise by 2% in 2018 as the economy improves.

site_title: SPH, SPH Foundation give S$350k to ComChest charities
summary: SPH and SPH Foundation donated S$350,000 to 20 charities under the Community Chest, with S$150,000 going to the Special Education Financial Assistance Scheme for over 1,000 disabled students. The donation was presented at an event held at the SPH News Centre Auditorium, where a minute of silence was observed for former president SR Nathan. The donation also supported charities serving underprivileged children, the disabled, and the elderly. This is the first year the SPH Foundation has donated to the Special Education Financial Assistance Scheme.

images.alt_text: Mr Lee (right), chairman of SPH and SPH Foundation, presenting the cheque to Community Chest vice-chairman Eric Ang.
The Singapore Chinese Orchestra paid tribute to former president SR Nathan, who died on Monday night, with a rendition of Amazing Grace.

site_title: Sharp reviewing TV licensing deals to boost global presence
summary: Sharp Corp, a Japanese electronics maker, plans to review its TV brand licensing deals overseas to boost global presence. The company will examine possibilities to buy back its TV business in the US and Europe after effectively exiting the business in those markets. Sharp licensed its brand to Hisense Group in the Americas and Universal Media Corp Slovakia in Europe. The review comes after Sharp trimmed its losses in the April-June quarter by withdrawing from the TV business abroad.

site_title: Magnus Energy adds new substantial shareholder
summary: Magnus Energy added a new substantial shareholder after converting $400,000 of redeemable convertible notes into 444 million shares at a price of 0.09 Singapore cents. The conversion brings the total issued shares to 4.463 billion, increasing the number of outstanding shares.

site_title: US: Wall St moves higher, led by tech; Nasdaq hits record
summary: The US stock market rose, with the Nasdaq hitting a record high, led by technology and financial companies. Investors await Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen's speech for clues on an interest rate hike this year. The Dow Jones industrial average and S&P 500 also rose, with the Nasdaq's gain attributed to gains in Apple and Microsoft. The technology index rose 0.61%, while the materials sector gained 0.99% due to Monsanto's merger talks with Bayer AG.

site_title: Turning to machines for advice
summary: Computer-driven quantitative strategies have become more mainstream in the low-yield environment, driven by their outperformance in returns and the competitive landscape for yield. These strategies have been popularized by the "new normal" of low interest rates and unconventional monetary policies. However, investors must be mindful of the risks associated with these strategies, as they may have higher house advantages and fewer winners. As a result, investors are looking for ways to gain an edge, such as with card-counting robots.

site_title: Emerging markets debt in Goldilocks situation
summary: Emerging markets debt has staged a strong recovery, with total inflow reaching $25 billion, the highest since 2012. The recovery is driven by five key reasons, including forecasted global growth of 3-4% and 4-6% in emerging markets, yield enhancement in local currency debt, and reduced current account deficits. Despite political noise, EM growth is expected to contribute 57% of global growth, increasing demand for EMD. Local currency debt offers high returns potential, especially with a gradual Fed hiking path, making it an attractive diversification in a global bond portfolio.

site_title: MinLaw, IPOS seek views on proposed changes to copyright rules
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Law and Intellectual Property Office of Singapore have launched a public consultation on proposed changes to the country's copyright rules. The consultation will run for two months until October 24. The move aims to gather feedback on the proposed changes, which will impact copyright holders and users in the country. The exact nature of the changes is not specified, but the consultation is seen as an effort to modernize the country's copyright laws.

site_title: Japan financial regulator extends safety net on Brexit worries
summary: Japan's Financial Services Agency (FSA) is extending provisions allowing regional banks and credit unions to borrow from the public purse more easily due to Brexit risks. The extension, for five years until 2022, aims to mitigate potential disruptions to Japan's financial system. This move follows the country's biggest daily stock fall in over five years after the Brexit vote. The FSA is also extending deadlines for other financial assistance programs, including those for banks and life insurance companies. The measures aim to maintain financial stability in Japan.

site_title: STI ends up after vacillating
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) closed 9.24 points higher at 2,850.43, boosted by gains in Singapore banks and telcos, despite low trading volume. DBS, UOB, and OCBC shares rose, while DBS gained 13 cents, UOB 9 cents, and OCBC 2 cents.

site_title: UK pension managers under strain
summary: UK pension managers face a funding crisis as the country's Brexit-induced slump widens funding gaps. The crash in global bond yields has pushed long-dated yields to record lows, crimping pensions' future income. The Bank of England's bond-buying program aims to support the economy, but experts warn that this may force companies to put more money into their pension plans, stifling economic growth. To ease the strain, pension experts propose adjusting discount rates, issuing more gilts, and linking plans to corporate bond yields. If left unaddressed, the crisis may lead to reduced pension benefits and increased reliance on individual savings for retirement.

site_title: Through all seasons: a look back on SR Nathan's life
summary: The article provides a brief look back at the life of SR Nathan, but the main news topics include reactions to US President Donald Trump's tariff announcement on Vietnam, a Malaysian agency's plan to seize Daim Zainuddin's assets, China's expected slowing GDP growth, Citigroup's forecast for the MSCI global equity index, and Thai Prime Minister Thaksin's confidence in clearing his daughter's suspension in an ethics case.

site_title: 3-month Sibor falls to 12-month low amid Singdollar strength
summary: Singapore's three-month Sibor (Singapore interbank offered rate) has fallen to a 12-month low of 0.87192% due to the strong Sing dollar, attracting inflows and improving liquidity. The SOR (swap offer rate) has also plummeted, 30% lower than its January high. Analysts attribute the low interest rates to the Sing dollar's appreciation by 5% against the USD and market optimism over the Fed not hiking rates soon. The Monetary Authority of Singapore's zero-appreciation policy is uncertain, with some speculating a potential easing to help exporters.

site_title: World's biggest bond traders get positive on negative yields
summary: Pimco and China are buying negative-yielding Japanese debt, a strategy that allows investors with dollars to lend to earn positive yields. The trade involves borrowing yen and lending dollars, with a basis spread on the cross-currency swap determining the profit. This strategy is taking advantage of the world's insatiable appetite for dollar assets, driven by record-low interest rates. China, with its $3.2 trillion dollar reserves, is seen as a strong candidate to enter into this trade, providing liquidity in dollars with minimal risk. The strategy has generated high yields, with dollar-hedged yields on three-month Japanese bills near 1.24%.

site_title: Qatar Airways announces first AFL sponsorship deal
summary: Qatar Airways has signed a three-year deal with the Australian Football League's Sydney Swans, becoming the airline's first AFL sponsorship partner. The deal grants Qatar Airways prominent branding at Sydney's home games and training grounds. The partnership runs until the end of the 2019 season and follows Qatar Airways' recent sports sponsorship announcements, including a deal with the International Cycling Union Road World Championships and a partnership with Bayern Munich. The airline's CEO, Akbar Al Baker, stated that the deal aligns with Qatar Airways' goal of connecting with global travelers through their passion for sport.

site_title: Oil slips below US$49 as rising supply trumps hopes for producer action
summary: Oil prices fell below US$49 a barrel, reversing August's strong rally, due to rising global supply. A Nigerian militant group announced a potential ceasefire, while Iraq resumed pumping oil. Despite hopes for OPEC producer action, analysts remain skeptical, citing logistical challenges and supply glut. Goldman Sachs said current prices won't be sustained, while Morgan Stanley warned of headwinds against a meaningful deal. Oil inventories and interest rate decisions will be closely watched for further market direction.

site_title: Meeting of German, French, Italian heads reflects uncertainty
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel, French President Francois Hollande, and Italian Prime Minister Matteo Renzi met on the Italian island of Ventotene to discuss the Eurozone's future, amid uncertainty and economic concerns. Despite the UK's Brexit, the Eurozone's economy has seen slight improvements, but its GDP remains low. The leaders emphasized the need to reject populist parties and promote youth opportunities, security cooperation, and economic growth. The meeting comes as Italy is set to hold a referendum on reducing senators and the Netherlands and France prepare for elections with strong right-wing populist parties.

site_title: Eurozone sees stable business growth in August: surveys
summary: The eurozone experienced stable business growth in August, with France's private sector showing surprisingly strong growth despite the UK's Brexit vote. The eurozone Composite Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) rose to a seven-month high of 53.3, suggesting a 0.3% expansion in GDP this quarter. However, new order growth in manufacturing slowed, and service firms were less optimistic about the year ahead. Consumer confidence remains low, and the European Central Bank is expected to ease monetary policy further by year's end.

site_title: Oil bounces on speculation of Iran supporting Opec freeze action
summary: Oil prices surged 2% on Tuesday, reversing early losses, after Reuters reported that Iran was sending positive signals on supporting a joint Opec action to prop up the market. Brent crude rose to $50.03 a barrel, while US crude jumped to $48.11. The news comes as Opec trimmed oil demand forecasts for the next four years, further supporting the market.

site_title: US overtakes Hong Kong as biggest Swiss watch market
summary: US overtakes Hong Kong as the largest market for Swiss watch exports, surpassing the territory with a 10.9% market share, compared to Hong Kong's 10.7%. Swiss watch exports declined 14.2% in July, with a 11.1% decline for the first seven months of 2016. The decline is attributed to reduced tourist visits to Europe, particularly from China, following recent attacks and government crackdowns. Britain saw a 13.4% rise in watch exports, while France remained weak due to fears of Islamist attacks.

site_title: NTUC, EDB jointly launch programme to offer global exposure to young executives
summary: NTUC and the Economic Development Board (EDB) have launched the U Future Leaders Programme, providing global exposure to young Singaporean executives. The programme aims to identify promising individuals, offer international opportunities, and develop key leadership attributes. Six multinational companies, including Dentsu Aegis Network and Unilever, are participating in the pilot programme, which is open to NTUC's U Circle of Friends. This initiative follows a study by NTUC and LinkedIn, which found that over half of Singapore's corporate executives have worked or studied abroad.

site_title: Iraq may base 2017 draft budget on US$35/barrel oil price: PM Abadi
summary: Iraq's Prime Minister Haider al-Abadi has stated that the country's 2017 budget may be based on an oil price of $35 per barrel, similar to this year's forecast of $32 per barrel. Iraq relies heavily on oil sales, accounting for 95% of its public spending. The budget assumption can be changed by parliament, which must approve it. Iraq is the second-largest OPEC producer, but sells its crude at a discount to international prices, currently around $50 per barrel.

images.alt_text: Iraq may base its public budget for 2017 on an oil price of US$35 per barrel, about the same level as this year, Prime Minister Haider al-Abadi told a news conference on Tuesday in Baghdad.

site_title: Eurozone consumer confidence falls again in August
summary: Eurozone consumer confidence fell 0.6 points to -8.5 in August, marking the second consecutive drop and a 1.3-point decline since the June 23 British vote to leave the EU. Economists had forecast a rebound, but the result defied expectations. The EU indicator showed a stable -7.8, edging down 0.1 from July. The decline follows a slight fall in June and two consecutive rises in April and May.

images.alt_text: Eurozone consumer confidence fell markedly again in August, the European Commission said on Wednesday releasing its monthly indicator, in a new sign of weaker morale after the June 23 British vote to leave the European Union.

site_title: CNMC Goldmine's application for large-scale operations approved
summary: CNMC Goldmine Holdings' application for large-scale operations at its Sokor gold field project has been approved. The mining lease, initially set to expire in 2018, will now extend to Dec 31, 2045, providing long-term certainty for the company's operations. The royalty rates for minerals produced in Sokor will be adjusted to 10% and the company will pay a processing payment of up to RM20 million for the lease extension. This approval enables CNMC to better plan and budget for the long term.

site_title: Gold rally reviving scrap recycling
summary: Gold prices have surged this year, reaching their biggest annual gain since 2010, prompting a revival in scrap recycling. The surge in prices has led to an increase in unwanted jewelry, coins, and trinkets being brought to pawn shops and cash-for-gold companies, with recyclers expanding capacity to meet the demand. The industry has seen a 10% increase in recycling from the same period in 2015, and some companies are planning significant expansions, such as Baird & Co's 50% expansion. The increase in gold prices is attributed to factors such as the Federal Reserve's decision not to raise US borrowing costs and negative interest rates in Europe and Japan.

site_title: China's richest man set to seal two billion-dollar US film deals
summary: China's richest man, Wang Jianlin, chairman of Dalian Wanda Group, is set to seal two billion-dollar US film deals, further expanding his company's Hollywood presence. Following the acquisition of Legendary Entertainment, Wanda aims to triple revenue from its cultural division to 150 billion yuan by 2020. Wang plans to acquire a "Big Six" movie studio, bringing its technology and capability to China, and co-invest in global blockbusters next year. The deal would bolster Wanda's control of 15% of global box office revenues, potentially reaching 20% by 2020.

site_title: Low growth will be a post-Brexit certainty
summary: The UK's decision to leave the EU has resulted in a significant economic downturn, with the country's annual growth of gross domestic product (GDP) expected to average zero percent from 2017 to 2019, according to the Economist Intelligence Unit. The cost of leaving the EU has turned out to be far higher than the benefits, with reduced access to the common market and limited bargaining power in trade negotiations. The UK's financial services sector is also expected to suffer, with foreign direct investment and exports declining. The government faces a difficult task in navigating the Brexit process, with many questioning the economic wisdom of the decision.

images.alt_text: The hope that Britain will gain greater freedom from the EU bureaucracy while retaining lucrative access to the pan-European market has turned out to be a chimera. The negative consequence of Brexit is already evident in falling growth rate.

site_title: US new home sales race to near nine-year high in July
summary: US single-family home sales surged 12.4% in July to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 654,000 units, the highest level since October 2007. This marks a significant increase from economists' forecasts and boosts the housing market outlook. Sales rose 31.3% from a year ago, driven by rising home values, low mortgage rates, and a shortage of previously owned houses. Despite robust sales, housing starts remain a concern, and builders will need to ramp up construction activity to meet demand.

site_title: JP Morgan changes ECB call after eurozone business growth data
summary: JP Morgan revised its expectations for the European Central Bank (ECB), no longer anticipating a rate cut or extension of its bond-buying program in September. The change comes after better-than-expected eurozone business growth data, as Markit's flash composite Purchasing Managers' Index edged up to a seven-month high in August. JP Morgan still expects the ECB to extend quantitative easing by nine months to December 2017, but now expects this decision to be announced at a later meeting.

site_title: Lack of safety culture a cause of disasters
summary: The Interferry conference in Manila will focus on ferry safety, with key statistics showing that human error is the primary cause of accidents and deaths. The conference aims to improve domestic ferry safety in developing nations, with speakers from regional authorities, naval architects, and industry experts discussing the reasons and remedies for life-threatening incidents. Research by Neil Baird shows that over 90% of accidents and deaths are directly attributable to human error, rather than structural or mechanical issues, and that improved safety measures can be achieved without huge expense.

images.alt_text: Ferry safety, or the lack of it at times, is an important issue in this region. It is also one that has been pursued energetically by the global ferry industry trade association Interferry.

site_title: Tiong Woon falls into the red for FY2016
summary: Tiong Woon Corporation reported a net loss of S$9.7 million in FY2016, down from a net profit of S$12.0 million in FY2015. Revenue declined 4% to S$139.4 million due to a fall in contributions from key segments. Foreign exchange losses and a higher impairment charge on trade receivables contributed to the loss. Operating expenses increased 32%, while finance expenses rose 409% due to currency translation losses. The company declared a final dividend of 0.2 cent per share.

site_title: Indonesia expects slower growth in direct investment this year: official
summary: Indonesia's investment board chief, Thomas Lembong, expects slower growth in direct investment this year, with a 12-14% annual growth rate, down from 17.8% in 2015. The country lost out to Vietnam in regional competition to attract funds. Indonesia's total direct investment from foreign and local investors is expected to reach $33.7 billion this year. To improve its investment climate, the government will review and drop regulations, and monitor permit handling in provinces with the most investment. The country's growth forecast has been trimmed to 4.9-5.3% due to a $10 billion spending cut.

site_title: Halcyon Agri makes offer for GMG; RHB Securities named GMG's independent financial adviser
summary: Halcyon Agri Corporation made a voluntary conditional general offer for shares of GMG Global, with RHB Securities Singapore as the independent financial adviser. The deal is part of a multi-part agreement between Halcyon Agri, Sinochem International, and GMG to merge rubber assets, creating the world's largest rubber supply chain manager. Minority shareholders of GMG have complained about the offer being undervalued.

site_title: AirAsia X posts quarterly profit on rise in passenger traffic
summary: AirAsia X, a Malaysian long-haul budget airline, posted a quarterly profit of RM1.0 million, a significant turnaround from a loss of RM132.9 million in the same period last year. Revenue rose 35% to RM883.2 million, driven by a 27% increase in passenger traffic and a 7% boost in load factor to 75%. The airline's forward bookings and average fares are also better than last year, indicating a promising third quarter.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 8 points to close at 1,683.07, with 1.84 billion lots valued at RM1.74 billion traded. The market saw 263 gains and 579 losses.

site_title: Volkswagen says reaches deal with suppliers to resume production
summary: Volkswagen has reached a deal with suppliers Cartrim and ES Guss to resume production at several halted plants. The stoppage, caused by negotiations with suppliers, began after Volkswagen halted production due to the suppliers' refusal to meet production demands. The deal allows the group to restart deliveries and prepare plants to resume production step-by-step.

site_title: Iran signals more willingness for Opec action to boost oil price
summary: Iran is signaling its potential support for joint Opec action to boost oil prices, amid efforts to revive a global production freeze deal. After boosting output following sanctions lifting in January, Iran had refused to join a previous Opec-Russia production stabilization attempt. However, sources suggest Tehran is now more willing to reach an understanding with other oil producers, potentially aiding the revival of a global deal next month.

site_title: Update: Singapore's July inflation at -0.7%, core inflation at 1%
summary: Singapore's July inflation rate remains at -0.7%, its 21st consecutive month in negative territory, matching June's reading. Core inflation, excluding accommodation and private transport costs, eased to 1% from 1.1% in the previous month. The low inflation rate is attributed to a decline in retail prices.

site_title: Hong Kong shares end flat, Shanghai stocks edge up
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended flat on Tuesday, despite the Hang Seng Index edging up 1.02 points to close at 22,998.93. Shanghai stocks, however, edged up 0.16%, while the Shenzhen Composite Index gained 0.27%. The flat performance followed another heavy sell-off in the oil market, which again dragged down energy firms.

site_title: Local interest rates fall to 12-month low amid Singapore dollar strength
summary: Singapore's interest rates have fallen to a 12-month low amid a strong Singapore dollar. The three-month Sibor rate is now at 0.87192%, a 30% drop from its January high of 1.254%. The three-month SOR rate has also plummeted to 0.75448%, a 60% decline from its January high. This decline is attributed to the Singapore dollar's strength, attracting inflows and reducing borrowing costs.

site_title: Delong plans to go into investment business, buy into China clothing design firm
summary: Delong Holdings, a Beijing-based steel manufacturing and trading group, plans to diversify into the investment business. The company will invest in companies and provide seed and mezzanine capital to private companies with growth potential. Delong's investment business will be evaluated on its own merits, and the company will acquire a 2% stake in Chinese clothing design firm Qingdao Kutesmart Co Ltd for 60 million yuan. This investment aims to leverage Qingdao Kutesmart's growth potential and expand Delong's network of contacts and business opportunities.

site_title: SembMarine to acquire remaining 15% of PPL Shipyard for US$115m
summary: SembMarine is acquiring the remaining 15% of PPL Shipyard for US$115 million in cash, making PPLS a wholly-owned subsidiary. This acquisition enables SembMarine to optimally manage PPLS' business and resources, aligning corporate strategies for sustainable returns. SembMarine first acquired an 85% stake in PPLS in 2003, having previously held a 50% stake in 2001.

images.alt_text: SEMBCORP Marine (SembMarine) is acquiring the 15 per cent of PPL Shipyard (PPLS) that it doesn't already own for US$115 million in cash, making the vessel design and construction firm a wholly-owned subsidiary of the group.

site_title: Hedge funds eye Japan stocks again after mauling by wrong-way yen bets
summary: Hedge funds are considering investing in Japanese stocks again after suffering losses from betting on a weaker yen earlier this year. Despite the yen's recent surge, some funds see Japanese stocks as attractive due to market repricing. Average losses for hedge funds in the first seven months of the year were 4.2%, with some funds adjusting their strategies to include big data and long-short approaches. Japan's economic growth stalled in the second quarter, and market watchers expect the Bank of Japan to ease policy further, potentially benefiting the yen and Japanese stocks.

site_title: Sharp to review TV licensing deals to boost global presence
summary: Sharp Corp will review its TV brand licensing deals in Europe and the Americas to boost its global presence under Taiwan's Foxconn. Sharp exited its money-losing TV business in these markets, licensing its brand to Hisense Group in the Americas and Universal Media Corp Slovakia in Europe. Sharp aims to make profits by leveraging Foxconn's procurement power and client network. The review follows a report that Sharp will dispatch officials for negotiations to buy back its US and European TV business.

images.alt_text: Japanese electronics maker Sharp Corp said Tuesday it will review its TV brand licensing deals overseas in an effort to boost its global presence under the aegis of Taiwan's Foxconn.

site_title: UK manufacturing export orders highest in 2 years after Brexit vote
summary: UK manufacturing export orders reached their highest level in two years in August, boosted by the post-Brexit fall in sterling. The Confederation of British Industry survey showed export orders improved to -6, while output expectations rose to +11. Average prices manufacturers expected to charge also rose to +8, the highest since February 2015. However, the weaker pound's impact on costs and prices was noted, with the CBI's Anna Leach saying it's a "double-edged sword" for manufacturers.

site_title: Sterling rises above US$1.32 as speculators trim unfavourable bets
summary: Sterling rose to a three-week high against the US dollar, surpassing US$1.32, as speculators cut short bets against it. The Commodity Futures Trading Commission reported record-high net short positions of 94,238 contracts in the week to Aug 16. Traders said a "short squeeze" occurred, with stop-loss orders above US$1.32 being triggered, but predicted the rise would be temporary, stalling around US$1.33/34.

site_title: SGX issues trading query to China Aviation Oil
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has issued a trading query to China Aviation Oil (CAO), the second query in four months. The stock was down 6% or 9.5 Singapore cents to S$1.32 as of 4pm Tuesday, with over six million shares changing hands. This is the third trading query issued by SGX this week, following queries to Magnus Energy and New Silkroutes Group.

site_title: China refiners, petrochemical companies to propose CO2 benchmarking plan
summary: China's oil refining and petrochemical companies will propose a plan to benchmark their carbon dioxide emissions, a step toward setting up an emissions market for the sector. The China Petroleum and Chemical Industry Federation plans to make the proposal by September, with 2,400 companies in the sector expected to be affected. The benchmarks will be used to set CO2 emissions caps for these companies, which account for up to 70% of the sector's emissions. China aims to bring in 8,000 companies into its national carbon trading program by 2025.

site_title: Singapore shares close with gentle gain
summary: The Straits Times Index rose 9.24 points to 2,850.43, driven by gains in Singapore banks and telcos, amidst low trading volume of 1.3 billion units worth S$735 million. Losers outnumbered gainers 184 to 170. This marks a gentle gain, following a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Big China cities could see renewed home price spikes as housing glut eases: Xinhua
summary: China's biggest cities may see a further spike in home prices as inventories of unsold homes fell sharply in July, according to an industry report. Unsold new homes in first-tier cities dropped 4% from the previous month, while those in second- and third-tier cities fell 0.5% and 1.2%, respectively. Analysts predict it could take 10 months to move the remaining 244.8 million square meters of unsold homes in 35 major cities, potentially driving prices up in the third quarter.

images.alt_text: China's biggest cities could see a further spike in home prices after inventories of unsold homes fell sharply in July, state news agency Xinhua reported on Tuesday, citing an industry report.

site_title: German private sector growth slows in August: PMI
summary: German private sector growth slowed in August, with Markit's flash composite Purchasing Managers' Index falling to 54.4 from 55.3 in July, below the 55.0 forecast. Despite this, the reading remains above the 50 line separating growth from contraction, indicating continued expansion. This suggests Germany's economy will continue to grow in the summer months after exceeding expectations in the second quarter.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's former president SR Nathan is to have a state funeral service on Friday at the University Church of Christ (UCC). The government has accepted the wishes of SR Nathan and his family for the funeral arrangements. Meanwhile, the Singapore Exchange (SGX) has imposed a moratorium on its minimum trading price (MTP) requirement to consider adding a market capitalisation test. Local interest rates have fallen to a 12-month low, with the three-month Sibor rate at 0.87192%. Singapore's July inflation rate remained negative at -0.7%, and the SGX has issued a trading query to China Aviation Oil.

site_title: SPH unveils new integrated marketing division with changes in senior management
summary: SPH unveils an integrated marketing division, merging sales and marketing staff across various platforms. The new division, led by Elsie Chua as group chief marketing officer, aims to offer effective media solutions to advertisers and partners. This move is expected to position SPH better in the market. Senior management changes also include Alan Chan as group CEO. The new division incorporates print, digital, radio, and out-of-home platforms.

images.alt_text: SINGAPORE Press Holdings (SPH) has unveiled its new integrated marketing division to bring together sales and marketing staff across various platforms and changes in the senior management team helming it.

site_title: AusGroup to cease Singapore fabrication and manufacturing businesses
summary: AusGroup, a Singapore-listed company, has decided to cease its Singapore fabrication and manufacturing businesses due to a prolonged adverse business environment and pressure from the upstream oil and gas industry. The company expects to report a net loss for the fourth quarter ended June 30, 2016. Further reductions in capital expenditure have impacted its Singapore businesses, leading to the decision.

site_title: Philippines to fast-track approval of more infrastructure projects
summary: The Philippine government plans to fast-track the approval of infrastructure projects worth 5 billion pesos (S$145.18 million) or less, aiming to quicken the process and boost investment in the country. This change, announced by the National Economic and Development Authority, will focus on smaller projects in regions outside of Metro Manila. The move is part of the government's efforts to overhaul the country's creaky infrastructure with new roads, bridges, airports, and trains.

site_title: Eurozone business growth stable in August; no Brexit hit yet
summary: Eurozone private business activity remained stable in August, with the Markit composite Purchasing Managers' Index reaching a seven-month high of 53.3. This indicates a 0.3% expansion in GDP this quarter. However, new order growth slowed to its weakest since early 2015, and service firms are less optimistic about the year ahead. The economic repercussions of the UK's Brexit vote appear to be confined to Britain, with the main trading partner showing no significant impact. The European Central Bank remains under pressure to announce more easing measures to address inflation concerns.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares end lower, snapping two-day rally
summary: Tokyo shares ended lower on Tuesday, snapping a two-day rally, as energy firms were hit by a drop in oil prices and low-volume trading. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.61% to 16,497.36, while the Topix index lost 0.47% to 1,297.56. This marks the end of a brief rebound from a three-day decline.

site_title: SGX suspends minimum trading price rules to consider addition of market cap test
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has suspended its minimum trading price (MTP) rules to gather feedback on a proposal to add a market capitalization test to existing criteria. Under the new rule, companies with share prices below 20 Singapore cents would only be added to the MTP watch list if their market capitalization is below $40 million. This change aims to improve the MTP system and provide more clarity for listed companies. The review frequency for both the MTP and Financial Entry watch lists will also be lengthened.

site_title: The 7-course tasting menu that will leave you wanting more
summary: Anglo, a London restaurant, offers a 7-course tasting menu for £45 (S$78) with wine pairing for an additional £25. Chef-patron Mark Jarvis's menu features modern British cuisine with local, seasonal ingredients, and is praised for its clean flavors, balanced dishes, and exceptional value. The restaurant, with a stripped-down setting, serves small plates that are visually appealing and easy to eat. Anglo is expected to gain Michelin recognition, and diners are advised to book a tasting menu before prices rise.

site_title: Shanghai envisages financial centre with capped population
summary: Shanghai has released a draft development plan for 2040, aiming to cap the permanent population at 25 million, down from 24.2 million in 2015. The plan seeks to boost the financial industry to 20% of the city's economic output and increase the supply of small and medium-sized apartments and rental housing. Authorities plan to limit land supply and handle 160-180 million airport passengers annually. The plan aims to address the city's lacklustre growth, driven by declining land sales, foreign investment, and exports, and inefficient land use.

site_title: MinLaw, IPOS seek public feedback on proposed changes to copyright regime
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Law and Intellectual Property Office are seeking public feedback on proposed changes to the country's copyright regime. The changes aim to keep pace with modern technological developments, supporting creativity and innovation. Key proposals include giving creators ownership of certain works, a right of attribution, and allowing not-for-profit schools to use digital tools and the internet for educational purposes. The public has until October 24 to submit their views on the proposed changes.

site_title: Seoul: Won pares recent losses, stocks edge up
summary: The South Korean won strengthened by 1% to 1,115.6 to the US dollar, recovering from recent losses as investors sold the US dollar on profit-taking. South Korean shares rose 0.4% as Samsung Electronics hit a record high, with foreign investors buying 45.2 billion won worth of Kospi shares. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) closed at 2,049.93 points.

site_title: BOJ may apply "fintech" to its operations in future: Kuroda
summary: Bank of Japan governor Haruhiko Kuroda announced that the central bank may apply financial technology, or "fintech," to its operations in the future. This move comes as fintech is gaining influence globally in payments, settlements, and financial services.
