The BOJ has established a fintech section to offer guidance to financial institutions seeking new business opportunities, and Kuroda expressed the bank's readiness to lead research and analysis on fintech to promote its sound development and enhance welfare of financial service users.

site_title: New Silkroutes responds to SGX trading query
summary: New Silkroutes Group responded to Singapore Exchange's (SGX) query regarding unusual movements in its shares, stating it's not aware of any undisclosed information. The group will release its full-year financial results after trading hours on Tuesday and a media release on its oil and gas unit's performance before trading hours on Wednesday. The company is exploring business opportunities to enhance shareholders' value, but no definitive agreements have been reached, and no assurance of a transaction is guaranteed.

images.alt_text: NEW Silkroutes Group said on Tuesday it is not aware of any information not previously announced that triggered the unusual movements in its shares.

site_title: Anchorvale Lane EC site fetches 16 bids; top bid from Hoi Hup
summary: A 99-year leasehold executive condominium (EC) site along Anchorvale Lane in Sengkang attracted 16 bids, with Hoi Hup Realty's top bid at S$240.95 million (S$355 per square foot per plot ratio). The 2.1-hectare site can generate approximately 635 homes. Other notable bidders include Wee Hur Development, Robert Kuok's Allgreen Properties, and the lowest bidder, City Developments' unit Bellevue Properties. The site is near Tongkang LRT Station.

site_title: Fraud suspect wanted by China pays US$31m to end New Zealand probe
summary: A Chinese-born businessman, William Yan, has agreed to pay US$31 million to settle a New Zealand money laundering investigation. Yan, who holds New Zealand citizenship, denies any wrongdoing and remains wanted by Beijing over alleged multi-million-dollar fraud. The settlement follows a three-year investigation into alleged laundering of money derived from Chinese frauds between 1999-2001. Yan's assets, including luxury cars and property, have been frozen until the money is paid, and it is unclear if China will seek his extradition.

site_title: Singapore's July inflation at -0.7%, core inflation at 1%
summary: Singapore's inflation rate remained negative in July, at -0.7% compared to the previous year, and core inflation eased to 1%. This is the same as June's reading, meeting market expectations. The core inflation reading was slightly larger than expected, while housing, transport, and clothing segments posted negative year-on-year readings. All other segments showed positive growth, with education experiencing the highest increase at 3.6%.

site_title: US dollar slips as market discounts Fed rate hike
summary: The US dollar weakened on Tuesday as traders await Federal Reserve chief Janet Yellen's speech, seeking clues about US monetary policy. The dollar had surged earlier in the week after hawkish remarks from a Fed official, but its gains were short-lived. The euro rose against the dollar, while the yen strengthened. Analysts expect Yellen's speech to provide fresh insights into the Fed's plans, with some speculating that a rate hike could happen in September. The dollar's weakness is seen as vulnerable, with a speech by Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda later in the day also being closely watched.

images.alt_text: The US dollar broadly weakened on Tuesday as traders awaited a speech by Federal Reserve chief Janet Yellen, which they hope will offer fresh clues about US monetary policy.

site_title: Chinese official defends protest-hit visit to Taiwan
summary: A top Chinese official, Sha Hailin, defended his visit to Taiwan as "open and transparent" amidst protests, with protesters burning his photo and accusing him of promoting Taiwan's unification with China. Sha visited a forum on municipal exchanges, marking the highest-level mainland visit since cross-strait ties worsened under Taiwan's new government. Relations between China and Taiwan have grown frosty since Taiwan's president, Tsai Ing-wen, took office, with Beijing warning against any attempt at independence. The visit has sparked tensions between the two sides.

images.alt_text: A top Shanghai official Tuesday defended his controversial visit to Taiwan as "open and transparent" as protesters burnt his photo and accused him of promoting the island's unification with China.

site_title: New Zealand dollar climbs after RBNZ wrong-foots doves, Aussie off lows
summary: The New Zealand dollar rose 0.5% to US$0.7310 after the Reserve Bank of New Zealand (RBNZ) Governor Graeme Wheeler announced smaller rate cuts than expected, disappointing doves in the market. This move pulled the kiwi closer to a 14-month peak of US$0.7351. The Australian dollar fell to NZ$1.0419, its lowest in a month, as investors await fresh clues from Fed Chair Janet Yellen on US monetary policy.

site_title: Bangkok shrine bomb trial postponed due to missing translator
summary: The trial of two Chinese Uighurs accused of planting a deadly bomb in Bangkok last year has been postponed due to the lack of a translator. Yusufu Mieraili and Bilal Mohammed, who are accused of the 2015 bombing that killed 20 and wounded over 100, are unable to secure a translator as the sole translator, an Uzbeck national, was arrested on drug charges. The trial has been postponed until September 15. The defendants deny involvement in the attack, which many analysts believe was a retaliation for the Thai junta's repatriation of Uighurs to China.

site_title: China's yuan edges higher but depreciation pressure remains
summary: China's yuan edged higher on Tuesday as banks' clients covered short positions following the dollar's easing, but downward pressure on the currency remains. A dealer at a European bank said the yuan's depreciation lost steam, but overall sentiment remains favorable to yuan depreciation. The yuan's short-covering does not indicate an uptrend, and traders expect the currency to continue depreciating.

site_title: Clinton proposes standard tax deduction for small businesses
summary: Hillary Clinton's presidential campaign has proposed a standard tax deduction for small businesses, allowing them to easily obtain tax relief without additional forms. The plan also expands healthcare tax credits and streamlines business licensing processes. Clinton aims to be the "small business president" and has promised to minimize regulatory burdens and guarantee a 24-hour response to small business inquiries about US government regulations. The proposals aim to improve access to financing and support entrepreneurship, with Clinton planning to discuss them with small business owners and hold a conference call.

site_title: Seoul: Won rebounds on US dollar selling, stocks firmer
summary: The South Korean won rebounded 0.7% to 1,118.5 against the US dollar, as investors sold the greenback after a sharp two-session gain. Analysts attribute the move to dollar selling, with the won reacting sensitively to dollar movements. Shares in South Korea were calm, with the Kospi index up 0.2% at 2,045.23 points, as investors await US Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen's speech later this week, which may influence the won's next moves.

site_title: China plans to open up more industries to private investors
summary: China plans to open up more industries to private investors, including oil and gas drilling, to boost investment growth. The government aims to remove "political barriers" and create a fair playing field for private companies. A negative list will specify areas off-limits to private firms, leaving others open to investment. The move aims to counter record-low investment growth by non-state firms and meet the country's 6.5% economic expansion target. The government seeks to generate more channels for private investment and create a predictable investment environment.

site_title: Australian unearths 'beast' of a truffle
summary: An Australian, Stuart Dunbar, discovered what is believed to be the largest black truffle in the country, weighing 1,511 grams, in his property in Victoria. The truffle was discovered after warmer weather ripened its aroma, prompting Dunbar to start digging last Thursday. He had no idea of the truffle's size until it was fully removed from the earth after a 45-minute excavation. The find is considered a world-beater and could potentially be the largest black truffle ever discovered in Australia.

site_title: Clinton ready for 'wacky' debate with Trump
summary: Hillary Clinton is preparing for the upcoming presidential debates with Donald Trump, joking about the "wacky stuff" she might encounter. Trump has suggested he may not attend all three debates, but the events could provide a chance to break through with undecided voters. Clinton has been targeted by Trump's barbs, including descriptions of her as "crooked" and vague health concerns. Despite the challenges, Clinton is drawing on her experiences to prepare for the debates.

site_title: Oil extends biggest loss in three weeks
summary: Oil prices extended their biggest loss in three weeks, falling as much as 1.7% in New York after declining for the first time in eight days. Crude stockpiles likely dropped by 1 million barrels last week, and the Nigerian government's proposal to end hostilities may be viewed with caution by analysts. Oil rose 20% just less than three weeks ago, entering a bull market, but prices may continue to decline due to ample supply. West Texas Intermediate fell to $46.62 a barrel, while Brent fell 1.3% to $48.51 a barrel.

images.alt_text: Oil extended declines after the biggest loss in three weeks before weekly US crude inventory data and as the market awaits comment from the Nigerian government on a proposal by militants to end hostilities.

site_title: Obama, Biden meet Costa Rica's President, discuss steps to protect migrants
summary: President Barack Obama and Vice President Joe Biden met with Costa Rica's President Luis Guillermo Solis to discuss steps to protect migrants in Central America. The leaders commended Costa Rica for its "protective transfer arrangement" with the UN and IOM to provide temporary safe haven for up to 200 migrants. The meeting aimed to improve security and governance in the region.

site_title: China's state construction giants to merge
summary: China's state construction giant, China National Building Materials Group Corp (CNBM), will acquire smaller rival China National Materials Corp (Sinoma) after government approval. The deal is part of China's plan to revamp its state sector, aiming to create globally competitive multinationals. CNBM, the country's largest construction materials producer, will merge with Sinoma to form a new entity with over 500 billion yuan in assets. The move aims to eliminate duplication, waste, and inefficiency in the sector, addressing concerns over plunging profits, soaring debt, and chronic inefficiency.

site_title: SGX issues trading queries to Magnus Energy, New Silkroutes
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has issued trading queries to Magnus Energy and New Silkroutes Group for "unusual movements" in their counters, the second query for Magnus Energy in four months. Magnus Energy's shares were the most heavily traded, with 318.8 million shares changing hands, after topping the list of most active counters by volume in early-morning trade. The queries are aimed at addressing the unusual trading activity.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened 6.35 points lower on Tuesday at 1,684.72, with 89 losers outnumbering 50 gainers. The market saw a lower trading volume of 29.5 million lots worth RM10 million.

site_title: Foreign leaders, diplomats, local organisations pay tribute to the late SR Nathan
summary: Singapore's former and longest-serving president, SR Nathan, died on Monday night after suffering a stroke. Foreign leaders, diplomats, and local organisations have paid tribute to him, including Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak and a US State Department spokesman. Condolences poured in from around the world, with a video message from the US expressing sympathy to Mr Nathan's family and the people of Singapore. A large number of people visited the Istana to pay their respects and pen tributes to the late president.

site_title: VW, suppliers struggle to resolve dispute in marathon talks
summary: Volkswagen and two of its suppliers, part of Prevent DEV group, engaged in marathon talks to resolve a contract dispute. The negotiations, spanning over 13 hours, failed to yield a breakthrough agreement. The dispute affects about 28,000 workers at six German factories, resulting in halted production of the Golf and Passat models, as well as assembly of engines, gearboxes, and emissions systems. The conflict threatens to cost VW thousands of vehicles in lost output this week. The two sides continue to seek a solution without elaborating on the details.

site_title: VPN technology being reviewed as part of proposed changes to Copyright Law
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Law is reviewing the legality of virtual private network (VPN) technology as part of proposed changes to the Copyright Law. VPNs allow users to circumvent technological protection measures and access unauthorized content from overseas. The review aims to determine whether VPNs should be considered a legitimate means of accessing copyrighted content or if they should be restricted. The proposed revisions to the Copyright Law are part of a broader effort to address issues related to copyright infringement and online content access. The outcome of the review is expected to have implications for internet users and content providers.

site_title: Australia shares close up, NZ hits another record
summary: Australia's shares rose 0.7% to a 38.74-point gain, reaching 5553.8, driven by strong results from several large companies. New Zealand's benchmark index reached an all-time high of 7467.33, up 0.07%. The gains followed better-than-expected company results.

site_title: Paris tourism lost 750m euros after attacks
summary: Paris's tourism industry suffered a 750 million euros loss in the first half of 2016 due to attacks, strikes, and floods, affecting 500,000 jobs. The decline in foreign tourists was particularly significant, with a 11.5% drop in hotel stays and a 46.2% decline in Japanese visitors. The situation has put pressure on the French economy, which relies heavily on tourism, generating over 13% of the Ile-de-France region's GDP. The Paris region tourist board has urged for massive investments to protect jobs and set up a relief plan.

images.alt_text: Islamist attacks, strikes and floods kept foreign tourists away from the French capital in the first half of the year and cost the Paris region tourism industry some 750 million euros (S$1.14 billion) in lost revenue, officials said on Tuesday.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks up with overseas markets; Mega Financial keeps slipping
summary: Taiwan's main Taiex index rose 0.6% on Tuesday, following a similar trend with overseas markets. The electronics subindex gained 0.7% and the financials subindex rose 0.8%, while Mega Financial Holding's shares declined 0.2% due to anti-money laundering fines. Despite a recent slump, Mega Financial's shares have fallen nearly 15% since August 12. The Taiwan dollar strengthened to T$31.707 per US dollar, and shares in Foxconn rose 0.4% despite a reported death at its China plant.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares down at open on Tuesday
summary: Tokyo shares opened modestly lower on Tuesday, falling 0.29% to 16,549.82, following a lacklustre lead from Wall Street. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index and broader Topix index also declined 0.30% and 0.29% respectively.

site_title: Amazon working on music subscription service for US$5 a month: Recode
summary: Amazon is reportedly working on a music subscription service for $5 a month, exclusively available on its Echo hardware, and plans to launch it in September. However, it has yet to finalize deals with major music labels and publishers. This cheaper service would be a significant departure from its planned $9.99 a month standalone music streaming subscription, which was also being prepared for launch. The exact pricing, $4 or $5 a month, remains uncertain.

site_title: Indonesia steps up security in Bali after arrest of suspected militant
summary: Indonesian authorities have increased security in Bali after the arrest of a suspected militant, who allegedly planned an attack on the island. A bomb and explosive materials were found at the suspect's house. The move comes after a 2002 nightclub bombing on Bali killed 202 people, and a recent resurgence in radicalism inspired by the Islamic State. Security measures include enhanced surveillance at ports and informal entry points, following a series of recent attacks in Indonesia, including a gun and bomb attack in Jakarta in January.

site_title: China fund managers ramp up stock connect marketing as regulations ease
summary: Chinese investment managers are aggressively marketing Hong Kong shares to mainland investors through stock connect schemes, taking advantage of relaxed regulations. At least 23 Chinese mutual funds have been established this year to buy Hong Kong shares via the Shanghai-Hong Kong Connect channel, a sharp increase from 7 in 2015. The relaxation of aggregate investment quotas allows mainland investors to buy unlimited volumes of Hong Kong listed shares for the first time.

images.alt_text: Chinese investment managers, taking advantage of a significant step to open up investment flows in and out of China, are aggressively marketing well-priced Hong Kong shares to mainland investors through stock connect schemes.

site_title: Apple boosts health while Microsoft revs machine smarts
summary: Microsoft acquired startup Genee to boost artificial intelligence capabilities, allowing for more efficient scheduling of meetings. Meanwhile, Apple acquired Gliimpse, a startup that uses machine learning to manage and share personal medical information, furthering its health focus. Both companies aim to integrate these technologies into their respective services, enhancing user experience and efficiency.

site_title: Singapore July industrial output seen -1.1% month on month: poll
summary: Singapore's July industrial production is forecast to decline 1.1% month on month, marking the third straight decline, according to a Reuters poll. This follows a 2.5% contraction in June and a 0.4% decline in May. Weak global demand is cited as the main factor, with exports to China and the US declining. Despite this, manufacturing output is expected to edge higher compared to the previous year, driven by a comparison against a low base, with a median estimate of a 0.9% increase.

images.alt_text: Singapore's July industrial production is expected to have declined on a monthly basis for the third straight month, a Reuters poll showed, underscoring the headwinds the manufacturing sector faces from sluggish global demand.

site_title: Singapore shares open 0.09% lower on Tuesday
summary: Singapore shares opened 0.09% lower on Tuesday, following the death of former president SR Nathan. The benchmark Straits Times Index fell to 2,838.53, with 304.1 million shares changing hands. Wall Street ended flat overnight, and some active counters included HLH Group, CNMC Goldmine, and Noble Group.

site_title: Deal puts Microsoft apps on Lenovo smartphones
summary: Microsoft has partnered with Lenovo to integrate its apps, including Office and Skype, onto Android-powered Lenovo smartphones. The deal allows patented Microsoft technology to be used in Lenovo and Motorola devices through cross-licensing. This collaboration aims to enable customers worldwide to be more productive and connected, as Lenovo ships millions of Android-powered devices in the next several years.

site_title: Brazil's Rousseff faces final impeachment battle
summary: Brazil's suspended President Dilma Rousseff faces her final impeachment trial on August 25, with senators expected to vote on removing her from office for manipulating state accounts. Rousseff, a 13-year leftist leader, denies the charges and calls the impeachment a "coup." If two-thirds of senators vote against her, she will be out of office, paving the way for her replacement, Michel Temer. Rousseff's allies and analysts predict a likely removal, citing her failure to address Brazil's recession and maintain alliances.

site_title: Australia shares gain on strong earnings; NZ hits another record
summary: Australia's shares rose 0.8% on Tuesday, driven by strong earnings from healthcare services provider Healthscope and major banks. The S&P/ASX 200 index reached 5,557.20 points, led by gains in healthcare and banking stocks. New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index also hit a record high. Despite a weaker overall market, analysts expect companies to continue performing well in the current financial year, driven by a revival in commodity prices and domestic economic strength.

site_title: State funeral service for SR Nathan to be held on Friday at UCC
summary: Singapore's former president SR Nathan will have a state funeral service held on Friday at the University Church of Christ (UCC). His body will lie in state at Parliament House from Thursday to Friday, with the state flag flown at half-mast from Tuesday to Friday.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares down at open
summary: Tokyo shares opened lower on Tuesday, following a lackluster lead from Wall Street and a slump in oil prices. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index fell 0.29%, while the Topix index lost 0.30%. Energy explorer Inpex and refiner JX Holdings both dropped over 2%. The US dollar slumped to 100.07 yen, weighing on exporters including Toyota and Honda. Traders await Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen's speech on Friday for policy direction clues.

site_title: Asia: Shares seen lower as oil slides; US dollar halts
summary: Asian equity markets are expected to decline on Tuesday, driven by weaker oil prices and uncertainty over a potential US interest rate hike this year. Despite Fed officials expressing a willingness to consider tightening policy, the odds of a rate hike remain uncertain. Oil prices fell 3% on Monday, and futures indicate a 51% chance of a rate hike this year, up from 45% a week ago. Markets in Japan, Hong Kong, and Australia also fell, while the US dollar halted its gains after two days.

site_title: CapitaLand to roll out e-waste recycling bins at 10 malls in Singapore
summary: CapitaLand is introducing e-waste recycling bins at 10 of its Singapore malls to encourage recycling. This initiative follows the success of its e-waste recycling programme at Funan DigitaLife Mall, which collected over 32 tonnes of e-waste by the end of 2016. The developer is also launching an e-waste collection drive at eight of its office properties from August 2016 to December 2016. This move aims to increase e-waste recycling efforts and make a natural progression of its waste-recycling journey.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SGX, SATS, Ezra, Lippo Malls
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) has received unanimous support from the Baltic Exchange's board for its proposed acquisition, with 74% of total votes in favor. The acquisition requires 75% of total votes and approval from the UK's Financial Conduct Authority and a UK court. SATS has become the first international cargo handler to operate in Saudi Arabia after obtaining a 2.5-year concession at King Fahd International Airport.

site_title: New Zealand central bank expects 35 basis points of cuts: governor
summary: New Zealand's Reserve Bank of New Zealand Governor Graeme Wheeler announced that the central bank expects 35 basis points of interest rate cuts to balance economic risks and generate inflation back toward the 1-3% target range. This follows a 25 basis point cut in early August, which brought the interest rate to a record low of 2.0%. The decision aims to stimulate economic growth while managing inflation.

site_title: Government on hook for China banks' shrinking capital
summary: Chinese banks' capital strength is expected to weaken in the first half of 2016 due to bad loans and a slowing economy, raising the prospect of a government bailout. The largest banks, including Agricultural Bank of China and Bank of Communications, are expected to report a 0.7% profit growth, while smaller banks face a capital shortfall of US$172 billion. The government has already started taking action, with smaller, unlisted banks receiving approval for capital raises, and analysts predict a sharp acceleration of recapitalization efforts in 2017.

site_title: Beyond war on drugs, Philippines' Duterte seen setting up economic boom
summary: Philippines President Rodrigo Duterte is gaining high marks from the business community for policies that could engineer an economic surge, despite controversy surrounding his anti-drug campaign. The country's economy grew 7% in the second quarter, its highest level in three years, and infrastructure spending is expected to boost growth. Companies are making new investments, with plans to open more stores and branches. However, concerns remain about the potential for extra-judicial killings and the country's history of strongman leadership.

images.alt_text: Less than two months in office, Philippines President Rodrigo Duterte is getting high marks from the business community for policies that could engineer an economic surge and companies say they are making new investments as a result.

site_title: Worldwide concern over 'too many immigrants': study
summary: A new survey by Ipsos found that at least six out of 10 people in 22 countries believe immigration has had a "negative impact" and 49% think there are "too many immigrants". Similar concerns were expressed in France, Belgium, Russia, Hungary, and Italy, with 46% feeling immigration is causing their country to change in ways they don't like. However, the British are becoming more positive about immigration, with 35% now believing it's been good for the country, a significant increase from 2011.

site_title: Crisis-linked case against Fannie Mae CEO resolved
summary: A five-year-old securities fraud case against Fannie Mae CEO Daniel Mudd was resolved in a stalemate, with no finding of guilt or innocence. The US Securities and Exchange Commission and Mudd agreed to resolve the case, with Mudd contributing $100,000 to the US Treasury. The case, filed in 2011, accused Mudd and six former Fannie Mae executives of approving misleading statements about the company's loan holdings during the 2008 financial crisis. The agreement marks the end of the case, which was inconclusive and resulted in no prevailing party.

site_title: Seven years in waiting, Qantas investors want dividend map
summary: Qantas shareholders, who have waited seven years for dividend payments, are urging the airline to provide a roadmap for reinstating dividends. The carrier is expected to announce record annual profit on Wednesday, driven by lower fuel expenses and gains from CEO Alan Joyce's restructuring. Analysts predict Qantas may restart dividend payments at the end of 2017, with a potential one-off return of A$500 million through a stock buyback. This move could attract a wider group of investors seeking income-generating assets, particularly given the current low interest rates.

site_title: Delta offers pilots 27% raise as contract impasse lingers
summary: Delta Air Lines has offered 13,000 pilots a 27% raise over four years, significantly less than the proposed 37% raise by the union. The airline's offer was made in response to the pilots' contract talks, which have been deadlocked since December 2015. The pilots, represented by the Air Line Pilots Association, have taken an aggressive stance in negotiations, citing the airline's profits as justification for the raise. Talks were suspended earlier this month, with the National Mediation Board citing stalled progress.

images.alt_text: Delta Air Lines Inc. offered its 13,000 pilots a raise of about 27 per cent over four years, significantly less than what the employees have proposed in contract talks that have lingered since the beginning of the year.

site_title: More tributes from the community pour in for former president SR Nathan
summary: Former Singapore President S.R. Nathan has passed away, with tributes pouring in from the community for his generosity and giving spirit. Nathan founded the S.R. Nathan Education Upliftment Fund in 2011 to support education for financially disadvantaged students. He also spearheaded the President's Challenge, which has raised over $160 million for the past 15 years. The late president was remembered for his humility, compassion, and commitment to inter-religious harmony. His family, including his wife and children, received condolences from various organizations and individuals, including the National Volunteer & Philanthropy Centre and The Boys' Brigade in Singapore.

images.alt_text: More tributes from the community pour in for former president SR Nathan

site_title: China's power overcapacity likely to continue for another five years: IHS
summary: China's power overcapacity is expected to persist for another five years due to declining demand growth and a strong pipeline of projects. The overcapacity, which began in 2013, will likely hit coal-generated power the hardest, with average utilisation rates continuing to drop. Environmental policies and the slowdown in the country's economy are contributing factors. The National Energy Administration has already urged the cancellation of planned coal-fired facilities, and power consumption growth has slowed to 6.1% over the last two years, despite a 22% increase in power capacity.

site_title: Oil prices fall as analysts say market still oversupplied
summary: Oil prices fell on Tuesday as analysts attributed the decline to an overdone price rally, citing oversupply in the market. International Brent crude oil futures dropped 18 US cents to US$48.98 per barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude fell 23 US cents to US$47.18 per barrel. Goldman Sachs warned that a proposed oil production freeze would not help balance supply and demand, expecting prices to average US$45 per barrel through next summer. The market's oversupply concerns persist despite a proposed freeze by Opec and other producers.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks retreat at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks declined in early trading on Tuesday, following losses on Wall Street and in Europe, with energy firms hit by falling oil prices. The Hang Seng Index fell 0.31%, while the Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indices also decreased. The declines were attributed to global market trends, with US stocks reaching fresh records despite tariff uncertainty and US-EU trade talks.

site_title: Gold and gemstones pile up in Singapore vault on quest for haven
summary: Singapore's Malca-Amit vaults have seen a 90% increase in gold, silver, and gems in the past year as investors seek refuge from negative interest rates and economic uncertainty. The company's facilities are 70% full, with 90% of its hoard comprising precious metals, and revenue has grown 45% in 2016. Gold has rallied 26% and silver 37% this year, with high net-worth individuals diversifying into tangible assets like precious metals and stones to preserve wealth.

site_title: Pokémon Go added to list of no-go zones for NYC's sex offenders
summary: New York Governor Andrew Cuomo has added Pokémon Go to the list of activities prohibited for sex offenders in the state, as part of a policy aimed at protecting children from online predators. The order, enacted this month, requires approximately 3,000 paroled sex offenders to sign a document stating they will not engage in internet-enabled gaming activities, including Pokémon Go. Advocates for civil liberties have expressed skepticism about the policy, citing concerns it may be overly restrictive and ineffective in reducing the risk of child assaults.

site_title: US dollar stays weak after comments by Fed's Fischer
summary: The US dollar remained steady at a low range on Monday following comments by Federal Reserve Vice-Chair Stanley Fischer, who stated the Fed was close to its policy targets and expects US growth to pick up in the coming quarters. Despite some hawkish remarks, markets remain cautious ahead of the Federal Reserve's Jackson Hole symposium and a speech by Fed Chair Janet Yellen. Analysts expect the Fed to move slowly on interest rates, and markets are looking for signals on this front.

site_title: Ley Choon unit awarded S$35.3m PUB contract
summary: Ley Choon Group Holdings' subsidiary, Teacly Pte Ltd, has been awarded a S$35.3 million contract by the Public Utilities Board (PUB) to lay and install a 2km steel pipeline. The project will improve water supply to residents and is the group's 26th contract with PUB. This win has boosted the group's unfulfilled order book to S$172 million, keeping it busy with projects for the next two to three years. The contract win follows the group's debt restructuring exercise and divestment of non-core assets to focus on its core business.

site_title: CNMC Goldmine glitters
summary: CNMC Goldmine Holdings' shares surged 8.7% in active trading, closing at 56.5 Singapore cents, following its strong second-quarter results and higher dividends. The company reported a 31% year-on-year growth in net profit to US$4.7 million, with record gold output and sales. The market's listlessness was attributed to a wait-and-see approach ahead of the US Federal Reserve chairman's speech, but unusual trading activities in other companies drew attention from the Singapore Exchange.

site_title: Speedo USA ends Ryan Lochte sponsorship
summary: Speedo USA has ended its sponsorship of Ryan Lochte, becoming the first company to officially terminate its endorsement of the US swimmer. Lochte admitted to exaggerating his robbery story in an interview, but claimed he didn't lie. Speedo USA stated they cannot condone behavior counter to their values and will donate $50,000 of Lochte's fee to Save The Children. Lochte's other sponsors, including Airweave and Ralph Lauren, have also taken down references to him. The decision comes amid an ongoing investigation into Lochte's claims of being robbed.

site_title: Li Ka-Shing's Pakistan terminal to start after 5-year delay
summary: Billionaire Li Ka-shing's Hutchison Port Holdings Ltd is set to start its second Pakistan terminal, a five-year delayed project, allowing mega vessels to access Karachi's port for the first time. The terminal's operations are expected to begin before the end of this year, as agreed with the Karachi Port Trust. The move is seen as a strategic investment in Pakistan's growing economy, which is set to complete an International Monetary Fund loan program next month and target a 7% annual growth rate next year. China's planned US$46 billion investments in power plants and road projects also support this expansion.

site_title: Further baht gains may hurt recovery: Thai central bank
summary: The Bank of Thailand is concerned that a stronger baht could harm exporters and the nation's economic recovery. The currency has risen to its strongest level in 13 months due to increased investor confidence and a new constitution referendum. Exports have contracted in 16 of the past 18 months, prompting increased government spending. The central bank warns that further appreciation of the baht could exacerbate these issues, potentially hindering the country's economic recovery.

site_title: US: Wall St little changed as biotechs offset energy drop
summary: US stocks ended little changed on Monday as a 3% drop in oil prices weighed on the energy sector, but biotech stocks offset the decline. The S&P energy index fell 0.9%, its worst performance in two weeks, while the Nasdaq Composite rose 0.12%. Biotech stocks received a boost from Pfizer's $14 billion acquisition of Medivation, with the Nasdaq biotech index up 2%. The S&P 500 is expected to face a rate hike assessment from the Federal Reserve, with traders pricing in an 18% chance for September.

site_title: Russia-Ukraine crisis could tip into 'total war'
summary: Russia's military build-up near the Ukraine border has raised concerns of a potential "total war". Ukraine's 25th anniversary as an independent state was marked by Prime Minister Petro Poroshenko's warning of a "full-scale Russian invasion along all fronts". The tensions follow President Vladimir Putin's visit to Crimea, which was annexed by Moscow in 2014. Moscow has also accused Ukraine of attempting an armed incursion into Crimea, and the death of three Ukrainian soldiers has further escalated the crisis.

site_title: UAE to deposit US$1b in Egypt central bank
summary: The United Arab Emirates (UAE) agreed to deposit $1 billion into Egypt's central bank, supporting President Abdel Fattah al-Sisi's government. The deposit, for a six-year period, comes as Egypt grapples with a dollar shortage and dwindling foreign reserves. The UAE's move is seen as a show of support for Egypt and its economy, with the country already receiving over $20 billion in aid from Gulf countries. The deposit aims to alleviate Egypt's economic challenges and help the country prepare for economic reform measures.

images.alt_text: The United Arab Emirates agreed Monday to deposit US$1 billion into Egypt's central bank in a new show of support for President Abdel Fattah al-Sisi, state news agency WAM said.

site_title: Brent slides under US$50 as Iraq moves to boost output
summary: World oil prices slid, with Brent North Sea crude dropping US$1.72 to US$49.16 a barrel, as Iraq signaled a possible increase in output from Kirkuk's oil fields. A deal between the region and the country's new oil minister could lead to 150,000 barrels a day more shipments. A rebel group in Nigeria also announced a conditional ceasefire and agreed to hold talks with the government, easing concerns about supply disruptions. Oil prices were also affected by the US dollar's gains and concerns about a possible output freeze by Opec.

site_title: Europe: Stocks dip awaiting clear US rate outlook
summary: European stocks declined on Monday, awaiting a key US interest rate outlook from Federal Reserve chief Janet Yellen at the Jackson Hole gathering. The dollar rose against the euro and yen after a vice chairman stated the US economy is meeting its targets and growth is expected to improve. Mining shares weighed on the London market, with Fresnillo and Randgold experiencing significant drops. Despite this, a takeover deal by Pfizer for cancer drugmaker Medivation boosted the Dow Jones index. Investors are seeking clarity on US monetary policy, which has been a topic of division among Fed officials.

site_title: Behind stable jobs data, China grapples with hidden unemployment
summary: China's labor market is experiencing hidden unemployment, with the underemployment rate jumping to over 5% from near zero in 2010, according to Professor Bai Peiwei. Despite stable jobless numbers, millions of workers are left in flux as struggling industrial firms cut jobs. This trend poses pressure on policymakers as China's GDP growth is expected to slow. The rise in underemployment rate highlights the challenges facing China's labor market, which has been marked by a shift towards lower-paying and more precarious jobs.

site_title: Japan, China, S Korea foreign ministers to meet this week
summary: Japanese Foreign Minister Fumio Kishida will host a dinner for Chinese and South Korean counterparts, Wang Yi and Yun Byung-se, in Tokyo this week, followed by an official trilateral meeting on Wednesday. The meeting comes amid tensions between the three countries, including a dispute over the Senkaku/Diaoyu islands and South China Sea territorial claims. The ministers will discuss North Korea's nuclear and missile developments, as well as preparations for a trilateral summit Japan is set to host this year, aiming to boost regional and global peace and stability.

site_title: Industry groups: disruption needs to be embraced
summary: Singapore's business groups welcome the government's emphasis on embracing disruptive technologies, citing it as a positive move amidst global protectionism. Industry leaders believe businesses must transform models, adapt to new environments, and invest in education to navigate uncertainty. They also emphasize the need for businesses to play a role in combating terrorism, including providing employee training and security measures. Despite the challenges, the groups see opportunities for innovation and growth.

site_title: Tech start-up sets sights on surveillance
summary: A Singapore-based tech start-up, Vi Dimensions, aims to enhance surveillance systems by utilizing machine learning software to manage existing security cameras. The company's technology, which is unique and different from existing systems, automates anomaly detection, enabling cameras to detect unusual behavior within normal patterns. While machine learning can reduce false positives, human intervention is still necessary to correct for potential technological shortcomings. Vi Dimensions has secured funding and is conducting trials with various clients, with the goal of improving security and reducing the amount of unused video data.

images.alt_text: Vi Dimensions - whose CEO is Mr Looi (left) and CTO, Mr Tay - has developed a software that enables all video data to be screened easily, compared to the 99% that currently goes unprocessed.

site_title: Indonesia weighs sins of tax dodgers against threat to investing
summary: Indonesia's Finance Minister Sri Mulyani aims to boost tax revenue through a government amnesty program, which seeks to increase the number of taxpayers. The program, which started in July, has already received 83% of assets from onshore companies, including small to medium-sized businesses. The government estimates it will bring in up to $16.8 billion in revenue. However, critics argue that the program's penalties of 2-10% may be too low, and that the government should focus on improving tax collectors' conduct to prevent harassment. The minister aims to balance tax revenue with fiscal incentives and tax holidays for businesses, while restoring confidence in the government.

site_title: Samsung plans refurbished smartphone programme: source
summary: Samsung plans to launch a refurbished smartphone programme, selling used versions of its premium devices at lower prices, to sustain earnings momentum and boost cost efficiency. The programme, expected to launch as early as 2017, will refurbish high-end phones returned by users in markets such as South Korea and the US, and sell them at a discount. This move aims to maximize operating margins above 10% and fend off lower-cost Chinese rivals, while also generating revenue from dated high-end smartphones.

site_title: PM Lee on medical leave until Aug 29
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong is on medical leave until August 29 after experiencing a brief fainting spell during the National Day Rally. He underwent a series of checks at the Singapore General Hospital and was advised to rest due to a vasovagal episode caused by prolonged standing, exhaustion, and dehydration. Lee is expected to return to work on August 29, with Deputy Prime Minister Teo Chee Hean covering his duties.

images.alt_text: Tests showed PM Lee has no heart abnormalities and did not have a stroke; his unsteadiness on stage came from a transient drop in blood pressure, caused by prolonged standing, exhaustion and dehydration.

site_title: Blockchain's backers gather to push governance for technology
summary: Blockchain technology's biggest backers, including IBM and JPMorgan, are gathering to address the lack of governance, a key issue hindering the technology's growth. The meeting, organized by Don Tapscott, aims to create a new standards-setting organization to speed up development and resolve disputes. Attendees include industry leaders from the Linux Foundation, Hyperledger Project, and other organizations, with the goal of gaining insights and concrete actions to move forward. The absence of such governance is seen as a major obstacle to the technology's adoption in finance and other industries.

images.alt_text: Some of blockchain's biggest backers, including people with ties to IBM and JPMorgan, will gather Wednesday to work on the biggest issue hobbling the technology behind digital currency - the absence of grown-up governance.

site_title: Change in appointments at Finance Ministry
summary: Heng Swee Keat has returned to the helm of Singapore's Finance Ministry after a three-month absence due to an aneurysm. Lawrence Wong has been appointed as Second Minister for Finance, while Sim Ann is moving to the Ministry of Trade and Industry. Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam has relinquished his duties as Finance Minister. Heng's return was announced during Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong's National Day Rally speech, and he will focus on next year's Budget and the Committee on the Future Economy's report.

site_title: Broadway unveils disposal deal in response to SGX query on share movement
summary: Broadway Industrial Group, a Singaporean precision components and foam plastics producer, has entered into a conditional sale and purchase agreement to sell its foam plastics and flow control device businesses for S$150 million. The deal is with Broadway Holdings III Ltd, an investment vehicle owned by US private equity firm Platinum Equity. The sale is in response to a query from the Singapore Exchange (SGX) regarding share movement. The transaction is expected to be completed once certain conditions are met.

site_title: Fortescue's profit up threefold, beats analysts' estimates
summary: Fortescue Metals Group Ltd, the world's fourth-largest iron ore exporter, reported a threefold increase in full-year profit to US$984 million, beating analysts' estimates. The company's net income rose due to falling costs and increased margins. Fortescue cut cash production costs 43% and declared a record dividend of 15 Australian cents per share. The company's CEO, Nev Power, expects a positive market outlook, driven by China's urbanization and industrialization, and forecasts prices to trade between US$55 and US$65 a tonne over the next 18-24 months.

site_title: Japanese megabanks face US funding squeeze
summary: Japanese megabanks face a funding squeeze due to high swap costs in the US dollar market, leaving them with few alternatives to secure US funding. Investors have pulled billions from prime money-market funds ahead of new SEC regulations, causing three-month US dollar Libor to hit a seven-year high. Japanese banks, which rely heavily on short-term US funding, are particularly affected, with Citigroup estimating $125-150 billion of maturing commercial paper and CDs by September. Rising funding costs threaten profitability and corporate clients, with some banks exploring alternative funding options, such as issuing US dollar bonds.

site_title: Manila to stick to deficit spending until 2022
summary: The Philippine government, led by President Rodrigo Duterte, has committed to deficit spending until 2022 to ensure sustainable economic growth. The 2017 budget aims for 6.5-7.5% economic growth and a budget deficit of up to 478.1 billion pesos. Finance Secretary Carlos Dominguez plans to submit a tax reform program, which may include lowering personal and corporate income tax rates. The government expects significant economic growth, but faces risks from fragile trade partners, territorial disputes, and potential job losses from mine closures.

site_title: Trump demands closure of 'corrupt' Clinton Foundation
summary: Donald Trump has demanded that Hillary Clinton shut down the Clinton Foundation, calling it a "corrupt enterprise" that has raised over $2 billion since its founding in 2001. Trump claims the foundation is "lined with insiders" and prioritizes donors over the American people. The Republican presidential candidate made the statement in a release, criticizing the charity's practices and accusing it of being the most corrupt in political history.

site_title: Funeral arrangements
summary: Former Singaporean President S.R. Nathan dies at 92. A state funeral service will be held on Friday at the University Cultural Centre at National University of Singapore, followed by a private cremation. The public can pay their respects at Parliament House from Thursday to Friday, and condolences can be expressed through a website, Facebook page, or condolence boards at the Istana. The state flag will be flown at half-mast from Tuesday to Friday as a mark of respect.

site_title: Review of ElderShield scheme seen as timely
summary: Singapore's ElderShield scheme, a severe-disability insurance program, needs improvement, according to Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong. The payouts have not kept pace with medical inflation, and the scheme only covers policy-holders for six years. A review is being formed to enhance the scheme, which covers long-term care costs for those unable to perform basic daily activities. Experts suggest revising payouts, increasing coverage, and offering perks for healthy lifestyles to make the scheme more affordable and sustainable.

site_title: US$ strengthens on Fed official's upbeat comments
summary: The US dollar strengthened on Monday, driven by upbeat comments from Federal Reserve vice-chairman Stanley Fischer, who hinted at a possible interest rate hike by the end of the year. The two-year Treasury yield rose to a post-Brexit high, and expectations for a rate hike in September increased. The dollar index rose 0.3% to 94.756, while the euro fell 0.2% to US$1.1295. Fischer's comments are seen as supporting the dollar, but Fed chairwoman Janet Yellen's comments at the Jackson Hole symposium will be closely watched for further market direction.

site_title: SGX close to allowing exceptions for dual-class share listings
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) is close to allowing exceptions for dual-class share listings, according to sources familiar with the matter. The Listings Advisory Committee (LAC) will unveil ground rules in the coming weeks that will allow dual-class structures only when there are compelling reasons, such as the founders of a company or an uneven ownership structure. The move aims to attract technology companies, including Chinese tech firms, which have been using dual-class structures to retain control. However, critics argue that the arrangement can lead to governance abuses and are pushing for safeguards, such as limiting special rights and ensuring investor education.

site_title: Possible Opec deal to freeze output pushes oil to US$50
summary: OPEC's potential deal to freeze oil output has led to a surge in oil prices, pushing it close to $50 a barrel. Money managers cut bets on falling prices by the most ever, with WTI transitioning from a bear to a bull market in under three weeks. The deal, if agreed, would stabilize the market, but analysts note that a huge surplus of supply remains, and the market remains uncertain. OPEC's biggest members are pumping at maximum capacity, with Saudi Arabia reporting an all-time high production level of 10.67 million barrels a day.

site_title: Startup creates alternative test for cancer
summary: A local biotech startup, Mirxes, is developing a blood test to detect early-stage cancer, aiming to improve detection rates and reduce costs. The test uses microRNAs, which are more reliable than current blood protein-based tests, and is designed to be compatible with existing clinical laboratory setups. With over 90% accuracy in clinical validation tests, Mirxes plans to launch its blood tests for gastric, breast, and lung cancers by 2018 and a pan-cancer screening test by 2021. The company has generated revenue through sales of microRNA products and research projects, and plans to expand globally to bring affordable cancer detection to more people.

site_title: Taiwan's July export orders fall again, but demand from China picks up
summary: Taiwan's July export orders declined for the 16th consecutive month due to weak global demand for technology products. However, Chinese orders increased, indicating a possible recovery in factory activity. Taiwanese tech manufacturers have adjusted their sales forecasts, expecting demand for consumer electronics to pick up ahead of the year-end festive season and the release of Apple's new iPhone. Despite this, the island's economy remains cautious due to global growth concerns.

site_title: Blazing a trail in health wearables
summary: Singapore-based healthcare technology company Cadi Scientific has developed a range of wireless sensing and tracking devices to improve integration with hospital systems. The company's devices can track various bio-signals and are designed to work with hospital electronic medical record systems. Cadi Scientific is working with the Health Informatics Technical Committee to standardize its platform, reducing interfacing costs. The company has also achieved ISO13485 certification and is planning to expand its international footprint, aiming to improve integration efficiency and allow hospital staff to focus on patient care.

images.alt_text: (Seated from left) Cadi Scientific CTO Ng Hon Cheong; CEO Goh Zenton; COO Neo Sian Sheng; and Dr Lim with staff
The ThermoSensor is used to continuously monitor a patient's body temperature and location.
Cadi Scientific contact tracing smart tag, infant tag, mother tag, and baby cot tag which use tag-to-tag communication technology.

site_title: Train derailment in Toronto causes diesel leak
summary: A Canadian Pacific Railway Ltd train derailment in Toronto caused a diesel leak near a residential area on Sunday, with approximately 1,200 litres of diesel fuel leaked. There were no reported injuries.

site_title: Amazon's core tech worth depends on which taxman asks
summary: Amazon's core technology worth is disputed by regulators in Europe and the US, with the company valuing its intellectual property differently in each region. In the US, Amazon pays little in taxes, while in Europe, it claims the technology is immensely valuable, justifying billions in tax-free revenue. European regulators investigate whether Amazon received illegal state aid from Luxembourg, while the US Internal Revenue Service claims the company owes $1.5 billion in back taxes. Amazon defends its tax payments, saying regulators are mistaking high revenue for high taxable profits.

site_title: LaSalle launches fifth Asia Opportunity fund
summary: LaSalle Investment Management has launched LaSalle Asia Opportunity V, its fifth Asia Opportunity fund, with a total fund size of US$750 million. The fund will focus on taking advantage of mispriced assets in Japan and Singapore, with a target market of income-producing assets and repositioning and redevelopment. LaSalle has a successful track record in Asia-Pacific, with over US$10 billion invested in the region, and expects to close its first seed asset acquisition in Japan, the Kishiwada Cancan Bayside Mall, in October.

site_title: Hot weather may wipe out investors' bets on record US corn crop
summary: US corn crop yields may not meet expectations due to hot weather in June and July, which damaged ear development. Despite the US Department of Agriculture's August 12 forecast of a record US corn crop, investors' bets on declines in prices are being put to the test. The 24th annual Pro Farmer Midwest Crop Tour begins this week, providing a closer look at yield potential. Experts warn that ear weights may not live up to expectations, tightening the supply outlook and potentially leading to higher prices.

site_title: Citigroup, Grab to offer credit card deal
summary: Citigroup has partnered with ride-hailing app Grab to allow credit card holders to use points to pay for rides in Singapore, starting from September. This is the first time Citigroup has integrated its credit cards with a transportation app. The partnership aims to provide cashless payment options for underbanked populations in South-east Asia, with Grab's existing partnerships with other firms, such as Bank Mandiri and Alipay. The move is part of Citigroup's broader strategy to tap into the vast networks of customers built up by ride-hailing apps in the region.

site_title: Heathrow expansion likely to win govt backing, says CEO
summary: UK Prime Minister Theresa May's decision to delay a new nuclear plant backed by China may lead to government backing for London Heathrow Airport's expansion, with CEO John Holland-Kaye stating that the UK will avoid fueling tension with China. The government seeks to support the economy post-Brexit, and Heathrow expansion is seen as a vital infrastructure project. A decision is expected by October, with Gatwick Airport also proposed for expansion, but Holland-Kaye notes that both options are unrealistic.

images.alt_text: Mr Holland-Kaye says that he expected Ms May's new government to decide on an expansion of Heathrow or Gatwick Airport by middle to late October.

site_title: GST refunds: 98% within 30 days
summary: IRAS assures businesses and the public that GST refunds are processed efficiently, with over 98% of claims refunded within 30 days of receipt. Selective audits are conducted to prevent mistakes and fraud, with the option for businesses to appeal through the Goods and Services Review Board. In cases of incomplete information, interest is paid within three months, and existing channels for objections and dispute resolution are available.

site_title: Typhoon grounds more than 400 flights across Japan
summary: Typhoon Mindulle made landfall near Tokyo, causing over 400 flight cancellations across Japan, with heavy rain and winds of up to 180 km/h. The storm's impact was largely limited to low-lying areas, with no immediate reports of casualties or significant damage. Most major commuter train services, including bullet trains, operated normally, but some lines experienced temporary delays and stoppages. The storm also affected flights to and from Tokyo's Haneda airport, with Japan Airlines and All Nippon Airways cancelling 185 and 112 domestic flights, respectively.

site_title: Four pairs of art frenemies, egging each other on to greatness
summary: A new book, "The Art of Rivalry," by Pulitzer Prize-winning art critic Sebastian Smee, explores the creative tensions in four friendships between artists, including Manet and Degas, Matisse and Picasso, de Kooning and Pollock, and Freud and Bacon. Smee examines how these tensions led to stylistic breakthroughs and the impact on the Modernist movement. The book reveals that artists often envied each other's boldness and impulsiveness, with Picasso and Matisse engaging in a period of intense influence that propelled them to artistic giants. Smee's analysis offers a nuanced understanding of the complex relationships between artists and their work.

images.alt_text: Smee's The Art of Rivalry is part mini-biographies, part broader art history.

site_title: Nomura to resume hiring of US bankers after cost cuts
summary: Nomura Holdings Inc plans to resume hiring US bankers after implementing cost cuts, aiming to boost its investment banking business in the US market. Chief Operating Officer Tetsu Ozaki expects rising merger and stock offering volumes, with the brokerage targeting around 20 new hires to cover various industries. This move follows a round of cost cuts and comes as the Tokyo-based firm prioritizes the US market, which remains a key focus area for Japan's largest brokerage.

site_title: Major Aussie banks switching from US money markets to longer-term bonds
summary: Australia's major banks, including Westpac, have sold $30.1 billion of US dollar bonds in 2016, surpassing last year's total of $25.5 billion. This shift is driven by a worsening dislocation in the US money markets, allowing banks to take advantage of attractive hedging costs and lock in low rates. The move is part of a broader strategy to switch funding away from shrinking US money markets.

site_title: Should you charge your phone overnight?
summary: Charging a phone overnight can be done without significant damage, but frequent charging takes a toll on lithium-ion batteries. Smartphones have built-in chips that protect against excess electrical current, but the act of charging itself causes batteries to corrode faster. To preserve battery life, using a charger meant for a less powerful device and avoiding overheating can help. Given the short lifespan of most phones, frequent overnight charging may not be a concern for many consumers, and most people will likely upgrade their devices within two years, before noticeable battery wear.

site_title: Why a delisting makes sense for Sim Lian
summary: Sim Lian Group, a Singaporean property construction and development company, is considering delisting from the Singapore Exchange due to persistent undervaluation and poor trading liquidity of its stock. The company's founders may privatize the company for approximately S$213 million, which is less costly than staying listed. Sim Lian has a diversified portfolio, including overseas properties, and its earnings are expected to become less susceptible to swings in the future. The company's exit from the bourse is imminent, with no substantial shareholders other than the Kuik family members and related parties holding 80.36% of the outstanding shares.

site_title: Baltic Exchange board fully in favour of acquisition by SGX
summary: The Baltic Exchange board has unanimously recommended shareholders vote in favour of its acquisition by Singapore Exchange (SGX). The proposed deal, valued at £87 million, includes £160.41 in cash and a special dividend for each share. SGX has received 74% of shareholder support, with the transaction contingent on approval from the Financial Conduct Authority and a UK court sanction. The Baltic's headquarters will remain in London, and existing fees will be maintained for at least five years.

site_title: Hunt is on for new yardstick to replace GDP
summary: The US Gross Domestic Product (GDP) is facing a crisis as its relevance is questioned due to its inability to measure modern economies, particularly those affected by technological change and inequality. The traditional metric is deemed "broken in theory" but still working in practice, leading to widespread revisions that threaten policymakers and investors. Governments and central banks worldwide are searching for alternative measures, such as consumption indexes, to better capture economic activity and distribution effects. Despite concerns, some experts argue that GDP is still a useful tool, citing its correlation with happiness and overall economic well-being.

site_title: Sub-Saharan Africa ministers here on learning trip and to woo investors
summary: Ministers from 10 Sub-Saharan African countries arrived in Singapore for a three-day visit to strengthen maritime and aviation links, and explore sustainable development, human capital development, and sanitation. The ministers, including Ghana's Hanna Serwaah Tetteh and Cabo Verde's José da Silva Gonçalves, aim to attract Singapore investments, particularly in transport. The visit will include meetings with politicians, business representatives, and visits to public housing projects and educational institutions, with a focus on addressing urbanization challenges and tapping opportunities for economic growth.

site_title: AXA Tower office space up for sale from S$2,550 psf
summary: AXA Tower in Singapore is up for sale with two office floors of strata space, spanning 25,500 square feet, priced at S$2,550 per square foot. Buyers can opt for individual strata units or the entire floor. The property, owned by Perennial Real Estate Holdings, is slated for extensive asset enhancement works, including a new lobby and retail expansion. The sale is expected to attract strong interest due to the affordable price point, with prices for newer strata office developments in the CBD typically ranging from S$2,800 to S$3,600 per square foot.

site_title: Coca-Cola bottler says S Africa sugar tax may hit profit
summary: Coca-Cola Beverages Africa (CCBA) may close South African plants and see profits halve due to a proposed sugar tax. The National Treasury recommends a levy on sugar-sweetened beverages generating 11 billion rand (S$1.1 billion) in government revenue. The tax could impact CCBA's profit margins, with the company considering plant closures as a response.

site_title: As ridership soars, PATH service disruptions cut deep in New Jersey and New York
summary: The PATH rail line, which connects New Jersey to midtown Manhattan, has been shut down on weekends through December 19 due to service upgrades and the installation of safety devices mandated by the federal government. The suspension affects nearly 7 million passengers, a 3.6% increase from June 2015, and is causing frustration among commuters who must adjust their routines. The PATH is providing alternative shuttle bus services and vouchers for free bus rides, but many are finding the new routes inconvenient and are choosing to change their schedules or weekend plans.

site_title: Rio wraps up challenging Games on upbeat note
summary: Rio de Janeiro closed the 2016 Olympics on an upbeat note, despite a stormy weather, with a Carnival-like party at the Maracana stadium. The city's athletes won two gold medals in football and volleyball, and the ceremony featured traditional Brazilian music and performances. International Olympic Committee President Thomas Bach expressed hope that the Games would leave a lasting legacy for the city's 12 million people, and the Olympic flag was handed over to Tokyo for the 2020 Summer Games.

images.alt_text: Fireworks lit up the night sky while samba dancers and singers performed at the closing ceremony at the storied Maracana stadium.
Fireworks lit up the night sky while samba dancers and singers performed at the closing ceremony at the storied Maracana stadium.
Fireworks lit up the night sky while samba dancers and singers performed at the closing ceremony at the storied Maracana stadium.

Above: International Olympic Committee president Thomas Bach (left) with the president of the Olympic Committee of Brazil and Rio 2016 Organising Committee for the Olympic Games, Carlos Arthur Nuzman.

site_title: In the end, it's all water under the bridge
summary: The 2016 Rio Olympics have come to a close, with most concerns about the event's water quality and Zika virus concerns proving unfounded. Despite initial fears, mosquito populations were low, and no athletes were affected by dirty water. The games saw numerous memorable moments, including Michael Phelps winning his 23rd gold medal and Katie Ledecky setting world records. Notable firsts included Simone Manuel becoming the first African-American woman to win an individual swimming event, and Lilly King speaking out against doping. However, the games were also marred by scandals, including Ryan Lochte's false robbery claim and the Russian doping scheme.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: A wholly-owned subsidiary of Yongnam Holdings is buying three industrial land parcels in Johor, Malaysia, for RM46.7 million, to move factory operations from Singapore. Lippo Malls Indonesia Retail Trust secured up to S$350 million in loans for property acquisitions and refinancing. Eu Yan Sang reported a widened net loss of S$14.1 million for its fourth quarter, despite a 2% revenue increase. The Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore will co-fund sustainability report production costs for listed companies.

site_title: Wing Tai doubles dividend despite profit dive
summary: Wing Tai Holdings has proposed a six Singapore cent dividend payout, double its previous year's payout, despite posting a 35% drop in revenue and a 69% drop in share of profits of associated companies. The proposal comes after the sale of its half-stake in the Nouvel 18 condo development for S$411 million. The company's net profit fell to S$7.08 million from S$150.30 million, but chairman Cheng Wai Keung remains optimistic about China's property market, citing the rising middle class and large population.

site_title: Eight things to mind in leveraging the Schooling Effect
summary: Singaporean swimmer Joseph Schooling's Olympic gold medal has sparked the "Schooling Effect," with brands seeking endorsements from the athlete. To leverage his star power, brands must consider key legal and commercial factors, including having a contract in place, clearly defining the celebrity's responsibilities, and protecting themselves from brand damage. Brands must also define and scope out exclusivity, stay tuned to sponsorship issues, and beware of ambush marketing. Additionally, they should protect ownership of intellectual property rights and decide what approvals the celebrity has over materials.

site_title: Pfizer beats Sanofi to buy Medivation for US$14b
summary: Pfizer Inc has agreed to acquire Medivation Inc for approximately US$14 billion, gaining a blockbuster prostate cancer treatment, Xtandi, which analysts project will generate US$1.33 billion in annual sales by 2020. The deal will boost Pfizer's earnings per share immediately after closing, adding about five US cents in the first full year. Pfizer's shares fell 0.7% to US$34.75 before the markets opened, while Medivation's shares rose about 20% to US$80.57. The acquisition is a blow to Sanofi's cancer ambitions and marks Pfizer's largest deal since buying Hospira Inc for about US$17 billion last year.

site_title: IT accounts for 4.6m US jobs - and most of them are going to men
summary: The US Census Bureau report reveals that the proportion of women working in the IT field has declined to 25% from 31% in 1990, a 6% drop over the past decade. Despite the decline, women hold 4.6 million jobs in the IT sector, mostly in men-dominated positions. The report provides a snapshot of the changing IT landscape since the 1970s, highlighting the ongoing underrepresentation of women in the field.

site_title: Heralding a tougher global tax era
summary: New international tax rules aim to counter base erosion and profit shifting (BEPS), where companies shift profits to low-tax locations to lower their tax burden. The rules, designed to impact multinational corporations, will require companies to rethink their global operations, value chains, and transfer-pricing policies. The changes are expected to have a significant impact on businesses, particularly those in developing countries, with estimated annual revenue losses ranging from $100 billion to $240 billion. The new rules will also increase transparency and compliance requirements, forcing companies to provide more information about their global operations.

site_title: UK still an attractive destination for international real estate investors
summary: UK real estate remains an attractive destination for international investors, despite Brexit uncertainty. Prime Minister Theresa May's government is committed to making a success of Brexit and ensuring the UK remains open for business. The UK's fundamentals, such as innovation, education, and technology, remain unchanged, offering reliable returns. Regional centers like Manchester and Bristol are gaining interest, and the UK government is investing in transport infrastructure to boost development. The UK is poised to continue offering opportunities for Singaporean investors, with a focus on sustainable and intelligent homes and offices.

site_title: FM Global breaks ground on S$80m loss prevention facility
summary: FM Global broke ground on an $80 million loss prevention facility in Singapore's Science Park, set to be completed in early 2019. The six-storey building will house the company's Asia SimZone, a hands-on training facility offering experiential loss prevention education at no cost to policyholders. The facility aims to enhance resilience to risk and provide scientific research-based loss prevention advice to local businesses, partnering with educational and government organizations. The project is expected to be operational in early 2019, with Ascendas-Singbridge constructing the facility.

images.alt_text: FM global president and CEO Thomas Lawson (seventh from left) and Ascendas-Singbridge deputy group CEO, Manohar Khiatani (fifth from right) at the groundbreaking ceremony on Monday.

site_title: China Vanke seeks talks with parties involved in ownership tussle
summary: China Vanke Co, the developer at the center of a battle for control, has sought talks with parties involved in the ownership dispute. The company's board secretary warned of challenges ahead as the protracted tussle creates uncertainty, while a 10% increase in first-half profit was reported despite the uncertainty. The ownership dispute has prompted banks to halt lending and spurred employees to resign, putting Vanke in a "difficult situation." The company hopes to reach an agreement over its shareholding soon, with its shares rising 0.3% in Hong Kong and 1.3% in the yuan-denominated A shares.

site_title: VW, suppliers to hold talks on stand-off over deliveries
summary: Volkswagen is set to hold talks with two component suppliers, Es Automobilguss and Cartrim, to resolve a stand-off over car parts deliveries. The suppliers suspended deliveries in August over a legal dispute with Volkswagen, which secured temporary injunctions to resume deliveries. However, the suppliers have appealed the decision, forcing VW to slash work hours and suspend production of the Golf model. The talks aim to achieve a result through negotiations, but VW may also pursue legal means to resolve the dispute, which is part of the carmaker's ongoing efforts to recover from the emissions cheating scandal.

site_title: Are ageing and the economic slowdown linked?
summary: A new academic study suggests that an ageing America weakens economic growth, shaving 1.2 percentage points off the economy's present annual growth rate. The study, which analyzed US states with fast- and slow-growing elderly populations, found that states with the fastest increases in elderly populations also had the weakest economic performance. The study's conclusions imply that demographics may be a major factor in the economic slowdown, potentially dwarfing other alleged causes. However, other economists have expressed skepticism, citing the study's simplicity and lack of clear explanations for the reduced productivity among workers.

site_title: World cannot afford to ignore the dire straits in the Middle East
summary: Russia has deployed bombers and fighter aircraft from Iran to strike at Syrian rebels, adding to the region's complex conflicts. The US claims the strikes are indiscriminate against all opposition to President Bashar al-Assad, while Russia's intentions remain unclear. The Syrian civil war has resulted in 250,000 deaths, 6 million displaced, and 13 million in need of humanitarian aid. The situation remains dire for the 18 million people still living in Syria, with all major cities devastated. The international community is urged to address the crisis, but a resolution seems elusive.

site_title: Leadership succession takes on fresh urgency as big challenges loom
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong's health has raised concerns about leadership succession. During the National Day Rally, Lee experienced a dizzy spell, prompting a reaction from Foreign Minister Vivian Balakrishnan. The incident has heightened urgency around the transition of power, with no clear successor in sight. The rally's themes, which include addressing global challenges, have emerged as key issues for the next prime minister. The country's future leadership will need to tackle pressing global and domestic concerns.

site_title: Trading ennui sets in as STI closes flat
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) closed flat on Monday, slipping 2.83 points to 2,841.19, amid fears of further fallout in the oil and gas sector and uncertainty over US rate hike timing. Trading sentiments were low due to a lacklustre trading day and the absence of price-moving catalysts. Most Asian markets fell, except for Japan's Nikkei 225 and Hong Kong's Hang Seng. Analysts expect the STI to continue its downward trend, potentially reaching 2,714 in the next one to two months.

site_title: FLASH: Former president SR Nathan dies
summary: Former Singaporean President SR Nathan has died at the age of 92 after suffering a stroke on July 31. He was 92 years old.

site_title: SATS debuts in Saudi Arabia
summary: SATS, a Singapore-based cargo handler, has secured a 20-year cargo handling concession in Saudi Arabia's Dammam, marking the company's largest greenfield investment at S$40 million. The new terminal will handle 150,000 tonnes of cargo annually, more than doubling the current tonnage. The move aims to stem "leakage" of airfreight from Dammam to other airports and provide a direct link with Singapore, enhancing connectivity for air cargo.

site_title: Closing tax avoidance loopholes
summary: The OECD/G-20 Base Erosion and Profit Shifting (BEPS) Project aims to close international tax loopholes allowing corporate profits to be artificially shifted to low-tax environments. In February 2016, the OECD agreed on a new framework allowing countries to join the project. The new forum, the BEPS Associates, will work with the OECD and G-20 members to implement the project and review its implementation. The initiative, led by the G-20, seeks to shut down loopholes facilitating tax avoidance, with OECD Secretary-General Angel Gurría stating that countries worldwide are working together to achieve this goal.

site_title: Sarkozy announces new presidential bid
summary: Former French President Nicolas Sarkozy announced his bid for the 2017 presidential election, seeking his party's nomination. He listed five major challenges for France, including defending French identity, restoring competitiveness, and enforcing state authority. Sarkozy, 61, stated that the next five years will be filled with danger but also with hope, amid an impassioned debate over the place of Islam in French society. His announcement comes ahead of a party primary in November.

site_title: Setting the benchmarks for a new paradigm in dialysis
summary: AWAK Technologies is revolutionizing dialysis with its sorbent technology, enabling patients to have 24-hour, portable dialysis. The company's AWAK PD System is a wearable, automated device that can be worn on a belt or carried in a bag, reducing the need for traditional dialysis machines. This technology has the potential to improve patients' quality of life and reduce fluid usage, with some devices using as little as 6 litres of fluid per session. AWAK is also actively involved in shaping standards for dialysis, with the company participating in international committees and drafting new standards for sorbent regeneration.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Singapore's industrial real estate is expected to undergo significant changes due to the government's push for higher value jobs and off-shoring of low-value operations. Business parks and high-tech areas are predicted to thrive, while warehouses remain resilient. Real estate industrial trusts (Reits) such as A-Reit and MINT are recommended for their potential to undertake development activities and diversify geographically.
