The Constitutional Commission's report, which proposes a mechanism to ensure minority representation, has been accepted in principle, with a White Paper and constitutional amendment bill to be published and debated in Parliament.

site_title: Be bold in pursuing your passion
summary: Simpliflying CEO Shashank Nigam, a 2007 Singapore Management University graduate, left a secure job to pursue his passion for airline branding after the 2008 financial crisis. With just seven employees, Simpliflying now works with over 75 brands worldwide, including Singapore Airlines and Emirates. Nigam's success is attributed to taking calculated risks, following his passion, and creating opportunities through hard work. He advises young entrepreneurs to be bold and take the first step, as luck favors the prepared.

images.alt_text: Mr Nigam's insights on airline branding: "With a can of Coke, your brand engagement is two minutes. With Starbucks, it's 20 minutes to an hour. With an airline, it can be anywhere from two to 24 hours depending on how long your flight is. Their respective branding methods are therefore not interchangeable."

site_title: Duterte threatens to pull Philippines out of UN
summary: President Rodrigo Duterte of the Philippines threatened to withdraw the country from the United Nations, criticizing the organization for its criticism of his war on crime. Since taking office, over 1,500 people have been killed, prompting UN and rights groups to condemn the actions. Duterte has repeatedly told the UN not to interfere, escalating his rhetoric against the organization.

site_title: India's new central bank governor has big shoes to fill
summary: India's new central bank governor, Urjit Patel, has been appointed to succeed Raghuram Rajan, who stepped down after a five-year term. Patel, a 52-year-old economist with a background in the IMF and the corporate world, is known for his analytical and persuasive approach. He will face challenges in dealing with India's stressed banking system, inflation, and the media's high expectations for monetary policy communication. Patel has a reputation for being "hawkish" on monetary policy, but his approach will be influenced by the new Monetary Policy Committee, which includes six members with a focus on inflation targeting.

site_title: China Star Food Group receives letter of demand
summary: China Star Food Group received a letter of demand from Cheong Chee Hwa, alleging breaches of a 2014 sale and purchase agreement due to the company's reverse takeover. The breaches relate to the sale of Cheong's shares in China Star Food Holdings. The company is assessing the allegations with its legal counsel and will keep shareholders updated on material developments.

site_title: India taps insider Patel as central bank head, seeking continuity
summary: India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi appointed Urjit Patel, a Reserve Bank of India insider, as the central bank head on Saturday, seeking continuity after Raghuram Rajan's single-term tenure ends. Patel, who will start his three-year term on September 4, aims to keep inflation low and address the country's $2 trillion economy, which is facing a clean-up of bad debts at banks. His appointment is seen as reassuring markets and offering policy continuity, but he may face pressure to adjust interest rates and address non-performing asset issues.

site_title: Q&M's largest shareholder to acquire another 1.19% stake in firm
summary: Q&M Dental Group's largest shareholder, Quan Min Holdings Pte Ltd, plans to acquire an additional 1.19% stake in the company by buying all shares held by Health Field Enterprises (HFE). This move would increase Quan Min Holdings' stake to 57.77%. The company has approved the lifting of a moratorium on HFE's share sales, paving the way for the deal.

site_title: China over-reliant on hospitals, needs more family doctors: WHO
summary: The World Health Organisation (WHO) has warned that China's healthcare system is overly reliant on large hospitals, which will struggle to cope with a growing population and increasing diseases. The system relies too heavily on hospitals for minor ailments, creating long queues and fierce competition. The WHO calls for more family doctors and local medical facilities to meet the challenges of China's ageing population. Despite efforts to overhaul the healthcare system, low doctor salaries and patient mistrust remain significant obstacles. China's healthcare system is deemed unsustainable in its current form.

site_title: Lyft move to sell itself got little traction: reports
summary: Lyft recently attempted to sell itself, with talks held with companies like Amazon, Apple, Google, Uber, and Didi Chuxing, as well as General Motors, which had invested $500 million in the ride-sharing service earlier this year. However, these discussions did not result in a written offer. The effort appears to have garnered little traction, with the outcome remaining unclear.

site_title: Committee to be formed to study how to improve ElderShield scheme: PM Lee
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong announced the formation of a committee to study enhancements to the ElderShield insurance scheme, which provides protection for those aged 40 and above with severe age-old disabilities. The scheme, introduced in 2002, currently has limited payouts and coverage. Since its inception, over 7,000 people have benefited from it. Lee aims to make the scheme more comprehensive and affordable, ensuring it covers more people and provides better protection. This enhancement is part of Singapore's efforts to strengthen its social safety net.

site_title: Man who introduced millions to bitcoin says blockchain is a bust
summary: Stefan Thomas, a key figure in popularizing bitcoin, has expressed skepticism about blockchain technology, citing its rigidity and inability to adapt to changing needs. In an essay, Thomas argues that the technology's reliance on consensus from a large group of developers and miners hinders its widespread adoption. He advocates for a more flexible system, like the internet, where breakthroughs can be deployed by anyone. Thomas' company, Ripple Labs, has developed an alternative solution, Interledger Protocol, which he believes offers more individualized and efficient payment options.

images.alt_text: "Harmony and consensus are valuable. But harmony taken to the extreme becomes a detriment. In The Lego Movie (above) utopia, 'everything is awesome' is only on the surface. Behind the scenes, there is tremendous diversity and a rapidly changing world, which doesn't match the established consensus," writes Mr Thomas.

site_title: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong's heart is fine, he did not have a stroke: PM's Twitter account
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong took ill during his speech at the National Day Rally, but his Twitter account clarified that his heart is fine and he did not have a stroke. Instead, he attributed his condition to feeling unsteady due to prolonged standing, heat, and dehydration.

site_title: Going for gold
summary: Singapore's Olympic success hinges on shifting from top-down discipline to self-discipline and self-motivation. Corporates can play a significant role in supporting athletes, providing employment opportunities and customised training, as seen with Deloitte's Ignite programme. More accessible financial sponsorship, including state-led and private backing, is also crucial. Singapore needs to focus on sports that its population is culturally inclined towards, invest in grassroots participation, and create pathways for athletes to excel globally. Developing a culture where sports form an integral part of people's lives and making them a viable career path are also essential.

site_title: Pound seems to be starting to win some friends
summary: The pound, the world's worst-performing major currency in 2016, has started to gain traction after UK economic data showed resilience in the wake of the Brexit vote. Sterling bulls were rewarded with its largest weekly gain versus the dollar in over a month, driven by doubts about US interest rate hikes and positive economic data. The pound advanced 1% to US$1.3047, its biggest gain since July 15, but remains vulnerable to changes in sentiment as the UK prepares to implement its divorce from the EU.

site_title: Japan's aeronautics industry taking major step into the future
summary: Japan's Mitsubishi Aircraft Company is set to launch its Mitsubishi Regional Jet (MRJ) airliner, a 70-90 seat short to medium-haul jet, with a flight test scheduled to take place in the US by the end of this month. The MRJ has emerged from flight tests satisfactorily, and the market for regional jets is expected to be huge, driven by growing demand for inter-city and inter-country flights. Several hundred orders have been placed, and the jet is powered by US Pratt & Whitney engines, with a range of up to 3,000 kilometers. The MRJ is seen as a step towards Japan's ambition to become a leader in high-tech industries, with potential sales to countries like Iran and a headstart over competitors such as Embraer and Bombardier.

site_title: Heng Swee Keat to resume duties as Minister for Finance: PM Lee
summary: Heng Swee Keat, who suffered a stroke in May, will resume his duties as Minister for Finance, according to Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong. Lawrence Wong will be appointed Second Minister to assist Heng, while Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam will stop covering as Acting Minister. Heng was discharged from hospital on June 25 and will undergo a full checkup after the National Day Rally speech.

site_title: Government aware of other plans for terrorist attacks on Singapore: PM Lee
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong revealed that the government is aware of other planned terrorist attacks in the country, aside from the foiled plot to target Marina Bay Sands. The government has taken precautions, including increased patrols and event protection, and shifted or rescheduled events due to threats. Lee also emphasized the need for Singaporeans to stand together and be prepared for potential attacks, citing the threat not only from external but also domestic sources, including jihadist propaganda.

site_title: Olympics broadcasting outlook as clear as Rio's diving pool
summary: The 2016 Rio Olympics have seen declining viewer numbers, with estimates suggesting a global audience similar to the 2012 London Games. This shift towards digital media has put pressure on TV ad rates for future events, as free-to-air television viewers switch to social media alternatives. Broadcasters like Seven West Media have warned of decreased profits, while NBCUniversal reported a 8.6% decline in US viewership. The International Olympic Committee (IOC) is reviewing its business model to adapt to the changing viewing habits, with a focus on digital platforms and emerging markets.

site_title: China's state grid is 'very disappointed' by Ausgrid rejection
summary: China's State Grid Corp of China is "very disappointed" after Australia rejected its bid to buy a majority stake in state-owned power network Ausgrid. The decision was made at a late stage citing national security concerns, despite State Grid following the guidance and conditions set by the seller. The rejection is expected to "severely" reduce foreign investment in Australia and hurt bilateral trade ties. Only State Grid and Hong Kong billionaire Li Ka-shing's Cheung Kong Infrastructure Holdings made binding bids for a 50.4% stake in the deal worth over A$10 billion.

images.alt_text: State Grid Corp of China, the world's biggest utility, "deeply regrets" Australia's decision to stop the company from buying a majority stake in the state-owned power network Ausgrid.

site_title: New capabilities, entrepreneurship and skills to be used in tackling disruption: PM Lee
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasized the need for a strategy to tackle disruption, which he believes will be a recurring challenge. He urged graduates to be prepared and adaptable, as disruption will occur relentlessly. Lee also highlighted the importance of entrepreneurship and developing skills to address disruption, noting that the government will support workers who need to upskill or reskill.

site_title: Peru says no need for new financing, but may refinance debt
summary: Peru's finance minister, Alfredo Thorne, stated that the country does not require additional financing to cover its fiscal deficit, but may consider refinancing government debt to take advantage of cheap credit. The government inherited a "worrisome" deficit from the previous administration and has scaled back its deficit reduction plans. Loans from the World Bank, arranged by the previous government, will help alleviate the need for new financing. Thorne also mentioned that borrowing costs for Peru are currently lower than those in Colombia and Brazil.

site_title: 'Sufficient chance' of BOJ easing in September: Kuroda
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda stated that there is a "sufficient chance" the central bank will add to its easing measures at the September policy meeting. The decision will be based on the results of a comprehensive review, which will be published along with the policy statement. Board members will discuss the economy and financial situation before taking further action if necessary, with Kuroda emphasizing that the bank will not hesitate to act if needed.

site_title: US democrats fear hackers targeted tight Florida races for latest data leaks
summary: US Democrats are concerned that hackers targeting leaked documents in Florida congressional races may be attempting to sabotage their candidates. The documents, obtained by hacker Guccifer2, contain personal and demographic information on candidates, which could damage their chances in competitive races. The hacking is part of a larger pattern of attacks on US political organisations by Russian intelligence agencies, with no indication of similar breaches on the Republican side. The incident raises concerns about the impact on the 2016 presidential election, particularly in key swing states like Florida.

site_title: Zuckerberg sells US$95m in Facebook shares for philanthropy
summary: Mark Zuckerberg has sold approximately $95 million worth of Facebook shares to fund his philanthropic initiative, the Chan Zuckerberg Initiative. This sale marks the first of many planned sales to support solutions for health, science, and education issues. As part of his pledge with his wife Priscilla Chan, Zuckerberg aims to give away 99% of his wealth during his lifetime, with the value of the pledge now estimated at over $45 billion due to Facebook's significant stock gain.

images.alt_text: Facebook Chief Executive Officer Mark Zuckerberg has made his first big share sale to fund his family's philanthropic initiative.

site_title: Viacom power struggle ends with CEO agreeing to exit
summary: Viacom's power struggle ended with CEO Philippe Dauman agreeing to exit, allowing 93-year-old Sumner Redstone to remain in charge. Tom Dooley took over as interim chief operating officer, and Dauman will remain non-executive chairman until September 13.

site_title: City that never sleeps: London opens first night tube
summary: London's Night Tube service launched on August 20, 2016, allowing Victoria and Central lines to operate all night on Fridays and Saturdays. The move aims to boost revellers, tourists, and shift workers, as well as support the city's cultural sector. The service is expected to transport 200,000 people by the end of the year, with plans to extend to other lines later. The launch follows a delay due to staff concerns and safety issues, with additional police presence provided to address potential crime increases.

images.alt_text: Midnight at bustling Oxford Circus Underground station in the heart of London, a band is playing and weekend revelry is only just beginning for some residents of the Big Smoke.

site_title: JPMorgan ends Washington Mutual disputes with FDIC, to receive US$645m
summary: JPMorgan Chase & Co. has reached a settlement with the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp (FDIC) and Deutsche Bank AG, receiving $645 million in exchange for dropping $1 billion in claims related to the 2008 purchase of Washington Mutual's banking operations. The settlement resolves four WaMu-related lawsuits involving JPMorgan and the FDIC, and requires court approval. The deal ends a long-standing dispute over liability for claims arising from WaMu's collapse, which was the nation's largest savings and loan before its seizure in 2008.

site_title: Facebook aims for video-loving teenagers with new app
summary: Facebook has released a new iPhone app called Lifestage, targeting teenagers with video clips about their classmates. The app allows users to create and share video profiles, which can be viewed by other Lifestage members 21 years or younger. The app aims to compete with Snapchat, and once a school has enough users, the profiles become "unlocked" for viewing. The app also includes tools to block and report older users. Lifestage is seen as an effort by Facebook to reconnect with young internet users who prefer other social media platforms.

images.alt_text: Facebook on Friday took direct aim at video-loving adolescents, and Snapchat, with the release of a new iPhone app that allows teens to watch clips about the lives of their classmates.

site_title: Legal spat between Otto Marine and Hoe Leong heats up
summary: Otto Marine and Hoe Leong Corporation are engaged in a legal dispute over an outstanding sum of US$920,000. Hoe Leong claims it has sufficient financial resources to pay the debt, while Otto Marine alleges the company failed to settle its debt. Otto Marine has filed a winding-up petition against Hoe Leong, which Hoe Leong plans to defend. This dispute is part of Otto Marine's efforts to collect debts from various trade creditors following a series of seven winding-up petitions in the last 18 months.

site_title: Credit agencies hold Singtel's rating steady post-acquisitions
summary: Singtel's proposed acquisitions of interests in Thailand and India's wireless markets will have no impact on its credit rating, according to three credit rating agencies. The company will fund the acquisitions mainly through a share placement and internal resources, with analysts largely neutral on the deal. However, one analyst downgraded the stock to "hold" due to expected lower free cash flow and potential risks in the Indian market. Singtel's shares slipped 1 cent to S$4.19 after the announcement.

site_title: Commodities rebound accelerating on China's doorstep
summary: Commodities are experiencing a rebound, driven by emerging economies in South-east Asia, particularly Indonesia, Thailand, Malaysia, the Philippines, and Vietnam. The combined GDP of these nations is expected to rise to $3 trillion by 2020, fueling infrastructure projects that will increase demand for commodities. Steel demand in the region is expected to grow 6% in 2017, driven by infrastructure building, and copper demand is becoming increasingly diversified beyond China.

site_title: Taiwan tea entrepreneurs brew up new twist on tradition
summary: Taiwanese tea entrepreneurs are introducing a high-end modern take on traditional tea brews, aiming to export globally and revive the island's tea industry. After bubble tea eclipsed traditional tea exports, labor costs rose, and the traditional tea industry suffered. This new approach, combining modern techniques with traditional methods, hopes to capitalize on the global demand for premium tea products.

site_title: Singapore's Q2 domestic wholesale trade drops 20.5%
summary: Singapore's domestic wholesale trade dropped 20.5% in Q2 2016, primarily due to lower prices of petroleum and chemical products. Excluding these products, the decline was 15.5%. When adjusted for price changes, the trade was flat, with a 0.1% year-on-year decrease. Eight out of 11 industries posted declines, with ship chandlers & bunkering, general wholesale trade, and petroleum & petroleum products experiencing the largest drops.

site_title: Death toll in Nice truck attack rises to 86
summary: A man has died in a French hospital, raising the death toll from the Nice truck attack to 86. The attack occurred on France's national holiday in July, where a truck drove into crowds, killing over 400 people. Investigators have found no evidence of the attacker's allegiance to the Islamic State, but he had expressed fascination with jihad and planned the attack for months. The attack follows a similar incident in Paris eight months prior, which killed 130 people.

site_title: 4WD good, 2WD better?
summary: The Lexus NX, a luxury SUV, is available in both 2-wheel-drive (FWD) and all-wheel-drive (AWD) variants. The FWD version is priced lower and lighter, consuming 2.5% less fuel and emitting lower CO2 emissions. Although the AWD version is slightly faster, the FWD model still offers the same level of luxury and performance, making it a more affordable option for those who don't need 4WD in urban landscapes.

site_title: US dollar reverses slump as market plumbs murky Fed direction
summary: The US dollar reversed its slump and rose against major currencies, reaching 100.20 yen and US$1.3080 against the pound, and US$1.1324 against the euro. Despite doubts about the Federal Reserve's September interest rate plans, two officials hinted at a possible rate hike. Markets remain uncertain about the Fed's direction, but the dollar's uptick suggests investors are cautiously optimistic about the possibility of a rate increase.

site_title: Europe: Shares suffer worst weekly fall since mid-June
summary: European stock markets plummeted, marking their worst weekly loss since mid-June, with the STOXX 600 index falling 0.8% and posting a 1.7% weekly decline. Uncertainty over a potential US interest rate hike weighed on markets, and the world's largest economy's central bankers will gather soon. The top fallers were Vopak, a storage tank group, and Italian banks, which have faced concerns over bad debts. The market decline raises questions about the sustainability of the current market rally, despite recent short-term gains.

site_title: Jakarta rolls out plan to develop Islamic finance
summary: The Indonesian government has launched a national master plan to develop its Islamic finance industry, aiming to awaken the niche sector in the country. Introduced over two decades ago, Islamic finance has managed modest gains in Indonesia, a country of 250 million people. The plan includes a range of initiatives to boost the sector, marking the latest effort to promote Islamic finance in the world's most populous Muslim country.

images.alt_text: The Indonesian government has launched a national master plan to develop its Islamic finance industry, the latest effort aimed at awakening what is still a niche sector in the world's most populous Muslim country.

site_title: New 'Flash Boys' market IEX opens on Wall Street
summary: The IEX stock exchange, a new market aimed at leveling the field for investors disadvantaged by high-speed traders, opened for business on Wall Street. The exchange features a 350 microsecond "speed bump" on all orders, preventing fast traders from cutting in front of slower orders. 130 broker-dealers have signed up for trading, including top ATS members. The SEC approved IEX's application to turn a private exchange into a public one, promoting competition and innovation. IEX plans to handle all 8,000 listed firms by the end of a two-week rampup, with the potential to disrupt the broader system if it catches on.

site_title: Joint tender to be called for KL-Singapore high-speed rail project
summary: Malaysia and Singapore will jointly call a tender on August 22 to appoint a development partner for the Kuala Lumpur-Singapore High Speed Rail (HSR) project. The partner will provide project management, technical, and procurement advice, as well as develop safety standards. The tender is open to firms with experience in HSR projects and large public-private partnerships. Several countries, including China, Japan, and France, have expressed interest in bidding for the project, which aims to reduce travel time between Singapore and Kuala Lumpur to 90 minutes. Construction is scheduled for 2018-2025.

site_title: FBI probing possible US ties to corruption by former Ukraine president
summary: The FBI and US Justice Department are investigating possible US ties to alleged corruption by former Ukrainian President Viktor Yanukovych, who fled to Russia after a popular uprising in 2014. The probe, led by firms headed by Paul Manafort and Tony Podesta, is examining whether US companies and the financial system enabled corruption by Yanukovych's party. Manafort, who resigned as Trump's campaign chairman, and the Podesta Group have denied being the focus of the probe, but the Podesta Group is investigating potential misrepresentation. The Justice Department remains committed to recovering stolen assets on behalf of Ukraine.

site_title: China's secret lists of 'zombie' borrowers leave banks in the dark
summary: China's regional authorities compile "zombie lists" of state-owned companies deemed too weak to survive, but banks are kept in the dark about the list to prevent them from cutting off financing. This secrecy creates challenges for China's efforts to stem bad loans and carry out an orderly restructuring of its state corporate sector. The move is part of President Xi Jinping's push to steer China away from its investment-led model and address overcapacity in industries such as steel and coal. The lack of transparency raises concerns about the impact on banks and the overall economy.

site_title: US: Wall Street closes down as Nike's gains stand out
summary: US stocks closed down 0.2% on Friday, marking the third consecutive week of decline. Despite this, Nike's shares rose 3% following the announcement of a supply-chain partnership with Apollo Global Management. Oil stocks also retreated, with Exxon Mobil and Chevron down 1.3% and 1.2%, respectively. Wal-Mart shares fell 2% after posting better-than-expected earnings on Thursday. The Dow Jones Industrial Average closed at 18,552.57, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq were down 0.1% and flat, respectively.

site_title: M1 to roll out HetNet, unveils plan for IoT network
summary: M1, a Singaporean telco, plans to roll out its HetNet, a heterogeneous network, by 2017, allowing customers to surf at high speeds of over 1Gbps. The network will be deployed across hundreds of hotspots, including MRT/LRT stations, malls, and outdoor areas, with a peak download speed of 450Mbps. M1 also announced a partnership with Nokia to roll out a nationwide NB-IoT network by 2017, investing over S$50 million in both projects.

site_title: Uber aims for an edge in race for self-driving future
summary: Uber is testing self-driving cars in Pittsburgh, using modified Volvo sport utility vehicles, and has acquired Otto, a startup developing self-driving truck technology. This move aims to upend the shipping industry and potentially bring autonomous vehicles to the market sooner than expected. The acquisition of Otto, a 90-person startup, also brings in former Google and Carnegie Mellon engineers, further solidifying Uber's efforts in self-driving technology.

images.alt_text: UBER'S NEW ACQUISITION: Otto co-founders Anthony Levandowski (left) and Lior Ron head the 90-person startup which includes former Google and Carnegie Mellon engineers focused on upending the long-distance trucking industry.

site_title: Trump pleads for black votes: 'What do you have to lose?'
summary: Donald Trump made a plea to African American voters, telling them "what do you have to lose" by supporting him, in an effort to broaden his support base. Trump claimed Hillary Clinton's policies have harmed African Americans more than any other group. Despite trailing in the polls, Trump held a rally in Dimondale, Michigan, to make his pitch. Trump faces an uphill battle to win over African American voters, who have largely backed Clinton.

site_title: Deutsche Bank whistleblower spurns US$8m SEC reward
summary: A former Deutsche Bank risk officer, Eric Ben-Artzi, is refusing a US$8.25 million SEC reward for blowing the whistle on the lender's overvaluation of a derivatives portfolio. Ben-Artzi expressed concern that the SEC didn't target senior executives despite a US$55 million fine paid by Deutsche Bank last year. The fine penalized shareholders but allowed top executives to retire with their multi-million dollar bonuses intact. Ben-Artzi's decision comes after the SEC settled with Deutsche Bank without pursuing charges against executives.

site_title: BP to Halliburton in 'barroom brawl' as drillers slash costs
summary: BP is slashing costs on its drilling project in the Gulf of Mexico, from a $20 billion initial estimate to a $9 billion price tag. Industry-wide, companies have reduced expenses by $1 trillion since 2015, with oil prices plummeting 60% since 2014. Service providers, such as Halliburton and Schlumberger, have cut rates to stay in business, but analysts predict most savings will be temporary. As oil prices recover, companies may struggle to sustain cost reductions, with only a third of the gains likely to be permanent.

site_title: Aussie banks denied interim approval to jointly negotiate with Apple
summary: Australia's three biggest banks - National Australia Bank, Commonwealth Bank of Australia, and Westpac Banking Corp - have been denied interim approval to jointly negotiate with Apple Inc. to install their own electronic payments applications on iPhones. The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) cited complexity and the need for more time to consult with industry and consumers. The banks claim Apple's restrictions on Near Field Technology constitute anti-competitive behavior, while Apple does not allow third-party electronic payment apps to be loaded onto iPhones. The ACCC will review the full application in October.

site_title: Australia treasurer officially rejects China bids for Ausgrid
summary: Australian Treasurer Scott Morrison has officially rejected bids by State Grid Corp of China and Hong Kong's Cheung Kong Infrastructure Holdings to purchase the country's biggest energy grid, Ausgrid, due to unspecified national security concerns. The decision comes despite China's criticism and a rift between the two countries, just eight months after a free trade agreement took effect. Morrison's decision is seen as a reflection of Australia's changing political climate, following the rise of protectionist lawmakers. The Foreign Investment Review Board's recommendation also influenced the decision, citing national interest.

site_title: Igniting interest, passion in sports
summary: Singaporean swimmer Joseph Schooling's victory in the men's 100-metre butterfly final at the Rio Olympics has the potential to boost interest in sports participation and sponsorship in the country. According to Ashoke Sengupta, managing director of Lagardère Sports, Schooling's heroics can serve as a springboard to increase interest in sports, particularly among young people. Schooling's success is seen as essential for swimming to become a more popular and commercially viable sport in Singapore. His achievement has the potential to inspire a new generation of athletes and fans.

site_title: Wal-Mart draws more shoppers, raises fiscal-year outlook
summary: Wal-Mart reported higher-than-expected quarterly earnings, driven by cleaner stores, improved online shopping, and higher employee wages. The retailer raised its fiscal-year forecast, bucking a trend of weak results from competitors. Sales were strong for grocery items and apparel, but weak for electronics. Online sales growth accelerated sequentially, and e-commerce growth was stronger in the US than in major overseas markets. Wal-Mart raised its earnings outlook to $4.15-$4.35 per share, excluding the impact of its Jet.com acquisition.

site_title: Thai Airways plans to expand, resume plane purchases
summary: Thai Airways plans to expand its operations after a five-year austerity drive. The airline will add routes and purchase new, fuel-efficient aircraft to boost passenger growth. A 10-year plan, set to run through 2027, is in place to achieve this goal, with the aircraft purchases aiming to replace ageing jets.

site_title: Lunar passion
summary: The Cantonese traditional baked mooncake is making a comeback after years of being replaced by modern, "snow-skinned" versions. To achieve the traditional mooncake's signature sheen and flavor, manufacturers use key ingredients like inverted sugar syrup, which requires tedious preparation and a specific ratio of ingredients. Pastry chefs emphasize the importance of using high-quality ingredients, such as lotus seed paste and Chinese olive seeds, and traditional techniques like reverse glazing to achieve the desired texture and appearance. With the resurgence of interest in heritage foods, traditional mooncakes are once again sought after by food enthusiasts in Singapore.

site_title: Square posts job opening, signalling European expansion
summary: Square Inc., a US mobile payments company, posted three new job openings in Europe, signaling its expansion plans in the region. The company aims to capitalize on the growth of small businesses adopting new technology. Square's card reader converts a mobile phone into a payment terminal, a solution that can benefit the European market. This move indicates Square's intention to establish an initial venture in Britain, marking its entry into the European market.

site_title: Concrete beach attracts Chinese to world's largest building
summary: China's New Century Global Center, a 1,760,000 square meter building in Chengdu, is the world's largest by floor space and features a water park with artificial ocean waves, a cinema, ice rink, and shops. Despite initial criticism of its wasteful construction, the complex has attracted hundreds of shoppers and bathers, with 90% of commercial space rented and 8,000 office workers commuting daily. The project is part of Chengdu's bid for top-tier city status and has sparked controversy over its construction links to China's former security chief.

site_title: S Koreans face rate cliff as loans rise
summary: South Korea is facing a surge in personal loans, with borrowers often being rejected by banks and turning to non-bank lenders at interest rates over 20%. This has prompted warnings of a potential economic disruption, with bankruptcies and debt defaults expected to rise. The country's economy is already slowing, and the high-interest loans are exacerbating the issue, with the International Monetary Fund urging the government to address high household debt and reduce poverty.

site_title: Dispute shows challenge to Thiam's strategy
summary: Credit Suisse is accusing five former investment bankers of stealing confidential information and trying to poach colleagues after they left for Jefferies Group LLC in May. The Swiss bank claims the bankers printed out and accessed proprietary information that could be used for Jefferies' benefit. The dispute raises questions about Credit Suisse's push into wealth management under CEO Tidjane Thiam, which may be prompting the departure of bankers sought by other Wall Street firms.

site_title: SembMarine: Provision adequate despite client's bonds pressure
summary: SembCorp Marine maintained adequate provisions for its rig-building projects despite Perisai Petroleum's struggling bonds, which have reached a record low price of 60 cents. Perisai Petroleum plans to discuss redeeming S$125 million securities due in October. The Singapore-listed client faces pressure to redeem the bonds, but SembCorp Marine remains confident in its provisions.

site_title: Fund transfers with just mobile numbers
summary: Singapore's Association of Banks in Singapore (ABS) is working with Banking Computer Services (BCS) to map mobile numbers to bank account numbers, enabling fund transfers without account numbers. Seven major banks, including UOB, DBS Bank, and OCBC Bank, are participating in the Central Addressing Scheme (CAS). A unified point-of-sale (UPOS) terminal will also be developed to accept all major card brands. The move aims to increase the use of the two-year-old online interbank funds transfer system, FAST. The banks have assured that security measures are in place to protect users, including older individuals who may not be comfortable with the cashless society.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Singapore Telecommunications (Singtel) has been downgraded to a 'Hold' by brokers due to its target price of S$4.41, which is below its closing price of S$4.19. The company's second-quarter revenue may be lower than expected, with an operating loss similar to the first half of the year. Meanwhile, NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer has been oversubscribed 9.8 times.

site_title: Latest economic figures in UK boost pro-Brexit economists
summary: The UK economy has seen a boost in retail sales and labor market resilience, defying gloomy predictions. Retail sales jumped 1.4% in July, the best reading since 2002, while jobless claims dropped in July. This suggests the economy may have entered the quarter on a firm footing. Pro-Brexit economists, such as Patrick Minford and Ruth Lea, see these numbers as vindication, while others, like Bank of America Merrill Lynch, predict the data will worsen and prompt the Bank of England to lower interest rates.

site_title: Forecasters pessimistic even as DAX leads Europe stocks
summary: German stocks, as measured by the DAX Index, are expected to slide 7% in 2016, according to 12 estimates compiled by Bloomberg. This marks the eighth time forecasters have cut their year-end targets on the gauge. Despite the DAX's recent gains, strategists remain pessimistic, citing concerns over the European market's performance.

site_title: Relentlessly modern
summary: Industrial designer Karim Rashid, known for his modern designs, asserts that design is not art and art is not design, but rather design provides performance in daily life. With a 30-year career, Rashid has created iconic creations, including the Garbo wastebasket and Oh Chair, and has worked with global brands. He emphasizes the importance of design in addressing human experience and differentiating it from art. Rashid, who has worn many hats, including DJ and artist, believes that his epitaph should read "That I was an inspirer, not a designer." He continues to innovate and push boundaries, driven by his desire to make a positive impact.

site_title: CRCT to buy mall in Chengdu shopping belt for 1.53b yuan
summary: CapitaLand Retail China Trust (CRCT) has agreed to buy the Galleria mall in Chengdu, China for 1.53 billion yuan (S$310.4 million), expanding its portfolio to 11 malls. The six-storey mall, valued at 1.52 billion yuan, is fully occupied and has a 5.4% net property income yield. CRCT plans to finance the purchase with existing cash and debt, with the acquisition expected to be distribution per unit-accretive. The transaction is expected to be completed by the end of the year, with CRCT's gearing ratio increasing to 37%.

images.alt_text: GALLERIA MALL: The six-storey mall in south Chengdu has a gross floor area of about 53,619 square metres (excluding the car park) and 900 car park spaces. As at end-May, it was fully occupied

site_title: Japan manufacturers' mood hits 3-year low
summary: Japan's manufacturers reported their lowest mood in three years, with the Reuters Tankan showing economic growth stalled in April-June. Exports declined 14% in the year to July, the fastest decline since 2009, due to a strong yen and weak external demand. Consumer spending remained sluggish, with private consumption rising only 0.2% quarter-over-quarter in April-June. The yen's strength has taken a toll on spending by foreign tourists, with per capita spending by Chinese tourists falling 22.9% in April-June. The Bank of Japan's stimulus programme is under pressure to boost growth, with a review set for September.

site_title: Neuroscience can help you trade better
summary: A US study published in 2010 found that traders' brain activity, measured by fMRI scans, reveals they unconsciously use "theory of mind" to read others and make trading decisions. This ability to understand others' thoughts and feelings helps traders infer new information and act on it, leading to prices quickly reflecting the information. The study suggests that this "X-factor" in trading can be explained by theory of mind, which is a trainable emotional competency that can be improved through practice and cognitive empathy.

images.alt_text: GETTING A CLEARER PICTURE: Using functional magnetic resonance imaging scans, neuroscientists can identify which brain structures are associated with particular activities.

site_title: Funds avoided losses despite 'Brexit' shock
summary: Hedge fund managers largely avoided significant losses despite the Brexit shock, with some even making money. Macro funds, which take large positions on economic trends, were better positioned to benefit from the vote. Funds that bought put options on British pounds before the vote profited from the pound's depreciation. Some managers, like Borut Miklavcic, stated that the "Brexit" bet was the better market bet, citing underpriced instruments. Managed futures funds also performed well, with trend-following strategies benefiting from the crisis.

site_title: The phone to beat in 2016
summary: The Samsung Galaxy Note 7 is a flagship device that surpasses expectations with its innovative features, including an iris scanner, improved S Pen, and High Dynamic Range (HDR) mobile display. The phone boasts a 64-bit octa-core processor, 4GB of RAM, and a 64GB internal memory. Key features include a water-resistant design, wireless charging, and a larger battery. The device also features a new Secure Folder for private data, a precise S Pen, and a GIF creation feature. The phone is available in four colors and starts at S$1,168, solidifying its position as the phone to beat in 2016.

site_title: Beyond 9 to 5
summary: Three individuals, including the founders of Thevar 2.0, The Social Kitchen, and CMC Markets, are breaking the mold by finding satisfaction in unconventional careers, such as running a cafe and promoting zero-waste living, rather than traditional desk jobs. This shift may be due to a lack of millennials content to work in such roles.

images.alt_text: MS LIM: 'To enter F&B, I feel it's very important to do your due diligence and your homework well. Making sure you have enough cash flow is very essential.'
MR CHUNG: 'Shoe-shining is a very tough job that requires a lot of manual labour, not many people can take it. You don't just have to love shoes, you have to be obsessed.'
MR TAY: 'My dad never told me what to do, how to run it, or anything. He had an old-school philosophy - it's best to learn from scratch on your own, because if you're spoon-fed, you'll never learn.'

site_title: Watching the luxury segment
summary: A luxury watch and jewellery exhibition, "A Journey Through Time," is on display at the ION Art Gallery in Singapore until August 28. The exhibition features over 20 brands, including Officine Panerai, Patek Philippe, Tiffany & Co, and others, showcasing their pieces through multimedia displays. Admission is free and the gallery is open from 10am to 10pm daily. The exhibition is a fitting event for Singapore's reputation as a luxury hub, with the ION Orchard complex hosting several luxury brands' flagship stores.

site_title: More openings than takers in Africa and Latin America: IE S'pore
summary: Singapore's International Enterprise (IE) agency sees significant business opportunities for Singapore companies in Africa and Latin America, citing natural resources, infrastructure, and consumer sectors as key areas. With over 100 Singapore companies already present in the regions, IE Singapore expects larger investments in Africa in the coming years due to the continent's growing stability. The agency has seen compound annual growth in bilateral trade with Africa since 2005, reaching S$11.5 billion last year.

site_title: Meals in a jiffy
summary: A vending machine in Singapore dispenses coffee powder, kaya, cooking pastes, and chilli sauce, targeting tourists. Kang Kang Express offers pre-paesterized instant noodles with a soft texture, while Batu Lesung Spice Company provides healthier, preservative-free spice pastes. Mekhala Living offers vegan and organic curry pastes, and Signature Delicacies provides a range of sauces for cooking. Shermay's Singapore Fine Food label introduces a ginger garlic sauce for added flavor.

site_title: Will women ever be able to beat men at the Olympics?
summary: Women's athletic performance is unlikely to surpass men's in most Olympic events due to the persistent 10-12% gap in world records between the sexes. This gap is attributed to testosterone, a hormone that gives men a genetic advantage in most sports. While women can compete with men in certain events, such as equestrian sports and shooting, the majority of events will remain out of reach. The assumption that linear improvements in past performance will continue into the future is flawed, as it neglects factors such as doping and individual differences in hormone levels.

images.alt_text: HORMONAL ADVANTAGE?: Intersex athlete Caster Semenya's best time for the 800m is far behind the men's world record.

site_title: 30% of US tech unicorns will see valuation fall: report
summary: A report by SharesPost Inc found that nearly 30% of US-based tech unicorns, valued at over $1 billion, will see their valuation fall. The report, analyzing data from 1995-2010, estimates that 30 US unicorns will eventually be worth less than $1 billion, with many receiving overvalued funding from venture capitalists. The report highlights the venture capital boom and the age of unicorns, which is significantly older than companies making initial public offerings, contributing to the lackluster tech IPO market.

site_title: Time for local firms to support S'pore athletes
summary: Singaporean athletes require financial support beyond just government scholarships to excel in international competitions. Many rely on crowdfunding, highlighting the need for corporate involvement. Companies like Deloitte offer internship and scholarship opportunities, but more can be done. Smaller sums of money, even a few hundred dollars a week, can make a significant difference in supporting athletes. This financial support, along with a strong school culture and government backing, is crucial for nurturing Singapore's future champions.

site_title: Stitch by stitch
summary: Ermenegildo Zegna introduces its Fall/Winter 2016 Made to Measure Collection, offering head-to-toe customization for formal and informal events. The collection includes luxury denim jackets, cashmere polo shirts, and seersucker jackets, all tailored to individual body shapes and lifestyles. Meanwhile, The Prestigious Bespoke offers bespoke-made suits crafted by skilled tailors, with a focus on personal relationships and attention to detail. Other tailoring houses, such as Dylan & Son and Kevin Seah Bespoke, also offer bespoke and made-to-measure suits with classic and understated designs.

site_title: New film-makers rising among indigenous groups
summary: A new generation of indigenous Canadian film-makers is rising, using their cameras to portray the harsh realities of life in native communities. Founded by Wapikoni, a non-profit group, the movement has produced 900 films, including 120 international prize winners, shedding light on issues such as high suicide rates, violence, and poverty. The films, made by young indigenous people, aim to promote honest portrayals and empower their communities, reflecting a broader trend in the Americas.

site_title: Twitter axes 235,000 more accounts
summary: Twitter has suspended 235,000 accounts in the past six months to curb violent extremist content, bringing the total to 360,000 since mid-2015. The company aims to balance free speech with preventing extremist groups from spreading violent messages. Since February, Twitter has neutralized 125,000 accounts for violating rules against violent threats and terrorism. The platform is using advanced technology and collaborating with other social media companies to identify and eliminate extremist content.

site_title: New NYC rental apartment block on sale as buyers swarm
summary: A 45-storey rental apartment tower in Queens, New York, is for sale despite not yet opening to the public or finding tenants. Developer Property Markets Group, led by Kevin Maloney, is taking advantage of investor demand to own rental apartments in the area, with the building's 391 units valued at a total of $364.2 million. The average price per unit is $364,816, and the building's price point is expected to be achieved through renting out the apartments, with the option to sell the units as condos if the rental plan fails.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: KS Energy subsidiary PT Atlantic Oilfield Services secured a $17.4 million US drilling contract in Indonesia, set to start in January 2017. Swing Media Technology Group agreed to buy Grace Health Group, expanding into the wagyu cattle business. SembCorp Marine acquired Norwegian ship design firm LMG Marin AS for $20 million, gaining design patents and expertise. China Fibretech received a $4.11 million refund for land use rights after a municipal government agency deemed the land "no longer suitable" for construction.

site_title: SWFs pull US$16.2b from external managers in Q2 as selling accelerates
summary: Sovereign wealth funds pulled $16.2 billion from external asset managers in the second quarter, with outflows exceeding $10.1 billion in the first quarter. The largest outflows occurred in US equities, fixed income, and emerging market debt funds. This trend is correlated with global commodity prices, particularly oil prices. SWFs are heavily reliant on oil exports, leading to a sell-off to close budget gaps. Despite strong global stock gains, SWFs are reevaluating their investment strategies, with a focus on niche strategies.

site_title: Indonesia's Indrawati aims to build trust, boost tax revenue
summary: Indonesian Finance Minister Sri Mulyani Indrawati is focusing on building trust with taxpayers to boost tax revenue, aiming to raise $16.9 billion through a tax amnesty program this year. The program aims to stimulate growth in Indonesia's massive economy, with President Joko Widodo seeking to increase economic growth to 7% during his term. Despite criticism from the OECD, Indrawati vows to take serious action against non-compliant taxpayers, while also addressing the country's complicated tax procedures and high tax rates.

site_title: Jokowi amnesty favours tax cheats and punishes payers: OECD
summary: The Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) has criticized Indonesia's tax amnesty program, stating it favors tax cheats and punishes payers, potentially harming compliance in an economy already struggling with tax collection. The program offers low penalties, ranging from 2-10% for tax-avoiding individuals and companies, compared to corporate tax at 25% and personal income levy at 30%. The OECD argues that non-compliant taxpayers should not be treated better than compliant ones, which may lead to an erosion of tax revenue and negatively affect overall tax compliance.

site_title: Claims received by Swiber climb to US$135.9m
summary: Swiber Holdings, a beleaguered offshore marine group, has received claims totaling US$135.9 million as of August 18. The company is seeking legal advice and has filed a judicial management application with the High Court after reversing a winding-up petition. An interim judicial managers' report will be submitted on September 2, with a judge pre-trial conference set for September 5.

site_title: Boards can create a healthy climate for developing CEOs
summary: Boards can create a healthy climate for developing CEOs by fostering a culture of learning and growth. To achieve this, boards should consider six key steps: building a strong external network, encouraging interaction with employees and customers, promoting knowledge sharing, promoting hypothesis-driven experiments, seeking evidence of learning, and remaining open-minded. By acting as a sounding board for ideas and questions, boards can encourage CEOs to continue learning and growing, leading to better decision-making and increased value for the company. This approach can also benefit the board itself by exposing them to new perspectives and ideas.

images.alt_text: LEND A HAND: Instead of just coaching CEOs, it is the board's job to act as a resource for them, ask questions, demand learning and encourage sharing of surprising news.

site_title: Banks still aiming for full EU single market access post-Brexit
summary: The City of London's banking sector is holding onto the hope of maintaining full access to the EU's single market post-Brexit. The British Bankers' Association stated that banks want to keep full access to the EU market to serve European customers. The key concern is passporting, which allows banks to operate in all EU countries with minimal staff presence. Despite a Financial Times report suggesting banks have given up hope, the industry remains committed to maintaining this access, with a US$19 trillion integrated economy at stake.

site_title: A question of endurance
summary: Singaporean Greg Teo, a Ferrari Challenge Asia Pacific series competitor, is progressing to endurance racing with his own team, T2 Motorsports. Teo has partnered Indonesian driver David Tjiptobiantoro and will compete in the Ferrari 488 GT3. This marks Teo's next level of racing, following his experience in one-make sports car racing series.

site_title: Soilbuild Reit to raise up to S$59.4m via preferential offering for property acquisition
summary: Soilbuild Reit is raising up to S$59.4 million through a preferential offering to fund the acquisition of Bukit Batok Connection, an industrial property. The Reit will issue up to 94.35 million new units at a discounted price of S$0.63 per unit. The acquisition cost is S$96.3 million, with additional expenses expected to total S$100.5 million. The Reit plans to use the funds to partially finance the acquisition and tap additional means of financing.

site_title: Cocoa spreads jump in London as global shortage starts to bite
summary: London cocoa traders are experiencing a global shortage as prices surge, with the premium for September delivery increasing 33% in the past week. Cocoa deliveries to Ivory Coast, the largest cocoa producer, are 18% behind last year's levels. Supplies this season are expected to be 320,000 tons lower than demand, leading to a widening output gap in cocoa-producing regions. This has resulted in higher premiums for physical cocoa, with Ivorian beans trading at a premium of £66 to London futures.

site_title: Growing loan pipeline suggests post-Labor Day M&A
summary: A growing loan pipeline and increased CEO confidence suggest a post-Labor Day pickup in M&A-related leveraged loan issuance. The technology, media, and telecommunications sectors, as well as pharmaceuticals, are expected to lead the way in M&A. Despite not exceeding 2015 totals, the second half of the year is expected to see an improvement in M&A volume, with strong capital availability and favorable terms. The third quarter's $18.7 billion in leveraged M&A volume is lower than last year's $118.7 billion, but bankers are optimistic about the rest of the year.

site_title: US:Wall Street opens lower
summary: Wall Street opened lower on Friday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 0.4% to 18,518.74, and the broader S&P 500 losing 0.5% to 2,175.40. Despite a gain in Viacom shares, which rose 2.0% on speculation about an end to corporate power struggles, media conglomerates were largely down. The tech-heavy Nasdaq fell 0.3% to 5,218.39.

site_title: Moonstruck
summary:
Here is a 100-word summary of the article content:

In Singapore, modern mooncake flavors have evolved, offering unique and innovative twists on traditional fillings. From smoked duck to blueberry with vintage hua diao wine, mooncakes now cater to diverse tastes and dietary preferences. Exclusive mooncake shops like Peony Jade and Feng Shui Inn have introduced anti-ageing properties and luxurious ingredients, such as pearl powder and wild cordycep. Meanwhile, pastry chefs like Herve Potus and Pang Kok Keong have created mooncakes that blend French and Asian flavors, offering a new level of sophistication and indulgence. These modern mooncakes are a treat for both locals and tourists.

site_title: Demand for Asian dollar bonds likely to stay robust: JPMorgan
summary: JPMorgan predicts demand for Asian dollar bonds will remain robust until the end of the year. Since June 30, dollar bond sales in Asia excluding Japan have reached a record $23.9 billion, a 48% increase from the same period in 2015. The extra yield over Treasuries demanded by investors has decreased to 204 basis points, the lowest since 2007.

site_title: Idle credit cards in Asia prompt banks' overhaul
summary: Asian consumers are increasingly jettisoning unused credit cards, prompting banks like HSBC, Citigroup, and Standard Chartered to overhaul their credit card offerings. The banks are slashing the number of card products and focusing on promoting a smaller number of cards for online payments, such as Apple Pay. This shift is driven by the growing popularity of mobile payment services and the need to reduce complexity and costs. As a result, banks are reorienting their strategies to prioritize digital features and targeted benefits, with Citigroup reducing its card offerings in Asia by 60% and HSBC increasing its mobile-banking clients by 50% over the past three years.

site_title: Japan sinking deeper into de facto helicopter money
summary: Japan is increasingly moving towards "helicopter money" as the Bank of Japan (BOJ) buys more Japanese government bonds, blurring the line between monetary policy and fiscal spending. The BOJ's efforts to combat deflation, combined with the government's plans to issue 40-year bonds, may lead to a monetization of debt. Economists fear this could trigger hyperinflation and currency devaluation, while the BOJ and government officials argue that the current policies are necessary to stimulate the economy and achieve a 2% inflation target.

site_title: China Fibretech to receive 20.3m yuan refund from municipal government
summary: China Fibretech Limited will receive a 20.3 million yuan refund from the Shishi municipal government for land use rights. The group had paid 18.7 million yuan plus other costs for a land parcel in 2008, but it was deemed "no longer suitable" for construction due to environmental protection planning. The refund will be made in the coming months. The company's shares remain suspended due to uncertainties surrounding claims from three customers, with an average utilisation rate of 5.57% in the first half of the year.

site_title: E-payments: Rules to be updated to protect users
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) plans to update its regulations to enhance consumer protection in the electronic payments sector. The MAS will establish a Payments Council to align payment initiatives with national and public interest, focusing on streamlined regulation, inclusive governance, interoperable infrastructure, and pervasive digitization. The goal is to create an e-payments society that provides swift, simple, and secure payments for everyone. The MAS aims to reduce the economic cost of using cash and cheques, which is estimated to be around 0.5% of GDP, by promoting the use of digital payment solutions.

images.alt_text: Singapore will update its regulation to beef up consumer protection as it moves into becoming an electronic-payments society, said the managing director of the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) Ravi Menon on Friday.

site_title: Target severs ties with Welspun over Egyptian-cotton dispute
summary: Target Corp is ending business with Welspun India Ltd, a major textile manufacturer, due to the supplier sending phony Egyptian cotton sheets. The company discovered 750,000 sheets and pillowcases labeled as Egyptian cotton were actually made with another type of cotton. Target notified customers that they will receive a refund for the products sold between 2014 and 2016, valued at up to $75. The move affects two lines of Egyptian cotton bedding and not all Egyptian cotton sheets. Target is phasing out its products from Welspun, a supplier for over a decade.

site_title: STI closes higher for the first time this week
summary: The Straits Times Index rose 7.04 points or 0.3% to 2,844.02 on Friday, marking the only positive day this week, as investors awaited clarity on the timing of the next US rate hike. Despite mixed economic data, regional bourses also saw gains, with Japan's Nikkei 225 up 0.4% and China's Shanghai Composite up 0.1%. The Fed's minutes suggested no rush to raise rates, with expectations for a rate hike easing to about 50% for this year.

site_title: SembMarine unit buys Norway ship design firm LMG for US$20m
summary: SembCorp Marine has acquired Norwegian ship design firm LMG Marin AS for US$20 million. Established in 1943, LMG has designed various ship types, including drillships and LNG carriers, and its designs were adopted by SembCorp Marine. The acquisition brings LMG's design patents and expertise in naval architectural design, engineering, and technology development to SembCorp Marine, supporting its efforts to move up the value chain and compete better in the global offshore and marine sectors.

site_title: AIG asset sales near US$100b with mortgage unit exit
summary: AIG has sold assets exceeding $100 billion, including a mortgage unit, to buyers such as Aabar Investments and Zurich Insurance Group. The sales, which began in 2008, aim to simplify the company and generate funds for share buybacks. CEO Peter Hancock initially stated the total sales figure was over $90 billion, but it has since increased. The latest deal, a mortgage insurer sale for $3.4 billion, brings the total to nearly $100 billion.

site_title: 2 Singaporeans planning to join ISIS detained, 2 others on Restriction Orders: MHA
summary: Two Singaporean nationals, Rosli Hamzah and Mohamed Omar Mahadi, have been detained under the Internal Security Act for planning to join ISIS in Syria. They received two-year detention orders this month. Additionally, two other Singaporeans are on Restriction Orders, indicating they are under surveillance due to suspected ties to terrorism. The Ministry of Home Affairs has taken these measures to protect national security.

site_title: Malaysia: Stocks end the day lower
summary: Malaysian shares closed lower on Friday, with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index falling 7.19 points to 1,687.680. 2.2 billion lots worth RM1.69 billion were traded, with losers outnumbering gainers 523 to 319.

site_title: Schwarzenegger wants world to be fitter
summary: Arnold Schwarzenegger launched the inaugural Arnold Classic Asia Multi-Sport Festival in Hong Kong, aiming to promote health and fitness globally. The event features various activities, including bodybuilding, rugby, yoga, and weightlifting, until Sunday. Schwarzenegger, a former bodybuilding champion, movie star, and California governor, believes his influence should extend beyond his individual achievements to inspire a healthier world. This marks one of his similar events worldwide, with the goal of spreading fitness awareness globally.

site_title: Indonesia urges action against slash-and-burn clearing as haze season arrives
summary: Indonesia's disaster agency urged prompt action against slash-and-burn plantation fires in the Malacca Strait, as the annual haze season began. Fires set by companies clearing land for plantations cause choking smog, closing airports and schools. The agency's spokesman Sutopo Nugroho said the number of fire hotspots in West Kalimantan increased significantly over the past week. Indonesia has been criticized for failing to stop the annual fires, which can blanket large parts of the region in smog. The government has declared a state of emergency for fires in five provinces, and imposed record fines on a local plantation company.

site_title: Indonesian central bank holds new key rate steady
summary: Indonesia's central bank, Bank Indonesia, held steady its 7-day reverse repurchase rate at 5.25% on Friday, as expected. The rate, also used for one-week reverse repo contracts with commercial banks, was unchanged following a previous announcement. The overnight repo rate was cut to 6.00% to peg it 75 basis points above the new main rate. This decision comes despite Indonesia's economy growing at its strongest pace in 10 quarters in April-June, with loan growth remaining modest.

images.alt_text: Indonesia's central bank on Friday held steady the 7-day reverse repurchase rate, its new main policy rate, as expected.

site_title: Maersk exploring all options as report points to 2-way split
summary: Maersk is exploring various options in its strategic review, following a report suggesting a possible two-way split into an energy and transport company. The company's chairman had previously stated that it wants to evaluate all options, but emphasized that structure alone does not guarantee growth. As the review continues, Maersk's head of media relations confirmed that the group is considering different possibilities, but did not confirm the split report.

site_title: Estee Lauder's quarterly sales rise 4.8%
summary: Estee Lauder's quarterly sales rose 4.8% to US$2.65 billion, driven by higher demand for its makeup brands. The company's makeup unit saw a 10.2% increase in sales to US$1.13 billion, contributing 42.6% to total sales. Net income fell to US$93.5 million due to restructuring and other charges, but the company expects fiscal 2017 net sales to grow 6-7% and adjusted profit to be between US$3.38-US$3.44 per share.

images.alt_text: Cosmetics maker Estee Lauder Cos Inc's quarterly sales jumped 4.8 per cent, its fourth consecutive rise, helped by higher demand for its makeup brands including M.A.C, Smashbox and Bobbi Brown.

site_title: Singapore Q2 domestic wholesale trade contracts 20.5%
summary: Singapore's domestic wholesale trade contracted 20.5% year-over-year in Q2 2016, primarily due to lower prices of petroleum and chemical products. Excluding petroleum, the decline was 15.5%. The drop was broad-based, with 8 out of 11 industries posting double-digit declines, while transport equipment and food rose by 11.9% and 1%, respectively.

site_title: Australian treasurer formally rejects Chinese bids for state-owned Ausgrid
summary: Australian Treasurer Scott Morrison formally rejected bids by State Grid Corp of China and Cheung Kong Infrastructure Holdings to acquire the country's largest energy grid, Ausgrid, citing unspecified national interests. The decision, made despite China's criticism, was backed by the Foreign Investment Review Board. The rejection has strained relations between Australia and China, just eight months after their free trade agreement took effect. The decision does not affect the plan to privatize Ausgrid, but its future remains uncertain.

site_title: VW halts German production after unprecedented move by supplier
summary: Volkswagen AG has halted production at its German factories due to a dispute with a supplier, Prevent Group's Car Trim and ES Automobilguss, who have suspended deliveries after VW canceled a contract. The supplier claims VW owes it for factory alterations made to provide services, while VW's top labor boss calls the move "reckless and asocial." Production of the Passat and Golf models is expected to be halted if the conflict isn't resolved, potentially reducing VW's earnings by up to 40 million euros per week.

site_title: Swing Media Technology ventures into wagyu cattle business through purchase of Grace Health Group
summary: Swing Media Technology Group Limited has entered into a non-binding agreement to buy Grace Health Group, owned by Total Victor Global Limited, for an undisclosed consideration. The proposed acquisition, valid for eight months, aims to expand Swing Media Technology's presence in the wagyu cattle market, with Grace Health Group holding 90% of the shareholding interest in Grace Health Australia Pty Ltd. The company will target the Greater China region and sell produce both domestically and globally. Shareholders are advised to exercise caution as there is no certainty the acquisition will take place.

site_title: KS Energy unit wins US$17.4m drilling contract
summary: KS Energy's subsidiary, PT Atlantic Oilfield Services, has secured a US$17.4 million drilling contract in Indonesia. The contract is expected to begin in January 2017 and last for 14 months. The new contract is not expected to impact KS Energy's earnings per share or net tangible assets per share for the 2016 financial year. KS Energy's shares closed 1.2 cents lower at 8.6 cents following the announcement.

images.alt_text: KS Drilling subsidiary PT Atlantic Oilfield Services has secured a new US$17.4 million drilling contract to work in Indonesia, parent company KS Energy announced on Friday.

site_title: Hong Kong exchange, Tradeweb in talks over "Bond Connect" platform
summary: Hong Kong exchange HKEX is in talks with Tradeweb to launch "Bond Connect," a platform connecting China's $7.5 trillion bond market with overseas investors. The talks are exclusive and advanced, with discussions now focusing on revenue sharing. The initiative aims to further open up China's onshore bond market, which is the world's third largest. Tradeweb, a fixed income trading platform, will match buyers and sellers of fixed income products across international OTC bond markets. The move is part of HKEX's strategic plan to act as a gateway between international investors and China.

site_title: Berli expects 2016 sales to hit 100 billion baht after Big C buy
summary: Thai trading firm Berli Jucker Pcl expects annual sales to reach 100 billion baht in 2016 after acquiring Big C Supercenter Pcl for $6.2 billion in May. This acquisition has pushed first-half revenue up 178% to 59 billion baht. Berli now owns 97.94% of Big C and aims to make the most of its relationship with Big C and Metro Vietnam. The company plans to sell up to 50 billion baht worth of bonds to refinance debt and will focus on its current business, particularly in Vietnam.

site_title: Getting schooled by our Olympians
summary: Singaporean swimmer Joseph Schooling made history by winning the gold medal in the 100m butterfly event at the Olympics. His victory brought the nation to its feet, and his return to studying and training in the US has sparked a sense of pride and normalcy. However, his achievements serve as a reminder to working adults of the importance of hard work and discipline. Schooling's story is a testament to the potential for individuals to make a significant impact, even in a small nation. His legacy is likely to inspire future generations of Singaporeans.

site_title: Myanmar's Suu Kyi says China to support peace talks
summary: Myanmar's State Counsellor Aung San Suu Kyi expects China to support historic peace talks with armed groups near the Myanmar-China border. Suu Kyi aims to achieve peace and unity, a prelude to rebooting the economy after her party's landslide election victory. Myanmar will hold peace talks later this month, with China's President Xi Jinping meeting Suu Kyi ahead of the conference. The talks come as Myanmar reviews the stalled $3.6 billion Beijing-backed Myitsone dam project, which has been on hold since protests in 2011.

site_title: National Day Rally will address elected presidency, says PM Lee Hsien Loong
summary: Singapore's National Day Rally will address the economy, the country's next 50 years, and the elected presidency, according to Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong. The rally aims to prepare Singaporeans for the future and strengthen racial harmony through the Elected President Scheme. The event is expected to discuss how Singapore can prosper and progress together amidst an uncertain and fast-changing world.

site_title: Singapore shares close 7.04 points up
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 7.04 points, or 0.3%, to 2,844.02 on Friday, driven by a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data. Turnover was 739 million shares worth S$696 million. Gainers outpaced losers 222 to 172.

site_title: China: Blue-chip index has 2nd straight week with solid gain
summary: China's blue-chip CSI300 index rose 2.1% for the week, marking its second consecutive gain, as financial shares led the rally on hopes of government stimulus. The Shanghai Composite Index finished flat, while the SSEC gained 1.9%. Analysts expect continued volatility but an upward trend in the market.

site_title: Europe: Stocks steady at open
summary: European stock markets remained steady at the open on Friday, following modest gains in Tokyo and on Wall Street. London's FTSE 100 dipped slightly, while the Paris CAC 40 and Frankfurt's DAX 30 remained unchanged and increased 0.1% respectively.

site_title: M1 to roll out HetNet, unveils plan for IoT network
summary: M1 Singapore telco will introduce its first commercial Heterogeneous Network (HetNet) allowing customers to surf at high speeds, with a peak download speed of over 1 Gbps by 2017. This is up from the current 450Mbps. M1 also announced a strategic partnership with Nokia to roll out a nationwide commercial narrowband Internet of Things (NB-IoT) network by mid-2017.

images.alt_text: SINGAPORE telco M1 will introduce the first commercial Heterogeneous Network (HetNet) following successful trials earlier this year.

site_title: Gold drops as Fed's Williams says he's for increasing rates soon
summary: Gold prices dropped 0.5% to $1,345.80 an ounce as the US dollar rebounded and Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco President John Williams suggested the US economy is strong enough for interest rate increases soon. This move may limit gold's upside, despite a 27% boost this year, as investors await further clues from Fed Chair Janet Yellen's speech in Jackson Hole.

site_title: NYC apartment tower without tenants for sale as buyers swarm
summary: A 45-story apartment tower in Long Island City, Queens, built with 391 units, is for sale after remaining empty despite being completed. The developer, Property Markets Group, is taking advantage of investor demand for rental properties in the area, with average prices per square foot rising 11% in the first half of 2016. The building's rent prices could start as high as $62 per square foot, and the developer is considering leasing out the units or selling them as condominiums.

site_title: Duterte's anti-gambling campaign sends bingo company tumbling
summary: The Philippines' largest electronic bingo operator, Leisure & Resorts World Corp, saw its shares plummet 20% after the gaming regulator announced it would not issue new permits or renew licenses for electronic platforms. This move is part of President Rodrigo Duterte's campaign to eradicate online gambling, which has already claimed the scalp of PhilWeb Corp's chairman. Online bingo is the most popular form of electronic gambling in the Philippines, accounting for three-quarters of internet gaming revenue.

site_title: Taiwan asks Uber to pay bill in sales tax stand-off
summary: Taiwan's government has asked Uber to pay an estimated US$6.4 million in sales tax, amid a dispute over the company's business classification. The tax bill is part of a broader overhaul of the tax regime for global online service providers. Uber has denied owing sales taxes, citing its compliance with local laws. The decision to pay the bill is a condition for Uber's continued operation in Taiwan, with a deadline of the end of August. The government may order Uber to exit the market if the issue is not resolved.

site_title: Singapore CPI seen declining 0.5% y-o-y in July, may have bottomed out: poll
summary: Singapore's consumer price index (CPI) is expected to decline 0.5% in July for a 21st consecutive month, according to a Reuters poll. This would mark the longest streak of annual declines since Singapore's independence in 1965. Analysts say prices may have bottomed out, with some predicting a return to positive territory by year-end due to a low base from last year. Core CPI, excluding housing and transport costs, is forecast to rise 1.0% in July.

images.alt_text: Singapore's consumer price index (CPI) is expected to show an annual decline for a 21st straight month in July, a Reuters poll showed, but some analysts say prices may have bottomed out and the index could return to positive territory by the year-end.

site_title: Singtel's proposed investment no impact on credit rating, say rating agencies
summary: Singtel's proposed investments in Intouch Holdings and Bharti Telecom have no impact on its credit rating, according to three major credit rating agencies. The company plans to spend S$2.47 billion on a 21% stake in Intouch and a 7.39% stake in Bharti Telecom to deepen its presence in Thailand and India. Moody's and Fitch Ratings have confirmed the company's credit rating, with Moody's warning that high leverage could lead to downward pressure on its credit quality if not managed.

images.alt_text: SINGAPORE Telecommunications' proposed acquisitions will have no impact on its credit rating, said the three credit rating agencies.

site_title: British landlords scope out office bargains as Brexit vote bites
summary: British landlords are taking advantage of the post-Brexit market, seeking bargains in office space as commercial property values fell 2.8% in July, the largest decline since 2009. Despite concerns over the financial services industry's future, rents and leasing demand have remained steady, with tenants providing stable incomes for landlords. Savvy investors are looking to buy properties on the cheap, with some firms increasing their stakes in landlords doing so, and new companies may also move into Britain to take advantage of the situation.

site_title: Brent crude oil rise; on track for seventh-straight day of gains
summary: Brent crude oil prices rose above $51 a barrel, reaching an eight-week high, for a seventh-straight trading day. The increase is attributed to hopes that producers can agree on measures to support crude, as well as US crude stocks declining. However, analysts warn the rally is overblown and the market is approaching overbought territory, with prices potentially rising another $1 to $2 a barrel before falling. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec) informal meeting next month may provide a catalyst for the selloff.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore plans to streamline regulations to enhance consumer protection as it transitions to an electronic payments society. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) aims to strengthen consumer protection. M1 will launch HetNet, a high-speed internet network, with peak speeds exceeding 1 Gbps by 2017. The country will also jointly tender for a High Speed Rail (HSR) project with Malaysia.
