The consumer price index (CPI) is expected to decline 0.5% in July, possibly bottoming out, and Singapore's shares rose 7.04 points to close at 2,844.02 on Friday.

images.alt_text: Singapore will streamline regulation to strengthen consumer protection as it moves towards an electronic payments society, said Ravi Menon, managing director of the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS).

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares close lower, but get a 3rd straight weekly gain
summary: Hong Kong shares closed lower on Friday, but still gained a third consecutive weekly rise. The Hang Seng Index fell 0.4% to 22,937.22, while the China Enterprises Index lost 0.5%. Investors are cautious ahead of a US central bank meeting next week. Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing Limited introduced a new Volatility Control Mechanism, which analysts expect to have limited impact on the market. The Shenzhen-Hong Kong stock connect scheme was also approved, potentially attracting mainland fund flows due to cheap Hong Kong market valuations.

site_title: Latest Earnings
summary:
Here's a summary of the article content in 100 words or less:

NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer received 9.8 times oversubscription. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss in H2. London's Heathrow is considering higher fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. OCBC announced Tan Teck Long as its incoming CEO, replacing Helen Wong. Singapore stocks rallied for the fifth day ahead of GDP data. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and People's Bank of China (PBOC) plan to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance.

site_title: Opec freeze wouldn't be so potent as Gulf rivals pump more
summary: Opec's potential oil production freeze in Algiers may not have the desired impact due to increased output from Gulf rivals, particularly Saudi Arabia and Iran. Despite a 10% rally in oil prices since the proposed meeting, the market remains oversupplied, with Brent crude trading at $50.89 per barrel. Iran, which had refused to join a freeze in April, may now consider participation, but its refusal to limit production could render the agreement less effective. The agreement would push the re-balancing process back by at least a year.

site_title: Australia: Miners lift bourse at the close, NZ ticks higher
summary: Australian shares rose 0.3% on Friday, driven by mining stocks, while New Zealand's benchmark index gained 0.27% and 0.6% for the week. The Australian S&P/ASX 200 index rose 18.88 points to 5,526.70, and New Zealand's S&P/NZX 50 index finished at 7,405.25.

site_title: Seoul: Won snaps weekly gaining streak; stocks rally
summary: The South Korean won ended a three-week winning streak, falling 1.1% to 1,117.6 to the dollar, marking a 1.3% weekly loss. Despite this, South Korean shares rose 0.3% for a fourth consecutive weekly rally, with tech giant Samsung Electronics Co Ltd rising 2.1% to set a record closing high. Offshore investors bought 221.2 billion won worth of Kospi shares, while the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) closed at 2,056.24.

site_title: Fund transfers via mobile phone number could come next year: MAS chief
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority (MAS) chief Ravi Menon plans to allow mobile phone number transfers for fund transfers by next year. This move aims to simplify transactions and enhance user experience. The MAS is also exploring other payment innovations, such as real-time interbank payments and central bank digital currencies. The regulator's vision for Singapore's payment landscape aims to make the country a leader in digital payments, increasing efficiency and convenience for users.

site_title: Pokemon Go spurs lifestyle changes, business boom as it rolls out in Asia
summary: Pokémon Go's release in Asia has sparked a lifestyle change and business boom, with gamers seeking better network signals and devices to play the augmented reality game. In Indonesia, gamers have switched to mobile carriers and purchased modems to overcome patchy signals, while in other countries, such as Hong Kong and Cambodia, players have taken to public transportation to catch Pokémon. The game's popularity has also driven sales of 4G modems and game innovations, with retailers and modem makers experiencing a surge in demand.

site_title: Australia: Stronger miners help keep shares steady
summary: The Australian share market remained steady on Friday, closing 0.16% higher at 5,516, despite mixed performances from mining and bank stocks. Woodside Petroleum and Santos reported progress on cost-cutting, sending their shares higher despite weak oil and gas prices. The S&P/ASX 200 index remained flat, with investors shrugging off disappointing financial results from other companies.

site_title: A commodities rebound is accelerating on China's doorstep
summary: A commodities rebound is accelerating, driven by emerging economies in South-east Asia, particularly China's Asean-5 neighbors. The region's combined GDP is expected to rise by a third to $3 trillion by 2020, fueling infrastructure projects and increasing commodity demand. This growth is expected to maintain and increase demand for commodities, with steel being a key indicator, as demand in the Asean-5 nations is projected to grow at 6% this year and in 2017.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks end higher on weaker yen, stronger oil
summary: Tokyo stocks closed higher on Friday, ending the week on a positive note, driven by a weaker yen and a rally in oil prices. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index rose 0.36% to 16,545.82, while the Topix index gained 0.38% to 1,295.67. The gains followed a stronger oil price, which lifted investor sentiment.

site_title: Taiwan's 2017 budget plan seen offering little boost for economy
summary: Taiwan's 2017 budget plan, set at TW$1.998 trillion, offers modest increases, with infrastructure spending up 3.1% and overall spending up 1.1%. Analysts predict the plan will not boost the sluggish economy due to weak global demand for Taiwan's exports, despite the government's efforts to stimulate growth.

site_title: US dollar up in Asia but gains capped by rate-hike doubts
summary: The US dollar rose against most Asian currencies on Friday but gains were limited due to uncertainty over a potential interest rate hike by the Federal Reserve this year. A recent statement from a Fed official hinted at a possible rate hike as early as September, while minutes from the Fed's July meeting showed policy members were divided on the need for a near-term rate hike. The dollar's gains were capped, leaving its performance in the region uncertain.

images.alt_text: The dollar rose against most Asian currencies on Friday but its gains were capped by doubts about the chances of a US interest rate hike this year.

site_title: Concrete beach lures Chinese to world's largest building
summary: China's New Century Global Center, a 1,760,000 square-meter building, is the world's largest by floor space, featuring shops, restaurants, offices, and an indoor ocean with artificial waves. The complex, built at a cost of over $6 billion, has attracted shoppers and beachgoers alike, with some traveling from coastal cities for a seaside experience. Despite controversy surrounding its construction, the building has been rented by 90% of commercial space and is part of Chengdu's bid for top-tier city status, with 8,000 office workers commuting there daily.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks fall before government revises 2016 GDP forecast
summary: Taiwan's stocks fell 0.7% to 9,063.03, amid cautious market sentiment ahead of the government's revised 2016 GDP forecast. The electronics subindex dropped 0.4%, while the financials subindex lost 1.1%. The Taiwan dollar softened to TW$31.630 per US dollar. The government had previously cut its GDP forecast three times due to weak demand from China and other global markets.

site_title: Asia: Stocks cautious but oil price holds above US$50
summary: Asia's stock markets moved cautiously on Friday, with Tokyo flat, Hong Kong down 0.3%, and other markets also declining. Despite a positive lead from Wall Street and the oil price holding above $50 a barrel, traders were cautious due to concerns about US interest rates and inventory levels. The recent oil price rally is expected to continue, with some producers potentially agreeing to cap output next month, according to Saudi Arabia.

site_title: Singapore, Malaysia to call tender for joint development partner for HSR project
summary: Singapore and Malaysia will jointly call a tender on August 22 to appoint a development partner for the Kuala Lumpur-Singapore High Speed Rail (HSR) project. The partner will provide project management, technical advice, and procurement support, as well as develop safety and technical standards. The tender is open to firms with experience in HSR projects or similar infrastructure projects. Interested parties can visit the MyHSR or LTA websites starting Monday to submit their bids.

site_title: Singapore to streamline rules to strengthen consumer protection as it moves to an e-payments society: MAS
summary: Singapore aims to create an electronic payments society by streamlining regulations to strengthen consumer protection. MAS will update its framework, merging the Money-Changing and Remittance Businesses Act and the Payment Systems (Oversight) Act into a single piece of legislation. The new framework will enhance consumer protection and cyber security requirements, making regulation modular and activity-based. A Payments Council will guide the development of Singapore's payments landscape, promoting open access, inter-operability, and electronic payments accessibility.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 1.73 points to 1,693.14. Volume was 52.9 million lots worth RM14.7 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 105 to 68.

site_title: Indonesia launches master plan to breathe new life into Islamic finance sector
summary: Indonesia launches a 10-year master plan to boost its Islamic finance sector, aiming to increase its share from 5% to 20-30% of the financial sector. The plan includes initiatives such as mobilizing Islamic charitable funds, modernizing investments, and increasing the use of Islamic bonds. The government hopes to drive growth through a range of measures, including a national coordination committee and potentially merging state-owned Islamic banks. The plan is designed to awaken Indonesia's dormant Islamic finance industry, which has struggled to gain momentum despite regulatory efforts.

site_title: Manulife Asset Management appoints new Singapore head of fixed income
summary: Manulife Asset Management appointed Murray Collis as managing director and head of fixed income, Singapore, with dual reporting lines to Endre Pedersen and Wendy Lim. Collis, with over 20 years of industry experience, leads Singapore-based fixed income strategies and oversees a local team of portfolio managers and credit analysts. He joins from Standish Mellon Asset Management, where he was overseeing Asian fixed income. The appointment reflects Manulife's commitment to identifying investment solutions in the Singapore and Asian fixed income space amidst a slow growth and low interest rate environment.

images.alt_text: Manulife Asset Management on Friday announced the appointment of Murray Collis as managing director, head of fixed income, Singapore. He assumed the role in the past week.

site_title: Indonesia might grow 5.2% this year but will be a 'little tough': Finance minister
summary: Indonesia's finance minister, Sri Mulyani Indrawati, expects the country's growth to reach 5.2% this year, but notes it will be a "little bit tough". This growth rate, which fell below 5% last year, may have reached its bottom, according to the minister. Indonesia's economic growth has shown signs of improvement in the April-June quarter with 5.18% growth, and the first quarter saw 4.92% growth.

images.alt_text: Indonesian Finance Minister Sri Mulyani Indrawati said the country might be able to grow 5.2 per cent this year but it will be "a little bit tough".

site_title: China eyes artificial intelligence for new cruise missiles
summary: China is planning to integrate high levels of artificial intelligence and automation into its next generation of cruise missiles, allowing for real-time control and fire-and-forget modes. This development is part of China's ambitious military modernization program, led by President Xi Jinping, aimed at protecting its legitimate security needs. China's growing assertiveness has raised concerns among its neighbors and the US, but the country maintains it has no hostile intent. The use of AI in missiles is a significant advancement, building on China's existing capabilities in the field.

images.alt_text: China is eyeing the use of a high level of artificial intelligence and automation for its next generation of cruise missiles, a senior designer was quoted as saying on Friday.

site_title: Chinese to invest 11b rand in South African car industry
summary: A Chinese state-owned car manufacturing company, Beijing Automotive International Corp, will invest 11 billion rand (S$1.1 billion) in a new plant in South Africa's Port Elizabeth, boosting the country's car industry. The investment is a result of agreements signed by South African President Jacob Zuma and Chinese Prime Minister Xi Jinping in December last year. This is the latest in a series of investments by Chinese companies in the African continent, further solidifying China's growing presence in the region's economy. The deal is expected to create new job opportunities and stimulate economic growth in South Africa.

site_title: Stocks to watch: CapitaLand Retail China Trust, Soilbuild Reit, Parkson Retail Asia, Civmec
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article:

CapitaLand Retail China Trust is acquiring a mall in Chengdu for 1.5 billion yuan, expanding its portfolio by 14%. Soilbuild Business Space Reit is raising up to S$59.4 million via a preferential offering to fund the acquisition of Bukit Batok Connection. Parkson Retail Asia reported a net loss of S$11.98 million for the fourth quarter, but narrowed losses due to revenue improvement. Civmec's fourth quarter net profit plummeted 77.4% to S$1.5 million due to a weaker Australian dollar and lack of tax gain. The companies' stock performance and financials will be closely watched.

site_title: China says navy carries out drills in Sea of Japan
summary: China's navy has conducted routine drills in the Sea of Japan, according to the People's Liberation Army Daily. The exercises, part of annual training arrangements, aimed to improve the fleet's ability to operate far out at sea. The drills were in accordance with international law and practice, and did not target any specific country or region. This follows previous exercises by the Chinese navy in international waters, including a 2015 exercise in the Bering Sea off Alaska. The Sea of Japan is a strategic waterway bordered by Japan, Russia, South Korea, and North Korea.

site_title: Australia, NZ dollars slide on negative outlook for bank ratings
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars declined on Friday following a negative outlook for bank ratings by Moody's, with the Aussie dropping 0.7% to US$0.7632 and the Kiwi falling nearly 1% to US$0.7255. Moody's cut the outlook on Australian banks to negative due to sluggish profit growth, prompting investors to sell both currencies. The decline was also influenced by euro buying and a weak Australian dollar against its kiwi counterpart, which was affected by New Zealand's banks being owned by Australian financial institutions.

site_title: Hong Kong 'rabbit cafe' hops onto high street
summary: A "Rabbitland" cafe in Hong Kong's Causeway Bay district has opened, offering customers the chance to interact with 12 resident rabbits in a unique petting experience. The cafe, inspired by a similar shop in Japan, aims to educate children about rabbit care and responsibility. Customers must follow rules to behave around the animals, and the rabbits are not for sale. Co-founder Teddy Chui hopes the experience helps parents understand the commitment required to care for a pet rabbit, rather than just playing with them.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open higher after oil's rise
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.24% at the open on Friday, driven by gains on Wall Street and a rise in oil prices. The Hang Seng Index reached 23,079.56, while the Shanghai Composite Index slipped 0.12%. China's second exchange, the Shenzhen Composite Index, remained flat. The gains followed a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks ahead of GDP data, and traders brushed off new US President Trump threats to extend the stocks rally.

site_title: Singapore's domestic wholesale trade down 22.6% in Q1
summary: Singapore's domestic wholesale trade declined 22.6% year-over-year in Q1, with petroleum and chemical products contributing to the drop. Excluding petroleum, the decline was 11.4%. The worst-performing industries were ship chandlers & bunkering, petroleum & petroleum products, and general wholesale trade. However, three industries showed growth - household equipment & furniture (12.5%), transport equipment (8%), and food, beverages & tobacco (1.4%).

site_title: Japan defence ministry seeks record budget for fiscal 2017
summary: Japan's defence ministry plans to request a record budget of 5.16 trillion yen (S$68.5 billion) for fiscal 2017, marking a 2.3% increase from this year's budget. The request includes funding for upgrades to Japan's missile defence system, the production of a new missile system with the US, and the acquisition of an upgraded F-35 stealth fighter. The proposed budget aims to strengthen Japan's defences amid rising tensions in the East China Sea and North Korea's missile threat.

site_title: Fed's Williams says he's for hiking US interest rates soon on strong economy
summary: Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco President John Williams stated that the US economy is strong enough to warrant an interest rate hike soon, warning that waiting too long could lead to high inflation or asset bubbles. He believes the economy is at full employment, with job gains above the 80,000 monthly target, and inflation is on course to meet the 2% goal. Williams suggests a gradual rate increase to normalize interest rates, contrary to his longer-term views that neutral rates may stay lower.

site_title: JPMorgan adds sukuk to emerging markets indices
summary: US investment bank JPMorgan will include Islamic bonds, or sukuk, in its emerging markets indices starting October 31, marking the first time the bank has included these instruments. Eight sukuk from Turkey, Malaysia, and Indonesia will be included, increasing the liquidity of the market and potentially attracting non-traditional investors. The move is expected to boost sukuk prices and foreign holdings, particularly in Malaysia, where two sukuk will be included in JPMorgan's Government Bond Index-Emerging Markets. The inclusion is seen as a step towards making sukuk more accessible to global debt investors.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Friday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index opened higher on Friday, gaining 9.14 points or 0.32% to 2,846.12. The benchmark index saw 44.2 million shares worth S$49.4 million trade hands, with 72 gainers outnumbering 34 losers. Gainers included Jardine Matheson, Dairy Farm, and UOB. This marks the 5th consecutive day of gains ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: Idle credit cards in Asians' wallets prompt Citi, HSBC overhaul
summary: Asian consumers are increasingly ditching unused credit cards, prompting banks like Citigroup, HSBC, and Standard Chartered to overhaul their offerings. The region's affluent population is driving growth in credit-card payments, but actual card numbers have fallen. To adapt, banks are focusing on promoting a smaller number of cards with targeted benefits, such as airline mileage programs, and digital features. This shift aims to simplify operations and reduce costs, as consumers increasingly use mobile payment services like Apple Pay and Alipay.

site_title: Trump says he regrets past remarks that 'caused personal pain'
summary: Donald Trump apologized for past remarks that "may have caused personal pain," acknowledging he had "said the wrong thing" and "regretted" them. The apology comes as Trump's campaign faces falling opinion poll numbers and criticism for his past comments on women, Muslims, and Mexican immigrants. Trump's new campaign manager, Kellyanne Conway, promised a more disciplined and uplifting message, while Trump will continue to use a teleprompter and focus on policy issues, aiming to appeal to women and independent voters.

site_title: Valeant accused in suit of secretly refilling prescriptions
summary: Valeant Pharmaceuticals International is accused of secretly refilling patients' prescriptions without permission and steering them to more expensive drugs to boost sales and profits. A lawsuit by T. Rowe Price Group, backed by former Valeant employees, alleges the company engaged in fraud. This claim is part of ongoing investigations into Valeant's practices, including congressional and regulatory probes into shielding branded drugs from generic competition. The lawsuit seeks damages and is the latest in a series of allegations against the company.

site_title: Seoul: Won falls sharply, stocks dip
summary: The South Korean won fell nearly 1% on Friday, reversing gains from earlier in the week, and trading at 1,116.7 as of 0217 GMT. Analysts attribute the drop to investors' decision to sell the currency due to a lack of expectation for future strengthening.

site_title: Viacom and controlling shareholder Sumner Redstone agree on settlement: sources
summary: Viacom Inc and controlling shareholder Sumner Redstone have agreed on a settlement, reportedly ending the battle for control over the US$40 billion media empire. The terms of the agreement will result in the departure of Chief Executive Philippe Dauman, according to sources. An announcement is expected Thursday night, bringing an end to months of uncertainty and shareholder angst. The settlement will resolve the dispute over control of Viacom and CBS, allowing the company to move forward.

site_title: Australia denies banks interim approval to jointly negotiate with Apple on payment apps
summary: Australia's anti-trust regulator denied the country's three biggest banks interim approval to jointly negotiate with Apple to install their own electronic payments applications on iPhones. The banks, including National Australia Bank, sought permission to negotiate as a bloc from the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission. The ACCC cited complexity and limited time for consultation before making the decision. The banks plan to continue consulting with the ACCC until the final determination is made. Apple does not allow third-party electronic payment apps on its iPhones.

site_title: Olympics: Bolt wins third Olympic 200m title
summary: Usain Bolt won his third consecutive Olympic 200m gold, timing 19.78 seconds, to keep his hopes of a "triple triple" alive. Bolt, 29, edged Canadian Andre de Grasse (20.02sec) and France's Christophe Lemaitre (20.12sec) to secure his 13th individual world or Olympic sprint title. The victory came in a raucous Olympic Stadium crowd, with Bolt performing an electrifying drive phase and completing a lap of honor to chants of "Usain Bolt."

site_title: Soilbuild Reit raising up to S$59.4m for Bukit Batok Connection acquisition
summary: SoilBuild Business Space Reit is raising up to S$59.4 million through a preferential offering to fund the acquisition of Bukit Batok Connection. Existing unitholders can purchase up to 94.35 million new units at S$0.63 per unit, a 8.2% discount to the previous day's price. The Reit will use the funds to partially finance the S$96.3 million acquisition, with the remaining amount coming from unsecured debt borrowings. The deal is expected to strengthen the Reit's balance sheet and enhance its financial flexibility.

site_title: Singapore defaults boost calls for state aid as oil firms falter
summary: Singapore's struggling oil and gas companies, such as Swiber Holdings Ltd, may receive government support if the economy worsens, according to EY. The government has already announced a loan assistance program for smaller businesses, and with 28% of corporate bonds due in the next 18 months from industries facing structural headwinds, more defaults are possible. The price of brent crude oil has halved in the past two years, and the government is engaging companies retrenching workers to place them in adjacent industries.

site_title: Thai Airways plans to resume plane purchases as earnings rebound
summary: Thai Airways plans to resume expanding its fleet after a five-year austerity drive, aiming to add routes and buy new, fuel-efficient aircraft to boost passenger growth. The airline, which last ordered planes in 2011, is drawing up a 10-year plan to replace aging jets and control costs. Thai Airways' earnings rebound has enabled it to repay debt and boost its competitiveness, with shares surging 191% this year. The carrier plans to consider new destinations, including the US, and has introduced a new management system to adjust ticket pricing in real-time.

images.alt_text: After a five-year austerity drive, Thai Airways International Pcl is ready to expand again.

site_title: Oil rally continues as Brent tops US$50 a barrel
summary: Oil prices continued their upward trend, with Brent oil reaching $50 a barrel for the first time in nearly two months. US crude stockpiles fell by 2.5 million barrels and gasoline stocks by 2.7 million barrels, contributing to the gains. A weaker US dollar and expectations of OPEC producers capping output next month also supported prices. Analysts cited these factors as bullish for the market, with traders targeting higher prices and oil prices expected to continue their rally.

site_title: Uber's US$100m driver pay settlement rejected by judge
summary: A US judge rejected Uber's $100 million settlement with drivers, potentially allowing the company to avoid significant changes to its business model. The drivers' lawsuit, which could have classified them as employees, may be overruled by an appeals court. If successful, Uber would keep its 350,000 California and Massachusetts drivers classified as independent contractors, maintaining its gig-economy workforce model without financial sacrifice.

site_title: Naked Trump statue leaves New York in giggles
summary: A naked statue of Donald Trump was unveiled in Union Square, New York, with an engraved plaque saying "The Emperor Has No Balls." The statue was met with laughter and amusement from onlookers, but was promptly demolished by park wardens. The statue was part of a series of four created by a California-based company, Indecline, which also released videos of the statues being made. The NYC Parks department deemed the statue an unpermitted erection and took it down, stating they stand against any unpermitted structures in city parks.

site_title: US tenant blacklist seen putting homes out of reach for the poor
summary: A tenant blacklist in New York City is making it difficult for low-income individuals to find apartments, as landlords use the list to weed out tenants with housing court records, including those who have won their cases. The list, compiled by tenant-screening database companies, is filled with errors and includes tenants who legally withheld rent due to poor living conditions. A new bill introduced by a councilman aims to provide more complete descriptions of housing court cases, but its success is uncertain. The blacklist exacerbates the affordable housing crisis, putting apartments out of reach for poor people.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher, tracking Wall Street gains
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Friday, tracking a positive lead from Wall Street, with the benchmark Nikkei 225 index climbing 0.44% to 16,558.38. Oil prices also contributed to the gains, lifting the broader Topix index 0.42% to 1,296.26. The increase follows a strong rally on US markets, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records despite trade uncertainty.

site_title: Japan manufacturers' mood at lowest since 2013: Reuters Tankan
summary: Japan's manufacturers are at their lowest mood since 2013, according to a Reuters poll. The service sector's mood rose, but the overall sentiment index for manufacturers fell to 1, indicating pessimism. A strong yen has caused a profit squeeze for exporters, and a new economic stimulus package unveiled by Prime Minister Shinzo Abe had little impact on business morale. The economy stalled in the second quarter due to weak exports and a strong yen, and policymakers face a huge task to generate growth.

site_title: Otto-Hoe Leong spat over US$920k payment
summary: Otto Marine Limited and Hoe Leong Corporation are in a public dispute over a US$920,000 payment. Otto Marine claimed Hoe Leong failed to pay US$1.5 million, but Hoe Leong disputes the claim, stating the payment of US$1.25 million has already been settled. Otto Marine is seeking to have Hoe Leong wound up due to unpaid debts. A hearing on the winding-up application is set for September 13.

site_title: Nigeria foils hijacking of British-flagged merchant tanker
summary: The Nigerian navy successfully foiled a pirate attack on a British-flagged merchant vessel, MT Vectis Osprey, 20 nautical miles off Bonny in southern Rivers state. The pirates were repelled by superior fire power, and the crew was rescued without injury. The incident occurred in a region known for piracy and militancy, where the Niger Delta Avengers have been blamed for recent attacks on pipelines. An investigation has been launched into the incident, and it marks a recent surge in pirate activity since President Muhammadu Buhari took office last year.

site_title: Desperate China airlines dangling lucrative pay at expat pilots
summary: Chinese airlines are offering lucrative pay packages to attract foreign pilots to meet the country's skyrocketing travel demand. The carriers need almost 100 pilots a week for the next 20 years to meet the growing demand. Offers range from US$26,000 a month to US$318,000 a year, with some recruiters reporting a significant increase in interest from pilots. The high pay is necessary due to the country's complex bureaucracy and limited brand recognition, with some foreign pilots earning up to five times more than their Asian rivals.

site_title: Hong Kong Exchange to start volatility controls for its markets
summary: Hong Kong Exchanges & Clearing (HKEX) will introduce a volatility control mechanism to regulate extreme price swings on its markets, starting next week. The system restricts stock price movements to 10% within a 5-minute period, aiming to prevent "fat fingers" and rogue algorithms from causing erroneous price swings. The measure is similar to those used by the Singapore Exchange and Tokyo Stock Exchange. The plan comes after a closing auction was introduced last year and amid concerns over sudden stock price swings, particularly after the UK's Brexit vote.

site_title: Twitter axes 235,000 more accounts in terror crackdown
summary: Twitter has suspended 235,000 accounts in a six-month crackdown on violent extremist content, raising the total to 360,000 since mid-2015. The suspensions, which are up 80% from last year, aim to curb the spread of violent messages and enlist people to extremist groups. Twitter has increased its use of technology to identify and shut down accounts, with automated tools helping to identify over a third of the suspended accounts. The company collaborates with other social platforms to combat terror content and has faced pressure to prevent extremist groups from using its platform.

site_title: Europe: Shares snap losing streak, financials and industrials firmer
summary: European shares rose 0.7% on Thursday, breaking a four-day losing streak, driven by dovish US Federal Reserve minutes and stronger-than-expected earnings from companies like Vestas Wind and NN Group. Financial and industrial stocks stood out, with shares in SAP and Luxottica also tipped for growth. However, some analysts, like Francois Savary, remain cautious, citing a weak economic backdrop and rising Portuguese bond yields, suggesting the equity rally may consolidate in the coming weeks.

site_title: German economy to grow despite increased risks such as Brexit: ministry
summary: Germany's economy is expected to grow despite external risks, including the UK's Brexit decision. The country's economy slowed to 0.4% growth in the second quarter, beating expectations. Strong domestic demand, fueled by record-high employment, rising real wages, and low inflation, will continue to drive growth. The Finance Ministry attributes the slowdown to a mild winter and increased state spending. Tax revenue is expected to remain positive, enabling Finance Minister Wolfgang Schaeuble to increase spending on migrants and infrastructure. The economy is expected to continue growing, despite increased external risks.

site_title: CapitaLand Retail China Trust to buy shopping mall in Chengdu for 1.5b yuan
summary: CapitaLand Retail China Trust (CRCT) has agreed to acquire a shopping mall in Chengdu, China for 1.5 billion yuan (S$303 million). The six-storey mall, Galleria, has a gross floor area of 53,619 square meters and is fully occupied. The acquisition is expected to diversify CRCT's income and strengthen its portfolio, with a potential distribution per unit-accretive. The transaction is expected to enlarge CRCT's portfolio size by about 14% and boost rental income by adjusting the tenant mix. The acquisition is planned to be financed with a mix of existing cash and additional debt.

images.alt_text: Capitaland Retail China Trust (CRCT) is acquiring a shopping mall in Chengdu for 1.5 billion yuan (S$303 million).

site_title: Prosecutors file two more charges against ex-BSI banker in 1MDB probe
summary: Singapore prosecutors have filed two additional charges against former BSI banker Yeo Jiawei in the 1Malaysia Development Bhd probe. The new charges include attempting to pervert the course of justice, allegedly ordering a witness to dispose of evidence. The case may now focus on Hong Kong-based financial services provider Amicorp Group, with whom Yeo was involved. The charges bring the total to 11 filed against Yeo in the ongoing investigation.

site_title: US swimmers made up Rio robbery, vandalised gas station: police
summary: US swimmer Ryan Lochte and three Olympic teammates were not robbed in Rio as they claimed, but were detained after vandalising a gas station bathroom while intoxicated. A security video shows the swimmers being restrained after they tried to leave after damaging the bathroom. Lochte and his teammates were seen handing over cash to pay for the damage. Police are considering charges of falsely reporting a crime and damage to property, but neither offense is punishable by prison. The athletes' claims of a robbery embarrassed the Olympic host city, but their apology is not needed, according to the Rio 2016 Games chief.

images.alt_text: US swimmer Ryan Lochte and three Olympic teammates were not robbed in Rio as they claimed but were detained after drunkenly vandalising a gas station bathroom, police said Thursday.

site_title: Ex-BSI Asia CEO settles Singapore bonus suit with bank
summary: Ex-BSI Asia CEO Hanspeter Brunner has settled a lawsuit against BSI SA, alleging breached bonus agreements and a separation pact. Brunner, 64, was referred to Swiss and Singapore regulators over BSI's ties with 1Malaysia Development Bhd (1MDB). The settlement involves deferred payments, with terms of the agreement not disclosed. Brunner was among six BSI bankers referred to prosecutors over lapses in dealing with 1MDB.

site_title: Uber to launch driverless car service in Pittsburgh
summary: Uber to launch driverless car service in Pittsburgh, starting this month, with Ford Fusions and Volvo XC90 SUVs. The service will initially feature "co-pilots" and safety personnel, before expanding to passengers. Uber also established a $300 million venture with Volvo Cars to develop self-driving cars for sale by 2021 and acquired Otto, a self-driving truck startup. The company aims to boost road safety, citing 90% of accidents caused by human error, and is part of a coalition pushing for a unified US legal code on self-driving cars.

images.alt_text: Uber said on Thursday it would deploy driverless cars for its ride-sharing services in Pittsburgh this month, pushing the envelope for the use of self-driving technology.

site_title: Qatar's oil products demand at record high on planes, World Cup
summary: Qatar's demand for oil products reached a record high in the first five months of 2016, with an average daily consumption of 228,000 barrels per day, more than double the pace in 2011. The country's expanding airline and infrastructure upgrades ahead of hosting the 2022 World Cup are driving the growth. In contrast, Saudi Arabia, the UAE, Oman, and Bahrain have reduced or eliminated fuel subsidies due to low oil prices. Qatar's non-oil economy continues to grow, with an expected 3.4% economic growth rate this year, making it an outlier in the region.

site_title: Fed president upbeat about US job market
summary: Federal Reserve President William Dudley expressed optimism about the US job market, citing strong recent job growth and a return of middle-wage employment. This trend is seen as a positive sign for the economy, as it could create more opportunities for workers and their families. Dudley's comments also reinforce his view that labor market conditions continue to improve, and he notes that the "tide has begun to turn" in terms of middle-wage job gains. This development is considered an important development in the economy, potentially paving the way for future rate hikes.

site_title: Six types of gamblers on the stock market
summary: Investors are often susceptible to various behavioral biases, leading to poor investment decisions. Six types of gamblers on the stock market include: emotional investors, momentum chasers, trend followers, value investors, contrarian investors, and risk-takers. To avoid these pitfalls, investors can acquire investment literacy by reading books and learning to recognize emotions and cognitive biases. By adopting a well-informed approach, investors can make better decisions and avoid "losing money in myriad ways".

site_title: US dollar weaken further on ambivalent Fed stance
summary: The US dollar weakened further against major currencies, including the euro and yen, following the release of the Federal Reserve's July 26-27 meeting minutes. The minutes showed a divided Fed with "options open" for interest rate increases, but no clear indication of policy direction. This led to dollar selling and a rise in euro and yen prices. The dollar fell to 99.94 yen, a low not seen since June, and reached 1.1354 euros per dollar, its highest level since the Brexit vote.

site_title: A 20-year-old play that's as current as ever
summary: The Singapore Repertory Theatre is reviving French playwright Yasmin Reza's award-winning play "Art" 20 years after its initial staging in 1998. The play, which explores the world of art and friendship, will be performed at the National Gallery Singapore, where the art scene has grown significantly over the past two decades, with local artists selling works for over $100,000 and foreign artists' works for six-digit figures. The revival is seen as a perfect fit for the National Gallery, and the play's witty humor and commentary on the art world are expected to resonate with the current audience.

site_title: Philippines to 'seriously consider' ore export ban
summary: The Philippine Lower House of Congress plans to fast-track hearings on a bill to amend the country's mining act, including a measure to ban raw mineral-ore exports. The bill aims to revamp the mining industry and retain more wealth domestically. The move follows Indonesia's halt on shipments two years ago and is part of President Rodrigo Duterte's crackdown on the industry, which has been criticized for environmental regulations. The bill's passage could create jobs and boost government revenue, but concerns about unemployment and economic impact have been raised.

site_title: Field of streams
summary: Singaporean long-time Netflix subscriber Lim Yeong Chun canceled his account six months after its debut due to the streaming service blocking his access to US content and redirecting him to a smaller local library. Chun opted to keep his $8.99 monthly subscription and consider other streaming options. This move highlights the growing competition in the streaming market, with local and international providers competing for subscribers. Chun's decision may signal a shift in his viewing habits, as he explores alternative streaming services available in the market.

site_title: More signs of China property market cool-off
summary: China's property market is showing signs of a cool-off, with analysts citing growing imbalances and slowing growth. Despite this, housing construction, real estate, and public services helped maintain year-on-year growth at 6.7% in the second quarter. Policymakers have responded with investment, public sector spending, and monetary expansion to offset the slowdown.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Singapore banks face significant challenges due to sluggish economic growth, particularly in the oil and gas sector, which may lead to asset quality deterioration. If NPL ratios for the support services sector reach 20-30%, DBS's net profits could decline by 3-5%, while UOB's decline would be 1-2%. The land transport sector is neutral, with ComfortDelGro and SMRT experiencing mixed results, and Viva Industrial Trust is expected to grow its DPU with additional acquisitions and asset enhancements.

site_title: US: Strong energy shares boost stocks
summary: US stocks rose Thursday, driven by gains in petroleum-linked equities. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.1% to 18,597.70, while the S&P 500 climbed 0.2% to 2,187.02. Chevron and Halliburton led the gains, with Brent crude oil closing above $50 a barrel for the first time in nearly two months. However, shares of private prison companies plummeted, including Corrections Corp. of America and The Geo Group, after the Justice Department announced it would phase out their use for federal inmates.

site_title: Short horror film stretched to death
summary: A full-length film based on a two-and-a-half minute YouTube horror clip, Lights Out, has been produced with a $4.9 million budget. The film, directed by David F. Sandberg, follows a middle-aged mother who is haunted by a ghostly figure, but the original short film's success is not replicated in the feature. The film relies on a simple visual trick and gets predictable quickly, with only decent jump scares. Despite the potential of its director, the film feels like a cash-in, and it's recommended to watch it only if time is scarce.

site_title: Singtel buys stakes in Thai, India telcos from Temasek for S$2.47b
summary: Singtel has agreed to buy a 21% stake in Thailand's Intouch Holdings and a 7.39% stake in India's Bharti Telecom Ltd from Temasek Holdings for S$2.47 billion. The acquisitions will be funded by internal cash, short-term debt, and a S$1.61 billion share placement to Temasek. The deals are expected to be completed by December this year, subject to regulatory and minority shareholding approval. The move aims to increase Singtel's exposure to high-performing associates in its portfolio of leading telecom businesses in the region, driven by rapidly increasing smartphone penetration and mobile data adoption in Thailand and India.

images.alt_text: Confirming media reports, Singapore Telecommunications (Singtel) said on Thursday that it has entered into a conditional share purchase agreement with Temasek Holdings to acquire 21 per cent of Intouch Holdings in Thailand and 7.39 per cent of Bharti Telecom Ltd (BTL) in India for a total consideration of S$2.47 billion.

site_title: Japan July exports fall at fastest pace since financial crisis
summary: Japan's exports plummeted 14% in July, the fastest pace since the 2009 financial crisis, due to a resurgent yen and weak external markets. This marks the 10th consecutive month of declining exports, raising concerns about the economy's reliance on domestic demand. The decline was driven by lower shipments to the US, Central America, and Italy, as well as a 12.7% annual fall in exports to China. The Bank of Japan is set to review its monetary policies, while the government has approved fiscal measures worth $180.6 billion to revive the economy.

site_title: Ghost boat sets sail for Venice next year
summary: Artist Zai Kuning's maritime sculpture and explorations of the Malay Archipelago will be featured at the Venice Biennale 2017, specifically at the Singapore Pavilion. His installations, including a ghostly boat sculpture, will convey a sense of loss, longing, and foreboding, highlighting the region's history and cultural influences. Zai will also conduct audio interviews with locals in Indonesia to further research and contextualize his work, which will be displayed from May 13 to November 26, 2017.

site_title: Iswaran tells financial services firms to collaborate while competing
summary: Singapore Minister for Trade and Industry S Iswaran urged financial services firms to collaborate while competing, emphasizing the importance of industry-wide dividends for the country's ability to remain a leading regional financial hub. He encouraged fintech and financial services companies to broaden and deepen their collaborations, extending beyond knowledge sharing to setting common standards and sharing data. Iswaran highlighted the potential of open innovation, citing Singapore's goal to evolve into a leading global fintech hub and its efforts to establish a regulatory sandbox to support innovation.

site_title: Gas glut upends global trade flows as buyers find leverage
summary: A global liquefied natural gas (LNG) glut is causing buyers to renegotiate long-term contracts with suppliers, with India and Japan set to rework existing deals to better align costs with spot market prices. The glut, fueled by new US and Australian supply, is expected to increase the share of spot and short-term deals to half of global trading by 2020. As a result, Asian spot prices for LNG have slumped by 60% since 2014, and Japanese traders are preparing for the opportunities that will arise from the Fair Trade Commission's potential probe into resale restrictions.

images.alt_text: Global LNG trade rose 2.5 per cent to a record 245.2 million tonnes in 2015, according to the International Group of Liquefied Natural Gas Importers.

site_title: Local Zika cases spread to Miami Beach: reports
summary: Miami Beach has reported locally transmitted Zika cases, according to US media reports. This marks the spread of the mosquito-borne virus to a new area in Florida, with 35 cases of local transmission reported statewide. The majority of cases, 25, have been linked to a one-square-mile area in Wynwood, north of downtown Miami. Florida Governor Rick Scott has called on state associations to work on Zika prevention and education, and to offer free mosquito spraying in affected areas. This is the first time local Zika transmission has been reported in the mainland United States.

images.alt_text: Miami Beach now has cases of Zika infection that appear to have been locally transmitted, US media reported on Thursday, suggesting that the mosquito-borne virus is spreading in Florida.

site_title: Dani Abdul Daim quits as executive director of Reliance Pacific
summary: Dani Abdul Daim, son of Malaysia's former finance minister, resigns as executive director of Reliance Pacific Bhd due to a bankruptcy case in Singapore. He owed S$1.65 million to Maybank Kim Eng Securities over Liongold shares. Daim's resignation comes less than a month after his appointment as executive director and follows Reliance's losses of RM24 million for the year to end-March. The company's share price has slipped to 36.5 sen, and management is working on a plan to turn around the company.

site_title: ECB warns against fuelling undue expectations on stimulus
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) has warned against fuelling excessive speculation about future stimulus measures following the UK's Brexit vote. Officials agreed to reiterate their capacity to act if necessary, but emphasized the need to avoid creating undue expectations. The ECB kept its stimulus unchanged, citing a lack of evidence on the full impact of Brexit on the euro area. Policymakers also expressed cautious optimism about the economy and the effectiveness of their monetary policies, while urging European governments to limit uncertainty surrounding exit negotiations.

site_title: Bosch worked 'hand-in- glove' with VW in emissions fraud: lawyers
summary: German car supplier Robert Bosch GmbH worked "hand-in-glove" with Volkswagen AG to evade US emissions laws, according to lawyers representing US owners of polluting VW diesel vehicles. Confidential documents show Bosch's deep understanding of emissions regulations and its role in developing a "cheat device" to circumvent tests. Bosch has not been charged, but German prosecutors are investigating potential wrongdoing. The company has set aside 650 million euros for potential legal costs and is cooperating with authorities.

site_title: Intimate moments and inventive spectacles
summary: The Singapore International Festival of Arts 2016 featured three shows, including "Hamlet | Collage," "Everything By My Side," and "The Last Supper." "Hamlet | Collage" showcased a one-man Hamlet in a spinning cube, while "Everything By My Side" was an intimate encounter with an actress in bed that evoked a person's entire life. "The Last Supper" was a critique of the Egyptian upper class, depicting their greed, self-absorption, and contempt for others. These shows demonstrated innovative storytelling and technical feats, but lacked emotional resonance and depth in some cases.

site_title: Parkson Retail Asia's Q4 loss narrows
summary: Parkson Retail Asia posted a net loss of S$11.98 million in Q4, narrowing from S$59.77 million a year ago. Revenue rose 10.9% to S$93.86 million, driven by stronger sales in Malaysia and Indonesia. "Other expenses" plummeted 70.4% to S$27.6 million. The group expects a challenging operating environment for the first quarter, but has introduced new concepts to diversify earnings. Parkson swung back to a net profit of S$33.1 million for the full year, recognizing a gain on the disposal of an associate company.

site_title: Allianz, AXA said to bid for StanChart Asia insurance rights
summary: Allianz and AXA, two major European insurers, are among first-round bidders for Standard Chartered's insurance rights in Asia, with MS&AD Insurance Group also submitting an offer. The bancassurance agreement aims to secure distribution rights for 15 years, valued at approximately $400 million. This deal follows similar partnerships in the region, as banks seek to expand their insurance offerings to meet growing demand.

site_title: Catalist IPOs: minimum public tranche needed
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) is considering introducing a minimum public tranche of 10% for mainboard IPOs and potentially extending it to Catalist IPOs. This move comes in response to public pressure and criticism of the current 100% placement shares practice, which allows companies to allocate shares to preferred parties. The SGX hopes to encourage greater retail participation and reduce the perception that IPOs are a "public lottery." A minimum public tranche of 30% is suggested for Catalist IPOs, which would require regulatory changes.

site_title: New bus stop concept launched in Jurong East
summary: A new bus stop concept, Project Bus Stop, has been launched in Jurong East, Singapore, designed to "make waiting fun" by incorporating features such as free WiFi, handphone charging points, interactive smart boards, a green roof, and a swing. The initiative, spearheaded by DP Architects, aims to encourage public participation in shaping public spaces and promote urban and social innovation. The bus stop is part of a multi-agency collaboration and will operate for a year from August 2016.

site_title: Correction
summary: A correction was made to an advertisement, stating that the watch is a CARTIER, not OFFICINE PANERAI, due to an error.

site_title: Setting Puccini's Turandot in another period
summary: The Singapore Lyric Opera is re-staging Puccini's Turandot, setting it in the Bronze Age, 3,000 years ago, to create a fantasy-like atmosphere. The opera, which traditionally dates back to the Ching or Ming dynasties, follows the tale of a merciless Chinese princess who refuses to let any man have her unless correctly answering three impossible riddles. The production, directed by Lo King-Man, features a new cast, including South Korean soprano Jee-hye Han as Turandot, and is being re-used from the 2008 production to save costs.

site_title: Civmec's earnings hurt by weaker Aussie dollar
summary: Civmec, a heavy engineering services firm, reported a 77.4% decline in net profit to S$1.5 million for its fiscal fourth quarter, due to a weaker Australian dollar and lack of one-off tax gain. Revenue also fell 22.9% to S$88.4 million for the same period. The decline was attributed to diversification into sectors outside of energy and mining, which is starting to bear fruit.

site_title: Citi CEO seen asking for more patience as targets still elusive
summary: Citi CEO Michael Corbat is under pressure to meet earnings targets as the bank struggles to return capital to shareholders. The Fed's requirement for the lender to retain more capital makes it harder to hit the earnings-to-capital ratio target. Corbat has asked for more patience, citing the bank's need to generate significant capital and improve its financial performance. Analysts say the Fed needs to allow the bank to return more capital to significantly improve shareholder returns. Despite efforts to shed underperforming businesses, Citigroup's shares have risen only 27% during Corbat's tenure as CEO, lagging behind peers.

site_title: The shifting identity of photography
summary: The Singapore International Photography Festival (SIPF) is showcasing its fifth edition, featuring six exhibitions across six MRT stations, with an estimated 120,000 visitors. The festival explores the theme "The Archive" and the shift in photography's role in society, alongside technological advancements and social platforms. Exhibits include works by six female artists, Japanese contemporary photographer Daido Moriyama, and a piece that uses Instagram images to create a narrative. The festival aims to expand the role of photography in everyday life and promote a museum dedicated to photography in Singapore.

site_title: Don't rush Brexit fences too early
summary: Theresa May, Britain's Prime Minister, is advised to wait until the UK knows its negotiating partners for Brexit, as the terms are not yet clear. Sadiq Khan, London's Mayor, suggests a 12-month wait. The article notes that the UK's economy, particularly the City of London, needs time to weigh up the importance of retaining single market access versus starting to implement visa requirements for EU workers. May is urged to avoid a "mad rush" to Brexit and instead adopt a "festina lente" approach, making haste slowly.

site_title: US$ at 7-week low with little Fed support for rate rise
summary: The US dollar fell to a seven-week low against major currencies, closing at 94.460, after Federal Reserve minutes showed a bias against raising interest rates soon. The minutes, released on Wednesday, indicated a slowdown in hiring pace would argue against a near-term hike. The euro rose to a seven-week high, while sterling gained nearly 1% to a two-week high. The dollar index is down 1.3% for the week, and traders remain cautious about pushing the Japanese yen higher due to Bank of Japan intervention expectations.

site_title: Cisco cuts workforce by 7% to speed up transition to software
summary: Cisco Systems Inc announced a 7% workforce reduction, cutting 5,500 positions from its 73,700-strong workforce. The move aims to accelerate the company's transition to software-based systems and services, with $700 million in restructuring charges. CEO Chuck Robbins stated that the company needs to make "immediate shifts" in its portfolio to adapt to rapidly changing customer expectations. The job cuts will focus on areas where growth is expected to come faster, such as security and collaboration.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: StarHub has reintroduced its 12GB mobile data bundles at a lower price of S$96.56 monthly for 24 months, half the cost of a standalone 12GB plan. Norwegian shipbuilder Vard Holdings has secured a US$70 million contract for designing and constructing three module carrier vessels for Kazakhstan's Kazmortransflot. Meanwhile, OUE Limited has acquired two land parcels in Singapore's Good Class Bungalow enclave for S$56.6 million.

site_title: Success or failure of Abenomics hangs precariously
summary: Japan's Abenomics policies, launched in 2012, continue to face intense scrutiny as the country's economic growth rates remain below target. Despite the Bank of Japan's massive monetary easing program, inflation remains elusive, and the economy is struggling with stagnant domestic demand and a rapidly ageing population. Critics argue that policymakers have underestimated the impact of China's economic evolution and misunderstood the consumption-averse psychology of the Japanese people. The government's planned spending program may not be sufficient to boost confidence, and concerns over public debt and the BOJ's monetary easing program persist, casting doubt on the long-term success of Abenomics.

site_title: As technology shifts, more layoffs loom at US tech companies
summary: US tech companies, particularly hardware firms, are expected to experience significant layoffs due to rapid technology shifts, with 63,000 jobs lost this year so far. Cisco's 5,500 layoffs are the latest in a series of announcements, including Intel's 12,000 and Dell's 10,000 job cuts. Analysts predict further cuts, with some estimating 370,000 job losses this year, as companies shift to software-oriented services. Hardware engineers may need to retrain to remain employable, with some recruiters labeling them as the "least attractive skill set" in Silicon Valley.

site_title: Champagne isn't just for that special occasion
summary: Champagne is not limited to special occasions, and its consumption can be enjoyed at any time. The bubbles in champagne are created through a second fermentation process after bottling, which increases pressure and results in the characteristic popping sound. However, shaking the bottle before uncorking can lead to an explosive release of wine, potentially causing injury. To enjoy champagne safely, it's recommended to uncork it slowly and carefully.

site_title: Finance industry needs to gear up for coming blockchain wave
summary: The finance industry is expected to experience a significant wave of blockchain adoption, with potential benefits including reduced transaction costs, improved security, and increased accessibility. Major companies such as Microsoft, Google, and IBM are developing blockchain applications, and private equity has invested over $1 billion in startups utilizing the technology. A prototype blockchain solution developed by the Infocomm Development Authority of Singapore and Bank of America Merrill Lynch has shown promise in streamlining Letter of Credit transactions, with the potential to convert a paper-based financial instrument into a digital one.

site_title: M'sia to take action if proven that 1MDB has been defrauded
summary: Malaysia has threatened to take legal action against individuals named in US civil lawsuits alleging they defrauded a Malaysian state-owned fund, 1MDB, which lost over $3.5 billion. The lawsuits, filed by the US Justice Department, claim the individuals misappropriated funds from the fund, founded by Prime Minister Najib Razak. If proof is found, Malaysia will pursue action against those named, according to a government minister.

site_title: Nanshan said to be party that triggered tender for Central Boulevard site
summary: A China-based group, Nanshan, is believed to have triggered the tender for the 1.1-hectare Central Boulevard site in Singapore, sparking interest in the 99-year leasehold island site. The site, valued at S$3.5 billion, will be developed into a mixed-use project with office, retail, and residential components. Nanshan, which entered the Singapore market a few years ago, is reportedly looking for partners to form a consortium to bid for the site, with the potential for a joint venture with other Chinese property groups or a Hong Kong-based entity.

site_title: Fed officials split in July on rate hike urgency
summary: Federal Reserve officials were divided in July on the urgency to raise interest rates, with some preferring to wait due to benign inflation and others advocating for a rate hike as the labor market nears full employment. The Fed's July meeting minutes showed a lack of consensus, with some officials expressing concerns about the timing of a potential rate increase. Despite this, some policymakers, including New York Fed President William Dudley, believe the US central bank is "edging closer" to another hike.

images.alt_text: Federal Reserve officials were divided in July over the urgency to raise interest rates again, with some preferring to wait because inflation remained benign and others wanting to go soon as the labour market nears full employment.

site_title: After years of pain, coal becomes one of 2016's hottest commodities
summary: Coal prices surged over 35% since mid-June to reach nearly $70 a tonne, making it one of the hottest commodities in 2016, despite being in terminal decline just a year ago. China's surprise increase in coal imports and restrictions on domestic production lifted prices globally, benefiting global mining majors like Glencore and Anglo American, whose shares have risen sharply this year. The price recovery contrasts with previous predictions of coal's decline and is supported by growing demand in Asia and India.

site_title: Ben-Hur remake misfires, not inspires
summary: The 2016 remake of the classic film Ben-Hur, directed by Timur Bekmambetov, has received negative reviews for lacking the epic nature and grandeur of the original 1959 version starring Charlton Heston. Despite a reported $100-million budget and modern technology, the film's narrative is less fully fleshed out, resulting in a "B-movie feel." The remake focuses on Judah Ben-Hur's compassion and faith, but ultimately falls short of inspiring, with many viewers left pondering the point of the remake.

site_title: Yen's rise could spark conflict over currency market intervention
summary: Japan's currency, the yen, rose to nearly 99 to the dollar due to diminishing US interest rate hike prospects, sparking concerns of unilateral action by Japan to stem the rise. This could lead to a possible currency conflict with the US and other major trading partners. The yen's relentless climb has raised alarm among Japanese authorities, who may be forced to intervene to prevent a sharp decline in their exports. The move could have significant implications for the global economy and trade relationships.

site_title: STI sees sixth straight day of losses
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.2% to 2,836.98 on Thursday, marking its sixth consecutive day of losses. The decline was attributed to concerns over Singapore's economic growth, despite the US Federal Reserve's minutes signaling no urgency to hike interest rates. The STI has fallen 1.6% this year, with investors focusing on weak macro data rather than the Fed's rate hike decision.

site_title: Transparency - hallmark of top annual reports
summary: The Best Annual Report Award (BARA) recognizes companies that prioritize transparency and clarity in their annual reports, showcasing their value creation strategies, risks, and sustainability efforts. Leading companies like Singapore Telecommunications Limited and DBS Group Holdings Ltd excel in disclosing their goals, strengths, and weaknesses, as well as their corporate governance and social and environmental sustainability practices. The award aims to encourage companies to go beyond minimum regulatory requirements, meeting the needs of investors and other stakeholders. Effective annual reports build trust, reduce transaction costs, and foster accountability, ultimately contributing to long-term value creation.

site_title: Can't go wrong with Spielberg, Dahl and Disney
summary: Steven Spielberg's adaptation of Roald Dahl's "The BFG" is a visually stunning film that brings the magical world to life. Mark Rylance shines as the titular Big Friendly Giant, and his expressive voice lends the character a realistic quality. The film follows Sophie, a young girl who befriends the BFG, as they band together to fight against the other giants. While some elements have been toned down to make it a family film, the screenwriter retained the original spirit of the book. Despite some flaws, the film is a heartwarming and enchanting experience.

site_title: Trek 2000's Q2 earnings up 3.3% at US$1.1m
summary: Trek 2000 International reported a 3.3% increase in Q2 earnings to US$1.1 million, driven by higher demand for Internet of Things related products. Revenue rose 16.6% to US$48.8 million, mainly from its Interactive Consumer Solutions division. Despite this, the company expects challenging business conditions and will focus on developing new innovations and expanding product offerings.

site_title: BOJ cornered as Japanese banks are running out of bonds to sell
summary: Japan's largest banks, including Japan Post Bank and the three megabanks, are nearly halving their government bond holdings to 114 trillion yen since March 2013. The central bank, Bank of Japan, is facing challenges in buying more bonds due to banks' dwindling capacity to cut their holdings, which are needed as collateral. The BOJ needs to boost its JGB holdings by 80 trillion yen annually, but finding willing sellers is a headache, draining liquidity from the market and making it more volatile.

site_title: China demand for aircraft steady despite economic slowdown: Boeing
summary: Boeing reports steady demand for aircraft in China despite the country's economic slowdown. Senior vice-president Ihssane Mounir stated that Boeing is not experiencing any slippage in demand for jetliners in China, with no signs of weakness in the market. The company is closely monitoring global economic conditions, but as of now, the Chinese market appears robust. This is evident in the delivery of the 50th 787 Dreamliner to ANA Holdings Inc, Japan's largest airline.

site_title: Revenue surge fuels 19% rise in AVJennings' full-year profit
summary: AVJennings, an Australian residential property developer, reported a 19% rise in full-year profit to A$40.9 million, driven by a 32.7% increase in revenue to A$421.9 million. The company declared a final dividend of 3.5 Australian cents per share, benefiting from strong revenues in the second half of FY2016 and stable gross margins. AVJennings attributed its success to its strategy of delivering quality traditional housing at affordable prices in diversified locations, with a low gearing ratio and minimal net debt.

site_title: School? No thanks, I'd rather see Schooling!
summary: National swimmer Joseph Schooling made a public appearance in Singapore, riding a red open-top bus for over three hours as thousands of fans lined the streets to catch a glimpse of him. The 21-year-old Olympic gold medallist, accompanied by his parents and sports officials, made stops at several locations, where he signed autographs, took photos, and sang the national anthem with fans. The event took place before Schooling's departure to the US on Friday, where he will resume his studies and training at the University of Texas.

site_title: Washington Establishment rocking: Hillary could win by a landslide in November
summary: In the Washington D.C. area, a majority of residents, mostly white and liberal, are backing Democratic presidential nominee Hillary Clinton due to her alignment with the local Establishment. This group, comprised of wealthy professionals and government officials, values the status quo and benefits from a strong federal government. In contrast, Republican nominee Donald Trump's anti-elite stance and lack of outreach to swing voters have hurt his chances in key states, including Wisconsin, Michigan, and Pennsylvania. With Clinton leading in polls, she is on track to win the election by a landslide, potentially securing 273 electoral votes.

site_title: US: Wall St opens flat as Fed divided on rates
summary: US stocks opened flat on Thursday, a day after minutes of the Federal Reserve's July meeting showed policymakers divided on raising interest rates. The Dow Jones fell 1.99 points, the S&P 500 gained 0.3 points, and the Nasdaq Composite index added 0.35 points. The mixed signals from the Fed followed a week of rising US stocks, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records. Investors remain cautious due to tariff uncertainty and split views on interest rate hikes.

site_title: Fed's Dudley upbeat on US employment, return of middle-wage jobs
summary: US Federal Reserve policymaker William Dudley expressed optimism about the US labor market, citing strong recent job growth and a return of middle-wage employment. This development has helped alleviate concerns about stagnant job growth and wage inequality. According to Dudley, middle-wage jobs are now gaining ground, creating opportunities for workers and their families. This positive trend may also influence the Fed's decision to raise interest rates in September.

site_title: City buzz
summary:
Here's a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

The Blue Lotus Chinese Eating House is hosting the Chilli Pomelo Crab Challenge, where participants must finish 600g of spicy crab in under five minutes to win. The event is part of the Yellow Ribbon Project, which aims to rehabilitate ex-offenders through art and community engagement. An art exhibition, "From Night to Light," is also on display at the Singapore Art Museum. Meanwhile, a new menu has been launched at Gallery & Co, showcasing contemporary Singaporean flavors. The Japanese film "Shin Godzilla" is set to release in Singapore, and the Yellow Ribbon Prison Run is scheduled for September.

site_title: No new rate hints as Federal Reserve joins Facebook
summary: The Federal Reserve launched a Facebook page, expanding its communications strategy, but provided no new insights into interest rate direction. The page, which includes press releases and reports, follows criticism of existing communications for being vague or shifting too frequently. The Fed's July 26-27 meeting minutes, released earlier, showed policymakers still divided on raising interest rates, with no convincing indication of a September rate hike. The market reaction to the minutes may be attributed to growing frustration over the Fed's communication style.

site_title: Philly Fed business index rises, job gauge hit 7-year low
summary: The Philadelphia Fed business index rose to 2.0 in August, the highest since January 2015, indicating expansion in the US mid-Atlantic region's manufacturing. However, local employment declined to its worst level in seven years, with the employment index dropping to -20.0. The new orders index also fell to -7.2, the lowest since December. Despite this, the six-month outlook measure rose for a second month to 45.8, suggesting continued improvement in the region's business activity.

site_title: Oil over US$50 at 6-week high on talk of supply freeze
summary: Brent crude oil reached a six-week high of $50.22 a barrel, surpassing $50 for the first time since July 4, as OPEC producers prepare to discuss a possible freeze in production levels. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries will meet in Algeria on September 26-28. However, analysts remain skeptical that a production freeze will lead to higher prices, citing Saudi Arabia's plans to boost crude oil supplies. The market is also vulnerable to a dip in demand during the northern hemisphere summer season and the potential for a price rally based on speculation about future talks.

images.alt_text: Brent crude oil hit a six-week high above US$50 a barrel on Thursday as the world's biggest producers prepared to discuss a possible freeze in production levels.

site_title: VW to cut hours at three more plants amid supplier row: source
summary: Volkswagen plans to cut working hours at three German plants due to a supplier shortage. The cuts, which could affect over 10,000 workers, are a possible response to supply problems caused by a parts maker refusing to meet delivery commitments. Volkswagen has not yet made a final decision on the plan. The affected plants are in Wolfsburg, Kassel, and Zwickau.

images.alt_text: Volkswagen will cut working hours in some parts of production at its core factory in Wolfsburg and two other German plants as it grapples with a supplies shortage caused by a parts maker refusing to stick with delivery commitments, a source close to VW said on Thursday.

site_title: ECB stresses 'readiness to act' in face of Brexit headwinds
summary: European Central Bank policymakers expressed concerns about "new headwinds" for the eurozone following Britain's Brexit vote, citing "downside risks" that had increased. The ECB remains "ready to act" but did not commit to further loosening monetary policy, despite low inflation and sluggish economic growth. The bank's quantitative easing program and deposit rate remain unchanged, but policymakers are considering options to boost the program, including extending it past its current deadline. The ECB will reassess its stance at its September meeting.

site_title: Zika virus infection may harm adult brain: study
summary: A study using lab mice found that Zika virus infection can damage adult brain cells, specifically those involved in learning and memory. The virus can destroy these cells, leading to a four- to 10-fold drop in adult stem cell proliferation. Researchers observed cell death and reduced generation of new neurons in two brain areas, including the hippocampus. The study suggests that Zika infection may have a more subtle effect on the adult brain, potentially leading to long-term effects such as impaired memory or depression.

site_title: Not your standard summer offering
summary: The film "Indignation" is a dialogue-driven drama based on Philip Roth's 2008 book, directed by James Schamus. Set in the early 1950s, it follows Marcus Messner (Logan Lerman), a Jewish young man from Newark, New Jersey, as he navigates his way through college and relationships amidst strict social norms and parental expectations. He becomes involved with Olivia (Sarah Gadon) and challenges the conservative community's values, leading to a tragic confrontation with the consequences of his actions. The film explores themes of identity, rebellion, and mortality, offering a nuanced portrayal of adolescence and the complexities of growing up.

site_title: Sage customers exposed to data breaches of their own making
summary: Sage Group, a British financial software provider, has been hit by two security breaches in two days. A US researcher uncovered online data from over 20 customers who failed to install Sage business planning software with basic firewall protections. The incidents highlight the security risks facing technology suppliers, from rogue employees to lax customer security practices. Sage has contacted vulnerable customers to shut down connections, and experts say the breaches are unlikely to be the result of outside hackers.

site_title: SIA senior vice-president (finance) Stephen Barnes on medical leave
summary: Singapore Airlines' senior vice-president of finance, Stephen Barnes, is on medical leave for about one month. The board wishes him a speedy recovery as he recuperates at home following hospitalization. In his absence, divisional vice-president Chia Siok Hua is covering his duties.

site_title: Courage Marine eyes South Korea artist management business
summary: Courage Marine, a South Korean shipping company, plans to acquire a South Korean artist management firm, BDG Entertainment, in an effort to diversify its revenue streams. The acquisition, which is subject to negotiations, aims to capture new business opportunities and create value for shareholders. The consideration for the acquisition will be determined after negotiations. This move is expected to expand Courage Marine's services beyond marine transportation and logistics.

images.alt_text: DRY bulk carrier owner Courage Marine is planning to acquire a South Korean artist management firm in order to diversify its revenue sources.

site_title: German state woos foreign banks after Brexit vote
summary: German Finance Minister Thomas Schaefer is trying to persuade foreign banks to relocate to Frankfurt after Britain's Brexit vote. He met with British banks in Frankfurt and offered reassurances about local labor laws and tax rates. Schaefer claims Frankfurt's infrastructure and hosting of the European Central Bank are sufficient reasons for banks to move. He emphasized that no special deals would be offered, unlike London, and acknowledged that some banks have expressed concerns about being seen as disloyal to London. This effort aims to bolster Frankfurt's financial capital at London's expense.

site_title: Amazon steps up British investment with Tilbury distribution centre
summary: Amazon plans to create 1,500 new jobs in 2017 with the opening of a new distribution centre in Tilbury, south east England. This investment follows the announcement of 500 new jobs at a fulfilment centre in Doncaster, northern England, and brings Amazon's total UK job creation to over 15,500 by the end of 2016. The new jobs are needed to meet increasing demand and support independent small businesses selling on Amazon Marketplace.

site_title: US jobless claims fall more than expected as labour market firms
summary: US jobless claims fell more than expected, dropping 4,000 to 262,000 for the week ended Aug 13, reinforcing views of a strong labor market. This marks the longest stretch of claims below 300,000 since 1973. Economists predict the Federal Reserve may raise interest rates soon due to labor market buoyancy, despite low inflation and sluggish economic growth. The US dollar extended losses, while US stock futures pared losses slightly.

site_title: Norway's wealth fund cuts value of UK real estate after Brexit
summary: Norway's $890 billion sovereign wealth fund has cut the value of its UK real estate portfolio by 5% after Britain voted to leave the European Union.
