The fund's deputy CEO attributed this move to market uncertainty, stating that the fund has no indication of further adjustments. Despite this, the fund returned to gains in the second quarter, driven by falling interest rates and a 1.3% gain in its stock portfolio. The fund's real estate holdings lost 1.6% in the second quarter, and government withdrawals totaled 24 billion kroner.

site_title: GLP, China's CIMC to develop integrated logistics facilities and solutions
summary: Global Logistic Properties (GLP) and China International Marine Containers (CIMC) have formed a strategic cooperation framework agreement to develop integrated logistics facilities and solutions. GLP will assist CIMC in planning and managing existing logistics facilities, while CIMC will benefit from GLP's collaborative platforms in the logistics ecosystem. This partnership aims to improve supply chain efficiency and competitiveness for customers, following GLP's established partnerships with Chinese state-owned companies since 2014.

site_title: Weezer keeps things short and sweet as usual
summary: Weezer performed a 75-minute concert in Singapore, featuring 16 songs from their extensive discography, including hits like "Buddy Holly" and "California Kids." The band's frontman, Rivers Cuomo, showcased his talent and knack for writing catchy choruses and infectious guitar hooks. The setlist included a mix of old and new songs, with Cuomo even performing a solo cover of Fun's "We Are Young" during the encore. Despite his 46 years, Cuomo proved he still has it, and the concert was well-received by the 3,000 fans.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end flat on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index ended flat on Thursday, closing at 1,694.87 after a slight 0.55-point drop. 2.85 billion lots valued at RM1.99 billion were traded, with 384 gainers and 439 losers.

site_title: Britain launches soft drinks sugar tax to fight obesity
summary: Britain has introduced a soft drinks sugar tax to combat childhood obesity, with the goal of reducing sugar intake in products aimed at children by 20% by the end of the year. The tax, which applies to drinks with above 5 grams of sugar per 100ml, will raise funds for health programs for school children. Critics argue the plan is too weak, while health experts welcome the initiative, citing the significant impact of sugary drinks on obesity and diabetes.

site_title: OUE acquiring two land parcels at Nassim Road after successful tender
summary: PROPERTY developer OUE Limited acquired two land parcels at 28 Nassim Road in Singapore's exclusive Good Class Bungalow enclave for S$56.6 million. The land parcels total 3,100 square meters and are adjacent to Eden Hall, the residence of the British High Commissioner. The bid price was determined based on factors including location and market value.

site_title: ECB did not consider any action at first meeting after Brexit: minutes
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) did not consider any policy change at its July meeting following the Brexit vote, taking comfort from a calmer-than-expected market reaction. ECB members agreed to reassess the situation in the following months, despite increased risks, and deemed it premature to discuss any monetary policy reaction. The decision was made to allow more time to assess incoming information and address downside risks.

site_title: Weaker Aussie dollar, lack of one-off gain hurt Civmec Q4 earnings
summary: Civmec reported a 77.4% drop in net profit to S$1.5 million in its fourth quarter, due to a weaker Australian dollar and lack of a one-off tax gain. Revenue declined 22.9% to S$88.4 million, with earnings per share sinking to 0.26 Singapore cents from 1.31 cents in the previous year. The company's net asset value per share edged up to 32.11 Singapore cents.

site_title: Hoe Leong faces winding up petition from Otto Marine
summary: Otto Marine Limited has filed a winding up petition against Hoe Leong Corporation, citing a debt of US$1.5 million that the company failed to pay. Hoe Leong paid US$580,000 after repeated demands, leaving US$920,000 outstanding. A hearing is set for September 13. Otto Marine is working with lawyers to enforce its rights and protect its interests and assets.

images.alt_text: OTTO Marine Limited has applied for a winding up of another listed company Hoe Leong Corporation for not being able to pay off debts owed to the group.

site_title: Saudi Arabia to let foreign investors participate in IPOs
summary: Saudi Arabia has approved regulations allowing foreign investors to subscribe to initial public offerings (IPOs) in the kingdom, starting January 1, 2026. This move comes after oil prices halved in the past two years, opening the Tadawul Stock Exchange to increased international participation. The Capital Market Authority has relaxed restrictions on foreign investors, enabling them to participate in IPOs and increasing international investment in the kingdom's stock market.

site_title: Singapore shares fall 0.2%
summary: Singapore shares closed lower on Thursday, falling 0.2% to 2,836.98, with the Straits Times Index losing 6.4 points. The decline was attributed to a relatively stable market with 756 million shares changing hands, resulting in 233 counters down and 171 up.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singtel plans to buy 21% stake in Intouch Holdings and 7.39% stake in Bharti Telecom for S$2.47 billion, deepening its presence in Thailand and India. Singapore prosecutors charged former BSI banker Yeo Jiawei with witness tampering in the 1MDB probe. Minister for Trade and Industry S Iswaran emphasized the importance of fintech for Singapore's economy. StarHub reintroduced 12GB mobile data bundles, while swimmer Joseph Schooling celebrated his Olympic gold medal victory parade. Singapore shares fell 0.2% on Thursday.

site_title: Indonesia's tax amnesty shows slow progress in first month
summary: Indonesia's tax amnesty program, launched last month, has seen slow progress, with only 0.4% of its target revenue of $16.88 billion collected in the first month. As of Thursday, the program had brought in $679 billion in revenue and 5,613 taxpayers had declared $33.3 trillion in assets, mostly already in Indonesia. The government hopes to collect $70 billion in offshore assets and is concerned by the low repatriation rate, which has been impacted by a legal challenge to the amnesty filed by activists.

site_title: Thailand raises investment target in wake of referendum
summary: Thailand has raised its investment target for 2016 to $15.9 billion, up 100 billion baht from the previous projection of $15.7 billion. The move comes after a referendum on a new military-backed constitution, which has reduced political uncertainty and boosted investor sentiment. The country expects 550 billion baht ($21.26 billion) in overall investment applications this year, a 152% increase from 2015. Foreign investors, including Japan and Singapore, have expressed interest in investing in Thailand's infrastructure and firms.

site_title: Nigeria oil min says Opec cuts unlikely, Algeria meeting could help price
summary: Nigeria's oil minister Emmanuel Ibe Kachikwu stated that a cut in Opec production is unlikely, but a meeting in Algeria could help stabilize crude prices. Nigeria's oil output has fallen to 1.56 million barrels per day due to militant attacks, while other Opec producers are expected to increase production. Kachikwu expressed hope that the Algeria meeting could lead to discussions with major producers like Russia, the US, and Mexico, potentially influencing crude prices.

images.alt_text: Nigerian oil minister Emmanuel Ibe Kachikwu said on Thursday that while a cut in Opec production is unlikely, there is hope a meeting of producers in Algeria next month could help shore up crude prices.

site_title: China smelters face lowest fees in 4 yrs as zinc market tightens
summary: China's zinc smelting industry has lowered its treatment charges by 20% to around $100-$110 a tonne, nearing a four-year low, amid dwindling global mine output and a tightening market. The move is expected to further drive up refined zinc prices, which have already gained 40% this year, to $3,900 a tonne by Q4-17, according to ICBC Standard Bank. The industry's ability to hold out before cutting output is uncertain, with analysts estimating they have one to two months of concentrate supply.

site_title: Otto Marine's application to wind up group 'an abuse of process': Hoe Leong
summary: Hoe Leong Corporation has accused Otto Marine of abusing the process by filing an application to wind up the group, citing a US$920,000 debt. Hoe Leong claims the debt is part of a US$1.25 million payment due to Otto Marine, but has already delivered 13 cheques totaling US$1.25 million. The company claims it only paid US$580,000, leaving US$920,000 outstanding. Hoe Leong denies the debt, saying Otto Marine failed to provide evidence of the debt.

site_title: Oil prices rise as potential supply cuts remain in focus
summary: Oil prices rose on Thursday, with Brent crude oil futures reaching US$50 a barrel for the first time in six weeks. Traders expect potential supply cuts from Opec and non-Opec producers at a meeting next month, driving up prices. US crude inventories fell unexpectedly last week, supporting prices. However, analysts remain skeptical about the likelihood of a deal, citing previous failed meetings. The potential for a price rally is also based on shaky ground, with Citi warning of risks.

site_title: NauticAWT unit snags US$2.5m turnkey project for 15 platforms in Indian waters
summary: NauticAWT's subsidiary, Nautic Offshore, has secured a US$2.5 million contract for a two-year turnkey project in Indian waters. The project involves detailed engineering, repair, and installation for 15 ageing platforms, valued at US$2.5 million. This is part of the Life Extension of Wellhead Platforms-2 (LEWP-2) project and is considered one of the biggest brownfield revamping projects in Indian waters. The contract is expected to start in the fourth quarter of 2016.

site_title: Europe: Stocks climb at open
summary: European stock markets rose at the start of trading on Thursday, with London's FTSE 100 index up 0.2% to 6,873.24 points, and Frankfurt's DAX 30 up 0.7% to 10,613.08 points. In contrast, Tokyo's main index slumped due to fading expectations of a Federal Reserve rate hike, sparking a yen rally.

site_title: Morgan Stanley says Fed rate bets too high, buy five-year notes
summary: Morgan Stanley predicts investors are overestimating US interest rate hikes this year, citing low inflationary pressures. The bank expects the probability of a rate increase by December to drop to 30% as inflation remains absent from the US economy. Benchmark Treasuries held gains after the Federal Reserve's July meeting minutes showed officials saw little risk of a sharp uptick in consumer prices. The bank recommends buying five-year Treasury notes, predicting yields will drop towards 1.14% and the yield curve will flatten.

site_title: Eurozone return to inflation confirmed as food prices surge
summary: Eurozone inflation rose 0.2% year-on-year in July, exceeding initial estimates, but still short of the European Central Bank's target of 2%. Food prices surged, with unprocessed foodstuffs increasing 2.9% year-on-year, while energy prices fell 6.7%. Core inflation remained unchanged at 0.8% and services prices rose 1.2% year-on-year. Smaller economies in the east continued to experience negative annual inflation rates, while Belgium and Sweden led those with rising prices. Overall, the eurozone's inflation rate remains below the bank's target.

site_title: Vard Holdings bags US$70m contract
summary: Vard Holdings has secured a US$70 million contract from Kazakhstan shipping firm Kazmortransflot for the design and construction of three module carrier vessels for the Caspian Sea. The vessels will be built at Vard Braila in Romania, with delivery scheduled between Q3 2017 and Q1 2018. This contract further solidifies Vard's commitment to the region, following its experience in building vessels for Kazakhstan.

site_title: Disasters cost US$71b in first half of 2016: Swiss Re
summary: Disasters worldwide cost US$71 billion in the first half of 2016, a 38% increase from the same period last year, according to Swiss Re. Natural disasters accounted for 97% of the losses, with 6,000 fatalities. In contrast, human-made events, such as cyber attacks and terrorism, were responsible for only US$3 billion in losses. This marks a decrease in the human cost of disasters, with 6,000 deaths compared to 12,000 in the first six months of 2015.

site_title: UK shoppers defy Brexit shock as spending jumps in July
summary: UK retail sales jumped 1.4% in July, exceeding forecasts, as shoppers defied the Brexit shock. Warm weather boosted clothing sales, while the weaker pound tempted overseas buyers to spend on luxury items. Sales of watches and jewelry surged 16.6% in July, the biggest jump in nearly two years. However, consumer morale suffered its sharpest drop since 1990, and the Bank of England expects lower growth in household spending due to the Brexit vote.

site_title: The digital airline takes flight
summary: A digital airline is taking flight in Singapore, with 46% of airline flights purchased online. The digital revolution is transforming the aviation industry, with airlines facing challenges in adopting a digital strategy due to cultural resistance, legacy technologies, and operational silos. Airlines must balance dependence on intermediaries with managing their own digital offerings. To improve customer experiences, airlines can leverage unique strengths such as flight ownership, customer insights, and touchpoints. Digital technologies can also enhance personalized experiences, improve operational efficiency, and reduce the power of intermediaries.

site_title: Parkson Retail Asia's Q4 losses narrow to S$12m
summary: Parkson Retail Asia Limited reported net losses of S$11.98 million for the fourth quarter ended June 30, narrowing from S$59.77 million in the same period last year. Revenue rose 10.9% to S$93.86 million, driven by a 21.5% year-on-year growth in same-store sales in Malaysia. In contrast, same-store sales in Indonesia grew 7.3%, while those in Vietnam and Myanmar declined 4.1% and 25% respectively. The group expects a challenging operating environment in the first quarter of fiscal 2017 due to the shift in festive buying days and uncertain economic conditions.

site_title: Europe is leaving the workforce of the future on the sidelines
summary: Europe is struggling with a significant issue: one in six people aged 20-24 are not in employment, education, or training, totaling 5 million individuals across the 28-nation EU. This group, known as "Neets," faces a permanent disadvantage on the labor market, according to policy expert Guntram Wolff. This problem has persisted for six years since the euro's debt crisis began.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks finish up but Shanghai slips
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.98% on Thursday, driven by gains in technology and telco stocks, while the Shanghai Composite Index fell 0.17%. The Hang Seng Index rose to 23,023.16, but the Shanghai Index dropped to 3,104.11. Investors await more corporate results, contributing to the mixed market performance.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks climb on foreign buying; Samsung Electronics hits record high
summary: South Korean shares rose 0.6% to a record high on Thursday, driven by foreign buying worth 195.4 billion won. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) closed at 2,055.47. Samsung Electronics led the gains, hitting a record high. The rally comes despite global market uncertainty, with investors seeking value in the Asian market.

site_title: Low-cost airlines bet on data to drive profit
summary: Low-cost airlines in Europe, particularly Ryanair and easyJet, are shifting their focus from mocking traditional customer loyalty schemes to leveraging data analytics to drive profits. Both airlines have launched customer loyalty schemes and invested in data analytics, aiming to personalize offers and adapt services to customer preferences. Ryanair focuses on selling optional extras, while easyJet uses ticket pricing algorithms to adjust seat prices in real-time. The move is seen as a transformation in the airline industry, with legacy carriers also investing heavily in digitization.

images.alt_text: Europe's low-cost airlines once mocked the air miles programmes run by flag carriers as expensive relics of a bygone era. But after watching wide-eyed as customer databases were valued at billions of dollars, they are scrambling to catch up.

site_title: Hong Kong shipping group calls for aid to crew on arrested coal ship
summary: A Hong Kong shipping group has called on the Hong Kong government to provide aid to the crew of a detained coal ship off the east coast of Australia, where the crew is running out of food and fuel. The Five Stars Fujian, a Hong Kong-flagged coal carrier, has been under detention for a month due to breaches of maritime labor laws. The Hong Kong Shipowners Association urges the government to provide necessary assistance to the seafarers, citing a moral and ethical obligation due to Hong Kong's significant merchant fleet.

images.alt_text: The Hong Kong Shipowners Association (HKSOA) on Thursday called on the city's authorities to provide assistance to the crew of a Hong Kong-flagged coal ship off the east coast of Australia that is running out of food and fuel.

site_title: China's Alipay deepens push into Europe with Ingenico partnership
summary: Alipay, China's largest online payments platform, has partnered with Ingenico Group to allow Chinese consumers to use its mobile payment app across Europe. The deal, signed in Paris, marks Alipay's push into Europe and complements Ingenico's existing presence in the region. With over 450 million active users, Alipay will be embedded into Ingenico's in-store payment gateway, while Ingenico expects to benefit from Alipay's ambitions in Africa and China. The partnership is seen as a strategic move to expand Alipay's global reach and deepen its mobile-payment push.

site_title: Singapore slaps 2 more charges of witness tampering against ex-BSI banker in 1MDB probe
summary: Singapore prosecutors have filed two additional charges against former BSI banker Yeo Jiawei, bringing the total to 11 charges related to tampering with witnesses in the 1MDB probe. The trial dates for these new charges are set for October 31 to November 11. Yeo, who has not been granted bail, is also scheduled for a criminal case disclosure conference on September 8. This development comes as part of the ongoing investigation into 1MDB, a Malaysian state-owned investment fund.

images.alt_text: SINGAPORE prosecutors filed two more charges on Thursday against former BSI banker Yeo Jiawei for tampering with witnesses in an ongoing probe into 1Malaysia Development Berhad (1MDB).

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks rally to one-year high on earnings optimism
summary: Hong Kong stocks reached a one-year high as Tencent Holdings, Ping An Insurance, and Lenovo Group reported earnings that topped estimates, with the Hang Seng Index jumping 1.6% at midday. The rally, fueled by optimism over an improving interest-rate outlook and a stabilizing property market, has lifted the benchmark index 26% from its February low. However, technical indicators signal that gains may be overheating, with some warning of a potential reversal.

site_title: China launches US$30b state-controlled venture capital fund
summary: China has approved a 200 billion yuan (S$40.5 billion) state-controlled venture capital fund to invest in innovative technology and industrial upgrading projects. The fund, financed by state-owned companies, aims to create globally competitive conglomerates by supporting firms that can upgrade and compete globally. The fund will implement national strategies, focusing on selective investments and cutting off credit for non-competitive firms. This move is part of China's efforts to upgrade its industrial sector and reduce dependence on state control.

site_title: China: Stocks fall, property shares pare gains on profit-taking
summary: China's stocks fell, with the CSI300 index dropping 0.3% to 3,364.49, and the Shanghai Composite Index losing 0.2% to 3,104.11 points. The market was initially boosted by a surge in the real estate sector, but profit-taking led to a decline in the afternoon. The property subindex rose 1.4% and home prices increased 0.8% in July, but at a slower pace than in June. The banking and consumer sectors also declined, with the former falling 0.5% and the latter losing 0.9%.

site_title: Yuan strengthens to two-month high as US rate concerns ease
summary: China's yuan strengthened to a two-month high, reaching 6.6277 per US dollar, as minutes from the Federal Reserve's latest meeting showed officials are divided on raising interest rates. This move, combined with a planned stock link between Shenzhen and Hong Kong, is seen as enhancing the yuan's investment currency status. The People's Bank of China also weakened its daily reference rate by 0.33%, while a trade-weighted yuan index fell 0.31%. The yuan's appreciation is attributed to concerns about the urgency of US interest rate hikes.

site_title: 'Buy' call on Singtel follows its proposed acquisition of stakes (Amended)
summary: Singtel has received a "BUY" call with a target price of S$4.55 following its proposed acquisition of stakes in Intouch Holdings and Bharti Telecom. The S$2.47 billion transactions are expected to be completed by December 2016, subject to minority-shareholder and regulatory approvals. The funding will come from new shares, cash, and short-term debt. The deal is seen as a strategic move to expand Singtel's presence in Thailand and India.

site_title: No Go: Vietnam bans Pokemon game from government, defence sites
summary: Vietnam has banned playing the popular game Pokémon Go in government offices, defence sites, and other restricted areas due to safety concerns. The country has seen thousands of players, mostly young citizens, caught up in the game since its release in August. The ban warns of risks such as accidents, theft, and loss of personal information. The move follows similar bans in neighboring Cambodia and Thailand, which have also restricted the game due to its potential to cause harm and disrupt daily life.

site_title: Chinese property investment overseas more than doubles in H1: CBRE
summary: Chinese investors more than doubled their overseas property investments in the first half of 2016, reaching US$16.1 billion, according to CBRE. The majority of this investment came from insurance companies, with hotels and offices being the most sought-after types of real estate. The US remains the top destination for Chinese investors, and they are seeking a safer investment environment with higher potential returns. While growth is expected to be more sustainable in the second half, investors are looking for alternative sectors such as student housing.

site_title: Olympics: Thousands at Singapore swimmer Schooling's parade
summary: Thousands gathered in Singapore for a victory parade of swimmer Joseph Schooling, who won the country's first Olympic gold medal in the men's 100m butterfly final at the 2016 Rio Olympics. Schooling, 21, waved to crowds from an open-top bus while sporting a new tattoo, and was formally congratulated by Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong. He has been exempted from National Service for four years to prepare for the 2020 Tokyo Olympics, and is considering a professional career in the US.

images.alt_text: Thousands turned out Thursday at a victory parade for swimmer Joseph Schooling, who clinched the country's first Olympic gold medal with a stunning victory over his boyhood idol Michael Phelps.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei falls to near 2-week low as strong yen sours mood
summary: Japan's Nikkei share average fell 1.6% to a near two-week low on Thursday, dragged down by a strong yen. The Nikkei closed at 16,486.01, its lowest level since August 5. The broader Topix and JPX-Nikkei Index 400 also declined 1.6% each. The yen's strength soured investor risk appetite, leading to a decline across the board.

site_title: Australia's ANZ and NAB named in US class action for BBSW trading
summary: Australia and New Zealand Banking Group (ANZ) and National Australia Bank (NAB) are named in a US class action for allegedly manipulating bank bill swap rates (BBSW). The class action, filed by two US-based investment funds and an individual derivatives trader, is separate from ongoing charges by the Australian Securities and Investments Commission (ASIC). The BBSW is a benchmark interest rate used to price home loans and other financial products in Australia. The banks have denied any wrongdoing and are facing additional charges from ASIC.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks flat; CTBC Financial rallies on reported stake fight
summary: Taiwan's stocks remained flat in cautious trading, with the main Taiex index nearly unchanged at 9,118.47. CTBC Financial Holdings surged 7.4% to its highest level in nearly a year, following reports of a prominent investor, Samuel Yin, hoping to seize control of the bank. The electronics subindex declined 0.2%, while the financials subindex gained 0.7%. The Taiwan dollar strengthened to NT$31.373 per US dollar.

site_title: Quake rocks Australia tourist towns
summary: A 5.7-magnitude earthquake struck Australia's northeastern coastline, affecting tourist towns from Sunshine Coast to north of Townsville, Queensland. The quake hit 54km off Bowen at a depth of 7km, causing buildings in Townsville to be evacuated but with no reported major damage. The Bureau of Meteorology issued no tsunami warning, and geoscience officials expect aftershock activity. The shaking lasted for about 6-7 seconds, with some residents describing it as funny and scary, while others reported no damage.

site_title: US dollar drops after Fed minutes dampen hike expectations
summary: The US dollar dropped after the Federal Reserve's July meeting minutes indicated policymakers remained divided on inflation, dampening hopes of an imminent interest rate hike. The minutes showed the Fed was keeping options open but unlikely to move until consensus on growth, hiring, and inflation. This led to a decline in the dollar against the yen and other currencies, with the euro rising to US$1.1306. The dollar's fall was attributed to the Fed's cautious stance, contradicting previous hints of a potential September rate hike.

site_title: Tencent rises over 6% in Hong Kong after Q2 beats estimates
summary: Tencent Holdings Ltd shares rose 6.2% in Hong Kong after beating Q2 earnings estimates with a 47% profit jump. The company's dominance in China's mobile gaming market contributed to the surprise result. This led to a record high opening price of HK$205. The benchmark index also rose 1.1% on the same day.

site_title: China's Greenland, Ping An, Agile to invest US$1b in US biotech site
summary: China's Greenland Holdings, Agile Group, Ping An Trust, and Poly Sino Capital are jointly investing over US$1 billion in a 210,000-square-metre biotech industrial park in south San Francisco. Greenland Holdings, the largest investor, aims to enhance cooperation between China and the US on biotech research and development. This investment marks the company's expansion outside China and its entry into the biotech industry, following its growth in the US real estate market. The project's total value is estimated to be US$1.12 billion, with Greenland Holdings owning 49% of the project.

site_title: Philippine Q2 growth hits 7.0% year on year, above forecasts
summary: The Philippine economy experienced a 7.0% year-on-year growth in the second quarter, exceeding forecasts of 6.7%. This is the fastest growth in a quarter in three years. The government announced the growth on Thursday, citing a pace of expansion. Growth for the April-June quarter is yet to be released, with economists predicting a 1.8% expansion.

site_title: Asia: Most stocks rise after Fed minutes show caution
summary: Asian stocks rose after US Federal Reserve minutes showed caution on raising interest rates, supporting markets. Most stocks tracked US gains, with Hong Kong up 1.2%, Shanghai 0.1%, and Seoul 0.3%. Tokyo fell 0.4% due to a strong yen affecting exporters like Toyota and Nissan. The dollar fell to 99.83 yen, while oil prices rose after US inventories showed declines in crude and gasoline stocks.

site_title: StarHub reintroduces 12GB mobile data bundles
summary: StarHub has reintroduced 12GB mobile data bundles as part of its new SurfHub service, offering customers a bundle of 4G mobile and fibre home broadband for S$96.56 monthly over 24 months. This is about half the cost of a standalone 12GB mobile plan, with additional perks including up to 700 minutes of local talktime and 1,500 local SMS/MMS. Customers also receive a mobile handset subsidy and discounts on complementary services, such as international roaming and multi-device sharing. The move aims to provide customers with affordable data bundles.

site_title: Brazil police detain two US swimmers on plane
summary: Brazilian police detained US Olympic swimmers Jack Conger and Gunnar Bentz on a plane bound for the US, questioning their claims of being robbed at gunpoint in Rio. The detentions follow a judge's order to probe inconsistencies in their stories, including varying accounts of the robbery and their behavior after the incident. The investigation raises doubts about the authenticity of the robbery claim, which had embarrassed Rio authorities and heightened fears for tourists during the Olympics.

site_title: Update: Singtel to buy 21% of Intouch, 7.39% of Bharti Telecom from Temasek for S$2.47b
summary: Singtel plans to buy a 21% stake in Intouch Holdings and a 7.39% stake in Bharti Telecom from Temasek Holdings for S$2.47 billion in cash. The acquisitions will deepen Singtel's foothold in Thailand and India's high-growth wireless markets. The deals will be fully settled in cash, with internal cash and short-term debt used to fund the purchases. Temasek's stake in Singtel will be boosted to 52.27% after the placement of new shares. The acquisitions are expected to enhance shareholder value and maximize the value of Singtel's existing businesses, with no impact on the company's dividend policy.

images.alt_text: Singapore Telecommunications (Singtel) said on Thursday it plans to buy a 21 per cent stake in Intouch Holdings PCL and a 7.39 per cent stake in Bharti Telecom (BTL) from Temasek Holdings for S$2.47 billion in cash.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks rally at open after Fed minutes
summary: Hong Kong stocks rallied at the open on Thursday, driven by minutes from the Federal Reserve's July meeting showing disagreement on interest rate hikes. The Hang Seng Index surged 1.18%, while the Shanghai Composite Index edged down 0.06%. The rally followed mixed signals from the Fed, with some investors interpreting the decision as a delay in rate hikes.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down slightly to 1,693.63 points. A total of 33 million lots were traded, worth RM11 million, with 73 gainers outnumbering 56 losers.

site_title: Australia, New Zealand dollars rally on jobs report, Fed
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars rallied after better-than-expected jobs figures in Australia and speculation that the US Federal Reserve is in no rush to raise interest rates. The Australian dollar rose to a three-month peak, while the New Zealand dollar rose to US$0.7290. The jobs report showed a steep fall in full-time work, but also a dip in the jobless rate to 5.7%. Futures markets indicated a 50-50 chance of another interest rate cut by the end of the year, with the Reserve Bank of Australia expected to keep rates on hold for at least two months.

images.alt_text: The Australian dollar received a fillip on Thursday after better-than-expected domestic jobs figures supported expectations that interest rates are likely to stay on hold for a couple of months at least.

site_title: Shenzhen link offers reprieve to Hong Kong's unloved small caps
summary: Hong Kong's small-cap stocks may experience a turnaround following their inclusion in the Shenzhen exchange link, with experts predicting outperformance compared to larger peers. The link, set to start in about four months, will allow eligible small-cap stocks with a market value of over HK$5 billion to be traded alongside larger companies. This could lead to increased investor interest and momentum, with valuations seen as attractive and potential for "catch-up" performance.

site_title: After US$65m hack, questions of whether Bitcoin can be safe
summary: Hackers stole US$65 million from Bitcoin exchange Bitfinex, highlighting the industry's lack of critical security despite years of improvement. The incident sparks calls for audits, but experts doubt new solutions will be found, citing the community's reluctance to adopt industry-wide measures. The hack is the latest in a long list of attacks on Bitcoin since its inception in 2009, raising questions about the digital currency's safety.

site_title: Malaysia plans legal moves against any 1MDB defrauders, Low says
summary: Malaysia plans to take legal action against individuals accused of defrauding its state investment company 1Malaysia Development Bhd, according to Minister Paul Low. The government takes the US Department of Justice's civil complaint "very seriously" and will pursue legal action against those found complicit in the alleged scheme. This move aims to defend the government's reputation and credibility amid allegations of funds embezzled from 1MDB.

site_title: Trump overhauls campaign team again as Clinton surges
summary: Donald Trump has overhauled his campaign team for the second time in two months, hiring Stephen Bannon as executive chairman and Kellyanne Conway as campaign manager. The shake-up comes as polls show Hillary Clinton leading Trump 47.3% to 41.2%. Critics warn that Trump's new team may not make him more palatable to moderate voters, citing his divisive rhetoric and history of controversy. Clinton's campaign has accused Trump of doubling down on hateful and divisive rhetoric, while Trump has dismissed suggestions that he should pivot to win the election.

site_title: Taiwan tea entrepreneurs brew up new twist on tradition
summary: Taiwan is reviving its tea industry with a modern twist, seeking to challenge the popularity of cheap, mass-produced "bubble tea" that has dominated global exports. Entrepreneurs are opening high-end tea shops and cafes, offering unique blends and premium packaging to attract new customers. Some, like Xie Xie and David Huang, are serving traditional oolong tea alongside modern flavors and designs, while others, like Lin Hua Tai, are maintaining traditional methods and offering a range of rare tea varieties. The goal is to reposition Taiwan's tea as a sophisticated and desirable product, appealing to younger generations and international markets.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Fed split over raising rates
summary: Singapore shares opened lower on Thursday, following the US Federal Reserve's split on raising interest rates. The benchmark Straits Times Index fell 3.69 points, or 0.13%, to 2,839.66. The split decision weighed on investor sentiment, with 59.5 million shares changing hands worth S$63 million.

site_title: Clinton Foundation hired cyber firm after suspected hacking
summary: The Clinton Foundation hired cybersecurity firm FireEye to examine its data systems after indications of suspected hacking, similar to the tactics used by Russian intelligence agencies against the Democratic Party. Despite no hacked documents surfacing, officials worry that emails and voice messages could be used to damage Hillary Clinton's presidential campaign. The attacks appear to be espionage rather than election interference, and the Obama administration is unlikely to publicly blame Russia for the attacks due to concerns about revealing American sources and methods.

site_title: AVJennings' FY2016 profit rises 19% to A$40.9m
summary: AVJennings, an Australian residential property developer, reported a 19% rise in its full-year net profit to A$40.9 million, driven by higher revenue and changes in product mix. The company's revenues grew 32.7% year-over-year to A$421.9 million, with strong demand for traditional housing solutions in well-planned communities. AVJennings declared a fully franked final dividend of 3.5 Australian cents per share and remains confident in its outlook for FY2017, citing low interest rates, positive population growth, and ongoing shortages in the Sydney, Melbourne, and Auckland markets.

site_title: Fintech to be a key differentiator for Singapore: Iswaran
summary: Singapore aims to become a leading global fintech hub, driven by the government's efforts to establish positions of leadership in the space. Minister for Trade and Industry S Iswaran emphasized the importance of fintech, highlighting the Monetary Authority of Singapore's recent regulatory sandbox initiative. The sandbox allows companies to test innovative solutions safely, reducing regulatory friction and giving innovations a better chance to take root in Singapore. The government seeks to balance innovation with the need for a safe and stable financial system, positioning fintech as a key differentiator for the country's economy.

site_title: Australia's jobless rate falls to 5.7% as part-time roles surge
summary: Australia's jobless rate dropped to 5.7% in July, beating economists' predictions of 5.8%. The economy saw a surge in part-time jobs, with employment rising 26,200, while full-time jobs fell by 45,400. The Australian dollar rose 12% since mid-January, but may pose a risk to service industries. The central bank cut interest rates to 1.5% to spur economic growth, but acknowledged uncertainty about the labour market. The resilience of the economy, driven by industries like construction and tourism, suggests it can absorb unemployed miners as the resource boom winds down.

site_title: China home prices rise 7.9% year on year in July
summary: China's average new home prices rose 7.9% year on year in July, surpassing the 7.3% increase in June. Home prices in Shenzhen and Xiamen surged 40.9% and 39.2% respectively. The booming property market has driven China's economic growth, but concerns grow that the rebound may be ending as local governments tighten restrictions to cool price rises, sparking fears of asset bubbles.

site_title: Seoul: Won, stocks edge up as Fed minutes ease rate hike fear
summary: The South Korean won rose 0.4% to 1,103.9 against the US dollar, while the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) increased 0.1% to 2,046.17 points. The move was driven by the release of US Federal Reserve minutes, which showed policymakers were split over the next rate hike, easing market fears. Tech giant Samsung Electronic Co Ltd rose over 1%, while Hyundai Motor Co lost 1.5%. The won is expected to remain around the 1,100 level ahead of the Jackson Hole conference, where the Fed's next rate move may be announced.

site_title: Ex-BSI Asia CEO Brunner settles Singapore bonus suit with bank
summary: Hanspeter Brunner, former BSI Asia CEO, has settled a lawsuit with the bank, withdrawing his claim against the bank in its entirety. Brunner alleged that BSI's Singapore unit breached bonus agreements and a separation pact without legal basis, amid investigations into the bank's ties with 1Malaysia Development Bhd. The settlement comes after Brunner's retirement was announced in March, and the bank's Singapore unit is set to lose its license. The bank is pleased with the outcome, while Brunner's lawyer declined to comment on details of the settlement.

site_title: Chinese airlines lure expat pilots with lucrative pay, perks
summary: Chinese airlines are facing a severe pilot shortage and are offering lucrative pay packages to attract foreign expats, with some offers reaching up to $318,000 per year. To meet the demand for 100 pilots a week for the next 20 years, carriers are paying 50% more than what senior captains at Delta Air Lines earn, and some are even offering signing bonuses and overtime pay. The shortage is driven by China's booming aviation industry, which has tripled its fleet in a decade and is set to become the world's busiest market in the next two decades.

site_title: Singtel to buy 21% of Intouch, 7.39% of Bharti Telecom from Temasek for S$2.47b
summary: Singtel plans to buy a 21% stake in Intouch Holdings PCL and a 7.39% stake in Bharti Telecom (BTL) from Temasek Holdings for S$2.47 billion in cash. The acquisition of Intouch shares costs S$1.59 million, while the BTL shares cost S$884 million. The deals are based on 20 trading days' volume-weighted average prices. The transactions are expected to be completed in the coming months.

site_title: Brent crude oil prices dip on prospect of record Saudi output
summary: Brent crude oil prices dropped 18 US cents to $49.67 per barrel, following a strong rally this month of nearly 20%. The price dip is attributed to profit taking and traders pricing in a potential record output from top exporter Saudi Arabia. The move comes as traders cash in on profits after an almost uninterrupted price increase.

site_title: New Zealand job ads extend rise in July: ANZ Survey
summary: New Zealand's job advertisements rose 1.4% in July, a 9.8% increase from the same month last year, according to an ANZ Bank survey. This suggests the economy is growing solidly.

site_title: Japan exports fall at fastest pace since financial crisis on strong yen
summary: Japan's exports fell 14% in July, the fastest pace since the 2009 financial crisis, due to a resurgent yen and weakness in overseas economies. Key declines included US-bound car shipments (11.8%), China-bound shipments (12.7%), and steel exports to Italy. The yen's 20% rise against the dollar threatens to cut into exporters' earnings and exacerbate deflationary pressure. The Bank of Japan will review its monetary policy at its next meeting, potentially easing policy to weaken the yen. This weakens Japan's reliance on exports for growth.

site_title: Asia: Stocks rise as Fed minutes spur optimism; dollar weakens
summary: Asian stocks rose, with the MSCI Asia-Pacific index up 0.4% as investors added to positions after the US Federal Reserve's July meeting minutes showed policymakers were in no rush to raise interest rates. The greenback weakened near two-month lows, while Hong Kong shares rose 1% and the yen strengthened, pulling Japan's Nikkei back 0.5%. Market participants interpreted the minutes as moderately positive for risk-taking appetite, with the Fed remaining divided on the timing of the next rate hike, leading to a dip in futures contracts and a rise in bond markets.

site_title: Lenovo's Q1 profit jumps 64%, beating estimates
summary: Lenovo reported a 64% increase in Q1 net profit to $173 million, beating analyst estimates. Solid PC sales offset tepid smartphone demand, with revenue dropping 6% to $10.05 billion. The results surpass the $130.1 million average estimate from Thomson Reuters SmartEstimates.

site_title: Allianz, Axa said to bid for StanChart Asia insurance rights
summary: Allianz and Axa, two major European insurers, are among first-round bidders for Standard Chartered's Asia insurance rights, with a unit of MS&AD Insurance Group also submitting an offer. The deal, worth around $400 million, would grant distribution rights for 15 years and is part of Standard Chartered's bancassurance strategy. The agreement aims to capitalize on rising demand for insurance products among Asia's wealthy population, with similar partnerships already agreed upon by CIMB and Fairfax Financial Holdings.

site_title: Bosch worked 'hand-in-glove' with Volkswagen in emissions fraud: lawyers
summary: German auto supplier Robert Bosch GmbH worked "hand-in-glove" with Volkswagen AG to evade US emissions laws, according to lawyers for US owners of polluting VW diesel vehicles. Confidential documents show Bosch's deep understanding of regulatory rules and helped VW obtain approval for emissions cheating devices. Bosch has not been charged but is cooperating with investigations, and German prosecutors are investigating staff involvement. The company has set aside 650 million euros for potential legal costs. Bosch's engine control units are used by several top automakers, including VW, and the company claims responsibility for software use lies with carmakers.

site_title: Expert shortage hampers Japanese financials in blockchain race
summary: Japanese financial institutions risk falling behind in the adoption of blockchain technology due to a severe shortage of specialists in the field. Despite efforts to develop and implement blockchain applications, banks, brokerages, and insurers are struggling to find qualified engineers and developers. The lack of talent is partly due to the stunted growth of fintech startups in Japan, which are traditional incubators of embryonic technology. As a result, Japanese finance houses may be left behind by global peers who are already reaping the benefits of blockchain technology.

site_title: Gold set for longest run of gains in six weeks on Fed rate view
summary: Gold prices surged for a fourth consecutive day, reaching a 0.5% gain to $1,355.06 an ounce, as the dollar retreated after the Federal Reserve's July meeting minutes indicated interest rates may remain lower for longer. This is the longest stretch of gains since July 6, driven by weak interest rates globally benefiting gold, which doesn't offer interest or yields. Odds of an interest rate hike in December fell to 48.5% from 51%.

images.alt_text: Gold climbed for a fourth straight day as the dollar retreated after minutes from July's Federal Reserve meeting signalled that US interest rates are poised to stay lower for longer.

site_title: Boeing says China demand for aircraft steady despite economic slowdown
summary: Boeing reports steady demand for jetliners in China, despite the country's economic slowdown. Senior vice president Ihssane Mounir stated that he's not seeing any signs of weakness in the Chinese market. Boeing delivered its 50th 787 Dreamliner to ANA Holdings Inc, a Japanese airline, and plans to expand its capacity in China. ANA's business travel from Japan to Latin America is experiencing robust growth, and the airline plans to launch a new route from Tokyo to Mexico City using the 787.

site_title: Europe: Shares slip; Wienerberger, Carlsberg drop after results
summary: European shares fell 0.8% on Wednesday, with Austria's Wienerberger, brewer Carlsberg, and UK insurer Admiral experiencing significant drops due to disappointing results. The STOXX 600 index is down 7% for 2016, amid concerns about the impact of the Brexit referendum on the European economy. Despite some recovery, investors remain cautious, with many preferring US stocks due to better earnings and a stronger market.

site_title: As technology shifts, more layoffs loom at tech companies
summary: Cisco Systems Inc plans to lay off 5,500 employees, a move analysts predict will be followed by other tech companies struggling to adapt to rapid technology shifts. The layoffs come as mobile applications and cloud computing become increasingly important, making hardware companies vulnerable. The US tech industry has already shed about 63,000 jobs this year, with analysts predicting more job cuts as companies shift to "super cloud" services. Experts expect 370,000 layoffs in the tech industry this year, with companies like IBM, Hewlett Packard Enterprise, and Oracle potentially next to shed workers.

site_title: Divided Federal Reserve wanted to keep rate 'options open': minutes
summary: US Federal Reserve policy makers maintained their interest rate at 0.25-0.5% in July, keeping options open due to differing views on the US economy. Despite a decrease in unemployment, inflation concerns persisted, with some members worried about a sudden upward push on prices. The Fed also acknowledged the uncertainty caused by the Brexit vote, but market expectations for a rate hike in September remain low.

site_title: Trump receives first classified intelligence briefing
summary: Donald Trump received his first classified intelligence briefing, a rare privilege for a presidential candidate, in a secure room at the FBI's New York office. The briefing, organized by the director of national intelligence, provided information about global threats against the US. Trump expressed skepticism about the US intelligence community's ability to deliver accurate information, citing past mistakes. He also stated he would not install members of the existing security establishment in his administration, citing their past "bad decisions."

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open down as stronger yen hits exporters
summary: Tokyo shares fell 0.57% on Thursday, with the Nikkei 225 index closing at 16,649.91, amid a stronger yen due to lower expectations of a Federal Reserve interest rate hike. The yen's surge hit exporters, contributing to the decline. The broader Topix index also lost 0.67%. The weaker yen is a result of the Fed's decision to keep interest rates steady, which reduced expectations of a rate hike next month.

site_title: Banks miss out as Chinese firms do DIY deal advice
summary: Chinese technology firms are increasingly opting to use in-house advisory teams instead of external investment banks for acquisitions and investments in foreign companies, missing out on estimated $60 million in fees. This trend, driven by a lack of familiarity with paying for advice, has led to a doubling of China's tech M&A to nearly $68 billion last year, despite only a 60% increase in fee volume. Chinese companies are instead hiring talent from Wall Street banks to build in-house teams, citing cost-effectiveness and better control in deal-making.

site_title: US dollar weakens as Federal Reserve minutes leave markets guessing
summary: The US dollar weakened against the euro and yen on Wednesday following the release of US Federal Reserve meeting minutes, which provided little clarity on future monetary policy. The euro rose to $1.1287 and the yen fell to 100.28 yen, while the pound also dropped slightly. Analysts said the minutes showed Federal Reserve policymakers were keeping their options open on inflation but remained divided, leaving markets uncertain about an imminent rate hike.

site_title: With TPP in doubt, Asia must look to trade deals in its own region
summary: US President Barack Obama has notified Congress that the White House will send a bill to implement the Trans Pacific Partnership (TPP), a 12-nation trade deal, after 30 days. However, the deal faces strong bipartisan opposition from presidential candidates and lawmakers, making it uncertain whether it will pass. As a result, Asia must focus on its own regional trade deals, such as the Asean Economic Community and the China-led One Belt One Road initiative, to ensure its economic growth and competitiveness.

site_title: Rise of the machines: Chinese investors flock to robo-advisers
summary: Chinese investors are flocking to robo-advisers, or automated investment programs, due to low interest rates and weak domestic equity markets. Investors like Lauren Ma, who invested 100,000 yuan in a phone app, are seeking affordable and convenient access to investment advice. The trend is driven by the need for improved returns, as well as pressure on real estate prices. As a result, Chinese retail investors are turning to robo-advisers to diversify their portfolios and gain a competitive edge in the market.

site_title: Swedish bank CEO fired for getting too high-tech
summary: Swedish bank Svenska Handelsbanken AB has fired its 48-year-old CEO, Frank Vang-Jensen, after he resisted the bank's shift towards digital banking. The bank's new CEO, Anders Bouvin, emphasized the importance of face-to-face interactions with customers and plans to empower local branches. Vang-Jensen's approach to centralizing operations was seen as a clash with the board, leading to his departure with a potential severance pay of 19 million kronor. The bank's decentralized business model has allowed it to maintain high customer satisfaction and remain a bastion of cash handling in a largely cashless Sweden.

site_title: New US rules require heavy-duty trucks to cut emissions by 25% over next decade
summary: The US administration has issued new emissions standards for heavy-duty trucks, requiring a 25% reduction in carbon emissions by 2027. The rules, which were made tougher after a public comment period, aim to cut 1.1 billion tonnes of emissions and represent a global benchmark for reducing vehicle-exhaust pollutants linked to climate change. The standards are expected to save the trucking industry an estimated $170 billion in fuel costs and improve fuel economy, with fuel consumption targets to be set by engine and truck-tractor makers.

site_title: World's 'largest aircraft' gets off ground
summary: The world's largest aircraft, the Airlander 10, successfully completed its maiden flight on Wednesday, four days after a previous attempt was abandoned due to technical issues. The 92m long plane-airship hybrid took off from an airfield in central England, marking a major milestone in its development. Originally designed for the US army as a surveillance aircraft, the Airlander 10 has potential uses in the commercial sector, including cargo transport. The aircraft's first flight was delayed due to a technical fault, but it flew for 30 minutes in clear weather conditions.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Singtel, Epicentre, Sin Heng Heavy Machinery
summary: Singtel plans to buy 21% stake in Intouch Holdings and 7.39% stake in Bharti Telecom for S$2.47 billion, aiming to expand its economic exposure to high-growth telecom sectors in Thailand and India. Epicentre Holdings issues a profit warning, expecting a loss due to decreased sales and increased competition. Sin Heng Heavy Machinery forecasts a net loss for the fiscal fourth quarter and financial year due to lower revenue and disposal of non-performing assets.

site_title: Singtel says to buy Temasek's stakes in Intouch and Bharti Telecom for S$2.47b
summary: Singtel plans to acquire a 21% stake in Intouch Holdings PCL and a 7.39% stake in Bharti Telecom for S$2.47 billion from Temasek Holdings. The acquisition will increase Singtel's exposure to the high-growth telecom sectors in Thailand and India. The deal will be funded by S$1.605 billion in proceeds from share placement and internal cash. Singtel expects the acquisitions to enhance shareholder value and maximize the value of its existing businesses, without affecting its dividend policy.

site_title: China warns Australia on protectionist move after blocked grid deal
summary: China has warned Australia about its decision to block a $10 billion energy grid sale to Chinese bidders, calling it a protectionist move that negatively affects investment. The move is the second time this year Canberra has rejected Chinese bids, citing unspecified national security concerns. China hopes Australia will create a fairer environment for Chinese investment, amid rising scrutiny from governments in Europe and the US. The decision has raised concerns about Australia's trade dependence on China and the potential for politically coercive policies.

site_title: Networking titan Cisco cuts 5,500 jobs as profit climbs
summary: Cisco announced plans to cut 5,500 jobs, or 7% of its global workforce, as it shifts focus to software and services. The move comes after the company reported a 20% increase in profit to $10.7 billion, despite revenue remaining flat year-over-year. CEO Chuck Robbins stated the restructuring will cut expenses in lower-growth areas and invest in priorities such as security, cloud computing, and the internet of things. The cost savings will be reinvested in the company.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Singaporean companies' Q2 earnings were mixed. Kim Heng Offshore reported a 31% drop in revenue and net loss, while ST Engineering maintained its growth outlook. Ho Bee Land Limited saw a 464% increase in revenue due to completed Australian residential projects. Despite the mixed results, analysts remain optimistic about these companies' long-term growth prospects, citing diversified businesses and investment in enhanced capabilities.

site_title: Terrorism and instability make cities less livable, report says
summary: Terrorism and social unrest have made life less livable in many major cities worldwide, according to the Economist Intelligence Unit's Global Liveability Index. Conditions in 29 cities worsened, with Western European and US cities hit by terrorist attacks and social tensions. The least livable city is Damascus, while Tehran improved its living conditions due to the lifting of sanctions. Australian and Canadian cities dominated the top 10, with Melbourne at the top for the sixth year in a row. The report highlights growing instability globally, with social unrest and terrorism contributing to declining livability.

images.alt_text: Instability and fears over terrorism have made life more challenging in many of the world's leading cities over the past year, according to analysis by the Economist Intelligence Unit.

site_title: Japan's ports to woo more foreign cruise ships
summary: Japan's ports are experiencing a significant increase in foreign cruise ship visits, with over 1,600 expected this year, a 40% rise from last year. The government aims to develop ports to attract large cruise ships, with a goal of increasing foreign tourists using cruise ships from 1.116 million in 2015 to five million by 2020. Port cities like Hakata, Nagasaki, and Okinawa are expected to receive a significant number of port calls, with some ports, such as Hirara, seeing a 7.3 times increase in foreign cruise ship visits.

site_title: US: Stocks edge up as Fed minutes dampen hike expectations
summary: US stocks edged up on Wednesday as minutes from the Federal Reserve's July meeting showed policy makers believed risks to the US economy had lessened, boosting expectations for a low chance of a rate hike in September. The S&P 500 rose 0.2% and the Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 0.1%, while Asian markets rebounded after a two-day losing streak. The dollar edged lower against the euro and yen, and oil prices pushed modestly higher following a significant decline in US inventories. Market expectations for a September rate hike remained low.

site_title: Shenzhen Connect unlikely to be a big draw: money managers
summary: Shenzhen Connect, a plan to connect Shenzhen and Hong Kong stock markets, is unlikely to attract many global investors due to high valuations and speculation, according to money managers. China's cabinet approved the scheme, a major capital market reform, but a launch date remains uncertain. The move offers access to China's growing tech sector, but concerns about the markets' volatility may deter buyers.

site_title: Constitutional panel submits report on elected presidency review to PM Lee
summary: Singapore's nine-member constitutional commission has completed its report on reviewing the country's elected presidency system, submitted to Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong. The commission, led by Chief Justice Sundaresh Menon, studied three aspects of the system and received over 100 public submissions. The government will study the report before publishing it along with its response. The review aims to improve the qualifying process for presidential candidates, custodial powers, and minority representation. Singaporeans are expected to vote for their next president by August 2017.

site_title: US millennials shun credit card debt: poll
summary: US millennials have significantly reduced their credit card debt, with only 37% of households under 35 holding credit card debt in 2013, down from 47% before the financial crisis. This decline is attributed to the reluctance to take on debt, partly due to the financial crisis and increased awareness of the risks involved. Millennials are opting for alternative payment methods, such as debit cards, Venmo, and PayPal, which draw funds directly from bank accounts. This shift may have lasting repercussions for millennials and the financial system, potentially affecting their ability to access credit in the future.

site_title: Moody's raises outlook for emerging markets in 2016, 2017
summary: Moody's Investors Service upgraded its outlook for emerging markets in 2016 and 2017, forecasting a 4.4% growth rate this year and 5% in 2017. The upgrades were attributed to economic stabilization in China, a recovery in commodity prices, and the return of capital flows. Moody's revised its outlook for Brazil, Russia, and China, predicting Brazil's return to positive growth in 2017 and Russia's growth of up to 2% in 2017. However, the US presidential election in November remains a downside risk to the global economic outlook.

images.alt_text: Moody's Investors Service revised its outlook on the world's largest emerging market economies upward for 2016 and 2017, the ratings agency announced on Wednesday, pegging growth for G20 emerging markets at 4.4 per cent this year and 5 per cent for 2017.

site_title: The return of the political economy
summary: Politics is re-emerging as a significant economic factor, contrary to the prevailing assumption of reduced influence in the 1990s. The shift, known as "political economics," focuses on how policy impacts the economy and how people adjust their behavior in anticipation of policy changes. This trend is driven by the understanding that economic outcomes can be influenced by political issues such as wealth distribution. The resurgence of politics in economics is seen as a response to the global financial crisis and the growing recognition of its impact on economic outcomes.

site_title: Britain's iconic red phone booths find their second calling
summary: Thousands of dormant phone booths in the UK are being repurposed as micro locations for businesses, with the first few already open in towns like Brighton and London. The phone boxes, once iconic symbols of British culture, are being refurbished and rented out to entrepreneurs at a daily fee of around $22. Businesses are using the small spaces for everything from cafes and restaurants to libraries and art galleries, and even mobile phone repair shops and charging stations. The initiative aims to breathe new life into the redundant phone booths, which were largely unused due to the rise of mobile phones.

site_title: British consumers begin to feel post-Brexit pinch
summary: British consumers are experiencing the post-Brexit pinch, with the country's tumbling currency affecting prices on the High Street. The consequences of the shock vote, which occurred in 2016, are now being felt, particularly in the property market. Recent economic data shows the UK economy shrinking for a second month, dealing a fresh blow to Prime Minister Starmer.

site_title: Soup Restaurant to open 5 new outlets by October
summary: Soup Restaurant Group plans to expand its reach in Singapore with five new outlets by October, boosting its total number of restaurants to 19. The new outlets will be located in Changi Airport and Holland Village, and will hire around 75 staff. To reduce manpower costs, the company will explore technology to streamline processes, including electronic ordering systems. The expansion will also include the introduction of a new concept, the Teahouse, at Changi Airport, serving local dim sum dishes.

site_title: Market volatility weakens Allianz Asia-Pacific's new business value
summary: Allianz Asia-Pacific reported a 9% decline in new business value (NBV) to €100 million (S$151 million) in the first six months of the year, primarily due to weaker unit-linked sales. However, new business margin rose 1.3 percentage points to 5.5%, driven by active portfolio management in the life business. Total revenues plummeted 34% year-on-year, while underlying operating profit for the Asia-Pacific region remained flat at €134 million. Despite market volatility, the company remains optimistic about the region's growth prospects.

site_title: Need to probe Indiabulls trust
summary: Indiabulls Property Investment Trust (IPIT) raised S$260 million in its initial public offer in Singapore in 2008, valuing its properties at S$2.3 billion. However, a rights issue in 2009 at S$0.16 followed, and the current buyout at S$0.05 suggests a significant collapse in real estate value. This raises questions about the accuracy of the initial valuation and the trust's financial performance, including unpaid dividends. The incident highlights the need for stringent standards in public listings, particularly in the Singapore market.

site_title: Asian funds pour into alternative assets as traditional returns slide
summary: Asian investors are shifting to alternative assets as traditional investments yield lower returns due to record-low interest rates. Conservative investors, such as pension funds and insurers, are pouring into alternative investments like private debt, real estate, and hedge funds to meet their predictable income needs. However, this shift comes with higher risks, including liquidity issues and lower transparency. Many investors are increasing their allocations to alternative assets, with some planning to allocate up to 50% of their portfolios to these investments, despite concerns that the weight of money could lead to reduced expected returns.

site_title: CPF: The ultimate trust fund for kids?
summary: Singapore's Central Provident Fund (CPF) offers a risk-free interest rate of 4% a year, making it a potential long-term savings strategy for children. Two key facts: Special Account (SA) monies exceeding the Full Retirement Sum (FRS) of S$161,000 compound until age 55, and parents can contribute to a child's CPF account immediately after birth. This can result in up to S$1.5 million by age 55, assuming a 4% interest rate. The strategy aims to encourage children to work by not providing a lump sum until age 55, and the interest earned can be withdrawn at any time.

site_title: World's mind made up on US presidential race
summary: A Pew Research Center survey of 15 nations found that Americans' choice of president can significantly impact foreign confidence in the US. Majorities or pluralities in 12 of 14 European and Asian countries trust Hillary Clinton over Donald Trump, with 83% of Swedes and 79% of Germans expressing confidence in her. In contrast, Trump has little to no confidence in him, with 92% of Swedes and 89% of Germans expressing little or no faith. The outcome of the 2016 US presidential election will likely influence foreign views of the US, with many countries having a more favorable view of the US under Obama than under Trump.

site_title: Tencent's splurge on premium content pays off with strong Q2 earnings
summary: Tencent Holdings Ltd reported strong Q2 earnings, beating analysts' estimates with a 47% climb in net income to a record 10.74 billion yuan. The company's splurge on premium content, including mobile games and online titles, contributed to the surprise, with online advertising revenue swelling 60%. Costs overall nearly doubled, but Tencent's approach to content acquisition and user spending appears to be paying off, defying concerns about a slowing Chinese economy. The company's founder, Ma Huateng, has shown a willingness to invest heavily in content, including a $8.6 billion acquisition of Supercell Oy.

site_title: Singapore consumer confidence plummets to post-2009 low
summary: Singapore's consumer confidence has plummeted to a post-2009 low, according to the Mastercard Index of Consumer Confidence for H1 2016. The index fell 10.7 points, with the largest drop in the quality of life measure, registering a 14.5-point fall. Other indices, including employment prospects, regular income prospects, and the economy, also showed significant declines. However, the Philippines and Taiwan experienced significant rebounds in consumer confidence, with the Philippines rising by 12.9 points and Taiwan rising by 16.3 points.

site_title: Oil prices higher as US stockpiles drop
summary: US oil prices rose as crude stockpiles fell by 2.5 million barrels and gasoline stocks declined by 2.7 million barrels, indicating a modest strengthening of US demand. The West Texas Intermediate price increased 21 cents to US$46.79 a barrel, while Brent North Sea crude rose 62 cents to US$49.85 a barrel. The decline in US crude production was offset by a 152,000-barrel increase, and Opec producers are set to meet in Algeria in September to discuss production limits. Analysts remain skeptical about a deal being struck, citing past meetings' lack of agreement.

site_title: PayPal, partners make paying at F&B outlets even breezier
summary: PayPal has partnered with TabSquare and Integral Solutions to equip over 200 food-and-beverage establishments with in-store digital payment capability by next year. The system allows customers to call for their bill on a restaurant's e-ordering tablet, receive a payment request on their mobile phone, and pay securely using PayPal. This partnership aims to reduce payment time, increase productivity, and enhance the customer experience for F&B operators, while also fostering innovation and entrepreneurship in Singapore through the PayPal Innovation Lab.

site_title: September hike possible, markets too complacent: Fed
summary: The Federal Reserve may raise interest rates as soon as next month, according to New York Fed president William Dudley. Dudley stated that the Fed is "edging closer" to raising interest rates further, citing a possible vote at its September meeting. However, he also emphasized that the pace and amount of tightening are still uncertain. This comes as markets have been considered too complacent, and investors may underestimate the likelihood of rate hikes.

images.alt_text: "We're edging closer towards the point in time where it will be appropriate to raise interest rates further," said Mr Dudley.

site_title: CDP, retail brokers roll out e-statement initiative
summary: Singapore's Central Depository (CDP) and retail brokers will begin providing electronic statements to retail investors starting from the fourth quarter. The initiative aims to reduce carbon footprint while delivering account statements and trade confirmations in a timely and secure manner. Retail investors with internet trading accounts can view statements and contracts electronically, while those without internet trading accounts will continue to receive hardcopy statements. The move is seen as a customer-centric effort to cater to different investor profiles, with notifications and options to opt-out of physical statements.

site_title: Wolfgang Baier joins Luxasia as CEO as it turns to e-commerce
summary: Luxasia Group has appointed Wolfgang Baier, 42, as its new CEO, effective immediately, as part of its strategy to expand into e-commerce. Baier joins after a year-long search, replacing founder-owner Patrick Chong, who will become chairman. Baier brings expertise in e-commerce and will lead the company's growth strategy, aiming to build "omni-channel" retail experiences for consumers. The company plans to invest in technology and train staff to support its e-commerce push, which will complement its existing brick-and-mortar presence.

site_title: S'pore's fiscal position strong in near term despite lower GIC, Temasek returns, says Moody's
summary: Moody's report notes Singapore's fiscal position remains strong in the near term despite lower returns from government-owned investment entities, such as GIC and Temasek Holdings. However, if these returns persist, it could curb fiscal space and limit future fiscal stimulus, potentially affecting the country's credit rating. Moody's estimates a 1% fiscal deficit if budgeted returns halve, but sees no immediate cause for concern due to conservative spending rules and existing fiscal reserves. A persistent fiscal deficit could, however, lead to a negative credit assessment.

site_title: Barclays, on a selling spree, aims to get back to basics
summary: Barclays is undergoing a major restructuring effort to refocus on its core businesses, including its British consumer bank and trans-Atlantic investment bank. The bank aims to sell or close riskier businesses, with a goal of delivering £1 billion in cost savings by 2017. Barclays has agreed to pay $100 million to settle a US investigation into bid-rigging related to the London interbank offered rate (Libor). The bank's new CEO, James E. Staley, is confident in the bank's core businesses and expects them to perform better than peers.

site_title: Post Properties surges on US$3.9b deal with Mid-America
summary: Post Properties Inc shares surged 9.4% after Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc agreed to buy the real estate investment trust (Reit) for approximately $3.9 billion, forming a company with 105,000 multi-family units. The combined firm will have a market value of $17 billion and become the largest listed apartment landlord. The deal is expected to create annual gross synergies of $20 million, with the largest share of net operating income coming from Atlanta, Dallas, and Charlotte, North Carolina.

site_title: US$ inches higher ahead of Fed minutes
summary: The US dollar strengthened against a basket of currencies on Wednesday, recovering from 7-week lows against the yen and euro, following hawkish comments from Federal Reserve officials. The comments, made by New York Fed chief William Dudley and Atlanta colleague Dennis Lockhart, suggested the US central bank could raise interest rates in September. The dollar gained 0.2% against the basket, while the euro fell 0.1% to US$1.1269. The Fed's minutes from its last meeting are due later in the day, providing insight into borrowing costs.

site_title: Bendable concrete invented by NTU-JTC could cut road-construction time
summary: Scientists at NTU-JTC in Singapore have invented bendable concrete called ConFlexPave, which is stronger and more durable than conventional concrete. This material could cut road-construction time in half, making it a potential substitute for asphalt in heavily-used roads. ConFlexPave's unique properties could revolutionize the construction industry, reducing costs and improving road safety.

images.alt_text: Asst Prof Yang En-Hua with a bent slab of ConFlexPave which has been put through a bending test. This new material is twice as durable as conventional concrete, and is thinner and lighter, which means they can be laid quickly.

site_title: Univision's US$135 million bid wins auction for bankrupt Gawker Media
summary: Univision has acquired Gawker Media, a bankrupt US$135 million, for the first time since its founding 14 years ago, outbidding Ziff Davis. The sale comes after Gawker filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy due to a US$140 million judgment in an invasion-of-privacy lawsuit by Hulk Hogan. The company, known for its fearless approach to web journalism, will have an outside owner for the first time. Univision, expanding its online portfolio, owns other digital media companies including The Onion and The Root.

site_title: Eastern Europe fights to turn tide of emigration
summary: Eastern European countries, including Latvia, Poland, and Romania, are launching campaigns to attract back citizens who have emigrated to Western Europe in search of better job opportunities. The "I want you back" slogan aims to tap into the diaspora's potential, citing the benefits of stints abroad in gaining new skills and perspectives. The campaigns follow the Brexit vote's impact on foreign workers in the UK and come as the region grapples with low birth rates, aging populations, and economic losses due to emigration, estimated to be around 7 percentage points of GDP.

site_title: Swiss private bank Falcon blocked from new S'pore business
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has blocked Swiss private bank Falcon from taking on new business in Singapore due to a possible breach of anti-money laundering rules in handling transactions linked to 1MDB, a scandal-hit Malaysian state fund. Falcon, owned by Abu Dhabi sovereign wealth fund International Petroleum Investment Company (Ipic), has cooperated with the Singapore investigation. The MAS declined to comment on its supervisory dealings with specific financial institutions, while Swiss financial watchdog Finma is working with MAS and other agencies on 1MDB probes.

site_title: Official: Malaysian oil tanker taken over commercial dispute, not hijacked
summary: Malaysian authorities believe an oil tanker, Vier Harmoni, was taken due to a commercial dispute, not hijacked. The tanker, carrying 900,000 litres of diesel, went missing after leaving a Malaysian port on Tuesday and was later relocated in Indonesian waters off Batam. The incident occurred amid a commercial dispute, and no claims of hijacking have been made.

site_title: Try matcha, the green alternative to coffee
summary: A registered dietician recommends matcha, a green tea alternative to coffee, as a morning pick-me-up due to its longer-lasting effects and lower caffeine content. Matcha contains antioxidants, vitamins, and L-theanine, an amino acid that promotes calmness and focus. Unlike coffee, matcha's caffeine is slowly released, providing a more gradual energy boost. Some users report a more refined and delicate energy sensation, while others convert from coffee to matcha after trying it.

site_title: Russia shelves US$5b deal as asset sales hit snag
summary: Russia is delaying a planned $5 billion sale of a stake in regional oil producer Bashneft PJSC, citing renewed weakness in global oil markets and tensions among potential buyers. The sale, which was set to be Russia's largest asset sale in a decade, will not happen this year. The delay follows a weak market and the state's plan to sell other assets, including a 20% stake in Rosneft, Russia's largest crude producer. The decision was made by Prime Minister Dmitry Medvedev with President Vladimir Putin's approval.

site_title: Huge fire breaks out at CK Building
summary: A fire broke out at the CK Building in Tampines, Singapore, on August 17, 2016, causing 67 occupants to be evacuated. The fire, which started on the third and fourth floors, was extinguished by 110 SCDF officers and 27 emergency vehicles. No injuries were reported, but a firefighter was treated for heat exhaustion. The cause of the fire is still under investigation. The building, which belongs to CK Holdings, operates the CK Department Stores, and contained highly flammable goods that made it difficult for firefighters to approach.

site_title: July NODX suffers double-digit fall
summary: Singapore's July NODX (non-oil domestic exports) fell 10.6% year-on-year, exceeding market expectations. Shipments to the top 10 markets declined, with only the EU posting growth. China, Singapore's largest market, saw a 16.6% drop in NODX exports, marking the 13th consecutive decline. The decline is attributed to de-stocking pressures and structural issues, potentially affecting manufacturing output.
