His Democratic rival, Vice President Joe Biden, criticized Trump as unqualified and accused him of endangering US troops.

site_title: US: Wall Street hits new record highs
summary: US stocks jumped to fresh records on Monday, driven by stronger oil prices and positive momentum. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq indices reached new highs for the second time in three sessions, propelled by the comparative strength of the US economy and expectations of accommodative monetary policy. Energy equities, industrials, and financials saw significant gains. In contrast, European markets were little changed, while Asian markets advanced except for Tokyo, which lost 0.3% due to a stalled Japanese economy.

site_title: US dollar treads water ahead of data, sterling nears post-Brexit lows
summary: The US dollar traded flat at 101.250 yen ahead of key US data releases, while sterling approached a 31-year low of US$1.2798 following weaker-than-expected UK data. The dollar index was little changed at 95.641, and the euro remained steady at US$1.1180. Commodity-linked currencies, such as the Canadian and Australian dollars, rose due to a rise in crude oil prices. Investors await US consumer prices, housing starts, and industrial output data for further insights into the US economy.

images.alt_text: The dollar treaded water early on Tuesday, caught in a narrow range ahead of a series of US data releases later in the session, while sterling was on the defensive after downbeat UK data nudged it towards a 31-year low.

site_title: Water tech firm Xylem nears deal to buy smart-meter provider Sensus: sources
summary: US water technology company Xylem Inc is nearing a deal to acquire Sensus USA Inc, a smart-meter provider, for around $1.7 billion. The acquisition would make Xylem a major player in the smart meter market, driven by regulatory requirements and a need for tighter water and energy consumption control. The deal would bolster Xylem's presence in the market and enhance its offerings in advanced metering technologies.

site_title: Cathay Pacific profit margin under pressure as fuel hedging losses mount
summary: Cathay Pacific Airways faces significant challenges to its profit margins due to mounting fuel hedging losses and increased competition from Chinese and Middle Eastern carriers. The airline's fuel-hedging policy, which involves locking in fuel prices at a higher rate than the current market price, has resulted in substantial losses. With the city of Hong Kong imposing new fees on passengers to fund the construction of a third runway, Cathay's ticket prices are under pressure, further threatening its profitability. The airline's shares have declined 4.6% this year, and analysts predict a 46% decline in net income for the first half of the year.

site_title: Carving S'pore link for China's silk road routes to Mid-East, Europe
summary: China is strengthening its Silk Road routes to the Middle East and Europe through a joint venture with Pacific International Lines Group in Singapore, aiming to export excess industrial capacity and build influence overseas. The venture underscores Singapore's potential as a gateway to South-east Asia for China, despite regional concerns over China's territorial claims in the South China Sea. Chinese companies are seeking local brokers to navigate local politics and avoid pitfalls, and Singapore is seen as an attractive choice due to its cultural and financial ties to China.

site_title: E50 Association gets first female president
summary: Susan Chong, founder of Greenpac, has become the first female president of the E50 Association, a prestigious organization that supports Small and Medium Enterprises (SMEs). Chong aims to develop SMEs' capabilities and encourage women leadership. Her appointment marks a significant milestone for the organization and reflects her impressive career, which includes Greenpac's ranking as one of the top SMEs in 2008.

site_title: Firms in ageing Thailand bet on demand surge for robots and diapers
summary: Thai firms are investing in healthcare for the aged as the country's population shifts toward the elderly. By 2020, nearly 20% of Thailand's 68 million people will be over 60, straining the healthcare sector. Companies like CT Asia Robotics and DSG International Thailand are seeing a surge in demand for robots, diapers, and other elderly care products. The government is also considering reverse mortgages to boost the market, but some essential services, like nursing homes, face cultural challenges in attracting customers.

site_title: China Fibretech posts losses in Q2, issues caution on financial statements
summary: China Fibretech reported a net loss of 73,000 yuan in Q2, down from a 2.87 million yuan profit a year ago, due to weak demand and lower revenue of 61.2% year-over-year at 7.29 million yuan. This represents a loss per share of 0.01 yuan. The company expressed caution on its financial statements, citing lower demand from consumers and a decrease in average fabric processing fee.

images.alt_text: China Fibretech on Tuesday said it swung into the red in its second-quarter earnings due to weak demand, with a net loss of 73,000 Chinese yuan (S$14,770) compared with a 2.87 million yuan profit a year ago.

site_title: Twitter shares jump on talk of Apple TV tie-up
summary: Twitter shares rose 6.58% to $20.82 after reports of a potential Apple TV tie-up, marking the first time shares have topped $20 since January. The New York Times cited people familiar with the matter as saying Twitter is exploring an application for Apple TV that would allow streaming of online content to television screens.

site_title: Logos, Yang Kee estimate S$150m cost to develop Tuas South warehouse
summary: Logos SE Asia and Yang Kee Logistics are jointly developing a 66,000 sqm warehouse in Tuas South, Singapore, at an estimated cost of S$150 million. Construction is expected to last 18 months, with practical completion by the end of 2018. This project marks Logos' first development in South-east Asia, and Yang Kee will enter into a long-term lease over the project. The joint venture aims to expand industrial and logistics properties in key South-east Asian markets.

site_title: British pound slumps against euro, US dollar
summary: The British pound has fallen to a fresh three-year low against the euro, at 86.80 pence, and edged lower against the US dollar, at US$1.2883. The currency's weakness is attributed to mounting signs of economic weakness in the UK, including a decline in London residential rents and home prices. Investors are also concerned about the UK's economic reports this week, which are expected to reveal further economic strain. The pound's decline comes despite the UK's formal departure from the European Union not being imminent.

site_title: Bolt gets closer to dreaded Olympic farewell
summary: Usain Bolt is nearing the end of his Olympic career, with his final event being the relay finale at the Rio Olympics. Bolt's performances have been a source of inspiration for fans worldwide, particularly his iconic "Lightning Bolt" pose after victories. With two remaining events, Bolt's absence from the sport will be deeply felt, and he is expected to leave a lasting legacy in athletics.

site_title: Resolve cash-flow conundrum faced by GST-registered exporting SMEs
summary: GST-registered exporting SMEs in Singapore face a cash-flow conundrum due to the delayed GST refund process, which can range from weeks to a year. This can trigger a cash-flow issue, similar to that faced by Swiber Holdings, and lead to reduced purchases and exports. To address this, the Ministry of Finance and Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore are urged to provide monthly breakdowns of GST refund cases and withheld refunds in their annual reports, offering public transparency and helping SMEs plan their cash flow projections.

site_title: London rents fall for first time since 2010
summary: London rents have fallen for the first time since 2010, according to a study by Countrywide estate agents. The average monthly rental contract in July was £1,280, 0.5% lower than last year. This decline is attributed to an increase in available homes due to buy-to-rent investors and uncertainty in the sales market following the EU referendum. Nationally, rents for new contracts increased by 1.5% last year, but London's slowdown is seen as a sign of a broader slowdown in the property sector, particularly in the booming London market.

site_title: Global palm oil buyers hold off business with Malaysia's IOI
summary: Global palm oil buyers are holding off on mending ties with Malaysian plantation giant IOI Group despite the Roundtable for Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) reinstating the company's green certification in April. The certification was withdrawn due to allegations of illegal rainforest clearance and peatland plantations in Indonesia. Industry buyers remain reluctant to mend business ties despite the certification reinstatement, citing concerns over IOI's sustainability practices.

site_title: Hospitality trusts lag other Reits in latest earnings season
summary: Hospitality Reits in Singapore performed the worst among Reits in the latest earnings season, with analysts citing volatility in earnings due to variable rent components and declining occupancies and room rates. Analysts noted that hotels are facing challenges domestically and internationally, with some Reits reporting lower distributions. Despite this, analysts expect Reits to outperform other sectors due to the pursuit of yields and potential fresh capital inflows. However, price upside may be short-lived if interest rate hikes occur, and DBS expects two rate hikes this year.

site_title: China signals growth, not political disputes, should dominate G-20
summary: China is shifting the focus of the upcoming G-20 summit from disputes like the South China Sea to boosting economic growth and financial issues. The Sept 4-5 summit in Hangzhou will prioritize open, inclusive trade and robust financial markets to stimulate sluggish global economic growth. Vice-governor Yi Gang emphasized the need for market confidence and avoiding competitive devaluations. Despite protectionist rhetoric, the G-20 is opposed to anti-trade sentiment, with Vice-Finance Minister Zhu Guangyao stressing the importance of public beneficiaries of economic growth.

site_title: Tahir is top bidder for 110 Robinson Road
summary: Indonesian tycoon Tahir is the top bidder for 110 Robinson Road, a 12-storey freehold office block in Singapore, with an offer of close to S$45 million. This translates to a gross yield of 1.38% based on the building's income stream, but there is upside potential for rental income and positive rent reversion. Tahir, who has already acquired several Singapore income-generating properties, is unlikely to undertake major refurbishments, instead focusing on adding to his collection of Singapore real estate.

site_title: Harnessing standards & conformance paying off for Freshening Industries
summary: Freshening Industries, a Singapore-based manufacturer of individually packed paper towels, has seen significant revenue growth, productivity gains, and export opportunities due to its focus on standards and conformance. The company has adopted various international standards, including ISO9001, HACCP, and ISO 22301, to ensure quality and consistency in its products. With 5,000 food service establishments as customers, Freshening now supplies its products to over 33 countries worldwide, including major airlines, hotels, and hospital groups. The company's commitment to standards has also led to improved supply chain security and business continuity management.

images.alt_text: "We are in the quest for perfection and we seek improvement in various aspects of our business that motivates us. We are motivated by the need for continual improvement. We benchmark ourselves against our international competitors." - Freshening executive director Jonathan Phoon

site_title: Oil continues rise on hopes of production freeze
summary: Oil prices rose on Monday, with West Texas Intermediate increasing by $1.25 to $45.74 per barrel, and Brent up $1.38 to $48.35 per barrel. Russian Energy Minister Alexander Novak hinted at a possible production freeze in cooperation with Opec, following statements from Saudi Arabia's oil minister. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries is set to convene an informal meeting in Algeria at the end of September, amid efforts to achieve oil market stability. Market analysts believe a production freeze is unlikely but prices are still pricing it in, leading to slight price increases.

site_title: Beefing up the code
summary: The International Ethics Standards Board for Accountants (IESBA) has released new standards to resolve potential conflicts of interest for accountants and auditors, aiming to clarify that they must actively address non-compliance with laws and regulations. The standards, known as non-compliance with laws and regulation (NOCLAR) standards, will help accountants better deal with ethical challenges. The IESBA's chairman, Stavros Thomadakis, stated that the rules are intended to bring about early detection and action by management or authorities. The changes will be used in over 100 jurisdictions.

site_title: July's new home sales recover from June lull
summary: Singapore's private housing market showed signs of recovery in July, with developers selling 1,091 units, more than double the 536 units sold in June. The surge in sales is attributed to a mid-year lull in the market and a surge in new project launches. The market is expected to stabilize, with sales performance hovering at around 500-700 units per month for the rest of the year. The EC market was also active, with 830 units sold in July, with prices remaining resilient despite cooling measures in place.

site_title: Rising bad debts weigh down National Australia Bank's profit
summary: National Australia Bank (NAB) reported a 3% decline in Q3 earnings to AU$1.6 billion, amid rising expenses for bad debts and provisions for mining and agricultural loans. The bank joins Commonwealth Bank of Australia and ANZ Bank in increasing provisions for bad loans, citing a challenging reporting season for Australia's lenders. NAB's shares fell 1.3% as the bank's net interest margin declined due to higher funding costs.

images.alt_text: National Australia Bank's shares fall 1.3 per cent at the opening in Sydney on Monday. They have lost 8 per cent this year, compared with a 4.3 per cent advance for the benchmark S&P/ASX 200 Index and a 9.5 per cent decline for an index of bank shares.

site_title: Maersk warns against US protectionism
summary: Maersk, the world's largest container shipping company, warns against US protectionism, stating it would hurt global economic growth. CFO Trond Westlie expressed concern over potential trade barriers, citing the impact on global trade and economic growth. The warning comes as US presidential candidates, Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton, take a tougher stance on globalization and trade. Trump has criticized the Trans-Pacific Partnership, while Clinton has criticized its failure to support American jobs. Maersk's warning highlights the potential risks of a more protectionist US policy on global trade and economic growth.

site_title: Revolutionary technology: Nissan's new petrol engine may make diesel obsolete
summary: Nissan's new Variable Compression-Turbo (VC-T) powertrain, set to be unveiled at the Paris motor show, may make diesel engines obsolete. The engine uses variable compression technology, allowing it to optimize power and efficiency, matching diesel and hybrid powertrains. It averages 27% better fuel economy than its predecessor, is cheaper than diesel engines, and meets emissions rules without costly treatment systems. Nissan believes the VC-T engine could replace or become an alternative to advanced diesel engines, offering a breakthrough technology that could improve fuel efficiency and performance.

site_title: H1 corp earnings a big let-down
summary: Singapore's corporate earnings for the first half of 2016 were largely disappointing, with many companies missing expectations and some even reporting losses. The offshore and marine industry was particularly hard hit, and analysts warn that this could lead to dividend cuts. Defensive stocks like Reits and telcos are seen as stable, but some analysts predict they may also face pressure due to the challenging economic environment. Analysts expect no earnings growth for Singapore this year and are trimming their earnings estimates, with some warning of a credit cycle that could lead to higher non-performing loans and earnings falls.

site_title: Japan's slowdown in Q2 signals lack of confidence in Abenomics: analysts
summary: Japan's economy grew 0.2% on an annualized basis in Q2, below forecast of 0.7%. The slowdown signals lack of confidence in Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's Abenomics policies, attributed to stagnant domestic demand and weak exports. This marks a halt in growth compared to the first quarter. Analysts question the success of Abenomics, which aims to boost economic growth through monetary and fiscal policies.

site_title: All or nothing when it comes to recovering China bond defaults
summary: China's defaulted bond repayment process has been largely inconsistent, with only nine out of 26 failed local public notes being fully repaid. One was partially repaid, while most have not disclosed repayment plans. Moody's Investors Service criticized the lack of transparency in the restructuring process.

site_title: KrisEnergy latest O&G firm to flag possible debt strain
summary: KrisEnergy, a Singapore-based oil and gas firm, reported a US$25 million quarterly loss and warned of possible debt strain due to the severe downturn in the industry. The company's shares fell 2.4% and its notes fell below 80 cents on the dollar. KrisEnergy is considering options such as equity or refinancing to address its debt challenges, which include a S$200 million debt paper due in August 2018. The firm's affiliation with Keppel Corp has helped it secure a new credit facility with DBS, but access to capital remains a concern for the industry.

site_title: Hero's welcome for S'pore's golden boy
summary: Singapore's first Olympic gold medallist, Joseph Schooling, was welcomed back with a hero's reception at Changi Airport Terminal 3. Hundreds of people gathered to meet him, and he spent over an hour signing autographs and taking selfies. Schooling set a new Olympic record in the men's 100-metre butterfly event and defeated top swimmers including Michael Phelps. His deferment of National Service enlistment was also granted until 2020, allowing him to focus on his studies and training at the University of Texas.

site_title: No conflict of interest? ISR's stand on adviser's role puzzling
summary: The board of ISR Capital insists there's no conflict of interest in taking deal advice from Timothy Morrison, a partner of Empire Capital Partners, who also sits on the opposite side of the ISR-REO deal. Despite Empire Capital advising ISR on the deal, Morrison's directorship at REO, the company ISR is buying a 60% stake in, is not considered a conflict. ISR's board argues that Empire Capital's primary role is fund-raising, not negotiating deal terms, and that Morrison's appointment at REO may aid the acquisition post-signing. However, experts find this stance puzzling and inconsistent with principles of independence and conflicts of interest.

site_title: World order, in a nutshell, inside the Olympic Village
summary: The Olympic Village in Rio de Janeiro features 31 high-rise apartment buildings, each decorated with the flags of participating countries. The village's 200 delegations, comprising nearly 18,000 athletes, coaches, and officials, were placed in the buildings based on mathematical and political calculations, taking into account cultural and language preferences. The top 10 national organising committees ranked their priorities, and some delegations made special requests. Large countries like Russia and China have separate buildings, while smaller delegations are distributed throughout the village, creating a mosaic of international diversity.

site_title: Tapping tech to cover new ground
summary: Equation Summit, a Catalist-listed group, is exploring IT-based platforms to revolutionize industries. The company has developed a gadget that can read driver behavior and a digital lock that reduces pilferage. Its analytics solution can track driving behavior and car data in Asia, and the data can be used to rate drivers and improve safety. The company also plans to deploy its solution for logistics, construction, and ride-sharing firms. Additionally, Digital Safety, the subsidiary of Equation, has partnered with Walmart for proof of concept testing on its anti-theft system and digital authentication solution.

site_title: MOE: Student loan default rate low, write-offs done only as a last resort (Amended)
summary: Singapore's student loan default rate is low, with written-offs only considered as a last resort. Acting Education Minister Ong Ye Kung made the statement in Parliament in response to questions about the government's tertiary education study loan schemes. The low default rate is attributed to the Ministry of Education's strict policies and measures to support borrowers.

images.alt_text: Mr Ong says the proportion of foreign students who default on fulfilling scholarship bonds stands at about one per cent currently

site_title: Bitcoin exchange's plan to impose losses on clients flawed: lawyers
summary: A Hong Kong-based cryptocurrency exchange, Bitfinex, plans to impose losses on all its clients due to a $72 million bitcoin theft by hackers. Lawyers argue that this plan is flawed, as it spreads losses across all customers, regardless of whether they were hacked or held bitcoin. The exchange's decision rests on two flawed pillars, according to lawyers, and has sparked concerns among clients.

site_title: IGB sells KL's Renaissance hotel for RM765m
summary: IGB Corporation sold its Renaissance Kuala Lumpur Hotel in Kuala Lumpur for RM765 million (S$257 million) to Ventura International Sdn Bhd. The sale, in a conditional agreement, will allow IGB to repay loans and redeem certain assets. The transaction is expected to "unlock business assets at a favourable price." The sale follows a period of disposals by IGB, which aims to strengthen its financial position.

site_title: Thailand risks losing 200,000 visitors this year after blasts: tourism office
summary: Thailand risks losing up to 200,000 foreign visitors and $293 million in tourism revenue due to a series of deadly blasts in tourist towns, including Hua Hin and Phuket. The attacks, which have killed four people and wounded dozens, may lead to long-term losses in terms of tourist arrivals, mainly from Asian countries. The blasts have also hurt business and consumer confidence, with Thai Airways' revenue expected to be affected. The attacks have been linked to an unspecified domestic issue and no group has claimed responsibility.

site_title: Nickel among UBS's most preferred commodity
summary: UBS analysts predict nickel prices will continue to rise due to rising demand and deficits, with prices forecasted to reach US$11,023 next year and US$19,621 by 2020. The Philippines' crackdown on mines, which accounts for about a fifth of world nickel supply, is expected to have a significant impact starting in early 2017, when exports fail to ramp up as usual. Rising stainless-steel output boosts consumption, supporting prices.

site_title: DBS unveils tech solution matching platform for SMEs
summary: DBS has launched a tech solution matching platform for SMEs in Singapore, in partnership with Infocomm Investments and Intellectual Property Intermediary Singapore. The platform allows SMEs to submit business problems online and be matched with tech solution providers. This initiative aims to support SMEs in innovation projects to solve business problems and build capabilities.

site_title: Contempt of court law passed after seven-hour debate
summary: Singapore lawmakers passed the Administration of Justice (Protection) Bill after a seven-hour debate, with 72 votes in favor and nine against. The bill sets out contempt of court laws, including disobeying court orders and scandalizing the court. Law Minister K Shanmugam defended the bill, stating that it was not rushed and that stakeholders had been consulted. He rejected claims that the bill limits freedom of speech, saying that public discussions are not prohibited and that the law will remain the same as it was yesterday. The bill now puts contempt laws in writing, with some changes to the threshold for scandalizing the court.

images.alt_text: Mr Shanmugam said: "I confirm for the record (that) the courts are the final arbiters."

site_title: Sime Darby to inject Aussie properties into Saizen Reit in reverse takeover
summary: Sime Darby Berhad is injecting Australian industrial properties into Saizen Reit in a reverse takeover, gaining a majority stake in the real estate investment trust (Reit). The deal, valued at S$300m, also sees Sime Darby taking an 80% stake in the Reit manager. A framework agreement was signed on August 15, with discussions on the definitive agreement underway. This move is expected to provide Saizen Reit with new business opportunities and expand its market capitalization.

site_title: The rise and fall of a Silicon Valley mogul
summary: Tech entrepreneur Gurbaksh Chahal is back in court for violating his probation after being accused of domestic violence. He previously pleaded down to two misdemeanors and accepted a probation sentence after being accused of punching and kicking his then-girlfriend 117 times in 2013. A personal surveillance video that captured the attack was deemed inadmissible in court but was recently ruled admissible by a San Francisco Superior Court Judge, potentially leading to up to two years in county jail. Chahal, 34, also faces accusations of domestic violence in a second incident in 2014.

site_title: Attacks, coup bring change to Istanbul's Istiklal Avenue
summary: Istiklal Avenue, a historic commercial street in Istanbul, faces an uncertain future following deadly attacks and the failed coup of July 15. The street, once lined with elegant shops and cafes, has seen visitor numbers plummet and many shops shuttered due to high rents and declining revenues. Despite this, Beyoglu Mayor Ahmet Misbah Demircan believes the street will regain its dynamism, viewing the current decline as temporary and a result of external factors rather than a permanent consequence of the attacks and coup.

site_title: China Inc's US$3b land grab among Europe's soccer royalty
summary: Chinese investors have made a significant land grab in European soccer, purchasing several clubs for around $3 billion since December, including AC Milan for $740 million. The buyers, mostly unknown, have backed by local Chinese government support, with President Xi Jinping aiming to turn China into a football superpower by 2050. The influx of Chinese cash has sparked concerns over the involvement of untested entities in European football, but most associations have yet to raise major concerns. The Chinese group plans to provide a $100 million shareholder loan to finance new players and secure transfer deals, fueling speculation that China aims to host and win the World Cup.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: ComfortDelGro's 2Q16 revenue fell 1.4% y-o-y to S$1.02 billion, driven by a negative S$18 million foreign currency translation effect. The company's profit after tax (Patmi) grew 5.3% y-o-y to S$85.2 million. The new bus government contracting model (GCM) is expected to improve CDG's free cash flow, as non-cash depreciation charges become a positive cash inflow. Riverstone Holdings' additional healthcare glove capacity is fully taken up, and Jumbo Group's 3Q16 results exceeded expectations, with rapid growth in China and higher margins.

site_title: Growing uncertainty over fate of TPP deal
summary: US Senator Bernie Sanders has called for the Democratic Party to abandon efforts to pass the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) trade deal in Congress, citing growing global concerns and opposition from both Democratic and Republican presidential nominees. The Obama administration will continue its push to boost support for the deal, which is seen as crucial for US leadership in the Asia-Pacific region. Despite a potential $300 billion economic boost by 2025, concerns over the deal's impact on jobs and wages have led to uncertainty over its fate, with some lawmakers questioning the deal's nature and others expressing concerns about the US's ability to write the rules of the global economy.

site_title: Sembcorp, Hock Lian Seng clinch Changi Airport deal
summary: Sembcorp Industries and Hock Lian Seng have entered a joint venture to undertake a S$1.107 billion contract from Changi Airport Group to develop the airport's three-runway operations. The joint venture will include taxiway pavement works, drainage, and other supporting infrastructure. The project is expected to boost Hock Lian Seng's construction order book to S$980 million, but is not expected to have a material impact on earnings per share and net asset value. The development of a three-runway system is part of Changi Airport's expansion plans, expected to be operational in the early 2020s.

site_title: ISR reveals deal adviser's link to vendor in major acquisition
summary: ISR Capital, a Singaporean firm, has revealed that it is taking advice on a major acquisition from Empire Capital Partners, whose partner is also a director of the vendor, REO Magnetic. Despite this, ISR claims its board does not view the appointment as a conflict of interest. Empire Capital Partners was hired to source funding and perform due diligence, not negotiate the acquisition terms. The acquisition has yet to be completed, with ISR set to issue shares to REO to pay for the stake.

site_title: June retail sales underperform market expectations
summary: Singapore's retail sales declined 3% year-on-year in June, underperforming market expectations, according to the Department of Statistics. Excluding motor vehicles, sales dropped 3.7%. The decline was seen across most categories, with growth only in furniture and medical goods. The sales of motor vehicles rose 17.1% in June, but decelerated from May's 35% growth. Economists attribute cautious consumer behavior to a plodding economy and soft labor market, with a forecast of slower growth for Singapore in the second half of 2016.

site_title: US$ subdued by easing Fed rate hike expectations
summary: The US dollar was subdued on Monday, dropping 0.3% to 100.95 yen, as sluggish US data tempered expectations of a Federal Reserve interest rate hike this year. Retail sales and producer prices came in weaker than expected, contributing to the decline. The euro rose 0.15% to US$1.1172, while the yen's decline was attributed to the weaker dollar. The easing expectations of a rate hike have reduced pressure on the dollar, resulting in a softer exchange rate.

site_title: PM Lee to visit India in October
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong will visit India in October to meet Prime Minister Narendra Modi and explore new avenues of cooperation. The visit comes after a "longstanding friendship" between the two nations, with a strategic partnership signed in 2015. The partnership aims to enhance cooperation in fields like trade, investment, skills development, and defence, with a focus on Smart Cities. Lee's visit is seen as a sign of growing bilateral ties between Singapore and India, with the two leaders expressing confidence in their relationship's future growth.

site_title: IMF calls for policies to support wage increases in Japan
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) is urging Japan to adopt an incomes policy to support wage increases, a strategy once used by US presidents Nixon, Ford, and Carter in the 1970s. The IMF wants Japan to use moral suasion, tax breaks, and penalties to prod companies into granting bigger pay gains and promoting higher inflation. This approach is seen as a response to Japan's entrenched "deflationary mindset" and resistance to traditional policies. The IMF's call is being echoed by Japanese officials, who are exploring ways to encourage a wage target policy and boost pay.

site_title: Can the private sector save us?
summary: The US economy's sluggish recovery since the Great Recession has led to a search for explanations and villains. A study by Josh Bivens of the Economic Policy Institute suggests that insufficient government spending, particularly by the federal government, has hindered the recovery. The study found that if government spending had increased at a similar rate to the 1981-82 recession, it would have been $1 trillion higher in 2015, translating to several years of full employment. However, the effectiveness of stimulus policies is also questioned, as a previous stimulus from 2009-2012 only partially succeeded in boosting the economy. The article concludes that the private sector's weakness is a more pressing issue, and providing more stimulus may distract from addressing the root problem.

site_title: Indonesian president removes energy minister over dual citizenship controversy
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo removed Energy and Mining Minister Arcandra Tahar after less than a month due to reports of dual citizenship, violating Indonesia's policy against dual citizenship. Tahar, a former US-based executive, held both Indonesian and US citizenship. The move is considered an embarrassing failure by the government, with analysts saying they should have conducted basic due diligence. Tahar will be replaced by Luhut Pandjaitan as interim energy minister.

site_title: Singapore is most innovative economy in Asia
summary: Singapore has emerged as the top Asian economy in innovation, ranking 6th globally in the 2016 Global Innovation Index (GII). The country has consistently maintained its ranks since the GII's inception in 2007, being the only Asian country to do so. Singapore's strong innovation input is attributed to its institutions, human capital, and research, infrastructure, market sophistication, and business sophistication. China, a "middle-income country," has improved its innovation performance and now ranks 25th overall, while an innovation divide persists between developed and developing countries.

site_title: Latest Earnings
summary:
Here is a 100-word summary of the article content:

NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss in the second half of the year. London's Heathrow plans to increase fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case. OCBC announced Tan Teck Long as its incoming CEO. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and People's Bank of China (PBOC) are expanding cooperation on green and transition finance. Singapore stocks rose for a 5th consecutive day ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 6.18 points to close at 1,690.33 on Monday, driven by a significant trading volume of 2.31 billion lots valued at RM1.75 billion. Gainers outnumbered losers 449-412.

site_title: SMRT: Gas leak from train's air-con caused smoke inside Tanjong Pagar MRT station
summary: Thick smoke was seen at the Tanjong Pagar MRT station in Singapore on August 15, 2016, due to a gas leak from a train's air-conditioning system. The leak, which was caused by freon gas, affected one trainload of passengers but no injuries were reported. The Singapore Civil Defence Force confirmed that no injuries occurred. SMRT, the operator of the MRT, released a statement about the incident.

site_title: Germany should consider raising retirement age to 69: Bundesbank
summary: Germany's central bank recommends raising the retirement age to 69 to ensure pension commitments can be met, as the current system faces pressure from aging baby-boomer retirees and declining workforce. The retirement age is scheduled to rise to 67 by 2030. The Bundesbank warns that failing to address this issue could have significant consequences for the country's pension system.

site_title: Presidential campaign gets serious - just briefly
summary: US presidential candidates Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton delivered dueling speeches on the economy, focusing on the crisis facing America's ageing and unskilled workforce. Trump's team, consisting mainly of wealthy hedge funders and business executives, proposed tax cuts, deregulation, and a moratorium on government regulation. However, he also hinted at populist policies, such as helping workers acquire skills and potentially ending trade agreements. Clinton countered that Trump's proposals would only benefit the wealthy, and she presented her own plans to make public college tuition free and raise taxes on corporations.

site_title: Consistel fined S$300k for licence breach; IDA files police report
summary: Consistel, a company with a 10-year license to run the telecommunications infrastructure at Singapore's Sports Hub, has been fined S$300,000 by the Infocomm Development Authority of Singapore (IDA) for breaching its licensing obligations. The IDA found that Consistel transferred ownership of the license to another company without prior approval, and Consistel failed to disclose executed agreements. The IDA has lodged a police report and will consider Consistel's application to become Singapore's fourth telco when reviewing the fourth mobile operator spectrum auction.

images.alt_text: The company which has an agreement with the Singapore Sports Hub to run its wireless telecommunication system has been fined S$300,000 by the Infocomm Development Authority of Singapore (IDA) for breaching its licensing obligations.

site_title: JES auditors unable to issue clean bill of health for shipping firm
summary: AUDITORS of JES International Holdings Limited, a Chinese shipping firm, were unable to issue a clean bill of health due to "material uncertainties" casting doubt on the company's ability to continue operating. The group incurred a net loss of $58.8 million and had significant cash outflows. A subsidiary filed for debt restructuring, and missing accounting records have not been recovered. The audit report highlighted concerns over the group's ability to recover from financial difficulties and resolve ongoing disputes. The company has ceased operations and reconstituted its board amid a series of resignations.

site_title: Indonesia's Sampoerna Agro fined record sum for 2014 forest fires
summary: Indonesia's Sampoerna Agro has been fined a record 1.07 trillion rupiah ($109.89 million) by a Jakarta court for its negligence in relation to 2014 forest fires on 3,000 hectares of its concessions in Riau. This is the largest ever fine handed down to a company linked to forest fires. The company is considering its options, including an appeal. The fine comes as Indonesia intensifies its efforts to penalize companies responsible for its annual forest fires, which cause a haze crisis that affects large parts of the region.

site_title: Helping accountants do the right thing
summary: The International Code of Ethics for Professional Accountants is set to undergo revisions, clarifying accountants' responsibilities when dealing with non-compliance with laws and regulations. The changes, effective July 15, 2017, come in response to high-profile corporate scandals such as Volkswagen's emissions-cheating scandal and inadequate money-laundering controls at financial firms. The new guidelines aim to strengthen ethical behavior in the profession and improve accountability.

images.alt_text: "Lengthened cooling-off period promotes an objective and independent challenge and serves to enhance trust in auditors' reports," says Ms Ong Bee Yen, chief ethics & compliance officer, Deloitte Southeast Asia.

"While every person is expected to play the good citizen duty, is it right that a citizen who happens to be an accountant is automatically held accountable to a higher public responsibility?" asks Kwok Wui San, chairman, ethics committee, Institute of Singapore Chartered Accountants (ISCA), and a partner at PwC Singapore.

"In the Singapore context, the social, educational and business environment in which accountants are groomed will have an impact on their behaviour and engender a low tolerance of anything unethical," says Sajjad Akhtar, managing director, PKF-CAP Advisory Partners.

site_title: China Sky shrouded in lawsuits, seeks extension to report Q2 results
summary: China Sky Chemical Fibre Co Ltd faces lawsuits from former employees and China Construction Bank, with one subsidiary ordered to pay 800,000 yuan to 34 former employees. The company has paid 330,000 yuan to nine claimants. China Sky is assessing the impact on Q2 results and has submitted an application to the Singapore Exchange for an extension to announce its results by Sept 30. The group is also dealing with an outstanding sum of 3.6 million yuan in salaries and 8.1 million yuan in social security/insurance contributions.

site_title: US: Stocks rise as energy shares gain
summary: US stocks rose in opening trade on Monday, driven by higher oil prices, boosting petroleum-linked equities. The Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 0.3% to 18,635.71, while the S&P 500 rose 0.2% to 2,189.12, and the Nasdaq Composite Index advanced 0.3% to 5,246.65. Chevron and ExxonMobil led the gains, up 0.5% each, amid speculation that OPEC producers may limit oil output next month.

site_title: Brexit vote to have "limited" economic impact on Germany: Bundesbank
summary: Germany's central bank, the Bundesbank, expects the country's economy to continue expanding over the summer, despite the UK's vote to leave the EU, citing positive expectations from German companies. The economy grew 0.4% in the three months to June, ahead of analyst expectations. The Bundesbank believes the economic impact of Brexit on Germany will be limited in the short term, as German companies' expectations have only been modestly dampened.

site_title: Parliament gives Olympian Schooling a standing ovation
summary: Singapore's national swimmer Joseph Schooling received a standing ovation in Parliament for winning the men's 100-metre butterfly event at the Olympic Games, securing the nation's first gold medal. Social and Family Development Minister Tan Chuan-Jin praised Schooling's achievement as a moment of "great national pride" for the entire nation. This historic win marked a significant milestone for Singapore in the Olympic Games.

site_title: Wall St strength fails to rub off on STI
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) declined 0.19 points to 2,867.21 on Monday, with low trading volume of 815.10 million units. Despite Wall Street's gains, the STI was largely unaffected, with Singtel's outperformance providing support. RHB maintained a "neutral" recommendation for Singtel, citing its stable yield and smaller exposure to the domestic mobile market. DBS fell 0.18 points after adjusting its earnings forecast, while Wilmar International rose 0.02 points. Accordia Golf Trust's units ended unchanged, and Nomura noted that Asian markets are at a "tricky juncture" awaiting further market settlement.

site_title: More winners than losers as technology advances
summary: Pokémon Go, a massively multiplayer online game, has led to a surge in demand for cafes, malls, and other public spaces, with players seeking fresh air and exercise. The game's augmented reality technology has also encouraged people to travel, explore their surroundings, and engage in physical activity, potentially leading to savings on healthcare subsidies. While some businesses, like tech giants and game-maker Niantic, will profit from in-app purchases, others, such as food and beverage companies, will also benefit from the craze. The game's success highlights the potential for innovation to stimulate demand and drive economic growth.

site_title: NYSE expects tech companies to spur revival in new Asian listings
summary: The New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) expects technology companies to drive a revival in new Asian listings, with double-digit IPOs expected through the end of 2017. According to NYSE's global head of capital markets, Garvis Toler, new listings are expected to pick up pace in the next months after a slow first half of the year.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares end at new 9-month high
summary: Hong Kong shares reached a nine-month high, closing at 22,932.51 on Monday, driven by depressed global interest rates and buoyant China stocks. The Hang Seng index rose 0.7% and the China Enterprises Index gained 1.6%. Financial and IT stocks led the gains, with Vanke shares reaching a seven-month high and AAC Technologies Holdings Inc hitting an all-time high. The rally was also fueled by optimism over potential policy easing measures in China to support its struggling economy.

site_title: Noble's liquidity crunch likely to ease in Q3, says Fitch
summary: Fitch Ratings Ltd says Noble Group Ltd's liquidity crunch is likely to ease in Q3, driven by a US$900 million influx from a recent rights issue, which includes US$500 million from the issue and working capital reductions. The company's liquidity ratio is expected to return to above 1, up from 0.5 times in the second quarter. Noble Group has seen a two-year decline in shares due to raw materials collapse and scrutiny of its accounting practices, and will sell a US unit to raise further funds, with Fitch warning that reduced business scale could impact ratings.

site_title: Gold firm on lower dollar, eyes on US rate hike signals
summary: Gold prices rose 0.4% to $1,340.51 an ounce as the US dollar edged lower following disappointing US retail sales data, lowering expectations of a US interest rate hike this year. The metal remains near a two-year high of $1,374.91, driven by the negative interest rate environment in the euro zone and Japan. Investors are also awaiting the release of Fed minutes, which may indicate the Fed's plans for rate hikes in the second half of the year.

site_title: URA turns down Centurion's request to raise bed capacity at Westlite Toh Guan
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) has rejected Centurion Corporation's request to increase the bed capacity at Westlite Toh Guan dormitory in Jurong from 7,820 to 8,628. The URA cited a documentation discrepancy as the reason for the decision. Centurion will have to reduce the number of workers housed in the dormitory to 7,820, as originally approved in 2011. If the decision is final, 808 beds will be reduced, and excess workers will be relocated, potentially affecting the valuation of the property and the company's profits.

site_title: Sembcorp Industries forms joint venture to take on Changi Airport work
summary: Sembcorp Industries has formed a joint venture with Hock Lian Seng Infrastructure to undertake a $1.107 billion contract from Changi Airport Group for development work on the airport's three-runway operations. The project, expected to be completed in the early 2020s, will boost Hock Lian Seng's construction order book. Both companies do not expect the project to impact their earnings per share and net asset value per share for the current financial year. The joint venture, with Hock Lian Seng holding 60% and Sembcorp's subsidiary holding the remaining stake, will carry out work including taxiway pavement, drainage, and security fencing.

site_title: Indonesia's July exports, imports plunge on yearly basis
summary: Indonesia's exports and imports declined in July, defying expectations for the first growth in 22 months. Exports fell 17.02% to $9.51 billion, while imports dropped 11.56% to $8.92 billion, resulting in a trade surplus of around $590 million, lower than forecast. The decline was attributed to the reduced working days in July due to Eid al-Fitr celebrations.

site_title: Oil hits August high on potential producer action to prop up market
summary: Oil prices rose to a high for August, with Brent crude reaching $47.40 a barrel, up 11.3% from its last close in July. Speculation about potential OPEC production freezes is driving the price increase, with Saudi Arabia signaling a willingness to discuss market stabilization. However, US producers are continuing to increase drilling activity, and Morgan Stanley warns that weak fundamentals will eventually outweigh bullish sentiment, citing high production and swelling inventories.

site_title: Singapore shares close mixed in thin trading
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) in Singapore dropped 0.19 points to 2,867.21 on Monday, with low trading volume. Despite this, the index has seen a 5-day rally. Singtel's stock rose 0.06 to S$4.31, adding 6 points to the index, driven by its strong performance this year. Analyst RHB maintained its "neutral" recommendation for Singtel, citing its stable yield and smaller exposure to the domestic mobile market.

site_title: Ex-Chopard manager jailed 15 years for siphoning S$11.2m
summary: A former Chopard accounting manager, Chew Siew Lang, was sentenced to 15 years in jail for siphoning S$11.2 million from her employer over 5.5 years. She misappropriated the funds using erasable ink to write on cheques for bogus transactions. The scheme was uncovered, leading to her conviction and lengthy prison term.

site_title: Europe: Stocks steady at open
summary: European stock markets stabilized at the start of trading on Monday, with the FTSE 100 index flat at 6,914.43 points. The eurozone's DAX 30 and CAC 40 also remained largely unchanged, with the CAC 40 adding 0.1%. This follows a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks, which await GDP data on Tuesday. US stocks reached fresh records, despite concerns over trade tensions between the US and EU.

site_title: Indonesia airlines cleared to fly to US
summary: Indonesian airlines have been cleared to fly to the US after the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) upgraded the country's safety rating. The ban, which was imposed in 2007, was lifted after Indonesia's efforts to improve its oversight system were deemed successful. Garuda, an Indonesian carrier, is expected to start direct flights to the US next year, with plans to expand its long-haul international network. The upgrade is seen as a positive move for Indonesia's aviation sector, boosting public trust and opening up new opportunities for airlines.

site_title: Tesla removes 'autopilot' from China website after Beijing crash
summary: Tesla removed "autopilot" and the term "zidong jiashi" from its China website after a Beijing driver crashed in "autopilot" mode, damaging both cars but causing no injuries. The driver claimed Tesla misled buyers about the function's capability. The incident follows a fatal accident in Florida and pressure to tighten rules for automated driving. Tesla has undergone training for staff to emphasize the need to keep hands on the wheel during demonstrations, and has stated the system is assistive, not self-driving.

site_title: Australia: Bourse ends higher on retail sector gains
summary: Australian shares ended higher on Monday, with the S&P/ASX 200 index rising 0.16% or 9 points to 5,539.96. Gains in the retail sector, led by condom maker Ansell Ltd and electronics retailer JB HI-Fi, offset losses in the mining sector. New Zealand's benchmark index also rose 0.3%. The gains came despite global market uncertainty, with US stocks reaching fresh records despite tariff concerns.

site_title: Thailand risks losing 200,000 visitors after blasts: tourism office
summary: Thailand risks losing 200,000 foreign visitors and $293 million in tourism revenue due to a series of deadly blasts in tourist towns. The attacks, which killed four people and wounded dozens, have been described as the biggest challenge to Thailand's tourism industry in years. The blasts may result in long-term losses, with up to 100,000 travel cancellations expected by the end of the year, costing the industry $196-196 million. The attacks have also hurt business and consumer confidence, according to Thai Airways.

site_title: China: Stocks close at 7-month highs on stimulus hopes
summary: China's stocks reached 7-month highs on Monday, driven by hopes of government stimulus following weaker-than-expected economic data. The CSI300 index rose 3.0% to 3,393.42 points, while the Shanghai Composite Index gained 2.4% to 3,125.20 points. Real estate stocks surged 7.3%, with developer Vanke jumping 10% on the day. The government's decision to ease policies and reforms is seen as a response to weak economic data, including investment, lending, retail spending, and factory output.

site_title: British millennials are 'collateral damage' as pension gap grows
summary: British millennials face a growing pension gap as the country's pension-fund liabilities reached a record £1 trillion, primarily due to quantitative easing and low interest rates. The Bank of England's decision to cut interest rates further is expected to worsen the situation. Younger workers will need to save more or work longer, as defined-benefit pension funds already saw a 40% increase in deficits. The UK's aging population and potential higher taxes for employees also pose a long-term pension problem.

site_title: KrisEnergy bonds fall below 80 US cents amid debt covenant pressure
summary: KrisEnergy Ltd bonds have fallen below 80 US cents amid debt covenant pressure due to the industry slump. The company's June 2017 notes were trading at 79.95 US cents, yielding 37%, as investors worry about debt covenants being tested. KrisEnergy is exploring equity issuance, refinancing, and asset sales to strengthen its capital structure. The company's SGX Oil & Gas sub-index has dropped 44% since March 31, affecting weaker upstream players.

site_title: Closing date for Eu Yan Sang takeover offer extended till Aug 29
summary: RIGHTEOUS Crane Holding has extended the closing date for its S$0.60 per-share takeover offer for Eu Yan Sang International to 5.30pm on Aug 29. The offer was previously extended from Aug 1 to Aug 15. Despite the public float falling below 10%, the consortium does not intend to restore the minimum float or maintain Eu Yan Sang's listing status. Substantial shareholders, including Hillhouse Capital Management Ltd and TFW Fund, hold a combined 10.6% stake, which is not counted as part of the public float.

site_title: Seoul: Markets closed for holiday
summary: Seoul's financial markets are closed on August 15, 2016, due to a public holiday. This is unrelated to the other news articles provided, which cover various stock market updates and company news from July 10-11, 2025.

site_title: World's biggest shipping firm warns against US protectionism
summary: Maersk, the world's largest container shipping company, warns that a shift in US policy towards protectionism could reduce global trade, hurting economic growth. The company's CFO, Trond Westlie, stated that trade barriers weaken global growth and that low barriers help trade and economic growth. The warning comes as US presidential candidates Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton are taking tougher stances on trade and globalization. The World Bank identifies trade as a key means to fight poverty, but trade growth has slowed since the global financial crisis.

site_title: Noble Group liquidity crunch is 'temporary', Fitch Ratings says
summary: Fitch Ratings says Noble Group Ltd's liquidity crunch is temporary, predicting the company will generate about $900 million in the coming months from a recent rights issue and working-capital reductions. The liquidity crisis, caused by a two-year collapse in shares and scrutiny over accounting practices, won't persist and Noble Group will have sufficient liquidity this quarter. The company is backed by China's sovereign wealth fund and has seen its debt cut to junk by ratings agencies.

site_title: One person injured in axe and shooting attack in Cologne: newspaper
summary: A person was injured in a knife and shooting attack in Cologne city centre, Germany, early Monday morning. Witnesses reported seeing men attacking each other with axes before the incident. Two suspects are on the run. The attack occurred shortly before 4 am local time.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei falls as strong yen, weak GDP hit mood in holiday-thin trade
summary: Japanese stocks fell on Monday due to a strong yen and weak GDP data, which hurt investor sentiment. The Nikkei dropped 0.3% to 16,869.56, while the Topix fell 0.5% to 1,316.63. Thin trade, with 1.24 billion shares changing hands, was also a factor, as many market participants were away due to Japan's 'bon' holidays. The economic growth data showed stalled growth in the second quarter, further impacting investor confidence.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary:
Here's a summary of the article content in 100 words or less:

New homes sold by developers more than doubled in July, reaching 1,091 units, according to the Urban Redevelopment Authority. Retail sales in June rose 0.9% year-on-year, driven by car sales. Consistel was fined S$300,000 for breaching its licencing obligations, and IDA filed a police report. KrisEnergy bonds fell below 80 US cents due to debt covenant pressure. Sime Darby will acquire a majority stake in Saizen Reit through a reverse takeover, injecting Australian industrial properties. Singaporean swimmer Joseph Schooling returned home to a hero's welcome after winning the country's first Olympic gold medal.

site_title: ANZ reviews Asian retail banking operations: senior exec
summary: ANZ is reviewing its Asian retail banking operations as part of a strategy to slash costs and boost returns. The bank is pulling out of less profitable areas to bolster earnings amid rising regulatory costs. This move is a departure from ANZ's previous strategy, which saw the bank struggle to generate steady returns in Asia. ANZ's institutional products and services business is being restructured to focus on higher-return opportunities.

site_title: Sterling steadies near 3-year low vs euro, eyes on post-Brexit data
summary: Sterling steadied near a three-year low against the euro, trading at 86.40 pence, amid uncertainty following the UK's Brexit vote. Traders await the release of key post-Brexit data, including retail sales, inflation, and jobs data, which could impact the currency. Analysts warn of potential short-term volatility, but some believe the UK may be able to weather the storm with the Bank of England's bold moves. Sterling is also under pressure due to falling gilt yields, which have hit a record low.

images.alt_text: Currency traders kept the pressure on sterling on Monday at the start of a week packed full of the first round of hard national data on consumer and corporate reaction to June's vote for Britain to leave the European Union.

site_title: Yen hit by weak Japanese GDP data
summary: The Japanese yen weakened Monday after disappointing second-quarter GDP data, with growth flat at 0.0% quarter-on-quarter. Economists predict the Bank of Japan will unleash more stimulus to counter a downturn. The yen fell to 101.31 against the US dollar, while the euro rose to 113.03 yen. The weak data is likely to pressure policymakers at the Bank of Japan's next meeting, which is set for next month, amid a US interest rate hike uncertainty.

site_title: Thailand's economy expanded more than expected in second quarter
summary: Thailand's economy expanded 3.5% in the second quarter, exceeding analysts' 3.3% estimate, driven by government spending on road and rail projects and robust tourism growth. The central bank kept interest rates unchanged, allowing time for fiscal spending to boost growth. Consumer and private investment are expected to recover gradually, offsetting the contraction of exports.

site_title: Reports of shots at New York's JFK airport lead to evacuation: media
summary: Reports of gunshots fired at New York's JFK airport led to the evacuation of Terminal 8. Police are investigating the incident while searching for a suspect. The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which operates the airport, was unavailable for comment. The incident occurred on Sunday, with no further information provided.

site_title: Asia: Shares recoup losses as China hits 7-month top
summary: Asian shares recouped losses as China's blue-chip CSI300 Index rose 1.3% to a seven-month high, driven by speculation of further stimulus from Beijing. This helped offset news of Japan's economic growth slowing in the last quarter. The MSCI's Asia-Pacific shares index stood steady, while rich-world bond yields have dropped dramatically, pushing investors to seek higher returns in emerging markets and equities.

site_title: Yuan weakens as large rise in forex sales raises outflow concerns
summary: China's yuan weakened sharply on Monday as the central bank sold a record 190.5 billion yuan worth of foreign exchange in July, sparking concerns of capital outflows. The yuan fell to 6.6475 per US dollar, 0.07% weaker than the previous day's close. Despite the drop, analysts expect the yuan to remain range-bound, with the central bank likely to avoid volatility ahead of the G20 summit in Hangzhou. The People's Bank of China (PBOC) had set the midpoint rate at 6.643 per US dollar prior to market open.

site_title: Sime Darby to acquire Saizen Reit, inject Australian industrial properties in reverse takeover
summary: Sime Darby, a Malaysian conglomerate, will acquire a majority stake in Saizen Real Estate Investment Trust (Reit) through a reverse takeover, injecting Australian industrial properties into the trust. Sime Darby Property Singapore will hold 80% of the Reit manager, while Hastings Deering (Australia) will sell its Australian assets. A framework agreement has been reached, with negotiations underway for final terms and due diligence.

images.alt_text: MALAYSIAN conglomerate Sime Darby will acquire a majority stake in Saizen Real Estate Investment Trust (Reit) through a reverse takeover and inject Australian industrial property into the trust, the Reit manager announced on Monday.

site_title: Search at New York's JFK airport finds no signs of gunfire
summary: A preliminary investigation at New York's JFK airport found no evidence of gunfire in Terminal 8 despite earlier reports of shots being heard, leading to an evacuation of the area. No gun casings were found after a search, and the airport's operator stated that the terminal was evacuated out of an abundance of caution. This incident follows a similar incident at a mall in Raleigh, North Carolina, where no suspects or bullet casings were found.

site_title: LOGOS, Yang Kee to develop 66,000 sq m GFA warehouse at Tuas South
summary: LOGOS SE Asia and Yang Kee Logistics have jointly developed a 66,000 sq m warehouse in Tuas South, Singapore, with an estimated development cost of S$150 million. The project, which began immediately following acquisition, is expected to be completed in the first quarter of 2018. The joint venture partners will include office space, a cafeteria, and a container yard. Yang Kee will enter into a long-term lease over the total project.

site_title: US nukes at Turkey base at risk of seizure: report
summary: US nuclear weapons stored at a Turkish air base near Syria are at risk of being captured by "terrorists or other hostile forces", a Washington think tank claimed. The base, Incirlik, is 70 miles from the Syrian border and has been the subject of renewed debate since a failed coup attempt in Turkey last month. The US has approximately 50 nuclear bombs stored at the base, which could pose a risk to global security. The Pentagon declined to comment on the issue, citing the need to maintain safety and security of personnel and facilities.

site_title: Australian, New Zealand: Stocks edge up in volatile trade
summary: Australian and New Zealand share indexes rose on Monday, with the S&P/ASX 200 index gaining 0.2% to 5,541.70. Key movers included Ansell Ltd, which surged 14% on potential sale of its sexual health division, and JB Hi-Fi, which added 6.7%. Gains were offset by falls in Newcrest Mining and Aurizon. New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index rose 0.1%. Overall, the market remained volatile due to profit reporting season and economic uncertainty.

site_title: Update: Hong Kong student leaders avoid jail time for 2014 democracy protest
summary: A Hong Kong court sentenced Joshua Wong, a 19-year-old democracy activist, to 80 hours of community service for his role in the 2014 "Umbrella Movement" protests. Wong, along with two other student leaders, Alex Chow and Nathan Law, were involved in a night-long standoff with police in front of government headquarters. The protests helped trigger a massive push for full democracy in Hong Kong, one of the boldest populist challenges to Beijing's Communist Party leaders in decades.

site_title: US dollar on defensive after downbeat US data, unfazed by weak Japan GDP
summary: The US dollar remained steady at 101.370 yen on Monday, despite downbeat US data and weak Japan GDP, which tempered expectations of a near-term interest rate hike by the Federal Reserve. US retail sales and producer prices data released on Friday showed weaker-than-expected numbers, trimming expectations for a US interest rate increase in September and December. The dollar index was effectively unchanged at 95.755, while the euro remained steady at US$1.1161.

site_title: Olympics: Hero's homecoming for Singapore star Schooling
summary: Singapore swimmer Joseph Schooling returned home to a hero's welcome after winning the city-state's first Olympic gold medal. Schooling, 21, edged out Michael Phelps in the men's 100m butterfly final, setting a new Olympic record. The government announced he won't have to undergo mandatory military training until after the Tokyo 2020 Olympics. Schooling was met with a crowd of 500 people, including international media, and was invited to a Parliament session and a victory parade. His victory is seen as a proud moment for Singapore, with many hailing him as a symbol of hard work and inspiration.

site_title: Japan, South Korea strike conciliatory note on war anniversary
summary: Japan and South Korea struck a conciliatory note on the anniversary of World War II, with South Korean President Park Geun-Hye calling for a "future-oriented" relationship with Tokyo. Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe avoided visiting a controversial Tokyo war shrine, sending a ritual donation instead. Despite this, a group of Seoul lawmakers visited disputed islets claimed by both nations, sparking official anger in Japan. The conciliatory tone suggests a desire to move forward and improve relations, but challenges remain in resolving historical disputes between the two nations.

images.alt_text: Tokyo and Seoul struck a conciliatory note Monday on the anniversary of the end of World War II, with South Korea's president calling for a "future-oriented" relationship and Japan's prime minister denouncing the "horrors of war".

site_title: Thai baht races to highest in over 1 year after solid Q2 GDP
summary: Thailand's baht reached its strongest level in over a year after the country's economy expanded 0.8% in the second quarter, beating expectations of 0.5%. The baht gained 0.2% to 34.685 per US dollar, its highest level since July 22, 2015. This growth is attributed to the country's solid Q2 GDP.

site_title: Consistel fined S$300,000 for irregularities; IDA also files police report
summary: The Infocomm Development Authority of Singapore (IDA) fined Consistel S$300,000 for breaching its licencing obligations for the communications system at the Sports Hub. IDA filed a police report, marking the first time a report has been filed for a breach of licencing obligations. Consistel sought to transfer its licence to a company owned by its parent company in 2014, but failed to submit required documentation. IDA gave in-principle approval for the transfer in 2015, but Consistel's actions were deemed irregular.

site_title: Philippines halts eighth nickel miner after audit
summary: The Philippines has suspended the eighth nickel ore mine, Emir Mineral Resources Corp, and halted another chromite miner, Mt Sinai Mining Exploration and Development Corp, amid an environmental probe. Environment Secretary Gina Lopez has ordered a nationwide audit of miners, threatening to shut the nation's biggest coal producer, Semirara Mining & Power Co, if it fails to explain alleged environmental violations. The move is part of her efforts to close mines that fail international standards, with the goal of increasing environmental protection.

site_title: PM Modi hails sweeping reforms for India's fast growth
summary: India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi praised sweeping tax reforms as a key factor in the country's robust growth, despite a global slowdown. In his Independence Day speech, Modi highlighted the recent passage of a landmark tax reform, which has contributed to India's 7.6% GDP growth in 2015-16, outpacing major economies such as China. Modi also credited his government's efforts in improving the ease of doing business and reducing retail inflation to 6%. The passage of the Goods and Services Tax (GST) bill marks India's most significant economic reform in decades.

images.alt_text: Prime Minister Narendra Modi said India was becoming the world's most attractive destination for foreign investors Monday, using his annual Independence Day speech to trumpet sweeping tax reforms designed to spur growth.

site_title: New homes sold by developers more than double from June
summary: Developers in Singapore launched 624 private homes in July, more than doubling from June, with 1,091 units sold. This represents a sales volume that doubled from June and a launch volume that was more than six times June's 234 units. The top-selling Executive Condominium (EC) in July was Sim Lian Group's Treasure Crest, which sold 398 units. Overall, the sales and launch figures indicate a strong demand for private and EC housing in Singapore.

images.alt_text: Developers launched 624 private homes (excluding executive condominiums) in July and sold 1,091 units, based on figures from the Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) released on Monday.

site_title: Singapore's KrisEnergy warns debt covenants may come under stress
summary: Singapore oil and gas firm KrisEnergy Ltd warned that some debt covenants may come under stress due to weaker oil markets, which have hit revenue. The company is exploring ways to strengthen its capital structure, potentially involving equity issuance, refinancing, or asset divestment. KrisEnergy, which has Keppel Corp as a major shareholder, has engaged external parties to help address the issue. The company's financial situation is a concern amid a plunge in oil prices.

site_title: All or nothing in China bond recoveries as bankruptcy murky
summary: China's defaulted bond recoveries have been either full repayment or delays and diversions, with only one partially made good out of 26 local public notes since 2014. Moody's Investors Service calls for a transparent restructuring process and secondary liquidity for defaulted bonds. The country needs to establish bankruptcy protection law like Chapter 11 in the US to help struggling firms negotiate with creditors. Chinese companies face a record 3 trillion yuan of local bonds due in the second half, with many firms listed with negative revenue growth and insufficient cash to cover short-term debt.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks dip; ETFs targeting China market rally
summary: Taiwan's stocks fell 0.1% to 9,139.26 points on Monday, despite recent gains, as investors remained cautious. Meanwhile, some ETFs targeting Chinese stocks surged, tracking China's market gains. This comes after Taiwan's market reached a one-year high, driven by massive foreign buying. The recent rally has been attributed to foreign investors' optimism on China's economic recovery.

site_title: Prices of UK homes for sale see biggest fall in 9 months: Rightmove
summary: The UK housing market experienced its largest price drop in 9 months, with asking prices falling 1.2% in August, according to Rightmove. The drop was driven by the summer lull and uncertainty surrounding the Brexit decision. London and the South East saw the biggest decline, with prices falling 2.6% and 2.0% respectively. This marks a reduction in the annual price increase to 4.1% from 4.5% in July, according to Rightmove's survey covering 90% of the market.

site_title: S'pore shares open lower as STI eases 0.2% to 2,861.54
summary: Singapore shares opened lower on Monday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) slipping 0.2% to 2,861.54. The top active stock was Attilan Group, which jumped 75% to trade at 0.7 Singapore cent. Banks, including DBS Group Holdings and United Overseas Bank, also fell. Despite a 5-day rally, investors are cautious ahead of upcoming GDP data.

site_title: Sharp shares up more than 10% after Foxconn completes stake purchase
summary: Sharp shares rose more than 10% after Taiwan's Foxconn completed its 388.8 billion yen (S$5.17 billion) stake purchase, increasing Foxconn's stake to 66.07%. The takeover marked a significant shift in Sharp's ownership structure. Following the announcement, Sharp's shares jumped to 124 yen, the highest since June 24, as investors reacted to the news.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Stocks start day up
summary: Hong Kong and Shanghai stocks opened higher on Monday, extending last week's gains. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.33% to 22,843.06, while the Shanghai Composite Index added 0.19% to 3,056.48. The Shenzhen Composite Index also increased 0.18%. These gains follow a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks ahead of GDP data release and come despite US trade uncertainty.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 2.66 points to 1,681.49. The market saw a trading volume of 77.8 million lots worth RM26.7 million, with 140 gainers outnumbering 61 losers.

site_title: Abe sends donation to Tokyo's Yasukuni shrine on war anniversary
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe sent a ritual donation to Tokyo's Yasukuni shrine on the anniversary of Japan's defeat in World War II, avoiding a visit to the site amid controversy over its enshrinement of Class-A war criminals. The move is likely to provoke criticism from China and South Korea, which view the shrine as a symbol of Japan's militarism. The incident escalates tensions between Japan and China, raising the risk of an unintended military clash, particularly over disputed islands in the East China Sea.

site_title: National Australia Bank Q3 cash profit drops 3%
summary: National Australia Bank (NAB) reported a 3% drop in third-quarter unaudited cash profits to A$1.6 billion, primarily due to higher charges for bad and doubtful debts. The charge rose 21% to A$228 million, driven by a mining downturn. NAB's revenue was stable, but growth in lending was offset by lower net interest margins. The bank's shares have underperformed the market, and NAB faces pressure to boost growth and shareholder returns, with a new management shake-up announced last month.

site_title: WeChat coming soon at 35,000 feet as China eases phone rules
summary: China is set to relax regulations on mobile phone use on planes, paving the way for in-flight internet and app usage. A legislation amendment is underway, expected to be approved by the end of 2016 or early 2017. The changes follow US and European safety standards, allowing passengers to surf the internet, use WeChat, and shop online at 35,000 feet. The move is expected to make China's skies more comparable to developed markets.

site_title: Update: Japan's economy stalls in April-June, casts doubts on Abe's policies
summary: Japan's economy stagnated in the second quarter, expanding by 0.2% annually, below forecasts and a slowdown from a 2.0% increase in the previous quarter. Weak exports and capital expenditure contributed to the slowdown, with overseas demand shaving off 0.3 percentage points from GDP. The government's stimulus package and the Bank of Japan's expansion of stimulus efforts may not be enough to sustain growth, as deflation persists. Policymakers face challenges in ending two decades of deflation, with consumer spending and wage gains weak.

site_title: South Korea's President Park tells North to abandon nuclear weapons
summary: South Korean President Park Geun-Hye urged North Korea to abandon its nuclear weapons program, calling it a threat to the region's stability. She defended the deployment of the US anti-missile system, Thaad, despite domestic protests and criticism from Beijing. Park emphasized that true liberation for the peninsula can only be achieved by removing the fear of nuclear weapons and missiles. The North's nuclear test in January strengthened UN sanctions, but Pyongyang has continued to test ballistic missiles, leading to increased tensions. Park warned that Pyongyang's provocations would only deepen its isolation and economic problems.

site_title: Australia, NZ dollars muted on China concerns; data eyed
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars were subdued on Monday due to concerns over China's economic data and future investment flows. The Australian dollar remained unchanged at US$0.7643, while the New Zealand dollar fell 0.2% to US$0.7192. Analysts expect the Aussie to trade within a US$0.7545-US$0.7755 band this week, with the Reserve Bank of Australia's August meeting minutes on Tuesday providing further clues about monetary policy. Key events this week include wage data, jobs numbers, and a global dairy auction in New Zealand.

site_title: Gold losing appeal for investors stepping back from rally bet
summary: Investors are losing confidence in gold's rally, with hedge funds cutting their wagers on a bullion rally for the fourth time in five weeks. The metal's 30-day historical volatility has dropped to its lowest since November, and open interest is declining. Gold prices have fallen 2.5% since reaching a two-year high on July 6, and are down about 1% in August due to a strong US economy and rising interest rates. Experts predict gold may stabilize around $1,250-$1,300 and fail to break above $1,430.

site_title: Olympics: Third gold as Biles wins vault in Rio
summary: Simone Biles wins her third Olympic gold in Rio, taking the vault title with a combined score of 15.966. The 19-year-old Texan has already secured the all-around and team titles, with beam and floor finals to come. Maria Paseka of Russia took silver and Giulia Steingruber of Switzerland secured bronze. Dipa Karmakar finished fourth, while Hong Un Jong of North Korea fell short of a medal, finishing sixth.

site_title: Japan Q2 GDP expands annualised 0.2%
summary: Japan's economy expanded at an annualised 0.2% in Q2, marking a second consecutive quarter of growth, but at a slower rate due to weak exports and capital expenditure. The GDP growth was weaker than forecast, following a revised 2.0% growth in Q1. On a quarter-on-quarter basis, GDP showed flat growth in the April-June period, contrary to the 0.2% expected by economists.

site_title: Pokemon No: Can a place declare the game off-limits?
