Economists attribute the strong industrial output to uncertainty having little impact, with "very few" respondents reporting it as an issue. This contrasts with a July survey suggesting a decline in output due to the Brexit shock.

site_title: US dollar wobbles, kiwi steady despite rate cut expectations
summary: The US dollar held steady in Asian trade on Tuesday, supported by growing confidence in a potential US interest rate hike by December. The US dollar index edged up 0.1% to 96.474, while the euro edged down 0.1% to US$1.1077. Despite expectations of a 25-basis-point rate cut by the Reserve Bank of New Zealand, the kiwi dollar remained steady at US$0.7133, with 24 of 25 economists polled predicting a cut.

site_title: No end in sight as anti-IS campaign enters third year
summary: The US-led military campaign against the Islamic State (IS) group entered its third year on August 9, 2016, with no end in sight. Despite initial claims of a swift and narrow campaign, billions of dollars and 14,000 air strikes later, experts say the effort is unlikely to completely destroy the group. Nearly half of IS's territory in Iraq has been liberated, but the group has morphed into a traditional terrorist organization, with a growing global presence. The campaign has resulted in significant civilian casualties and is seen as creating more violent extremists.

images.alt_text: The US-led military effort against the Islamic State group started exactly two years ago, aimed at halting the jihadists as they swept across Iraq, leaving a trail of human butchery and destruction in their wake.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks flat; Cathay Financial up on earnings
summary: Taiwan's stocks were flat on Tuesday, with the main Taiex index up fractionally at 9,156.40 points. The financials subindex was up 0.2%, while the electronics subindex remained unchanged. The positive performance was driven by Cathay Financial's earnings report, which boosted investor confidence. Despite global market uncertainty, investors appear to be looking to earnings reports for direction.

site_title: Hong Kong shares end little changed, take breather after hitting 8-mth highs
summary: Hong Kong shares ended little changed on Tuesday, taking a breather after hitting eight-month highs. The Hang Seng index fell 0.1% to 22,465.61 points, while the China Enterprises Index gained 0.3%. Energy and property shares rose 0.6% and 0.5%, respectively, offsetting falls in IT and utility stocks. Developer China Evergrande Group rose 0.9% for the fourth straight day, extending gains after acquiring a stake in rival Vanke. The market was unfazed by China's consumer price inflation easing to a six-month low.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Stocks open slightly lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened slightly lower on Tuesday, following a weak lead from Wall Street. The Hang Seng Index dipped 0.18%, and China stocks also weakened as investors awaited July inflation data. The Shanghai Composite Index edged down 0.10%, while the Shenzhen Composite Index slipped 0.03%.

site_title: Australia business conditions resilient in July: National Australia Bank
summary: Australia's business conditions cooled slightly in July, with the National Australia Bank's index of business conditions dipping to +8, the highest since the global financial crisis but still above the long-run average. Sales remained strong, and employment index held above average. Despite Brexit and the Federal election, firms reported positive levels of business confidence. The Reserve Bank of Australia's decision to cut interest rates to a record low of 1.5% was seen as a necessary move to stabilize the economy. Further stimulus may be needed in 2017 to achieve inflation targets.

site_title: Alibaba offers to help global tech companies navigate China
summary: Alibaba Group Holding Ltd is extending an offer to global tech companies to navigate China's increasingly hostile market. The company's AliLaunch program aims to help clients comply with local regulations and sell their products in China, where foreign technology has faced significant challenges. Alibaba's cloud computing platform will be used to facilitate joint ventures and marketing. The company aims to sign up 50 partners over the next 12 months, with its cloud division being its fastest-growing business and a primary driver of growth.

site_title: Xi's here to stay: China leader tipped to outstay term
summary: China's President Xi Jinping is likely to extend his term beyond 10 years, analysts say, a move that would be unprecedented since Deng Xiaoping. Xi's leadership is set to be cemented at the 19th Party Congress next year, which will decide the composition of the Politburo Standing Committee. This could solidify Xi's position as the most powerful leader in decades, potentially setting a precedent for future leaders.

site_title: European shares flat, Altice jumps after results
summary: European shares remained steady in early trading on Tuesday, with Altice shares surging over 10% after reporting a 2.7% increase in core operating profit. Weaker commodities-related stocks, including those in the STOXX Europe 600 Basic Resources index, declined 0.8% due to lower crude oil and industrial metal prices. Pandora fell 5.3% after its second-quarter profits came in below market consensus, while the broader STOXX 600 index was little changed.

site_title: More women win power but still few and far between
summary: Women are increasingly holding positions of influence worldwide, with 64 experienced and ambitious women in key roles, including US presidential nominee Hillary Clinton, British Prime Minister Theresa May, and Chancellor Angela Merkel. However, women remain underrepresented, with only about 10% of UN member states led by women. Regional variations exist, with countries like Finland and Norway having more female leaders. Despite progress, cultural and societal barriers persist, and women face different standards for leadership than men.

site_title: Japan summons Chinese envoy amid ship 'incursions'
summary: Japan summoned China's ambassador Cheng Yonghua for a second time, following the country's ships being spotted near disputed East China Sea islands for a fifth straight day. Foreign Minister Fumio Kishida stated that Japan cannot accept unilateral actions raising tensions, amid a long-running dispute over the Senkaku/Diaoyu islands. The incident strains bilateral relations, which had relaxed over the past two years through dialogue. Japan wants "high-level" talks with China to address the issue.

images.alt_text: Foreign minister Fumio Kishida called in Cheng Yonghua, Beijing's envoy to Tokyo, the foreign ministry said - the second such summons since Friday.

site_title: New iPhone may buoy Taiwan exports after first gain in 17 months
summary: Taiwan's exports rose 1.2% in July, the first gain in nearly a year-and-a-half, driven by a jump in orders for semiconductors ahead of the release of new iPhones. Electronic goods shipped overseas increased 5.7% and account for nearly two-thirds of the country's GDP. The positive trend may boost economic growth, with economists predicting exports could grow as much as 5% in the third quarter. The new iPhone models, expected to be released next month, are expected to boost shipments and further support Taiwan's trade-dependent economy.

site_title: Oracle says Micros credit card readers hacked
summary: Oracle confirmed that hackers infected software in Micros credit card scanners used globally, particularly in hotels and restaurants. The malicious code was detected and addressed, but the extent and severity of the attack remain unknown. Oracle's internal systems and cloud services were not breached, and payment card data was encrypted. The company is requiring Micros customers to change their passwords. The attack is attributed to a Russian organized crime group with a history of hacking banks and shops.

site_title: MH370 plunged into ocean at high speed: report
summary: MH370, a Malaysia Airlines Boeing 777, crashed into the southern Indian Ocean at a high speed of up to 20,000 feet a minute, according to a report. The jet, carrying 239 people, disappeared on March 8, 2014, on a flight from Kuala Lumpur to Beijing. Extensive testing and data analysis by Boeing and the Australian Defence Department suggest the plane dived into the ocean after running out of fuel, supporting the "most likely" scenario that no one was at the controls. The search area remains the 120,000 square kilometre zone being searched.

site_title: Thai junta chief Prayut reiterates election in 2017
summary: Thai Prime Minister Prayut Chan-o-cha reiterated that a general election will be held in 2017, following a referendum that saw 61% of voters support a military-backed constitution. The move aims to restore democratic rule, which Prayut's military government has been working towards since a 2014 coup. The US State Department urged Thai authorities to hold an elected government as soon as possible. Analysts believe the "yes" vote was driven by a desire for greater stability, with the opposition planning to scrap the military charter if a party they support wins the 2017 election.

site_title: Gold holds declines as expectations firm on 2016 US rate hike
summary: Gold prices fell to the lowest in a week, trading at $1,335.80 an ounce, as expectations of a 2016 US rate hike strengthened. The US Federal Reserve's jobs data showed a 255,000 increase in payrolls, boosting the probability of a rate hike to 47% in December. Rising borrowing costs hurt the appeal of gold, which doesn't offer yields or dividends. Silver and platinum were little changed, while palladium fell. The decline was attributed to the US economy's strength, which is seen as supporting the Fed's case for a rate hike.

site_title: Pokemon Go tough act to follow, says big game studios
summary: Top video game companies struggle to replicate the success of Pokémon Go, citing its unique augmented reality gameplay and brand recognition. Executives from companies like Sony, Rovio, and Warner Bros express doubts about creating a rival app, with some stating that the challenge is not worth it. Analysts predict Pokémon Go will earn $200-500 million in revenue in one year, making it a top-grossing mobile game. The game's social features, mapping technology, and brand power, led by the Pokémon franchise, are seen as difficult to match, making it a tough act to follow.

site_title: Seoul: Won wobbles on US dollar strength; stocks edge up to 9-month high
summary: The South Korean won wobbled slightly early Tuesday, trading at 1,108.7, after a Standard and Poor's credit rating upgrade on Monday. Despite dollar strength, the won rose to its strongest level since June 25, 2015, due to foreign investors buying local stocks. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) edged up 0.2% to a 9-month high, with offshore investors buying 77.1 billion won worth of Kospi shares.

site_title: Apple buys US machine learning startup Turi
summary: Apple has acquired US machine learning startup Turi for an estimated $200 million, expanding its artificial intelligence efforts to compete with Amazon, Google, and Microsoft. Turi specializes in enabling developers to imbue software applications with AI, allowing them to learn like humans. This move is part of Apple's growing focus on AI, particularly with its Siri virtual assistant, which aims to better understand user intent and voice commands. The acquisition is seen as a strategic move to improve Siri's capabilities and stay ahead in the AI-powered services market.

site_title: VW fined by Italy watchdog over 'dieselgate'
summary: Volkswagen has been fined 5 million euros (S$7.41 million) by Italy's competition authority for "improper business practices" related to the "dieselgate" scandal. The German carmaker installed emissions-cheating software in 11 million diesel engines worldwide since 2009, tricking pollution tests. The fine is for marketing vehicles in Italy since 2009. The scandal broke last year, and Volkswagen has faced significant repercussions globally.

site_title: New terminal for Indonesian capital's crowded airport
summary: Indonesia's Soekarno-Hatta International Airport has opened a new terminal, capable of handling 25 million passengers a year. The US$380 million facility, set to be operational by March 2017, aims to alleviate overcrowding at the airport, which currently handles 60 million passengers annually. The terminal, built to accommodate domestic Garuda flights, will eventually connect to central Jakarta via a rail link, addressing a major transportation challenge. The opening comes as Indonesia's aviation sector faces safety concerns and a string of deadly crashes in recent years.

site_title: China July inflation cools to 1.8% y-o-y, matching forecasts
summary: China's consumer inflation eased to 1.8% year-on-year in July, matching market expectations. Producer prices fell 1.7% for the month, compared to a 2.6% drop in the previous month. This marks a slight improvement in the country's inflation outlook, alleviating concerns for policymakers. The data also suggests that China's economy may be slowing down, as it has in the past when inflation cooled.

site_title: Taliban, IS claim Pakistan hospital suicide bombing
summary: At least 70 people died and over 100 were injured in a suicide bombing at a Pakistani hospital in Quetta, the capital of Balochistan province. The attack, claimed by both the Taliban and Islamic State group, targeted a crowd of mourners gathered to pay respects to a senior local lawyer who was assassinated earlier in the day. The bombing was described as powerful, with victims' bodies scattered everywhere and pools of blood. Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif called for security forces to "decimate" terrorists, while international leaders condemned the attack as "appalling" and "abominable".

site_title: Glorious Property shares halted pending privatisation notice
summary: Glorious Property Holdings Ltd shares were halted in Hong Kong pending a privatisation bid by founder Zhang Zhi Rong, who holds 63.89% of the shares. The company reported a net loss of 3.88 billion yuan in 2015 and is struggling with loan repayments. This is not the first attempt by Zhang to go private, having previously offered HK$4.57 billion in 2013. The shares fell 13% this year, leaving the company with a market capitalization of just over HK$6 billion. An announcement is expected to provide details on the privatisation bid.

site_title: BP seeks buyers for China petrochemicals JV stake in up to US$3b deal: sources
summary: BP is seeking buyers for its 50% stake in Secco, a Chinese petrochemicals refinery, in a deal worth US$2-3 billion. This would be BP's first significant exit from a business in China. Secco, located near Shanghai, is China's largest petrochemicals refinery, built at a cost of US$2.7 billion in 2001. The sale is part of BP's drive to cash out of businesses where it lacks control.

site_title: ANZ nine-month profit drops, focus on high returns
summary: ANZ's nine-month cash profit dropped 3% to A$5.2 billion due to slowing revenues and higher bad debts. The bank is focusing on high-returning businesses and shrinking its balance sheet, with a stronger-than-expected Tier-I capital ratio of 9.7%. ANZ is shifting its focus from international growth to domestic markets, with CEO Shayne Elliott aiming to boost productivity and cut costs.

site_title: Singapore puts off decision on whether to buy Lockheed's F-35
summary: Singapore has delayed its decision on purchasing Lockheed's F-35 jets, with a potential purchase of 12 aircraft now expected to be finalized by 2022. The decision was made after the country's permanent secretary of defense development informed the US Pentagon of the delay in mid-June. The US continues to encourage Singapore to buy the fighter, with President Barack Obama expressing welcome to the country's interest in the aircraft.

site_title: Asia: Stocks extend gains with crude near US$43 as copper retreats
summary: Asian stocks rose for a fourth day, extending gains at a one-year high, as US crude oil traded near $43 a barrel and copper declined ahead of Chinese price data. Mining and consumer stocks drove gains, with Japanese equities up following a yen pullback. The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC) said informal talks would discuss market stabilization, boosting oil prices. Commodities also gained from Friday's US jobs data, bolstering confidence in the global economy.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open slightly higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened slightly higher on Tuesday, rising 1.110 points to 1674.490. Gainers outnumbered losers 110 to 49, with a volume of 49.8 million lots worth RM19.26 million.

site_title: Update: Delta cancels hundreds of flights after computer meltdown
summary: Delta Airlines cancelled hundreds of flights and delayed many more due to a computer meltdown, affecting tens of thousands of passengers worldwide. The US carrier blamed a power outage in Atlanta, Georgia, on the issue, which began at 2:30am. Despite resuming flights on a limited basis, delays and cancellations continued. As of 1700 GMT, Delta had cancelled 427 flights, with 6,000 scheduled flights operating at that time. The airline offered refunds and compensation to affected passengers, and teams worked "around the clock" to bring systems back online.

site_title: Amazon plans big push for voice control service
summary: Amazon plans to expand its voice control service, Alexa, beyond its Echo smart speaker. The company aims to integrate Alexa into various devices, including those made by third-party manufacturers, to create a comprehensive voice-controlled home ecosystem. This move follows the success of Echo, which has become a popular way to control smart home devices with voice commands. Amazon's goal is to make Alexa a standard feature in homes and beyond, offering users a seamless and convenient way to interact with their surroundings.

site_title: Anbang denies report it's considering a bid for InterContinental
summary: ANBANG Insurance Group Co has denied reports that it's considering a bid for InterContinental Hotels Group Plc, citing no plans to make a bid. The UK-based hotel company has been a subject of takeover speculation amid industry consolidation. Anbang previously withdrew its $14 billion takeover offer for Starwood Hotels & Resorts Worldwide Inc. InterContinental has a market value of £6.27 billion. Marriott International Inc expects to complete the Starwood acquisition once Chinese regulators approve the transaction.

site_title: Output at Norway oil firms exceeds forecasts despite price slump
summary: Norway's oil output has exceeded forecasts for the past two years, despite a slump in crude prices. According to Petoro AS, the state-owned oil company, companies are boosting efficiency and pumping at full capacity as revenue declines. This trend is expected to continue, driven by the need to maintain production levels. The silver lining for Norway is that the country has maintained its oil output despite the global price slump, likely due to the efforts of oil companies to optimize their operations.

site_title: Junk bond dealmaking rebounds as Asian yields hit 3-year low
summary: Asia's high-yield bond market rebounded last week after a rally in credit spreads led to a flurry of new issues. Six Asian companies with sub-investment grade credit ratings sold US dollar bonds in two days, adding to hopes of a recovery after a dismal first half for new issues. This rebound follows a 3-year low in Asian yields, sparking optimism for a recovery in the market.

site_title: US urges Thailand to restore civilian rule after pro-junta vote
summary: The US has expressed concern over Thailand's approval of a new military-backed constitution, urging the country to return to civilian rule. The constitution's drafting process was deemed non-inclusive, and open debate was restricted. The US State Department called for the government to lift restrictions on civil liberties and organize new legislative elections. This move follows the country's two-year rule by the junta, which ousted the elected government. The US maintains a military alliance with Thailand but has strengthened ties with other Southeast Asian countries.

images.alt_text: The United States expressed concern Monday after Thailand approved a new military-backed constitution in a victory for the country's ruling generals.

site_title: Facebook denies reluctance in giving data to German investigators
summary: Facebook has denied claims it was reluctant to cooperate with German investigators on criminal investigations, stating many requests were incorrectly formulated. The company provided "round-the-clock assistance" following a spate of violent attacks in Germany. Facebook rejected 42% of requests in Germany, citing overly broad or vague requests, and works with law enforcement officials to raise awareness of correct procedures. The German Interior Ministry is examining whether new laws are needed to improve cooperation between social media companies and security agencies in the fight against terrorism.

site_title: 50 Republican national security officials reject Trump
summary: Fifty Republican national security officials, including former homeland security chiefs and intelligence directors, rejected Donald Trump as their party's White House nominee, calling him "the most reckless president in American history" if elected. They warned he would put the country's national security and well-being at risk. The group's statement was published in The New York Times, highlighting their strong opposition to Trump's candidacy.

site_title: Europe: Stocks edge up, lifted by financials
summary: European stock markets rose on Monday, driven by gains in major banks and financial stocks. The Stoxx 600 index edged up 0.04%, while Germany's DAX, Britain's FTSE, and France's CAC all rose 0.1-0.6%. The Stoxx Europe 600 Bank index advanced 1.4%, boosted by a 3.6% rise at Barclays after it was upgraded to "outperform" from "neutral".

site_title: Teenage girl charged with planning attack in France
summary: A 16-year-old French girl has been remanded in custody on charges of planning a jihadist attack, with authorities finding no explosives or firearms at her home. The teenager, who was highly radicalized, administered a Telegram group promoting Islamic State propaganda and expressed her intention to take action. This comes amid a heightened security state in France following recent terror attacks, including the July 26 church massacre and the July 14 Nice truck attack. The investigation is ongoing, with no identified target at this stage.

site_title: Taiwan exports end 17-month losing streak with surprise growth
summary: Taiwan's exports ended a 17-month losing streak with a 1.2% growth in July 2015, surpassing analysts' expectations. The boost was attributed to strong demand for electronic parts, particularly ahead of Apple's new iPhone launch. This marks a surprise turn in the country's export performance, which had been declining since November 2014.

site_title: Japan military on alert to destroy any N Korea missile: report
summary: Japan's newly appointed Defence Minister Tomomi Inada ordered the nation's military to be ready to destroy any North Korean missile that threatens the country, without indicating any specific threat. This comes amid heightened tensions following North Korea's recent missile launch off Japan's coast. Inada is expected to renew the readiness order every three months. The order is a response to North Korea's growing missile capabilities, which have raised concerns among Japanese officials.

site_title: Barclays, US states in US$100m Libor fraud settlement
summary: Barclays Bank PLC has agreed to a US$100 million settlement with 44 US states and the District of Columbia over interest rate manipulation. The settlement accuses Barclays of manipulating benchmark interest rates, including the London Interbank Offered Rate, to hide financial problems and benefit traders. New York Attorney General Eric Schneiderman said the misconduct led to the defrauding of government entities and not-for-profits, depriving them of funds that could have benefited the people of New York. The settlement marks a resolution to the Libor fraud allegations against the bank.

site_title: US: Wall Street takes tiny step back from record highs
summary: US stocks fell on Monday, receding from record highs, as a drop in healthcare stocks offset gains from higher oil prices and a strong jobs report. The S&P 500 dropped 0.09% to close at 2,180.89, while the Dow Jones industrial average edged down 0.08%. The healthcare index fell 0.9%, with Bristol-Myers, Merck, and Allergan among the losers. Analysts expect third-quarter earnings to fall 0.2% for the sixth straight quarter.

site_title: China-Japan tensions rise over disputed East China Sea isles
summary: China has increased pressure on Japan over disputed East China Sea islands, with hundreds of fishing boats and 14 coastguard vessels spotted in the area. Japan responded with formal complaints to China's ambassador, while China accused Japan of escalating tensions. The move comes ahead of the September Group of 20 summit and may raise the risk of an unintended military clash. The dispute over the islands, known as Diaoyu in China and Senkaku in Japan, has escalated in recent years, with both countries accusing each other of encroaching on territorial waters.

site_title: Conflicts of interest appear at think-tanks
summary: Conflicts of interest appear at prominent think-tanks, including the Brookings Institution. The organization accepted donations from corporate donors, such as Lennar Corp, in exchange for promoting their agendas. In a 2010 letter, Brookings Vice-President Bruce Katz wrote that a US$8 billion plan to revitalize a San Francisco area could be mutually beneficial, with Lennar donating US$400,000 to Brookings. This raises concerns about the influence of corporate interests on think-tanks and their ability to provide unbiased research.

site_title: The way to another country's heart . . .
summary: The US is conducting culinary diplomacy, a form of Track 3 diplomacy, using food to create cultural understanding and resolve conflicts. The Diplomatic Culinary Partnership (DCP) was launched by former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton in 2012, and current Secretary of State John Kerry continues the initiative. Chefs and diplomats participate in events and exchange programs to promote American cuisine and values abroad. This approach has proven effective in boosting tourism, trade, and cultural exchange, and has even helped resolve conflicts, such as racial tensions in the US. Countries like Thailand, Japan, and Peru have also adopted culinary diplomacy, using food to promote their cultures and values.

site_title: Denmark pursues EU concessions to escape bill for migrant worker welfare
summary: Denmark's Prime Minister Lars Loekke Rasmussen is pushing for EU concessions to avoid paying welfare bills for migrant worker EU citizens. This move comes amid the UK's Brexit chaos. Denmark, like the UK, had previously agreed to foot the bill under the EU's freedom of movement principle. However, with the UK's departure, Denmark is seeking to escape this obligation. The outcome of these negotiations is uncertain, but Denmark's efforts to secure an exemption are seen as a response to the UK's similar situation.

site_title: Three fresh challenges to test Singapore's unity: PM Lee
summary: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong warned Singaporeans of three major challenges that will test the country's unity: economic uncertainty, the rise of extremist terrorism, and societal changes that put strains on the political system. The economy is at a turning point due to globalization and technological change, while terrorism poses a threat to the nation's harmony. Lee called on Singaporeans to band together to overcome these challenges, citing the need for constructive politics and effective government to ensure a brighter future.

site_title: Corporate Indonesia gears up for revival in consumer demand
summary: Indonesian firms are investing and launching new products as consumer demand improves due to easier access to credit and economic growth. A consumer confidence index reached its highest level since March 2015, with companies such as PT Astra International Tbk and PT Mayora Indah Tbk raising revenue targets. The economy grew 5.18% in the second quarter, its fastest pace in 2.5 years, and companies expect more favorable business conditions in the next 12 months.

site_title: 'Dozens of members' in group behind rocket terror plot
summary: Indonesian authorities arrested six suspected Islamist radicals on Batam island, suspecting they were planning to attack Singapore. The group, believed to have "dozens of members," has been active for two years and is taking orders from an Indonesian who has joined the Islamic State (IS) in Syria. The arrests come amid growing concerns about the spread of Islamist ideology in Indonesia, the world's largest Muslim-majority nation.

site_title: Oil prices continue rise on world markets
summary: Oil prices continued to rise on Monday, with benchmark crude gaining over $1 per barrel in both New York and London. A barrel of West Texas Intermediate rose to $43.02 and a barrel of North Sea Brent rose to $45.39. Analysts attribute the rise to rumors that the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries may freeze output levels, as well as expectations of a drop in North American production and an increase in global fuel demand. The market is experiencing a "covering rally," with buyers jumping in, but some analysts caution that the rally may not last.

images.alt_text: Oil prices continued to rise on Monday, with benchmark crude moving up more than a dollar per barrel in both New York and London.

site_title: China Evergrande ups stake in Langfang
summary: China Evergrande Group raised its stake in Langfang Development Co Ltd to 15% through a 5% purchase for 399 million yuan (S$80.7 million), becoming the company's largest shareholder. This move follows Evergrande's acquisition of 4.68% of China Vanke Co Ltd for US$1.37 billion in April. Langfang shares jumped 10% after the announcement, as Evergrande began amassing shares in the company.

site_title: Germany June factory output points to weak quarterly growth
summary: Germany's industrial production rebounded 0.8% in June, but the growth won't redeem a sluggish second quarter. The production increase comes after a 0.9% decline in May, with manufacturing growth of 1.5% and construction shrinkage of 0.5%. The economy ministry predicts a one-percent decline in production over the second quarter, with little prospect of a resurgent German economy over the second half of the year. Brexit-related uncertainty may impact German industrial activity, but the economy ministry expects a moderate upwards trend in new industrial orders.

site_title: Japanese emperor's possible abdication raises issues
summary: Japan's 82-year-old Emperor Akihito hinted at possible abdication in a video speech, citing his advanced age and concerns about his ability to perform public duties. The move would have significant constitutional implications, requiring changes to Japan's Imperial Household Law or the enactment of a special law. This would be the first time the Chrysanthemum Throne would be relinquished by the monarch. Akihito's son, Naruhito, would likely succeed him.

site_title: Emerging markets aren't really in charge of their own rates anymore: study
summary: A new Bank for International Settlements (BIS) paper reveals that emerging markets' domestic monetary policy has become largely ineffective due to financial globalization. Local long-term interest rates are heavily influenced by the US Federal Reserve and other advanced economies. The study found that a 100 basis point rise in US 10-year yields is associated with a 70-80 basis point rise in emerging market yields, indicating a striking correlation between global and local rates. This renders emerging market central banks' ability to chart their own monetary course at the long-end limited, despite their control over short-term rates.

site_title: Ex-Philippine leader to 'rekindle ties with China'
summary: Former Philippine President Fidel Ramos departed for Hong Kong on a five-day trip to rekindle ties with China, following a maritime dispute in the South China Sea. The trip comes after an arbitration court ruled that China had no historic title over the waterway and had breached the Philippines' sovereign rights. Ramos, 88, was appointed special envoy to China by President Rodrigo Duterte to meet "old friends" and possibly play golf, paving the way for future diplomatic talks. Officials from both countries will hold formal talks, and China's state news agency described the trip as a "concrete step" towards settling disputes.

site_title: Conflict pushed him to Singapore
summary: Malaysian businessman Jacky Tan, CEO of Singapore-based lubricant manufacturer United Global, credits conflict in Indonesia in 1998 for his move to Singapore, where he established the company. Initially, he "lay low" with his family until the riots dispersed, then launched the firm with a friend's help. United Global has since grown to post a profit of $6.2 million on revenue of $99.9 million, with plans to expand its business. Tan worked to improve the company's risk management framework and processes after realizing they weren't suitable for a publicly listed firm.

site_title: UK bosses win 10% pay rises as workers face restraint: study
summary: UK bosses received 10% pay rises in 2015, with the average FTSE 100 CEO's pay package reaching £5.48 million, 140 times more than their employees. The top 10 highest-paid CEOs were all men, with Martin Sorrell's package increasing 64% to £70 million. The High Pay Centre notes the widening wages gap and says boards continue to award large pay packages despite occasional shareholder pressure.

site_title: ValueMax Group, Maxi-Cash report stronger bottom lines
summary: ValueMax Group and Maxi-Cash, two Singaporean pawnbroking chains, reported stronger bottom lines despite slow growth. ValueMax Group's Q2 net profit surged 46% to S$3.95 million, driven by lower costs, while Maxi-Cash's net profit rose to S$2.3 million, up from S$721,000 a year ago. Revenue dropped 10% for ValueMax Group, but revenue for Maxi-Cash increased 30%. Both companies expect challenging operating environments due to competition and volatile gold prices.

site_title: Short-seller Glaucus Research targeting new stocks in HK
summary: Hong Kong-based short-seller Glaucus Research Group is targeting new stocks in the market, with director Soren Aandahl stating the firm may publish two more reports this year. The group's July 28 report declared Tech Pro Technology Development Ltd's stock worthless, causing its shares to plummet 86% in two days. Tech Pro has denied accusations and plans to sell 2.6 billion new shares. Research firms have published reports targeting over a dozen Hong Kong-listed companies since 2011, with more potentially coming this year targeting companies that listed under the old regime for initial public offerings.

site_title: Vancouver tax set to scuttle over 400 deals: brokers
summary: Vancouver's 15% tax on foreign buyers aims to cool the scorching housing market. The measure is expected to derail over 400 deals worth approximately C$404 million. The Real Estate Board of Greater Vancouver estimates this is based on an average purchase price of C$946,945 by foreign buyers. The tax move may prompt legal challenges, as it could impact multiple deals and potentially harm the market.

site_title: Sim Lian founder leads offer to take developer private
summary: A consortium led by Sim Lian Group's founder Kuik Ah Han is seeking to take the property developer private with a voluntary conditional cash offer of S$1.08 per share for all outstanding shares not already owned. The offer, which represents a 14.9% premium over the last traded price, has secured irrevocable undertakings from key shareholders. The offer is conditional on receiving acceptances or acquiring a stake of 90% or more, and Coronation 3G intends for SLG to continue with its existing activities without major changes.

site_title: Another good run ahead; Or a path littered with obstacles?
summary: Singapore's 51-year-old nation is facing significant challenges as it looks to the next half-century. Business leaders polled in a survey express confidence that the current generation can surpass the previous one in some aspects, but many are pessimistic about rapid economic growth. Key concerns include a lack of agility, complacency among the rich, and a decline in resilience among younger generations. The respondents emphasize the need for Singapore to adapt and evolve, embracing new ideas, innovation, and entrepreneurship to stay relevant in the global landscape.

site_title: London rail workers begin 5-day strike, causing travel chaos
summary: London rail workers began a 5-day strike, affecting hundreds of thousands of commuters, over the role of conductors in opening and closing train doors. The RMT union opposes driver-only operated trains, citing safety concerns, while Govia Thameslink Railway (GTR) claims it would reduce cancellations. The strike, the longest British rail walkout in almost 50 years, will see 60% of services operate, with no trains on some routes. The dispute began after GTR axed 341 trains in July to provide a more regular service.

site_title: 'Inevitable cascade' of O&G defaults seen
summary: Oil-related firms in Singapore face a growing risk of defaults due to sustained weakness in crude prices, with $1.4 billion of bonds maturing through 2018. Investment banks warn of an "inevitable cascade" of defaults, citing high debt levels and weak cash flows among smaller, independent oil and gas companies. Companies such as Swiber Holdings and Perisai Petroleum Teknologi Bhd are struggling to repay debts, with some bonds trading at low levels indicating a high probability of restructuring.

site_title: Jack Ma opening mobile wallet to China travellers in Europe
summary: Alibaba's Alipay is signing deals with European retailers to enhance its mobile wallet app for Chinese tourists and expats in France, UK, Germany, and Italy. The app will allow users to set aside items at favorite stores or hail rides in cities like Rome. Alipay will not offer its services to non-Chinese consumers. The move aims to increase its presence in Europe as Chinese travelers spend billions of dollars abroad.

images.alt_text: MR MA: Alipay has no plans to offer its services to consumers who aren't from China.

site_title: S'pore to get Deliveroo's 'remote kitchen' model
summary: Deliveroo, a London-based food delivery startup, will launch its "remote kitchen" model, named RooBox, in Singapore by September. RooBox allows restaurants to set up "delivery-only" kitchens in new locations, expanding options for consumers and enabling restaurants to access areas without a presence. Five restaurants have signed up, and Deliveroo has raised US$275 million in funding to consolidate its market leader position, expand in the Asia-Pacific, and innovate to improve the customer experience.

site_title: SMRT's rail losses deepen for Q1
summary: SMRT Corporation's Q1 results show a 22.9% net profit decline. The company is seeking a new rail financing framework and exploring a takeover bid by Temasek Holdings. Under the proposed framework, SMRT Trains will operate under an asset-light model, focusing on providing quality service and maintaining trains for smooth operation.

site_title: Better margins, loan growth, non-interest income cushion DBS against Swiber fallout
summary: DBS Group Holdings posted a higher-than-expected net profit of S$1.05 billion in its second quarter results, despite taking a S$150 million hit from oil services firm Swiber's collapse. The bank's loan growth expanded 4% and non-interest income rose 8%, driven by corporate loans and market share gains in Singapore housing loans. However, DBS has flagged S$900 million as weakness in the oil and gas sector and expects contagion from Swiber. The bank's cost-income ratio improved to 44%, and it expects full-year loan growth in mid-single digits.

site_title: Tapping grants to improve capabilities
summary: Wong Fong Industries, a Singaporean engineering firm, has reportedly received tapping grants to enhance its capabilities. The grants, provided by Spring Singapore, have supported the company's Research and Development efforts. Eric Lew, the company's CEO, initially aimed to bring his family business to greater heights as a young accountant but now reflects on his past endeavors with a sense of humor. Lew's experience serves as an example of the challenges faced by small and medium-sized enterprises in Singapore.

site_title: Deutsche Asset Management buying Barcelona shopping mall
summary: Deutsche Asset Management has acquired the Diagonal Mar shopping mall in Barcelona for 493 million euros, expanding its Iberian real estate portfolio to 17 assets valued at 1.3 billion euros. The 90,000 square meter mall, featuring shops like Primark and Hennes & Mauritz, attracts 17 million visitors annually. The deal marks Deutsche's recent acquisitions in Barcelona, Madrid, and Portugal.

site_title: Obama's star-studded galas at White House a classified matter
summary: President Barack Obama celebrated his 55th birthday in style at the White House with a star-studded party, attended by celebrities, sports stars, and business executives. The event, which included performances by Stevie Wonder and a possible appearance by Paul McCartney, was kept secret until the last minute, with guests asked not to tweet pictures or reveal details. The party was paid for with the Obama family's personal funds, marking a departure from previous years when the White House had kept costs private.

site_title: Next lap: to be more open, diverse, inclusive
summary: Singapore business leaders urge the government to evolve into an open, diverse, and inclusive society as the country advances socially. A survey of 51 CEOs found that 52% consider diversity essential for economic growth, while 38.5% see it as a mark of an enlightened global city. However, some respondents expressed concerns that diversity will alter Singapore's essence. The poll comes as Singapore turns 51, and business leaders highlight the need for informed, engaged, and consulted citizens.

site_title: Wall St high, DBS results help lift STI by 1.5%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 42.61 points or 1.5% to 2,870.78 on Monday, boosted by Wall Street's new all-time high and DBS's better-than-expected second-quarter profit. DBS's net profit dropped 6% to S$1.06 billion due to a one-off provision related to Swiber Holdings' bankruptcy. Despite this, DBS finished S$0.21 higher, and shares of Singtel, the Jardine group, and several O&M stocks also rose. The market's advance-decline score was mixed, indicating a volatile trading session.

site_title: UK fraud office starts Airbus criminal bribery probe
summary: The UK Serious Fraud Office has launched a criminal investigation into Airbus for alleged fraud, bribery, and corruption related to third-party consultants in its civil aviation business. Airbus has cooperated with the investigation and flagged "misstatements and omissions" in export financing applications. The investigation follows similar scrutiny of cross-border intermediaries, such as Monaco-based Unaoil SAM, and comes amid uncertainty in the global market due to suspended financing. Airbus is undertaking a review of its consultants and third parties used to support sales.

site_title: Pyongyang Cafe: Kim Jong Un's modest ally in Spain
summary: North Korea has a modest ally in Spain with the Pyongyang Cafe, a small bar founded by Alejandro Cao de Benos, who is also the president of the Korean Friendship Association. Located in Tarragona, the bar serves traditional North Korean tea and Asian beers, and features socialist propaganda posters and a bookshelf of Kim dynasty works. The cafe is the only Western establishment of its kind, and aims to break down myths and misconceptions about North Korea. Despite criticism from human rights groups, Cao de Benos defends the country, citing widespread access to food, housing, and work as human rights.

site_title: Firms are big customers for Apple's iPads
summary: Apple's corporate sales have become a significant bright spot for the company, with nearly half of all iPads sold to businesses and governments. Despite struggling with declining sales of iPhones and Macs, Apple's enterprise market has grown 40% year-over-year, driven by demand for its devices' security features, intuitive interfaces, and tight hardware and software integration. Companies like IBM and British Airways have developed custom apps for Apple's iOS, leveraging its devices to streamline business processes and improve customer experience.

site_title: Staying astute and agile key to sustaining Singapore's economy
summary: Singapore's economy remains resilient despite global trade and investment slowdowns, thanks to its strategic location and liberal trade policies. The country's role as a financial hub and its efforts to become a "Smart Nation" are also driving growth. Foreign direct investment into ASEAN reached $136 billion in 2014, and the region's exports are forecast to hit $2.8 trillion by 2025. Singapore's involvement in trade agreements, such as the Trans-Pacific Partnership, and its business-friendly reputation make it an attractive location for global companies. The country's adaptability and efforts to control its own destiny are key to sustaining its economy.

site_title: Elected Thai govt to take power earliest by end-2017: official
summary: Thailand's government, backed by the military, will take power by December 2017 after a referendum on a military-backed constitution saw 61% of voters in favor. Analysts attribute the "yes" vote to a desire for greater stability, following over a decade of turmoil and two military takeovers. An election is expected to take place in September or October 2017, with a new government to follow by the end of the year.

site_title: US swimmer shatters world record at Olympics
summary: US swimmer Katie Ledecky shattered the world record in the 400m freestyle event at the Olympics, finishing with a time of 3 minutes 56.46 seconds. This marks her sixth fastest time ever in the event and cements her position as one of only two women to break the four-minute barrier. Ledecky's gold medal swim came with a 4.77-second lead over silver medalist Jazz Carlin of Great Britain.

site_title: Eu Yan Sang offeror faces stumbling block in compulsory acquisition
summary: A consortium making a bid to take Eu Yan Sang International private faces a stumbling block due to substantial shareholders holding a combined stake of over 91% in the company. Hillhouse Capital Management Ltd and TFW Fund, along with Righteous Crane Holding Pte Ltd, hold the majority stake. This exceeds the required 10% public float, making it impossible for the consortium to proceed with compulsory acquisition of shares it doesn't already own. The offeror has reiterated its intention to take the company private, with the offer closing on August 15.

site_title: Former civil service head to receive Distinguished Service Order award
summary: The former head of Singapore's civil service, Peter Ho, will receive the nation's highest honour, the Distinguished Service Order, for his distinguished conduct in service. A total of 3,959 recipients will receive National Day honours this year, including prominent figures such as Chew Gek Khim and Tan Wee Kiat. The awards are part of Singapore's National Day celebrations, recognizing outstanding contributions to the country.

site_title: Makers of superbikes woo Chinese women
summary: Ducati Motor Holding SpA and Harley-Davidson Inc are targeting Chinese women and novice riders with lighter, sleeker motorcycles in response to the country's declining motorcycle market. Ducati's sales in China have almost doubled, with a 74% surge for BMW AG, as the company introduces models such as the Scrambler Sixty2 and Multistrada 1200 S. The government's exemption of foreign motorcycle makers from ownership limits is also expected to boost demand, with Ducati poised to become the second-largest motorcycle brand in China by 2019.

site_title: Consortium led by Sim Lian chairman launches cash offer for Sim Lian Group
summary: A consortium led by Sim Lian Group founder Kuik Ah Han has launched a voluntary conditional cash offer to privatize and delist the property developer. Coronation 3G is offering S$1.08 per share, a 14.9% premium over the last traded price, to acquire 80.36% of SLG's shares. The offer is conditional on receiving acceptances or acquiring shares representing 90% of the total number of issued shares. This move presents a cash exit opportunity for SLG shareholders, given the illiquidity of the shares since listing in 2000.

site_title: Oversupply beats Brexit as biggest London office risk: UBS
summary: UBS predicts that the oversupply of office space in London, with 51 new buildings under construction, poses a bigger threat to rents and values than Brexit. The additional space will hit the market in 2017 and 2018, potentially leading to a 20% decline in values. According to UBS, around 25,000 jobs may be relocated from London within two years due to passporting rights concerns, although this is lower than a previous estimate of 100,000 jobs.

site_title: Is there value in having so many indices to track residential market?
summary: A study by the Singapore Institute of Surveyors and Valuers (SISV) compared indices tracking Singapore's residential market, including the Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) and SRX Property. The analysis found conflicting signs in the indices, with SRX Property's index showing similar long-term trends to URA's or HDB's. However, the study also highlighted limitations, such as differences in data collection and index computation methods. Despite this, the study concludes that having multiple indices may not necessarily provide clearer insights for consumers, and that investors should instead focus on micro-level data analysis.

site_title: Wal-Mart to buy US online retailer Jet.com for US$3.3b
summary: Wal-Mart is acquiring US online retailer Jet.com for $3.3 billion, bolstering its e-commerce operations in response to Amazon and other competitors. The deal includes $3 billion in cash and $300 million in Wal-Mart shares for Jet.com shareholders. The move aims to help Wal-Mart keep up with the shift to online shopping.

site_title: Gaylin Holdings expect to record loss for Q1 FY17
summary: Gaylin Holdings expects to record a net loss for Q1 FY2017, with further details to be disclosed on August 14. CFO Goh Guat Bee resigned on August 8 to pursue new opportunities, and Hing Lai Kuen, 33, has been appointed as financial controller, replacing her.

images.alt_text: THE board of Gaylin Holdings has flagged that the group is expected to record a net loss for Q1 FY2017.

site_title: Third Spanish election will produce another hung parliament: poll
summary: Spain is set for another hung parliament following a third election, with the People's Party (PP) expected to win but short of a majority, according to a poll. The PP would secure 32.5% of the vote, while the Socialists would come second with 23.1%. The far-left Unidos Podemos and liberal Ciudadanos parties would trail behind, with 19.6% and 12% of the vote, respectively. This outcome would prolong Spain's political deadlock, which has been in place since two inconclusive elections eight months ago.

site_title: DBS's oil & gas exposure up by another S$1b
summary: DBS Bank's oil & gas exposure has increased to S$23 billion, up S$1 billion, due to more trade finance loans. The bank's Q2 profit slid 6% to S$1.05 billion, while Piyush Gupta warned of potential contagion from the collapse of Swiber Holdings, a firm linked to S$900 million of DBS's oil & gas exposure. Despite this, DBS expects its total non-performing loan ratio for 2016 to not exceed 1.3-1.4%. The bank's oil & gas exposure is primarily in the support services sector, with S$7 billion at risk, down from S$9 billion in Q1.

site_title: Bank of France forecasts GDP to grow 0.3%
summary: The Bank of France forecasts a 0.3% growth in French GDP for the third quarter, surpassing economists' predictions of 0.2%. This comes after the economy stagnated in the second quarter. A gauge of sentiment among French manufacturing executives rose to 98 in July, while confidence in the services sector slipped. The forecast is seen as a positive step for President Francois Hollande ahead of next year's general election.

site_title: Oil prices rebound as Opec announces meet
summary: Oil prices rebounded Monday, rising 66 cents to $44.93 a barrel for Brent North Sea crude, as Opec announced an informal meeting in Algeria next month, potentially leading to lower output. Analysts believe this could result in a lower supply glut, which would be a vindication of Opec's Saudi-led strategy since 2014. Prices had been fluctuating since entering a "bear" market, falling over 20% and closing below $40 a barrel for the first time since April.

site_title: Cosco Guangdong Shipyard bags deal for trio of container vessels
summary: Cosco Guangdong Shipyard Co, a subsidiary of Cosco Corporation, has won a contract to build three 1,750 TEU container vessels for a European buyer. The vessels are scheduled for delivery in Q2 and Q3 2019. The contract prices are confidential, and the transactions are not expected to impact Cosco Corporation's net tangible assets and earnings per share for the year ending December 31, 2016.

site_title: An islander's vision
summary: A 79-year-old Singaporean, Lui Hock Seng, is a cleaner who still takes beautiful pictures with his old Rolleiflex camera, a hobby he picked up in 1957. Despite being unable to afford a digital camera due to his limited budget, he won several photo competitions and honed his skills. However, the advent of digital photography has rendered mechanical cameras obsolete, making it too expensive for him to continue. Seng still takes pictures on weekends at his favorite seaside spot, cherishing his hobby and the memories it brings.

images.alt_text: Mr Lui, 2016
Mr Lui, 1966
1965: This interesting composition was captured during a visit to the old Tanah Merah village.
60s: Who can resist these charming kids playing near the Redhill brick factory?
70s: " I opened the door one morning to investigate the commotion going on below my Toa Payoh HDB block - a crowd had gatheredt o watch an outdoor silat performance."
1961: "A friend tipped me off about the scenic Clarke Quay's Teochew market. I went there in the morning and was rewarded witha catch."
1964: "A common scene over Merdeka bridge, captured on my way to work."
60s-70s: On Kusu island, rows of hawkers selling drinks under parasols.

site_title: Delta flights resume after power outage strands passengers
summary: Delta Air Lines' flights resumed after a power outage grounded planes and stranded passengers worldwide. The outage began at 2:30 am EDT in Atlanta, causing "large-scale" cancellations. Although departures were halted, flights started taking off again by Monday, with customers expecting delays and cancellations. The airline lifted its departure halt at 8:40 am EDT, allowing some flights to resume, though the situation was still fluid.

site_title: US stocks edge up on higher oil prices, Wal-Mart deal
summary: US stocks rose on Monday as oil prices advanced and Wal-Mart gained 0.2% on news of its $3.3 billion acquisition of Jet.com. The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries announced informal talks next month, potentially signaling tougher action in response to weak oil prices. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty, with investors focusing on the US-EU trade talks.

site_title: China's July trade performance disappoints
summary: China's July trade performance was disappointing, with imports plummeting 12.5% year-on-year to US$132.4 billion, exceeding the expected 7.0% fall. Weaker global commodity prices and lackluster domestic demand contributed to the decline. This worsens China's economic outlook, putting pressure on policymakers.

images.alt_text: DISAPPOINTING FIGURES: Exports fell 4.4 per cent to US$184.7 billion - compared with expectations of a 3.5 per cent decline. July was the fourth month in a row that exports declined in dollar terms.

site_title: After Brexit, Draghi faces oil hurdle on path to higher inflation
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) faces a new challenge in its path to higher inflation due to the recent decline in oil prices, which has fallen over 13% since the Brexit referendum. Despite encouraging economic signals, inflation remains below the ECB's 2% goal, and policymakers may need to revise their outlook. Economists predict that ECB President Mario Draghi will have to ease policy before the end of the year to address the issue.

images.alt_text: IN SAFE HANDS? With growth not strong enough to generate price pressures, Mr Draghi may have to revise his inflation outlook yet again.

site_title: Grants by Spring & SGX lead to IPO listings
summary: Singapore's joint initiative with Spring Singapore and the Singapore Exchange (SGX) to support small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) has led to nine SMEs launching initial public offerings (IPOs) on the Catalist board this year. The initiative, which offers grants of up to 70% for SMEs to improve financial management capabilities, has been successful, with about half of the participating SMEs tapping the grant. The move aims to give SMEs easier access to capital markets, enabling them to sustain business growth.

site_title: Chip Eng Seng Corp reports lower Q2 profit on increased income tax expense
summary: Chip Eng Seng Corp reported a 33% decline in Q2 net profit to S$14.27 million, weighed down by higher income tax expense, despite an 18.9% year-over-year increase in total revenue to S$234.3 million. The company attributed the decline to a challenging Singapore private residential market and increased competition in public housing projects. However, its hospitality division performed better, and it plans to expand its hotel portfolio in the region.

site_title: Delta says Atlanta power outage triggered computer system freeze
summary: Delta Air Lines stated that a power outage in Atlanta on August 8, 2016, caused a widespread computer problem, resulting in flight delays and cancellations worldwide. The outage began at 2:38 am ET and impacted Delta's computer systems and operations globally. The airline's IT team is working to resolve the issue. Airport screens and Delta's website displayed outdated flight status information due to the outage.

site_title: Trump to outline economic policy as he seeks to regain momentum
summary: US presidential nominee Donald Trump will outline an economic plan focusing on trade, taxes, and immigration in a Detroit speech. The plan aims to help working families with tax relief and is an attempt to regain momentum after self-inflicted wounds. Trump's advisers expect the speech to address trade, taxes, immigration, and regulation, targeting key business leaders in the Detroit area.

images.alt_text: MAJOR SPEECH TO COME: Mr Trump speaking during a rally at Windham High School in New Hampshire on Saturday. Last week, he announced a 13-man team of economic advisers.

site_title: Deutsche Bank to pay US$12.5m fine for mishandling squawk box information
summary: Deutsche Bank Securities Inc. has been fined US$12.5 million by the Financial Industry Regulatory Authority for failing to properly supervise access to confidential "squawk box" information, which could impact stock prices. The bank's internal policies did not adequately control who heard sensitive information meant for research and trading employees. Despite warnings from its compliance department, the bank ignored concerns and allowed private client services employees to hear confidential information. No brokers were accused of misusing the information, but the watchdog criticized the bank's failure to ensure proper supervision.

site_title: Phelps gets 19th gold with 4x100m relay win
summary: Michael Phelps wins his 19th gold medal with Team USA, helping the US secure its first win in the men's 4x100m freestyle relay at the Rio Olympics since Beijing. Phelps, the most decorated Olympian of all time, swam the second leg of the relay, clocking 47.12 seconds, as the US narrowly beat France and Australia. Phelps and his teammates celebrated their victory, with Phelps getting emotional after the win, saying it feels "damn good" to get a win in his final 400 free relay.

site_title: Valuemax Q2 earnings surge 46% at S$3.9m
summary: VALUEMAX Group Limited reported a 46% surge in Q2 net profit to S$3.9 million, driven by increased income from pawnbroking and moneylending. Revenue dropped 10% to S$64.9 million due to lower earnings from retail and trading of pre-owned jewellery and gold. The company's earnings per share and net asset value per share increased, but no dividend was proposed. The counter rose 1.96% to close at S$0.26 following the earnings release.

site_title: Flight bookings to Britain rise after Brexit weakens pound
summary: Flight bookings to Britain rose 4.3% in the month following the Brexit vote, reversing a 2.8% decline in the previous month, according to travel information firm ForwardKeys. The pound's 10% weakening against the dollar and euro made the UK cheaper for international visitors. Bookings from outside Europe increased 8.6%, driven by visitors from Hong Kong, the US, and Canada, while bookings from Europeans declined 1.8% compared to the same period last year. This uptick in visitor numbers could benefit tourist attractions, hoteliers, and shops across Britain.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Swiber Holdings, an offshore services firm, has received claims totaling US$99 million and is seeking legal advice. The company's subsidiary, Swiber Offshore Construction, has been called upon by Oil and Natural Gas Corp and Punj Lloyd to pay bank guarantees totaling US$94.48 million and S$12.99 million, respectively. The court has granted an interim order to hold back on payments until the next hearing date. Meanwhile, other companies, such as International Healthway Corp and Chip Eng Seng, have reported financial updates, including Swembcorp Industries' investment in Sembcorp Green Infra and Chip Eng Seng's decline in net profit.

site_title: After German attacks, Facebook insists it works with probes
summary: Facebook has dismissed complaints from German officials that it has not been helpful in fighting terrorism, saying it is committed to working with authorities. The US-based social network provided answers to about 37% of German security requests over the last three years, according to Welt am Sonntag newspaper. Facebook urged authorities to better formulate their requests and is working with police to train them on how to submit official applications. The company said it has zero tolerance for terrorism and supports law enforcement investigations to fight terrorism in Germany.

site_title: Malaysia Airlines appoints new chief commercial officer
summary: Malaysia Airlines appoints Arved von zur Muehlen as the new chief commercial officer, effective September 5. He replaces Paul Simmons, who will leave in mid-September. Von zur Muehlen previously held the role of senior vice president of commercial network operations for Qatar Airways. This appointment comes after Malaysia Airlines' struggles following the disappearance of MH370 and the shooting down of MH17. The airline had also recently appointed a new CEO.

site_title: Travelite pays for option to buy planned HQ building for S$19.3m
summary: TRAVELITE Holdings has paid S$192,750 to gain an option to buy an industrial building in Singapore for S$19.3 million. The four-storey building has a 60-year leasehold tenure and will be used to consolidate and expand the company's corporate headquarters. Travelite plans to finance the acquisition with internal funds and bank borrowings, with its borrowings expected to be 0.73 times shareholders' funds. The option can be exercised within 71 days from August 8.

site_title: Swiber receives claims totalling US$99 million
summary: Swiber Holdings, an offshore services firm, has received total claims of around US$99 million. The company is seeking legal advice regarding the claims and has called on bank guarantees totaling US$94.48 million and 644.2 million rupees. Swiber's wholly owned subsidiary, Swiber Offshore Construction, has filed petitions in court to prevent the payment of these guarantees. The court has granted an interim order to hold back on any payment until the next hearing date. Swiber is also discussing potential steps to preserve its rights related to the paid-out bank guarantees.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 8.64 points to close at 1,672.68, driven by gains in 455 stocks. The index saw 2.63 billion lots valued at RM1.85 billion traded. The rally comes as investors brush off new US President Trump threats, focusing on Asia's economic growth.

site_title: Latest Earnings
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Singapore's NTT DC Reit's public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. Meanwhile, US stocks opened lower due to a fresh tariff salvo by Trump on Canada. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue and operating loss for the second half of the year. London's Heathrow plans to increase fees for a £10 billion upgrade. In Indonesia, a Trafigura employee was detained in a graft case. OCBC announced Tan Teck Long as its incoming CEO. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and the People's Bank of China (PBOC) are set to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance.

site_title: Sembcorp Utilities lands long-term power purchase deal with Bangladesh Power Development Board
summary: Sembcorp Utilities, a subsidiary of Sembcorp Industries, has secured a 22.5-year power purchase agreement with the Bangladesh Power Development Board for 414 megawatts of power. The US$400 million combined cycle gas-fired power plant is set to be completed in 2018, with Sembcorp owning 71% of the project.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 1.51% on Monday, driven by a strong lead from Wall Street following the US economy's better-than-expected job growth in July. The Hang Seng Index ended at 22,479.60, while the Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.93%. The rally comes as investors brush off new US President Trump's threats, extending the stocks rally.

site_title: Three fresh challenges that will test Singapore's resolve to stay united: PM Lee
summary: Singapore faces three major challenges to maintain unity: extremist terrorism, the disruption of the economy by globalization and technological change, and the strain on its society due to a changing demographic. Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasized that despite these challenges, Singapore has the ability to overcome them due to its shared resolve to tackle them together. He highlighted the country's unique ability to remain united and work towards a brighter future for its children.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Sembcorp invests 750m rupees in India renewable energy sector
summary: Sembcorp Industries has invested an additional 750 million rupees (S$15.1 million) in the Indian renewable energy sector through its subsidiary Sembcorp Utilities. The investment raised Sembcorp Utilities' stake in Sembcorp Green Infra to 68.74% and enabled it to acquire a 74% stake in Mulanur Renewable Energy, a special purpose vehicle with 25.5 megawatts of wind power assets in Tamil Nadu. The transactions are expected to have minimal impact on Sembcorp Industries' earnings per share and net asset value per share for the year ending December 31, 2016.

site_title: China needs housing space 'the size of Singapore' each year till 2030: Fitch
summary: China needs to build 800 million square meters of new residential property each year until 2030 to meet demand, according to Fitch Ratings. This translates to an annual demand of roughly the size of Singapore. The estimate assumes one-third of new demand will come from demolishing old properties, while demand from first-time buyers will decline after peaking in 2013. This prediction comes despite reports of oversupply and overbuilding in China, with the country completing 737 million square meters of residential property in 2015.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's second-quarter GDP is likely to confirm sluggish growth due to concerns over Brexit and weakening global demand. DBS Group Holdings' chief defended the bank's decision to extend a S$197 million lifeline to Swiber Holdings, a struggling energy-services company. The company's near-liquidation has set off tremors in Singapore's banking and energy industries. Meanwhile, Sembcorp Industries invested S$15.1 million in the Indian renewable energy sector. The Straits Times Index rose 1.5% to 2,870.78, driven by Wall Street's jump to a new all-time high and DBS's better-than-expected earnings.

site_title: Far East Hospitality Trust's financial controller quits
summary: Far East Hospitality Trust's financial controller, Annie Khung Shyang Lee, has resigned effective August 9 to pursue personal interests. Lee, 40, was responsible for overseeing financial and tax matters. The trust's board expressed appreciation for her contributions and wished her well in her future endeavors.

site_title: CEFC narrows losses for Q2, says discussions on acquisitions still ongoing
summary: CEFC International reported a Q2 loss of US$328,000, narrowing from US$758,000 in Q1, despite revenue jumping to US$292.3 million. The company is still in discussions for acquisitions, including a port facilities project and a floating storage project, with ING Bank agreeing to a US$150 million credit facility. CEFC's performance remains uncertain due to global markets and the UK's Brexit decision, with its net asset value at 4.641 US cents. The company's stock closed at S$0.20, up 10.5% before results were released.

site_title: DBS chief Gupta defends decision to extend lifeline to Swiber
summary: DBS Group Holdings' CEO Piyush Gupta defended the bank's decision to extend a S$197 million lifeline to struggling energy-services company Swiber Holdings Ltd, citing that the bank was caught off guard by the company's rapid collapse. Despite other lenders not classifying Swiber as nonperforming, Gupta said the bank had personally checked on Swiber's financial health three months prior and had spoken with a would-be investor to secure an equity injection. The bank expects to recover more than S$320 million of its total exposure to Swiber.

site_title: Fed's Powell urges patience on US rates, citing growth risks
summary: Federal Reserve policymaker Jerome Powell urged patience on US interest rates, citing growth risks due to global factors. Powell favors a gradual path for rate rises, as inflation remains below target. He expressed concern about the probability of weaker growth and lower potential growth, which he believes poses a greater worry than previously. Powell suggested the Fed can be patient, indicating lower interest rates may be needed sooner than expected.

site_title: Taiwan July exports rise y-o-y, ending 17-month streak of falls
summary: Taiwan's exports rose 1.2% in July, ending a 17-month streak of declines, driven by stronger demand from China for electronics components and information products. This marks the first year-over-year expansion since January 2015. The trade surplus for July was $3.61 billion, up from $3.58 billion in June. The growth reverses a trend that saw exports contract by 2.1% in June, the smallest decline since February 2015.

site_title: SMRT Q1 FY17 profit down 22.9% as train losses deepen
summary: SMRT Corporation reported a 22.9% decline in net profit for the first quarter of financial year 2017, to S$15.5 million, due to deeper losses from train operations and engineering services. Total revenue fell 2% to S$313.9 million, down from S$320.3 million in the same period last year. This is the first quarterly results since SMRT's transition to a new rail financing framework and Temasek Holdings' bid to take the company private.

site_title: Dozens of Philippine officials surrender after being linked to drugs trade
summary: Dozens of Philippine officials, including 27 mayors and 31 police officers, surrendered to the national police office on Monday after being linked to the country's drug trade. The move follows President Rodrigo Duterte's threat to hunt down those who fail to surrender within 24 hours. Since taking office in June, police have killed over 400 suspected drug dealers, with some estimates as high as 800, including executions by vigilantes. The officials turned themselves in to clear their names amid the ongoing "war on narcotics" in the Philippines.

site_title: Maxi-Cash chalks up higher profit for Q2
summary: Maxi-Cash reported a 217% increase in net profit to S$2.3 million for the second quarter, driven by 30% higher revenue at S$38.98 million. The company expects its operating environment to remain challenging due to competition, volatile gold prices, and weak retail sentiment. An interim dividend of $0.005 per share has been declared, payable on August 31.

images.alt_text: Maxi-Cash's net profit for the second quarter ended June 30 rose to S$2.3 million, up from S$721,000 a year ago.

site_title: Indonesian group behind Singapore plot has 'dozens of members': police
summary: Indonesian authorities arrested six suspected radicals on Batam island last week, suspecting they planned a rocket attack on Singapore. The group, believed to have dozens of members, mostly recruited online and took instructions from Bahrun Naim, an Indonesian in Syria with Islamic State ties. The arrests come after Bahrun Naim was reportedly planning to carry out a rocket attack on Singapore.

site_title: Japan's emperor worries age may make it tough to perform his duties
summary: Japanese Emperor Akihito, 82, expressed concerns about his declining fitness level and potential difficulty in carrying out his duties as the country's symbol of the state. The emperor, who has undergone heart surgery and prostate cancer treatment, stopped short of saying he wants to abdicate, but his remarks sparked debate about the possibility of legal changes to allow for retirement. Public opinion polls show the majority of Japanese people sympathize with the emperor's desire to retire, but opposition from conservative Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's base could hinder any potential changes.

site_title: Europe: Stocks ahead at open
summary: European stocks rose at the open on Monday, driven by pre-weekend gains on Wall Street and earlier in Asia. The FTSE 100 index gained 0.1% to 6,797.46 points, while the DAX 30 and CAC 40 added 0.5% and 0.2% respectively. The rally was partly attributed to strong US jobs data and upgraded employment estimates, which boosted the odds of a Federal Reserve interest rate hike this year.

site_title: Singapore shares end higher as STI gains 1.5% in line with Wall St, DBS's results
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 1.5% to 2,870.78, driven by Wall Street's new all-time high and DBS's better-than-expected second quarter profit. Singtel led the gain, followed by the three banks and Jardine group. Despite mediocre volume, the index outperformed its advance-decline score, which was 226-186. DBS's profit drop was largely due to a one-off provision related to Swiber Holdings' bankruptcy.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks rally after upbeat US jobs data
summary: Tokyo stocks surged 2.44% on Monday, driven by upbeat US jobs data that lifted sentiment and weakened the yen. The Nikkei 225 index rose to 16,650.57, while the Topix index advanced 2.00% to 1,305.53. Toyota and Nissan, among other exporters, benefited from the boost.

site_title: S&P upgrades South Korea's long-term sovereign credit rating to AA
summary: Standard and Poor's upgraded South Korea's long-term sovereign credit rating to AA from AA-minus with a stable outlook, citing the country's steady economic growth and improved fiscal and monetary flexibility. The rating remains unchanged for the next two years, but may revert to the mean of other developed economies if growth slows. The country's diversified economy and strong monetary policy support sustainable growth, but high household debt and geopolitical risks pose challenges.

site_title: China July iron ore imports rise to near record, other commodities drop
summary: China's iron ore imports rose 2.7% to 88.4 million tonnes in July, the second-highest monthly volume on record, driven by a stronger steel market. This surge in demand has helped iron ore prices rally 42% this year. In contrast, copper and crude oil imports declined, with copper imports down 14.3% and crude oil imports at a 7.32 million barrels per day low. The increased iron ore shipments are expected to remain steady unless prices reach US$65-70, encouraging domestic production.

site_title: Amazon Japan raided on suspicion of antitrust practices: Nikkei
summary: Amazon Japan's office was raided by Japan's Fair Trade Commission on suspicion of pressuring retailers to offer products on more favourable conditions than on rival sites. The commission is suspected of Amazon Japan imposing conditions such as lower prices if retailers advertise on other online shopping sites. An Amazon Japan spokeswoman declined to comment, while a Fair Trade Commission spokesman confirmed the raid but did not confirm the report's contents.

site_title: Australia: Shares end higher with help of banks, miners
summary: Australian shares rose 0.7% on Monday, tracking a positive lead from Wall Street, with banks and miners leading gains. The S&P/ASX 200 index reached its highest level since August 2015, closing at 5,537.8. This follows a similar performance by New Zealand's S&P/NZX 50 index, which gained 0.5%.

site_title: Australia dollar steady near 3-week high, kiwi falls
summary: The Australian dollar held steady near a three-week high, trading at US$0.7612, as investors sought to escape negative interest rates in Europe and Japan. The currency's triple A credit rating and rising risk appetite contributed to its gains. Despite a recent interest rate cut, the Aussie offers high yields compared to other developed countries. The New Zealand dollar slipped 0.3% to US$0.7116, as strong US jobs figures boosted the greenback and increased the probability of a Federal Reserve interest rate hike.

site_title: Bangladesh kicks out North Korea diplomat over smuggled goods
summary: Bangladesh has kicked out North Korean diplomat Han Son Ik after he was caught smuggling over 1 million cigarettes and electronics worth nearly half a million dollars into the country. The diplomat failed to declare the goods, which were suspected to be sold to local smuggling gangs.
