Following an EY report highlighting breaches of fiduciary duties, Sim was suspended as CEO and his travel documents were impounded. The report found issues with deposits, accounts receivable financing, inventories, and improper transactions, including a vehicle hire purchase involving his spouse. Shares of Jason Holdings remain suspended, and Sim has been ordered to produce documents and information from 2008 to 2016.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SGX, Genting Singapore, DBS, SingPost, UOL, Bumitama Agri
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) made a £77.6 million (S$137 million) cash offer for the Baltic Exchange, with existing shareholders set to receive a final cash dividend. Genting Singapore narrowed its Q2 loss to S$10.5 million. DBS Group Holdings is under scrutiny due to its exposure to Swiber Holdings, which has filed for wind-up. Singapore Post's operating loss in its e-commerce segment widened to S$3.5 million, while UOL Group's Q2 earnings slid 55% due to fair value losses. Bumitama Agri's Q2 profit fell 39% to 107.6 billion rupiah.

site_title: Facebook giving the hook to "clickbait" headlines
summary: Facebook updated its News Feed formula to reduce "clickbait" headlines that mislead users. The change aims to show users fewer clickbait stories and more relevant content. The update targets headlines that withhold crucial information or exaggerate to mislead readers. Facebook researchers analyzed thousands of headlines to identify and remove clickbait content. The move is expected to impact publishers, as changes to the algorithm can significantly affect traffic and advertising revenue.

site_title: Self-driving start-up Otto to test with truckers by year's end
summary: Self-driving trucking start-up Otto plans to test its software with long-haul truckers by the end of 2016, with a goal of "thousands" of testers by 2017. The company will also test five retrofitted Volvo trucks at Northern California's autonomous vehicle testing grounds. Otto's technology uses sensors and mapping to allow trucks to drive autonomously, with the potential for increased efficiency and safety. Partners will test the trucks by leaving the wheel, similar to a plane's "autopilot" system, with some trucks able to drive more than double their normal daily mileage.

images.alt_text: Self-driving trucking start-up Otto is poised to put its software in the hands of long-haul truckers by the end of this year for testing, its co-founders said on Thursday.

site_title: Europe: Stocks climb, pound plunges after BoE stimulus
summary: The Bank of England cut interest rates to a record low 0.25% to counter Brexit fallout, sparking a surge in European stocks, with London leading the gain. The pound plummeted, while US shares were flat ahead of a key jobs report. The BoE also announced an additional £170 billion of stimulus, hinting at further easing to come.

site_title: With Trump talk of 'rigged' election, a line crossed?
summary: Donald Trump's assertion that the US presidential election will be rigged has sparked alarm among observers, who warn he could be laying the groundwork for rejecting a Hillary Clinton win and even sparking civil unrest. Trump's claims, made in a speech in Ohio, have been likened to a "line crossed" by the Republican nominee, who has a history of claiming a "rigged system" is responsible for his opponents' losses. Experts warn that such statements undermine the legitimacy of the system, but Trump's comments also tap into legitimate public concerns about the complexity and potential for voter fraud in the US election process.

site_title: British pound slides following Bank of England stimulus
summary: The British pound fell 1.5% to $1.3114 after the Bank of England cut interest rates to a record low 0.25% and delivered a £170-billion stimulus package in response to the Brexit vote. The move was seen as a surprise by analysts, snapping a streak of underwhelming action by global central banks. The pound's decline was attributed to the uncertainty surrounding the UK's economic future, with the BoE governor Mark Carney stating that the country is "living through a time of considerable uncertainty."

site_title: Bumitama Agri Q2 profit falls 39% to 107.6b rupiah
summary: BUMITAMA Agri's 2Q net profit fell 39% to 107.6 billion rupiah, driven by a 21% decline in crude palm oil sales. Revenue decreased 12.9% to 1.4 trillion rupiah. In contrast, the first half saw a 2.8% increase in net profit to 337.1 billion rupiah.

site_title: Rivals face off in UK Labour leadership race
summary: Britain's Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn will debate Owen Smith, a rival seeking to unseat him, for the first time on Thursday. The debate is part of several leadership hustings ahead of a postal vote by party members that will choose the new leader by September 24. The contest follows Labour's June 23 vote to leave the European Union, which has led to lawmakers demanding Corbyn's leadership step down amidst party turmoil.

site_title: Trump, in fierce new broadside, says immigrants pose hidden threat
summary: US presidential hopeful Donald Trump launched new attacks on immigrants, calling Somalis and refugees from "terrorist nations" a hidden threat. He claimed that vetting these individuals is impossible and warned of a "Trojan horse" of terrorists sneaking into the US. Trump pointed to a Somali refugee population in Maine as an example of problems caused by high unemployment and potential recruiting targets for Islamist terror groups. He also listed several immigrants arrested for supporting terror groups, stating, "We're dealing with animals."

site_title: French mobile operator SFR, unions clinch deal to cut jobs
summary: French mobile operator SFR has agreed to cut 5,000 jobs through a voluntary departures plan, shedding a third of its staff, after reaching a deal with two unions. The move is expected to cost around 600-800 million euros over two years but will bring annual savings of 400 million euros. The decision comes two years after SFR was bought by Altice, and the agreement was backed by unions Unsa and CFDT, with the CGT union opposing the deal.

site_title: Quitting while he's ahead
summary: Kenny Rogers, a 77-year-old Grammy award winner, will embark on his final concert tour "The Gambler's Last Deal" with a stop in Singapore on August 6. After five and a half decades in the music industry, Rogers is retiring due to not spending enough time with his two sons. He credits his longevity to his mother's advice to be happy in his situation and his successful duets with artists like Dolly Parton. Rogers will not be pursuing music full-time after 2017, but may write songs for personal enjoyment.

site_title: Tough Apple Pay deal raises question on costs to consumers
summary: Apple Inc is expected to collect around S$10 million from Singapore banks for offering Apple Pay to customers, on top of relatively high transaction fees ranging from 0.1% to 0.2% per transaction. This is significantly higher than US banks, which pay around 15 US cents per hundred US dollars. The high fees are attributed to Singapore's smaller payment infrastructure and the security benefits offered by Apple Pay in the US.

site_title: BOJ 'not sounding a retreat from monetary easing'
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) has defended its monetary easing policies despite market speculation that it was retreating from its aggressive stance. Deputy governor Kikuo Iwata and Economy Minister Nobutero Ishihara stated that the central bank's comprehensive policy review, announced last week, did not signal a change in direction. The review aims to assess the BOJ's monetary transmission mechanism and obstacles to its policy. The review will be published in September, and the BOJ is willing to ease policy further if necessary to achieve its 2% inflation target.

site_title: Man wounded in Nice attack dies, taking toll to 85
summary: A 31-year-old Tunisian man, Mohamed Lahouaiej Bouhlel, died Thursday from injuries sustained in the Bastille Day truck attack in Nice, France, bringing the death toll to 85. Bouhlel rammed a lorry into revellers on Nice's seafront Promenade des Anglais, claiming responsibility for the attack, which also left 434 people injured. The attack is the latest in a string of jihadist attacks in France, prompting mounting demands for improved security.

site_title: Oil market downturn presages dramatic price hike
summary: The oil market is experiencing a downturn, threatening a dramatic price hike due to a decline in investment in upstream oil and gas production. Companies have cut spending by $1 trillion through 2020, resulting in a projected 5-6 million barrels of oil equivalent per day less supply this year and next. As demand continues to rise, a supply crunch and price spike are expected, with Wood Mackenzie predicting a potential price spike in the years ahead.

site_title: Jaguar Land Rover recalls US cars with airbag defect
summary: Jaguar Land Rover is recalling over 54,000 US vehicles to fix defective Takata airbags. The affected vehicles, produced from 2007-2011, include 2009-2011 Jaguar XF vehicles and 2007-2011 Land Rover Range Rover vehicles. The recall is part of a larger effort to address the issue, which affects a total of 108,000 vehicles. Owners have been notified, and repairs are expected to be made. The recall is aimed at preventing potential injuries and fatalities caused by the faulty airbags.

site_title: GST will make India a truly unified market for the first time
summary: India's upper house of parliament passed a bill for the constitutional amendment to introduce the goods and services tax (GST), a major tax reform since independence. The GST will replace various state and central taxes, encouraging compliance and reducing costs for consumers. Experts expect a 1.7 percentage point increase in GDP growth, but some states may benefit more than others due to revenue sharing disputes. The GST will be imposed by both the centre and states, aiming to transform the way business is conducted in the country and create a truly unified market for the first time.

site_title: Hub Singapore opens second co-working space
summary: Hub Singapore, one of the country's largest co-working spaces, has opened its second facility at Cuppage Terrace. The 10,000 sq ft space offers both hot desks and private offices, catering to users seeking a more private setting. The new space is part of the company's growth and diversification of the startup ecosystem, targeting companies at their next stage of growth. Hub@Cuppage is the second facility to achieve near 100% occupancy, following the success of Hub@Prinsep Street.

site_title: Emirates jet tried to abort landing shortly before Dubai crash
summary: An Emirates Boeing 777-300 jet attempted to abort its landing in Dubai shortly before crashing and catching fire, killing one firefighter. All 282 passengers and 18 crew members escaped unharmed. The cause of the incident is under investigation, with factors including wind shear and possible pilot missteps being considered. The aircraft, which entered service in 2003, had logged over 7,000 flying hours. The Dubai airport reopened after a three-and-a-half-hour shutdown, with 13 people hospitalized with minor injuries.

site_title: More cities measuring climate footprint after Paris deal
summary: The number of cities reporting on their efforts to tackle global warming has increased 70% to 533 worldwide since the Paris climate change agreement in 2015, according to the Carbon Disclosure Project (CDP). These cities represent 621 million citizens globally and are now providing annual information on their greenhouse gas emissions, renewable energy targets, and other environmental aspects. The increase in reporting cities is attributed to growing awareness of climate risks, with a nearly fourfold increase in African cities disclosing climate information since last year.

site_title: Rio Tinto's rewind to 2004 shows it's a victim of own success
summary: Rio Tinto, the world's second-largest mining company, has seen its success backfire due to its own expansion efforts. The company invested $90 billion in expanding production over the past decade, but when China's economy slowed, commodity prices collapsed, and Rio's profits suffered. To combat this, Rio is adopting a new strategy of investing in existing projects and expanding profitable operations, rather than focusing on mergers and acquisitions. The company has reported underlying earnings of $1.56 billion for the first half, the lowest since 2004, and has cut its dividend in half.

site_title: Tesla posts 13th straight quarterly loss, eyes more stores
summary: Tesla reported its 13th consecutive quarterly loss, with a net loss of $293.2 million, despite plans to accelerate store openings and meet ambitious production targets. The company delivered 14,402 vehicles in the second quarter, below its goal of 17,000. Tesla expects to spend $2.25 billion in capital expenditure in 2016 to prepare for its upcoming Model 3 sedan. The company also plans to open a new store every four days on average for the rest of the year.

site_title: Maxi-Cash expands into gold jewellery retail
summary: Maxi-Cash, a pawnbroker, has expanded into gold jewellery retail with its LeGold range, offering over 20,000 new jewellery pieces. The launch marks a significant move into retail, following the company's decision to expand into the market in response to high customer demand for gold jewellery. The LeGold range features modern and lightweight designs, with prices starting from S$68, and offers competitive pricing and exceptional value to customers. The company plans to expand its retail business in the future, but will retain its pawnbroking business as its mainstay.

site_title: A-HTrust's Q1 DPU rises 0.8%
summary: Ascendas Hospitality Trust (A-HTrust) reported a 0.8% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.29 Singapore cents for its first quarter ended June 30, 2016, driven by a 5.5% climb in net property income. Despite a 0.8% drop in gross revenue, underlying performance improved, and the trust expects the Australian dollar's weakness to boost hotel sector performance. However, challenges remain in the Singapore hotel market due to weak corporate demand and increased competition.

site_title: Honouring towkays that aspire to inspire
summary: The Business Times honored 31 businesses at the BT Salutes Enterprise gala dinner, celebrating their contributions to Singapore's economy. The event, themed "Aspire to Inspire," recognized SMEs that make up 99% of businesses, employ 70% of the workforce, and account for half of the country's GDP. The evening featured performances by a local acapella group and a song by Minister of State Chee Hong Tat. The series of interviews with SME leaders ran from July 19 to 22, highlighting their expansion, strategic planning, and growth.

site_title: City buzz
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Singapore's dining scene features a showcase of Sichuan cuisine at Si Chuan Duo Hua Restaurant, with 100 authentic dishes highlighting various sauces and flavors. Korean cinema is also gaining momentum, with films like "Train to Busan" and "The Wailing" wowing audiences. Theatrical performances include SITI Khalijah Zainal's one-woman show "Rosnah" and the experiential dining experience "The Spy, The Thug, His Wife and Her Lover". Additionally, a unique brunch event combines Sicilian and Hakka cuisine, and a nomadic theatre group offers an immersive dining experience. These events showcase the diversity of Singapore's cultural and culinary scene.

site_title: Music festival boom
summary: Singapore is becoming a hub for music festivals, with more events catering to various genres. The city-state is set to host Singapore Rhapsodies, a new annual music festival celebrating homegrown music, following the success of last year's Sing50 mega concert. This event aims to showcase and promote Singaporean music, solidifying the city's position as a key destination for music enthusiasts in the region.

site_title: Serious Delhi-state differences likely on GST implementation
summary: India's ruling Bharatiya Janata Party is close to passing the Goods and Services Tax (GST) Bill, with the federal Cabinet approving key changes after consulting state finance ministers. The bill, which aims to create a "one India market," will provide full compensation to states for revenue loss and remove an additional 1% levy on goods from manufacturing states. However, serious differences are expected in its implementation, particularly with a hostile government at the center, and concerns have been raised about the concentration of power and erosion of state autonomy.

site_title: Vale mulling over monetising future output: sources
summary: Brazil's Vale SA is considering selling up to 3% of its future iron ore output to Chinese companies over a 30-year period, potentially raising $10 billion. The deal, part of a broader plan to reduce $27.5 billion in net debt, would allow the company to raise cash during low prices while keeping control of its mines. Vale's shares rose 4.5% after the report, and the company plans to sell 340 million tonnes of iron ore this year, down from 346 million last year.

site_title: Wider e-commerce loss erodes SingPost Q1 earnings
summary: SingPost, a Singaporean postal and e-commerce group, reported a 23% decline in net profit to S$35.9 million in its Q1 earnings, despite a 30.9% surge in revenue to S$333.4 million. The group incurred a wider operating loss of S$3.5 million in its e-commerce segment, primarily due to investments in IT and operational capabilities. The losses are expected to take at least one or two years to contribute to profits, with the group's e-commerce segment accounting for 49.3% of total Q1 revenue.

site_title: Oil prices rise for second day as petrol stocks lower
summary: Oil prices rose for the second consecutive day, increasing by $1.10 to $41.93 per barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange. North Sea Brent oil also rose $1.19 to $44.29 per barrel. The rise was attributed to lower gasoline inventories, which fell 1.4% to 238.2 million barrels, but US crude stocks rose 0.3% to 522.5 million barrels. Hedge funds had gone short on oil, leading to short covering and contributing to the price increase.

images.alt_text: Oil prices continued to rise on Thursday, making for a second straight day of increases in what has been a bearish market since June.

site_title: Pound slides as BOE cuts rate for first time since 2009
summary: The Bank of England cut interest rates for the first time since March 2009, lowering the benchmark rate to 0.25% and increasing its asset-purchase target to £435 billion. The move was seen as a stimulus to boost the economy after the UK's Brexit vote. The pound slid 1.2% to US$1.3167, reaching a 31-year low, amidst concerns about the economic consequences of the decision, including a contraction in the services sector and a decline in consumer confidence.

site_title: US county rejects bill against housing discrimination
summary: The Baltimore County Council rejected a bill that would have barred landlords from discriminating against tenants based on their source of income, including those receiving government assistance. The law, aimed at protecting low-income tenants, was needed in a county with a long history of racially charged housing obstruction. The bill's rejection will likely keep voucher holders concentrated in poorer areas, hindering their ability to escape poverty and access better schools and job opportunities.

site_title: Power vacuum, Alzheimer's trials fuelling Biogen takeover rumours
summary: Biogen, a biotechnology company, is facing rumors of a potential takeover due to a leadership vacuum and its experimental therapies for Alzheimer's disease. Merck & Co and Allergan have considered acquiring the company, but analysts remain skeptical, citing its high market capitalization and the competitive nature of its pipeline. Biogen's market capitalization is over $70 billion, and its value is largely dependent on its pipeline of high-risk, high-reward therapies. The company's shares rose 9.4% after a successful late-stage trial for an experimental therapy for a deadly muscle disorder.

site_title: Singapore market drags down Aviva Asia's value of new business
summary: Aviva Asia reported a 23% year-on-year decline in value of new business (VNB) in the first half of 2016, mainly due to the end of its bancassurance partnership with DBS Bank in Singapore. Operating profit grew 45% to £112 million, driven by growth in its life business, while operating expenses increased to £88 million. Despite this, the group posted a 63% year-on-year plunge in profit after tax to £201 million.

site_title: Genting Singapore Q2 loss narrows to S$10.5m
summary: Genting Singapore's Q2 loss narrowed to S$10.5 million from S$16.9 million a year ago due to lower expenses and finance costs. Revenue fell 17% to S$481 million, with gaming revenue at Resorts World Sentosa dropping 23% to S$332 million. Despite a weak gaming environment, the company maintained good earnings in the mass and premium mass market. The company also reported a 51% jump in net profit to S$18.9 million, driven by lower impairment losses.

site_title: Kevin Spacey adds life to Nine Lives
summary: Kevin Spacey stars as Tom Brand, a billionaire who becomes trapped in the body of a cat after making a deal with a cat whisperer. As Tom Cat, he must learn to reconnect with his family and navigate his new feline form. Spacey brings his signature humor and deadpan delivery to the film, which also features Jennifer Garner, Robbie Amell, and Christopher Walken. The movie follows Tom's journey as he faces humiliation and learns valuable life lessons, ultimately leading to his transformation back into his human form.

site_title: UK banks pin Brexit hopes on financial crisis bailout negotiator
summary: UK banks are pinning their hopes on financial crisis bailout negotiator Shriti Vadera, chairwoman of Santander UK, as Britain negotiates its exit from the EU. Vadera's experience in addressing the 2008 financial crisis has earned her a reputation for being a forceful leader who can drive consensus between the government and the financial sector. Her new task force will push the government to retain access to the single market, a key issue in the Brexit negotiations.

site_title: HDB resale prices up 0.7% in July; volume down 13.7%: SRX
summary: HDB resale prices in Singapore rose 0.7% in July, but transaction volume fell 13.7% to 1,573 flats. This marks a rebound from the 0.6% drop in June, which was attributed to the school holiday period. Experts attribute the decline in transactions to a lack of clear factors. Despite this, resale prices have still risen 0.8% year-over-year, and consultants expect flat prices to remain stable for the rest of 2016.

site_title: DRB-Hicom jumps almost 7 per cent
summary: DRB-Hicom Bhd shares jumped nearly 7% to RM1.09 after the company proposed disposing of its majority interest in Corwin Holding Pte Ltd to Singapore's Lum Chang Holdings Ltd. Analyst Daniel Wong believes the recent rally is driven by optimism over a potential foreign acquisition of Proton Holdings, a loss-making automotive company. The Malaysian government is reportedly open to supporting a transaction that allows a foreign company to control Proton, citing its strategic sector status and employment impact.

site_title: Reflections of Singapore's past
summary: Singaporean artist Foo Kwee Horng's solo show at Ion Art Gallery reflects on the country's past through a series of oil paintings. Inspired by family roots and historical events, including the pro-China policies of late Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew, the works aim to show the complexity of Singapore's journey from independence. Foo's search for his own roots led him to explore the country's history, using old photographs and deliberate oil painting techniques to convey the nuances of national events and personal identity.

site_title: The themes of this 'Monkey Business'
summary: Singaporean artists Justin Loke and Samuel Chen have created a group show titled "Monkey Business," which parodies traditional Chinese paintings by depicting apes engaging in everyday human activities, such as going to school or watching TV. The show is a commentary on the commodification of art and the value attached to authenticity, referencing the widespread forgeries of Chen Wen Hsi's works. The artists aimed to subvert the usual art-making process by having unnamed artists create the works, which are intentionally imperfect and humorous, blurring the line between homage and parody.

site_title: DBS CEO underscores psychological impact of negative rates
summary: DBS CEO Piyush Gupta emphasizes the psychological impact of negative interest rates, citing their effect on global markets and the global economy. He attributes the uncertainty and volatility to the rising disenfranchisement of the middle class and geopolitical risks. Gupta notes that Singapore has successfully built a first-world infrastructure in a third-world region, but changing circumstances call for a different tack, including a sustainable immigration policy. A panel discussion at the DBS Asian Insights Conference 2016 agrees that innovation and adapting to changing circumstances are crucial for the country's future.

images.alt_text: From left: DBS head of consumer banking and wealth management Tan Su Shan (moderator), Committee on the Future Economy member Harish Manwani, SPH Deputy CEO Anthony Tan, Insead dean Ilian Mihov and SBF vice-chairman Gautam Banerjee.

site_title: Hacking the election!
summary: The US Democratic National Committee and the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee were hacked by someone, possibly the Russian military, releasing sensitive documents and emails. The possibility of hacking America's voting machines poses a significant threat to the election's outcome, raising concerns about the integrity of the democratic process. Cyber-security experts warn of the dangers of electronic voting and suggest switching to paper ballots to preserve election integrity. With close results in several states and the use of electronic voting machines, the risk of cyber tampering could lead to widespread controversy and chaos if the outcome is disputed.

site_title: Big US banks try to win hearts and minds
summary: US banks, including Citigroup, JPMorgan Chase, and Bank of America, are launching advertising campaigns to counter negative perceptions of being too big and too risky. The efforts aim to show the banks' role in supporting the economy and society, with examples including sponsoring the Olympics, raising worker wages, and rebuilding Europe. Despite regulators declaring banks safer, public anger persists, with some politicians calling for breaking up big banks and reinstating the Glass-Steagall Act. The banks' efforts to improve their image may take time, with some executives acknowledging they have struggled to explain the benefits of large banks to the public.

site_title: Minmetals Land outbids Hong Kong rivals for Kowloon site
summary: Minmetals Land Ltd, a Chinese developer, outbid Hong Kong rivals for a Kowloon site with a HK$4 billion (S$692.5 million) offer, working out to HK$7,058 per square foot. The price is nearly twice industry estimates, highlighting the aggressive bidding by smaller Chinese developers to gain a foothold in Hong Kong's housing market. The site's sale marks a significant move by mainland Chinese companies into the local market, despite a slump in property prices.

site_title: DBS's S$17b exposure to O&G sector in focus
summary: DBS's second-quarter earnings are expected to be impacted by its $700 million exposure to failed oil services firm Swiber Holdings, with a potential $150 million loss. The bank's $17 billion oil and gas sector exposure accounts for 5.9% of its loan book, and analysts will scrutinize how DBS, as Swiber's main banker, failed to detect cash flow problems. DBS's net profit is expected to be lowered by 12.8% to $882 million, with some analysts suggesting loan growth may stabilize and margins may not be as affected as rivals OCBC and UOB.

site_title: UOL raises concerns about rising land prices
summary: UOL Group has raised concerns about rising private residential land prices in Singapore, citing intense competition and a lack of state land sales. The company's Q2 earnings dropped 55% year-on-year to S$68.8m, mainly due to fair value losses on investment properties. Despite this, UOL has seen strong take-up rates for its existing projects, with 97% of homes sold in the Botanique at Bartley project and 80% sold in Riverbank@Fernvale. The company plans to launch a new 505-unit condo in the first quarter of next year.

site_title: Hyflux profit dives despite surge in revenue
summary: Hyflux's second-quarter earnings plummeted 90% to S$2.6 million, despite a 176% surge in revenue to S$260 million. The company's higher finance costs and increased raw materials and subcontractor costs weighed down the results. Revenue from the TuasOne waste-to-energy project and Qurayyat Independent Water Project contributed significantly to the growth. However, the company expects weak financial performance from its Tuaspring power plant in the second half of the year due to low electricity prices.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Fraser and Neave reported a 3.5% drop in third-quarter net profit to S$38.6 million, excluding discontinued operations. OUE Limited swung back to profitability with a net profit of S$25.7 million in the second quarter. CEFC International entered into a non-binding term sheet to acquire Rompetrol France SAS, a French fuel distributor. AA Reit announced a greenfield BTS facility for Beyonics International with a 10-year master lease term.

site_title: Samsung in talks to buy assets of Fiat's components unit: sources
summary: Samsung Electronics is in talks to buy assets of Fiat's components unit, Magneti Marelli, potentially worth over $3 billion. The deal would help Samsung reduce its reliance on consumer electronics and expand its presence in the automotive industry. Vice Chairman Lee Jae Yong, who is reshaping the company, would benefit from the acquisition, which could also position Samsung to capitalize on the growing interest in cars from technology companies like Apple and Google.

site_title: Thirteen lenders extended over US$736m of facilities to Swiber group
summary: Thirteen lenders, including DBS, China Development Bank, and ICICI, have extended over US$736 million in facilities to Swiber group. DBS is confirmed as the single largest creditor, followed by China Development Bank and ICICI. The facilities include loans tied to ongoing projects, vessels, and properties, with DBS having a significant exposure to these areas. The judicial management application filed by Swiber is seen as a more positive development for creditors and bondholders.

site_title: BOE surprises with rate cut to record low, £170b stimulus
summary: The Bank of England (BOE) surprised markets with a record-low interest rate cut of 0.25% and a £170 billion quantitative easing and lending program to boost the post-Brexit UK economy. The move aims to boost borrowing, business investment, and consumer demand, but critics argue it may not have a significant impact. The pound fell by 1% against the dollar, while the FTSE 100 and gilts rose. The BOE predicts a recession will be averted, but growth in 2017 is expected to be just 0.8%.

site_title: CapitaLand Q2 profit slides 36.6%
summary: CapitaLand, a Singaporean property developer, reported a 36.6% decline in net profit for the second quarter due to higher costs and lower fair value gains. Despite this, the company's underlying performance improved, and it plans to mitigate currency risks by shoring up yuan borrowings, tapping panda bonds, and raising RMB funds. The company expects to continue selling homes in China and Singapore, with a focus on integrated developments and serviced apartments. Analysts remain optimistic about the company's earnings, citing its optimal capital structure and tools to hedge against currency risks.

site_title: Woman killed, five hurt in London knife attack
summary: A man with suspected mental health issues attacked multiple people with a knife in London's Russell Square, killing one woman and injuring five others. The incident occurred at 10:33pm, prompting armed police to intervene. Authorities believe the attack could be linked to terrorism, although no specific motive has been confirmed. The suspect is currently in custody, and an investigation is underway.

site_title: SGX to offer £77.6m in cash for Baltic Exchange
summary: SGX is making a formal offer of £77.6m (S$137m) in cash, or £160.41 per share, to acquire the Baltic Exchange. The offer price is around the mid-range of market speculation and represents about 40-45 times the Baltic Exchange's 2015 after-tax profit. The deal will include a final cash dividend of at least £18.80 per share. SGX aims to grow its forward freight agreements market, especially in Asia, and strengthen its presence in Europe. The Baltic Exchange's headquarters will remain in London.

site_title: Stocks mixed as O&M sector gets respite
summary: Singapore stocks rose 4.38 points to 2,831.96 on Thursday, driven by bounces in Singtel, Singapore Exchange (SGX), and SPH. Noble Group topped the active stocks list, rebounding from selling and gaining 10% on volume of about 400 million. The Straits Times Index's gain was attributed to short-covering, despite a mixed advance-decline score of 219 to 175. There was little indication of how Wall Street would trade, with futures markets showing slight changes.

site_title: Noble Group shares in trade frenzy
summary: Noble Group shares surged 16% in Singapore as the company's new rights shares began trading, rebounding from a 19% plunge in the previous two days. The shares closed at 14.5 cents, with about 13 billion shares now in issue. The funding, raised from chairman Richard Elman and China Investment Corp, will be used to repay borrowing and bolster operations. Analysts expect a strong rebound once the rights shares settle, citing successful disposal of the Naes business as a catalyst. Noble Group reports quarterly earnings on August 11 under new leadership.

site_title: Yum!, McDonald's seek buyers for China assets as tastes shift
summary: McDonald's and Yum! Brands Inc are seeking buyers for their China assets as consumers increasingly prefer healthier options and local food chains. The two companies, which once dominated the Chinese fast-food market, are facing declining market shares, with Yum's share dropping from 40% in 2012 to 23.9% last year. McDonald's has attracted interest from suitors, but potential buyers are hesitant due to the established brands' familiarity with Chinese consumers and the need for significant investment to adapt to changing tastes. Both companies remain confident in their China operations' future growth.

site_title: Net-zero emissions world possible - but only with carbon capture and storage: Shell
summary: Royal Dutch Shell concludes that a world with net-zero greenhouse gas emissions is possible, but only with the implementation of carbon capture and storage (CCS) technologies. The report emphasizes the need for a system to offset existing emissions, as the energy sector accounts for 40% of global emissions. To meet a net-zero goal, the power sector must provide more than half of the world's energy demand, and the industry and transportation sectors require significant decarbonization efforts. Shell's head of scenarios, Jeremy Bentham, highlights the need for carbon pricing and taxation to incentivize CCS technology development and scaling up.

site_title: Where first-time US home buyers can go big
summary: A new research by Trulia reveals US metro areas with the largest starter homes, measured by median square footage. Texas takes the lead, with Austin ranking first and Houston at No 5. The research found that these areas offer more space for first-time home buyers, with prices varying across the country.

site_title: China must step up efforts to minimise flood damage
summary: China is facing a severe flood season, with 32 million people affected, 186 dead, and 1.4 million relocated. The country has experienced three of the ten most costly global floods since 1950, with the 2011 Thailand flood and the 1998 and 2010 Chinese floods being the most devastating. While China has made progress in reducing fatalities, economic costs are increasing, and the country needs to step up efforts to minimize flood damage. The government has taken measures to prepare for floods, but systemic problems such as inadequate infrastructure and poor land use planning persist.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: StarHub reported Q2 2016 results with revenue falling 0.6% year-on-year to S$585.7 million and net profit jumping 9.6% to S$108.6 million, driven by a non-operating gain. However, mobile revenue declined 2.1% and the pay TV segment saw continued weakness. Analysts maintain a hold stance, with target prices ranging from S$0.80 to S$3.94. Despite dismal results, some analysts remain optimistic, citing the telecom business's revenue growth and potential for a special dividend.

site_title: Goldman Sachs says Brexit could adversely affect operations
summary: Goldman Sachs warns that Britain's vote to leave the EU may negatively impact its operations in the EU and require restructuring of certain businesses. The bank expects changes to the way UK firms provide services in the EU, potentially affecting its operations.

site_title: US seeks to protect its electronic voting system against cyberattacks
summary: The US government is considering new measures to protect its electronic voting system against cyberattacks, following recent hacking incidents, including the breach of the Democratic National Committee. Secretary of Homeland Security Jeh Johnson is conducting high-level discussions about "election cybersecurity" and may designate the electronic ballot-casting system as "critical infrastructure". Johnson is also planning to inform state and local election officials about "best practices" to guard against cyberintrusions. Despite the risks, the White House downplays the dangers, saying voters can have confidence in the administration's ability to mitigate those risks.

site_title: Asean growth drives US firms' optimism in region: survey
summary: A survey has found that Asean's economic growth is making the region more important to US firms, with American companies becoming more optimistic about the region. However, the future of US-Asean relations may be impacted by the ratification of the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) agreement. The survey highlights the growing importance of Asean to US firms, but also notes that trade tensions and tariffs could affect these relations in the future.

site_title: Three's a triumph
summary: The NTU Centre for Contemporary Art Singapore in Gillman Barracks is hosting a successful exhibition titled "The Sovereign Forest" by Amar Kanwar, which runs from now until October 9. The exhibition is part of a trio of strong shows at the art cluster, making it worth a visit.

site_title: Ascendas Hospitality Trust posts rise in Q1 DPU at 1.29 Singapore cents
summary: Ascendas Hospitality Trust reported a 0.8% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.29 Singapore cents for its Q1 2015-2016. Gross revenue dipped 0.8% to S$52.4 million, while net property income rose 5.5% to S$22.6 million. The increase in net property income was partly offset by adverse currency movements. The underlying performance of the portfolio improved by S$1 million in local currency terms.

site_title: Global investors flocking to Taiwan as China, technology concerns fade
summary: Global investors are flocking to Taiwan, with US$5.4 billion in inflows into the island's equities last month, making it the most popular destination among nine Asian markets. The influx is driven by bets on the release of Apple's iPhone 7, which is expected to boost profits at Taiwan suppliers, and relief that President Tsai Ing-wen's new administration hasn't strained ties with China. The Taiex index has rallied 15% since Tsai's inauguration, and the Taiwan dollar has strengthened 3.4%, with technology companies driving the advance.

site_title: StanChart sees further cuts to bad loan provisions in China, India
summary: Standard Chartered expects to further cut provisions for bad loans in China and India, with loan impairment levels in the two countries more than halving in the first six months of 2016. The bank aims to reduce its exposure to the heavy industry sector and focus on sectors like technology and pharmaceuticals. It also plans to invest more in its private banking business in Asia, leveraging its existing corporate and commercial banking client base to boost private banking assets.

site_title: More suburbs with A$1m houses on Australia's map
summary: The number of Australian suburbs with median home prices over A$1 million has surged 29% to 613 nationwide, according to CoreLogic Inc. This represents more than a doubling over the past three years, driven by declining interest rates and investor demand. The housing boom has made more suburbs with high-priced homes a reality, with the report covering a four-year period.

site_title: Bringing in the old and the new
summary: The Silver Arts Festival, a five-year-old event organized by the National Arts Council, is set to return with over 40 programmes featuring 80 artists and arts groups. The festival aims to integrate the arts into the lives of seniors, providing a unique way for them to spend time with loved ones. With a focus on inclusivity, the event features a diverse range of programmes, including films, musical performances, and seminars. The festival's director, Chua Ai Liang, notes that age is just a number and that the arts can have a profound impact on seniors' lives, challenging preconceived notions about the role of the arts in older adults.

site_title: Landmark US visit was truly a proud moment
summary: US President Barack Obama welcomed Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong of Singapore to the White House for the first official visit in 31 years, marking a significant milestone in bilateral relations. The visit, which included a black-tie state dinner, showcased the strong ties between the two nations, forged since 1966. The state dinner celebrated 50 years of relations and marked a rare privilege for Singapore, a testament to the close partnership between the two countries.

site_title: Nokia's profits fall more than forecast
summary: Nokia's second-quarter profit fell 49% to 332 million euros, beating only the lowest analyst forecast. The company's network equipment sales dropped 11% and mobile network products accounted for 80% of the decline. Nokia raised its cost-cutting target for its Alcatel-Lucent business to 1.2 billion euros, citing weak sales and a decline in margins due to operator cost-cutting measures. Despite this, the company reiterated its full-year forecast for network sales to fall, but adjusted its operating margin target to 7-9%.

images.alt_text: The company said that sales of mobile network products were particularly weak, accounting for around 80 per cent of the overall decline in network sales.

site_title: Latest Earnings
summary: Singapore's NTT DC Reit's public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. Creative Technology warned its H2 revenue may be below target, with a similar operating loss to H1. London's Heathrow plans to increase airport fees for a £10b upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. OCBC's incoming CEO is Tan Teck Long, a former DBS veteran. The Monetary Authority of Singapore and the People's Bank of China agreed to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance. Singapore stocks rose in a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: Don't bank on this Suicide Squad
summary: The DC Comics film "Suicide Squad" is a major disappointment, despite its ensemble cast and big-name stars. The film, directed by David Ayer, follows a team of meta-humans recruited by the government for a black ops mission. The team, led by Amanda Waller, includes Deadshot, Harley Quinn, and other members with unique skills, but the film's origins tale and black ops mission are marred by tedium and poor execution. The film's villain, The Enchantress, is underwhelming due to kitschy special effects, and the overall experience is described as a "dreariness" that fails to deliver excitement.

site_title: US: Stocks flat after Bank of England stimulus
summary: US stocks opened flat on Thursday after the Bank of England's more aggressive monetary stimulus package, slashing interest rates to 0.25% and delivering a £170-billion stimulus package. The move was seen as a response to the UK's Brexit vote. British stocks rose 1.7%, while the pound declined. The US market's muted reaction reflected concerns about excessive central bank policy driving investors into riskier assets, according to analyst Patrick O'Hare.

site_title: S-E Asia-C America partnership growing
summary: A nascent economic corridor connecting Central America with South-east Asia has emerged, with bilateral trade growing 350% to $15.5 billion in 2014. Import and export growth has increased in sectors such as electrical machinery, seafood, and textiles, with Singapore firms considering investment and expansion possibilities in Central America. Thailand, Malaysia, and Vietnam have benefited from access to cheap commodities, while Costa Rica and Panama have made a concerted effort to broaden global trade linkages, with partnerships with ASEAN on the rise. Trade is expected to continue with a steep trajectory.

site_title: SingPost Q1 profit falls as e-commerce operating loss widens
summary: SingPost's Q1 profit fell 23% to S$35.9 million due to a loss of rental income and a wider operating loss from e-commerce. Revenue surged 30.9% to S$333.4 million, driven by growth in cross-border e-commerce. Earnings per share dropped to 1.49 Singapore cents, while net asset value per share edged up to 73.68 Singapore cents. The interim dividend per share remained flat at 1.5 Singapore cents.

site_title: Having more choices not always a good thing
summary: The CPF Advisory Panel's proposals for higher Central Provident Fund payouts have raised concerns, as they come with significant trade-offs. Escalating annuity payouts could result in a 20% reduction in monthly payouts for those who cannot afford to wait, while higher returns through private plans carry significant risks, including market downturns. The panel's report highlights the importance of mitigating downside risk and suggests that people should be educated on returns and risks. Ultimately, the proposals may not be palatable to those seeking better returns, and the government should continue nudging people towards the scheme's risk-free interest rates.

images.alt_text: The long-awaited suggestions of the advisory panel on how to get higher Central Provident Fund (CPF) payouts are finally out.

site_title: SGX to make £77.6m offer for Baltic Exchange
summary: SGX to make a £77.6m (S$137.2m) offer, or £160.41 per share, in cash for a full takeover of the Baltic Exchange. Existing shareholders will receive a final cash dividend of at least £18.80 per share. The offer price is around the mid-range of market speculation, representing about 40-45 times Baltic Exchange's £1.3 million after-tax profit in 2015. SGX will solicit support from Baltic Exchange's roughly 380 privately held shareholders.

site_title: Hi-P International back in the black for Q2
summary: Hi-P International reported a net profit of S$7.6 million for its Q2, reversing a net loss of S$8.0 million in the previous year. Revenue decreased 9.3% to S$285.4 million, primarily due to delayed project production and subdued market demand. Earnings per share improved to 0.94 Singapore cent, while net asset value per share dropped to 62.97 Singapore cents. No interim dividend was proposed, and shares closed flat at S$0.37.

site_title: Australia shares edge higher on rate cut, Wall St boost; NZ higher
summary: Australian shares rose 0.2% to 5,475.8, while New Zealand stocks climbed 0.3% to 7,298.08, driven by optimism over a recent rate cut and a higher Wall St close. The gains come despite soft economic data. The benchmark indexes have risen for seven of the last 10 sessions, with the ASX 200 up 5% since the start of the new financial year.

site_title: Life at the top!
summary: A wine dinner featuring two Henri Jayer wines, a Richebourg Grand Cru 1989 from Domaine Romanee-Conti and an Echezeaux Grand Cru 1994, was held, showcasing the wines' aging potential and complexity. The 1989 Richebourg was deemed the standout, with its rich, transparent texture and long finish. The 1994 Echezeaux, despite being from a poor vintage, was found to be already at its best, with a rich, youthful palate. The event highlighted the exceptional quality of Burgundy wines, particularly those from renowned producers like Domaine Romanee-Conti and Henri Jayer.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 6.79 points to close at 1,655.29, driven by 460 gainers and 326 losers. The index saw 2.05 billion lots valued at RM1.53 billion traded.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Stocks end higher
summary: Hong Kong and Shanghai stocks rose on Thursday, driven by a positive lead from Wall Street. The Hang Seng Index increased 0.43% to 21,832.23, while the Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.13% to 2,982.43. Investors await a Bank of England policy decision and US jobs data, despite uncertainty over US tariffs.

site_title: Indonesian ride-hailing app Go-jek raises over US$550m from investors
summary: Indonesian ride-hailing app Go-jek has raised over $550 million from investors including US private equity firm KKR. The company, which primarily offers cheap motorcycle rides in Jakarta, has also received investments from Warburg Pincus, Farallon Capital, and Capital Group Private Markets. This funding round is a significant milestone for the Indonesian start-up, further solidifying its position in the ride-hailing market.

site_title: Rotary Engineering's Q2 profit tumbles
summary: Rotary Engineering reported a 44.8% decline in net profit to S$2.0 million for the second quarter, down from the previous year. Revenue fell 23.1% to S$51.8 million. Chairman Roger Chia attributed the decline to the challenging economic environment, particularly in the oil and gas industry. The company's order book stands at S$89.8 million, and no dividend has been proposed. Shares closed at S$0.40 on Thursday.

site_title: Siemens hikes profit forecast but warns of global risks
summary: Siemens has raised its annual earnings forecast to 6.50-6.70 euros per share, up from 6.0-6.40 euros previously predicted. The company's second-quarter order books swelled to 21 billion euros, driven by booming demand for renewables. However, CEO Joe Kaeser warned of increasing geopolitical risks, citing uncertainty from Brexit, terrorism, and EU-Turkey relations, which could impact Siemens' business in the upcoming financial year.

site_title: Singapore shares close mixed as pressure eases on O&M sector
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 4.38 points to 2,831.96 on Thursday, driven by short-covering and gains in Singtel, SGX, and SPH. Noble Group rebounded 10% after several days of selling, while offshore and marine stocks benefited from oil's price rise above $40 per barrel. The index ended the day up 0.4% despite mixed futures and a negative Europe opening.

site_title: F&N Q3 profit slips 3.5% at S$38.6m in absence of Myanmar beer
summary: F&N's third-quarter net profit slipped 3.5% to S$38.6m due to the absence of Myanmar Brewery's contributions. Excluding discontinued operations, profit rose 52.6% to S$38m. Revenue fell 4.1% to S$524m, driven by lower Malaysian beverages and printing revenues. Despite this, overall beverage revenue shrank 8.6% and Singapore beverages improved. The company expects subdued consumer sentiment in South-east Asia and will invest in digital businesses and new markets.

site_title: Toyota Q1 net profit down, cuts FY forecasts
summary: Toyota reported a 15% decline in Q1 net profit to 552.5 billion yen, due to a sharp yen rally and falling North American sales. Revenue fell 5.7% to 6.59 trillion yen. The company trimmed its FY forecasts, citing the yen's impact on competitiveness overseas. Toyota now expects 1.45 trillion yen in net profit and 26.0 trillion yen in revenue, down from previous forecasts of 1.5 trillion yen and 26.5 trillion yen. The yen's rally is attributed to volatile equity markets and the UK's Brexit vote.

site_title: Manulife profit below expectations, warns of C$500m charge
summary: Manulife Financial Corp reported second-quarter earnings below market expectations, with core earnings of C$833 million, down from C$902 million a year earlier. The company warned of a potential C$500 million charge in the third quarter due to an annual review of actuarial methods. Despite strong sales and new business growth in Asia, core earnings were impacted by low interest rates and market volatility. The company maintained a dividend of 18.5 Canadian cents a share and reported cost savings of C$450 million in the first half of the year.

images.alt_text: Canada's biggest life insurer, Manulife Financial Corp, posted second-quarter results which were below market expectations and warned of a charge of up to C$500 million (S$513 million) in the third quarter.

site_title: Analysts say another KL rate cut would push ringgit further down
summary: Malaysia's ringgit is Asia's worst-performing currency, with a 3.3% drop in the past three months. Analysts predict another interest rate cut, which would push the currency further down, with some predicting a 4.40 per dollar by the end of December. The decline is linked to oil prices, with Brent crude slumping 13% this quarter, and a political scandal surrounding a state investment fund. Economic growth is expected to slow to 4.2% for the year, the lowest since 2009.

images.alt_text: Both Rabobank and UBS predict Bank Negara Malaysia will add to its first rate cut in seven years in the coming months.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: DBS Group Holdings Ltd's ability to manage bad loans was questioned by JPMorgan analysts after the bank revealed potential losses from its S$700-million exposure to a troubled oil-services firm. Keppel refuted a report alleging bribery by its executives. Meanwhile, Vietnam was surprised by US Trump's tariff announcement, seeking a lower rate. The Asian garment industry is bracing for higher US tariffs.

images.alt_text: HDB resale prices rose 0.7 per cent in July compared to June.

site_title: UOL's Q2 profit eases 55% at S$68.8m on fair value losses on investment properties
summary: UOL Group's Q2 net earnings dropped 55% to S$68.8 million, primarily due to fair value losses on investment properties. Revenue grew 6% to S$363.6 million, driven by higher progressive revenue recognition from ongoing projects. Property development revenue increased 14% to S$185.5 million, despite the net earnings decline.

site_title: Eu Yan Sang loses free float after Teng Ngiek Lian's Target fund raises stake
summary: Eu Yan Sang International, a traditional Chinese medicine seller, has lost its free float after boutique fund manager Target Asset Management raised its stake to 5.04% in the company. The stake is now above the 10% threshold required by the Singapore Exchange, which may lead to trading suspension. The offeror and its concert parties control 80.76% of the group, and substantial shareholder Hillhouse Capital holds a 5.56% interest. Eu Yan Sang does not intend to keep the stock listed and may not take steps to lift the trading suspension.

site_title: Genting Singapore Q2 losses narrow to S$10.5m
summary: Genting Singapore reported a Q2 loss of S$10.5 million, narrowing from a loss of S$16.9 million in the same period last year, due to declining business in the VIP gaming segment. Revenue fell 17% to S$481 million. Adjusted ebitda slipped 61% to S$116 million from S$296 million. The decline in gaming revenue led to the reduced loss.

site_title: DBS's ability to manage bad loans questioned in JPMorgan report
summary: DBS Group Holdings Ltd, Singapore's largest lender, has faced a downgrade from JPMorgan Chase & Co due to potential losses from its S$700-million exposure to troubled oil-services firm Swiber Holdings Ltd. Analysts cut their rating to neutral and recommended investors sell the bank's stock ahead of its earnings announcement. DBS expects to recover only half of its exposure, setting aside provisions of S$150 million. This challenges the bank's ability to handle nonperforming loans, leading to a 6% cut in earnings forecasts for this year through 2018.

site_title: Nokia to cut deeper as merger spills red ink
summary: Nokia reported a net loss of 665 million euros in the second quarter due to costs from integrating Alcatel-Lucent. The company aims to achieve 1.2 billion euros in total cost savings by 2018. Net sales fell 11% and operating margin decreased to 6.0%. Nokia is expanding into internet networks and "cloud" services, abandoning the mobile handset market. The company expects slight sequential improvement in net sales and operating margin in the coming quarters. Markets were disappointed by the results, with Nokia shares plummeting 4.6%.

site_title: China charges three for stock futures manipulation
summary: China has formally charged three individuals for manipulating the stock futures market, following a share collapse in 2015. Two executives from Yishidun and an employee from China Fortune Futures were accused of using high-frequency trading software to buy and sell stock index futures under fake names. The three were arrested in November and Yishidun reaped gains of over 2 billion yuan. The charges are part of China's efforts to limit volatility in the market after a 40% decline in Shanghai's benchmark index. Authorities have since restricted trading with borrowed money.

site_title: Bank of England cuts rates for first time since 2009, restarts bond purchases
summary: The Bank of England cut interest rates for the first time since 2009, lowering the main lending rate to 0.25% to ease the economic impact of the UK's Brexit vote. The central bank also announced plans to buy 60 billion pounds of government debt and 10 billion pounds of corporate bonds to ensure banks keep lending. Policymakers expect the economy to stagnate in 2016 and 2017, with growth forecasts cut to 2.0% and 0.8% respectively, and inflation expected to rise to 2.4% by 2018.

site_title: Hyflux Q2 profit plunges 90% on higher staff and amortisation costs
summary: Hyflux' Q2 profit dropped 90% to S$2.6 million due to higher staff and amortisation costs despite a 174.3% revenue surge to S$260.0 million. Revenue growth was driven by the TuasOne waste-to-energy project and Qurayyat Independent Water Project. The decline in net profit was attributed to increased costs.

site_title: US factory orders fall, business spending shows signs of stabilising
summary: US factory orders fell 1.5% in June, the second straight month, due to weak demand for transportation equipment and capital goods. However, signs of stabilisation in business spending, such as a 0.4% increase in non-defense capital goods orders, offered hope for struggling industries. Manufacturing, accounting for 12% of the economy, has been pressured by a strong dollar and weak global demand, leading to a 1.2% annualised GDP growth rate in the second quarter.

site_title: Woman killed, five injured in central London knife attack
summary: A 19-year-old man with suspected mental health issues carried out a knife attack in central London's Russell Square, killing one woman and injuring five others. The attack, which occurred at 10:33 pm, is being investigated as a potential terrorist incident. Police used a Taser to arrest the suspect, and the investigation is being handled by the homicide command with counter-terrorism support. Britain's terrorist threat level remains at "severe," and police chiefs have warned of the risk of Islamic State attacks.

site_title: China: Stocks roughly flat as policy dilemmas cause uncertainty
summary: China's stocks ended flat on Thursday, despite a rally in other Asian markets, due to uncertainty over the government's economic stimulus policies. The CSI300 index rose 0.2%, while the Shanghai Composite Index gained 0.1%. The central bank and state planner, NDRC, signaled the use of monetary policy tools to stimulate the economy, but later deleted a reference to interest rate cuts, sparking concerns of policy rifts. The government faces a dilemma between stimulating the economy and preventing property price bubbles.

site_title: Pound volatility gauge climbs as traders brace for BOE rate cut
summary: The pound's volatility gauge climbed to a record high as traders awaited the Bank of England's policy decision, with a 100% chance of a rate cut forecast. Sterling fell 0.3% to $1.3287 and dropped to a 31-year low of $1.2798 on July 6. Overnight implied volatility reached 31%, the highest level since the EU referendum in June. Economists predict a 25 basis-point rate cut and potential expansion of the BOE's bond-purchase program to tackle a Brexit-induced economic fallout.

images.alt_text: A measure of overnight potential price swings for the pound against the dollar approached the highest closing level since Britain voted to leave the European Union in June as traders braced for the Bank of England's policy decision Thursday, which most economists forecast will bring the first interest-rate cut in seven years.

site_title: China's IPOs bring record 400%-a-month returns on supply curbs
summary: China's initial public offerings (IPOs) have reached a record-breaking 420% average return in their first month of trading, with 62 new stocks completing their first month of trading in 2016. The average size of IPOs has dwindled to $88 million, the smallest since 2005, as regulators seek to stabilize the nation's $6.1 trillion equity market. Despite a 16% decline in the Shanghai Composite Index in 2016, regulators are cautiously approving more IPOs, with over 800 companies waiting for approval.

site_title: Aviva Asia posts 23% drop in value of new business on weaker Singapore performance
summary: Aviva Asia reported a 23% year-on-year drop in value of new business (VNB) in the first six months of 2016, primarily due to a £10 million decrease in Singapore. The decline was largely attributed to the end of the bancassurance partnership with DBS. Despite this, higher sales in protection through the financial advisers network helped offset the loss. VNB for Asia fell to £61 million on a constant currency basis.

images.alt_text: INSURER Aviva Asia has reported a 23 per cent year-on-year fall in value of new business (VNB), a measure of the expected profits from new premiums written, in the first six months of 2016.

site_title: Merck KGaA lifts FY profit forecast on strong lab supplies
summary: Merck KGaA lifted its full-year earnings forecast due to strong growth at its lab supplies business, which saw 8.1% currency-adjusted sales growth in the second quarter. The company's Life Science business, boosted by the takeover of Sigma-Aldrich, also reported a 29% increase in adjusted Ebitda. Merck now expects earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortisation (Ebitda) to be 4.25-4.4 billion euros for 2016, up from a previous target range.

site_title: Europe: Stocks open higher before expected BoE cut
summary: Europe's stock markets rose on Thursday, with London's FTSE 100 index gaining 0.1%, Frankfurt's DAX 30 adding 0.6%, and Paris CAC 40 winning 0.5%, as investors await an expected interest rate cut from the Bank of England. The cut, expected at 1100 GMT, would mark the lowest level in the BoE's 322-year history. Asian equities also climbed, following a positive lead from Wall Street, ahead of the BoE rate call and US jobs data.

site_title: 43 recall exercises made for defective Takata airbags since 2013: LTA
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) in Singapore reports that 43 recall exercises have been conducted for defective Takata airbags since 2013, affecting approximately 130,000 airbag inflators across eight vehicle makes. As of now, 88% of recalled airbag inflators have been rectified, with 32% of those initiated in 2015 or later also fixed. Vehicle owners can check if their vehicle is affected by recalling the LTA's Electronic Vehicle Recall System (EVRS) or contacting their motor dealers.

images.alt_text: A TOTAL of 43 recall exercises have been made for vehicles affected by defective Takata airbags since the recalls were first initiated in Singapore in 2013, according to the Land Transport Authority (LTA) on Thursday.

site_title: First Ship Lease Trust posts 10.9% fall in Q2 profit
summary: First Ship Lease Trust reported a 10.9% decline in Q2 profit to US$5.49 million, down from US$6.16 million in the same period last year. Revenue fell 7.9% to US$25.3 million, primarily due to the disposal of two panamax containerships and softening tanker market rates.

site_title: British PM May promises to help small businesses navigate Brexit
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May is set to meet with small business owners on Thursday, promising to help them navigate the opportunities and challenges presented by Britain's vote to leave the European Union. May aims to foster a fairer economy, overhaul corporate governance, and boost productivity. She also plans to crack down on tax evasion and avoidance, and give the UK government a way to block foreign takeovers. The meeting comes as the UK economy faces concerns of a recession and a hit to consumer confidence following the Brexit vote.

site_title: Taiwan is Asia's hottest investment as China, tech concerns fade
summary: Taiwan has become Asia's hottest investment destination, with $5.4 billion in overseas funds pouring into its equities last month, taking the year's total to $11.6 billion. The island's stocks and currency have reached one-year highs, driven by bets on the upcoming iPhone 7 release and President Tsai Ing-wen's efforts to maintain peace with China. Despite concerns over a weaker currency and sluggish economy, Taiwan's high dividend yield and below-average valuations have attracted investors, with some predicting further gains.

site_title: AirAsia to launch sale of stake in leasing arm, could value unit at US$1b: sources
summary: AirAsia plans to sell a majority stake in its plane leasing unit, Asia Aviation Capital, valued at approximately US$1 billion. The sale, facilitated by three investment banks, aims to boost the airline's finances and reduce debt. Potential buyers include the leasing units of China's HNA Group, China Merchants Bank, and Hong Kong billionaire Li Ka-shing's CK group. The sale is expected to be completed by early next year, with AirAsia considering using the proceeds to pay down debt or distribute a special dividend.

site_title: UK car sales fell slightly in July after Brexit: preliminary data
summary: UK car sales fell slightly in July after Brexit, marking the first two-month decline in four and a half years, according to preliminary data. The decline was less than 1% year-on-year, with registrations growing for 43 consecutive months ending in October last year. The sales drop is attributed to the Brexit vote, which likely hit demand due to a lag in recording changes in demand. This marks the second decline in sales this year, following the June decline.

site_title: Noble Group's roller-coaster ride gathers pace with share price jump
summary: Noble Group's share price surged 12% to 14.8 Singapore cents as new rights shares began trading, reversing a 19% decline in the preceding two days. The stock closed 9.8% higher at 14.5 cents. The company's quarterly results, set to be released next week, will provide insight into its performance, funding, and plans for asset sales.

site_title: India eyes prompt GST launch, talk of 18% rate "premature": official
summary: India aims to implement a new Goods and Services Tax (GST) in April 2017, with Revenue Secretary Hasmukh Adhia targeting a 30-day ratification period by states. The official stated it would be "premature" to expect a 18% standard rate, citing potential revenue losses. The GST would transform India's US$2 trillion economy into a common market, with long-term growth benefits. However, tax experts warn that setting up a new IT system and training officials could cause the launch date to slip by six months, maintaining revenue neutrality.

site_title: Gold slips on firmer dollar; market awaits BoE policy decision
summary: Gold prices slipped 0.4% to $1,351.52 an ounce as the dollar firmed following strong economic data and Asian stocks' upward trend ahead of the Bank of England's expected interest rate cut. The BoE is expected to halve its benchmark interest rate to a record low of 0.25%. Investors anticipate the move to ward off recession following Britain's Brexit vote.

site_title: Bitfinex disables trading on exchange after hack
summary: Hong Kong-based digital currency exchange Bitfinex temporarily disabled trading, deposits, and withdrawals after a security breach on its website, resulting in the theft of approximately 120,000 bitcoins, valued at around $70 million. The breach is the second-largest bitcoin heist from an exchange since MtGox's $350 million loss in 2014. Bitfinex is working to restore limited service to its trading platform and is investigating the theft, which has led to a significant drop in the bitcoin price.

site_title: Insurer Aviva pumps out cash to keep payouts on track
summary: Aviva, a British insurer, reported a 13% increase in operating profit to £1.33 billion in the first half of 2016, driven by strong performance in its UK life insurance business. The company raised its interim dividend by 10% to 7.42pence per share, despite a challenging market backdrop. Aviva's capital surplus under Solvency II capital rules stood at £9.5 billion, enabling the company to maintain dividend payouts. Shares rose 4% following the announcement, with the company citing its strong financial position and resilience to external events.

site_title: Asia: Stocks mostly up after Wall Street rally
summary: Asian stock markets rose on Thursday following a positive lead from Wall Street, driven by expected Bank of England rate cuts and upbeat US jobs data. Oil prices extended gains, lifting energy and mining stocks. Key gains were seen in Sydney, Hong Kong, and Jakarta, while Tokyo shares slipped due to a stronger yen. The Bank of England is expected to cut interest rates and boost its bond-buying stimulus program, further supporting markets.

site_title: Seoul: Won, stocks close higher
summary: The South Korean won and shares rose on Thursday as investors anticipated a policy easing from the Bank of England. The won closed at 1,114.0 to the dollar, up 0.3%, while the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) rose 0.3% to 2,000.03 points. Offshore investors bought 42.7 billion won worth of Kospi shares.

site_title: Asean now more important for US firms' global bottom line; 8 in 10 see higher profits in 2017: poll
summary: A survey by the US Chamber of Commerce and AmCham Singapore found that 53% of senior American executives believe Asean is now more important for their global bottom line, with 78% expecting profits to increase next year. Asean's economic growth and the rise of the middle class are key drivers of this optimism. Respondents cited corruption, transparency, and good governance as top factors for regional integration. The US Chamber of Commerce emphasized the importance of ratifying the Trans-Pacific Partnership to strengthen the US-Asean trading relationship and prevent long-term economic negative impacts.

site_title: Seoul: Won, stocks edge up, investors await BOE policy meeting
summary: The South Korean won and stocks rebounded on Thursday following expectations of the Bank of England's monetary easing, boosting risk sentiment. The won rose 0.4% to 1,113.5 and the Kospi index gained 0.2% to 1,997.79 points. Steelmaker Posco rose 1.8% and software firm Samsung SDS Co Ltd gained 2.2%. Investors await the BoE policy meeting, expecting potential rate cuts and stimulus to support the market.

site_title: Thousands gather in Bangkok urging Thais to vote in their 'big day'
summary: Thousands of students, civil servants, and military cadets gathered in Bangkok to urge Thais to vote in a constitutional referendum on Sunday. The referendum aims to approve a military-backed constitution that could give the generals a permanent role in overseeing Thailand's economic development. The ruling junta claims the constitution will end divisive politics and ensure politicians prioritize people's interests, but critics say it will weaken political parties and allow the military to maintain control. An 80% turnout is expected, with 50 million Thais eligible to cast their votes.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks edge up; TSMC jumps
summary: Taiwan's main Taiex index rose 0.1% to 9,006.95, driven by a 0.9% gain in TSMC, the world's top contact chip maker. The electronics subindex also rose 0.3%, while the financials subindex fell 0.2%. The Taiwan dollar strengthened to NT$31.701 per US dollar.

site_title: Jokowi demands spending restraint as Indonesia budget gap widens
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo has called for spending curbs as the country's budget deficit widens to 2.5% of GDP, fueled by a shortfall in tax revenue and falling commodity prices. The government estimates a revenue gap of $22.5 billion. Widodo instructed ministries to reduce expenditure and study each point in detail, aiming to plug the budget deficit with additional funds. The country's economy grew 4.79% last year, the lowest since 2009, and is expected to expand 5% in the second quarter.

site_title: In demand: Singapore's Michelin-starred street food
summary: A Michelin-starred street food stall in Singapore's Chinatown, run by Chan Hon Meng, is struggling to meet the surge in demand following his one-star award. His soya sauce-braised chicken stall, which usually has a loyal customer base, now has a 100-person queue. Chan's award is part of the inaugural Singapore guide, launched in late July, which recognized two other hawkers as well. The sudden influx of new customers has overwhelmed the stall, with Chan working to keep up with orders.

site_title: Australia, New Zealand: Shares follow Wall Street higher
summary: Australian shares rose 0.4% to 5,487.2, defying weaker-than-expected retail sales numbers, driven by gains in the mining sector. Oil and gas producers Santos and Origin Energy surged, while miners such as Rio Tinto, BHP Billiton, and South32 also rose. Shares in vitamin maker Vitaco Holdings jumped 21% on a buyout by a China-led consortium, but the healthcare sector declined. New Zealand shares rose 0.1% to 7,287.51, tracking gains on Wall Street.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei ends a see-saw session higher, Idemitsu falls
summary: Japan's Nikkei share average rose 1.1% to 16,254.89, its first gain in three days, driven by bargain hunting after a see-sawing session. The index was boosted by financials, with large European banks reporting strong results. In contrast, refiner Idemitsu Kosan fell 7.7% after its founding family reportedly blocked its takeover bid for Showa Shell. The broader Topix and JPX-Nikkei Index 400 also rose, with the Nikkei closing above the 16,000 threshold for the first time in three days.

site_title: Update: British police say mental health a significant factor in London knife attack
summary: British police have confirmed that mental health was a significant factor in a knife attack in central London that left one woman dead and five people injured. The 19-year-old suspect, who is being held, is being investigated for possible terrorism as a motive. Police initially responded to the scene shortly before midnight and used a Taser gun during the arrest. The incident has raised concerns about the potential link between mental health and violent crime, with authorities urging caution in drawing conclusions.

site_title: Samsung Electronics expects Galaxy Note 7 sales to beat predecessor's
summary: Samsung Electronics expects sales for its new Galaxy Note 7 smartphone to exceed those of the previous version, according to the head of the company's mobile business. The exact sales targets were not disclosed. This marks a positive turn for the company, which faced significant issues with the recall of the previous Galaxy Note 7 model due to battery overheating concerns. The new Galaxy Note 7 was unveiled in New York and is expected to improve sales for the company.

site_title: US jobs data could be key to presidential campaign
summary: US jobs data is crucial in the presidential campaign, with the July employment report set to be released this week. The economy has grown at an annual rate of 2.1% since the recession ended in 2009, but the pace of expansion has been the weakest since 1949. Economists expect nonfarm employment to increase by 185,000 payrolls and the unemployment rate to dip to 4.8%. A disappointing jobs report could boost the Trump campaign's narrative of radical change being needed to boost the economy.

site_title: Singapore shares open marginally higher on Thursday
summary: Singapore shares opened 0.33% higher on Thursday, boosted by overnight gains on Wall Street. The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 9.43 points to 2,837.01, with 58.3 million shares traded worth S$107.5 million. Gainers outpaced losers 87 to 32. The rally came despite tariff uncertainty and split Fed views, with investors staying positive.

site_title: China's giant 'unicorn' Fosun races for more deals
summary: Chinese conglomerate Fosun has made a string of overseas investments, including a stake in an Indian drugmaker, a Brazilian investment firm, and plans to take a stake in Portugal's biggest private bank, in a bid to secure natural resources, open new markets, and gain access to foreign technology. Founded 24 years ago, Fosun has announced over $15 billion in overseas acquisitions since 2010, and its chairman, Guo Guangchang, has urged proceeding slowly to refine the company's existing products and services while seizing opportunities.

site_title: Brexit knocks growth in Irish services to 2 1/2-year low
summary: Ireland's services sector growth slowed to its weakest in almost two-and-a-half years in July, following Britain's vote to leave the European Union, according to a survey. The Investec Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) fell to 59.5, from 61.2 in June. Key factors contributing to the slowdown included a decline in new business, input prices, and employment, while new export business improved due to a boost from continental Europe and Asia. The government has cut its forecast for 2017 to 3.4% due to concerns of a worse post-Brexit deal with the EU.

site_title: Oil continues climb on mixed US data
summary: Oil prices continued their upward trend in Asia, rising 27 cents to $41.10 a barrel for US benchmark West Texas Intermediate and 21 cents to $43.31 for North Sea Brent.
