The rebound follows mixed US data, including a 0.3% increase in commercial crude oil supplies, but analysts caution that gains may be short-lived due to rising production and concerns about a supply glut. The market will continue to watch US trade and payroll data, as well as China's July trade balance, for further clues.

images.alt_text: Oil prices extended their rebound in Asia on Thursday following a mixed set of US stockpile data but analysts warn that the gains might not hold.

site_title: Australia PM says to bring banks before house economics committee each year
summary: Australia's Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull announced that the country's major banks will be brought before the parliament's economics committee annually to provide full accounts of their affairs, increasing transparency and accountability. This move comes after the banks refused to pass on a quarter-point interest rate cut, with Turnbull demanding top executives appear in public to explain themselves. The annual appearances will be part of the regular schedule for bank CEOs, with the goal of institutionalizing regular accountability and transparency in the banking system.

site_title: Australia dollar up on sterling ahead of BOE; NZ dollar off lows
summary: The Australian dollar rose 0.22% against the British pound to A$1.7514, ahead of the Bank of England's meeting where a rate cut is widely expected. Sterling has been trading in a tight range since the UK's Brexit vote, and dealers anticipate a potential further decline if the BOE takes aggressive action.

site_title: Boustead wins contract from AA Reit to build industrial property (Amended)
summary: Boustead Projects Limited has secured a design-and-build contract from AIMS AMP Capital Industrial REIT (AA Reit) to develop a five-storey industrial facility in Marsiling, Singapore. Construction is expected to commence soon and be completed by mid-2017, boosting the company's order book backlog to S$234 million.

site_title: HDB resale prices up 0.7% in July; transactions down 13.7%: SRX
summary: HDB resale prices rose 0.7% in July, with increases in three-room, four-room, and five-room flats, while executive flats decreased 0.4%. Year-on-year, prices have risen 0.8% since July 2015, but declined 10.9% since April 2013. Resale transactions fell 13.7% to 1,573 units in July, down from 1,823 in June. Resale volume was up 1.4% compared to July 2015 but down 56.9% compared to its peak in May 2010.

site_title: Choose your own future economy
summary: The Singapore government is planning its next long-term economic strategy, with the Committee for the Future Economy tasked to explore options. A committee is formed, led by Mani Inderbank, to examine five key issues: improving innovation and capabilities, identifying growth industries, harnessing connectivity, building the city of the future, and jobs and skills. The committee recommends a five-year plan, but the prime minister accepts a more incremental approach, planning for small, incremental changes in exchange for being right. The committee's findings are announced, focusing on building corporate capabilities and innovation, and the government plans to address this challenge by building big data infrastructure and providing incentives for corporate innovation.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks track Wall Street rally at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened higher on Thursday, following a positive lead from Wall Street, with the Hang Seng Index gaining 0.76% to 21,904.04. In contrast, the Shanghai Composite Index slipped 0.07% and the Shenzhen Composite Index edged down 0.06%. This follows a heavy sell-off in the previous session. The gains were attributed to the positive lead from Wall Street.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Ezra, Swiber, OUE, CapitaLand, Mapletree Commercial Trust, Frasers Commercial Trust
summary: Singapore stocks may see trading activity influenced by Wall Street's overnight rally and quarterly earnings results from companies such as Ezra Holdings, Swiber Holdings, and CapitaLand Limited. Despite oil and gas sector concerns, some developers like OUE Limited posted strong financial results. Real estate investment trusts (Reits) like Mapletree Commercial Trust and Frasers Commercial Trust also released capital-raising updates.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open higher, track Wall Street gains
summary: Tokyo shares rose 0.53% on Thursday, tracking gains on Wall Street after a two-session decline. The Nikkei 225 index opened at 16,168.34, while the Topix index climbed 0.37%. The gains followed a strong performance on US stock markets, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records despite ongoing trade tensions.

site_title: No break for ringgit as clouds gather over Malaysia
summary: The Malaysian ringgit faces another potential rate cut by Bank Negara Malaysia, with analysts predicting a further decline of over 2% by year-end. The currency's slide is linked to the decline in oil prices, which accounts for 20% of Malaysia's revenue. The nation's economy is expected to grow at 4.2% this year, the lowest since 2009, and the ringgit is expected to weaken to 4.10-4.15 per US dollar by year-end. The recent rate cut and ongoing scandals surrounding a troubled state investment fund are also affecting the currency's appeal.

site_title: Asia: Stocks rise after posting biggest daily drop in five weeks
summary: Asian stocks rebounded 0.3% to 134.64, their biggest daily gain in five weeks, after Japanese shares climbed and material companies led gains. Commodity producers and technology companies drove the rally, while commodity producers and technology companies led gains. The Bank of England is set to cut rates to a record later Thursday, according to economists. Asian equities have retreated after their best month since March, with concerns over Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's economic program and weak economic data.

site_title: Harvard grads win Sequoia funding for Indonesian lending startup
summary: Indonesian lending startup Modalku, co-founded by two Harvard alumni, secured a 100 billion rupiah (S$10.3 million) Series A funding round led by Sequoia India. The company, which matches loan-seeking businesses with investors, has a 0-per cent default rate on its loans since launching in January. Modalku aims to expand its services across Indonesia, with plans to enter new markets, including Bandung, next month. The funding will accelerate the company's mission to empower small and medium-sized enterprises in Indonesia.

site_title: Nike will stop making golf equipment as Tiger Woods's star fades
summary: Nike will stop selling golf equipment, citing declining sales and a loss of appeal, particularly among millennials. The company will continue to sell golf footwear and apparel, with a focus on innovation and growth. The decision follows a 8.2% decline in golf sales, the worst performance among major categories. The golf business was built around Tiger Woods, but his star has faded since a car accident in 2009, and the sport's overall popularity has declined in recent years.

site_title: Samsung said in talks to buy assets of Fiat auto-parts unit
summary: Samsung Electronics is in talks to acquire Fiat Chrysler Automobiles' (FCA) auto-parts unit, Magneti Marelli, in a deal potentially worth over $3 billion. The acquisition would help Samsung decrease its reliance on consumer electronics and expand its presence in the automotive industry. Vice Chairman Lee Jae Yong is reshaping the company, selling off assets and narrowing its scope, as he seeks to bounce back from a smartphone downturn. The deal could position Samsung to benefit from the rising interest in cars from technology companies like Apple and Google.

site_title: MCT places out 364.88 million new units at S$1.45 each
summary: MAPLETREE Commercial Trust (MCT) is placing 364.88 million new units at S$1.45 each, pricing the private placement at the top end of its indicative range. The issue will increase its total units to 2.5 billion.

site_title: Billionaire Klarman slams Trump, vows to work for Clinton
summary: Billionaire hedge fund manager Seth Klarman has pledged to work for Hillary Clinton's presidential campaign, criticizing Donald Trump's comments as "shockingly unacceptable." Klarman, who manages $29 billion, had previously supported Republican candidates, but his recent statements suggest a shift towards supporting the Democratic nominee. Klarman's comments come after Trump suggested the election might be rigged and made controversial remarks about Muslim parents of a decorated American soldier. Klarman's support for Clinton could potentially boost her campaign, given his significant financial resources and influence.

images.alt_text: Billionaire hedge fund manager Seth Klarman said on Wednesday he would work to get Hillary Clinton elected president of the United States because he finds recent comments by Donald Trump "shockingly unacceptable."

site_title: Yum! Brands, McDonald's look for buyers as Chinese tastes shift
summary: Yum! Brands and McDonald's are exploring spinoffs of their Chinese operations as the fast food industry shifts towards healthier options and local flavors. The companies, which dominated the market in 2015, face declining shares as consumers increasingly prefer Chinese-style food chains. Analysts question whether the "glory days" of super-sized growth are over, as KFC and Golden Arches' market dominance begins to slip.

site_title: Japan Foods Q1 net profit up 24%
summary: Japan Foods Holding Ltd reported a 24.1% jump in net profit to S$1.3 million for the first quarter, driven by 6.4% growth in revenue to S$16.8 million. Higher revenue from increased stores and better gross profit margins contributed to the performance. Group executive chairman and CEO Takahashi Kenichi emphasized the need to innovate and update restaurants to stay competitive in the intensifying industry.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Thursday with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index up 3.15 points to 1,651.65. The index had 88 gainers and 36 losers, with a total trading volume of 36.7 million lots worth RM8.9 million.

site_title: Indonesian tax amnesty pitch: bring it home to a new home
summary: Indonesia is promoting a tax amnesty program, allowing citizens to repatriate billions of dollars in offshore assets and bring them back home to invest in property, with the aim of securing at least $30 billion. The program, which must be completed by March 2017, offers a 2-5% tax rate in exchange for a pardon for past tax evasion. Property developers are targeting wealthy individuals, including Indonesian tycoons, to invest in the market, which is expected to see a 5-10% boost in the high-end property market.

site_title: Democracy's left-behinds challenging the system
summary: Western capitalist democracy is shifting towards fear-driven politics due to faltering economies and a perceived disconnect between politicians and citizens. The US and Britain's recent decisions to leave the EU and elect Donald Trump as president reflect this trend. A growing mistrust in government, fueled by economic disparities and ineffective leadership, is leading to a rise in authoritarianism and populism. The erosion of trust in institutions has resulted in a focus on personal sentiment and misinformation, with both Trump and Brexit campaigns relying on emotional appeals rather than facts.

site_title: US dollar slips ahead of jobs data, BoE meet in focus
summary: The US dollar slipped ahead of the release of jobs data and a Bank of England meeting. The ADP report showed the US added 179,000 jobs in July, slightly more than expected, but the official job figures are due on Friday. The US dollar is under pressure as traders wait for the jobs data, while the Bank of England meeting is expected to influence interest rates. The BoE meeting is scheduled for Thursday, with traders watching for any changes to monetary policy.

images.alt_text: The US dollar was under pressure Thursday as upbeat jobs data did little to boost hopes for a US interest rate rise, while traders also eyed a Bank of England meeting.

site_title: Big tech may halt earnings recession, if it delivers Q3 numbers
summary: Technology heavyweights such as Facebook and Alphabet may prevent a US earnings recession from extending into a fifth quarter with strong Q3 numbers, according to analysts. Despite a decline in other sectors' expectations due to global growth concerns and the US dollar's strength, technology's improved third-quarter analyst expectations offer a bright spot. Analysts expect profit growth in consumer discretionary and materials sectors, but overall earnings growth remains uncertain.

site_title: Australia orders climate change U-turn at peak science body
summary: Australia's re-elected conservative government has announced a U-turn on climate change policy, reinstating climate science as a key function of its peak science body, the Commonwealth Science and Industrial Research Organisation (Csiro). The new Science Minister, Greg Hunt, has announced 15 new climate science jobs and $37 million in research investment over 10 years. The move reverses severe cuts made by the previous government, which had axed hundreds of jobs and slashed funding. The decision is seen as a positive step by some climate scientists, but others warn that the damage has already been done and more needs to be done.

site_title: OUE swings into the black in Q2
summary: OUE Limited reported a net profit of S$25.7 million in Q2, reversing a net loss of S$16.3 million in the same period last year. Revenue jumped 40.4% to S$134.3 million, driven by strong property investments and development. The company also saw higher sales at OUE Twin Peaks, with over 100 units sold in the quarter. Despite a slight dip in hospitality division revenue, the board proposed an interim tax-exempt dividend of one cent per share and a special tax-exempt dividend of two cents per share.

site_title: UN asked to investigate North Korea missile tests
summary: The United Nations has been requested to investigate North Korea's recent ballistic missile tests, with 11 countries, including the US and Japan, calling for targeted sanctions against individuals and companies involved in the missile program. The launch of three Scud ballistic missiles and an intermediate-range missile in July 18 has prompted concerns of further significant measures by the Security Council. China, North Korea's ally, and Russia did not back the request, while the US and Japan have urged the council to take action, including a global visa ban and assets freeze.

site_title: Keppel refutes report alleging bribery by executives
summary: Keppel Corp has denied allegations of bribery by its executives in Brazil. The company responded to a Bloomberg article alleging that former third-party commercial representative Zwi Skornicki bribed public officials on behalf of Keppel in exchange for Petrobras contracts. Keppel stated that none of its top executives authorized Skornicki to make such payments. The allegations were made in criminal proceedings against Skornicki in Brazil. Keppel's CEO, Chow Yew Yuen, was also named in the article but denied any involvement.

site_title: Europe: Shares end steady as banks gain, Fiat rallies
summary: European shares ended flat on Wednesday as struggling banks rebounded, while Fiat Chrysler rallied 8.2% after a report on potential sale of its parts unit. Despite this, the Stoxx 600 index remains down 8% for the year, with concerns over bad debts and weak balance sheets persisting. Some banks, such as HSBC and ING, rose after reporting better-than-expected profits, but UniCredit fell 2.3% after posting a surprise decline in core capital.

site_title: SunEdison India sale said to draw Khazanah, billionaire Hindujas
summary: Hinduja Group and Malaysian sovereign fund Khazanah Nasional Bhd are among parties vying for SunEdison Inc's Indian solar assets, valued at around $700 million including debt. The US clean-power giant, which filed for bankruptcy protection in April, has drawn interest from Tata Power, Greenko Energies, and Sembcorp Industries. A deal could be finalized in about a month, with Hinduja Group potentially preferring bidders with an existing presence in India.

site_title: Eight West Coast blocks picked for redevelopment
summary: The Singapore government has identified eight West Coast blocks for redevelopment under its "selective en bloc redevelopment scheme" (Sers). Residents of 994 flats in Blocks 513-520 will be offered new flats at two sites, with construction to begin in 2017 and completion in 2022. Residents can choose to stay in the new flats or opt for compensation, a new flat elsewhere, or selling their Sers flat with rehousing benefits. The Sers plan also involves compensation for commercial property owners, with options to buy a new unit or receive an ex-gratia payment.

site_title: Thai central bank leaves key rate alone, sees higher risks to economic growth
summary: The Bank of Thailand kept its key interest rate unchanged at 1.5% as expected, citing accommodative monetary conditions supporting economic recovery. However, economists predict growth to slow in the second half of the year, with some expecting a rate cut by end-2016. Downside risks to the economy have increased, despite a forecast of 3.1% GDP growth this year, with exports contracting for a fourth year. The central bank also noted that the baht's appreciation may not be beneficial to the economy.

site_title: CapitaLand Q2 net profit down 36.6%
summary: CapitaLand Limited reported a 36.6% drop in Q2 net profit to S$294 million, mainly due to higher cost of sales and lower fair value gains. Operating PATMI fell 33% to S$171.6 million, excluding a one-off gain from development projects. However, contributions from shopping malls, China, and Singapore's CapitaGreen and serviced residence business supported earnings. Excluding the gain, operating PATMI would have grown 31.8%.

site_title: Cuba chooses French firms to expand airport as tourism booms
summary: Cuba has chosen two French firms, Bouygues and Aeroports de Paris SA, to modernize and expand its Jose Marti International Airport in Havana due to a surge in tourism. The number of foreign visitors to Cuba jumped 12% in the first half of 2016, setting the country on track for a new annual record. The airport project aims to improve services and invest in infrastructure to cope with the growing demand. Cuba's reliance on tourism is increasing as exports decline due to falling global commodities prices and reduced oil shipments from Venezuela.

site_title: SGTI 2016: How the scoring is done
summary: The Singapore Governance and Transparency Index (SGTI) evaluates companies on their corporate governance practices and disclosures. For SGTI 2016, 631 SGX-listed companies were assessed, with scores based on five areas: board responsibilities, shareholder rights, stakeholder engagement, accountability and audit, and disclosure and transparency. The SGTI score has two components: base score and adjustment for bonuses and penalties, with reports and advice on the scoring methodology available on the Centre for Governance, Institutions and Organisations' website.

site_title: Argentina to see 'concrete growth' by end of year: finance minister
summary: Argentina's finance minister, Alfonso Prat-Gay, predicts "concrete growth" by the end of the year due to free-market reforms under President Mauricio Macri. The country has unwound protectionist policies, lifting capital controls and easing import restrictions. Macri's government inherited a struggling economy from Cristina Fernandez and has freed up access to dollars. Despite some slow-to-recover sectors, Prat-Gay believes the nation is "much better off than many thought."

site_title: Pokemon Go creators launch game in Rio ahead of Games
summary: Pokémon Go has been released in Brazil ahead of the Rio Olympics, which start on Friday. The game's creators, Niantic, confirmed the rollout across Central and South America, including Brazil, after some athletes had already been playing it. The game's launch comes despite concerns over player safety, particularly in Brazil where crime and public finances are strained. The game has already drawn attention from athletes, with some expressing disappointment that it was not widely available before the Olympics.

site_title: Fed's Kashkari to spend day in life of struggling black family
summary: Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis President Neel Kashkari spent a day with a black family struggling to make ends meet, aiming to understand the challenges of poverty. The experience, he said, makes anecdotes about economic inequality more real and influences his thinking on the issue. Kashkari, who has faced criticism for the Fed's lack of diversity, is committed to improving diversity on the Fed's boards of directors. His effort comes as national poverty levels among blacks stand at 26%, more than double those for whites, and racial tensions worsen following recent fatal police shootings of black men.

site_title: Cabinet reshuffle: Abe signals priorities beyond Abenomics
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe has announced key appointments in a Cabinet reshuffle, signaling his intention to press ahead with constitutional revision and potentially run for a further term in office. Key positions remained unchanged, but Abe replaced Defence Minister Gen Nakatani with ultra-conservative politician Tomomi Inada, who shares Abe's ambition for constitutional revision. The appointment comes as pro-reformers in the ruling Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) hold a two-thirds majority in the Diet, legally required to propose the amendment.

site_title: US dollar gains on currency markets after encouraging jobs data
summary: The US dollar strengthened against major currencies, including the euro and pound, following encouraging jobs data. The euro fell to $1.1148, while the US dollar rose against the yen to 101.25. A private payroll firm reported 179,000 new jobs in July, up 1.7% from the prior month, and a private survey of the US services sector showed continued growth. This data eases concerns about US economic data, which may lead to a hike in US interest rates.

images.alt_text: The US dollar strengthened on Wednesday against major currencies, including the euro and the pound, following the release of encouraging jobs data.

site_title: Republicans mull Clinton amid repeated Trump stumbles
summary: US Republicans are increasingly considering voting for Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton amid Donald Trump's deepening controversies. Prominent conservatives, including tech executive Meg Whitman and former House Speaker Newt Gingrich, have defected to the Clinton camp. Trump's refusal to endorse House Speaker Paul Ryan, crass language, and refusal to end his feud with the parents of a fallen Muslim American soldier have raised concerns about his ability to lead. Other high-profile Republicans, such as former Secretary of State Richard Armitage and former Senator Larry Pressler, have also endorsed Clinton, highlighting the party's growing unease with Trump's candidacy.

site_title: Austrian Chancellor suggests ending EU accession talks with Turkey
summary: Austrian Chancellor Christian Kern suggested ending EU accession talks with Turkey due to the country's democratic and economic deficits. European leaders have raised concerns over Turkish President Tayyip Erdogan's crackdown on suspected dissidents and his proposal to reintroduce the death penalty. Kern stated that accession talks are a "diplomatic fiction" and that Turkey's economic situation is far from the European average, making its accession to the EU unjustified.

site_title: BOE chief to quantify impact on UK economy after Brexit vote
summary: Bank of England Governor Mark Carney will present a detailed assessment of the UK economy's impact after the Brexit vote on Thursday. The assessment aims to balance a realistic picture of the economy's future with the risk of being labelled a doom-monger. The UK may be headed for recession, according to initial reports. Carney will also outline his plan of action to address the economic uncertainty.

site_title: UK economy shrinking at fastest since '09
summary: The UK economy is shrinking at its fastest rate since the 2008-09 financial crisis, with a 0.4% decline in the three months to September, according to Markit's PMI. This has raised the chances of a mild recession, with economists predicting a Bank of England rate cut on Thursday. The unexpected drop in business activity is attributed to the June EU vote, and confidence among firms has fallen to its lowest level since February 2009. A quarter-point cut in interest rates is expected, but the extent and nature of other non-standard stimulus measures remain uncertain.

site_title: Jakarta pins hopes on underground transit system
summary: Jakarta is investing heavily in its underground mass rapid transit (MRT) system, which aims to alleviate the city's notorious gridlock. Four tunnel boring machines are making progress beneath the city, with the first half of the 27km network expected to be completed by early 2019. However, landowners near the southern terminus are refusing to sell, and the government is using legislation passed last year to limit their holdouts. Despite the challenges, the MRT project may be a turning point for Jakarta, which needs around $20 billion to keep up with Indonesia's rapid urbanization.

site_title: US: Higher oil prices, jobs data boost stocks
summary: US stocks rose on Wednesday, driven by solid hiring data and a rise in oil prices. The Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 0.2%, while the S&P 500 rose 0.3% and the Nasdaq Composite Index advanced 0.4%. Key gains were seen in Apple, Bank of America, Goldman Sachs, and Twitter, while AIG surged 7.3% after reporting better earnings. Conversely, Kate Spade plummeted 18.2% after slashing its full-year forecast.

site_title: Oil prices rise as US reports mixed data
summary: Oil prices rose by $1.32 to $40.83 a barrel for West Texas Intermediate and $1.30 to $43.10 a barrel for North Sea Brent, after several days of losses. The US Energy Department released mixed data on US production and inventories, showing commercial crude oil supplies up 0.3% but gasoline inventories down 1.4%. Analyst James Williams said the data was mixed and did not clearly correspond to market conditions, citing excessive crude oil inventories and declining gasoline stocks.

site_title: Obama determined to push TPP through
summary: US President Barack Obama is determined to push the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) through Congress before his term ends, despite opposition from Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump. Obama stated that if the US fails to establish high standards for trade in Asia-Pacific, China's rules will apply. The TPP has just five months left before Obama leaves office, and he believes he has the better argument to support the agreement.

site_title: Brexit impact flowing through to S'pore PMI
summary: Singapore's July Nikkei purchasing managers' index (PMI) fell to 50.7, down 1.6 from June, indicating a slight improvement in private-sector health but weighed down by reduced new export sales amid sluggish global economic conditions. The decline is attributed to Brexit uncertainty, China's slowdown, and a weaker domestic climate. Economists warn that Brexit's impact will be felt in the months or years ahead, with investment and trade decisions continuing to be affected by uncertainty.

site_title: Seoul to limit old diesel vehicles to fight air pollution
summary: Seoul, South Korea, will limit old diesel vehicles to fight air pollution. Starting in 2017, vehicles registered before 2006 weighing 2.5 tonnes or more will be restricted to "low emission zones" unless equipped with emission-reducing devices or low-pollution engines. A penalty of 200,000 won will be issued for non-compliant vehicles, and a diesel car scrappage program will be implemented. The goal is to bring Seoul's air quality to European standards within a decade. This move follows similar restrictions in other major European cities, such as Paris and London.

site_title: Firm backed by Alibaba founders in talks to seed new hedge fund
summary: Blue Pool Capital, backed by Alibaba founders, is in talks to seed a new pan-Asia hedge fund led by former Balyasny Asset Management executive Avinash Abraham. The market-neutral fund will invest in rising and falling stocks, and will be managed by Abraham and other hires from Merricks Capital Services. This deal comes as Asian hedge funds face redemption pressures, with investor withdrawals cutting regional industry assets by 10% in the first half of the year.

site_title: AIG buying back US$3b of stock as asset sales boost profit
summary: AIG reports a 6.3% increase in net income to $1.91 billion, or $1.68 a share, in the second quarter, driven by asset sales. The insurer also announced plans to buy back $3 billion of stock. Operating profit rose to 98 cents a share, beating analyst estimates. AIG's CEO, Peter Hancock, has been selling assets and slashing jobs to boost margins, with a goal to return $25 billion to shareholders over two years.

site_title: Harry Potter script makes record UK and US sales
summary: A new Harry Potter script, "Harry Potter And The Cursed Child," has achieved record sales in the UK and US, with over 680,000 copies sold in Britain and more than 2 million copies sold in the US within the first two days. The script's success surpasses that of other bestselling books, including "The Lost Symbol" and "An Inspector Calls." Despite initial sales falling short of those of the final Harry Potter novel, the script's popularity is expected to continue, with additional tickets set to go on sale for performances until 2017.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Sembcorp Industries shares were recommended to buy with a target price of S$3.07, after closing at S$2.74 on August 3, 2016.

site_title: Better for CCT to redevelop Golden Shoe site sooner
summary: Speculation resurfaces that CapitaLand Commercial Trust (CCT) may begin redeveloping Golden Shoe Car Park in Singapore's Raffles Place financial district. Rumors suggest retail tenants will be told to vacate the site by mid-2024, with some on short-term leases. The 10-storey building offers 1,053 car parking lots and a hawker center. Redevelopment could provide a prime opportunity for CCT to increase property value.

site_title: 'Nightmare' Vancouver home tax threatens foreign tech talent
summary: Vancouver's tech industry faces a threat from a new 15% levy on overseas property investors, which may deter foreign talent and hinder the city's goal of becoming a Canadian Silicon Valley. The city already struggles with high housing costs and low wages, making it an unattractive destination for tech workers. The move is a surprise and has been described as a "nightmare" by a Singaporean computer scientist relocating to Vancouver. The levy is part of British Columbia's push to rein in spiraling home prices, but it may have unintended consequences for the city's tech sector.

site_title: Baidu, Tencent retreat from US$3b tie-up
summary: Baidu and Tencent have withdrawn from a $3 billion venture with Dalian Wanda Group, a Chinese billionaire's company, just two years after its launch. The venture, ffan.com, aimed to revolutionize mall shopping by helping shoppers find products and merchants manage payments and data. However, Baidu and Tencent were replaced as shareholders by a company backed by Wang Jianlin as of July 7. The reasons for the withdrawal are unclear, marking a significant setback for the ambitious project.

site_title: IOC berates anti-doping agency at meeting just before Games
summary: The International Olympic Committee (IOC) has defended its decision not to bar Russia from the Rio Games entirely, citing concerns about "death and devastation" if a blanket ban were implemented. US Olympic Committee chairman Larry Probst expressed support for the IOC's decision, acknowledging that the current system is broken and needs to be fixed. The IOC has instead asked individual sports federations to scrutinize Russian athletes, with the World Anti-Doping Agency (WADA) facing criticism for its handling of the doping scandal.

site_title: BreadTalk's Q2 profit crumbles 54.8% to S$1.3m
summary: BreadTalk Group reported a 54.8% decline in Q2 net profit to S$1.3 million, largely due to a 3.3% drop in revenue to S$149.8 million. The bakery division's revenue fell 2% year-on-year, while the food atrium division declined 5%. In contrast, the restaurant division delivered 6.3% revenue growth to S$73.5 million. BreadTalk expects its bakery division to remain on the recovery path and will focus on cost control.

site_title: StarHub rings in 9.6% rise in Q2 earnings
summary: StarHub, a Singaporean telecommunications company, reported a 9.6% increase in Q2 net profit to S$108.6 million, driven by lower costs and increased broadband revenue. Despite a 0.6% dip in revenue, the company's Ebitda margin rose to 34.2%. Mobile service revenue declined 1.8% due to lower usage, but was partially offset by an increase in post-paid mobile subscribers. The company announced an interim dividend of S$0.05 per share and revised its 2016 service revenue outlook to be at about 2015's level.

site_title: Oil and gas sector facing S$1b bond redemptions by next year
summary: Swiber Holdings' collapse is raising concerns about a potential domino effect on its peers in the oil and gas sector. Several Singapore-listed oil-and-gas firms have bonds maturing this year and next, totaling S$970 million, and fears are growing about how these issues will be refinanced due to the bond markets being largely closed to offshore marine issuers. Some issuers, such as Ausgroup and Ezra Holdings, are in discussions with bondholders, while others, like KS Energy, are seeking buyers for their assets.

site_title: India Parliament to vote on new sales tax
summary: India's Upper House of Parliament is set to vote on the Goods and Services Tax (GST), a major tax reform that has been held up by political in-fighting. The proposed tax is expected to boost India's economy, which is already the world's fastest-growing large economy, expanding by 7.9% year on year. The vote requires a two-thirds majority and will kick off a legislative marathon to pass further laws setting the rate and scope of the GST. The reform aims to provide a non-inflationary and efficient way of taxing without tax evasion.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Otto Marine initiated arbitration proceedings against Robert Knutzen Shipholdings Ltd for alleged default on charter parties, totaling over $2.83 million. k1 Ventures reported a 463.9% surge in earnings to $140.6 million, driven by investment income from portfolio company Knowledge Universe Holdings. Acromec Ltd secured a $10.3 million contract for a Class 100 research cleanroom.

site_title: Strong outlook for Singapore office sector in medium term
summary: Singapore's commercial real estate sector is expected to remain a compelling opportunity over the medium term, despite current subdued economic conditions. Strong demand fundamentals, including a steady stream of businesses setting up offices and growing inbound investment, support the sector. A moderate 5% decline in CRE prices is forecast for 2016, with prime office spaces expected to remain in demand due to the city-state's ease of doing business and status as a global financial and regional business centre. The supply pipeline is expected to taper off after 2019, lending support to an uptick in rents and capital values.

site_title: Investor confidence in S'pore takes a hit, post-Brexit
summary: Investor confidence in Singapore's economy took a hit after the UK's Brexit vote, with a survey finding the index at 101, four points down from pre-Brexit levels. Local retail investors became more bearish, with 30% expecting the local economy to improve in the next six months, down from 33% pre-Brexit. Despite the bearish sentiment, 85% of respondents planned to maintain or increase their investments, with a focus on diversification to navigate the uncertain global economy.

site_title: Jinjiang Environment makes debut on SGX mainboard
summary: Jinjiang Environment Holding Co Ltd debuted on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) with its stock opening at S$0.885, below its IPO price of S$0.90 per share. The stock rose to a day's high of S$0.915. This marks the company's entry into the mainboard of the Singapore Exchange.

site_title: SGX formal offer for Baltic Exchange could be in soon
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) is reportedly preparing a formal offer to buy the Baltic Exchange, a 1744-established British institution, with a potential deal valued between US$80 million and US$120 million. The offer, expected to be submitted by August 31, follows months of exclusive talks between the two parties. SGX aims to grow products adjacent to its iron-ore contracts and maintain the Baltic Exchange's headquarters in London, along with its market benchmark production and governance model.

site_title: SISV comes up with own indices to track suburban condos (Amended)
summary: The Singapore Institute of Surveyors and Valuers (SISV) has launched an index series to track resale transactions of completed condominiums in suburban regions. The index, which was launched at the Singapore Realtors Conference 2016, shows that average prices in the East and West regions have softened to levels last seen five years ago, while average prices in the North and North-East are generally still higher than in 2011. The index is not designed for predictive forecasting, but rather to inform investors of price movements on a quarterly basis.

images.alt_text: JOINING the bandwagon of index providers tracking residential price movements here, the Singapore Institute of Surveyors and Valuers (SISV) has come up with an index series to track resale transactions of completed condominiums in the suburban region.

site_title: Tesla loss widens as company works to speed production
summary: Tesla reported a net loss of $293.2 million, or $2.09 per share, in the second quarter, exceeding expectations. Revenue rose to $1.27 billion, driven by strong demand for its electric cars. The company delivered 14,402 new vehicles, falling short of its 17,000 vehicle production target. Tesla is speeding up production to meet demand, with plans to deliver approximately 50,000 new Model S and Model X vehicles during the second half of 2016. CEO Elon Musk stated that vehicle production efficiency is improving rapidly.

site_title: PM Lee expresses hope that US engagement in Asia will continue
summary: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong of Singapore expressed hope that the US will continue its rebalancing towards Asia, maintaining its healthy presence in the region. He welcomed the US engagement, citing its benefits for both the region and the US, securing peace and stability in the Asia-Pacific. Lee noted Singapore's bipartisan approach to US leadership, stating it would work with any administration. US President Barack Obama echoed Lee's sentiments, predicting strong people-to-people ties between the two nations 50 years from now.

images.alt_text: PM Lee (centre) speaking at the luncheon hosted by US Secretary of State John Kerry (right) and US Vice-President Joe Biden (left) at the US Department of State in Washington DC on Tuesday.

site_title: Higher taxes erode Q1 DPU for RHT Health Trust
summary: RHT Health Trust, formerly Religare Health Trust, reported a 13.2% decline in net profit to S$10.7 million in Q1, primarily due to higher corporate taxes and finance costs. Revenue edged up 0.1% to S$35.4 million, driven by a contractual increase in base fees and higher variable fees. Distributable income fell 2% to S$15.1 million, leading to a 7.7% drop in DPU to 1.79 Singapore cents. The trust plans to distribute 95% of its distributable income, impacting earnings per unit and net asset value per unit.

site_title: HSBC's up-to-US$2.5b buyback takes sting out of H1 profit fall
summary: HSBC reported a 29% drop in first-half pre-tax profit to $9.7 billion, primarily due to slowing growth in its home markets. However, the bank's shares rose 1.9% after announcing a $2.5 billion share buyback. This move is intended to boost investor confidence and mitigate the impact of the profit decline. Despite the share price increase, the bank's profit fall was still below the average estimate of $10 billion compiled by Thomson Reuters.

site_title: China's robotics rush shows how its debt can get out of control
summary: China's municipalities are rapidly expanding robotics parks, despite warning signs of overcapacity, as part of the country's "Made in China 2025" initiative. Dozens of cities, including Wuhu, are planning robotics parks with government-backed financing vehicles (LGFVs), which have contributed to China's high debt burden. LGFVs have been used to fund infrastructure projects, often with high-interest rates and implicit government backing, allowing companies to borrow despite weak credit metrics. This financing model has raised concerns about duplication, risk, and the lack of transparency, as Beijing's support for local projects can lead to overinvestment and debt issues.

site_title: Banks can sow goodwill during crisis - restructure debtors' finances
summary: Singapore's offshore marine services firms, heavily impacted by falling oil prices, are seeking refuge from creditors under judicial management. Two listed entities, Swiber Holdings, have taken this route, signaling the sector's financial struggles. Banks, particularly the largest in South-east Asia, are being scrutinized for their capital buffers to withstand the sector's downturn. While OCBC and UOB's capital buffers remain sufficient, experts warn of potential systemic risk if distressed firms default. Lenders, including DBS, are advised to restructure debtor finances early to prevent such risks, and banks must closely monitor lending activity to prevent a credit crunch.

site_title: Husky, Cnooc resolve Liwan gas dispute
summary: Husky Energy Inc. and China's state-owned Cnooc Ltd have resolved a dispute over gas prices from the Liwan offshore project, settling an overhang on Husky's shares. The agreement reduces prices paid for gas output by about 13%, with Husky to receive between C$12.50 and C$15 per thousand cubic feet. The deal also allows for the development of Liuhua 29-1, a field at Liwan, adding to the project's growth. The agreement is seen as a positive for Husky and foreign operators in China, indicating a commitment to indigenous gas development.

site_title: Enhancing corporate governance in Singapore companies
summary: Singapore's 2016 Governance and Transparency Index (SGTI) reports an all-time high mean score of 49.7 points among 631 listed companies, with the top scoring company reaching a record 124 points. The index, which assesses board responsibilities, shareholder rights, stakeholder engagement, accountability, and disclosure, shows significant improvements in areas such as director appraisal and whistleblower policies. However, areas like interested person transactions and stakeholder engagement require further attention, with many companies lacking adequate disclosures and policies.

site_title: Mubadala award brightens up M'sia O&G sector
summary: Mubadala Petroleum has awarded the front-end engineering and design (Feed) contract for its Pegaga gas field development in Malaysia to Aker Engineering Malaysia Sdn Bhd. The award marks a significant move to revive Malaysia's oilfield services sector, which has been stagnant due to a lack of upstream contracting activity. The Feed award is expected to lead to a $1 billion engineering, procurement, construction, installation, and commissioning (Epcic) contract, generating billions of dollars in contracting opportunities. The project, backed by Abu Dhabi's sovereign wealth fund, is seen as a promising development despite the ongoing oil price downturn.

site_title: Are there other Swibers lurking in DBS's balance sheet?
summary: DBS, Singapore's largest lender, faces scrutiny over its exposure to oil-rig company Swiber, which filed for liquidation. The bank had a $700 million exposure to Swiber, representing 92% of the company's equity, and expected to recover half. This raises concerns about DBS's lending practices and potential nonperforming assets. The bank's CEO, Piyush Gupta, was questioned about oil-related loans on a previous earnings call, but did not provide a clear answer. Shareholders may want to review DBS's exposure to the oil industry to avoid similar surprises in the future.

site_title: UK retailer Next says no big Brexit impact so far as sales pick up
summary: UK retailer Next reported a pickup in sales for its second quarter, with no significant impact from Britain's Brexit vote. Despite consumer confidence surveys showing a drop following the June 23 vote, Next's sales have remained steady. This contrasts with concerns over a potential economic slowdown.

site_title: M&C posts 11.6% drop in Q2 profit to £38m
summary: MILLENNIUM & Copthorne Hotels (M&C), a London-listed hotel arm of Singapore's City Developments Limited, reported an 11.6% drop in profit before tax to £38m in its second quarter. Revenue inched up 5.1% to £226m, while hotel revenue declined 1.4% to £360m due to deteriorating trading in key gateway cities. The company attributed the decline to uncertainty over the global economy, particularly the UK referendum vote to leave the EU. The board declared an interim dividend of 2.08 pence per share.

site_title: ANA cites terrorism, strong yen and earthquakes as Q1 profit tumbles 20.7%
summary: ANA Holdings reported a 20.7% decline in its April-June net profit to 6.6 billion yen (S$87.5 million), citing terrorism incidents in Europe and earthquakes in Japan. A strong yen also negatively impacted its bottom line. The airline attributed the decline to various factors, including terrorism and natural disasters.

site_title: Top Gear looks to 'Joey' from Friends to salvage ailing show
summary: Matt LeBlanc, known for his role as Joey in Friends, is set to take the lead at Top Gear in the UK, following Jeremy Clarkson's departure and Chris Evans' short-lived tenure. The show, a key cultural export for the BBC, generates over £50 million annually in international sales. LeBlanc's name recognition may help boost international viewership, with the new series sold in over 130 territories. The BBC aims to increase its revenue to £1.2 billion over the next five years, while facing competition from Amazon's Prime streaming service with Clarkson's new series, The Grand Tour.

site_title: Eating red meat linked to higher mortality risk: study
summary: A 32-year study analyzing over 150,000 participants found that consuming 10% more protein from animals increased mortality risk by 2%, while a 3% increase in plant-based proteins resulted in a 10% decrease in mortality. The study, led by Dr. Mingyang Song, suggests that plant-based proteins from sources like beans, nuts, and seeds are a healthier choice than red and processed meats. However, certain meats like chicken and fish carried a lower mortality risk. The traditional American diet, high in animal products, is associated with various bad outcomes.

site_title: Facebook to let emerging market companies sell through their pages
summary: Facebook will allow emerging market companies to sell products directly through their Facebook pages for free, marking the company's first foray into online commerce in these regions. The move aims to build potential advertisers in emerging markets, where Facebook has about 60 million businesses with free pages. The company hopes that businesses seeing value from their pages will eventually become paying advertisers, increasing ad sales. This initiative is part of Facebook's strategy to reach a large group of potential users in emerging markets, where it has largely saturated Western markets.

site_title: Malaysian democracy group plans protest rally over 1MDB
summary: Malaysian democracy group Bersih plans a protest rally to demand greater government accountability and action over the 1MDB scandal, which allegedly misappropriated over $3.5 billion. The rally comes after the US Justice Department filed civil lawsuits against the scandal, founded by Prime Minister Najib Razak. Bersih aims to raise awareness and gather diverse groups to challenge Najib's power, following a similar rally last August that drew 200,000 people. The group's chairwoman, Maria Chin, stated that "not protesting is not an option."

site_title: Emirates Airline flight crash-lands at Dubai airport: govt
summary: An Emirates Airline Boeing 777-300 crashed-landed and burst into flames at Dubai International Airport on August 3, 2016, after landing from India. All 275 passengers and crew escaped safely, but departure flights were delayed. The incident occurred on the tarmac, with a tower of flames and thick black smoke visible. Emergency services managed the situation, and the airline confirmed all passengers and crew were evacuated. The cause of the crash is unknown, with Boeing and Emirates working to gather more information.

site_title: Corporate governance scores are at a high, but concerns remain
summary: Singapore-listed companies achieved record-high scores in the annual corporate governance scorecard, with top rankings from Singtel, DBS Group, and SGX. However, panellists noted that lower-ranked companies still have governance shortfalls. The Singapore Governance & Transparency Forum unveiled the individual scores and overall rankings of each company, highlighting the need for improvement in practices. Despite the high scores, industry watchers remain concerned about the actual implementation of governance practices among lower-ranked companies.

site_title: Vancouver's 'nightmare' housing tax threatens foreign tech talent
summary: Vancouver's tech industry is at risk due to a 15% levy on overseas property investors, which may deter foreign talent and hinder the city's goal of becoming a Canadian Silicon Valley. The city already faces high housing costs and low wages among North America's emerging tech hubs. This move is part of British Columbia's efforts to control spiraling home prices. The levy may further exacerbate Vancouver's housing crisis, threatening the city's ability to attract and retain top tech talent.

site_title: A grand state dinner buoyed by friendship and humour
summary: US President Barack Obama hosted a state dinner at the White House, marking 50 years of diplomatic relations between Singapore and the US. Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong and his wife Ho Ching attended the lavish dinner, which featured a mix of Asian and Western flavors. In his toast, Mr Obama praised Singapore's dynamism and called for continued cooperation between the two countries. The evening was also notable for a speech by Mr Lee, who named an orchid hybrid after the President and First Lady, and joked about Singapore's infamous durian fruit.

site_title: CrimsonLogic, ASM introduce electronic service for issuance of building certificate
summary: CrimsonLogic and the Association of Strata Managers (ASM) launched an electronic service to simplify the issuance of the Section (S).47(1)(c) Certificate under the Building Maintenance and Strata Management Act (BMSMA) for strata titled private residential and commercial buildings. The new service, available since August 1, allows law firms to submit online requisitions to government agencies and managing agents via the InteReq portal. The fee for issuance is S$25 (excluding GST), with CrimsonLogic charging a processing fee of S$6 per certificate, waived for six months.

site_title: COE premiums mixed in 1st tender for period with fewer COEs
summary: Singapore's COE premiums remained flat in the first tender of the August-to-October quota period, with two categories (Cat B and Cat E) rising and three others (Cat A, Cat C, and Cat D) falling. The August-to-October quota has 10% fewer COEs than the previous period, largely due to fewer vehicle deregistrations. Despite the contraction, premiums did not spike, with dealers attributing this to resistance to perceived high premiums and caution amid the slumping economy.

site_title: Cruise ships a beacon for Germany's KfW
summary: Germany's KfW Ipex development bank is lending 2.8 billion euros to fund cruise ships this year, with more than half of its 16 billion-euro maritime loan book now devoted to the industry. The bank's exposure to cruise ships is unique among German shipping lenders, which have traditionally focused on container ships and bulk carriers. KfW Ipex's global head, Carsten Wiebers, expects the Chinese to take several years to catch up with international cruise ship companies in terms of technology, and sees the cruise industry as a bright spot in the shipping market.

site_title: Post-Brexit rally runs out of steam
summary: The global post-Brexit rally appears to be losing steam, with the Straits Times Index (STI) falling 29.09 points to 2,827.58 on Wednesday, following a 4% decline since its peak on July 20. The rally, driven by central bank support and delayed interest rate hikes, has been attributed to factors such as weak oil prices and the shock bankruptcy of offshore and marine company Swiber Holdings. The STI has now shed 118 points, or 4%, since its peak, and is 1.9% down for the year.

site_title: Wiser to use foreign passport to enter China
summary: Two Hong Kong journalists, James Wang and Sandy Phan-Gillis, were sentenced to prison in China, highlighting the treatment of ethnic Chinese nationals of other countries. Wang, with an American passport, was denied permission to visit his friend in prison and was sentenced to five years and three months, while Phan-Gillis, also a US citizen, was regularly visited by diplomats and will be tried in the Nanning Intermediate People's Court. This case raises concerns about China's jurisdiction over ethnic Chinese nationals, contradicting its own nationality law, and highlights the importance of using a foreign passport to enter China.

site_title: Bitcoin slumps after report of breach at major HK exchange
summary: A major Hong Kong-based Bitcoin exchange, Bitfinex, has suspended trading after hackers reportedly stole US$65 million in Bitcoins, causing the digital currency to plummet over 20%. The breach, which involved the theft of 119,756 Bitcoins, has raised concerns about the security of digital currencies. The incident is the latest blow to the virtual currency industry, following similar breaches in the past.

site_title: US crude inventories rise unexpectedly as distillate stocks grow
summary: US crude inventories rose unexpectedly, increasing by 1.4 million barrels in the last week, contrary to analyst expectations. Distillate stocks also rose, while gasoline stocks fell by 3.3 million barrels. Refinery crude runs rose by 266,000 barrels per day and utilization rates increased by 0.9 percentage point. US crude imports rose by 301,000 barrels per day. Despite refinery utilization growth, the unexpected increase in crude stocks may raise concerns.

site_title: Living a rejuvenating work life at OCBC
summary: OCBC Bank in Singapore launches the Life Refresh@OCBC programme, a lifelong learning scheme for employees aged 50 and above, offering support in four areas: fintech, financial planning, career planning, and health and fitness. The programme is an extension of the OCBC FutureReady Programme and aims to help employees stay ahead of the times. A pilot programme, Life-App Day, was recently conducted, where 32 students introduced over 30 apps to 50+ employees, providing hands-on experience and personal interaction. The programme is open to 1,000 eligible employees.

site_title: US drug benefit manager cuts coverage for 35 products in exclusion expansion
summary: CVS Health Corp will exclude coverage for 35 products, including cancer and diabetes treatments, in 2017 due to high price increases. The excluded list includes 10 drugs with "hyperinflationary" price increases, such as Tasigna and Lantus. CVS aims to favor lower-priced treatments and target expensive products when alternatives are available. The company will remove coverage for brand-name cancer drugs, including Novartis's Tasigna, and expand its strategy to exclude expensive products.

site_title: Long-term, low-cost investment proposal could be a hard sell for CPF
summary: The CPF Advisory Panel has proposed a "Lifetime Retirement Investment Scheme" (LRIS) to address concerns over retirement savings adequacy in Singapore. The scheme aims to reduce annual expense ratios to 0.5% or lower through passive low-cost funds, addressing concerns over investment costs and fund choices. However, the proposal also faces challenges, including members' fear of loss and volatility, and the CPF's guaranteed interest rates, which may be an implicit hurdle rate for fund managers. The CPF must now mount a high-profile education campaign to promote the benefits of long-term, low-cost investing.

site_title: JTC must fulfil stated obligation of redeeming JCC-linked notes at par
summary: JTC Debenture Note 2003 holders are demanding early redemption of their interest-free loan at par, citing the bundled nature of the notes with Jurong Country Club (JCC) memberships. Despite JTC's claims that the notes can be held independently, the holders argue that the notes and memberships are linked in all legal documents. JTC's proposal to buy back the notes at a discount is seen as tantamount to redeeming the notes in 2033, and the holders are seeking repayment of the principal amount of S$120,000. The holders claim that JTC's actions will prejudice their interests and they will be "very angry and aggrieved" if their demands are not met.

site_title: Why US millennials find it harder to buy a home than their parents did
summary: US millennials face challenges in buying homes due to a lack of inventory and affordability issues. The median national home price reached $247,700 in June, the highest since 1968, attributed to inventory issues. Lawrence Yun, chief economist of the National Association of Realtors, warns that affordability is a "flashing yellow light" on the housing market, potentially leading to a slowdown in home sales.

site_title: Foreign rail firms shunted as 'Made in China' mantra gathers pace
summary: China's "Made in China 2025" plan is tightening bidding criteria for rail tenders, favoring wholly local firms over foreign-invested companies. Foreign firms, including Siemens and Bombardier, have previously partnered with local companies to build the world's biggest railway network. However, Beijing now seeks to make local partners globally competitive, leading to concerns that foreign-invested companies are being discriminated against. Four foreign rail suppliers claim they are struggling to win contracts due to the new rules, which score companies based on their local ownership.

images.alt_text: Four rail suppliers with offshore funding said that they were finding it harder to win contracts.

site_title: Hacker creates new rating system for software security
summary: Famed hacker Peiter Zatko, known as Mudge, has created a new rating system for software security, with the goal of making software consistently secure or very expensive to compromise. The system, licensed to a non-profit, rates software based on its digital outputs, or binaries, rather than the code itself. Preliminary findings show Apple's Macs and Google's Chrome browser are more secure than others, while Microsoft's Office suite for Mac scored poorly. The system aims to address the lack of unbiased, consistent methods for rating software security, and could lead to major changes in the software industry.

site_title: Britain's road to Brexit long and complex
summary: Britain's road to Brexit will be long and complex, with four major negotiations needed to establish a new relationship with the EU. The UK must negotiate its own World Trade Organization (WTO) membership, which requires depositing tariffs, quotas, and concessions with the WTO's 163 member countries. The process is expected to be challenging, with potential difficulties arising from other countries, and British officials anticipate it may take two years to complete. This is part of the Article 50 negotiation, which began after the UK voted to leave the EU in 2016.

site_title: Lauder finds artwork with cloudy provenance
summary: Ronald Lauder, chairman of the Commission for Art Recovery, has found an artwork with a clouded provenance at the Neue Galerie museum he co-founded. The piece, which he declined to identify, may be returned to rightful owners after Lauder's staff hired additional specialists and overhauled the museum's website to provide more detailed provenance information. Lauder had previously been criticized for incomplete provenance listings, and this discovery marks the first time he is facing the prospect of returning an artwork held by the museum. Lauder has returned three works from his personal collection due to concerns over their rightful ownership and has acknowledged that his profile as a restitution advocate will continue to subject him to greater scrutiny.

site_title: Lum Chang buying The Verge for redevelopment
summary: Lum Chang Holdings, a Singaporean construction and property group, has agreed to buy The Verge in Little India for under S$300 million. The Verge, 90% owned by Malaysian conglomerate DRB-Hicom, will be redeveloped into a new mall and serviced residences with a gross development value of about S$400 million. The acquisition, which is expected to be completed by November, will be the group's first major foray into the Singapore property market in over a decade. Lum Chang plans to team up with an equity partner and established mall and serviced residences operators to run the two components of the development.

site_title: Fed fines Goldman Sachs for unauthorized use of confidential data
summary: The US Federal Reserve Board has ordered Goldman Sachs to pay $36.3 million in fines for unauthorized use and disclosure of confidential information. The Fed Board also seeks to bar former managing director Joseph Jiampietro from the industry and requires Goldman to implement an enhanced program for proper use of confidential supervisory information.

site_title: US stocks edge higher as Hulu boosts Time Warner
summary: US stocks rose early Wednesday, with Time Warner shares up 2.8% after announcing a 10% stake in Hulu. Other gainers included Apple, Goldman Sachs, and JPMorgan Chase. ADP reported 179,000 new jobs in July, slightly better than expected. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 also edged higher, while the Nasdaq Composite rose 0.1%. In contrast, Kate Spade plummeted 19.4% after slashing its full-year forecast.

site_title: US loan demand for home purchases lowest since February: MBA
summary: US home loan demand fell to its lowest level in five months, with a 2% decline in weekly mortgage applications for home purchases, according to the Mortgage Bankers Association. Interest rates on 30-year fixed-rate mortgages declined to a three-year low, with the average rate falling to 3.67% last week. This marks the lowest level since late February and follows a three-week decline in mortgage activity.

site_title: CPF to offer low-fuss, low-cost investment scheme
summary: The Singapore government has accepted recommendations from the CPF Advisory Panel to introduce a low-fuss, low-cost investment scheme, the Lifetime Retirement Investment Scheme (LRIS), to address under-utilised CPF savings. The LRIS will offer passively managed funds through a single administrator, aiming to provide convenience and simplicity at bare-bones costs. The government also plans to review the CPF Investment Scheme and introduce an escalating payout option for the CPF Life annuity scheme, which will increase payouts by 2% per year. The proposals aim to address concerns about inflation and longevity, and provide more flexibility for CPF members.

site_title: Ginseng sets, lavish meals off limits in S Korea graft crackdown
summary: South Korea is implementing an anti-corruption law that restricts lavish gifts and entertainment for civil servants, teachers, and journalists. The law, set to take effect next month, limits spending on gifts, including expensive meats like beef and ginseng, and entertainment like golf. This move aims to curb widespread corruption in professional life but has raised concerns among business owners, who fear it will harm their industries. The law's restrictions are seen as a significant shift in the country's approach to tackling graft.

site_title: Singtel adds suite of new services to its cloud portfolio
summary: Singtel has added a suite of hybrid cloud solutions to its cloud portfolio, including the Data Centre and Cloud Connect Service (DC Connect) and the Cloud Life Cycle Service (CLS). The DC Connect allows seamless data movement between public and private clouds, while CLS helps companies chart their cloud maturity. The suite also includes Liquid Sky, a platform for orchestrating hybrid cloud environments. The new services aim to simplify hybrid cloud adoption for enterprises, providing low latency, secure management, and automated workflows. This move is part of Singtel's efforts to support its customers' digital strategies.

site_title: US private sector adds 179,000 jobs in July: ADP
summary: US private employers added 179,000 jobs in July, exceeding economists' expectations of 170,000 jobs, according to ADP's National Employment Report. This marks a revision up from the previously reported 176,000 jobs added in June. The July jobs report is expected to be followed by the US Labor Department's non-farm payrolls report on Friday, which is forecast to show a 170,000 job gain and a 4.8% unemployment rate.

site_title: Growth at US services industries cools from seven-month high
summary: US service providers saw a slowdown in growth in July, with the Institute for Supply Management's non-manufacturing index falling to 55.5 from 56.5. Orders to service producers rose to a nine-month high, indicating further economic growth. The job market, property and stock prices, and low borrowing costs support consumer spending, which reached its best quarter since 2014. Despite this, the manufacturing sector's easing growth may signal a more measured progress in the economy.

site_title: Latest Earnings
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times. Creative Technology warned of lower-than-expected H2 revenue and operating loss similar to H1. London's Heathrow is considering higher fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. OCBC announced Tan Teck Long as its incoming CEO. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and People's Bank of China (PBOC) plan to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance. Singapore stocks rose for a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Dubai intl airport to resume flights at 1430 gmt: govt
summary: Dubai International Airport has resumed flights at 1430 GMT after a traffic suspension following the emergency landing and subsequent fire of an Emirates Airline plane earlier in the day.

site_title: Departure flights from Dubai delayed after crash-authorities
summary: All departure flights from Dubai International Airport have been delayed due to an Emirates Airline plane from India crashing and bursting into flames. The plane, carrying 275 passengers and crew, had safely evacuated passengers. Authorities are managing the situation. The cause of the crash is currently unknown.

site_title: RHT Trust, formerly Religare, posts drop in Q1 DPU
summary: RHT Trust, formerly Religare, reported a 13.2% drop in net profit to S$10.7 million in Q1, citing higher taxes in India. Revenue edged up 0.1% to S$35.4 million, while distributable income dipped 2% to S$15.1 million, leading to a 7.8% drop in DPU to 1.798 Singapore cents from 1.94 Singapore cents in the previous year. The trust attributed the decline to management's decision to distribute 95% of the distributable income for the current financial year.

site_title: Noble shares fall for second day ahead of rights shares listing
summary: Noble Group's shares plummeted 18.5% in two days, with heavy trading ahead of the listing of its new rights shares on Thursday. The stock fell 12.2% to 12.2 Singapore cents, with 319.4 million shares changing hands worth S$41.1 million. Market participants attribute the price drop to the listing of rights shares, with some speculating that shortsellers may have cashed in on the poor market sentiment. Analysts predict further downside, but some believe the stock may rebound as short positions are covered.

site_title: BreadTalk Q2 profit dives 54.8% at S$1.3m
summary: BreadTalk Group's second-quarter profit plummeted 54.8% to S$1.3 million due to a decline in revenue, mainly from bakery and food atrium divisions. Revenue fell 3.3% to S$149.8 million, and earnings per share dropped to 0.46 Singapore cents. Despite a slight increase in net asset value per share to 52.4 Singapore cents, the company's shares closed flat at S$1.12.

site_title: Catalist-listed Acromec bags S$10.3m contract
summary: Acromec Limited, a Singaporean engineering service provider, has secured a S$10.3 million contract to fit out a Class 100 research cleanroom at Fusionopolis. The project is expected to be completed by the second quarter of the next financial year (Sept 30, 2017) and will contribute to the company's revenue and earnings per share. This win brings Acromec's current order book to approximately S$40 million.

site_title: Update: Bitcoin worth US$72m stolen from Bitfinex exchange in Hong Kong
summary: A significant security breach occurred at the Hong Kong-based exchange platform Bitfinex, with nearly 120,000 units of bitcoin worth around US$72 million stolen from users' accounts. This is the second-largest security breach of a bitcoin exchange in history. The exchange has not yet decided on how to address customer losses.

site_title: Indonesia capital's airport to open new terminal next week
summary: Indonesia's Soekarno-Hatta International Airport will open a new $380 million terminal next week, aiming to ease congestion at the country's busiest aviation hub. The 25 million passenger capacity terminal, starting operations at midnight Monday, will initially handle Garuda flights and is expected to be fully operational by March next year. The terminal's opening is a response to soaring air passenger numbers in Indonesia, where ageing infrastructure and safety concerns have been issues. The new terminal will eventually connect to central Jakarta by rail, reducing traffic jams.

site_title: Singapore retail investors' confidence falls post-Brexit: poll
summary: Singapore retail investors' confidence in the local stock market and economy has dropped following Britain's vote to leave the European Union (Brexit), a JP Morgan Asset Management survey found. The index fell to 101, four points down from the previous week, and 4 points down from December 2015. Despite the bearish sentiments, 85% of respondents planned to maintain or increase their investments post-Brexit. The survey results showed that investors turned more pessimistic about the global economy, with 44% saying it was unlikely to improve in the next six months.

site_title: US$ struggles near 6-week lows
summary: The US dollar struggled near six-week lows against a basket of currencies on Wednesday, pressured by expectations of a delayed US Federal Reserve interest rate hike. The dollar index inched up 0.2% but remained close to its low of 95.003. Traders will watch US labour market data on Thursday ahead of the non-farm payrolls report on Friday. The dollar has been volatile, with some analysts predicting it will break below 100 yen in the near future.

site_title: Lum Chang looking to buy The Verge mall
summary: Lum Chang Holdings has entered into a term sheet to acquire The Verge mall in Serangoon Road, Singapore. The eight-storey mall has a total gross floor area of 238,527 square feet and is encumbered. Lum Chang will start due diligence and negotiations with the seller, Corwin Holding, within a four-week exclusivity period. The acquisition sum has not been disclosed, and Lum Chang aims to agree on the terms within this period.

site_title: Private company wins US clearance to fly to the moon
summary: A Florida-based company, Moon Express, has won US government permission to send a robotic lander to the moon in 2017, marking the first time a private space mission will fly beyond Earth's orbit. The Federal Aviation Administration's approval sets a framework for commercial expeditions to the moon, asteroids, and Mars. The mission will include science experiments and commercial cargo, including cremated human remains, and will beam back pictures and video to Earth. The decision paves the way for other private companies to follow, with plans for missions to Mars and asteroid mining.

site_title: Singapore shares close lower on weak Wall Street, soft oil and Swiber's woes
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) in Singapore fell 29.09 points to 2,827.58 on Wednesday, following a weak Wall Street performance and soft oil prices. The Dow Jones Industrial Average's seventh consecutive decline may have contributed to the STI's loss. The rally seen after the Brexit vote has largely fizzled out, with the index now 1.9% down for the year. The recent bankruptcy of Swiber Holdings and concerns over central bank action have also impacted the market.

site_title: Global Premium Hotels Q2 earnings down on lower room revenue
summary: Global Premium Hotels reported a 13.5% decline in net profit to S$2.7 million for its second quarter, mainly due to lower room revenue. Revenue dropped 2.7% to S$14.6 million, with three hotels temporarily closed for asset enhancement work. This resulted in lower hotel room revenue recognition. The decline in revenue was attributed to the closure of hotels for maintenance work.

images.alt_text: Lower room revenue from most of its hotels eroded Global Premium Hotels' (GPH) results for its second quarter.

site_title: k1 Ventures full-year earnings leap on investment income
summary: k1 Ventures reported a 463.9% leap in full-year earnings to S$140.6 million, driven by investment income from portfolio company Knowledge Universe Holdings. Revenue surged 221.8% to S$195.1 million, mainly from cash distributions from KUH's childcare operations sales. The group's board has decided not to make new investments, focusing on managing current assets and realising them at an appropriate time. No final dividend was proposed, but a capital distribution of 7.5 Singapore cents per share was suggested.

site_title: South Korea in final stages of preparations to trade with Iran in euro
summary: South Korea is nearing final preparations to trade with Iran in euros, aiming to do so "as soon as possible" according to Finance Minister Yoo Il-ho. The move comes as sanctions against Iran are being lifted, and South Korea seeks to diversify its oil imports from euros. The country expects to facilitate trade with Iran in euros within this year. Yoo also emphasized the need for international coordination to prevent protectionist trade policies, particularly in light of the US presidential election.

site_title: Indonesia delays rules for reporting credit card customer data
summary: Indonesia has delayed the implementation of a regulation requiring credit card providers to submit customer data to the tax office until the end of its tax amnesty program in March 2017. The delay aims to support the government's cash-less campaign, which aims to reduce cash transactions and combat money laundering and corruption. The finance ministry had initially planned to start the regulation on May 31.

site_title: Bank CEOs in no rush to move staff from UK after Brexit vote
summary: Bank CEOs in the UK are delaying decisions on relocating staff due to uncertainty surrounding the UK's post-Brexit status. Key to their decision is whether the UK will retain EU passporting rights for financial services, a possibility not settled until 2018 or later. CEOs, including HSBC's Stuart Gulliver, have shifted from warnings of immediate moves to a more patient tone, citing the need to see how the UK government negotiates its future relationship with the EU.

site_title: Otto Marine starts arbitration for alleged default on charter parties
summary: Otto Marine has initiated arbitration proceedings against Robert Knutzen Shipholdings Ltd (RKSL) for alleged default on charter parties. RKSL is accused of owing over $2.83 million in principal plus interest for overdue payments. Robert Knutzen, a shipping veteran and personal guarantor to the charter parties, is also being targeted. Otto Marine's lawyers are working to progress the arbitration and enforce any awards against Knutzen to safeguard the company's interests and assets.

site_title: StanChart swings back to profit, shares rise 4%
summary: Standard Chartered reported an underlying pretax profit of US$994 million for the six months to end-June, reversing a US$1 billion loss in the second half of 2015. The bank attributed the improvement to cost-cutting measures, with expenses falling 13% over the period. The bank also deferred its goal to reach a tangible return on equity of 8% by 2018, citing slowing global growth and lower interest rates. The bank's shares rose 4.1% to 611 pence following the results announcement.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 11.73 points to close at 1,648.50 on Wednesday. The index saw 2.1 billion lots valued at RM1.6 billion traded, with 398 gainers and 416 losers.

site_title: Hong Kong stocks end sharply lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted 1.76% on Wednesday, following a global sell-off, as investors reacted to a typhoon that closed the city's exchange the previous day. The Hang Seng Index fell to 21,739.12, while the Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.24%. The Shenzhen Composite Index also gained 0.42%. The decline was part of a broader global market downturn.

site_title: China will use multiple monetary policy tools, maintain reasonable credit growth: PBOC
summary: China's central bank, PBOC, plans to use multiple monetary policy tools to maintain reasonable credit growth and liquidity in the second half of the year. The bank will keep the yuan stable and continue market-based interest rate reform. PBOC aims to fine-tune its monetary policy as necessary to achieve a prudent approach.

site_title: Emirates Airline flight crash-lands at Dubai airport: govt
summary: An Emirates Airline flight, EK521 from Thiruvananthapuram to Dubai, crash-landed at Dubai International Airport on August 3, 2016. There were no reported casualties. The Boeing 777-300 aircraft was engulfed in a thick black smoke. Takeoffs and landings at Dubai were suspended due to the incident. The cause of the crash is not yet known, and airport and company representatives were unavailable for comment.

site_title: COE premiums mixed
