summary: COE premiums were mixed in the first quota tender of 2016, with two categories increasing and three decreasing. Category A fell to S$52,503, while Category B rose to S$57,903. Category E climbed to S$58,201, while Category C and D decreased to S$48,302 and S$6,206 respectively. Dealers attribute negative sentiment to high premiums and economic concerns.

site_title: Japan's ANA cites terrorism as Q1 net profit tumbles
summary: Japan's All Nippon Airways (ANA) cited terrorism in Europe and earthquakes in Japan as factors contributing to a 20.7% decline in its Q1 net profit to 6.6 billion yen. The airline's cargo business struggled, and demand for domestic flights was affected by deadly earthquakes in southern Japan. Despite this, ANA's overseas business saw stronger results due to expanded international routes. The airline left its profit and sales forecasts unchanged for the fiscal year to March 2017, with net profit expected to hit 80 billion yen.

site_title: Pound falls before services data as market awaits BOE decision
summary: The pound dropped 0.3% to $1.3322 against the US dollar, paring gains made on Tuesday, ahead of the Bank of England's policy decision. Economists forecast that UK services contracted in July, with a purchasing managers' index of 47.4, leading to speculation of interest rate cuts. All but two of 52 economists surveyed predict the central bank will ease policy, with some expecting a comprehensive package of measures to fuel further pound depreciation. The Bank of England's decision is expected to be released on Thursday.

site_title: CPF to offer more convenient investment scheme, escalating annuity
summary: The Singapore government has accepted recommendations from the CPF Advisory Panel to introduce a low-fee, passively managed investment scheme called the Lifetime Retirement Investment Scheme (LRIS) for CPF members. The scheme aims to provide simplicity and convenience with minimal costs, and could include life-cycle and balanced funds. The government also plans to offer an escalating payout option for the CPF Life annuity scheme, which will increase payouts by 2% per year. The government agrees with the panel's views, saying the additional options will help address concerns about rising costs in retirement and desire for higher investment returns.

site_title: Indonesia central bank to ease monetary policy when time is right: official
summary: Indonesia's central bank executive director Juda Agung said the country has room to ease monetary policy, but will do so when the time is right. The annual inflation rate, which peaked at 6% in 2015, is no longer a major concern at 3.21% in July. Agung is optimistic the economy will grow stronger in the second half of the year due to increased consumption and fiscal spending. The next policy review is scheduled for August 19.

images.alt_text: Indonesia's central bank has room to loosen its monetary policy further and it will do so when the time is right, Juda Agung, its executive director for economic and monetary policy, told reporters on Wednesday.

site_title: HDB selects West Coast Road site for redevelopment
summary: The Housing and Development Board (HDB) has selected Blocks 513 to 520 West Coast Road for selective en bloc redevelopment scheme (SERS), marking the 80th site to benefit from the scheme since its introduction in 1995. The site comprises 994 sold flats, approximately 37 years old.

site_title: Australian PM exhorts banks to slash lending rates further
summary: Australian Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull criticized the country's largest banks for not fully passing on the official interest rate cut, demanding top executives explain themselves. The Reserve Bank of Australia cut interest rates to a record low of 1.50% amid opposition calls for a judicial inquiry into the banking sector. The four major banks lowered borrowing costs by only 10-14 basis points, sparking concerns over record-low margins and rising bad debts. Treasurer Scott Morrison urged the banks to share the benefit of the rate cut with customers, as analysts predicted higher deposit rates would squeeze their margins further.

site_title: Europe: Stocks rebound at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets rebounded at the open on Wednesday, with London's FTSE 100 up 0.3%, Frankfurt's DAX 30 up 0.1%, and Paris's CAC 40 up 0.4%. Asian stocks tumbled for a second day, extending the global retreat, after Japan's economy-boosting stimulus program fell flat with investors.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's private sector conditions worsened in July, with the PMI declining 1.6 points to 50.7. This is attributed to a second decline in foreign demand this year. Vietnam was surprised by the US Trump tariff announcement, seeking a lower rate. The Asian garment industry is bracing for higher US tariffs. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers. Meanwhile, Citigroup forecasts a 1,150 target for MSCI's global equity index by mid-2026.

images.alt_text: Conditions in the private sector here worsened in July compared to the preceding month, dragged down by a second bout of steep decline in foreign demand this year in Singapore's trade-reliant economy.

site_title: Panama seeks to punish countries that blacklist it as 'tax haven'
summary: Panama has proposed legislation to retaliate against countries blacklisting it as a "tax haven" in response to the Panama Papers scandal. The bill would impose tax, trade, and migration measures on companies or individuals from those countries that harm Panama's economic interests. This move is directed at France, which recently blacklisted Panama, and potentially Colombia, which has imposed tariffs on Panama textile imports despite a World Trade Organisation ruling calling for their removal. The bill will be debated and voted on by Panama's Congress.

site_title: China Jinjiang Environment makes its debut on SGX mainboard
summary: China Jinjiang Environment Holding Company Ltd debuted on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) on August 3, 2016, with its stock opening at S$0.885, below its offer price of S$0.90. The stock rose to S$0.90 by 2:13pm with 2.6 million shares traded. The company, a waste-to-energy operator in China, offered 92.42 million new shares at S$0.90 each.

site_title: Didi, SoftBank said to lead US$600m-plus round for Grab
summary: China's Didi Chuxing and SoftBank Group Corp are leading a US$600 million-plus round of funding in ride-sharing service Grab, valuing the company at over US$1 billion. The deal comes days after Didi bought out Uber's operations in China, allowing Grab CEO Anthony Tan to expect Uber to focus on the South-east Asian market. This investment marks the latest move by Didi to thwart Uber's presence in the region, following a previously forged alliance with Grab, Ola, and Lyft.

site_title: UK economy contracting at fastest since 2009: Markit PMI survey
summary: The UK economy is contracting at its fastest rate since the 2008-09 financial crisis, with a 0.4% shrinkage in the three months to September, according to Markit's PMI survey. Economists expect the Bank of England to cut interest rates by at least a quarter percentage point on Thursday, with a mild recession looming. The contraction is attributed to the June European Union vote, with confidence among firms in the services sector at its lowest since February 2009. A Bank of England rate cut is now seen as "a foregone conclusion".

images.alt_text: Britain's economy is shrinking at its fastest rate since the 2008-09 financial crisis, making a Bank of England rate cut on Thursday "a foregone conclusion", the publishers of a closely watched business survey said.

site_title: US crude remains below US$40 as oversupply weighs
summary: US crude oil prices remain below $40 per barrel, with WTI trading at $39.54 per barrel and Brent at $41.77 per barrel, due to oversupply and stuttering economic growth. Analysts attribute some support to a weaker dollar, but warn that rising supplies from Libya and high inventories will continue to weigh on prices. Morgan Stanley predicts longer-term growth will be challenging, while Citi argues recent price falls were overblown and the global oil market has rebalanced.

site_title: Volcanic eruptions in Indonesia hit air travel
summary: Volcanic eruptions in Indonesia's Mount Gamala on the eastern island of Ternate forced the closure of the island's airport and disrupted flights to Bali. Ash rose 600 meters into the air after a moderate earthquake. Authorities advised people to stay calm, but no evacuations were planned. The eruptions also affected air travel in the region, with two airports closed. Officials are monitoring the situation and working to restore normal air travel services.

site_title: Eurozone business growth picks up slightly on German lead: PMI
summary: Eurozone business activity expanded slightly in July, with a composite Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) of 53.2, above the 50 mark that indicates growth. The expansion was led by Germany, but growth in France, Spain, and Italy remained stagnant. Despite the uptick, the economy is expected to grow at a modest 0.3% quarterly rate. The European Central Bank is under pressure to boost growth, and a Reuters poll suggests it may soon extend its asset purchase program. Inflation remains below the 2% target ceiling.

images.alt_text: Eurozone business activity expanded a touch faster than thought last month, with the region appearing to have so far largely shrugged off Britain's vote in late June to quit the European Union, a survey found.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end at 3-week low, won down as global stocks slump
summary: South Korean stocks and the won ended at a three-week low, closing 1.2% lower at 1,994.79 points and 0.7% lower at 1,117.6 to the dollar. Foreign selling and a drop in global stocks led the decline. Shipping company Hyundai Merchant Marine Co Ltd plummeted 29.7% after issuing convertible bonds. Offshore investors sold 77.8 billion won worth of Kospi shares. The slump in global stocks, including the US and Europe, contributed to the downturn in South Korean markets.

site_title: Malaysian democracy group plans 1MDB protest rally
summary: Malaysian democracy group Bersih plans a protest rally to demand greater government accountability and action on the 1MDB scandal, which the US Justice Department alleges misappropriated over $3.5 billion. The group aims to raise awareness and gather more diverse groups to join the rally, following a similar event last year that drew over 200,000 people. The rally is part of a roadshow and protests planned ahead of the event, with Bersih chairwoman Maria Chin stating that "not protesting is not an option."

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks end lower, extend global sell-off
summary: Tokyo stocks fell for a second session, extending a global sell-off, with the Nikkei 225 index down 1.88% and the Topix index down 2.17%. Investors were underwhelmed by a government stimulus package, with banks leading the decline. The sell-off is part of a broader global trend, with US stocks also reaching fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: German private sector growth hits year-high in July: PMI
summary: Germany's private sector growth reached a year-high in July, with Markit's PMI survey showing a composite index of 55.3, up from 54.4 in June. The services sector, which accounts for two-thirds of the economy, saw a two-month high in growth, with underlying trends similar to the past three years. However, companies' positive sentiment fell to an eight-month low due to concerns over the Brexit vote, with some companies adding staff and increasing new orders. The German government forecasts 1.7% economic expansion for 2016.

site_title: 22 missing after India bridge collapse
summary: A bridge collapse in western India, south of Mumbai, has left at least 22 people missing after two buses plunged into a fast-flowing river. The collapse occurred following days of torrential monsoon rains. Rescuers are searching for the passengers swept away, with large chunks of the bridge having fallen into the rain-swollen Savitri river.

site_title: StarHub becomes Autodesk Value Added Distributor in Singapore
summary: StarHub has been appointed as a Value Added Distributor (VAD) in Singapore for Autodesk, becoming the first telco in South-east Asia to hold this title. StarHub will sell Autodesk's 3D design, engineering, and entertainment software through its network of VARs, aiming to broaden the reach of Autodesk's solutions and meet customer needs across multiple industries in Singapore. This partnership is expected to bring significant value to Autodesk resellers and enhance its presence in the local market.

site_title: Ringgit leads emerging currencies lower as stocks extend decline
summary: Malaysia's ringgit fell 0.8% to 4.0668 per dollar, the largest decline in five weeks, amid concerns over global growth and a decline in oil prices. The won also dropped 0.4% against the US dollar. The MSCI Emerging Markets Index fell 0.7%, its two-day drop at 1.4%. The decline is attributed to a selloff in oil, which weakened Brent crude to below US$42 a barrel for the first time since April.

site_title: China: Stocks edge up, helped by property sector strength
summary: China's stocks rose 0.1% on Wednesday, driven by a second day of gains for property shares and growing expectations of state-owned enterprise (SOE) reforms. Despite a two-month low trading volume, the CSI300 index rose to 3,193.51 points, while the Shanghai Composite Index gained 0.2% to 2,978.46 points. However, concerns over China's economy persisted, with a private survey showing slower growth in the services sector. Analysts attribute the shift in investor focus to perceived safe-haven assets like bonds and gold.

site_title: Baidu, Tencent retreat from US$3b tie-up with Chinese mogul
summary: Baidu Inc and Tencent Holdings Ltd have withdrawn from a US$3 billion venture with Chinese mogul Wang Jianlin's Dalian Wanda Group, just two years after its launch in 2014. The venture, ffan.com, aimed to revolutionize mall shopping but failed to gain traction, with Baidu and Tencent being replaced by a company backed by Wang. The move is part of a growing trend of Chinese tech companies competing with each other, leading to increased competition and decreased returns on investments.

site_title: Australia: Shares plumb two-week low; NZ shares slip
summary: Australian shares fell 1.4% on Wednesday, reaching a two-week low, due to concerns over wholesale funding of the country's financial sector. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 5,465.70 points, a 74.94-point loss. New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index also declined 0.7% to 7277.40, marking its second consecutive drop.

site_title: Bank of England set to axe rates to record low 0.25%
summary: The Bank of England is set to cut interest rates to a record-low 0.25% to stimulate the economy amid the fallout from Britain's vote to leave the EU. This would be the first reduction since March 2009 and the lowest level in the BOE's 322-year history. Analysts expect the BOE to increase the amount of quantitative easing, citing weaker economic data and recession concerns. The move aims to address the uncertainty caused by the Brexit vote, which has led to a slowdown in the economy and a faltering property market.

site_title: VW warns of plunge in China demand if tax cut lapses
summary: Volkswagen AG warns that industry-wide demand in China will plummet if a tax cut on smaller engine vehicles expires at the end of the year. The German automaker is in talks with the government and China Association of Automobile Manufacturers to extend the tax cut, which has boosted sales. Volkswagen China delivered a record 1.86 million vehicles in the first half, driven by the tax cut. The company's Volkswagen Group delivered 1.86 million vehicles globally in the same period, and the tax cut has been a key factor in its success.

site_title: Asia: Markets slip, weak stimulus hits Japan stocks
summary: Asian markets slipped for a second day, with Tokyo's Nikkei down 0.9% due to a strong yen after Japan's stimulus package fell short of market expectations. The package, worth 28 trillion yen, only included a quarter of fresh spending, disappointing investors and sending the yen surging. Global markets also retreated, with US and European stocks ending down, as concerns about European banks' ability to make money in a low-interest rate era grew. The US jobs report on Friday is expected to provide a fresh snapshot of the US economy, with a weak figure potentially denting expectations of a Federal Reserve rate hike.

site_title: Supermodel, dancers to lead Rio opening ceremony show
summary: Supermodel Gisele Bundchen, Lea T, and carnival dancers will perform at the Rio 2016 Olympic opening ceremony. The event, held in a recession-hit country, is expected to be more modest compared to London 2012's high-profile ceremony. The performers aim to showcase Brazil's vibrant culture amidst economic challenges. The ceremony will feature a mix of humor and sophistication, with a focus on Brazil's multicolour heritage.

site_title: AXA says H1 net income up 4%, below expectations
summary: AXA, Europe's second-largest insurer, reported a 4% increase in net profit for the first half of 2016, reaching 3.2 billion euros, despite higher natural catastrophe costs and lower asset management revenue. The company cited resilient underlying earnings and proceeds from real estate disposals. Net income was below the average forecast of 3.6 billion euros.

site_title: HSBC profits plunge 45% as Brexit bites
summary: HSBC reported a 45% plunge in pre-tax profits to $3.61 billion for the second quarter, amid Brexit uncertainty. The bank cited a 29% drop in pre-tax profits to $9.7 billion and a 28% decline in net profit to $6.91 billion for the six-month period. HSBC announced a share buy-back program and assured annual dividend payouts would be protected. Group chairman Douglas Flint stated that the bank is entering a period of heightened uncertainty, requiring re-positioning in Europe and establishing fresh terms of trade with EU and global partners.

images.alt_text: HSBC said Wednesday pre-tax profits almost halved in April-June and that the bank was heading into a "period of heightened uncertainty" after Britain voted to leave the European Union.

site_title: Hewlett Packard's Meg Whitman joins CEOs endorsing Clinton
summary: Meg Whitman, CEO of Hewlett Packard Enterprise, has endorsed Hillary Clinton's presidential bid, calling Donald Trump an "authoritarian character" and a threat to democracy. In a Facebook post and interview with the New York Times, Whitman expressed her decision to put country over party loyalty and pledged a "substantial" contribution to Clinton's campaign. Her endorsement is seen as a significant shift among high-profile Republicans.

site_title: China's yuan firms as companies cover short positions
summary: China's yuan strengthened on Wednesday as some companies covered their short positions after a dollar weakening in global markets. The People's Bank of China set the midpoint rate at 6.6195 per dollar, firmer than the previous fix. The yuan has rebounded 1.2% since slipping through the 6.7/dollar level on July 18. The central bank has reduced its intervention, allowing the market to determine the yuan's value. The offshore yuan was trading 0.11% below the onshore spot at 6.635 per dollar, with the Thomson Reuters/HKEX Global CNH index standing at 95.44.

site_title: Singapore private sector conditions worsen with July PMI down 1.6 to 50.7
summary: Singapore's private sector conditions worsened in July with a PMI of 50.7, down 1.6 from June, indicating a decline in business conditions. Soft external demand, particularly from overseas, and weak global economic conditions contributed to the decline. Employment also decreased, while total input costs rose, with some companies increasing prices and others cutting them due to promotional activities. This marks the 13th straight month of contraction for the manufacturing sector, according to the manufacturing PMI released earlier.

site_title: China regulator asks insurers to examine product risks: Caixin
summary: China's insurance regulator, the China Insurance Regulatory Commission (CIRC), has asked insurers to thoroughly assess business risks and strengthen risk controls. This comes after insurers have rapidly moved into risky investments in recent years. Insurers will examine risks in product offerings, fund use, administration practices, and debt burden. The request is part of increased regulatory scrutiny following investigations into insurers' risk controls and equity investments.

site_title: HSBC profits fall 29% as Brexit bites
summary: HSBC reported a 29% decline in half-year profits to US$9.7 billion, citing the impact of Brexit on its UK business. Group chairman Douglas Flint described the period as "heightened uncertainty" with economic risks overshadowed by political and geo-political events. Group CEO Stuart Gulliver predicted tough times ahead, expecting volatility to continue for some time. Net profit for the first half fell 28% to US$6.91 billion, with UK business entering a new era as Britain negotiates its departure from the EU.

site_title: Xero partners UOB to let small businesses manage their cashflow
summary: Xero, an online accounting software, has partnered with United Overseas Bank (UOB) to enable small businesses to manage their cash flow more efficiently. The integration allows UOB customers to automatically transfer their bank transactions to Xero, saving time and administrative work. This is part of Xero's over 80 financial institution integrations worldwide, aiming to create a financial web that simplifies small business finances. The partnership is also in line with UOB's BizSmart solution, designed to help small businesses streamline their administrative work and improve their bottom line.

site_title: Taiwan says set to order Uber to exit market
summary: Taiwan's Investment Commission plans to order Uber to exit the domestic market due to the company misrepresenting its business as an internet-based information technology platform rather than a transportation service. A final decision is expected by August 11. This move comes after the commission found that Uber misrepresented its business in Taiwan.

site_title: China should cut interest rates, researchers at its top economic planner say
summary: Researchers at China's National Development and Reform Commission called for interest rate cuts and "proactive" fiscal policy to boost investment and lower business costs amid downward pressure on spending. They also suggested implementing measures to remove excess capacity, promote healthy property investment, and reduce housing inventories. The commission's research office, which advises on economic planning, rarely comments on monetary policy, highlighting the need for further monetary easing to support China's economic growth.

site_title: Hyatt CEO says hotel company in active talks on 'couple' sales
summary: Hyatt Hotels Corp is in talks to sell some of its properties as the company weighs purchasing opportunities in key markets. CEO Mark Hoplamazian stated that Hyatt is active in discussions on disposition and acquisition, aiming to recycle its assets to fund growth. The company sold the Andaz 5th Avenue in Manhattan to Japan's Takenaka Corp for $250 million in June, generating $10 million in earnings. Hyatt has cut its forecast for revenue per available room growth this year to 2-3%, following industry-wide decelerating growth.

site_title: China's online population exceeds 700m: govt
summary: China's online population has surpassed 700 million, according to the government-linked China Internet Network Information Centre (CNNIC). The number represents a 3.1% increase from December and accounts for more than half of the world's largest national population. The country is pushing for an "internet plus" project to modernize its economy, with e-commerce playing a vital role. However, rural users remain underrepresented, with less than a third of the total population accessing the internet. Beijing's strict online controls and censorship policies also continue to shape the country's online landscape.

site_title: China Inc has US$1t in cash that it's too scared to spend
summary: China's companies have a record $1.2 trillion in cash reserves, a 18% increase from the previous quarter, amid the country's weakest economic expansion in a quarter century. This surge in cash holdings surpasses the US, Europe, and Japan. The unprecedented hoard is frustrating policymakers and investors, with some warning of potential economic pressures. The growth in cash holdings highlights the uncertainty surrounding China's economic prospects, which are expected to slow, raising concerns for policymakers.

site_title: Keppel's former agent in Brazil says managers backed bribes
summary: Keppel Corp, a Singapore-based offshore oil rig builder, faces growing corruption allegations in Brazil. A former agent, Zwi Skornicki, testified in court that top executives, including CEO Chow Yew Yuen, authorized bribes to win Petrobras contracts worth over $1 billion. Keppel denies the allegations, stating it has zero tolerance for illegal activities and will investigate. The company has terminated its relationship with Skornicki, who claimed he was given autonomy to sign contracts with Petrobras on behalf of Keppel. The allegations come as a major client, Sete Brasil Participacoes, has filed for bankruptcy protection.

site_title: Australia new vehicle sales resilient in July: VFACTS
summary: Australia's new vehicle sales declined 1.1% in July to 91,331 units, the second-best result for the month ever, despite a slight dip from last year. The market is on track for a record-breaking year, with a running total of 689,471 units, 2.8% ahead of the same period last year. SUV sales cooled, while passenger vehicles fell 8.2%, but light commercial vehicles saw a 8.5% increase. Toyota maintained its lead with 19.1% market share, followed by Mazda and Hyundai.

site_title: Gold rises back above US$1,360 as talk of US rate hikes fades
summary: Gold prices rose to a three-week high on Tuesday, reaching US$1,365.09 an ounce, after US growth data showed softer-than-expected results, reducing expectations for a near-term interest rate hike. European and US shares fell, while the US dollar hit its lowest in over a month. Platinum and palladium also surged, with platinum hitting its highest since April 2015. Analysts attribute the price increase to concerns over interest rates and equities, with the likelihood of a Fed rate hike possibly delayed until 2017.

site_title: Australia shares slide on bank funding concerns, NZ stocks fall
summary: Australian shares fell 0.92% to a near two-week low, with the S&P/ASX 200 index at 5,489.8 points, amid concerns over wholesale funding of the country's financial sector. The decline was attributed to banks passing less interest rate reduction to mortgage holders and raising term deposits. New Zealand's benchmark index fell 0.39% to 7,300.66 points. Analysts questioned whether banks are raising capital without tapping the wholesale market, impacting bank shares and sector performance.

site_title: PM Lee, Obama toast 50 years of Singapore-US ties at state dinner
summary: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong and US President Barack Obama toasted 50 years of diplomatic relations between Singapore and the US at a state dinner at the White House. The event, attended by around 200 people, was the 12th state dinner hosted by Obama and the first for a South-east Asian nation. The dinner celebrated the milestone anniversary and honored notable guests, including authors, actors, and former US officials.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks slip to near 2-week low, won weakens
summary: South Korean shares fell to a near two-week low, with the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) down 0.7% at 2,004.07 points. The won also eased, down 0.2% to 1,112.0. Investors were cautious amid a decline in global stock markets, with foreign buyers breaking a 19-day buying streak. Decliners outnumbered advancers 571 to 220, with automobile-related shares slumping. Analysts expect a rebound in local equities, citing positive second-quarter earnings results.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks fall; HTC down after Q2 loss
summary: Taiwan's main stock index fell 0.7% to 9,005.29 on Wednesday, following declines in other Asian markets. HTC, a struggling smartphone maker, dropped after reporting a loss for the second quarter. The electronics subindex sank 0.9% and the financials subindex lost 0.4%. The losses were attributed to the decline in HTC's shares, which were down 5.2% at 0244 GMT.

site_title: Newly elected protectionist senators could harm Australia's trade ties
summary: Australians' newly elected protectionist senators may harm the country's trade ties with China, Indonesia, and the US. The razor-thin government majority and Senate composition pose a concern for Australian living standards and jobs. The parliament is set to sit on August 30, and Trade Minister Steve Ciobo warns that pro-protectionist forces will degrade living standards and harm jobs. This shift may impact Australia's economic relationships with key trading partners.

site_title: US says will defend itself, allies after North Korea missile test
summary: The US has warned it will defend itself and its allies after North Korea test-fired a ballistic missile towards the Sea of Japan. The US State Department said it remains prepared to work with allies and partners to respond to further provocations, and plans to rally against Pyongyang at the UN. The US commitment to defending South Korea and Japan remains "ironclad," and the UN Security Council has imposed its toughest sanctions on North Korea to date. The US has warned of "real consequences" if North Korea continues nuclear and missile tests in defiance of UN sanctions.

site_title: Noble Group shares retreat to lowest since 2003 in Singapore
summary: Noble Group shares plummeted 5.3% to a 13-year low of 12.6 Singapore cents, their lowest since 2003, ahead of a rights issue and quarterly earnings report. The stock dropped for a second consecutive day, prompting a query from the Singapore exchange. Noble Group, a Hong Kong-based commodity trader, attributed the decline to being unaware of the reason for the move.

images.alt_text: Noble Group Ltd dropped for a second day in Singapore, slumping to the lowest price since 2003, ahead of a one-week period that'll see the commodity trader's new rights-issue stock begin trading and the company report quarterly earnings.

site_title: Southwest Air flight attendants join CEO, COO no-confidence vote
summary: Southwest Airlines flight attendants have joined pilots and mechanics in a no-confidence vote against CEO Gary Kelly and COO Mike Van de Ven, citing the company's failure to update its aging computer system. The Transport Workers Union Local 556 approved the resolution, criticizing the executives for spending billions on stock buybacks instead of addressing operational failures. The unions are in contract talks with the airline, but the no-confidence votes are seen as an effort to pressure the airline into meeting demands.

site_title: Aeromexico boosting international flights, a contrast to US carriers
summary: Aeromexico, Mexico's largest airline group, is increasing the frequency of flights on five main international routes, including daily flights to Amsterdam, London, and Santiago, Chile. The airline will also boost seat capacity to Madrid by 15% and service to Asian destinations such as Shanghai by over 65%. These changes contrast with US carriers, which have been reducing international flights.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks tumble at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted 1.74% at the open on Wednesday, following a global sell-off triggered by a typhoon in the city the previous day. The Hang Seng Index fell to 21,743.32, while the Shanghai Composite Index dropped 0.27% to 2,963.21. This decline was attributed to losses on Wall Street and investors playing catch-up after the market was closed due to the typhoon.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 3.44 points to 1657.44. The market saw 98 gainers and 71 losers, with a total volume of 94.2 million lots worth RM23.4 million.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on US stocks slip
summary: Singapore shares opened 0.98% lower at 2,828.66 on Wednesday, following a decline in US stocks overnight, with retailers and carmakers taking a hit. The Straits Times Index (STI) saw 62.2 million shares change hands, with losers beating gainers 81 to 44.

site_title: North Korea fires ballistic missile into sea off east coast: South Korea
summary: North Korea fired a ballistic missile into the sea off its east coast, South Korea's military said on Wednesday. This is the latest in a series of missile launches by the North in defiance of UN Security Council resolutions. The previous launch was two weeks ago, when it fired three ballistic missiles into the sea. Details of the missile are not immediately available.

site_title: Stocks to watch: PACC Offshore Services, Global Yellow Pages, SingHaiyi
summary: PACC Offshore Services Holdings posted a net loss of US$17.5 million for Q2, reversing a profit from the same period last year. Global Yellow Pages expects a loss for FY2016 due to impairment and fair value losses. Meanwhile, SingHaiyi's Celine Tang has taken the reins at OKH Global, a property developer, as executive chairman and CEO.

site_title: An American is left to salvage BBC's ailing 'Top Gear'
summary: Matt LeBlanc, an American actor best known for his role in the sitcom "Friends," is set to lead the BBC's popular car show "Top Gear" after Jeremy Clarkson's departure. LeBlanc's predecessor, Chris Evans, failed to gain traction. The show is a significant cultural export for the BBC, generating over £50 million annually in international sales. LeBlanc's success will be crucial to the show's continued popularity, as it is a key revenue stream for the BBC's commercial arm, BBC Worldwide.

site_title: US dollar struggles at 6-week low as US rate hike prospects cool
summary: The US dollar is at a six-week low against a basket of currencies due to cooling expectations for a near-term US interest rate hike. The dollar's value was hurt by unconvincing economic data and pessimistic views on the US economy, which could lead to a cautious Federal Reserve to keep interest rates low. The euro was little changed, while the yen rose 0.2% against the dollar, with some analysts predicting a potential break below the 100 yen threshold. The Australian dollar also rose against the dollar, despite an interest rate cut by the Reserve Bank of Australia.

site_title: Korea Post's 110t won fund to purchase US stocks, bonds
summary: South Korea's Korea Post, a state-run fund overseeing 110 trillion won (S$132.4 billion) in savings and insurance, plans to boost its holdings of US assets amid record-low interest rates and sagging economic growth at home. The fund aims to increase its foreign investments to around 20% of assets and will focus on US equities, bonds, and alternative investments such as hedge funds and real estate. This move follows other state-run funds, including the National Pension Service, which also plans to increase its overseas investments to more than 35% by 2021.

site_title: Japanese PM Abe to pick hawkish ally for defence in cabinet rejig
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe is expected to appoint conservative ally Tomomi Inada as defence minister, a move that could strain relations with China and South Korea. Inada, a hawkish politician, shares Abe's goal of revising Japan's post-war constitution, which some conservatives consider a symbol of Japan's past militarism. The appointment could be seen as preparation for constitutional revision and a stern stance towards China, with Abe set to travel to China in September for a Group of 20 summit.

site_title: Bitcoin plunges after hackers breach HK exchange, steal coins
summary: Bitcoin plummeted 7.3% against the dollar after Hong Kong-based exchange Bitfinex disclosed a security breach, halting trading, withdrawals, and deposits. The breach resulted in bitcoin losses, with prices down 15% over two days. The exchange acknowledged that some bitcoin have been stolen from users and is cooperating with law enforcement. This is similar to the 2014 Mt Gox hack, which led to a 30% price drop. Bitfinex's losses are limited to bitcoin, and it is still investigating the breach.

site_title: Foreign rail firms shunted as "Made in China" mantra gathers pace
summary: Foreign rail firms are struggling to access China's vast railway market as the government tightens bidding criteria, favoring local companies. The "Made in China 2025" plan prioritizes domestically competitive firms, leading to concerns of an uneven playing field. Foreign-invested companies, such as Knorr-Bremse and Siemens, are losing out on contracts, with some reporting discriminatory treatment. The European Chamber of Commerce in China warns of an increasingly hostile business environment, with restrictions on foreign companies bidding directly for rolling stock and signalling business.

site_title: French police patrol UK ferries after attacks
summary: France has introduced sea patrols for UK-bound ferries, starting August 1, following recent jihadist attacks. The marine police unit will conduct random but regular patrols to secure vessels against the terrorist threat. The measure aims to enhance security for passengers traveling between France and Britain.

site_title: Singtel tops governance rankings
summary: Singtel has been ranked the most well-governed and transparent company in Singapore for the sixth time by the Singapore Governance and Transparency Index (SGTI). The telecom company excelled in board responsibilities and executive remuneration disclosure, as well as stakeholder engagement practices. The SGTI incorporates the G20/OECD Principles of Corporate Governance and is jointly published by CPA Australia, NUS Business School, and the Singapore Institute of Directors. This ranking reinforces Singtel's commitment to corporate governance and transparency.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower, extend global sell-off
summary: Tokyo stocks declined 1.54% on Wednesday, extending a global sell-off, as a stronger yen hit exporters. The Nikkei 225 index fell to 16,138.72 and the Topix index plummeted 1.79% to 1,276.88. Investors shrugged off a government stimulus package, despite its potential to boost the economy. The decline was part of a broader global sell-off, with markets in Europe and the US also experiencing losses.

site_title: Abenomics return to fiscal lever shows failure to hit goals
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe has approved a 28 trillion yen spending-and-lending package to stimulate the economy, exceeding the 4 trillion yen initially planned. The move comes amid public concern that Abenomics, a three-arched economic plan, is failing to hit its ambitious targets. The package includes cash handouts for low-income individuals and low-cost loans, but analysts say it may not have a sustained impact. The government aims to boost productivity gains, not just fiscal policy, to revive the economy, which has struggled with growth below 1% for three years.

site_title: Verizon to buy GPS vehicle-tracking company Fleetmatics for US$2.4b
summary: Verizon agreed to buy GPS vehicle-tracking company Fleetmatics Group Plc for $2.4 billion, a 40% premium to Fleetmatics' closing price. The deal is expected to close in the fourth quarter and will help Verizon expand its presence in the automotive-technology market. This acquisition follows Verizon's recent purchase of Yahoo!'s Web assets for $4.83 billion and is aimed at improving liquidity. The deal is seen as a strategic move to restore Verizon's credit rating profile by 2019 and build on its growing commercial fleet management segment.

images.alt_text: With its wireless business slowing, Verizon has been pursuing new sources of growth like mobile advertising, streaming video and the so-called Internet of Things.

site_title: One Raffles Place stake boosts OUE C-Reit Q2 DPU
summary: OUE C-Reit, a Singapore office space landlord, reported a 139.8% increase in net property income to S$35.2 million for Q2, driven by revenue contributions from its majority stake in One Raffles Place. The trust's DPU rose to 1.36 Singapore cents, up from 1.01 cents last year. However, the trust manager warned of potential vacancy rate increases in Singapore and Shanghai due to new office supply in the second half of 2016.

site_title: US auto sales grow in July, with signs of slowdown
summary: US auto sales grew in July, but at a slower pace, with major automakers posting declines. General Motors, Toyota, and Ford reported declines of 2%, 1.4%, and 3% respectively. The industry's six-year boom may be slowing, indicating a possible slowdown in the market.

site_title: Yen strengthens as Japan announces stimulus
summary: Japan's Cabinet adopted a $273 billion stimulus package to revive its listless economy, including infrastructure spending and efforts to raise the birthrate. The yen rose against the US dollar and euro, while the euro and British pound also gained. This move comes amid dwindling hopes for a US interest rate hike in September, following the release of weak US quarterly growth figures. Personal spending figures showed rising incomes, but not at the expected pace.

site_title: Asia: Stocks drop after yen jumps on Abe stimulus disappointment
summary: Asian stocks fell for a second day, dropping 0.9% as the yen surged 1.5% against the US dollar following Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's stimulus package. The MSCI Asia Pacific Index declined, with Japan's Topix index sliding 1.8%. Risk-averse investors sent global equities lower, amid concerns about the global recovery. The US stock market also retreated, with the S&P 500 index dropping 0.6% on Tuesday. The disappointing stimulus package is expected to negatively impact Asian stocks, reflecting the negative response seen in the US and Europe.

site_title: India's biggest tax reform looms, many companies unprepared
summary: India is poised to pass its biggest tax reform since independence, the Goods and Services Tax (GST), with a constitutional amendment likely to be passed by parliament by year's end. The GST aims to transform India's US$2 trillion economy into a single market, but many companies, particularly smaller ones, are unprepared for the likely impact and seeking advice. The tax rate and scope are still unknown, and experts warn that a high rate could lead to economic slowdown, while the government's target launch date of April 1, 2017, may be ambitious.

images.alt_text: Mr Modi's government favours a GST rate of 18 per cent but states are lobbying for more.

site_title: In first since April, oil closes below US$40 in New York
summary: Oil prices dropped below $40 in New York for the first time since April, as bear markets continued due to a supply glut, weak demand, and increasing production. A barrel of West Texas Intermediate closed at $39.51, while Brent in London fell to $41.80. Analysts attribute the decline to a softening of demand in the US summer and increasing production from OPEC countries, with the number of active drilling rigs in the US rising.

site_title: UK bank voice warns of London's status shrinking after Brexit
summary: The UK's financial lobby group, TheCityUK, warns that London's status as the world's pre-eminent financial hub could be undermined if the UK loses the right to sell its services freely within the European Union after Brexit. TheCityUK emphasizes the importance of access to the EU single market, citing Europe's biggest companies' reliance on London for capital and financial advice. UK Prime Minister Theresa May has vowed to restrict EU citizen immigration, but the financial industry urges decisive action to sustain its competitive advantages, risking tax revenue and thousands of jobs.

images.alt_text: London's financial lobby group warned that the city's status as the world's pre-eminent financial hub could be undermined if the UK loses the right to sell its services freely within the European Union as doubts mount over Britain's ability to retain full access to the trading bloc.

site_title: Obama says Trump 'unfit' to be president
summary: US President Barack Obama publicly rebuked Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump, calling him "unfit" to be president due to his unpreparedness and divisive comments. Trump's campaign has been marred by multiple scandals, including criticism of Muslims, babies, firefighters, and the military. Obama urged Republican party leaders to disown Trump, highlighting the party's need for unity.

site_title: Singapore, US to enhance bilateral strategic partnership
summary: Singapore and the US announced plans to enhance their bilateral strategic partnership, celebrating 50 years of diplomatic relations in 2016. Key areas of cooperation include Smart City development, digital innovation, counter-terrorism efforts, and cybersecurity. The two countries also launched a new exchange scholarship, ramped up military training in Guam, and inked an agreement to cooperate on cybersecurity issues. The partnership aims to deepen people-to-people links, support peace and stability in the region, and promote cooperation globally.

images.alt_text: Singapore and the United States will enhance their bilateral strategic partnership as they celebrate 50 years of diplomatic relations in 2016.

site_title: Teva completes US$40b purchase of Allergan generics arm
summary: Teva Pharmaceutical Industries has completed its $40 billion acquisition of Allergan's generics arm, Actavis Generics, making it one of the world's largest drugmakers. The deal catapults Teva into the top 10 pharmaceutical firms globally and gives it a large market lead in the generics market. Teva CEO Erez Vigodman expects net efficiency savings of $1.4 billion over the next three years and aims to branch out into specialty areas such as migraine and respiratory problems, with plans to become a more integrated company.

site_title: UK finance body urges courting "old friends" like US, Japan post Brexit
summary: The UK finance body, TheCityUK, has urged the government to strengthen ties with European companies, including the US and Japan, to preserve Britain's global role in finance after leaving the EU. The industry body published a report highlighting the importance of maintaining access to the single market and securing the backing of European corporates. It called on the government to strengthen its Financial Services Trade and Investment Board and to focus on "old friends" like the US and Japan, rather than new markets in China and India.

site_title: Didi shows Uber the way to doing business in tough China market
summary: Uber is exiting the Chinese market after a year-long battle with Didi Chuxing, with the Chinese company acquiring Uber's local business for $35 billion. The deal will give Didi a 20% stake in the enlarged company. Uber's loss in China comes after the company spent $2 billion on subsidies and was unable to gain traction. The move is seen as a setback for Uber, but analysts believe it could have been worse. The deal clears the way for Uber to focus on other markets, including India and South-east Asia, and may pave the way for an initial public offering.

site_title: US air strikes intensify Western focus on Libya
summary: The US has conducted air strikes against Islamic State (IS) militants in Libya's coastal city of Sirte, following a request from the UN-backed Government of National Accord (GNA). The strikes mark a deepening commitment to bolstering the Libyan administration militarily, politically, and economically. IS estimates suggest the group has doubled its fighters in Libya to 4,000-6,000, posing a threat to regional stability. The international community, including the US, UK, and EU, are working to stabilize Libya, restore oil production, and prevent IS from establishing a stronghold in the country.

site_title: US: Stocks down as retailers, automakers pummeled
summary: US stocks fell on Tuesday due to disappointing auto sales and poor forecasted summer sales for retailers. Automakers Fiat Chrysler, Ford, and General Motors dropped 4-4.4% respectively, while retailers Macy's, Nordstrom, and Kohl's fell 6% or more. Other factors contributing to the market retreat included a drop in oil prices. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.5%, the S&P 500 fell 0.6%, and the Nasdaq Composite Index shed 0.9%.

site_title: China's e-commerce boom a lesson for creating jobs in India
summary: India needs to add 80 million jobs by 2025 to manage its youth population, but will fall short by 24 million due to the services sector's lack of employment. E-commerce could fill half of this gap if India replicates China's online shopping boom, according to HSBC economists. This is a lesson for India to create jobs, as China's e-commerce growth created millions of jobs.

site_title: Lone Chinese hotelier finds a way to dodge purge on extravagance
summary: China Lodging Group Ltd, a Shanghai-based hotel operator, has defied the government's crackdown on extravagance, rising 23% in 2016 to US$38.43. The company's strong presence in major cities like Shanghai and Beijing has helped it adapt to the new consumption climate, while competitors have struggled. Analysts attribute this success to robust demand for accommodation in Beijing and Shanghai, driven by tourism and new theme parks, such as Shanghai Disneyland.

site_title: Europe: Shares fall as Commerzbank slumps to record low
summary: European shares fell to a three-week low on Tuesday, led by a 9.2% drop in Commerzbank after it warned its earnings would fall this year due to decreased borrowing and negative interest rates. The bank's capital position was also a concern after it ranked among the weakest banks in a recent EU stress test. This slump followed a three-day rally, with other European stocks experiencing a similar decline.

site_title: Warts and all, Americans love their candidates
summary: US presidential candidates Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton enjoy strong support from their respective base, despite numerous scandals and controversies surrounding them. Trump has faced criticism for his inflammatory comments and policies, including his stance on Muslims and his willingness to recognize Russia's annexation of Crimea. Meanwhile, Clinton has been accused of unethical behavior, including her use of a private email server as secretary of state. A recent poll shows that both candidates are running close in the polls, with Trump's supporters attributing his behavior to a "frontal assault on democratic norms" and Clinton's supporters viewing her actions as "conventional" and typical of a politician.

site_title: New Zealand wage growth remains subdued
summary: New Zealand's wage growth remains subdued, with private sector wage inflation totaling 0.4% in the June quarter and 1.6% compared to the same quarter last year. This is lower than economists' forecast of 0.5% on the quarter and 1.8% on the year. The slow wage growth is attributed to a period of slow consumer inflation, which may put pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Global M&A to remain sluggish until UK decides on EU exit plan: survey
summary: A survey of 1,001 M&A professionals found that global mergers and acquisitions will remain sluggish until the UK clarifies its exit plan from the EU. 70% of respondents believe the number of deals will fall until Brexit worries subside. The value of announced M&A deals worldwide dropped by a third in the second quarter, and dealmaking in Britain suffered before the June 23 Brexit referendum. 66% of global dealmakers expect a drop in demand for British assets, while 82% of British dealmakers believe Brexit will have a negative economic impact on their region.

site_title: Brazil impeachment trial closer to sealing Rousseff's fate
summary: Brazil's suspended President Dilma Rousseff's impeachment trial is nearing its conclusion after a Senate report found she manipulated government accounts, violating the constitution. The report, set to be approved by the full Senate next Tuesday, will lead to the final trial phase where 81 Senators must reach a verdict by the end of August or early September. The impeachment has paralyzed Brazilian politics for seven months, hindering efforts to address the country's fiscal crisis and severe recession. Rousseff's fate is now largely in the hands of the Senate.

site_title: MAS sets up international panel to tap advice on fintech
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has established a 15-member international panel to provide advice on fintech developments. The panel, convened on August 2, discussed emerging trends in fintech, including decentralized systems and new business models. MAS chairman Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam led the meeting, which aimed to facilitate innovation and adoption of new technologies while maintaining trust and confidence. The panel will meet again in 2017, marking another step in Singapore's efforts to become a fintech hub.

site_title: High street brands replace luxury stores that exit HK prime space
summary: High street brands, including H&M, Maison Kitsune, and Innisfree, are moving into prime shopping districts in Hong Kong, previously occupied by luxury stores that exited due to weak sales. This trend is driven by falling rents and a slump in retail sales, with luxury goods experiencing a 21% decline in sales from January to May. Experts predict mass market brands may struggle to achieve the same margins as luxury retailers, but are attracted to the lower rents.

site_title: Singapore bonds up despite Swiber woes
summary: Singapore's bond market continues to perform well, with the Markit iBoxx Singapore corporates return index hitting a new high of 117.43 on August 1. Despite the high-profile collapse of Swiber debt, investors are flocking to safer Singapore-dollar issues, driven by low interest rates and a global trend of corporate bonds outperforming equities. The Singapore Fixed Income Index is up 5.41% year-to-date, outperforming the Straits Times Index by 5.9%. Experts attribute the market's resilience to the accommodative monetary policies of central banks, which have created a "lower for longer" interest rate environment.

site_title: A grand White House welcome for PM Lee
summary: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong of Singapore was welcomed to the White House with a grand ceremony on Tuesday, marking 50 years of diplomatic relations between Singapore and the US. The event featured a 19-gun salute, a review of the guard-of-honour, and a private bilateral meeting with President Barack Obama. Lee reaffirmed Singapore's commitment to the US, stating that the country will maintain bipartisan links regardless of the upcoming presidential election. The visit included a state luncheon and a state dinner, the first time Singapore has received this honor since 1985.

site_title: Melding the best of both worlds
summary: Impact Investment Exchange Asia (IIX) is a platform that marries investment capital with social enterprises, aiming to create a sustainable and profitable business model. Founded in 2009, IIX has helped channel over $13 million of capital for development, generating $20 million in social value and benefiting 10 million lives. The organization is working towards launching its first "impact exchange" in Mauritius, listing a Women's Livelihood Bond supported by the Rockefeller Foundation and USAID. IIX also offers various programs, including an impact accelerator and academy, to support social enterprises and investors in impact investing.

site_title: Slew of resignations hits Foreland Fabrictech
summary: Foreland Fabrictech Holdings Ltd has faced a slew of resignations, including executive chairman Tsoi Kin Chit, executive director Zhang Hong Lai, and non-executive director Chen Chao Ying, citing "other interests". The resignations come after an independent audit in May raised doubts on the validity of a defective dyed textile claim by customer Jiangxi Longdu, resulting in a 282.99 million yuan compensation payment to Fulian. Foreland Fabrictech has appointed Yang Meng Yang as executive director and chairman, and identified a professional accounting firm to be the statutory auditors.

site_title: Australia cuts rates to record low to counter disinflation, spur jobs
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) cut interest rates to a record low of 1.5% to counter disinflation and support the labor market, which has been hampered by high part-time work and underemployment. The move aims to boost economic growth and inflation, which remains low. The RBA also noted that the labor market indicators are consistent with a modest pace of expansion in employment, but the period of low inflation is uncertain.

site_title: Glimmerglass Festival spotlights opera-musical divide
summary: The Glimmerglass Festival in Cooperstown, NY, hosted a discussion on the opera-musical divide, with composer and lyricist Stephen Sondheim stating that the difference lies in audience expectations. A production of Sondheim's Sweeney Todd, set in a community hall and presented in a realistic setting, was performed without amplification, highlighting the differences between opera and musicals. The festival also presented Robert Ward's 1961 opera The Crucible, which was faithful to the original play but lacked dramatic effect due to melodramatic flourishes and abridging the text. The event showcased the challenges of presenting a musical with operatic voices without amplification.

site_title: Equity traders flip from hate to love for China
summary: Equity traders have shifted their sentiment towards China from negative to positive in less than half a year, with a gauge of firms in developed markets that get sales from China rising 33% since February, outpacing global shares. This recovery follows a slump of up to 35% in less than a year. The rebound is attributed to China's economic growth and companies' efforts to tap into the Asian market.

site_title: Why did board not consider JM or creditor scheme before winding-up move?
summary: Swiber Holdings Ltd, a Singapore-listed offshore and marine business, applied to the High Court of Singapore to voluntarily wind up the company on July 28, 2016, after announcing the appointment of provisional liquidators and the resignation of three executive directors. The company had also taken out applications for judicial management. The sudden move shocked the market and raised concerns about timely and accurate disclosures, highlighting the need for transparency and fairness in public announcements. An investigation into the circumstances leading to Swiber's winding-up application is underway, which may shed more light on the company's decision-making process.

site_title: Greater regulatory independence: a difficult but necessary road
summary: Singapore's stock exchange, SGX, is shifting towards greater regulatory independence. After struggling with conflicts of interest and public skepticism, the exchange has set up separate committees and a wholly-owned subsidiary, RegCo, to oversee listings and disciplinary matters. While these steps are a step in the right direction, RegCo's independence is still uncertain as it is tied to the for-profit SGX. The move aims to address concerns and pave the way for total independence, but experts caution that it won't be easy, citing the need for careful study of other jurisdictions' models.

site_title: S'pore, US sign MOU to take infrastructure tie-ups to next level
summary: Singapore and the US have signed a memorandum of understanding to foster greater collaboration in the infrastructure sector, promoting technology partnerships between Singaporean and American firms in third-party markets. The agreement aims to take infrastructure tie-ups to the next level, enhancing economic growth and competitiveness. The signing took place in Washington, marking a significant step in strengthening bilateral ties between the two nations.

site_title: Singapore's weak July PMI backs economists' downbeat views
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sector showed a decline in July, with the purchasing managers' index (PMI) falling to 49.3, a 0.3 drop from the previous month. This downward trend is in line with economists' expectations of sectoral activity easing in the months ahead. The weaker PMI indicates a weaker manufacturing sector, which could have broader implications for the country's economy.

site_title: Dim global growth forecast fails to deter metals investors
summary: Investors in metals and mining are pouring money into industrial metals despite a dimming global growth forecast, with copper, zinc, and nickel prices rising as expectations of increased demand and slower production grow. The market is focusing on rising demand for key metals and slower production, with China's real-estate sector driving growth and US purchases of new single-family homes reaching a 8-year high. The World Bank and IMF forecast 3.1% expansion this year, but investors are optimistic about future demand growth.

site_title: Malaysia may attend US suit on 1MDB-linked seizures: report
summary: Malaysia may attend a US Department of Justice civil suit to seize over $1 billion in assets linked to the 1MDB scandal. Attorney-General Mohamed Apandi Ali is considering a "watching brief" to protect Malaysia's interests. The move comes despite the Malaysian government initially stating it would not get involved in the private matter between US authorities and four defendants.

site_title: POSH sails into loss territory as market conditions worsen
summary: POSH, an offshore marine services provider, reported a net loss of US$17.5 million for the second quarter, reversing a net profit of US$6.1 million in the previous quarter. The loss was driven by a surge in general and administrative expenses and a decline in revenue from its OSV, OA, and T&I businesses, which dropped 35% to US$46.1 million. The company's CEO attributed the financial performance to the industry's uncertainty, vowing to focus on cost reduction and improving vessel utilization to achieve positive net operating cash generation.

site_title: Impact investing via private equity (Amended)
summary: Credit Suisse has partnered with UOB Venture Management to launch the Asian Impact Investment Vehicle, a private equity fund focused on social and environmental impact enterprises. The fund aims to raise $100 million and invest in companies in Asia, particularly in regions such as China, Indonesia, and Laos, with a focus on sectors like agriculture, healthcare, and clean energy. The fund is marketed exclusively to Credit Suisse clients and is expected to deliver returns aligned with the market, with a typical hurdle rate of 6-8%. The goal is to invest in companies with a proven business model that can generate both social and financial returns.

site_title: New production gives Richard III a twist
summary: A new production of Shakespeare's Richard III at the Almeida Theater has been compared to current politics, with audiences drawing parallels between the play's themes of power and manipulation and Brexit. The production's twist on the classic tale has resonated with audiences, who see the story as eerily relevant to contemporary politics. The play's exploration of ambition, power, and the consequences of unchecked ego has struck a chord with viewers, making it a timely and thought-provoking production.

site_title: Ratifying TPP a litmus test of US's credibility: PM Lee
summary: US Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong urged American industry leaders to support the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) ratification, calling it a "litmus test of US credibility" in Asia. He emphasized that ratification would be a statement of the US commitment to the region and a unique opportunity to anchor engagement. However, Loong acknowledged that the ratification process would be "politically tough" during the US election season, potentially affecting the country's credibility internationally.

site_title: CFOs play crucial role in shaping tech agenda
summary: Chief Financial Officers (CFOs) are increasingly expected to play a bigger role in shaping technology agendas for their organizations due to the impact of new technology on business. A recent survey of nearly 90 CFOs found that two-thirds of those polled see evolving technology as a major challenge. However, many CFOs feel that technology is outside their remit and lack the necessary skills and knowledge to effectively partner with the CIO and IT functions. To overcome this, CFOs must develop their business partnering skills and stay up-to-date with the latest technologies, including blockchain, to drive successful technology investments and improve operations.

site_title: It's OK to spend a bit as world wriggles free of austerity grip
summary: Governments worldwide are planning increased spending to boost growth and support wages, following advice from economists like Larry Summers. This shift signals the rise of pro-growth leaders like Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe and the decline of austerity advocates like former UK Chancellor George Osborne. The move aims to address stagnant productivity and an aging society.

site_title: STB, NATAS launch Travel Agent Roadmap
summary: The Singapore Tourism Board (STB) and the National Association of Travel Agents Singapore (NATAS) have launched the Travel Agent Roadmap to enhance the industry's capability and sustainability. The roadmap focuses on three main areas: business transformation, technology, and manpower. It aims to guide travel agents to become "Designers of Travel Experience" and address the trend of consumers planning trips online. A new committee and resources will be provided to support travel agents in adopting new business models and technologies, with a goal of increasing their competitiveness and productivity in the dynamic travel landscape.

site_title: Thailand's anti-junta 'Red Shirts' charged as referendum looms
summary: Thailand's anti-junta 'Red Shirts' were charged on Tuesday with breaching a ban on political gatherings as a referendum looms next Sunday. The referendum will decide on a new military-drafted constitution, the first vote since the generals toppled the elected government in 2014. 19 leaders of the pro-democracy "Red Shirt" movement were charged with breaching the ban.

site_title: Consumer confidence in S'pore low but stable in Q2: Nielsen
summary: Singapore's consumer confidence remained unchanged in Q2 at 88 points, the lowest level since 2009. Job security and the economy are top concerns, with 49% identifying recessionary sentiment, down from 52% in the previous quarter. Despite easing anxiety, concerns about job security and debt increased. Consumers are allocating spare cash towards savings and building a secure financial nest, but spending on holidays, new clothes, and home improvements decreased. Singaporeans are still among the top spenders on vacations, ranking third globally.

site_title: O&M concerns return with a vengeance
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) plummeted 35.85 points or 1.2% to 2,856.67 on Tuesday, driven by concerns over the health of the offshore and marine (O&M) sector. Banks, particularly Singtel, were among the top index losers, with Singtel's S$0.13 drop to S$4.05 cutting 13 points off the STI. DBS shares fell S$0.21 or 1.4% to S$15.15 after Macquarie Equities Research downgraded the bank to "neutral" due to Swiber's collapse.

site_title: Oil market turns bearish on excess supply concerns
summary: Oil prices fell below $40 a barrel for the first time since April, entering a bear market, due to concerns of a global supply glut. Saudi Arabia cut prices to Asian customers, while US drillers boosted rigs, leading to the highest seasonal oil and gasoline supplies in two decades. Oil has tumbled from its June peak, with WTI settling 22% below its peak and Brent at a premium to WTI. The US oil drilling rig count reached its highest level since March, and demand is expected to decline in the coming months.

site_title: Working capital crunch may have been straw that broke the firm
summary: Swiber Holdings Ltd, a listed offshore and marine (O&M) company, narrowly escaped liquidation after its board of directors decided to apply for judicial management instead of winding up the business. The company's cash on hand was a fraction of the $25.9 million in letters of demand from creditors as of July 26. Swiber's board realized its key offshore marine subsidiary, Swiber Offshore Construction Pte Ltd, lacked working capital to carry on with projects. The company's major bank creditors, including DBS, contributed to redeeming Swiber's bonds, but their role in the decision-making process is unclear.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Singapore Airlines downgraded to "hold" by OCBC Investment Research due to industry-wide yield deterioration, increasing expenses, and potential delays in A350 deliveries. The research firm cuts its target price to S$11.56 from S$12. Meanwhile, iFAST Corporation is cut to "hold" with a target price of S$0.88 due to expected earnings decline in China and weak sentiment in the financial markets. Frasers Logistics & Industrial Trust is upgraded to "buy" with a target price of S$1.08, citing a prime Australian portfolio with fixed and/or Consumer Price Index-linked increments.

site_title: DBS says it does not issue bonds to pay down stressed loans
summary: DBS, Singapore's largest bank, denies issuing bonds to pay down stressed loans on its books, despite its role in arranging bonds for Swiber Holdings, a company with five outstanding bonds suspended from trading due to judicial management. DBS has a total exposure of S$700 million to Swiber, with a net allowance charge of S$150 million. The bank's spokeswoman says it's not unusual for a bank to lend to a company and issue bonds for it, and commission earned from bond sales is paid to the bank, not relationship managers.

site_title: 1940s Hollywood musical comedies actress Gloria DeHaven dies at 91
summary: Gloria DeHaven, a 91-year-old actress known for her roles in 1940s Hollywood musical comedies, died on July 30 from complications of a stroke. She debuted in Charlie Chaplin's Modern Times in 1936 and sang and danced alongside Gene Kelly and Fred Astaire. DeHaven's career spanned decades, with notable roles in films like Thousands Cheer and Best Foot Forward, and she transitioned to television and stage work.

site_title: Samsung to release Galaxy Note7 in Singapore from Aug 20
summary: Samsung unveiled the Galaxy Note7 in New York, with the device set to go on sale in Singapore from August 20. The Note7 features a 5.7-inch QHD Super Amoled screen, an octa-core processor, and wireless charging. It includes iris-recognition technology, a fingerprint scanner, and a Secure Folder for added security. The device also features an updated S pen stylus and supports high-dynamic-range video-streaming, HDR capabilities, and dual SIM card slots. The 64GB model will retail for S$1,168, and pre-orders start on August 3.

site_title: Citigroup expects post-Brexit uncertainties
summary: Citigroup expects a challenging business environment due to "significant uncertainties" following the UK's Brexit vote. The bank has $108.4 billion in exposure to the UK, the largest among its peers, with half of that being unfunded corporate lending commitments. Despite the uncertainty, Citigroup has not yet experienced significant negative impacts on its results. The bank is preparing for potential changes in the UK's economic growth and Federal Reserve interest rate increases.

site_title: Tokyo okays 13.5 trillion yen fiscal package
summary: Japan has approved a 13.5 trillion yen fiscal package aimed at stimulating demand and achieving sustainable economic growth. The package includes 7.5 trillion yen in government spending and 6 trillion yen from the Fiscal Investment and Loan Programme. However, the International Monetary Fund (IMF) has expressed strong doubts about Japan's economic health, citing weak demand, uncertainty over low interest rates, and financial stability risks. Despite this, analysts believe the package may succeed in restoring growth to the sluggish economy due to its backing by the government and Bank of Japan.

site_title: McDonald's tweaks recipes: real butter now, not margarine, in its McMuffins
summary: McDonald's has announced several changes to its ingredients, including eliminating artificial preservatives from some breakfast foods and Chicken McNuggets, and removing high-fructose corn syrup from its buns. The company also revealed it will start using real butter instead of margarine in its McMuffins. These changes aim to address consumer demands for healthier options and fewer artificial ingredients, as well as to compete with competitors promoting the quality and freshness of their foods.

site_title: UK's Labour faces deepening divisions with leadership contest
summary: The UK's Labour Party is facing deepening divisions with a leadership contest, with hundreds of thousands of grassroots supporters fiercely defending Jeremy Corbyn's left-wing principles. The party's internal strife has turned violent, with lawmakers receiving death threats, vandalism, and abuse. Corbyn faces a leadership challenge from Owen Smith, and if re-elected, the party risks splitting, potentially leaving Britain without a strong opposition party. The party's internal divisions have been exacerbated by Corbyn's inability to prevent Brexit and match his words with action, with some lawmakers calling for him to step down.

images.alt_text: Mr Corbyn (above) now faces leadership rival Mr Smith in a contest so divisive it could ultimately lead to the party splitting if he is re-elected leader, as the bookmakers expect.
Mr Corbyn now faces leadership rival Mr Smith (above) in a contest so divisive it could ultimately lead to the party splitting if he is re-elected leader, as the bookmakers expect.

site_title: Mumbai home prices may take 2 years to recover
summary: Mumbai home prices may take 2 years to recover due to a glut of unsold properties, according to Indiabulls Asset Management Co. Despite a 10% sales increase in the first quarter, Mumbai still has 266 million square feet of unsold homes. Private-equity firms are stepping in to fund developers as banks pull back on lending. Home prices in Mumbai are trading near a record, with prices in Delhi and its surrounding areas expected to take up to six years to recover.

site_title: Navigating volatility in a low-return world
summary: BlackRock's Investment Institute warns investors to navigate volatility in a low-return world, particularly in Europe, where sovereign bonds and gold remain useful diversifiers. The institute expects more volatility in markets due to the US presidential election, Brexit-related anxiety, and a risk of a UK recession. Emerging-market economies and currencies are stabilizing, but credit growth in China could lead to a bust in the long run. Fiscal stimulus and structural reforms are needed to foster growth, and governments face challenges in financing infrastructure spending amidst fractious politics and rising populist movements.

site_title: Nestle to invest 2b pesos in new Milo plant in Philippines
summary: Nestle Philippines will invest 2 billion pesos (S$57 million) to build a new plant to produce protomalt, a key ingredient in Milo chocolate-and-malt drink. The facility, located south of Manila, will start operations late next year and cater to the domestic market, with potential for exports. The investment is part of Nestle Philippines' expansion efforts, which have seen nearly US$300 million invested in the past five years. The Philippines is Nestle's eighth-largest market worldwide and the second-biggest in Asia, with Milo being a significant contributor to the company's revenue.

site_title: Independent or irrelevant directors?
summary: Swiber, a Singapore-based oil and gas company, has been embroiled in controversy over its corporate governance practices and disclosures. The company's board of directors, which includes six executive directors and three independent directors, has been criticized for its lack of transparency and independence. The independent directors, who lack financial and accounting expertise, have raised questions about their role and authority. The company's remuneration disclosures are also opaque, with the executive directors' fees ranging from S$500,000 to S$2 million. The chairman and deputy CEO, who are controlling shareholders, have significant influence over key decisions despite owning only 18% of the company. Regulatory actions and investigations are likely to be taken, and investors are advised to scrutinize the company's governance practices.

site_title: Pokemon sued for monster trespassing in backyard
summary: A New Jersey resident has filed a lawsuit against Niantic Inc and Nintendo Co, alleging that the companies' game Pokémon Go has created a nuisance by allowing players to trespass on private properties in search of virtual Pokémon. The complaint claims that players have visited homes, including a US Holocaust Memorial Museum and an Alabama cemetery, without permission. The lawsuit seeks class-action status and argues that the companies have shown a "flagrant disregard" for property owners' rights.

site_title: DBS says Swiber had no overdue payments with it
summary: DBS Bank said it has no overdue payments with Swiber Holdings, a company it had provided a bridging loan to. The loan was intended to be repaid after an equity injection, but the injection fell through. DBS's exposure to Swiber is significant, with a single net allowance charge of S$150 million, which is 75% of its assumed allowance for the entire oil-and-gas portfolio in a stressed scenario. Analysts question DBS's credit-risk assumptions and whether the bank underestimated the risk of Swiber's debt. DBS's net allowance charge for Swiber is lower than expected, raising concerns about the bank's ability to recover the debt.

site_title: New fund from Technology Crossover Ventures raises US$2.5b
summary: Technology Crossover Ventures (TCV) has raised US$2.5 billion for its latest fund, TCV IX. The venture capital firm, known for investing in companies like Dollar Shave Club, Netflix, and Zillow, has continued to attract investors despite concerns about the venture capital industry. This latest fund is part of a trend of large venture capital investments, indicating the industry's resilience.

site_title: Euro hits 5-week high as it rises above US$1.12
summary: The euro rose above US$1.12 for the first time in over a month, while the yen reached its strongest level in three weeks, pushing past 102 yen per dollar. The dollar index fell to 95.466 due to steady sales and weak US bond yields. Weaker-than-expected US manufacturing data and gloomy global growth prospects contributed to the dollar's decline.
