site_title: Uncertainty over Brexit will continue to bedevil markets
summary: The UK's vote to leave the European Union (Brexit) has created uncertainty and volatility in global markets, particularly for the pound, which has slumped over 10% this year. Investors are hesitant to make long-term judgments due to the complexity and protracted nature of the Brexit process, with the UK unlikely to formally begin the process until 2017. The EU wants London to start negotiations as soon as possible, but the new UK Prime Minister, Theresa May, has stated she will not rush to trigger Article 50, citing the need for preparation and maintaining market access.

site_title: Excellent E-class
summary: The new Mercedes-Benz E-Class boasts impressive safety features, including Pre-Safe Sound, which prepares the ears for impact, and innovative controls such as a super widescreen cockpit with two 12.3-inch displays. The sedan is 43mm longer and has a class-leading 0.23 drag coefficient, offering improved ride comfort and rear legroom. The E200 model features a 2.0-litre turbocharged engine, nine-speed automatic transmission, and advanced assistance programs like Pre-Safe and Active Brake Assist. The E-Class rivals the flagship S-Class in terms of luxury and features, with a starting price of S$272,888.

site_title: Keppel Land sees China home sales rising on big-city demand
summary: Keppel Land, the real estate arm of Keppel Corp, expects China home sales to rise this year due to strong demand in larger cities. The company sees signs of inventory reduction in "tier two" cities and prices consolidating upwards. China's national sales are rising despite authorities tightening home and land purchase requirements. Average new home prices in China's 70 major cities rose 7.9% in July. Keppel Land also sees opportunities in Vietnam and the UK, where the pound's slump makes property cheaper.

site_title: Tech industry's legal shield is feeling the heat
summary: The US Communications Decency Act's Section 230, a 20-year-old law shielding website operators from liability for content posted by others, is being challenged in a San Francisco case involving Airbnb. The law, enacted in 1996, has been criticized for being applied too broadly, with judges pushing back in recent cases. Section 230 has protected social media and e-commerce sites from activities not intended when it was enacted, including libelous comments and the sale of stolen photos. The outcome of the Airbnb case could impact the law's future and its application in other cases, including a similar trafficking case against Backpage.com.

site_title: Olympics: Singapore firms warned over Schooling ads
summary: Singaporean companies have been warned to stop unauthorized commercial campaigns featuring local swimmer Joseph Schooling, who won the city-state's first Olympic gold medal. The Singapore National Olympic Council advised firms to comply with International Olympic Committee rules, which restrict the use of athletes' names, images, or performances for advertising purposes during the Games. The rule, in effect from July 27 to August 24, aims to protect the assets and marks of the Games. Several local firms, including in transport, services, and retail, had publicly associated themselves with Schooling's feat on social media.

site_title: Asia capital outflows into global real estate down in H1
summary: Asian capital outflows into global real estate decreased to $17 billion in the first half of 2016, down from $18.3 billion in the same period last year. London's share of Asian capital outflows dropped to 16% from 22% over the past three years, while US cities became a larger recipient of Asian capital. Brexit is not expected to reverse the trend, with investors seeking stable markets and aggressive pricing in Asia. Chinese investors dominated Asian outbound investment, accounting for 60% of total investment, with the US being the favored target region.

site_title: Forex house FXCM illegally short of capital when Swiss franc devalued: US
summary: US regulators charged FXCM, a foreign exchange broker, with operating with inadequate capital after it was hit by the Swiss franc revaluation in 2015, leaving customers at risk of losing funds. FXCM was found to be short of its daily net capital requirement of $25 million, with losses exceeding $200 million. The company was given a $279 million cash injection to steady its finances. The Commodity Futures Trading Commission (CFTC) is seeking significant civil fines against FXCM for its failures.

site_title: Japan leaps towards Smart Factory Implementation with 1st Expo
summary: Japan is set to host its first Smart Factory Expo, showcasing the latest technologies and solutions in the "smart factory" revolution. The event aims to promote innovation and automation in manufacturing, driven by IoT and industrie 4.0 concepts. Major Japanese companies, including Mitsubishi Electric, Hitachi, and Fujitsu, are already investing in Smart Factory initiatives. The expo will also highlight 3D Additive Manufacturing and its growing adoption in Japanese factories. The event is open to global companies to participate as exhibitors or visitors, aiming to explore business opportunities in Japan's Smart Factory market.

site_title: Questions to Indiabulls went unanswered, says SIAS
summary: The Securities Investors' Association (SIAS) in Singapore claims that the board of Indiabulls Properties Investment Trust (IPIT) ignored questions sent to it regarding the trust's troubled eight-year history, including issues with asset value collapse and performance fee structures. SIAS had sent three questions to IPIT on June 30, but received no response. The association criticized IPIT's trustee-manager for its evaluation of a takeover offer, stating it was a contradiction that didn't help minority shareholders.

site_title: Developers offer townhouses to millennials hungry for ownership
summary: US townhouse construction is experiencing a resurgence among millennials, driven by affordability and accessibility. According to data, townhouse starts increased to 28,000 in the second quarter, a 26% jump from the previous year, and accounted for 13% of single-family starts. This trend is expected to continue, with small builders leading the charge, and townhouse prices reaching a 16% peak by 2007. Developers are catering to first-time buyers, who now account for 33% of sales, with townhouses offering a more affordable path to homeownership, often with walking distance to downtown areas.

site_title: Singapore's fiscal position strong despite lower real returns from GIC, Temasek: Moody's
summary: Singapore's fiscal position remains strong despite lower real returns from its GIC and Temasek Holdings, according to Moody's Investors Service. The credit-rating agency expects Singapore to meet its fiscal targets for 2016 and notes that the country has sufficient fiscal buffers to withstand deficits over the near to medium term. However, persistent low returns could weigh on budgetary balances and limit future fiscal stimulus, making lower returns a credit negative if they result in fiscal deficits or erosion of accumulated reserves.

site_title: DMX Tech and Hong Kong unit sued in the territory
summary: DMX Technologies Group Limited and its Hong Kong subsidiary DMX Technologies (Hong Kong) Limited have been sued by Chinacast Education Corporation (CEC) in Hong Kong for a sum of US$4 million. CEC claims that the companies acted as constructive trustees for the claim. DMX intends to vigorously defend the claim and will make further announcements as necessary. This lawsuit follows a previous action by Anken HR Limited, claiming a fee of S$55,000 from DMX, and comes amid an ongoing investigation into irregular accounting practices at two of DMX's subsidiaries in 2008 and 2009.

site_title: AGV Group launches IPO for Catalist listing
summary: AGV Group, a Singapore-based provider of hot dip galvanising services, has launched an initial public offering (IPO) for a Catalist listing. The company, led by the Ang brothers, plans to use the expected net proceeds of $4.3 million to fund business expansion and working capital. AGV Group posted a net profit of $2.2 million for FY2015, driven by revenue growth to $18.8 million. The IPO is priced at a price-earnings ratio of 10.2 based on FY2015 earnings, with shares priced at $0.22 apiece.

site_title: BOJ rising to top of shareholder rankings
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) is rapidly increasing its ownership of Japanese companies, projected to become the top shareholder in 55 of the Nikkei 225 Stock Average's firms by the end of next year. The central bank has boosted its annual ETF buying target to 6 trillion yen, aiming to spur economic activity and inflation. While some critics argue that the BOJ's purchases artificially inflate equity valuations, others see the strategy as effective in boosting risk appetite and reaching the 2% inflation target. The BOJ's influence on Japanese stocks rivals that of major traders, and its purchases could disrupt the market, particularly for stocks with low free float.

site_title: Slowing China home price rises could dent economic growth prospects
summary: China's home price rises slowed in July, with average prices rising 7.9% year-over-year, but only 0.8% month-over-month, the slowest pace since April. This easing of price growth has raised concerns about the economy's growth prospects and the potential for a property bubble. Analysts, including Wendy Chen at Nomura, believe the housing market is cooling down, and property investment will continue to drop, putting pressure on the economy. Local governments are tightening restrictions on home purchases, and some cities are seeing price declines, with the market remaining uneven.

site_title: US commercial paper market shrinks to 10-month low
summary: The US commercial paper market contracted to its 10-month low, with outstanding amounts falling to $1.012 trillion in the week ended Aug 17. This represents a decline of $11 billion from the previous week. Non-seasonally adjusted commercial paper outstanding also decreased to $1.019 trillion, the lowest since January 2016. The contraction is attributed to reduced demand for bank debt from domestic money market funds, which have shifted to hold only government bonds to avoid new SEC regulations.

site_title: Malaysia's economy grows 4% y-o-y in Q2 as slowdown drags on
summary: Malaysia's economy grew 4% in Q2, the slowest pace in nearly seven years, as exports and domestic investments were weak. This marks the fifth consecutive quarter of declining growth. The central bank reported a narrowed current account surplus of RM1.9 billion. The government revised its 2016 growth projection to 4.0-4.5% from 4.0-5.0%. The economic slowdown is attributed to the slowdown in exports and domestic investments.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares end higher on energy firms, exporters
summary: Tokyo stocks closed higher on Wednesday, with the Nikkei 225 index rising 0.90% to 16,745.64, and the Topix index up 0.97% to 1,311.13. A halt in the yen's rally lifted exporters, while oil-linked shares and banks rose.

site_title: Wanda Commercial says shareholders approve delisting plan
summary: Dalian Wanda Commercial Properties Co Ltd announced that shareholders have approved a $4.4 billion buyout plan, aiming to delist from the Hong Kong stock exchange and take the company private. The plan, valued at $52.8 per share, was approved by 88.5% of independent shareholders. The buyout is expected to reduce funding costs and allow the company to relist in China, where its brand is more recognized, potentially leading to a higher valuation. This move may also encourage other Hong Kong-listed Chinese firms to follow suit, tarnishing the territory's image as a major financial centre.

site_title: Coming down from the peak
summary: Nestle Chairman Peter Brabeck reflects on his nearly 50-year career, focusing on water as the most critical issue. He has been warning global leaders about a looming water crisis, which will affect 30% of the world's population within 15-20 years. Brabeck formed the 2030 Water Resources Group to accelerate reforms in water management, citing a 40% gap between supply and demand. Despite progress in raising awareness, the crisis has worsened, with a 20% water deficit. Brabeck advocates for improved water governance, pricing water correctly, and reducing waste. His comments on privatizing water supply in 2005 sparked controversy, but he clarified that water is a human right. Brabeck will step down as Nestle Chairman next year, but plans to remain involved in advisory work and monitor developments.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Singapore Medical Group, SBS Transit, Wilmar, Noble, Olam, GAR
summary: Singapore Medical Group rose to an all-time high after RHB initiated a "buy" rating and boosted its ownership in Lifescan Imaging. SBS Transit reported a 19% year-on-year net profit increase and revenue growth. In contrast, Wilmar International and Noble Group posted quarterly losses, while Olam International and Golden Agri-Resources (GAR) reported jumps in net profit.

site_title: Bukit Sembawang's Q1 earnings fall on lower profit recognition
summary: Bukit Sembawang Estates reported a 9.4% drop in net profit to S$27.5 million in its Q1 earnings, primarily due to lower profit recognition on development projects using the percentage of completion method. Revenue declined 62% to S$44.9 million, and earnings per share slipped to 10.62 Singapore cents. The group's net asset value per share edged up to S$5.09. Shares closed two cents down at S$4.60.

site_title: Australia: Shares hit 10-day low, NZ stocks end near record
summary: Australian shares hit a 10-day low, falling 0.49% to 5,507.80, amid mixed earnings reports and a rising Australian dollar. New Zealand's benchmark index rose 0.41% to a near-record high. The decline was attributed to dampened export potential and the impact of the Australian dollar's increase.

site_title: Wheelock Properties net profit doubles in Q2 2016 on Panorama, Ardmore Three sales
summary: Wheelock Properties reported a net profit of S$35.3 million for Q2 2016, doubling from S$17.7 million a year ago. Revenue nearly quadrupled to S$300.9 million due to sales of units in Ardmore Three and The Panorama, offset by lower sales and rental income. At end-June, 83% of Scotts Square units were sold, and Ardmore Three and The Panorama saw 42 and 655 units sold respectively, at average prices above S$2,800 and S$1,240 psf.

site_title: Hoe Leong 'able to pay US$920,000' related to dispute with Otto Marine
summary: Hoe Leong Corp says it has the financial resources to pay a US$920,000 sum owed to Otto Marine, despite a winding-up petition filed by Otto Marine. Hoe Leong claims the outstanding amount is the balance of a US$1.25 million payment already settled. The company plans to file a defence against Otto Marine's petition, which has a hearing fixed for September 13. Hoe Leong's majority shareholder, Hoe Leong Co, and its bankers are expected to continue supporting the company.

images.alt_text: Hoe Leong Corp has said it has the financial resources to pay a US$920,000 sum owed to Otto Marine and that it can continue on a going concern basis.

site_title: Car sales prop up June retail sales index, which posts 0.9% y-o-y increase
summary: Singapore's retail sales index rose 0.9% year-over-year in June, driven by a 17.1% increase in motor vehicle sales. Excluding motor vehicle sales, retail sales fell 3% year-over-year, with categories like telecommunications apparatus and petrol service stations experiencing significant declines. The total retail sales value in June was estimated at S$3.6 billion, similar to that in June 2015.

site_title: Cheung Kong's Victor Li says open to selling Hong Kong buildings
summary: Deputy Chairman Victor Li of Cheung Kong Property Holdings expressed openness to selling Hong Kong buildings, citing challenges in the local residential and retail markets. Despite a 51% increase in first-half profit, the company's shares slumped 4.2% due to concerns about property investments in the region. Chairman Li Ka-shing also signaled a consideration of looking outside the region for growth, with China accounting for nearly 60% of total sales in the first half. The company will pursue global investments to extend its reach to new business areas amid a challenging property market.

site_title: Europe: Germany's DAX hits 2016 high, boosted by Wall Street and earnings
summary: Germany's DAX index reached a 2016 high, closing up 2.5% at 10,701.33, driven by new highs on Wall Street and strong earnings from companies like Munich Re. The Stoxx Europe 600 also advanced for a fifth straight session, with European shares up 16% from their June low. The US S&P 500 and Nasdaq hit fresh record highs, fueled by easy monetary policy expectations. Despite Brexit volatility, investors focus on stimulus sparking risk assets.

site_title: Brexit could end up strengthening the EU
summary: The European Union may experience increased cohesion following the UK's Brexit vote. The UK's economic struggles and failure to negotiate a better deal with EU partners could deter other countries from leaving. Additionally, the EU remains a key platform for solving European problems. This outcome contradicts initial perceptions that Brexit would lead to the EU's disintegration.

site_title: Bloated Malaysia civil service presents headache for Najib
summary: Malaysia's bloated civil service poses a challenge to Prime Minister Najib Razak as the country seeks to narrow its budget deficit. With 1.6 million employees, the civil service accounts for about 11% of the labor force and drains resources at a time of falling government revenues. Najib's government has pledged to improve the public sector's efficiency, but trimming the workforce is difficult due to ethnic sensitivities and the need to maintain support from the majority Malay population. The government has increased salaries and benefits for civil servants, making it unlikely to make significant changes to its expenditure on the public sector.

site_title: Indonesia allows tax amnesty seekers to purchase gold, property
summary: Indonesia's tax amnesty program allows individuals to invest in gold, property, and infrastructure projects, potentially bringing back $57.3 billion in stashed assets. The program, aimed at boosting economic growth, will allow participants to move funds between approved assets before a three-year holding period ends. President Joko Widodo plans to use the taxes from the plan to fund an infrastructure agenda, with Bank Indonesia estimating the program could recover 560 trillion rupiah in assets.

site_title: The bond sale that may solve a US$566b problem
summary: Wells Fargo, Bank of America, and Morgan Stanley are set to sell a nearly $871 million bond, the first to comply with new regulations requiring commercial mortgage-backed securities to hold 5% of the debt sold. The deal aims to provide "certainty of execution" and may prevent Wall Street banks from exiting the $566 billion business, which generates $2 billion in annual revenue. The move could also impact property owners' ability to borrow, with regulators pressuring banks to reduce risk from the assets.

site_title: France headed for small rebound
summary: The French economy is expected to experience a small rebound in the third quarter, with a 0.3% growth rate, according to the Bank of France. This rebound is attributed to most sectors, except for the automobile industry, which is struggling with a slowdown in production. The central bank based its estimates on a monthly survey of business leaders.

site_title: Valeant said to be under criminal investigation: WSJ
summary: Valeant Pharmaceuticals International Inc is under a criminal investigation by the US Attorney's office in New York, who are investigating whether the drugmaker defrauded insurers by hiding its ties to a mail-order pharmacy, Philidor Rx Services LLC. Prosecutors are looking into whether Philidor made false statements to insurers about its relationship with Valeant, which filled prescriptions for Valeant dermatology drugs. Valeant severed ties with Philidor in October after reports of tactics used to gain insurance reimbursements. This investigation is part of multiple probes by the US Securities and Exchange Commission and other US Attorney's offices.

images.alt_text: Valeant Pharmaceuticals International Inc. is the subject of a criminal probe by federal prosecutors, who are investigating whether the drugmaker defrauded insurers by hiding its ties to a mail-order pharmacy, the Wall Street Journal reported.

site_title: Gold at 'rich level' to struggle as Fed may hike three times
summary: Gold prices may struggle to rally further due to the Federal Reserve's probable three rate hikes by the end of 2017, which could negatively impact gold prices. The dollar's long-term uptrend and robust US economy also limit gold's potential gains. Despite recent rallies, gold is considered a "rich level" and may stabilize around $1,250-$1,300 per ounce, according to Pictet Wealth Management. A neutral call on gold is expected, with no significant catalysts to drive further gains.

site_title: US dollar remains buoyant following US jobs report
summary: The US dollar rose marginally against major currencies, following the US Labor Department's report of 255,000 jobs added in July, exceeding analyst expectations. This led to speculation of a potential interest rate hike by the Federal Reserve this year, boosting the dollar's value. The euro fell to US$1.1081, while the yen dropped to 102.49 yen, and the pound fell to US$1.3040. Analysts attribute the dollar's rise to the US economy's stronger growth prospects, which could lead to higher interest rates and benefit the dollar against peers with lower borrowing rates.

site_title: Olympics: Feng Tianwei beats Austrian Liu Jia for place in quarter-finals
summary: Singapore's Feng Tianwei beats Austrian Liu Jia in the women's singles event at the Olympics, advancing to the quarter-finals with a 4-1 win. Feng Tianwei, the second seed, defeated her world No 25 opponent 11-6, 11-6, 11-7, 6-11, 11-4.

site_title: US to auction US$16 million worth of bitcoin from various cases
summary: The US government plans to auction nearly US$16.1 million worth of bitcoin, seized from various cases, including the Silk Road online black market. The auction, set for August 22, will be held by the US Marshals Service and requires potential bidders to register by August 18. The 2,700 bitcoin are valued based on the Bitstamp exchange price.

site_title: Surviving the F&B industry
summary: British chef Tim Ross-Watson is opening a new modern European eatery, PyxieMoss, along North Canal Road in Singapore. This marks his comeback three years after closing his first restaurant, Garden of Eden. Despite intense competition, Ross-Watson is expanding his culinary presence, showcasing his ability to adapt and thrive in the industry.

site_title: Philippine mine crackdown rattles global nickel markets
summary: The Philippine government, led by President Rodrigo Duterte, has suspended 8% of the country's nickel mines as part of a campaign against irresponsible mining. The move has driven up global nickel prices by 13% and raised concerns about the impact on China's nickel ore imports. The government has threatened to shut down mines that fail to comply with environmental rules, citing the need to redistribute wealth among citizens. The move has sparked concerns among miners and industry experts, who fear it could lead to job losses and economic disruption.

site_title: New body formed to look into aviation, maritime incidents
summary: Singapore has formed the Transport Safety Investigation Bureau (TSIB) to investigate air and sea incidents, replacing the Air Accident Investigation Bureau (AAIB). The TSIB aims to prevent further accidents and incidents, not to apportion blame or liability. The new body will conduct independent safety investigations into marine accidents and incidents, making recommendations to enhance sea transport safety. This move follows similar setups in countries like Australia, Japan, the UK, and the US, which have established transport safety investigation bodies.

site_title: Reinventing French fizz in face of climate change
summary: Climate change poses a significant threat to France's champagne production, with rising temperatures and changing harvest patterns affecting grape quality and yield. To address this, the Champagne Committee is collaborating with the National Institute for Agricultural Research to develop new, more resistant grape varieties through hybridization and genetic research. The goal is to maintain the traditional champagne style while ensuring the long-term sustainability of the industry, with results expected by 2030.

site_title: Merkel's popularity plunges in wake of attacks
summary: Angela Merkel's popularity has plummeted to 47% due to her refugee policy, down 12 points from July. Her government's welcoming policy towards refugees has received the lowest result, with 65% dissatisfied. Conservative Premier Horst Seehofer's popularity has surged 11 points to 44% despite being a critic of the policy. Merkel is expected to run for a fourth term in general elections in over a year, with regional elections in September on her home turf trailing in the polls.

site_title: Deep ties must carry through to next generation of leaders: PM
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasized the importance of deepening US-Singapore relations, stating that the recent visit reflects the US's emphasis on Asia. The four-day visit, the first by a Singapore prime minister in 31 years, included official state dinners and meetings with top US officials, highlighting shared values, interests, and strategic outlooks. The two countries released a joint statement on advancing their strategic partnership in areas such as cybersecurity, defense, and smart cities, with plans to set up a scholarship for 100 students. Lee sees the partnership as crucial for the next generation of leaders, citing the need for sustained cooperation to maintain stability in the region.

site_title: Global Yellow Pages issues profit warning for FY2016
summary: Global Yellow Pages Limited has issued a profit warning for FY2016, citing a loss mainly due to impairment of assets, investment losses, and fair value losses. The company expects a loss, but notes these are non-cash items that won't impact cash flows. Further details on its financial performance will be disclosed when it announces its unaudited financial results in August. Shareholders and investors are advised to exercise caution when dealing in the company's shares.

site_title: From fencing to Fitch
summary: Fitch Group CEO Paul Taylor, who stumbled into banking and credit ratings, attributes his success to understanding what he rates and adapting to changing circumstances. He rose from a graduate trainee to become a mortgage-backed securities analyst, eventually leading the company's European finance team before becoming CEO in 2012. Under his leadership, Fitch expanded its market share by 1% annually for five years. Taylor emphasizes the importance of being tenacious in digging into details and facts, and Fitch's focus on building a strong team and publishing research to gain market share. He also acknowledges the challenges posed by the global financial crisis and the need for transparency and honesty in ratings.

site_title: Oversupply beats Brexit as biggest London office risk, UBS says
summary: UBS says the oversupply of office space in London is a bigger risk to rents and values than the impact of Brexit, with 51 office buildings under construction in central London expected to hit the market in 2017 and 2018. This could lead to a decline in values of up to 20% and potentially 25,000 jobs moving away from London due to passporting rights. UBS plans to invest $3 billion in European property outside the UK over the next two to three years.

site_title: Creating systems of content
summary: Miles Young, global chairman of Ogilvy & Mather, is stepping down on September 1, 2016, after a distinguished career in advertising. Young notes that digitalization has transformed the industry, ushering in an age of transparency, where consumers demand authenticity and behavior from brands. Marketing has become a service-oriented business, where delivering value is crucial. The rise of digital media and the internet has turned advertising into a publishing business, with consumers choosing what content to consume. Young highlights the shift from a bipolar to a poly-global world, where Asian brands are becoming global, and Western companies may be acquired by Asian firms. He emphasizes the importance of women's empowerment and education in driving economic growth in Asia.

images.alt_text: 'I don't think Dentsu has got it in its grasp to buy WPP (the British parent of O&M) but I think in the future an Indian group or a Chinese group might well do so.' Mr Young

site_title: SGX prepares formal offer to buy UK's Baltic Exchange: sources
summary: Singapore Exchange Ltd (SGX) is preparing a formal offer to buy the UK's Baltic Exchange, a privately-owned benchmark index for global shipping rates and freight derivatives market. The deal, valued at around US$100 million, would boost SGX's revenue diversification efforts and benefit from the weakened pound. The Baltic Exchange, founded in 1744, has exclusive talks with SGX, which have been ongoing since May, and a deadline for panelists to sign exclusivity agreements has been set. The deal faces no major hurdles, including Brexit, and is seen as a strategic move by SGX to expand its global presence in shipping.

site_title: Shambolic start to Rio Games amid queues, security scares
summary: The Rio Olympic Games got off to a chaotic start on Saturday, with security scares and long queues keeping fans waiting outside venues. Organizers apologized for the delays, citing a lack of coordination between security personnel. The first day of full competition saw athletes compete in front of empty stands, with some events delayed due to security concerns. A bomb scare and a shooting also took place, prompting authorities to tighten security. Despite 85,000 police and military personnel deployed to guard the Games, security remains a top concern, with robberies and thefts targeting tourists and media.

images.alt_text: A long queue of visitors waiting to enter the Olympic Beach Volleyball stadium, in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, on August 7, 2016.

site_title: US$4.4b buyout proposal for Wanda wins support
summary: US$4.4 billion buyout proposal for Dalian Wanda Commercial Properties Co has gained support from Institutional Shareholder Services Inc, recommending shareholders approve the deal. China Life Insurance Co and Kuwait Investment Authority, the largest shareholders, also back the proposal. A shareholder vote is scheduled for August 15, requiring 75% approval for the deal to pass. If rejected, Wanda won't be able to try again for 12 months, and some investors could lose money due to the lower offer price.

site_title: Ringgit sinks as crude's tumble bodes ill for Malaysia finances
summary: Malaysia's currency, the ringgit, declined 0.5% to 4.0415 per US dollar, as crude oil prices hit a four-month low due to a global supply glut. Brent crude fell 0.8% and US oil slid into a bear market. The decline in oil prices is expected to impact Malaysia's export earnings, with the nation deriving a fifth of its revenue from energy-related sources. The country's annual income of 450 million ringgit is lost for every US$1 drop in oil prices.

site_title: StarHub posts 9.6% jump in profit for Q2
summary: StarHub reported a 9.6% increase in net profit to S$108.6 million in Q2, despite a 0.6% dip in revenue to S$585.7 million. Earnings per share rose 10.5% to 6.3 Singapore cents. The company also announced an interim dividend of 5 Singapore cents per ordinary share, and its Ebitda increased 5% to S$375 million. Half-year net profit grew 16.6% to S$201.4 million, with Ebitda margin at 34.2%.

site_title: Japan's core consumer prices down by 0.5% in July
summary: Japan's core consumer prices fell by 0.5% in July, marking the fifth consecutive month of declines and the fastest fall in over three years. The drop was attributed to weakened oil prices, which are expected to continue influencing prices downward until next year. Analysts say the credibility of "Abenomics" is waning, and the BOJ's 2% inflation target may be unattainable. The BOJ's next policy review is expected to endorse its easing actions and highlight the impact of falling energy prices.

site_title: Wearable device maker Fitbit's revenue beats estimates, shares sprint
summary: Fitbit's revenue for the second quarter exceeded estimates, with sales of 5.7 million devices, a 46.5% increase from the same period last year. The company's new products, Blaze and Alta, accounted for 54% of revenue, driven by strong demand from new customers. Fitbit's shares rose 6.2% in after-hours trading, despite concerns about rising competition from Xiaomi, Garmin, Samsung, and Apple. The company reported a net loss of $6.3 million, but beat analyst estimates for revenue and excluding items.

images.alt_text: Wearable fitness device maker Fitbit Inc's quarterly revenue raced past analysts' estimates as demand jumped for its new devices, sending its shares up as much as 8.1 per cent in after-market trading.

site_title: Hong Kong: Financial markets closed
summary: Hong Kong's financial markets were closed due to a typhoon on August 2, 2016. No other significant news or market updates were found in the provided articles, as they appear to be unrelated to the Hong Kong typhoon.

site_title: Australia dollar holds ground as yield chase continues
summary: The Australian dollar maintained its gains, rising nearly 1% on Tuesday and holding steady on Wednesday despite a Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) rate cut to record lows. The currency's attractiveness is attributed to its 1.8% 10-year coupon and AAA credit rating, drawing foreign investor capital. The Aussie's resilience has led to a 50-50 chance of a November rate cut, while the New Zealand dollar slipped 0.5% due to subdued wage growth and pressure on the Reserve Bank of New Zealand (RBNZ) to ease rates.

images.alt_text: The Australian dollar held its gains on Wednesday as yield-hungry investors continued to pour money into the currency despite a central bank easing the day before.

site_title: "Lop-sided" eurozone factory growth slowed in July: PMI
summary: Eurozone factory growth slowed in July, with Markit's Purchasing Managers' Index falling to 52.0, just beating a flash estimate of 51.9. The slowdown is driven by lopsided growth, with Germany's expansion outpacing other countries, while Italy, Spain, France, and Greece experience contractions. The European Central Bank may loosen policy to address concerns, despite keeping interest rates unchanged last month. The bank aims for an inflation rate of just below 2% and will soon expand its asset purchase programme.

images.alt_text: Manufacturing growth across the eurozone eased in July, a survey showed on Monday, and signs of a sharper slowdown outside powerhouse Germany may add to calls for the European Central Bank to loosen policy again.

site_title: Not just a face for Wild Turkey, this actor writes the ads too
summary: Matthew McConaughey has signed a multi-year deal with Gruppo Campari to serve as creative director for Wild Turkey bourbon. In addition to appearing on camera, he will write and direct ads, record music, and have a say in brand photography and product development. McConaughey aims to reintroduce the 161-year-old brand to millennials, emphasizing its authenticity and quality. The campaign, set to launch in September, will feature the tagline "It'll Find You" and focus on the brand's unapologetic nature.

images.alt_text: McConaughey has signed a contract with Gruppo Campari, to serve as creative director for Wild Turkey bourbon. In addition to appearing on camera, he will write and direct the spots, and be involved in recording music for the campaign. The campaign will be introduced in September.

site_title: UK manufacturing shrinks at fastest pace in over 3 years
summary: UK manufacturing contracted at its fastest pace in over 3 years in July, with a closely watched index of factory purchasing managers falling to 48.2, its lowest since February 2013. Business confidence plummeted following the Brexit vote, with surveys pointing to a higher chance of a UK recession ahead. This has fueled the case for the Bank of England to cut interest rates this week, with economists predicting a rate cut of at least 25 basis points.

site_title: The heat is on
summary: Two new products have generated buzz: the LG Styler, a garment steamer and dryer that steam-cleans, dries, and sanitizes clothes, and the Dyson Supersonic, a high-end hair dryer with a unique design and features such as a magnetic attachment system and reduced noise. The LG Styler is priced at S$2,999 and can handle up to three items, while the Dyson Supersonic costs S$599 and features a V9 motor that generates a thin sheet of concentrated air. Both products offer innovative solutions for their respective needs, but may be out of reach for some consumers due to their high price tags.

images.alt_text: HOT STUFF: The LG Styler is an all-in-one locker-size machine that steam-cleans, dries, disinfects, reduces wrinkles and even presses.
HOT STUFF: The Dyson Supersonic's handle houses the motor of the hairdryer.
HOT STUFF: The Dyson Supersonic's handle houses the motor of the hairdryer.

site_title: Temasek bought stake in India's ICICI Bank, US filings show
summary: Temasek Holdings, a Singapore investment firm, has bought a stake in ICICI Bank Ltd, India's largest private sector lender, purchasing 2.55 million American depositary receipts (ADRs) worth US$18 million. This investment aligns with Temasek's focus on Asia's growing middle-income populations and transforming economies. The firm has also acquired stakes in US companies B/E Aerospace Inc and Intellia Therapeutics Inc, and increased its ownership in Alibaba Group Holding Ltd.

images.alt_text: Temasek Holdings has bought shares in ICICI Bank Ltd, India's largest private sector lender by assets, in the second quarter as it expanded its foothold in Asia's third-biggest economy, Bloomberg said in a report on Tuesday.
